column2: As part of an article coming Friday in the Weekend section, we asked The Times's dance critics to compare notes after seeing the same performance (City Ballet on Sunday) from different parts of the theater. Here are Parts 1 and 2 of their conversation, which ranged from the performances themselves to the people you meet in the cheap seats and even dancers' facial expressions, the subject that kicks off the final round:
Minh Uong/The New York Times
There was a heated exchange of letters on Tuesday as the J. Crew settlement over its proposed leveraged buyout collapsed.

The Times's Judy Battista today profiles the Rooneys, the family that owns the Steelers and operates them with patience rarely seen in the N.F.L. in recent years. It has paid off with two Super Bowl victories in the past five seasons. Art Rooney II explains his philosophy as "You pick good people and you try to stay with them."

Not yet 30 years old, Joaquin Trias is already revealing a certain kinship with his fellow Spanish designer Cristóbal Balenciaga (to whom his grandmother, Countessa Frida Trias, was model and muse). Trias's aristocratic roots fostered his reverence for simple elegance, and his technical acumen and focus on innovation, perhaps picked up from his background with pattern makers and seamstresses, are apparent in every seam and silhouette. Gearing up for Fashion Week, Trias shares with us some of his day-to-day inspirations. Is he looking forward to it? "Yes," he says. "Very much! Thank you."

The pick-and-roll is as foundational as N.B.A. plays come; it occurs on the professional level of the game in both pure and varied forms, in assorted rhythms and placements, all of which serve to modify its orchestration. The elasticity of the pick-and-roll is truly impressive, as the sequence always subscribes to the same basic action but can differ wildly in the style of its execution.

On some college campuses, students are agitated about the presence of Chick-fil-A, a purveyor of Southern-style chicken sandwiches that has run afoul of some proponents of same-sex marriage. But at a New York University cafeteria, the only place in the city where a craving for Chick-fil-A can be sated, the squawking has been limited.
CNBC discusses the planned split of Fortune Brands into three separate companies, a proposal supported by the activist investor William A. Ackman, who owns an 11 percent share of the company.

Overview | What is meditation? How have scientists explored the effects of meditation on the mind and body? In this lesson, students participate in a guided meditation, then learn about meditation and current research showing how meditation affects the brain and body. They then annotate diagrams of the brain and body with the information they've learned about meditation's effects.
Citigroup has barely owned EMI for a day, but it has already achieved a dubious distinction: a No. 1 album with notably low sales - even in a season of painfully low sales for the music industry.

Freescale Semiconductor, the chip maker acquired by several buyout firms in 2006 for $17.6 billion, has hired a bevy of investment banks to underwrite an initial public offering, people briefed on the matter told DealBook on Wednesday.
6:10 p.m. | Updated
Reports of sales, events, openings and collaborations in the fashion world.

The report from the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission has been assailed as a confusing mishmash - poorly organized, unclear about what's new and weakened by conclusions that are at once obvious and unsatisfying. The problems of the commission were evident from the start: its mandate was too broad, its timetable too short, its budget too small and its commissioners too partisan.
Need some tools? Scott Freidheim is your man.

Over the last 8,000 years, forest cover on the planet has plummeted to around 13 million square miles from about 24 million square miles, the advocacy group Global Forest Watch estimates. Rain forests in particular are being felled at stunning rates.
A brief recap of an afternoon spent bingeing on Super Bowl coverage:
Updated 5:50 p.m. with additional reporting from the event.

Three San Francisco start-ups are hoping to persuade car owners to rent their vehicles to locals and out-of-town visitors. The three companies -- Getaround, RelayRides and Spride Share -- recently launched online services in the Bay Area to help car owners profit from their vehicles when not using them, while allowing drivers to book the cars at rates potentially lower than what major rental companies charge.

ALBANY - "I say no new taxes, period," Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo declared on the day of his inauguration last month, echoing a top promise from his campaign. And after leafing through his first executive budget on Tuesday, lawmakers and others at the Capitol seemed to agree that Mr. Cuomo had indeed kept his pledge.
5:40 p.m. | Updated It's not an easy thing to mount a big exhibition of artifacts from China without any artifacts from China.

It has been said that life's greatest luxury is idle time. Yet Kenny G, the saxophonist who experienced his commercial high water mark sometime around 1996, has generously dedicated 2 minutes and 47 seconds of his ample supply to a new television advertisement for Audi.

This week's Bits: Tech Talk podcast takes a look at how technology is being used to press both for and against social and political change. Bettina Edelstein speaks to Matt Richtel, a New York Times technology reporter, about the impact and implications of the Internet shutdown in Egypt. And J.D. Biersdorfer speaks with David Perry, global director of education for the security firm Trend Micro, about how technology can be deployed as a weapon.

Before the Super Bowl, the only part of a newspaper more predictable than the sports section is the food section. It's time for chili and dips, chicken wings and snacks, all touched up with flourishes like city-themed suggestions ("Make your jambalaya a Green Bay jambalaya by adding bratwurst!"), nods to simplicity ("If kickoff is approaching, you do not have to butcher your own hog,") or healthy living ("Discourage guests from diving face first into the cream cheese dip").

The film star James Franco (an Academy Award nominee for "127 Hours") and the theater director David Cromer (the acclaimed Off Broadway revival of "Our Town") have had two meetings in recent months to discuss Mr. Franco's making his Broadway debut as the gigolo and aspiring actor Chance Wayne in a fall 2011 revival of Tennessee Williams's "Sweet Bird of Youth," Mr. Cromer said in an interview on Tuesday.

As one of the most stringently modern skyscrapers in New York, Lever House is an outright snub to the 19th century. Or it was until last week, when the sculptor Rachel Feinstein turned its glass-enclosed lobby into an Old World storybook palace that must have the building's architect, Gordon Bunshaft, turning over in his grave.

DALLAS - Maybe it's the frigid temperatures outside, or the ever-present talk about how to increase the N.F.L.'s revenue, but football in Los Angeles - or the lack of it - has been a topic of conversation here.

According to the National Weather Service, 100 million people live in the path of the monster snow storm that has turned my driveway into a sheet of ice. (I am thinking of teaching the poor, confused dog to do an axel.)

We asked The Times's dance critics, who sat in different sections of the David H. Koch Theater for Sunday's City Ballet matinee, to compare notes. Here's Part 2 of their conversation, which ranged from dancers' expressions to the best place to sit with kids. Check back for the final installment later today and be sure to share your experiences in different seats.

The Environmental Protection Agency has issued the results of a study documenting the severity of the pollution in the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn. The agency redoubled warnings that New Yorkers should not swim or fish there, citing the risks to human health.

David Brooks: Gail, every few years we turn on the TV and we see the main square of some foreign capital filled with people and before too long, a dictator falls. This is truly a great time to be alive. Now, I understand all the worries that go along with this. I understand my Israeli friends who feel that they are in the process of losing the least bad Egyptian leader. But my bottom line is this: the world will be far safer when more of the world is normal, meaning mostly open and mostly democratic. If we have to go through a period of turmoil to get there, it is more than worth it. That's especially true in the Middle East.

Raj Rajaratnam, the Galleon Group's founder, is scheduled to begin trial on Feb. 28 on charges that he engaged in insider trading, and prosecutors and defense lawyers are aggressively sparring over a range of preliminary issues in an effort to frame their cases for the jury. While it is still possible the two sides will agree to a plea bargain, the intensity of the fight certainly makes it look like they are gearing up for one of the biggest insider trading trials ever.
The government's lofty vision of bringing health care into the computer age to improve care and curb costs will come to nothing, unless some mundane technical problems can be solved.
Neither rain nor snow nor sleet nor gloom of day ...

A group of leading climate scientists, including eight members of the National Academy of Sciences, call on Congress to take a "fresh look" at the science linking human activity to climate change, which they contend is strong. "The debate about climate change has become increasingly ideological and partisan," their joint letter states. "But climate change is not the product of a belief system or ideology. Instead, it is based on scientific fact, and no amount of argument, coercion, or debate among talking heads in the media can alter the physics of climate change." [The Hill]
It was a "no-brainer," says Joe Santana, who is vice president of operations for Mi Rancho, a family-owned Tortilla-producer in San Leandro, Calif.

Updated, 4:21 p.m. | Cathleen P. Black, the new schools chancellor, faced an angry crowd of nearly 2,000 people as the Panel for Education Policy voted to close 10 schools. The meeting, at Brooklyn Technical High School, lasted more than six hours Tuesday night into early Wednesday as about 300 people spoke, some of them screaming and taunting Ms. Black until she could not take it any longer.

The effects of the storm that blanketed much of the country yesterday are being felt by travelers from the Great Plains to the Midwest to the Northeast, Michael Cooper and Monica Davey report. The weather affected those traveling by air, rail and road. Mr. Cooper and Ms. Davey reported that the storm resulted in the cancellation of 4,892 flights by Wednesday at 7:30 a.m., about 1,500 of them in New York's three airports; the temporary closing and delays  of Amtrak service along the Northeast corridor, and the closing of Interstate 70 in Missouri.

I don't make stuffed cabbage all that often: perhaps once or twice a year. And I generally make it more or less the same way, using paprika, caraway and sauerkraut: a Hungarian inflection, if not a purely Hungarian recipe. A batch lasts through several meals, even when we have company to help eat it, and perhaps that is why I don't need to make it more frequently than I do.
The Darden family, which holds a major stake in Quicksilver Resources, said in a regulatory filing that it believed the energy company was worth $16 a share, putting its total value at $2.7 billion.

Lynn Nottage's new Off Broadway play "By the Way, Meet Vera Stark," her first since winning the Pulitzer Prize for drama in 2009 for "Ruined," has announced its star: The stage and film actress Sanaa Lathan will play the title character, a black maid in Hollywood who pursues her dream of making it in the pictures while also grappling with racial stereotypes through decades of the 20th century.

Every now and then, Microsoft undoes months or years of excellent work by pulling off a sleazy tactic. There was the time it hired a P.R. firm to write phony "grass-roots" letters to the editors of newspapers, defending Microsoft's position in the government's antitrust lawsuits. There was the time Microsoft bribed bloggers with free $2,500 laptops to "assist in their evaluation" of Windows Vista.

A quick thought about the Egyptian uprising. Many people have sought parallels either in the Philippines 1986 or in Indonesia 1998; I've done it myself. But there is a possibly important or revealing difference. As the chart above shows, both of those political crises followed on drastic economic crises -- Marcos was caught up in the Latin American debt crisis of the 1980s (in some important ways the Philippines was in effect a Latin American economy at the time), Suharto in the Asian financial crisis. Nothing comparable for Egypt now.

Justin Sablich captures the silly side of Tuesday's Super Bowl media day in an interactive video feature. In 12 video clips, see what it's like to be interviewed by a superhero, delve into beard issues or Chris Kemoeatu's hand-eye coordination.

Clearly there's a lot of concern circulating -- along with quite a bit of misinformation -- about the nasty, painful disease called shingles (herpes zoster, more formally) and how to protect oneself or one's parents against it.

A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.
In a piece in the New York Times Magazine this weekend, Emily Bazelon explores shaken baby syndrome -- and the possibility that doctors are not as certain about it as they were once thought to be.

Eduardo Porter and I were colleagues on the economics beat at The New York Times several years ago, and he is now a member of the editorial board. He's also the author of the recent book "The Price of Everything." Our conversation, the latest installment of this blog's Book Chat series, follows:

The minute Jeff Chang heard that the pioneering Bronx hip-hop D.J. Kool Herc was having health problems, he knew it was time for payback. Mr. Chang, a prolific writer on politics and culture, was honored when Herc wrote the introduction to his hip-hop history book "Can't Stop, Won't Stop." But this week he was alarmed that Herc, born Clive Campbell, was in financial straits because his lack of medical insurance was complicating his treatment for kidney stones.

The Adam Scher Dance Company's new piece, "Five Blind Mice," which was presented last week at the Irondale Center in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, is a tour de force of choreography and technology. Kate Atherton, Molly Merkler, Veronica Carnero, Casey Loomis and Adam Scher performed separate vignettes, each specifically programmed by the technical director, Christopher Langer, to sync with the piece's emotional core. As an opener, Merkler performed in almost complete darkness; a sensor strapped to her stomach detected her breathing and illuminated a light bulb overhead with every inhale. Later in the lineup, Atherton began her more up-tempo piece against the backdrop of a blank projection. As the piece went on, time-lapsed footage of her movements appeared in repetition every 30 seconds, creating an army of her own image that seemingly danced along with the real performer.

Today President Mubarak seems to have decided to crack down on the democracy movement, using not police or army troops but rather mobs of hoodlums and thugs. I've been spending hours on Tahrir today, and it is absurd to think of this as simply "clashes" between two rival groups. The pro-democracy protesters are unarmed and have been peaceful at every step. But the pro-Mubarak thugs are arriving in buses and are armed -- and they're using their weapons.

Perhaps the safest statement you could make in the run-up to the Super Bowl is that N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell is not a popular man in Steelerville. First, media day on Tuesday became embroiled in a "what he said" dust-up over comments Goodell made about the Ben Roethlisberger suspension for a Sports Illustrated profile. Let's just say the Steelers weren't happy the commish tossed them under a bus for not supporting their quarterback. Then the reporter, Peter King, quickly scrambled to clarify Goodell's supposed comments, and Goodell declared them "misreported."

The Obama administration announced on Wednesday that it planned to regulate toxic substances in drinking water more strictly and would issue the first limits ever on perchlorate, a dangerous chemical found in rocket fuel that has seeped into groundwater in at least 400 locations.

With self assurance, eloquence and a soupçon of mild defiance, Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky gave his first speech on the floor of his new legislative home Wednesday, noting that while he would be sitting at the desk of "the great compromiser," Henry Clay, he would not be taking many cues from the 19th-century Kentucky lawmaker and founder of the Whig Party.
A sampling of the madness at Cowboys Stadium, where hundreds of reporters were unleashed on those preparing to play in Super Bowl XLV.

Perhaps this will be a comfort to him: Christopher Nolan's "Inception" was the big winner at the Visual Effects Society on Tuesday. His film picked up all four prizes for which it was nominated - Outstanding Visual Effects in a Visual-Effects Driven Feature Motion Picture; Outstanding Created Environment in a Live Action Feature Motion Picture; Outstanding Models & Miniatures in a Feature Motion Picture and Outstanding Compositing in a Feature Motion Picture - and Mr. Nolan himself was honored with the inaugural visionary award. In a bit of a surprise, "How to Train Your Dragon" bested "Toy Story 3" in the animated category. For the first time, the show will be broadcast on the Reelzchannel on Feb. 19.
Pro-Mubarak and antigovernment protesters face off in Tahrir Square.

As Europe continues to ship off its up-and-coming actors to play dashing American superheroes, the United States is apparently responding by sending one of its most virile specimens of manhood to that continent in exchange: namely, Woody Allen. Mr. Allen's latest film, "Midnight in Paris," will open the Cannes Film Festival on May 11, the event's organizers said on Wednesday. The film, the 41st feature-length work that Mr. Allen has directed, is a romantic comedy whose cast includes Owen Wilson, Rachel McAdams, Marion Cotillard, Kathy Bates and Adrien Brody, though one cast member, Carla Bruni-Sarkozy, has received a bit more attention than the others. In a statement, Thierry Frémaux, the director of the Cannes festival, described "Midnight in Paris" as "a wonderful love letter to Paris," adding: "It's a film in which Woody Allen takes a deeper look at the issues raised in his last films: our relationship with history, art, pleasure and life." The film will be released in France on the same day it makes its debut at Cannes, though an American release date has not yet been announced. The full Cannes Film Festival runs through May 22.

A prominent black Wall Street money manager has filed a lawsuit against the Dakota, accusing the legendary New York apartment building of racial discrimination and defamation in preventing him from buying an apartment there.

For Friday's Weekend section, Claudia La Rocco is writing about seeing dance performances from the cheapest seats of some of New York's important halls. As it happened, all four of The Times's dance critics were in attendance at the Sunday matinee of City Ballet at the David H. Koch Theater. Roslyn Sulcas and Gia Kourlas in orchestra, the chief critic Alastair Macaulay a level up in the First Ring, and Ms. LaRocco in the Fourth Ring (specifically, three rows from the very top of the theater). As it turns out, it does make a difference but it's not necessarily what you think.
Evercore Partners on Wednesday announced fourth-quarter profit of $3.27 million, up from $1.65 million in the period a year earlier -- results that topped Wall Street expectations.

I recently had an interesting conversation with Rafael Pastor, the chairman and chief executive of Vistage, a leading organization for chief executives. He relayed a story that one of his members had told him. This particular C.E.O. has a school-age son who came home one day and asked if his father would call himself something other than a C.E.O. It seems that the boy's classmates were giving him a hard time about the fact that his father runs a company -- as if it were something to be embarrassed by. My first thought was, "What?" Maybe I could understand it if his father were a politician! But then I started thinking.

Katherine Vasquez can't get enough of New York City. She loves its neon signs. She loves its holiday lights. She loves its museums, its bookshops, its parks, its fashionistas. But for Ms. Vasquez, who was born with spina bifida, getting around can be a challenge. She can't feel her feet, so she navigates the city in a manual wheelchair.

So in honor of Wednesday's observance of Groundhog Day, we ask: Are you ready for six more weeks of winter? A court-appointed special master rejected on Tuesday the N.F.L. players union's claim that the league should not have access to $4 billion in television payments if there is a lockout. But he awarded the union $6.9 million in damages in connection with two particular contracts, with ESPN and NBC. The union claimed in its filing against the N.F.L. that the league had negotiated lockout insurance with the networks that gave the teams unfair leverage over the players.

Updated at 8:02 p.m. | Citigroup on Tuesday seized control of EMI from Terra Firma, ending the private equity firm's disastrous ownership of the famous music company and most likely accelerating the search for new owners. Terra Firma, which is led by the British financier Guy Hands, had borrowed heavily to acquire EMI for $8.4 billion at the height of the credit market.

TEIRSTEIN--Alvin S.,MD. The trustees, faculty, and staff of The Mount Sinai Medical Center are deeply saddened by the passing of our cherished colleague, Dr. Alvin S. Teirstein, who died at age 83. Dr. Teirstein joined The Mount Sinai Medical Center in 1953 and for 27 years, served as Chief of the Division of what is now the Catherine and Henry Gaisman Division of Pulmonary, Critical Care, and Sleep Medicine. He established medical and respiratory intensive care units and introduced the fiberoptic bronchoscopy program which, in the 1980s, Mount Sinai physicians used as leaders in the research of pulmonary manifestations of AIDS. Dr. Teirstein was internationally recognized for his contributions to our understanding of sarcoidosis, as well as to the diagnosis and treatment of lung cancer, asthma, emphysema, and environmental and fibrosing lung disease. Recipient of numerous honors, he also trained generations of students, residents, fellows, and junior faculty. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Dr. Teirstein's family and friends. Peter W. May, Chairman of the Boards of Trustees, The Mount Sinai Medical Center Kenneth L. Davis, MD, President and CEO, The Mount Sinai Medical Center

JACOBSON--Franklin M. With great sorrow we mourn the loss of our beloved partner and member of our family for over four decades. And for his devotion to his partners and staff, and his gentle presence among us, we are forever grateful. No one was too humble for his genuine concern and interest. To Naomi, to Elissa, Richard and Ruby, to Neil and the family, we offer our love and support. You are all in our thoughts. The Partners and Staff of Joel E. Sammet & Company

For decades, Americans believed that we had the world's healthiest and safest diet. We worried little about this diet's effect on the environment or on the lives of the animals (or even the workers) it relies upon. Nor did we worry about its ability to endure -- that is, its sustainability. That didn't mean all was well. And we've come to recognize that our diet is unhealthful and unsafe. Many food production workers labor in difficult, even deplorable, conditions, and animals are produced as if they were widgets. It would be hard to devise a more wasteful, damaging, unsustainable system.

PERLMAN--Norma, 94, of Roslyn Heights on February 1, 2011. Survived by children Janice (Rick Spreyer) and Andrew (Phyllis Gardner), and grandchildren Nicola and Jay. Her generosity, intelligence, and warmth will be missed. Please join family and friends on Thursday February 3, from 12pm to 4pm at the Bryant Library (2 Papermill Rd., Roslyn).

SUNDEL--Elyse L. Formerly of New York City, passed away January 30 at the Jewish Home for the Elderly in Fairfield, CT. A passionate, humorous, yet gentle soul, Elyse's smile cheered those around her even in her last months. She was the devoted and loving mother of Ron and Jeffrey Tauscher and their spouses Lori and Nancy. "Leecy", as her parents called her, was the beloved daughter of the late Robert Sundel and Sally Troper Sundel and sister of the late Arthur Sundel. Her uncle was Brig. Gen. Morris C. Troper, a leader with the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, who helped try to secure safe passage for those on board the ill-fated German ocean liner St. Louis in 1939. Elyse loved working with people and touched the lives of all who knew her in her own very special way. She graduated from Julia Richmond High School in 1944 and went on to attend the New York Institute of Dietetics, graduating valedictorian. After taking classes at NYU, she worked at the FAO Schwarz toy store, where she once helped sooth an upset young customer - Liza Minelli. Elyse also worked as a volunteer with kids at the New York Foundling Hospital, as librarian for the Shell Oil Company, and as office administrator for the law firm Simpson Thacher & Bartlett. But it was her work at the Community Health Project (now Callen-Lorde Community Health Center) that she was most proud of. There, for 15 years, she tireless counseled hundreds of men and women struggling with HIV illness and did whatever she could to help them laugh and allay their fears. After retiring in 2000, she continued to volunteer with kids at Beth Israel Medical Center. Services, Thursday, February 3, 12:30pm at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91st and Amsterdam, New York City. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Jewish Home for the Elderly, 175 Jefferson St., Fairfield, CT 06825.

Dr. Ernest A. McCulloch, a father of the stem cell research that scientists say holds promise for the treatment of many ailments, died on Jan. 20 in Toronto. He was 84. His death was announced by the University of Toronto, where he was an emeritus university professor.

A juvenile-justice counselor who almost got a no-jail plea deal last year in the sexual assaults of three young girls under his care was sentenced Tuesday to four years in prison, the maximum allowed, after a jury convicted him on sexual assault charges last month. Before imposing her sentence, Justice Carol Berkman of State Supreme Court in Manhattan said that the case of the counselor, Tony Simmons, ''cries out for the maximum.''

If self-hurt and demotivational books ever become a publishing trend, you can bet that Sue Sylvester, the deliciously nasty cheerleading coach on the Fox musical comedy ''Glee,'' will have a best seller. In the meantime, Jane Lynch, who has won a Golden Globe and an Emmy Award for her portrayal of that character, hopes to take a more inspirational tone in a book of her own. Ms. Lynch's memoir, called ''Happy Accidents,'' will be released in September by Voice, an imprint of Hyperion Books that publishes works by women, the publisher said on Tuesday. The book will recount her comedy career at the Second City improv theater and her work in films like ''Best in Show'' and ''The 40-Year-Old Virgin'' while addressing how she learned to her embrace her homosexuality and overcame alcoholism, and perhaps show how intertwined she and her ''Glee'' persona are.

NOLAN--Charles, died peacefully at home January 30, at 53, with dignity and style. Born in Brooklyn and raised on Long Island, Charles was a graduate of the Fashion Institute of Technology and a member of the Council of Fashion Designers of America. He began his career working with Frank Tignino at Jerry Silverman, then with Bill Haire, and then Blassport among others...went on to design the Ellen Tracy collection and expose it to the international press...rejuvenated a bankrupt Anne Klein...left to join Howard Dean's campaign...and then launched his own line, which debuted in six full windows on Fifth Avenue at Saks. His particular passion was his own shop, in the Meatpacking District, on Gansevoort Street. His other passion: wonderful women. (The famous "kiss" at the 2000 Convention? Tipper was wearing Charles Nolan. Elaine Stritch at the Carlyle and on 30 Rock? Charles Nolan). He once successfully costumed Arianna Huffington on the fly as Queen Elizabeth, for a Renaissance Weekend skit, using only hotel tablecloths and a roll of tinfoil. Charles is survived by his father, Philip; his sisters Elizabeth, Joyce, Carola and Virginia; his brothers Philip, David, Kenneth, and Edward; his beloved nieces and nephews; his partner, Andrew Tobias; and his work, archived at charlesnolan.com. Visitation at Frank E. Campbell, Tuesday, February 1 from 6pm to 9pm, funeral service at Blessed Sacrament 11am Wednesday, February 2, 152 West 71st Street. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Women in Need, 115 W. 31 St. New York City 10001.

MAHON--Myra. The Board of Trustees and staff of the Museum of the City of New York mourn the passing of Myra Mahon, who served on the Museum's Board of Trustees. She and her husband Arthur have been generous supporters of the Museum and made many projects possible, including our landmark 2008 exhibition Catholics in New York: 1808-1946. We extend our heartfelt sympathy and deepest condolences to Arthur, her children and grandchildren, including her daughter Nancy -- who now faithfully carries on her mother's legacy as a Museum trustee.

Jimmy Bradley, the chef and an owner of the Red Cat and the Harrison, two restaurants in Manhattan, said he is recovering from oral cancer, and will not be moving forward with plans to open J & S Food Hall in the Nolitan Hotel. ''It's a bad break,'' he said in a telephone interview on Tuesday morning, his voice only slightly thicker than its usual laconic drawl. ''But long-term the prognosis is pretty good. I just think at this point the best thing for me is to concentrate on my health and on the livelihood of the 100 people I already have working for me, not on hiring 50 people for a new business.''
ABATE--Vincent. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Vincent Abate, associated with The New York Times from March 20, 1966 until retiring on March 18, 1996.

Ron Patterson, who nearly half a century ago helped found the country's first Renaissance fair, which inspired a thriving nationwide industry of jousters and jesters, hawking street vendors and brave men in doublets and tights, died on Jan. 15 in Sausalito, Calif. He was 80. Mr. Patterson, who lived in San Francisco, Homewood and on a houseboat in Sausalito, had been in declining health for some time and died of natural causes, his son Kevin said.

On Monday's episode of MTV could show minors in the kind of flagrante delicto that is usually reserved for mature audiences. Yet most adult Americans still can't watch Al Jazeera English on television - even now, when the world is transfixed by images of Egypt in revolt. It seems like a perverse application of free speech. But sex is sexier than foreign affairs and it certainly sells better. Freedom of expression is guaranteed to all Americans, but mostly it follows the money.

A television review on Tuesday about ''Post Mortem,'' a documentary on PBS about lapses in the American system for investigating causes of death, misattributed a quotation from the film and rendered part of it incorrectly. The forensic pathologist Vincent Di Maio -- not Marcella Fierro, the retired chief medical examiner of Virginia -- said that the work done ''varies from excellent to absolutely lousy.'' He did not say ''really, really lousy.''

From a posting by Emily Weinsteinon Diner's Journal atnytimes.com/dining. THE invitation promisedthe most exclusive secretdining event of the newyear. Held last Saturdayat the old Bronx Borough Courthouse,a Beaux-Arts building decayingfrom years of disuse, thefirst Bronx Pipe Smoking SocietySmall Game Dinner was devotedto sampling small woodland creatures.The organizer was Justin Fornal,a knowledgeable and accomplishedeater, who under thename Baron Ambrosia is the starof the local television show''Bronx Flavor.'' He had given ahandful of cooks the task of preparingthe animals, including twobeavers, two raccoons, two otters,an opossum, a fisher, asquirrel and ''God knows howmany muskrats,'' said the chefMichael Sherman, of Cloud Cateringin Greenpoint, Brooklyn,who prepared otter three ways:braised, pan-fried and roasted.Jim DeStephano, a retiredtruck driver, had trapped the meatin the Adirondacks with his friendBill Guiles. ''Like a water rat, butbigger and fatter,'' Mr. DeStephanosaid of muskrat. ''It has verypretty fur, softer than mink.''After explaining that the purposeof the meal was to explorewhat these meats had to offerand to challenge the cooks towork with them, Mr. Fornal invitedeveryone up to the buffet. Dinershelped themselves to muskratau vin (a leg was moist andsweet) and roasted DeKalb beaver(perfumey, dry and a bit likepork chop), which had beenstuffed and wrapped in pigskin ina kitchen on DeKalb Avenue inBushwick, Brooklyn.Tlacuache en chile ajo, smallchunks of Mexican-style opossumwith dried pepper and garlicsauce, was spicy and complex,thanks to three different peppersin the sauce. The chef, RafaelMata Sr., of the nearby restaurantXochimilco, said he soakedthe meat in vinegar, then in aslaked lime solution to soften it,boiled it and fried it in pork lardbefore simmering it in the sauce.Before the meal, Mr. DeStephanosaid he planned to try everything,with the possible exceptionof the schnapps digestif, flavoredwith beaver parts andserved in a large glass jug withthe look of an oversize apothecaryjar. ''I don't know aboutthat,'' he said. A dip of the longcoppery ladle drew up a paw.From the ReadersReally gives me the creeps toread this story about people whofind pleasure in stuffing theirfaces with flesh and who delight ineating what they call ''game.''''Game'' -- as if it were all just a''fun'' experience. It's totally grosswhat you all are delighting in.Elizabeth Tobier, BrooklynFolks, these animals are killedall the time in the production offruits and vegetables. My folkshave an apple orchard, and until Istepped in, it was baited everyyear to kill animals like these.Since we stopped, apple productionis null, so I guess we are luckyto not depend on the farm for income.Most apple producers dependon the rodenticides. Foodand death are interconnected.Melissa, New York

8 P.M. (TCM) 31 DAYS OF OSCAR Day 2 of this tribute salutes Jack Nicholson (the most nominated actor: 12 nods and three wins) with four of his best-known films, starting with ''Five Easy Pieces'' (1970), in which he plays a classical pianist who returns to his upper-class family after dropping out of society to work in a California oil field, above. The evening continues with ''Terms of Endearment'' (1983), at 10, for which Mr. Nicholson won the best supporting actor award for his role as a womanizing astronaut who is not as bad as he seems. ''Easy Rider'' (1969) follows at 12:30 a.m., in which he portrays George Hanson, an alcoholic civil rights lawyer who shares a cell with Wyatt and Billy, the motorcyclists played by Peter Fonda and Dennis Hopper. ''The Last Detail'' (1973) is broadcast at 2:15, in which he stars as Buddusky, a Navy lifer who, with his fellow escort (Otis Young), decides to show a young prisoner (Randy Quaid) a good time on his way to the brig. 9 A.M. (Fox News Channel) AMERICA'S NEWSROOM Martha MacCallum talks with David Axelrod, a former senior White House adviser, about the crisis in Egypt, his experience in the White House and his impressions of potential opponents President Obama may face in 2012. The interview will conclude on Thursday.

Last week, Rocco Landesman, the chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, prompted an outcry when he publicly suggested that perhaps the supply of arts organizations exceeded the demand for them. On Monday, Mr. Landesman weighed in on the debate his comments has generated. ''When I say that 'decreasing supply' has to be on the table when talking about the future of not-for-profit arts organizations, in no way do I mean that that is the only thing that should be on the table,'' Mr. Landesman said in a post on Art Works, the N.E.A.'s official blog. Other options to consider, he said, include increasing arts education, offering free samples (like free broadcast concerts) and examining arts infrastructure. ''There are 5.7 million arts workers in this country and two million artists,'' he said. ''Do we need three administrators for every artist?''

TEIRSTEINAlvin, M.D. The Department of Medicine of The Mount Sinai Medical Center mourns the passing of Alvin S. Teirstein, M.D. As Chief of what is now known as The Catherine and Henry Gaisman Division of Pulmonary, Critical Care and Sleep Medicine for 27 years, Dr. Teirstein helped shape the practice of this field of medicine. As a researcher, he was world renowned for his contributions to the care of patients with sarcoidosis and made important contributions to the diagnosis and treatment of lung cancer, asthma, emphysema and environmental and fibrosing lung disease. As a teacher and mentor, he trained generations of students, residents, fellows and junior faculty to follow in his footsteps and dedicate their lives to improving the lives of others. Most of all, as a physician, he gave hope and inspiration to his patients. We extend our sincerest sympathy to his family and friends. Mark Babyatsky, MD, Chair, Medicine
TEIRSTEIN--Alvin S.,MD. Respected colleague, mentor and teacher. He led by example. He will be greatly missed. Louis DePalo, MD

Victoria Clark (''The Light in the Piazza'') will play Mother Superior in the coming Broadway production of ''Sister Act,'' the show's producers announced on Tuesday. The musical, based on the 1992 Whoopi Goldberg film, has a score by Alan Menken, lyrics by Glenn Slater, and a book by Cheri and Bill Steinkellner. It will be directed by Jerry Zaks. The show is to begin previews on March 24 at the Broadway Theater, with opening night scheduled for April 20. She originated the role when the West End production of ''Sister Act'' opened at the London Palladium in June 2009. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

MAHON--Myra. Calvary Hospital mourns with great sadness the passing of our dear friend and longtime Calvary Fund Board member, Myra Mahon. Together with her loving husband, Arthur, Myra was a generous benefactor and devoted guardian of Calvary's mission of non-abandonment, compassion, and excellence. She will be remembered for her untiring dedication to the improvement of the health and welfare of all New Yorkers, and for her enthusiasm, warmth, wide-ranging interests, grace, and deep and abiding faith. In 1999, on the occasion of Calvary's one-hundredth anniversary, Myra and Arthur were awarded the Hospital's highest recognition, the Calvary Medal, in gratitude for their outstanding leadership. Myra's lifetime of good works serves to inspire us all. We extend our sincere condolences to Arthur and their children, Maura, Madonna, Arthur, and Nancy, and the entire Mahon family. Thomas J. HUTCHINS--Carol F.,died at home February 1, 2011, after a courageous battle with cancer. Born November 24, 1932, in New York City, eldest daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Leo C. Fennelly. Devoted wife of Waldo Hutchins III, beloved mother of John Devendorf, Andree Welsh, and Marcia Morrell; loving stepmother to John, Fred, Elizabeth and Anne. Cherished sister of Marcia Gowen, dear aunt to Cynthia Crawford and Lee Marine. "Gagi" was absolutely adored by her nine grandchildren, grandnephew and three grandnieces. Carol was an active member of the Creek Club and the Colony Club. She was a dedicated member of the North Country Garden Club of Long Island, where she chaired numerous committees, including Garden History and Design. She will be terribly missed by her family and many friends, but the love she gave will be in our hearts forever. The head of Gap North Americais leaving the company, one ofa number of changes that Gapannounced for its flagship brandafter years of declining sales atthe division.''Unless we put cute clothes infront of our customer on theshelf,'' said Art Peck, who willsucceed Marka Hansen as presidentof Gap North America, ''everythingelse we do isn't going tomatter.''Ms. Hansen, who has been atGap Inc. for 24 years, has run theGap North America divisionsince 2007. Though she had somenotable hits, like the revision ofthe denim line and the redesignof Gap's basic black pants, saleshave continued to drop.Mr. Peck, who has run the outletbusiness at Gap Inc. until now,will take over immediately. Thebrand will also create a new designhub, called the Global CreativeCenter, based in New York,which will combine design, productionand marketing under oneroof for the first time. Pam Wallack,currently the president ofGap Adult North America, willbecome the head of that unit.And the Gap stores will have anew ad agency, Ogilvy & MatherWorldwide, along with tapping anOgilvy executive, Seth Farbman,to become the new global chiefmarketing officer.The company had a marketingsnafu in the fall when it introduceda new Gap logo, designedin part by its former agency,Laird & Partners. The classiclogo, with a navy backgroundand tall, thin letters, was replacedby a white background with atiny blue square and a thick sansseriffont. Consumers objected tothe new logo on social networkingsites, and within days, Gapwent back to the original.''I expect more from our Gapbusiness in North America,''Glenn K. Murphy, chief executiveof Gap Inc., said in a statement.Analysts said a change at thedivision was due.''It has struggled over the past10 years,'' said Paul Lejuez, an analystwith Nomura Securities.Gap North America has notposted an annual increase insales at stores open at least ayear since 2004. In the first 11months of the 2010 fiscal year,even as retail in general bouncedback, sales at Gap North Americawere down 1 percent.And overall sales at the divisionhave decreased every yearfor the last five years. In 2009,sales were $3.82 billion, down almostone-third from where theywere in 2004.''They've closed a ton of storesover the past several years, butthey've not seen a boost in compsas a result -- you would thinkthat some sales would transfer toother existing Gap stores, butthat's not happening, and thattells you something,'' Mr. Lejuezsaid.The problem, analysts said, isthat people don't want the clothingthat Gap is selling.''They stand for these keyitems that are fairly basic in nature,and quite frankly, it's toughto keep recreating what are somefairly fundamental items insomebody's closet,'' said AdrienneTennant, an analyst withJanney Capital Markets. ''Ajean's a jean.''John D. Morris, an analyst atBMO Capital Markets, noted thatthe spring clothing did not lookmuch more promising.The spring merchandise is''uncompelling and not resonatingwith the brand's target market,''he said in a note to clients.Also, ''the company brought intoo much spring too early,'' leadingto markdowns even on newarrivals.

Bowing to the inevitable, Senator Daniel K. Inouye, the chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee, announced Tuesday that the panel would not allow pet spending projects known as earmarks to be included in this year's appropriations bills. Mr. Inouye, the nine-term Hawaii Democrat and an expert at steering money to his island state, conceded he did not have much choice since the Republican majority in the House had instituted its own ban and President Obama had also said he would veto any spending measure that contained earmarks. ''The handwriting is clearly on the wall,'' Mr. Inouye said. ''The president has stated unequivocally that he will veto any legislation containing earmarks, and the House will not pass any bills that contain them. Given the reality before us, it makes no sense to accept earmark requests that have no chance of being enacted into law.'' The decision clearly pained the chairman and he suggested he would resurrect the issue for another look once lawmakers of both parties became tired of not having the ability to direct spending to popular projects in their districts and states. ''Next year, when the consequences of this decision are fully understood by the members of this body, we will most certainly revisit this issue and explore ways to improve the earmarking process,'' Mr. Inouye said. The decision eliminates one complication from this year's difficult spending debates, but the Democrat-controlled Senate and Republican-run House have different ideas on where Congress should end up on spending both in terms of the total amount and the priorities. Congressional earmarks have been the subject of a long struggle between senior lawmakers who favor them and other lawmakers and watchdog groups who argue that they increase federal spending and breed corruption. The impact on the federal deficit is negligible, but winning a total ban on such spending is an important symbolic victory for earmark opponents. ''A one-two punch from Congressional Republicans and the president has brought an end to earmarks - at least temporarily,'' said Ryan Alexander, the president of Taxpayers for Common Sense. ''No more political muscle trumping project merit. This should usher in a new era for accountability and oversight on federal spending, not just in earmarked accounts, but budget-wide.'' Lawmakers are always searching for ways around such restrictions and will no doubt still try to influence spending decisions outside the formal definition of earmarks.

Dr. Evil had his cat, Mr. Bigglesworth; President Obama has Bo; even Jabba the Hut had an interstellar critter named Salacious Crumb. And at the seats of power in some of New York City's private schools, there's sometimes something fluffy curled around the chair legs. ''Animals have an interesting ability to humanize the people that they are around,'' said Robert Lauder, the head of Friends Seminary in the East Village. Mr. Lauder has at least a brace of finches cheeping in his office at all times, and used to have a Boston terrier that skittered around his desk. ''It's another way of making contact with somebody in a position of authority who can be somewhat remote-seeming,'' he says. ''A dog is sort of a common denominator.''

TEIRSTEIN--Alvin S. The Association of the Attending Staff deeply mourns the passing of our distinguished colleague and mentor. Professor of Medicine and former Division Chief, Dr. Teirstein was an innovative pioneer in the diagnosis and treatment of Sarcoidosis and other pulmonary disorders. Referred to as the "Guru of Lung Disease," he was internationally renowned for his research and personally trained generations of pulmonary specialists. He was an active member of the AAS Board of Directors for several decades, as a constant voice of reason and support for Mount Sinai, our staff, and our patients. Dr. Teirstein will be remembered for his outstanding contributions in teaching and patient care, and as a supremely compassionate man. The medical world has lost one of the giants. We extend our sincere condolences to his entire family and to his many friends. Steven B. Weinfeld, MD President Gila Leiter, MD Vice President Amy J. Weinstein Administrator

TEIRSTEIN--Alvin S. The Mount Sinai Alumni Association and all of its members mourn the passing of Dr. Alvin Teirstein on January 31, 2011. Born in New York City, NY, Dr. Teirstein came to Mount Sinai Hospital as an Intern in 1953, and completed his residency in 1956. Dr. Teirstein was a recipient of the Jacobi Medallion in 1986, for his distinguished achievement in the field of medicine and his extraordinary service to the Hospital, the School, and the Alumni Association, the most prestigious honor the Alumni Association bestows. He also received the Mount Sinai Alumni Association Special Recognition Award in 2008 for his exceptional service to the Alumni Association over the years. The Alumni Association and its Executive Board, Martin S. Goldstein, Jeffrey Laitman, Lyris Schonholz, Jonathan Schiff, and Elliot Rayfield, extend its sincere condolences to his wife, Alice, and his long surviving legacy of children and grandchildren. An article on Tuesday about obstacles to construction of nuclear reactors in the United States misstated the Florida Public Service Commission's rules on allowing utilities to bill ratepayers for construction costs while a reactor is being built. The commission does indeed allow some billing for expenses before and during construction; it does not forbid it. The article also misstated the status of two companies' proposals to build reactors. Progress Energy and Florida Power and Light both have drawn up plans, though they have not made a commitment to build; they have backed off their proposals. And the article misidentified the nuclear plant adjacent to a site where Ameren UE proposes to build a reactor in Missouri. It is the Callaway plant -- not Wolf Creek, a plant in Kansas.

An article on Saturday about a debate within the Obama administration over legal challenges to the Defense of Marriage Act, which bars the federal government from recognizing same-sex marriages, misstated one of the factors considered by judges in discrimination cases. They are more likely to strike down a law if it discriminates against a class of people (for example, a racial minority) who cannot choose to leave the class-- not people who have the option of leaving it.

The N.F.L. will have no trouble playing 18 and even more regular-season games if it can persuade the players to accept an expanded schedule, Jerry Jones, the owner of the Dallas Cowboys, said Tuesday. ''We've had the ability to go to 22 games, had we wanted to as owners without anybody's approval. We haven't done that without the approval of players. Certainly, we want players to buy into what we do on a going-forward basis.''

Species die. It has become a catastrophic fact of modern life. On our present course, by E.O. Wilson’s estimate, half of all plant and animal species could be extinct by 2100 — that is, within the lifetime of a child born today. Kenya stands to lose its lions within 20 years. India is finishing off its tigers. Deforestation everywhere means that thousands of species too small or obscure to be kept on life support in a zoo simply vanish each year.

It took only a few days for Egyptian protesters to bring the regime of Hosni Mubarak to near collapse. But it took decades for the conditions for revolt to ripen. A range of widely noted books offer clues to the country's accumulated discontents and thwarted desires. Max Rodenbeck's Cairo: The City Victorious is a cultural and social history of the Arab world's largest city, written by the Economist's Middle East Correspondent. Mary Anne Weaver's A Portrait of Egypt examines Egyptian society in the 1990s, with an emphasis on Islamist opponents of the Mubarak regime.

Roger Deakins is almost the Susan Lucci of cinematography: he's been nominated for an Oscar nine times, starting with "The Shawshank Redemption" in 1994, and never won. He's on deck again this year, for the Coen brothers' "True Grit." Many of his honors came from his collaboration with the Coens; he has been their go-to cinematographer since "Barton Fink." They first met more than two decades ago, at a coffee shop in Notting Hill, in London. "By then they were great cult filmmakers," Mr. Deakins said, in a phone interview from his home in Santa Monica. "I don't know why they had chosen to meet with me, but they did and we got on." Does he understand them any better now? "I guess," he said, laughing. But Mr. Deakins professed as much surprise as the Coens have about "True Grit" being such a box office hit. "It's maybe more accessible than most of their films," he said. "I think it's a great movie, but I think most of their films are great movies." He is currently working on "Now," a futuristic thriller from the director Andrew Niccol ("Gattaca"), his first experience shooting in digital. What does he make of the divide between film and digital? "I don't really see the point of the argument," Mr. Deakins said. "You use images and light and texture and camera movement to tell a story. I think it's a technical argument, and films aren't really made by technique."

With only one season under her belt, Giovanna Randall, the designer behind the New York-based label Honor, is opening a shop in the meatpacking district. But there is more in store than Randall's girlie cocktail dresses and long chiffon evening gowns. Like the label that shares its name, Honor is all about the prettier, finer points of a woman's pleasures. "I started asking myself, 'What do you think Sophia Loren's couch looks like?' or 'What kind of typewriter would Grace Kelly have used?' " the designer says. Randall plans to display her collection alongside vintage and new books. Cafe treats like Bellocq tea and espresso are a small step toward Randall's dream of turning Honor into a multidimensional lifestyle brand. "I fantasize about coming by the shop and being able to pick up a lovely party dress and wonderful bouquet of flowers en route to a friend's birthday dinner." So do we.

In our column today, the Bagger looks at the documentary race, where there may actually be some drama. Not that you would know it from the behavior of the presumed front-runner, Charles Ferguson, the director of "Inside Job," his dissection of the financial meltdown. Mr. Ferguson, an early Internet millionaire, is soft-spoken and unconcerned with appearances; he's been known to show up at awards shows in sneakers. He's been through the Oscar process before, with his first film, "No End in Sight," in 2008. What's changed in his approach since then? "I have an agent now, which I never did before," he said. "I've spoken to the Sony publicity people a few times." (Sony Pictures Classics is the distributor of "Inside Job," which is being re-released in theaters on the back of its Oscar nomination.) "But," he added of the Oscar race, "this is totally not my department."

"Kahn in Venice," an exhibition at the Italian Cultural Institute in Los Angeles, celebrates the architect Louis I. Kahn's special relationship with Italy. His unbuilt 1968 project for a congress hall in Venice is the centerpiece of the show, which was organized in collaboration with the Architectural Archives of the University of Pennsylvania, and which also includes many of Kahn's lush, expressive travel sketches of buildings, gardens, bridges and street scenes in Venice, Rome and the hill towns of Tuscany. (The exhibition, which is on view through March 19, was curated and designed by the Los Angeles architects Barton Myers and David Karp, both of whom were Kahn's students and apprentices.)

Dean Jerrehian, founder and chief executive of JadeYoga, a high-end yoga-mat manufacturer in Conshohocken, Pa., recently stumbled on a trove of his grandfather's letters. Mr. Jerrehian had to laugh when he saw what the man had to go through to set up meetings with clients in his real estate business 70 years ago. "It took him months of letters to arrange to meet someone by the side of road," he said. "And this was for a client who was all of 40 miles away. I was complaining the other day because it took me three days of swapping e-mail to nail down a deal in Jakarta. It's a dream come true for fans of ''Dallas,'' the vintage-1980s prime-time soap opera, and presumably one that doesn't end with Pam Barnes waking up to find Bobby Ewing in the shower and an entire season of the show wiped out. The pilot episode of a new ''Dallas'' series being prepared for the TNT cable network will feature Larry Hagman, Patrick Duffy and Linda Gray, reprising their roles from the original CBS series, TNT said on Tuesday night. Mr. Hagman is set to return as J. R. Ewing, the Texas oil magnate who became a one-name shorthand for '80s-era greed and ruthlessness. Ms. Gray will once again play Sue Ellen, J. R.'s wife, and Mr. Duffy his younger brother Bobby, who appeared to be hit by a car and killed in the original series, only to reappear, alive and well, in the shower the following year. (Mr. Duffy had intended to leave the series but decided to return.)

An article on Tuesday about Apple's tightening of its control of the App Store misstated part of its policy. While the company is requiring e-book purchases within apps to go through its payment system, customers can still use apps to access e-books and other content they bought elsewhere. It is not the case that access to that content will be cut off.

DUNN--Kempton, former vice president of the Council on Foreign Relations and program director of The Conference Board, died on January 25 in Maui, HI with his wife by his side. He was 69 years old and lived in New Canaan, CT. Born in New York City on January 5, 1942, Mr. Dunn graduated from the Kent School and from Yale College in 1965. After graduation, he served as a Fulbright scholar in India, received a Master's degree from The Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies, and worked at Time Inc. and the Asia Society before arriving at the Council. During his two decades with the Council in New York City, Kempton eventually rose to Vice President for Membership and Fellowship Affairs, earning from his colleagues the fond nickname "Dean of Admissions" and recognition for his leadership of the Council's prestigious International Affairs Program. Over his decade with the Conference Board, also in New York City, Kempton served as Director of International Programs, organizing hundreds of conferences, seminars, and workshops on issues ranging from economics and marketing to healthcare and sustainability. He also conceived and orchestrated conferences on emerging topics such as corporate security and risk and crisis management. Kempton is survived by his wife, the former Ellen Gage Anderson, of New Canaan, CT; two sons, Kempton Dunn III of San Francisco and Seth Simrall Dunn of Saratoga Springs, NY; a daughter, Heather Anderson Drugge of Darien, CT; and a sister, Holly Bodman of New York City and Cambridge, MA.

The musician who first took the stage of the Apollo Theater in Harlem as Little Stevie Wonder at age 12 in 1962 and then went on to some very big things will receive an honor from the theater later this year. The Apollo is to announce on Wednesday that it will induct Mr. Wonder - he's just Stevie now, thank you very much - into its Apollo Legends Hall of Fame. Mr. Wonder, the best-selling pop and soul artist whose albums include ''Talking Book,'' ''Innervisions'' and ''Songs in the Key of Life,'' was a child performer on Berry Gordy's Motown Revue when he made his Apollo debut, and returned several times to the theater for performances including its ''Save the Apollo'' concert in the 1980s and a series of solo shows in 2005, the theater's press representatives said. Other artists already named to the theater's Hall of Fame include Michael Jackson, Aretha Franklin, Quincy Jones, Smokey Robinson and Ella Fitzgerald. Mr. Wonder is to be officially inducted on June 13 at the Apollo's annual spring gala. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

The Yankees continued to round out the fringes of their roster on Wednesday, acquiring the right-handed-hitting outfielder Justin Maxwell from the Washington Nationals. Maxwell, a career .201 hitter over parts of three seasons with Washington, could make the Yankees as a backup outfielder or, at the very least, improve their depth at Class AAA. His career highlight came on Sept. 30, 2009, when he hit a game-winning grand slam off Mets closer Francisco Rodriguez with two outs and a full count in the bottom of the ninth.

BEHRMAN--Stanley J.,DMD., former professor of surgery and chief of dentistry, oral and maxillofacial surgery at New York Presbyterian Hospital-Weill Cornell Medical Center, and prominent New York surgeon, Dr. Stanley J. Behrman passed away comfortably on January 30th after a short battle with colon cancer. He is remembered by his former colleagues and residents for his 55 years of both clinical and academic excellence. During his tenure as Chief his abilities to teach, innovate upon, and improve jaw surgery led to significant advances in his specialty of Orthodontics. The generations of surgeons he trained, and patients he helped with his advanced and specialized techniques, are his legacy. A graduate of New York University and the University of Pittsburgh School of Dentistry, Dr. Behrman was one of the founders of the technique of intra-oral surgical manipulation of the upper and or lower jaw to correct deformities, improved the esthetic appearance, and improved the occlusion or, bite. Dr. Behrman was a practitioner and life long friend to many celebrated personalities. Amongst others this included the star, Betty Davis. He was able to preserve her mandible from a severe bone infection as she was performing on Broadway. He was acclaimed throughout the media, appearing on television numerous times and including the CBS special, The Body Human-The Body Beautiful. He is survived by his wife Marla, stepson Peter Grayson and his wife Josephine, grandsons Bradley and Eric, and brother Lawrence. He lived his life generously, intelligently, and faithfully and gave life a rich and purposeful meaning. A celebration of his life will be held at a later date. For information please call: 917-596-7174. Contributions may be made to Hospice of Palm Beach.

Android users who upgrade to Google Maps 5.1, available since Tuesday, will find a bunch of new features added to Latitude, Google's location-based social network. The first is the ability to check in to actual places, like restaurants and stores. In the past, Latitude users could indicate where they were on a map, but the actual business or building they were in remained a mystery. (''I'm in Rockefeller Center'' is not terribly helpful. ''I'm in J. Crew'' is.) Since Latitude works with Google Maps and Android, it is constantly aware of your location (if you want it to be). That leads to the other enhancements: notification and automatic check-in and checkout. When you arrive somewhere, Latitude can prompt you to check in, in case you have forgotten to do so already. You can also set Latitude up to automatically check yourself in to frequently visited places, like your office. Latitude will also automatically check you out when you leave a location.

Citigroup has barely owned EMI for a day, but it has already achieved a dubious distinction: a No. 1 album with notably low sales - even in a season of painfully low sales for the music industry. Amos Lee, a folk-meets-soul singer-songwriter who records for EMI's Blue Note label, sold 40,478 copies of his new album, ''Mission Bell,'' the label said. It is Mr. Lee's best sales week, but by one significant measure it is also the industry's worst. Last month the record for the least sales of a No. 1 album was broken first by Taylor Swift's hit ''Speak Now'' (with 52,000) and then the band Cake's ''Showroom of Compassion'' (44,000). (The previous record holder was the ''Dreamgirls'' soundtrack, which sold 60,000 copies one week in January 2007.)

The firm's fourth-quarter profit represents a sharp swing from a loss at the same time in 2009, when it took charges related to its compensation and stock payouts tied to the death of its former chief executive, Bruce Wasserstein. The firm's profit amounts to 76 cents a share on a fully exchanged basis.

An article on Monday about Dan Greenhaus, chief economic strategist at Miller Tabak & Company, who has become a folk hero among fans of the band Phish for slyly working in references to its music during his media appearances, misstated part of the name of one media outlet where he has made the references. It is Fox Business Network, not Fox Business News.

KNAPP--Anna, died peacefully, on January 31, 2011. For 94 years she resided in New York City, the first of five children of immigrant parents. While working as a comptroller in publishing firms, she was a sophisticated patron of theater, ballet, opera, museums and the Asia Society, as she became the quintessential New Yorker. She was passionate about anthropology, traveled the world and was an avid equestrian (and occasional dromedarian) in her youth. Anna was uncompromising in her beliefs, her familial loyalty and her passion for learning. There are few who possessed her wide-ranging knowledge and strong opinions of world events. Her legacy is that she lived life in her own way, on her own terms: independent and impassioned to the end. She leaves behind younger brothers and sister, Julius, Philip and Beatrice, her sisters-in-law Irene and Fay, ten nieces and nephews, and fifteen grand-nieces and grand-nephews. Services will be held at noon on February 4, 2011 at the Star of David Memorial Chapel in Babylon, NY. Donations to City-Meals-On-Wheels in lieu of flowers would be welcome.

SOMARY--Johannes, conductor, composer, organist, teacher and friend. In countless performances and more than 50 recordings, in sacred music and secular, Hannes was both innovator and careful steward of tradition. With skill, scholarship, humor, love and an inexhaustible, contagious enthusiasm, he brought joy and inspiration to thousands. "Lux aeterna luceat eis, Domine". Services will be at The Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, Park Ave. at 84th St. on Saturday, February 5, at noon. The Board of Directors of Amor Artis, Inc

MATTHEWS--William O. We were saddened by the passing of William O. Matthews our Partner at Cowen & Co. We send our condolences to his widow, Janet; daughter, Jennifer and son, William Jr. Bill helped Cowen orchestrate its great success in the bond brokerage business. Cowen was the leading bond broker in the United States. Bill was a man of integrity, stood by his word and a person you could depend on to have a job well done. We will miss him. Former Partners of Cowen & Co.

A moment of silence for the White Stripes, please. The band, consisting of the not-really-brother-and-sister Jack and Meg White, have not released an album in almost four years, and on Wednesday they formally announced on their Web site that they have broken up.

BEHRMAN--Stanley, D.M.D. We mourn the loss of Dr. Stanley Behrman, beloved colleague and member of our medical center family for more than 55 years. Emeritus professor of surgery at Weill Cornell Medical College and retired chief of the Division of Dentistry, Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery at NewYork-Presbyterian/Weill Cornell, Dr. Behrman built a widely respected clinical and academic program and pioneered effective new treatments, particularly in the area of facial jaw surgery. We offer our heartfelt condolences to his nephew, Dr. David Behrman, who continues his legacy of excellence at our medical center; his brother, Dr. Lawrence Behrman, formerly of NewYork-Presbyterian/Weill Cornell; wife, Marla; first wife, Nancy; son, Peter, and the entire Behrman family. Antonio M. Gotto Jr., M.D. Dean, Weill Cornell Medical College Herbert Pardes, M.D. President and CEO, NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital
International FOR IN-DEBT FRENCH REGION,

NAEGELE--Philipp. The musicians, staff, trustees and family of Marlboro Music mourn the loss of a beloved member of its community and send heartfelt condolences to his wife Barbara and his family. One of our first participants, he shared his love of music and his belief in all that we strive for with us for six decades, and he generously made valuable contributions to Marlboro in so many areas. The Marlboro family will miss him dearly.

RADY--Elsa, 67, died at home in Los Angles, January 29. An extraordinary ceramic potter, she is survived by her adoring sister Jane Rady Lynes, brother-in-law George Lynes, nephew Joshua Lynes and aunt Gertrude Barlow, all of New York City. A memorial will be announced in the spring.
TEIRSTEIN--Alvin, MD. Dr. Joseph Masci, Director of Medicine at Elmhurst Hospital Center and the entire Department of Medicine extend our sincere condolences to his family and all who loved him.

BOTTEGA VENETA is known for its neutral-toned, trend-defying bags, like the woven Cabat. But for spring, it welcomes a lighter choice. This tribal dotted papier leather tote ($2,680) stood out in a collection that was cool in palette and easy in construction. At select Bottega Veneta stores, including 699 Fifth Avenue, (212) 371-5511.

KURZ--Edythe. NYU Libraries mourns the passing of Mrs. Kurz, a therapist and psychiatric social worker who dedicated her life to family, friends, and those in need. Through the family foundation, she was a generous supporter of our Ewen Center programs in academic freedom. The NYU community extends heartfelt sympathy to her family.
''I want to be clear. 'Now' started yesterday.'' ROBERT GIBBS, on President Obama's call on Tuesday for a political transition in Egypt to begin now.

WAR OF WORDS There was a heated exchange of letters on Tuesday as the J. Crew settlement over its proposed leveraged buyout collapsed. Lawyers for objecting shareholders started the public fight by sending a letter to the Delaware judge on the matter, Vice Chancellor Leo E. Strine Jr., stating that they were walking away from the previously negotiated settlement. In turn, J. Crew's lawyers responded with their own letter to the vice chancellor. So who is right? The Deal Professor has the answer. STEVEN M. DAVIDOFF BAILOUT PAYBACK Fifth Third Bancorp, the large regional Midwestern bank, announced on Wednesday that it had repaid the $3.4 billion taxpayer bailout it received at the height of the financial crisis.

TEIRSTEIN--Alvin, MD. The Division of Pulmonary, Allergy and Critical Care Medicine of Columbia University Medical Center/NYPH marks with deep sadness the death of Dr. Alvin Teirstein. Dr. Teirstein was widely recognized as a leader in our field and one of the outstanding pulmonary physicians in the country. His influence as a teacher, colleague and friend to generations of physicians was enormous. We mourn his loss and extend our condolences to his family. Neil W. Schluger, M.D., Chief Division of Pulmonary, Allergy and Critical Care Medicine

THE Little House is smaller than some apartments, but the 400-square-foot underground store carries its own line of raw denim jeans and logo-free clothing for men and women -- and doubles as a party space. ''I'd rather have a dinner at my house than be at someone's bar or a restaurant,'' said Savania Davies-Keiller (center), who owns the store with Michael Capotosto (right), her husband, and Joel Alexander Morales (left). The Little House, 71 Sullivan Street (near Broome Street), (212) 966-6099.

MAHON--Myra. The Board of Trustees and the entire Hospital for Special Surgery community extend our deepest sympathy at the passing of Myra Mahon, wife of Arthur Mahon, long time friend of our Hospital. Myra was a dedicated advocate for patient education and women's health. We extend our deepest condolences to Arthur, their children and grandchildren. Dean R. O'Hare Aldo Papone Co-Chairs, Board of Trustees Thomas P. Sculco, M.D. Chief Medical Officer Louis A. Shapiro President and CEO Hospital for Special Surgery

An article on Dec. 3 about a lawsuit filed against JPMorgan Chase by the Madoff trustee misidentified the court in which the suit was filed. It is the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan, not the Federal District Court. The article also misstated the date when internal Chase files were published in France. The documents were published in L'Express on Oct. 7, 2010, not on July 10. The errors were discovered during follow-up reporting about the continuing litigation.
JOHNSTON--W. Elbert. May 25, 1963-February 3, 1978 So long as we remember - you live always. Your family

JACOBSON--Franklin M. With great sorrow we mourn the loss of our beloved partner and member of our family for over four decades. Frank was always an inspiration to us, with his dedication to our clients, their business, their families and their lives. He worked closely with them, not simply for them. And for his devotion to his partners and staff, and his gentle presence among us, we are forever grateful. No one was too humble for his genuine concern and interest. To Naomi, to Elissa, Richard and Ruby, to Neil and the family, we offer our love and support. You are all in our thoughts. The Partners and Staff of Joel E. Sammet & Company

Last week, the Facebook chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, found his personal account hacked. If it could happen to Mr. Zuckerberg, users realized, it could happen to anyone. The most likely way for someone to gain access to an account would be to capture traffic on an insecure network, like a public Wi-Fi hotspot.

PINTO--Kim, died suddenly of respiratory failure at age 54 on January 31, 2011 in New York City. Beloved daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Eugene Pinto, sister of Ronald (Alyse) Pinto. Kim was a Magazine Publishing Executive primarily at Conde Nast and Hearst. She was on the Board of the Susan G. Komen Foundation. She also volunteered with the Ovarian Cancer Research Fund. Donations in her memory can be made to the Susan G. Komen Foundation. Rest peacefully our precious one. We cannot imagine our lives without you. Family receiving at Macken Funeral Home, Rockville Ctr., Saturday from 2-4pm and 7-9pm. 516-766-3300.

On some college campuses, students are agitated about the presence of Chick-fil-A, a purveyor of Southern-style chicken sandwiches that has run afoul of some proponents of same-sex marriage. But at a New York University cafeteria, the only place in the city where a craving for Chick-fil-A can be sated, the squawking has been limited. Some N.Y.U. students have complained to the university's Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgender and Queer Student Center, said John Beckman, a university spokesman. And a Facebook group Remove Chick-fil-A from NYU (and thus NYC!) is up and running.

Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about revelations that Ehud Olmert, when he was prime minister of Israel, and Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian president, came close to a peace agreement in 2008 misattributed a comment expressing concern that five million Palestinian refugees and their descendants could not all move to Israel because that would destroy it. That comment was made by Mr. Abbas, not by Mr. Olmert.
ABRUZZO--Elissa L.,May 24, 1955 - February 3, 2010. Beloved daughter, sister, friend. Love you forever. Arrivederci. Dad, Mom, Claudia, Jamie

WorldGate's Ojo Vision digital videophone is an option worth considering for those who don't want to sit in front of a computer or use a smartphone to make video calls. Set up was snap-simple: It took less than five minutes from unboxing to dialing. You can use a number assigned to you by WorldGate or port your existing number to the phone.

As Europe continues to ship off its up-and-coming actors to play dashing American superheroes, the United States is apparently responding by sending one of its most virile specimens of manhood to that continent in exchange: namely, Woody Allen. Mr. Allen's latest film, ''Midnight in Paris,'' will open the Cannes Film Festival on May 11, the event's organizers said on Wednesday. The film, the 41st feature-length work that Mr. Allen has directed, is a romantic comedy whose cast includes Owen Wilson, Rachel McAdams, Marion Cotillard, Kathy Bates and Adrien Brody, though one cast member, Carla Bruni-Sarkozy, has received a bit more attention than the others. In a statement, Thierry Fremaux, the director of the Cannes festival, described ''Midnight in Paris'' as ''a wonderful love letter to Paris,'' adding: ''It's a film in which Woody Allen takes a deeper look at the issues raised in his last films: our relationship with history, art, pleasure and life.'' The film will be released in France on the same day it makes its debut at Cannes, though an American release date has not yet been announced. The full Cannes Film Festival runs through May 22. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

JACOBY--Miriam (Itkind), 90, passed away peacefully at home surrounded by her children on February 2, 2011. Predeceased by her beloved husband, Mark J. Jacoby. She is survived by her daughter, Joan Levick (Bill); her son Ken (Alice); Jon (Maggie); grandchildren Jordan (Kim), Geoffrey, Jocelyn (Avitai), Michael (Rachel), Jennie Rose, and Steven; great-grandson Elijah; great-granddaughter Victoria; nieces and nephews. We will all miss her greatly and cherish her memory forever. Private graveside service. Her memory may be honored by donations to: Alzheimer Association Long Island, 3281 Veterans Memorial Highway, E. 13, Ronkonkoma, NY 11779 or Hospice Care Network, 99 Sunnyside Boulevard, Woodbury, NY 11797.
CHIARA--Judith Loeb Beaty. Please join us to celebrate Judy's life on Tuesday, February 8th, 2011 at 5:30pm. For venue please email: jlcmemorial@hotmail.com

(Bravo) MILLION DOLLAR LISTING In this Season 4 opener the real estate agents Josh Flagg, above, and Madison Hildebrand are joined by Josh Altman (who replaces Chad Rogers) in their quest to move some of the most magnificent homes in Los Angeles with the economy still in a slump -- never mind their private lives. The trouble begins as Mr. Altman faces off with an angry seller who thinks he knows best how to market his home. In a new episode of ''Selling New York,'' at 9 on HGTV, the sisters and brokers Samantha Kleier Forbes and Sabrina Kleier Morgenstern have a chance at a double commission when a wealthy bachelor hires them to find his dream home on a budget to match. At 9:30 Ms. Forbes helps her best friend decide whether to stay in the city or move to the suburbs. And Deborah Lupard tries to convince a client that he should actually live in his newly purchased apartment in the financial district of Manhattan before putting it up for sale.

5:40 p.m. | Updated It's not an easy thing to mount a big exhibition of artifacts from China without any artifacts from China. That's the position the University of Pennsylvania Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology now finds itself in, as it prepares to open a major show on Saturday, ''Secrets of the Silk Road,'' which was organized by the Bowers Museum in Santa Ana, Calif., last year and traveled from there to the Houston Museum of Natural Science.

Since I last wrote about this year's Academy Award nominees for Best Picture, there has been a significant shift in the conventional wisdom about the probable winner. "The Social Network," which was once considered as likely as 90 percent certain to win by betting markets, is now given only about a 20 percent chance. "The King's Speech," instead, has become the heavy favorite.
