In Tuesday's column, "When Microcredit Won't Do," I wrote about microconsignment, a way for village entrepreneurs to sell innovative and important products for which there is no established market - such as solar lamps, water purifiers, stoves and reading glasses - without having to take on debt.  Instead, village women are given the products and the training to sell them.  Once they make the sale, they repay the supplier and keep a portion of the proceeds.  Done right, microconsignment provides new businesses for village women - and helps make life healthier and more prosperous for her neighbors.

DALLAS - Curtis Martin's career with New England and the Jets was much like the man himself: understated, consistent, workmanlike. Only Martin and Barry Sanders topped 1,000 rushing yards in each of their first 10 seasons. Only Emmitt Smith, Walter Payton and Sanders gained more rushing yards than Martin's 14,101.

The Carmelo Anthony trade saga has been one of this season's dominant storylines. With all the focus on whether or not Anthony will still be a Nugget after this season's trade deadline or next summer, the fact that the Nuggets are currently the best offensive team in basketball has been lost in the shuffle. The Nuggets' defense has kept them from being one of the West's elite teams this season, but they have done an excellent job of surrounding Anthony with efficient offensive players. And no Nugget has been more efficient than Nene.

The energy secretary, Steven Chu, was publicly using the phrase "Sputnik moment" two months before President Obama picked it up in the State of the Union speech to describe the need for a national effort to improve competitiveness in a technical field. Now he has moved on to a new space-challenge term: SunShot.

In the Oscar competition for best-foreign language film, the entry from Greece, "Dogtooth," is definitely the outlier - and underdog. In one fashion or another, all four of the other films are outwardly directed, addressing aspects of relations between the West and the Third World. "Dogtooth," in contrast, is hermetic, a study of a family in which the parents have decided to literally wall their children off from the rest of the world in order to protect them from malign outside influences.
Far fewer partners switched law firms last year than in 2009, according to an article in The American Lawyer this week.

Illness will keep Matthew Polenzani out of tonight's Metropolitan Opera production of "Don Pasquale." Barry Banks will take over for him in the role of Ernesto, the Met said. Banks sang the role at the Met in November 2010.

By any reasonable measure, Specialist Peter Sprenger, a radio operator in an Army infantry company, could easily have been dead. It was Dec. 19, 2003, in Talafar, Iraq. An Iraqi man driving an explosives-laden car had breached his company's perimeter. American soldiers fired at him with light machine guns, but the driver accelerated toward the company command post.

Riccardo Muti, the Italian maestro and music director of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, will have surgery to repair "multiple facial and jaw fractures" suffered when he collapsed on the podium during a rehearsal on Thursday and fell to the stage, the orchestra said on Friday.

It's not often that a nonfiction book appears whose thesis is immediately tested by events. But such is the fate of Evgeny Morozov's "Net Delusion," which I review in this Sunday's Book Review. Morozov's argument that the internet does more harm than good in political contexts is running up against violent reality in Egypt.
The Op-Ed columnists Nicholas D. Kristof, in Cairo, and Thomas L. Friedman, in Amman, on the growing unrest across the Middle East.

Timothy Hull's work is informed by an obsession with politics ("I like subtle, oblique statements") and secret societies ("There's a quiet queerness that I love"). While he's known primarily for his dense, rigorously detailed drawings in graphite or blue gel pen, he's been painting on a large scale lately. (Perhaps it's due to a recent studio development that doubled his space.) Hull recently curated "Cover Version (LP)" at the Brooklyn Academy of Music (on view until March 20), for which he asked fellow artists to visually remix their favorite album covers. When we visited him, he was gearing up for a new show at Taylor de Cordoba Gallery in Los Angeles in May.
The unemployment rate has declined more in the last two months than in any two months since 1958.
Fortune Brands, in its fourth-quarter earnings announcement on Friday, said the company was on track to split into three businesses.

Doug Bourn, the Tesla Motors executive who was killed last year when the airplane he was piloting struck high power wires in East Palo Alto, Calif., had not flown for 18 months before the day of the crash, according to two lawsuits filed against his estate by the families of the other men killed in the accident.

Savoy, which is serving a daily cassoulet special in February, is hosting a tasting festival Saturday at the restaurant, 70 Prince Street (Crosby Street), from 12:30 to 3:30 p.m. Chefs from Back Forty, Cookshop, Fatty Johnson's, Nuela, Vinegar Hill House and WD-50 will prepare different versions of cassoulet. The $65 ticket includes wine, but not tax or gratuity.

It's a great weekend to be a sports fan. The N.H.L. has a packed schedule through Sunday afternoon, at which point the Super Bowl takes over the spotlight. But while the games will be entertaining, the transition may be jarring.

Despite his French training and a previous stint at Orsay, the chef Jason Hicks has gone back to his roots in a Cotswolds village for Jones Wood Foundry, a pub in a part of the city once called Jones Wood. It's opening on Feb. 14.

A film crew accompanying a researcher with Brazil's Indian Affairs department captures rare aerial footage of a highly isolated tribe living deep in the Amazon rain forest, near the Peru-Brazil border. Advocates for the region's indigenous people say illegal logging in Peru is driving other isolated tribes across the border into Brazil, causing conflicts over resources and territory. Responding to the release of video and images of the tribe, Peruvian authorities said this week that they would work to stop the intrusion of loggers into protected areas.  [Survival International]

Not every Super Bowl feature is about Ben Roethlisberger, Troy Polamalu, or the price of a 30-second commercial. Role players, backups, and coaches suddenly become media darlings, as hometown papers profile neighborhood kids who grew up to become backup linebackers and news outlets cast a wide net for undiscovered coverage angles. No Super Bowl participant is too obscure for a few candelas of the limelight, not even:

Right about the time the Pittsburgh Steelers were starting a run to another Super Bowl, Billy Gardell, a lifelong fan and native son of the Steel City, was beginning his own season as the star of a new CBS sitcom and taping his first prime-time stand-up comedy special - a show that will appear the night before his team takes the field in Dallas.
Do you remember which team won the Super Bowl last year? Do you remember which was your favorite ad?

Unlike the majority of fashion labels, which are subject to a constant wax-and-wane credibility cycle, A.P.C. is ever cool. That's due in large part to the brand's founder, Jean Touitou, a man to whom the conventions of fashion - trend-based collections, high-profile ad campaigns - are so many canards, a conviction that his loyal customers, many of whom wouldn't wear any other jeans, wholeheartedly endorse. A.P.C.'s second Manhattan shop will open next week at the corner of Perry and Bleecker Streets in the West Village, to be followed this summer by a third location just a few blocks away. "The West Village is classy. SoHo is getting a bit commercial. Every time you turn around, there's a new store. Of course, who am I to talk? I'm opening new stores." Touitou said with typical candor when The Moment rang up his Paris office to chat. Here, he talks to us about the fashion habits of 19th-century British aristocrats, the pleasures of sewing and why the classics aren't as simple as they look.

The final briefs have been filed in Air Products and Chemicals' legal battle to gain control of Airgas, and a ruling in Delaware Chancery Court is expected next week. The briefs are fine pieces of work, no doubt worthy of the hundreds of thousands of dollars spent to write each of them.

"I'm a worker, not so much a talker," Mark Lee, the chief executive of Barneys New York, said Friday morning, explaining his reluctance these last few months to publicly discuss his makeover plans for the store. Mr. Lee, the former chief executive of Gucci, arrived at Barneys in September.
Facebook can often be a time suck, but a new initiative by JetBlue offers rewards for logging onto the site.

Thursday night's TNT double-header featured two premier matchups, both of which delighted national audiences by living up to their billing. For the first game, the ever-prominent Miami Heat played the latest in its season series (and budding rivalry) against the quasi-contending Orlando Magic. In the second, the best team in the West, the San Antonio Spurs, teed off against the honorary best team in the West, the Los Angeles Lakers. Tremendous individual performances, game-winners, strong defense, and highly competitive play ruled the day.

Never let it be said that Gucci does not know how to throw a party. On Wednesday night, the luxury brand threw an uptown soiree at Gucci's Madison Avenue location that was abuzz with pre-Fashion Week excitement. The event was to celebrate the brand's new made-to-order bamboo bag, which gives the Palm Beach staple a much-needed New York face-lift.

We tend to think of nurses as yet another item on that expensive list labeled "medical care," but around the country about 15,000 nurses, most of them acting as volunteers, provide elderly support services free of charge. The members of the faith community nurse movement, as it's called, are available to anyone, regardless of religion. In many communities, getting help is simply a matter of picking up the telephone.

BMW DesignworksUSA has conceived a new vehicle big on headroom, with seating capacity for the entire family -- along with several hundred of their closest friends. The new Siemens Metro Inspiro, penned by the BMW Group-owned design consultancy, might lack the acceleration of an M5 sports sedan or the curves of a Z4 Roadster, but it is equipped with enough curious features and functions to give BMW's iDrive interface a run for the money.

Laura Hillenbrand, the best-selling author of "Seabiscuit: An American Legend," is known for her exuberant storytelling and dynamic characters. Her newest book, "Unbroken: A World War II Story of Survival, Resilience and Redemption," is a riveting tale of the life of an athlete and war hero, Louis Zamperini.

The imam who was named three weeks ago to lead religious services at the proposed Muslim community center and mosque near ground zero said Friday that he was stepping down. The move is the latest in a string of public relations setbacks for the project.

Nippon Steel and Sumitomo Metal Industries said they envisioned merging by October 2012, a move that could reduce costs and ease the effect of rising prices for raw materials. Shares of Japanese steel makers climbed on the news as investors expected the deal to lead to further consolidation in the industry. This Reuters Business video explores the implications of the planned merger.

For a pretty pink pucker this Valentine's Day, try Chanel's new Rouge Coco Shine lipstick in Boy, the shade Vanessa Paradis wears in the campaign for the shimmery new collection. The line has its official debut in April, but the lipstick is available presale from Thursday through Feb. 13 at Chanel boutiques and at department stores. Named after Arthur Capel, known as Boy, the love of Coco Chanel's life, it is $32; for stores: chanel.com.

Cold weather and winter vegetables lend themselves to comforting, bubbly baked dishes, writes Martha Rose Shulman in this week’s Recipes for Health.

A lawsuit brought by the trustee for the victims of Bernard L. Madoff's multibillion-dollar Ponzi scheme accuses the owners of the Mets of being so enamored of the enormous profits they earned while investing over decades with Mr. Madoff that they ignored repeated and specific warnings that he might have been operating a fraud, The New York Times reports.

Mary Cleere Haran, one of the foremost cabaret singers of the 1990s, was gravely injured in a biking accident on Thursday near Deerfield Beach, Fla., where she has been living for the last year, said a friend, Bridge McIntyre. Ms. Haran, 58, is known for her celebrations of the American songbook, especially the work of Rodgers and Hart, Harry Warren, and the music of Doris Day.
Minh Uong/The New York Times
To the thousands of parents who yelled and screamed this week about the city's plan to close nearly two dozen schools, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has a message: You are an embarrassment.

Even the most disciplined savers are heavily relying on the stock market to reach their retirement goals. But that often amounts to a giant gamble, which is the thrust of the thinking behind a new retirement planning program that treats investing in stocks like a trip to the casino.

The Williams F1 team prepared the ground a few weeks ago,  saying that it was considering taking the team public. On Friday, the team announced that it would indeed go through with a listing on the Frankfurt stock exchange.

A day after the first test session ended in Spain, the McLaren Mercedes team on Friday launched its new car in Berlin. While several teams this year did away with the full-fledged launch to save money, McLaren took the unusual approach of inviting fans to piece together the new car at the launch, with the team's drivers, Jenson Button and Lewis Hamilton, putting on the final pieces. Nice original idea.
In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:
Cairo's "Day of Departure" protests end peacefully in Tahrir Square; and Helene Cooper reports on the Obama administration's proposal for President Mubarak to resign.

Conventional wisdom over the last few years has been that, with staff jobs scarce, more of America's relentlessly entrepreneurial workers have turned to self-employment. The numbers don't quite bear that out.
Floyd Norris and I discuss this morning's jobs report in more detail here. My summary follows:
Today's Patient Money column focuses on the challenges of treating chronic pain and getting reimbursed for treatment.

Fashion Week is coming up, and that means scads of runway shows and presentations and a whole lot of late nights. So, what's a T fashion editor to do? We turned to Delilah DiCrescenzo, an All-American titleholder for Columbia University's cross-country and track team. She's also a founding member of the New Jersey/New York Track Club, which is sponsored by Puma. "We always say two days before the race is the most important night for sleep," DiCrescenzo says. "But that doesn't mean overcompensating."

The novelist Peter S. Beagle is the latest author to have his work adapted into the graphic novel format. "The Last Unicorn," from IDW, lands at No. 2 on our hardcover list this week. The novel, originally published in 1968, was also turned into an animated film in 1982. In her review of the film version, Janet Maslin wrote: " 'The Last Unicorn' is an unusual children's film in many respects, the chief one being that it is unusually good. This animated fable also features a cast that would do any live-action film proud, a visual style noticeably different from that of other children's fare, and a story filled with genuine sweetness and mystery. Children, except perhaps for very small ones, ought to be intrigued by it; adults won't be bored. And no one of any age will be immune to the sentiment of the film's final moments, which really are unexpectedly touching and memorable."
This weekend, co-vocabularists of all faiths are invited to share their prayers.

The Times's Alan Schwarz outlines the difference in how the two Super Bowl teams, the Packers and Steelers, have dealt with head injuries. While Steelers like Hines Ward and James Harrison argue against new N.F.L. rules against hits to the head, the Packers' most memorable moment of the season came when receiver Donald Driver urged quarterback Aaron Rodgers to sit out of the game after a head injury.

Hey, you, art collector or philanthropist with a prominent space to fill in your museum or over your fireplace: how much would you pay for a painting whose contributors include Shepard Fairey, Andres Serrano and Frank Stella? Before you answer that, know this: it's a portrait of Stephen Colbert. The financial value (if not the artistic merit) of such a work will be determined on March 8 at an auction held by Phillips de Pury & Company, where a painting of the "Colbert Report" host will be sold, Comedy Central said on Friday.
12:35 p.m. | Updated For those who ahbor hockey violence, shield your tender eyes. For old-school types who love fights, Thursday's Bruins-Stars game had more than its share.

One of the most profound limitations of climate science arises from a simple fact. While humans have existed on this planet in more or less their present form for perhaps a quarter-million years, the historical record covers only a few thousand years, and the record of accurate weather and climate observations is much shorter than that.

Dear Sarah Palin: We are all Alaskans now. We live in New York, where 52 inches of great white stuff has come down week after week since December, freezing and melting in endless rounds of arctic folly. It has really been rough sledding, and some of us, cooped up overlong in candlelight, have gone crazy. We've concocted conspiracy theories, like: The gods must be angry because Mayor Mike bought himself extra innings, or they're punishing the Jets, or they can't stand the sight of another Sperry Topsider slip-on, and their nerd/cool appeal that is less "oxy" than "moron." Some of us even toyed with the idea of riding above the blackened mounds of snow - just like you - and mowing down anything clad in fur.

Somehow, Kirkland & Ellis has gotten off to a terrible start with the new United States Trustee in New York.

The United States added 36,000 jobs on net in January, the Labor Department said today. The growth was again disappointingly slow, but many economists are unsure how to interpret the latest number because January snowstorms most likely played a big role in depressing employment.

The makeup and effects designer Rick Baker received the first Oscar for makeup, in 1982, for "An American Werewolf in London." He's won five more since, for everything from "Ed Wood" to "Norbit." Mr. Baker also has a long history with wolf creatures; when he first started experimenting with makeup, the second mask he ever made was of a Wolfman. He was 10. (The first mask he made was Frankenstein. He still has a lot of these early efforts in his studio. "I'm a bit of a hoarder," he said.)

This weekend in the Book Review, Emma Donoghue reviews "Swamplandia!," the first novel by Karen Russell (author of the story collection "St. Lucy's Home for Girls Raised by Wolves"). Both Russell and Donoghue have written novels from the perspective of young narrators isolated from the wider world: in "Swamplandia!" the protagonist is a girl on the cusp of adolescence who lives in an alligator theme park; in Donoghue's "Room," one of the Book Review's 10 Best Books of 2010, the narrator is a 5-year-old boy raised in an 11-by-11-foot room.
Two Staten Island police officers are facing criminal charges after they were accused of writing fake traffic tickets.

John Lennon's 1965 Ferrari 330 GT, which was scheduled to be auctioned this weekend by Bonhams at the Grand Palais in Paris, has been withdrawn. "The vendor unfortunately decided at the last minute that he could not bear to part with it," wrote Leonora Oldfield, a Bonhams spokeswoman, in an e-mail on Friday.
Calling Friday a Day of Departure, protesters gathered by the hundreds of thousands in Cairo’s central Tahrir Square to call for the ouster of President Hosni Mubarak.

There is almost exactly one year to go until the Iowa caucuses, which are tentatively scheduled to take place on Feb. 6, 2012. No mainstream Republican candidate has yet declared for the presidency, but that is sure to change soon, perhaps as soon as there is a lull in the news - something we have not had in weeks, because of the Tucson shootings and the Egyptian protests.

3:29 p.m. | Updated With nearly every Super Bowl-related story line picked over endlessly in the two-week period since anyone played an actual football game -- the story buffet looks a bit like the grocery aisles the day before a blizzard -- we move on to wondering how an event so ostentatiously awash in money is also the stage for people explaining why the N.F.L. is on the verge of a lockout.

Ford is recalling about 291,000 of its F-150 pickups in the United States because the door might open in a side-impact crash, according to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. The affected model years are 2009-10.

A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

Gavyn Davies has a good post on core inflation, monetary policy, and all that. He summarizes nicely the thinking behind the Fed's belief that a one-time surge in commodity prices is not a reason to tighten. But I'm a bit surprised -- not so much about Davies as about the discussion in general -- at how little attention is given to the ECB's Mistake of 2008, which illustrates the trouble with focusing on headline inflation.
The volume of mergers and acquisitions surged 69 percent, to $309.6 billion worldwide in January from a year ago, Thomson Reuters data shows.

In this "Daily Show" segment that was technically shown late Thursday night, Jon Stewart and Justin Bieber went all "Freaky Friday" on us. The nightly news satire opened with its anchor's chair occupied by Mr. Bieber, the pint-size pop star, who seemed to be channeling Mr. Stewart - and who was then interrupted by a hoodie-clad Mr. Stewart, who appeared to have Mr. Bieber's spirit stuck in his body. With the aid of a magic skull, the two were quickly restored to their correct anatomies, which is too bad, because we really would have liked to have seen Mr. Bieber interview Adm. Mike Mullen, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, later in the show.

Kickstarter, the Web site that helps people raise money for their creative projects, from films to restaurants, has introduced a new feature: pages that have been "curated" by arts organizations, schools, media companies, and, in one case, a city.

It's been, what, two days without an award show this week? The Bagger is nearly going through withdrawal. (Telltale signs: donning a cocktail dress just to blog; introducing ourselves to our neighbor on the subway, and asking them to pass the rolls; clapping at random intervals when our editor speaks; appreciating actors just as much as possible, lest they feel starved for attention.) Luckily, some honorary awards have been announced to stave off our total self-congratulation meltdown.
6:43 p.m. | Updated

A student production of "Joe Turner's Come and Gone" that overcame the objections of a school superintendent in order to proceed has been temporarily halted by Mother Nature. The Waterbury Arts Magnet School in Waterbury, Conn., had planned to perform that August Wilson play on Thursday, Friday and Saturday of this week, but has postponed the performances following the heavy snowfalls that have recently hit the Northeast. Dana Manning, the school's fine arts coordinator, told The Republican-American newspaper of Waterbury that the bad weather had prevented rehearsals for the production. Additional performances planned for next week were also likely to be rescheduled and new dates for the play were not immediately announced.
CAIRO - It is a beautiful Friday morning in Cairo.

Anyone who ever said Harlem is dead forgot that dead doesn't mean a thing in Harlem. After all, the neighborhood is more alive in itself and its history than any other in New York, a city that has rebuilt itself so repeatedly and so relentlessly that it's a wonder the Hudson still knows where to go. But Harlem is the brain of New York; it is the deep memory of the city, where past and present are fused into something that looks like the future. Harlem has always been Harlem, and can't help it.
The investment firm Elliott Advisors is calling from some directors at Actelion, the Swiss biotech company, to step down because they had refused to consider takeover approaches.

After this morning's announcement that the United States economy added 36,000 jobs in January, two Times columnists -- David Leonhardt and Floyd Norris -- are continuing the discussion they began on Thursday about the employment situation and the prospects for the economy. Good morning. Alternate-side parking rules are suspended for the 15th straight day. Now it is cold. By afternoon it will be in the mid-30s. It will not snow. On Saturday, it will snow and then rain.

The "Pin Tab" feature of the Google Chrome browser neatly reduces page tabs down to just the site's icon - which can make it easier to switch between screens full of open sites. To shrink a tab down to its icon, right-click on it and choose Pin Tab. While this makes room for plenty of open tabs, it also hides the number of unread messages that is normally displayed on the full tab of an open Gmail page.

On Friday, The Lede continues to provide updates on the street protests in Egypt. For a summary of the latest developments, read the current version of our main news article from our colleagues in Cairo. Updates below mix alerts on breaking news with reports from bloggers and journalists posted on other news sites and social networks. A stream of Twitter updates on the protests is in this blog's right column. Readers can share information in the comment thread below or send photographs or video from Egypt to pix@nyt.com.

I attended a symposium last week at the University of Georgia on the Deepwater Horizon oil spill, with panelists (I was one) revisiting many of the issues that came up during that disaster last summer. As I chatted him up, one of the scientists in attendance, Ian MacDonald, pointed me toward a recent article of his that tries again to get at one of the central mysteries of the spill.

The Dallas metro area's public-transportation infrastructure would never be mistaken for Copenhagen's. Consequently, ticketholders for this Sunday's Super Bowl XLV will arrive at Cowboys Stadium in Arlington, Tex., almost exclusively by car. With 100,000 game tickets sold, the City of Arlington has partnered with ParkWhiz.com, an online parking-reservation service, to not only secure nontraditional parking spaces to handle the remarkable volume, but to guarantee drivers a space on game day.
Can you imagine attending a big-time sporting event at a large stadium and actually being able to see the game from the comfort of that expensive seat you bought?
Emilio Botín, chairman of Banco Santander, said that he planned to list the lender's British unit in the second half of the year, as he announced the bank's results on Thursday.

A London institution is getting a makeover. Since 1932 the crossroads of Oxford and Regent Streets has been home to the headquarters for the BBC in a 12-story building known as Broadcasting House. From here, countless historical moments have gone out over the airwaves and been heard around the world, from performances by Vivian Leigh to the world's longest running soap opera, "The Archers." But although the building will soon go through a transformation, visitors can still take a tour of the historic spot.

Today on A Year at War, our series about a battalion's yearlong deployment to Afghanistan, we have updates on three more soldiers. All are noncommissioned officers -- men who came into the Army as privates without a college degree and worked their way up to leadership roles. They have all been deployed previously, to Iraq or Afghanistan or both. They all figured they knew more or less what to expect this time.
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's job rating took a major hit in the aftermath of the post-Christmas blizzard, but he is starting to recover, according to a new poll released Thursday night.

This morning I decide to try a little experiment: I opened up my iPad, clicked on the little Wired icon and purchased the magazine's latest digital issue. After I agreed to fork over $4, it began downloading. For the next phase of the experiment, I grabbed my car keys, left my apartment and drove about 12 blocks to a local magazine store in Brooklyn,  where I also purchased the latest issue of Wired magazine, this time in print.

New research shows why teenagers often make bad decisions when their friends are with them or watching them. Are you aware of being influenced by peer pressure? Do you take greater risks - like driving faster and less carefully - when you are with your friends?

Ed Sabol is one of the modern-era finalists who will be considered by the selection committee for election into the Hall of Fame on Saturday. Andy Barall writes about pro football history for The Fifth Down.

Total scandal on "American Idol" Thursday night: GB5 is breaking up! Aaron and Mark, two of the five Gutierrez brothers that make up the group, got it in their heads that chasing the "Idol" dream was compelling enough to break off from the family flock. Oh, the horror.

The AXA Rosenberg Group, a pioneer in the field of quantitative investing, and two affiliated companies agreed to pay more than $240 million to settle charges that they misled customers after discovering an error in the computer code the companies used to manage client assets, Edward Wyatt reports in The New York Times.

AZZARETTI--Ellen G. (nee Holliday), of Brewster, NY passed away on January 24, 2011. She was 58 years old. Ellen was born in Manhattan to Robert and Florence (Ogostalick) Holliday. Ellen and her husband Charles, both dentists, practiced together in Mount Kisco. She is survived by her husband Charles, two sons Lawrence and Gregory, a daughter-in-law Lindsey, two brothers Robert and Joseph Holliday and her mother Florence Holliday of Mount Kisco. She was predeceased by her father Dr. Robert W. Holliday. Ellen attended Mount Holyoke College and received her DDS and MPH from Columbia Univ. Her smile, kindness and tender words will be deeply missed. A Memorial Service will be held at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church, 26 Prospect St., Brewster, NY on Saturday, February 5, 2011 at 2pm.

Sarah Palin has declined an invitation to join leading Republicans at the next Conservative Political Action Conference, a major gathering of party activists with an influential voice in the Republican presidential nominating contest. Ms. Palin, the former Alaska governor, was the last prominent Republican who had yet to confirm her attendance, and some of her supporters had held out hope that she would agree to deliver a speech at the three-day forum, which starts next Thursday in Washington. But organizers of the event confirmed Thursday that she would not attend -- the third year in a row that she has opted out of the conference, attended by thousands of conservative activists.

HUTCHINS--Carol F.,died at home February 1, 2011, after a courageous battle with cancer. Born November 24, 1932, in New York City, eldest daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Leo C. Fennelly. Devoted wife of Waldo Hutchins III, beloved mother of John Devendorf, Andree Welsh, and Marcia Morrell; loving stepmother to John, Fred, Elizabeth and Anne. Cherished sister of Marcia Gowen, dear aunt to Cynthia Crawford and Lee Marine. "Gagi" was absolutely adored by her nine grandchildren, grandnephew and three grandnieces. Carol was an active member of the Creek Club and the Colony Club. She was a dedicated member of the North Country Garden Club of Long Island, where she chaired numerous committees, including Garden History and Design. Last September Carol was awarded the Club Medal of Merit from the Garden Club of America for her many years of distinguished service. She will be terribly missed by her family and many friends, but the love she gave will be in our hearts forever. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday, February 5 at 10:30am, St. Dominic's Chapel, Oyster Bay. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the National Trust for Historic Preservation, 1785 Mass. Ave. NW, Washington, D.C. 20036.

Two of Japan's largest steel makers said on Thursday that they were in talks to merge, a move that would form the world's second-largest producer of steel after ArcelorMittal. Nippon Steel, Japan's largest steel producer, and Sumitomo Metal Industries, the country's third largest, are in talks to merge by October 2012, the two companies said in a statement. At their closing stock prices Thursday, they would have a combined market capitalization of 2.88 trillion yen, $35 billion, compared to $57 billion for ArcelorMittal.

MINING MERGER Newmont Mining, the biggest gold producer in the United States, said on Thursday that it had agreed to acquire Fronteer Gold of Vancouver, British Columbia, in a deal valued at more than $2 billion. The acquisition will enable Newmont to expand its mining operations in Nevada. Fronteer is developing a gold mine about 100 miles from Newmont's operations in that state.

Chinese Lunar New Year Celebrations (Saturday and Sunday) The rabbit may be the headliner, but other animals will have featured roles this weekend in celebrations of the Year of the Rabbit (Year 4708 in the Chinese calendar). The Wolf co-stars with Little Red Riding Hood in the Chinese Theater Works production of ''Little Red Riding Hood: The Chinese Opera,'' above, on Saturday at 3 and 7 p.m. at the Metropolitan Museum of Art; other festivities from 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. will include a lion dance, arts workshops and a tea ceremony. Show tickets are $15 and $30; other activities are included in suggested museum admission: $20; $15 for 65+; $10 for students; free for children under 12; metmuseum.org/lunarnewyear.aspx. Dragon puppets will mingle with revelers, many in animal costumes, at the 12th Chinatown Lunar New Year Parade & Festival on Sunday; the parade begins at 1 p.m. at Hester and Mott Streets and ends at a festival in Sara D. Roosevelt Park, Grand and Forsythe Streets, Lower East Side; betterchinatown.com. Other events include entertainment and fashion on Saturday at 7 p.m. at the Chinese Community Center Auditorium, 62 Mott Street, Chinatown ($15, or $10 in advance; asianinny.com.); and a tour of Chinatown on Saturday at 1 p.m., leaving from the Museum of Chinese in America, 215 Centre Street, near Howard Street ($18; $15 for students and 65+; $8 for members; free for under 5; reservations required: 212-619-4785). Gong Xi Fa Cai! Happy New Year! (Anne Mancuso)

JACOBSON--Frank The Alpert, Roizen and Rodbell families, along with the employees of Spartan Petroleum Corp., mourn the loss of our friend, mentor and advisor, Frank Jacobson. Our prayers and condolences go out to the extended Jacobson family.

Readers are often warned not to judge a book by its cover, but what about its publicity? That is the basis of a class-action lawsuit against former President Jimmy Carter and his publisher Simon & Schuster over his 2006 book ''Palestine: Peace, Not Apartheid,'' which was filed in Manhattan federal court on Tuesday. David Schoen, a Montgomery, Ala., attorney who filed the suit, said by telephone that the book was falsely marketed as an accurate account of peace negotiations in the Middle East. ''You cannot market it as the absolute truth on something when it's not,'' Mr. Schoen said, citing as examples criticisms of the account by the United States diplomat Dennis Ross and Kenneth W. Stein, a Carter adviser who resigned from the Carter Center after calling the book ''replete with factual errors.'' The book became a target of criticism from the moment it was published because of the use of the word ''apartheid'' in the title. Mr. Schoen said the pro-Israeli group Committee for Accuracy in Middle East Reporting in America formally asked the publisher to make corrections, but was rebuffed.

Detwiler, a former public relations executive, four children -- Anne D. Crecraft of Sterling, VA.; Richard M. Detwiler, Jr. of Bronxville, NY; John B. Detwiler of Charlotte, NC and William S. Detwiler III of Brooklyn, NY and eight grandchildren. A funeral Mass will be held at St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church, 84 Sherwood Ave., Greenwich, CT. on Saturday, February 5 at 10am.

Let other museums have their Picassos and Monets; when the National Children's Museum opens in Prince George's County, Md., in 2013, the big names in the galleries will be Cookie Monster, Elmo, and Oscar the Grouch. On Thursday, the museum announced a partnership with Sesame Workshop, the nonprofit organization behind Sesame Street, in which the workshop will help the museum develop programming for young children, and Sesame Street characters will be woven into the exhibits. The National Children's Museum, which was formerly called the Capital Children's Museum, was located until 2004 in northwest Washington. It will break ground on its new building in Maryland, designed by the architecture firm Pelli Clarke Pelli, later this year. In a phone interview, the museum president and CEO, Kathy Dwyer Southern, described its mission as ''to inspire kids to care about and improve the world'' and called the partnership with Sesame Workshop ''very, very exciting for us.'' The workshop's president and CEO, Gary Knell, said that the workshop had long wanted a permanent museum home. And while there is no money changing hands, Mr. Knell said he hoped that the partnership would help the museum reach its $182 million fundraising goal. ''Having Elmo and Big Bird as part of the museum now in a public way we hope will help them get to the finish line faster that they might have otherwise,'' he said.

HONG KONG - Nearly 25 years after the fictional financier Gordon Gekko declared in ''Wall Street'' that ''lunch is for wimps,'' Asia's leading stock exchanges seem to have gotten the memo. With investors' attention focused on the fast-growing markets, the region's main financial hubs are jockeying for dominance with a host of new efforts intended to increase their competitiveness on a global scale. As they move to gain share, local exchanges are upgrading their infrastructure, expanding their operations and even throwing out longstanding traditions like lengthy lunch breaks.

Mick Jagger will perform at the Grammy Awards on Feb. 13, his first-ever solo performance at the show. He will be paying tribute to his hero Solomon Burke, who died in October, as part of the ceremony's ''In Memoriam'' segment, the Recording Academy announced. Other performers already scheduled for the show, which will be broadcast live on CBS: Eminem, Lady Gaga, Arcade Fire, Justin Bieber and Usher, Katy Perry, and the very intriguing combination of Cee Lo Green with Gwyneth Paltrow and the Jim Henson Company Puppets. Mr. Jagger's appearance will likely stir further speculation about whether the Rolling Stones will go on tour later this year or next. The music industry has been abuzz for months with rumors about a possible tour, which have been stoked by a legal dispute between two potential promoters, Live Nation and Michael Cohl, the former Live Nation executive (and current lead producer of the Broadway musical ''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark'') who has been a longtime promoter of the band's tours. Late last year Live Nation sued Mr. Cohl over an agreement that allowed him to work with the Stones, and this week The Hollywood Reporter said that Mr. Cohl had countersued, asserting his rights for a tour timed to the band's 50th anniversary. (It was founded in 1962.)

TOLAN--Michael, passed away January 31, 2011, at age 85 at Columbia Memorial Hospital, Hudson, NY after a courageous battle with multiple illnesses. A man of great integrity and intelligence who excelled in a memorable career that spanned radio, theatre, movies, television as well as live poetry readings. Born Seymour Tuchow in Detroit, MI, graduated from Wayne University, had an acting Fellowship at Stanford University and was put under contract by Warner Brothers Studio. While at Wayne in the 1940's Tolan's deep sonorous voice was heard originating live on Radio Station WXYZ from Detroit in "The Lone Ranger" and "The Green Hornet". He made his debut at age 24 in "The Enforcer". Other movie credits include "The Greatest Story Ever Told", "Julius Caesar", "John and Mary", "All That Jazz", Presumed Innocent" and "The Perfect Stranger". He co-produced "Five On The Black-Hand Side", a non-violent movie about an Afro-American family in Harlem. Broadway roles included "Will Success Spoil Rock Hunter?", "A Hatful of Rain", Romanoff & Juliet" and A Far Country". Tolan starred in the TV series "The Nurses" as Dr. Tazinski and in "The Senator". He had guest roles on "The Mary Tyler Moore Show" and "Murder She Wrote", dramatic roles in plays produced for the "US Steel Hour" and "The Dupont Show of the Week". Michael was co-founder of The American Place Theater and The Apple Core Theater, an inter-racial repertory group. Michael is survived by his partner Donna Peck (of Copake, New York), three daughters, Alexandra Tolan, Jenny Tolan and Emily Tolan, a brother Gerald Tuchow, and sister-in-law, Marilyn Tuchow of Bloomfield Hills, MI. A Celebration of Michael's life will be held at The Lotos Club, 5 East 66th St., New York, 10065 at 5pm. Donations in Michael's memory may be made to The Lotos Club Foundation.

PLATT--Martin, MD, FAAP, of Cairo, Egypt. Born 9 May 1938 to Dr. Abe and Laura Kinberg Platt of St. Louis, MO, he attended Washington University (B.A., 1960; M.D., 1964), was chief resident of Pediatrics, Maimonides Med Ctr (1968-69), and served as a lieutenant, US Navy (1966-68). Devoted pediatrician in private practice for 30 years in Westchester Co., NY. Retired to Cairo and died at home, 27 January 2011. Survived by his loving children Reina, Thomas, Alec; and grandchildren Asa, Jasper, Esme, Silas.

Intent on fixing a banking system that contributed heavily to the recent financial crisis, lawmakers and regulators pushed Wall Street to overhaul its pay practices. Mechanics of legislating should be simple: Bring a bill to the floor, fight over amendments, vote the measure up or down and move on to the next one. But in the Senate, that approach had been largely replaced by partisan procedural brawls, writes Carl Hulse in his On The Hill column, "Meant to Be Broken? Maybe Not This Time." Now, though, there appears to be growing support for going back to those civics-book basics.

In a provocative article in the latest issue of Inc. magazine, Max Chafkin takes a look at the relationship between taxes and entrepreneurship. For the piece, Mr. Chafkin spent two weeks in Norway, which ranks higher than the United States in effective income tax rates and has a 1.1 percent wealth tax -- but also has more entrepreneurs per capita and higher rates of start-up creation. The case of Norway, Mr. Chafkin writes, should give us pause: "What if we have been wrong about taxes?"

DALLAS - Curtis Martin's career with New England and the Jets was much like the man himself: understated, consistent, workmanlike. Only Martin and Barry Sanders topped 1,000 rushing yards in each of their first 10 seasons. Only Emmitt Smith, Walter Payton and Sanders gained more rushing yards than Martin's 14,101. Yet Martin is no lock to make the Hall of Fame on Saturday. The field includes first-year eligible players in Deion Sanders, Marshall Faulk, Jerome Bettis and Willie Roaf, along with a host of holdovers, all considered for up to five modern-day slots.

Black.

Tyson Foods, the meat processor, reported a profit for the first fiscal quarter on Friday that beat analysts' estimates as the company reduced costs in the chicken unit and the price of pork rose. Net income increased 86 percent, to $298 million, or 78 cents a share, from $160 million, or 42 cents a share, a year earlier, Tyson said. Earnings excluding a 3-cent-a-share gain from the sale of interests in an investment were 75 cents a share. The average estimate of analysts in a Bloomberg survey was a profit of 62 cents.

Clowns everywhere can breathe easier: Jeff Koons's lawyers have backed down in an intellectual property dispute over balloon dog-shaped bookends. In December, Peter D. Vogl of the firm Jones Day, which represents Jeff Koons LLC, sent a cease-and-desist letter to Imm-Living, the Toronto company that manufactures the bookends, and Park Life, a San Francisco gallery that sells them, arguing that they violated Mr. Koons's intellectual property rights. Mr. Koons is well-known for his stainless-steel versions of the canines. Bloggers largely scoffed at the threat, but Park Life decided not to just sit around and see if Mr. Koons would sue. On January 20, its lawyer, Jedediah Wakefield of Fenwick and West, working pro bono, sued Jeff Koons LLC in San Francisco federal court, asking the court to declare that Park Life wasn't infringing on Mr. Koons's i rights. ''They very quickly indicated they weren't interested in putting up a fight,'' Mr. Wakefield said of Mr. Koons's lawyers. Ultimately, Jeff Koons LLC agreed not to pursue the gallery for the sale of the bookends, and the gallery agreed not to indicate that the bookends were by Mr. Koons, which, Mr. Wakefield added, ''they hadn't done and weren't going to do anyway.'' As a result of the deal, he said, he was planning to file on Thursday for a dismissal of the declaratory judgment suit.

The imam who was named three weeks ago to lead religious services at the proposed Muslim community center and mosque near ground zero said Friday that he was stepping down. The move is the latest in a string of public relations setbacks for the project. The imam, Sheik Abdallah Adhami, who stirred controversy shortly after his appointment by telling a reporter for NY1 News that most homosexual behavior was linked to early childhood abuse, said in a statement that he was giving up his role in the project, known as Park51, to devote more time to completing a book.

Even the most disciplined savers are heavily relying on the stock market to reach their retirement goals. But that often amounts to a giant gamble, which is the thrust of the thinking behind a new retirement planning program that treats investing in stocks like a trip to the casino. In this program, however, you lose every single bet you make. In other words, if you invest 60 percent of your contributions to retirement savings in stocks each year, that money is treated as if it were lost on the craps tables. But the program also shows the chances that all will not be lost.

Hey, you, art collector or philanthropist with a prominent space to fill in your museum or over your fireplace: how much would you pay for a painting whose contributors include Shepard Fairey, Andres Serrano and Frank Stella? Before you answer that, know this: it's a portrait of Stephen Colbert. The financial value (if not the artistic merit) of such a work will be determined on March 8 at an auction held by Phillips de Pury & Company, where a painting of the ''Colbert Report'' host will be sold, Comedy Central said on Friday. The painting, ''Portrait 5, Stephen(s)'' and attributed to Mr. Colbert, reached its completed state in an episode of the ''Colbert Report'' shown in December. During a discussion of art with Steve Martin, the author and aesthete, Mr. Colbert asked Mr. Martin how much he would pay for the work. Unimpressed or unsatisfied with Mr. Martin's assessment, Mr. Colbert invited in Mr. Fairey, who stenciled the word ''obey'' onto the painting; Mr. Serrano, who drew a mustache on it; and Mr. Stella, who looked at it.

A chart on Friday with an article about shifts in population in New Jersey reversed the legends for increases and decreases. The purple circles indicated areas where the population increased and the yellow ones showed areas where it decreased.

9 P.M. (Showtime) A SINGLE MAN (2009) Colin Firth, in the first of his Oscar-nominated roles (he's currently favored to win for best actor for ''The King's Speech''), plays George, a middle-aged professor in 1962 Los Angeles who, in one emotion-filled day, prepares to commit suicide after the death of his longtime lover, Jim (Matthew Goode). Nicholas Hoult is the flirty student and Jon Kortajarena the charming hustler who cross George's path; Julianne Moore (above with Mr. Firth) is Charley, the close friend who wishes she and George could be more. Reviewing this directorial debut from Tom Ford, the former creative director of Gucci, following the outline of the 1964 novel by Christopher Isherwood, Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times: ''That Mr. Ford has placed so much weight on Mr. Firth suggests that he knows how valuable his actor is to his first effort. And while 'A Single Man' has its flaws, many of these fade in view of the performance and the power of Isherwood's story. Part of the radical importance of Isherwood's novel is its insistence on the absolute ordinariness of George's life, including with Jim, whose relationship together is pictured only briefly in both the novel and the film, and yet reverberates deeply (then as now). Mr. Ford's single man might be less common than Isherwood's, a bit too exquisitely dressed. But with Mr. Firth, Mr. Ford has created a gay man troubled by ordinary grief and haunted by joy, a man apart and yet like any other.'' 10:30 A.M. (13) RELIGION & ETHICS NEWSWEEKLY Bob Faw examines the use of costly miracle drugs to prolong life in terminally ill patients and asks, ''How much is it worth to live a little longer, and who should pay for it?'' Fred de Sam Lazaro reports on a micro-lending program in Pakistan that has provided the equivalent of $200 million to 300,000 mostly poor women to start their own businesses, complying with strict Islamic rules on money lending while avoiding the abuses that crippled the micro-lending program in India. And Bob Abernethy interviews Qamar-ul Huda, a scholar of Islam and senior program officer at the United States Institute of Peace, about the role Islamists may play in a transitioning Egyptian government.

GREENWALD--Harry, died at Westchester Medical Center on February 1, 2011. He was born on July 18, 1924 in Waldgirmes, Germany as Heinz Gruenewald. He emigrated to the United States in 1936 and lived in Washington Heights. He served his country with distinction as a staff sergeant in the US Army during World War II in combat at Guadalcanal, New Guinea, the Solomon Islands, and in the Philippines. He operated a business, in partnership, Majestic Market in the northeast Bronx for 38 years. He lived in the Kingsbridge section of the Bronx, Valley Cottage, and in Peekskill, NY. He is survived by his wife of 62 years, Ilse Stern-Greenwald. His sons Howard and Jeffrey, his daughters in law Michelle and Ilene and his grandchildren Joshua, Elisa, Brandon, and Joseph. The Greenwald family mourns the loss of its patriarch, and his strength, wisdom, guidance, and love. Harry Greenwald was above all an American. He epitomized the traditional values of his country. God, country, and family were the foundations of his ethos. He believed in working hard to obtain his goals and he worked to provide sustenance to his family. He was a loving husband, father, and grandfather. He instilled the importance of family, and was always there for anyone friend or family who needed him. We mourn the irreplaceable loss of his fortitude sagacity, and love. May he rest in peace. The family will gather for observance of Shiva at 281 Carroll Close, Tarrytown, NY 10591 from February 3, 2011 to February 10, 2011.

Updated 8:41 p.m. | The New York Observer on Friday replaced its editor after barely a year on the job, bringing in a new leader whose experience is not in newspapers but in the blogosphere that has eaten away at The Observer's exclusivity. Elizabeth Spiers, one of the first editors at Gawker, was named the new editor effective immediately. She replaces Kyle Pope, who joined the paper after working in the ink-on-paper world of Conde Nast and The Wall Street Journal.

To help readers better protect themselves from thieves who want to swipe their sensitive debit card information, we've shared pictures in the past of how to spot skimming devices on A.T.M.'s. Skimmers applied to card readers (think fake card readers on top of the real ones) are designed to capture debit card magnetic stripe data, while tiny wireless cameras or overlays to existing personal identification number pads are designed to capture PIN information. Once thieves capture such data, they can use it to make fake cards or sell the information on the Internet to others.

LANGLEY--Susan, age 63 passed away peacefully on January 31, 2011, after a long illness. She is preceded in death by her parents, John and Dorothy of Brighton-Sussex UK and her beloved companion, Dominic Annechiarico. Susan leaves behind many devoted friends who will mourn the loss of her unique charm, wit and love of life. She arrived on these shores in 1968 and began her long distinguished career at CBS and Sony Music from which she retired as Director Of Human Relations. Susan will be honored at a Memorial service 11am on February 12, 2011 at the Park Avenue United Methodist Church 106 East 86 In lieu of flowers, please make donations to Park Avenue United Methodist Women.

An article on Friday about plans by the New York Fire Department to replace its new fire-retardant gloves gave an incorrect name for a tool cited as one the department had also been a leader in developing. It is a Halligan, a crowbar-like device used by firefighters to pry open locked doors; it is not a ''halogen tool.''

Kickstarter, the Web site that helps people raise money for their creative projects, from films to restaurants, has introduced a new feature: pages that have been ''curated'' by arts organizations, schools, media companies, and, in one case, a city. Some pages - like those for Pitchfork, Creative Commons, Rhizome (an organization dedicated to new media art), and the city of Portland, Ore. - simply highlight the projects that they want to support. Other pages, including those for the Rhode Island School of Design, the School of Visual Arts and the Interactive Telecommunications Program at New York University, feature projects by students who are looking for financing. The projects promoted by such groups as Kill Screen (a video game arts and culture company) and the Brooklyn Flea range from a baking company raising money in order to open a new store to a law student designing a video game that takes place ''on an exotic alien world, complete with rocket boots and rocket gloves.''

MASSAR--Phyllis Dearborn passed away January 8, 2011 at the age of 94. Originally from Seattle, she was educated in the Liberal Arts at the University of Washington and graduated in 1937. In New York City she studied photography at the Clarence H. White School of Photography and through a series of courses taught by Ansel Adams at the Museum of Modern Art. Her photographs were recognized for a sense of balance and exactness in their composition. The photographs of architectural works in the Pacific Northwest made from 1943-1963 with her husband, the late Robert Massar, are archived under the professional name of Dearborn-Massar in the UW Libraries, Special Collections Division. She traveled in Italy with her 4x5 camera on commissions to chronicle the architecture of Andrea Palladio and of Filippo Brunelleschi. In the 1970's she curated several photographic exhibits and print exhibits at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. As an art historian she was author of many articles and monographs as well as the book "Presenting Stefano Della Bella." A museum volunteer since 1966, Phyllis was an ardent print researcher with precise cataloging skills, an encyclopedic knowledge of art history and a true dedication to scholarship. Remembrances in her name may be made to the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Department of Drawings and Prints.

BOURDETTE--Dorothy N.,passed away on February 2, 2011. Devoted wife of the late Leonard C. Bourdette, loving mother of Claudia, Eric and Carol Bourdette. Dorothy had a joy for life. Her wit and wisdom delighted us. Her eloquence and grace defined her. Dorothy was a gentle soul who loved nature and all creatures great and small. She was loving and caring to all. Dorothy will be dearly missed. We are grateful that she is at peace and with her beloved husband, Leonard.

House Republicans are hoping to push back debate on three expiring provisions of the law that expanded the F.B.I.'s counterterrorism powers after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001. On Friday, the House of Representatives scheduled a vote for next week on legislation that would extend the provisions of the law, the USA Patriot Act, without modification until Dec. 8, instead of letting them expire at the end of this month. The move is designed to give the House Judiciary Committee, now under Republican management, time to hold hearings on the law, according to an aide to the committee's new chairman, Representative Lamar Smith of Texas.

Riccardo Muti, the Italian maestro and music director of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, will have surgery to repair ''multiple facial and jaw fractures'' suffered when he collapsed on the podium during a rehearsal on Thursday and fell to the stage, the orchestra said on Friday. Doctors were still conducting tests to figure out what caused him to collapse, according to a statement by Deborah Rutter, the orchestra's president. The operation will take place on Monday at Northwestern Memorial Hospital, she said, describing Mr. Muti as being in ''good spirits.'' A member of the orchestra said Mr. Muti, 69, appeared in fine condition during the rehearsal on Thursday morning. ''He was his normal jovial self,'' the musician said, until a moment in the third movement of the Shostakovich Symphony No. 5, when he pitched forward off the podium. ''He didn't put his hands out to break his fall or anything,'' said the player, who spoke on condition of anonymity because management had urged discretion.

An article on Tuesday about Feisal Abdul Rauf, an imam who was one of the founders of the Islamic center planned for Lower Manhattan, referred incorrectly to Abdallah Adhami, who was to take up Mr. Abdul Rauf's role in leading services in a temporary space at the project site. Mr. Adhami is not affiliated with any downtown mosque.

CHORLEY, England -- The practice session began as it would for most soccer players across England, with a juggling drill. In a small circle, they kept the ball in the air, passing it to one another. For Bolton Wanderers, an English Premier League team, there was a playfully cruel twist to the game: the first man to let the ball touch the ground would have his ears flicked by every member of the team. Some of the flicks were so loud they could be heard across the field.

In the last few years, Mumbai has witnessed something of a culinary explosion. In 2010, two internationally acclaimed chefs -- Ian Kittichai, who is Thai, and Vineet Bhatia, an Indian -- brought their considerable talents to the city. This year, two prominent global restaurant brands, Megu and Hakkasan, will open outposts here. But most of the city's gourmands will tell you that fine dining options in Mumbai are still woefully inadequate. Mumbai's population hovers somewhere around 14 million, but there are perhaps no more than 40 high-end restaurants in the city.

BLUMBERG--Doris Gaines, 85, died peacefully in Longwood, FL on January 26, 2011. Predeceased by her husband, Kurt Blumberg, Do leaves a legacy of love, music, rhyme, kindness, wit, and laughter to her children, Charles and Ann, their spouses Norma and Stephen, step-grandchildren, Lillian, Emily, and Caroline, and all who knew her. A Memorial is planned for Spring in New York. Donations in Do's memory will be gratefully received by the Neuro Challenge Foundation, Sarasota, FL

Fullback John Kuhn is the only active member of the Green Bay Packers with a Super Bowl ring, which he earned during the 2005 season as a member of Pittsburgh's practice squad. Kuhn, 28, was on the Steelers' active roster for nine games in 2006, Bill Cowher's final season as coach. He landed in Green Bay after being cut during Mike Tomlin's first Pittsburgh training camp in 2007. Kuhn, who grew up in York, Pa., and played at Division II Shippensburg University, had a career-high six touchdowns, four rushing and two receiving, this season.Q.You watched the 2010 Super Bowl with sailors inside a nuclear-powered supercarrier off the coast of California. Which is more claustrophobic, the football line of scrimmage or a nuclear supercarrier?A.It's pretty tight quarters. They deserve their just due. They do an incredible job with their everyday life. They go out sometimes for six months at a time, and they go through that whole experience right there, and they are happy to do it. They have great morale while they are out there, and we're very proud of them.Q.Have any of your teammates seen your Super Bowl ring?A.I don't think I've shown it to anyone on this team. We are so focused on trying to win one ourselves that we're not going to get caught up in anything that's happened before or anything like that.Q.Why not use your ring as a motivational prop?A.To me, it is just as much motivation kept away as it is to bring it out. I don't really need to get it out. It's still something that I treasure and really look to sometimes as, Wow, that was a great time in my life. It's something that I want to earn on the field. And I got that one on the practice squad - which is a great accomplishment - but I want to earn one and play a part in the one that we're trying to win this year.Q.What do you make of getting back to the Super Bowl and having your opponent be the team with whom you made your first trip?A.It's pretty funny and fitting even, that I would get the opportunity to play against them in the Super Bowl, and I am very happy for that. But it would not have mattered. It could have been any team in the A.F.C. and we'd have the same focus and determination that we do in this game.

Can you imagine attending a big-time sporting event at a large stadium and actually being able to see the game from the comfort of that expensive seat you bought? Not long ago, I ventured to New Meadowlands Stadium to see the New York Giants battle the Washington Redskins. What I saw instead was the hundreds of fans in the rows in front of me who constantly rose from their seats at the slightest incitement.

To the Sports Editor: Courage, excellence, persistence, justice, teamwork, commitment, citizenship, determination and integrity. Those are the nine words featured on the walls of the Jackie Robinson Rotunda, the first thing you see when you enter the Mets' stadium, Citi Field. What a pity that Fred Wilpon has made such a mockery of these principles that personified Robinson, and so many of us hold dear.

L IKE most fairy tales, the writer Camilla Morton's begins with the words ''once upon a time,'' but then it takes a very fashionable twist. ''Christian Lacroix and the Tale of Sleeping Beauty'' (It Books, $21.99), the first in her series of fantasy designer biographies, tells the story of Beauty, a starry-eyed princess condemned to wearing bland sack dresses, and stars Mr. Lacroix as the gallant prince who creates for her the dress she has always deserved, as well as the court's entire new ensemble. ''It all started when I was trying to explain my job to my godson,'' Ms. Morton said, about writing a fairy tale. ''And I realized when you watch a couture show come together -- the drama, the glamour -- you literally see magic.'' Mr. Lacroix was recently forced to close his couture business, but here, at least, he gets a happy ending. Next up: ''Manolo Blahnik and the Tale of the Elves and the Shoemaker.'' CHELSEA ZALOPANY

Best Western has announced that this week it is designating two upscale tiers under its brand. In addition to Best Western, travelers now will be able to reserve rooms in Best Western Plus and Best Western Premier. ''This is a major change,'' said Dorothy Dowling, senior vice president of marketing and sales for Best Western International. With more than 2,200 North American properties in diverse locations - from seaside resorts to highway roadsides - and ranging in price from $59 to $500 a night, Best Western found that its customers did not know what level of lodging to expect, Ms. Dowling said.

If the gray days of winter are dragging you down, why not wear the most colorful clothes in your wardrobe? On the Park Avenue mall, 25-foot roses, the work of Will Ryman, are blooming in the snow, lending cheer to swank. Among the eye-catchers in a city of basic black are shearling coats jazzed up with paint (bottom row), rainbow-colored fake fur scarves and pink gloves, blanket coats, a dog with blue points and women in shades of tea rose. Orange becomes both men's trousers and a Lamborghini parked next to a snowbank on Fifth Avenue.

THE first collection of Helmut Lang bags since Nicole and Michael Colovos took over as the label's creative directors is about to hit the stores. Styles range from duffels and messengers to clutches and pouchettes -- just the right complement to their tough -yet-polished motorcycle-jacket-and-skinny-leather-pants aesthetic. The Syn (above), a half-clutch/half-shoulder bag, blends Mr. Colovos's past as a commercial fisherman (straps have fisherman knots and braids) with Mrs. Colovos's penchant for utilitarian dressing. ''We wanted to create something sculptural, in an interesting fabrication, yet keep it functional,'' Mrs. Colovos said. The Syn, $350 to $495, is available at Barneys New York. CHELSEA ZALOPANY

KARSAN, the Turkish company whose taxi is one of three finalists in New York's Taxi of Tomorrow competition, showed off the first prototype of its body at a press event in Manhattan on Wednesday. As early as 2013, there will be a single taxi design, and it will carry the designation for 10 years. The Karsan V1 is competing with the Ford Transit Connect and Nissan NV, although the Taxi and Limousine Commission has said it may not choose any of the three.

An article last Sunday about the photographer and filmmaker Yann Arthus-Bertrand erroneously attributed a distinction to his book ''Earth From Above'' (Éditions de la Martinière), which came out in 1999. Mr. Arthus-Bertrand has published many books since ''Lions'' (Éditions Hachette), in 1983; ''Earth From Above'' was not his first.

TRAINA--John A.,Jr., (September 26, 1931 February 1, 2011) passed away last Tuesday in San Francisco. Beloved father and grandfather, notable society figure, entrepreneur, civic leader and San Francisco legend, John Traina attended Grant School, Lowell High School, graduated from Stanford University '53, and served in the U.S. Army in the Pacific. He enjoyed a long and respected career in shipping (American President Lines, Grace Lines, Prudential Lines, Delta Lines) and was among the first to start cruises into China. Traina engaged in numerous pursuits, with vineyards in the Napa Valley, was the author of two books ("Extraordinary Jewels" and "The Faberge' Case"), was a world traveler and famous collector of important objects. He had the largest collection of Faberge' cigarette boxes exhibited in museums around the world. Interested in everything, engaged in many endeavors, beloved by all, Traina had a passion for exotic travel, lived in Washington, D.C. in the 1960's, and loved his homes in San Francisco and the Napa Valley. He was extremely elegant, known for his impeccable style and limitless charm, he added glamour and sophistication to the San Francisco social scene for his entire life. He is survived by three sons, Trevor, Todd and Maxx, and four daughters, Samantha, Victoria, Vanessa, and Zara, and was the father of the late Nick Traina. He was the stepfather of Beatrix Lazard Seidenberg. And he was the grandfather of Johnny and Delphina Traina, Daisy Traina, and Sebastian and Isabel Seidenberg. He is also survived by two ex-wives Diane "Dede" Buchanan Wilsey, and Danielle Steel. He was married to each for 17 years. He is also survived by a sister, Marisa Traina Hahn, three nephews and a niece. Funeral services will be held privately. A memorial service will be held at The Maritime Museum, 900 Beach Street, San Francisco, 94109, on Friday, 11 February, at 2:00pm. The family requests that memorials be contributions to the California Historical Society, 678 Mission Street, San Francisco, 94105, or The Nick Traina Foundation, P.O. Box 470427, San Francisco, 94147.

SLIFKA--Alan B.,a prominent New York investment manager and philanthropist died on Friday, February 4, 2011 at home after a battle with cancer. Mr. Slifka is survived by his beloved wife Riva Ariella Ritvo-Slifka, his sister Barbara Slifka, his children, Michael, Randolph (Jan), and David (Michele) Slifka, his stepchildren Torrie, Skye and Max Ritvo and his grandchildren Grace Gill, Joshua Slifka and Braylan Ritvo. Born in New York City in 1929, Mr. Slifka graduated from the Fieldston School, received his B.S. from Yale in 1951, and his M.B.A. from Harvard in 1953. In 2003, he received an honorary Doctorate from Brandeis University and also in 2008 Mr. Slifka received an Honorary Doctorate in the field of Coexistence from Haifa University. Mr. Slifka was the founder and co-chairman of Halcyon Asset Management LLC. He was also the founding chairman of the Big Apple Circus which became an institution in New York. In 1989 he co-founded The Abraham Fund Initiatives, which is the first not-for-profit organization whose purpose is to further coexistence between Israel's Jewish and Arab citizens. At the time of his death, he was an honorary trustee of the Abraham Joshua Heschel School in NY. Mr. Slifka was instrumental in the development and expansion of the school. Additionally, he was a member of the boards of the Jewish Funders Network, the Tannenbaum Center, the Interfaith Center, and the American Jewish Congress. In 2001, Mr. Slifka established the Slifka Program on Intercommunal Coexistence at Brandeis University. Mr. Slifka was passionate about and committed to coexistence, Judaism, and Israel. He founded the Alan B. Slifka Foundation through which he could impact his love for Israel and his commitment to Jewish life and coexistence. We, the Slifka family, will deeply mourn Alan's loss. He was our strong and loving leader, always inspiring us to serve humanity, grow in our faith, and embrace and respect differences. We will continue his mission of Tikun Olam. The funeral service will be private. A memorial service will be held at B'nai Jeshurun synagogue on April 10th, 2011 at 11am. For more information please call 212-303-9442. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to The Abraham Fund Initiatives, The Big Apple Circus or the Abraham Joshua Heschel School.

SOLANGE AZAGURY-PARTRIDGE was born in the Chinese Year of the Ox, which by definition means she's not only incredibly strong-willed but also a firm believer in tradition. Her 12 lacquered and hand-carved critters set on 18-karat gold bands and pendants share a similar dualism, serving double duty as conventional commemorative gifts for Chinese New Year and as unconventional tokens of love for Valentine's Day. ''You can feel love emanating from these sweet creatures, and they are incredibly personalized,'' Ms. Azagury-Partridge said of the designs, which start at $2,450 and include a plump purple poodle for those born in the Year of the Dog. ''I definitely like unconventional gifts.'' Admirers, take note. Available in February at Solange Azagury-Partridge boutiques; information:(212) 879-9100. CHELSEA ZALOPANY

Russell K. Frederick began photographing the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn in 1999, shortly after he picked up a camera. ''When I told people where I lived, they would cringe, as if Bed-Stuy was this place where I had to wear a helmet and a bulletproof vest,'' Mr. Frederick said in an interview with James Estrin. ''They just assumed it to be this slum or this place that was just a war zone.''
