SILSBEE--Joan Malloy. After a long illness, Joan Malloy Silsbee, age 78, died peacefully at her Malibu, California home on January 19, 2011, attended by friends and family. Born February 17, 1932 in Los Angeles, California to John and Dorothy (Gall) Malloy, she attended John Burroughs Junior High School, John Marshal High School, University of California at Berkeley, University of Munich, Germany, and UCLA. She was a member of Phi Mu. At UC Berkeley, working towards a Master's degree in Anthropology, she met physicist Dr. Henry (Hank) Briggs Silsbee whom she married in 1956. They moved to Seattle, then Setauket, New York, when Hank accepted a teaching position at Stony Brook University on Long Island. Hank and Joan loved foreign travel, and finding their greatest interest in Africa, returned there many times. Joan was very interested in African archaeology, and social and cultural anthropology, especially in the sociological ramifications of the ivory trade, but had a broad range of interests, covering many fields. She visited more than one hundred fifty countries. Joan was a voracious reader, greatly enjoying her book clubs, and doing volunteer work with art museums and the Republican Party, in both Seattle and Stony Brook. In recent years she had spent Winters in Malibu; in other seasons, she lived on Long Island, New York, or was travelling, mostly to Africa. The destinations of many other trips were defined by the locations of the viewing spots of solar eclipses which she and Hank had routinely managed to attend, the most recent being Joan's trip to Easter Island in July 2010. Joan's proclivity for traveling, resulted in a fascinating and extensive collection of souvenirs and tourist art from around the world. Joan was preceded in death by her parents, her husband, Hank, and her sister-in-law Frances (Brownie) Silsbee Ames: She is survived by her cousin Yvonne (Gall) Weischedel of Indio, California, her brother-in-law Robert H. Silsbee of Ithaca, New York, and seven nephews and nieces. A memorial service is to be held at 2pm on February 19, 2011 at her Malibu home; if tributes are considered, contributions to Hospice or a favored charity are preferred in lieu of flowers. (For information call 310-709-6200)

SCHEPT--Dr. Chester. Beloved husband of the late Sophie. Loving father of David (Linda) and Debbie. Adored grandfather of Stuart (Susan), Michael (Lauren), Rachel (Ian), Robert and Julia. Donations may be made to Queens Centers for Progress.

Four ways the Steelers can gain an advantage over the Packers on Sunday. Establish the Screen GameThe best way to slow an opponent's pass rush and open up deep opportunities for wide receivers is to establish the screen passing game. The Steelers used screens effectively to complement their deep passing attack all year. On passes thrown behind the line of scrimmage, Ben Roethlisberger was 58-of-75 for 419 yards, with 13 of those short passes netting more than 10 yards. A screen or two to Mike Wallace or Antonio Brown will bring cornerbacks close to the line of scrimmage and make rushers leery, setting the Packers up for the long pass.Hide HarrisonJames Harrison recorded 11 sacks in the regular season, but he also made 27 plays in pass coverage, chasing down running backs, tight ends and the occasional receiver. Unlike Clay Matthews, who rushes the quarterback on most passing plays, Harrison often fakes a blitz, then drops into coverage. If the Steelers can disguise Harrison's assignment until the ball is snapped, they can confuse the Packers' pass protection.
UPPER EAST SIDE CO-OP $1,095,000

An article on Jan. 23 about restaurants in Berlin that double as art spaces referred incorrectly to an Austrian writer for whom a restaurant was named. The restaurant Joseph-Roth-Diele is named for Joseph Roth, not for Joseph Roth Diele. (Diele means hall in German.) So the restaurant's walls are lined with quotes from Mr. Roth's books, not Mr. Diele's.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''A $60 Million Palace,'' Jan. 30: Apparently, Allen, Tex., has decided that a $60 million investment in a high school football facility will ensure supremacy in producing American-style football players, besting all others competing for primacy in that important international specialty.
ROSENBLATT--Harvey M.D.,January 26, 2011, survived by wife Ursula, children Adam and Kirsten, grandchildren Monica, Colette, and Ma'ayan

Add to the list of post-Katrina comeback efforts from the City of New Orleans a circuit of new streetcar routes. The project, announced last week, will include two and a half miles of new track, to run past the Central Business District and the famed French Quarter, and then eastward into residential, working-class neighborhoods like Treme, Marigny and Bywater, with the hopes of serving those still-struggling communities.

HOLLAND--Ruth. Our Grandmother Taffy was, in many ways, the "solar" of our familial "system," thus our family was perhaps the only Taffy System in the world. Her incredible wealth of knowledge on almost any topic lent itself well to crossword puzzles, which she adored, heated, in-depth and entertaining conversations ranging from topics on art and authors to politics (domestic and global), from cooking and knitting to careers, as well as to life-changing advice and guidance for her two daughters, two sons-in-law, and four grandchildren. She was much more than a Grandmother or Mother to us all, she was a devoted friend and confidant. Above all, our Grandmother Taffy's commitment to and love for all of her family was unparalleled and present each and every day. It is unfathomable to imagine this "system" without her. But we promise to continue to live our lives in ways that would make her very proud. Annie, Sally, Francesca, Nicky

TANNENBAUMPaul J.,Clinical Professor of Dental Medicine, Columbia University College of Dental Medicine, passed away on February 2, 2011 after a tragic accident. Dr. Tannenbaum earned his DDS and a Certificate in Periodontics from Columbia University, and served on our faculty for more than 30 years. Paul was a renowned periodontist, a Diplomate and Director of the American Board of Periodontology, and a member of many professional organizations. He served as a member or chair of numerous committees, including the Executive Committee, Awards Committee, and the Committee on Informatics, of the American Academy of Periodontology. He was a past president of the Columbia Periodontal Alumni Association and the New York Academy of Dentistry. Dr. Tannenbaum was a mentor to generations of students and a loyal alumnus. Our thoughts and prayers are extended to all members of his family. In lieu of flowers, the family has requested donations in honor of Dr. Tannenbaum to the College of Dental Medicine or to the American Academy of Periodontology. Donations to the College in his memory may be sent to: Ms. Geraldine Connors; Director of Development; College of Dental Medicine; 630 West 168 St.; New York, NY 10032. Your check should indicate on the memo line that it is in Dr. Tannenbaum's memory. You may also make a donation on line at http://dental.columbia.edu/ alumni/giving.html. Donations to the American Academy of Periodontology may be sent to 737 N. Michigan Ave.; Attention Dr. Robert A. Vitas, Suite 800; Chicago, IL 60611. Ira B. Lamster D.D.S., M.M.Sc. Dean, Columbia University College of Dental Medicine Panos N. Papapanou D.D.S., Ph.D. Chair, Section of Oral & Diagnostic Sciences Director Division of Periodontics

SOSNE--Jeffrey J. We are deeply saddened by the sudden and untimely loss of our cousin, Jeffrey Sosne, age 65, last week. Jeff was a dear friend and devoted family member. He leaves Aline (Berger) Sosne, his wife of 41 years; and sons Zachary and Ben, and wives Lindsey and Amy. You will be forever in our hearts with your playfulness and nurturing. Annie, Jordan, Alan and Anita

Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the revival of the Logan Square neighborhood in Chicago misidentified the chef at Owen & Engine, a new gastropub. The chef de cuisine is Charles Burkhardt, not Martial Noguier, who is also a chef. (Mr. Noguier was recently seen at the restaurant, but has no affiliation with it.)

I have come to realize that I do not love solitude as much as I think. It is always with happy anticipation that I arrive in my study: alone, at last, to write! But once the door is closed I have a paradoxical sense of loss, as if I am cut off from my source. Is this why I spend such an unreasonable amount of time staring out the window? The rampant energy of Delhi, this city of almost 20 million people, presses in on my leafy street. Most families around here arrived as refugees from the horrors of India's partition in 1947. To protect themselves from such a thing ever happening again, they built solid rows of houses -- which are nonetheless turning to vapor in the white heat of the city's 21st-century economic boom. One of the houses in this drawing has already disappeared, to be replaced, inevitably, by another block of flats. In the top left you can see the steel zigzags of Nehru Stadium, centerpiece of the 2010 Commonwealth Games, whose preparations involved a stupefying scale of destruction and rebuilding around the city.

OBITUARIES An obituary in some editions last Sunday about the composer Milton Babbitt misstated the name of one of his compositions, the name of a film for which he wrote the score, and the name of an ensemble that was an early champion of his work. The composition was titled ''All Set,'' not ''All Set for Jazz.'' The film was titled ''Into the Good Ground,'' not ''Into the Ground.'' And the ensemble was the Group for Contemporary Music, not the Group of Contemporary Music.

3-D WORD HUNTBY WILL SHORTZImagine that the lettered balls in the three-dimensional grid at the right are arrangedintwoverticallayers:P,C,S/A,D,B/R,E,PinfrontandM,A,T/E,N,I/L,G,O in back. Find as many words of exactly five letters as you can spell by following the rods connecting the balls. You may return to a letter and use it twice in one word (as the T and S in STATS), but you may not ''stand'' on a letter and use it twice before proceeding (as the D in ADDER). Be sure not to jump between balls that aren't connected directly by a rod. For example, PEARL is not an acceptable answer, because no rod connects the P in the upper left of the front layer to the E in the middle left of the back layer. Plurals are fine. Proper names, prefixes and suffixes, capitalized acronyms and initialisms, and words appearing only as parts of phrases (like CANEM of ''cave canem'') are prohibited. Finding 20 words is good; 25 is expert; 30 is genius-level. Our answer list, containing 31 relatively familiar words and 11 unusual or not-so-common ones -- all from Merriam-Webster's Collegiate Dictionary, 11th edition -- will be shown next week.Your answers:
Film Mike Hale

ROBINSON--Shirley Brown, 89, of Southampton, New York, died January 28 in Portland, Oregon. Born July 4, 1921, "Brownie" was a descendant of Walter Rogers Burling, founder of many Long Island newspapers in the 1800's including the Southampton Press, which she published through the 1970's with her former husband William Read Robinson. She graduated from Southampton High School and Smith College class of 1943, and is survived by a son, Peter Burling Robinson, of Southampton; daughter Leslie Read Robinson Sharp and husband William Sharp of Portland, Oregon; and granddaughters Emily Dawson Sharp and Clair Burling Sharp of Washington state. No funeral services are planned; a memorial ceremony will take place later this year. Contributions would be appreciated to The Rogers Memorial Library or Peconic Land Trust of Southampton, New York.

''I'M a worker, not so much a talker,'' Mark Lee, the chief executive of Barneys New York, said Friday morning, explaining his reluctance these last months to publicly discuss his makeover plans for the store. Mr. Lee, the former chief executive of Gucci, arrived at Barneys in September. Still, his changes have been hard to miss. They include the dismissal in December of the Barneys stalwarts Judy Collinson and Julie Gilhart and the hiring of Daniella Vitale, a former Gucci colleague of Mr. Lee's, as chief merchant and executive vice president; and the unconventional choices of Dennis Freedman as creative director, responsible for windows and visual displays, among other things, and Amanda Brooks as fashion director. Mr. Freedman is known for his work at W magazine, and Ms. Brooks, a onetime Vogue editor, was fashion director at William Morris Endeavor Entertainment.

MASSAR--Phyllis Dearborn passed away January 8, 2011 at the age of 94. Originally from Seattle, she was educated in the Liberal Arts at the University of Washington and graduated in 1937. In New York City she studied photography at the Clarence H. White School of Photography and through a series of courses taught by Ansel Adams at the Museum of Modern Art. Her photographs were recognized for a sense of balance and exactness in their composition. The photographs of architectural works in the Pacific Northwest made from 1943-1963 with her husband, the late Robert Massar, are archived under the professional name of Dearborn-Massar in the UW Libraries, Special Collections Division. She traveled in Italy with her 4x5 camera on commissions to chronicle the architecture of Andrea Palladio and of Filippo Brunelleschi. In the 1970's she curated several photographic exhibits and print exhibits at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. As an art historian she was author of many articles and monographs as well as the book "Presenting Stefano Della Bella." A museum volunteer since 1966, Phyllis was an ardent print researcher with precise cataloging skills, an encyclopedic knowledge of art history and a true dedication to scholarship. Remembrances in her name may be made to the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Department of Drawings and Prints.

TOLAN--Michael, passed away January 31, 2011, at age 85 at Columbia Memorial Hospital, Hudson, NY after a courageous battle with multiple illnesses. A man of great integrity and intelligence who excelled in a memorable career that spanned radio, theatre, movies, television as well as live poetry readings. Born Seymour Tuchow in Detroit, MI, graduated from Wayne University, had an acting Fellowship at Stanford University and was put under contract by Warner Brothers Studio. While at Wayne in the 1940's Tolan's deep sonorous voice was heard originating live on Radio Station WXYZ from Detroit in "The Lone Ranger" and "The Green Hornet". He made his debut at age 24 in "The Enforcer". Other movie credits include "The Greatest Story Ever Told", "Julius Caesar", "John and Mary", "All That Jazz", Presumed Innocent" and "The Perfect Stranger". He co-produced "Five On The Black-Hand Side", a non-violent movie about an Afro-American family in Harlem. Broadway roles included "Will Success Spoil Rock Hunter?", "A Hatful of Rain", Romanoff & Juliet" and A Far Country". Tolan starred in the TV series "The Nurses" as Dr. Tazinski and in "The Senator". He had guest roles on "The Mary Tyler Moore Show" and "Murder She Wrote", dramatic roles in plays produced for the "US Steel Hour" and "The Dupont Show of the Week". Michael was co-founder of The American Place Theater and The Apple Core Theater, an inter-racial repertory group. Michael is survived by his partner Donna Peck (of Copake, New York), three daughters, Alexandra Tolan, Jenny Tolan and Emily Tolan, a brother Gerald Tuchow, and sister-in-law, Marilyn Tuchow of Bloomfield Hills, MI. A Celebration of Michael's life will be held at The Lotos Club, 5 E. 66th St., New York, 10065, March 16, 5pm. Donations in Michael's memory may be made to The Lotos Club Foundation.
The 36 Hours column on Jan. 30, about Lisbon, misspelled part of the address of Casa das Histórias, a museum in the suburb of Cascais. The address is Avenida da República 300 (not Repúbica).

GOLDENBERG--Rabbi Bernard, passed away in Jerusalem on Friday, January 28. He was a founder and leading figure of Torah Umesorah, served as Rabbi in Vancouver BC, and had a distinguished career in Jewish education. His legacy will be cherished and remembered by his children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren

THE FRUGAL TRAVELER In search of a more temperate climate, Seth Kugel heads off to Málaga in between trips to Paris and London, and finds irresistible cuisine, a dose of culture (including iron rests at the Museo de Artes y Costumbres Populares, above) and, well, more cuisine.
Theater Patrick Healy

''Until we see a sustained period of stronger job creation, we cannot consider the recovery to be truly established.'' Ben Bernanke, chairman of the Federal Reserve. ''It is much more than a currency. It is the embodiment of Europe today.'' Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany, talking about the euro. ''Enjoy your food, but eat less.'' From the latest nutrition advice issued by federal regulators, who also urged people to drink water instead of soda, eat more fruits and vegetables and cut down on processed foods. ''This reflects the dire fiscal circumstances the city faces.'' Marc La Vorgna, a spokesman for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York, who has proposed sweeping changes to the city's costly pension system. ''I don't see success for someone like me who doesn't understand the law. But it's better than nothing.'' Skylar Perea of Albuquerque, who is working without a lawyer to save her home from foreclosure. She fell behind on her mortgage payments during the eight months she was unemployed.

STEBBINS--Richard P.,of Brookline, MA on Tuesday, February 1, 2011. Born January 4, 1913 in Mt. Vernon, NY, Richard Poate Stebbins was the son of Howard L. Stebbins, long-time librarian of Boston's Social Law Library, and Lucy Poate Stebbins, author of novels and biographical works, who was herself awarded a Guggenheim fellowship in 1944. Graduating from Harvard Magna Cum Laude with highest honors in English (1933), Richard Stebbins taught at Harvard while earning the degrees of A.M. (1935) and Ph.D. (1940), at the same time collaborating with his mother in biographical research and publication and laying the foundations of an independent career in international studies. Appointed in 1940-41 as a fellow of the Social Science Research Council and a member of the Institute for Advanced Study at Princeton, he served in government during and after World War II in the Office of the Coordinator of Information, the Office of Strategic Services and the Dept. of State, transferring to New York in 1949 as author-editor of The United States in World Affairs, the Council on Foreign Relations' annual foreign policy Survey, and other publications. Returning to Boston after his retirement in 1978, he continued to engage in biographical and genealogical research and translation, serving for several years as a volunteer assistant in the Boston Symphony Orchestra Archives. His last major publication, The Making of Symphony Hall, Boston, was prepared for the centennial of Symphony Hall in October of 2000. Stebbin's German-born wife, the former Maria-Luise Rosinski (nee Trip), died in Boston in 1987 of an Alzheimer-type disability. There are no immediate survivors. Interment will be Private. Donations in Richard's memory may be made to Development Office, Boston Symphony Orchestra, c/o Richard P. Stebbins Fund, Symphony Hall, 301 MA Avenue, Boston, MA 02115. Boston Harborside Home, J.S. Waterman & Son-Waring-Langone. 617-536-4110

MAHON--Myra Ellen. Myra Ellen Mahon (nee Murphy) passed peacefully at home in Delray Beach, Florida, on Saturday, January 29, 2011, embraced and enveloped by the love and caring presence of her dear and cherished husband of 54 years, Arthur J. Mahon, and her four beloved children, Maura, Donna, Arthur and Nancy. Myra was also the dear Nana to her two grandchildren, Christopher and Emelia, and a wonderful mother-in-law to Susan who were holding her hand in spirit when she passed. Myra's date of passing was the Feast Day of Saint Thomas Aquinas, a day that her husband Arthur treasures and holds close to his heart, because on the day when he first met his beautiful, seventeen year-old wife-to-be at a Manhattan College dance, she told him she was reading the teachings of Saint Thomas Aquinas. Born in New York City on April 15, 1937 to James H. Murphy, from County Clare, and Mary Murphy (nee Caroon) from Westmeath, Ireland, Myra was always proud of, and true to, her roots in the Bronx and Ireland. She is predeceased by her parents, her deeply loved sister, Clare, and sisters-in-law, Mary Therese and Delia Rose. Her baby sister, Nula, who Myra loved dearly, survives her. Myra is also survived by her nieces, Maria O'Leary and Diane Slote, to whom she became a surrogate mother after their mothers' deaths, and by twenty other wonderful nieces and nephews from the Neil Mahon, Fitzpatrick, Burris, Thanhauser, and Slote families who were blessed to spend many weekends, Christmases, Thanksgivings, ski trips and also summers in Madison and Candlewood Lake, Connecticut, with their beautiful, generous, wise, funny and slightly irreverent Aunt Myra. A kid from Woodycrest Avenue in the Highbridge section of the Bronx, Myra lived from childhood with enormous intelligence, passion, elegance, conviction and concern for the underdog and the underserved. When the family moved to Queens, she attended St. Agnes High School in College Point. Married at the age of 20 to her love, Arthur, she returned to college as a young mother of four and graduated from Marymount, Tarrytown, summa cum laude as the valedictorian of her class, going on to earn her Masters in Social Work with high honors from Fordham University. Myra initiated her business career as a social worker at the United Way of Tristate in New York City, rising rapidly to Executive Vice President overseeing corporate partnerships and giving. She went on to become the Development Director of the Archdiocese of New York where she was fueled by her passion for raising funds for children to attend inner-city Catholic primary schools like the one she attended, Sacred Heart. An extraordinary team builder, mentor and leader, Myra took great joy and pride in the many people she worked alongside of, and she forever cherished their shared accomplishments and victories. Myra also lent her enormous energy and passion for social justice as a Member of the Board of Directors of a legion of wonderful organizations that embodied her unending commitment to giving all people the opportunity to live full, dignified and joyful lives. Those organizations included Marymount College, Women In Need, New York Foundation, Calvary Hospital and Hospice, New York State Parks and Recreation Commission, Museum of the City of New York and the Healthcare Chaplaincy. Myra took great joy serving for many years as the Co-Chair of the Women's Health Symposium at Weill Cornell Medical Center with her very dear friend and fellow New Yorker, Joan Weill. Myra was surprised five years ago when her loving husband, Arthur, told her that the second floor of the Weill Cornell Medical College's new building under construction at 1305 York Avenue in New York City would contain a resource center and it would be named in her honor. She was so pleased that the Myra Mahon Patient Resource Center included reading rooms and a library to help patients and families learn about and manage their illnesses. Upon its completion, Myra personally dedicated the Center "To those who serve unseen." Myra's immediate family and her personal assistant, Joan Hanebury, whom Myra loved dearly, attended a private memorial mass on Monday, January 31, 2011, at Holy Name of Jesus Church, Palm Beach, Florida, to honor and bless her memory. How appropriate and meaningful it is that Monday was the feast day of St. John Bosco, who dedicated his life to the education of poor children. There will be a mass celebrating Myra's life and all of her many loves, joys and accomplishments at Saint Patrick's Cathedral in New York City in the Spring. Donations in Myra's memory can be made to the Inner City Scholarship Fund of the Archdiocese of New York (Ms. Helen Lowe (212)371-1011, ext. 3325) for the Myra Mahon Fund for students at the Sacred Heart School in the Bronx, or to the Weill Cornell Medical College (Mr. Larry Schafer (212)746-4070) for the support of the Myra Mahon Patient Resource Center. Myra blessed the many people she loved with her warm spirit, endless wisdom, grace and intuitive gift for understanding and helping them. She leaves us with the memory of her sharing her favorite Irish prayer, "May the road rise up to meet you. May the wind always be at your back. May the sun shine warm upon your face, and rain fall soft upon your fields. And until we meet again, may God hold you in the hollow of His hand."

WOLL--Edward Woll, a pioneer in gas turbine development in the United States, died at 96 on December 17, 2010, at his home in Westwood, MA. Mr. Woll, born in New York and raised in Boston, MA, graduated Boston Latin School and Massachusetts Institute of Technology in mechanical engineering (1935), on active duty in WWII at Wright Patterson Field and Edwards AFB developing jet engines and earned a masters degree from Renssellaer Polytechnic Institute (1946). He joined General Electric Company's Aircraft Gas Turbine Department, retiring in 1979 as VP Engineering for military and commercial gas turbine product engineering. GE named an engineering hall and the Edward Woll Young Engineer's Award for him. Woll was a Distinguished Member of the Jet Pioneers Association of America (1975), elected to the National Academy of Engineering (1977), an American Institute of Aeronautics & Astronautics fellow and in GEAE's Propulsion Hall of Fame and received the Dr. Alexander Klemin Award for Notable Achievement in the Advancement of Rotary Wing Aeronautics (1975) and American Institute of Aeronautics & Astronautics Air Breathing Propulsion Award (1977). MIT class secretary until his death, he endowed a fund for educating deserving MIT undergraduates. Woll leaves his daughter Barbara Jones of Falmouth, MA and son Edward Woll, Jr., of Cambridge, MA, four grandchildren - Bryn Allpress of Bristol, England, Edward Chris Woll of Wayland, MA, Ben Jones of Chicago, IL and Evan Jones of New York, NY, a brother Saul and five great-grandchildren Alice, Carly, Eloise, Hugh and Sophia. A memorial service at Story Chapel, Mount Auburn Cemetery, Cambridge, MA, will be on April 17 at 3pm. The family would be honored if in lieu of flowers, donations are made to Society of Jesus of New England, PO Box 9199, Watertown, MA 02471-9199, and MIT-Hillel, 40 Massachusetts Avenue (Building W11), Cambridge, MA 02139, in the name of Edward Woll.

DALLAS -- A substantial wing of the Dallas Cowboys' suburban headquarters is devoted to the Dallas Cowboys Cheerleaders. On Thursday afternoon, in an immense dance studio, members of the world's most famous cheer squad rehearsed for one of their dozens of appearances surrounding the Super Bowl this week. ''We have never been this busy,'' said Kelli McGonagill Finglass, a Cowboys cheerleader in the 1980s and the director since 1991.

Intent on fixing a banking system that contributed heavily to the recent financial crisis, lawmakers and regulators pushed Wall Street to overhaul its pay practices. Big banks responded by shifting more compensation into stock, a move intended to align employees' interests more closely with those of investors and discourage excessive risk-taking. But it turns out that executives have a way to get around those best-laid plans. Using complex investment transactions, they can limit the downside on their holdings, or even profit, as other shareholders are suffering.

MATSIL--Shirley (Sherry). Died peacefully on February 4, 2011 at her home of almost 50 years surrounded by her daughters, a sister and her long time care giver, after a long illness. She was just six weeks shy of her 83rd birthday. Her husband, Irving Matsil, predeceased her. She leaves behind her loving daughters and sons-in-law Amy and Richard Richer and Joelle and Geoffrey Serota, her devoted grandchildren, Haylee and Gregg Donovan, Matthew Seltzer, Jonathan and Wesley Mehr, and three step-grandchildren, Jessica, Chelsea and Scott Richer. She is also survived by her two sisters Gloria Fischel and Mara Spiegel and her brothers-in-law and sisters-in-law, Milton Matsil, Reginald and Estelle Matsil, and Roz Gershuny and numerous nieces and nephews. She was an extraordinary woman and the matriarch of a large and loving family who will miss her greatly. Funeral services will be held Sunday 12 noon at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY.

TOLAN--Michael. The American Place Theatre notes the passing of our cofounder who enhanced our beginnings.

An entry in last Sunday's Playlist column about the rapper and producer Blaqstarr misstated his professional connection to the rapper M.I.A. Blaqstarr made a remix of M.I.A.'s ''Paper Planes'' for a single, but he did not produce the song for M.I.A.'s album ''Kala'' in 2007. (Diplo and Switch produced that song, while Blaqstarr collaborated with M.I.A. as writer and producer of ''The Turn,'' another song on ''Kala.'')

An article on Jan. 23 about a proposal by the Obama administration that would grant Mexican truckers greater access to Texas roadways misstated the amount of tariffs that Mexico imposed on American products after the end of a two-year long-haul pilot program, which gave Mexican truckers access to American roads. Mexico put tariffs on $2.4 billion worth of American goods, not more than $2 billion in tariffs on American products.

TANNENBAUM--Dr. Paul, a Brooklyn native born on April 30, 1936 received his dental degree from Columbia School of Dental and Oral Surgery in 1961. He then served as a Lieutenant in the Dental Corps of the United States Navy from 1961-1963. In 1964 he attended Cornell University Graduate School of Medical Sciences for Graduate Biostatistics. Following this he returned to Columbia for a certificate on Periodontology in 1971. Dr. Tannenbaum always had a keen interest in the Crystalline Chemistry of Bone and published numerous scientific papers while he was a research fellow and consultant at the Hospital for Special Surgery in New York. Dr. Tannenbaum was a gifted and beloved teacher at Columbia University School of Dental and Oral Surgery for over 30 years. He served on numerous committees at the American Academy of Periodontology and chaired many of them. He also served as President of the New York Academy of Dentistry and President of the Columbia Periodontal Alumni Association. Most recently he served as a Board Examiner for the American Board of Periodontology. He was also chairman of the American Board of Periodontology. Dr. Tannenbaum maintained a private practice in Periodontics in Manhattan along with his previous partner, friend and mentor Dr. Robert Gottsegen, Dr. Susan Karabin, and Dr. Edward Gottesman. Paul was an avid photographer, and traveled the world in search of natural beauty. In the last year he traveled to Antarctica, Africa, and Europe. He also loved to ski and play tennis. However, his greatest joy in life was his grandchildren. Dr. Tannenbaum is survived by two sons Stephen (Nina) and Daniel (Codie) from his marriage to Willma Reichek, and his six beloved grandchildren William, Beatrice, Dorothy, Julia, Pablo, and Sofia. He also is survived by his adoring companion of fourteen years Jane Cates, her family, Melissa and Roger Claman, Jon and Elena Cates, David and Christine Cates, and Gil Cates Jr., and Jane's grandchildren Julia, Harrison, Evan, Leah, and Jordan. His cousins Beth Polansky and Helene Richards also mourn his passing. A Memorial Service in his honor will be held at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, New York, NY Thursday, February 10 at 11:30am. 212-288-3500.
'I have my teammates to blame. I said that as long as we're winning games, I'll let this thing go. So it's their fault.' BRETT KEISEL,

COWING--Evianne. The management, agents and staff of Warburg Realty note with deep distress the death of Evianne Cowing, our colleague and friend and the daughter of our long time associate Evie Muller. Evianne was dynamic, principled, optimistic and generous, a giver not a taker. We have all admired her courageous struggle with cancer these last two and a half years and though the disease has taken her life it will not take her from our hearts and minds. To her husband Chas and son Grayson, to our beloved Evie and her husband Skip, we extend our heartfelt sympathy.

In last week's Appraisal column, the author Jill Kargman reminisced about her first apartment on the Upper East Side, where her roommates included so many mice that she learned to make plans, lots of plans, so that she was never home. The City Room blog asked readers to share their own tales of their first apartments in New York. Here are a few:

SCHLOSS--Sir Alex, 89 NY City artist/painter, beloved art institution at the Plaza Hotel for 35 years, died January 29, 2011. He is survived by sculptor/ wife Gloria, daughter Arleen, son Paul (Gisela), grandchildren Sarah Sequoia, Susannah Sequoia, and sister Ruth Goldsmith. Sir Alex was not only an incredible artist but also enormously generous to all who asked; a veteran of WWII, serving in the Pacific with pride. He will be missed greatly by all of his family, friends and relatives.

BLOOMSTEIN--Morris J.,of Wanaque, NJ, died on February 7, 2011. He was a prominent attorney for 56 years and author. Beloved husband of Ellen, devoted father of Nina (Shatz) and Josh, and father-in-law of Aliza. Adored "Papa Moose" of Rachel, Noah and Ari.

CONLIN--Peter, of Chatham Township, NJ, died February 1, 2011 at Morristown Memorial Hospital. Born in Orange, he grew up in South Orange, lived with his family in Summit and moved to Chatham 30 years ago. He was a graduate of Columbia High School class of 1949. Mr. Conlin was a graduate of MIT class of 1953 and earned his B.S. in Business and Engineering. He served as Treasurer for his Theta Chi fraternity and was on the swim, baseball team and was a member of the MIT Varsity lacrosse team. During summer breaks, Mr. Conlin reported for AFROTC camp and worked at the Hollinger Gold Mine in in Timmins, Ontario, Canada. After college, Mr. Conlin served as a USAF pilot with the 1739th Ferrying Squadron (MATS) from 1953 to 1956. He was a 2nd Lieutenant stationed out of Amarillo Air Force Base, Texas. He was proud of his service and enjoyed attending many pilot and veteran reunions over the years. Mr. Conlin worked for several Wall Street firms as an institutional salesman starting his career at Bache & Co. in the late 1950s. He earned his New Jersey CPA license and later practiced accounting and managed individual investment accounts. He spent the last 15 years of his career trading his accounts at Spear, Leeds & Kellogg. He was still actively trading and managing investment accounts until shortly before his death. He was a former member of Baltusrol Golf Club, Morris County Golf Club, the Pinehurst Country Club, The Bond Club of New Jersey, and the New Jersey Society of CPA's. Mr. Conlin was a 4 handicap golfer in his prime and a member of the Baltusrol Hole in One Club scoring a hole-in-one on the third hole of the Upper Course on May 17, 1969. In his later years, Mr. Conlin was an avid walker until shortly before his death. His daily walks around Chatham and the Hickory Tree Mall made him a local fixture and he enjoyed striking up conversations with merchants, managers, shoppers and townspeople. He was the father of the late Kitty Lobo, and is survived by his daughters, Patricia Conlin Leitz of New Providence and Bay Head, NJ, and Molly Tucker and her husband Lin of Charlotte, NC, and his grandchildren, Charlie, Barbara and Martha, and his brother James A. Conlin of Morristown, NJ. Peter was predeceased by his brothers Frank W. Conlin, Jr., and brother Thomas A. Conlin, Sr. Visiting will be on Friday, February 11, 2011 from 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 pm at Burroughs, Kohr & Dangler Funeral Home, 309 Springfield Ave, Summit, NJ. A Memorial Mass will be held on Saturday, February 12, 2011, at 9.30 am at St. Teresa Church, 306 Morris Avenue, Summit, NJ. He will be buried at the New Jersey Veterans cemetery. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations in his memory be made to Chatham Emergency Squad 45 Spring Street, Chatham, NJ 07928, whose service, Peter remarked, was "first class." Enough said, God bless.

PLATT--Martin, MD, FAAP, of Cairo, Egypt. Born 9 May 1938 to Dr. Abe and Laura Kinberg Platt of St. Louis, MO, he attended Washington University (B.A., 1960; M.D., 1964), was chief resident of Pediatrics, Maimonides Med Ctr (1968-69), and served as a lieutenant, US Navy (1966-68). Devoted pediatrician in private practice for 30 years in Westchester Co., NY. Retired to Cairo and died at home, 27 January 2011. Survived by his loving children Reina, Thomas, Alec; and grandchildren Asa, Jasper, Esme, Silas.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Tipping the Scales Over,'' Jan. 29: The mind-set that linemen must be huge to be effective is not limited to the N.F.L. A recent publication in The Journal of American College Health compared the risk of cardiovascular disease in collegiate football players with that of nonathletes. It noted that players focus on resistance training with little aerobic training, and tend to eat a high-fat diet. They found that half the linemen had metabolic syndrome, characterized by central adiposity, elevated blood pressure and low levels of protective HDL.

HAMANN--Bente, died peacefully at her home on January 16, 2011. She is survived by her daughter, Kristine Hamann, son-in-law, AlanFriedberg, and two granddaughters, Anna and Kate Friedberg. Bente was born in Copenhagen, Denmark on September 13, 1919, where she married Ole Hamann. The couple moved to America in 1947, where Ole eventually became the Postmaster General for the United Nations and Bente held various creative jobs. She found a true kinship with New York, soaking in inspiration for her beautiful works of art. A Memorial Service was held in her honor at the Danish Seaman's Church in Brooklyn and another will be held in Denmark this summer.

WILMARTH--Susan, artist, teacher, musician and cherished friend, passed away January 12, 2011, survived by her beloved partner, Nick Ullo, sister Phyllis Rabineau, brother-in-law John Alderson, and nephew Isaac Alderson. Susan was also widow of Christopher Wilmarth and daughter of the late Eli and Ruth Rabineau. Her survivors honor and remember Susan, for her dauntless spirit, life-affirming expressions of beauty through art and music, and kindness. Perhaps her life and art is best expressed by a quote from her 1999 artistic statement: "My work states my faith in Art as a force that withstands chaos and destruction by creating poetry and meaning that transforms and transports us beyond the baseness of existence." A memorial service is being planned, and will welcome all of Susan's friends.

Four ways the Packers can gain an advantage over the Steelers on Sunday: Pass on First DownThe Steelers allow only 2.5 yards per run on first down. The Packers average 7.9 yards per pass on first down. Forget ''establishing the run;'' the Packers must play their style of football, spreading the field on early downs and using the running game as a counterpunch.Beware the BunchThe Steelers like to run from a ''trips bunch'' formation, with two wide receivers and a tight end aligned in a V on one side of the line. The trips bunch is traditionally a passing formation, but with hard-blocking Hines Ward and Heath Miller bunched together, the formation creates a Bermuda Triangle of blocks for running back Rashard Mendenhall. The Steelers average 6.5 yards per rush on runs to the outside, thanks in large part to their receivers' blocking ability. Packers defenders must slice through the bunch, stay away from Miller's and Ward's crack blocks, and keep Mendenhall contained.

RESIDENTS can go online at www.nyc.gov/planning to determine how their homes are zoned. Under ''find the data'' (in the lower left corner of the screen) click on ''by address'' and enter your address. Then click on ''nyc.gov CityMap.'' When the map comes up, click on ''Show Additional Information'' and then on ''Building & Property Information.'' On the right side of the screen, under zoning, you will see your zoning district, which will begin with an R, for residential, a C, for commercial, or an M, for manufacturing. Individual properties can also be clicked on to display zoning and other building information. FRED A. BERNSTEIN

GRANT--Richard H.,beloved husband of Nancy, father of Leslie, Nanci and the late Eric, stepfather of Robin, grandfather of Jamie, Roger, Ilyssa, Jeremy and Halle, great-grandfather of six, died peacefully after a long illness on February 5 in Delray Beach.

MOTORISTS who leave their cars parked on the street this winter are getting ample time to hone their exhumation techniques. However, the subsequent forward-reverse ballet used to get a vehicle onto open pavement is often treated indelicately, damaging vehicle and wallet. Some repair shops are reporting that this winter has been one of their busiest periods in memory, largely because of drivers who, eager to leave snowy parking spaces, apply too much gas and spin their wheels in forward and reverse. That can overload the transmission and damage pumps, bushings and housings.

BEHRMAN--Stanley J.,DMD., former professor of surgery and chief of dentistry, oral and maxillofacial surgery at New York Presbyterian Hospital-Weill Cornell Medical Center, and prominent New York surgeon, Dr. Stanley J. Behrman passed away comfortably on January 30th after a short battle with colon cancer. He is remembered by his former colleagues and residents for his 55 years of both clinical and academic excellence. During his tenure as Chief his abilities to teach, innovate upon, and improve jaw surgery led to significant advances in his specialty of Orthodontics. The generations of surgeons he trained, and patients he helped with his advanced and specialized techniques, are his legacy. A graduate of New York University and the University of Pittsburgh School of Dentistry, Dr. Behrman was one of the founders of the technique of intra-oral surgical manipulation of the upper and or lower jaw to correct deformities, improved the esthetic appearance, and improved the occlusion or, bite. Dr. Behrman was a practitioner and life long friend to many celebrated personalities. Amongst others this included the star, Betty Davis. He was able to preserve her mandible from a severe bone infection as she was performing on Broadway. He was acclaimed throughout the media, appearing on television numerous times and including the CBS special, The Body Human-The Body Beautiful. He is survived by his wife Marla, stepson Peter Grayson and his wife Josephine, grandsons Bradley and Eric, and brother Lawrence. He lived his life generously, intelligently, and faithfully and gave life a rich and purposeful meaning. A celebration of his life will be held at a later date. For information please call: 917-539-7174. Contributions may be made to Hospice of Palm Beach.

HULINGS--Clark, an Artist who Pursued Timeless Beauty, Dies at Age 88. Clark Hulings, whose paintings are prized by art collectors worldwide, died on Wednesday, February 2, 2011, in Santa Fe, NM, where he lived. He was 88. As one of the leading American realist painters, Mr. Hulings traveled the world looking for rural and urban landscapes and genre scenes that became the subjects of paintings reflecting the vibrancy of the human spirit. Admired for his genius in manipulating the formal elements, he searched for beauty in places where others might only find misery: In the world of street people he saw compassion and self-respect. In urban alleyways he envisioned sunlit corridors of family activity. Among rustic farmers he discovered people whose lives were synchronized with cycles of the seasons and the animals they care for. Mr. Hulings' ability to see timeless beauty in momentary human gestures and activities won him the appellation "master" on numerous occasions. His celebration of textures as expressed through light, shadow, and atmosphere was explained as "describing air itself." His modesty in the face of such acclaim was legendary. Throughout his career he maintained a personal profile far lower than his national acclaim. Mr. Hulings' subject matter was gathered throughout North America and Europe, notably France, Italy, and Spain, where he lived as a child and frequently visited as an adult. Among his signature subjects are complex Mexican and European market scenes that include panoplies of colors, surfaces, and shapes. His affection for donkeys was a trademark, with the animal's quiet demeanors becoming a metaphor of human patience and perseverance. Born in Florida, November 20, 1922, Mr. Hulings was raised in Westfield, NJ. Over his lifetime, he resided in New York, Louisiana, and throughout Europe before settling in Santa Fe in 1972. His art training began as a teenager with Sigismund Ivanowsky and the fames draftsman George Bridgman and continued at The Art Students League with Frank Reilly. With a degree in physics from Haverford College, PA., Hulings pursued an initial career as a portraitist in Louisiana, followed by freelance illustration in New York, notably paperback book covers, during the 1950s. By the early 1960s, Mr. Hulings devoted himself to easel paintings. In 1965 he debuted in New York, N.Y., at The Grand Central Art Galleries. In 1976 he was the subject of a solo exhibition at the National Cowboy and Western Heritage Center, Oklahoma City, Ok., which was documented in the book Hulings--A Collection of Oil Paintings (Lowell Press), followed in 1978 by a retrospective at the Museum of the Southwest, Midland, TX, and a 1981 exhibition at the C.M. Russell Museum, Great Falls, Mt. Most recently, Mr. Hulings' work was the subject of a 2007 one-man exhibition at J.N. Bartfield Galleries, New York, and Morris & Whiteside Galleries, Hilton Head, SC. His scheduled exhibition of paintings at the Forbes Galleries, New York, takes place March 23 through June 18, 2011. In 1986, Mr. Hulings authored the book A Gallery of Paintings by Clark Hulings (White Burro Publishing). The book was updated and reissued in soft cover in 2006. His paintings have been included in countless articles and surveys such as The Majesty of the Grand Canyon: 150 Years of Art (Pomegranate Press) and Landscapes of New Mexico: Paintings of the Land of Enchantment (Fresco Fine Art Publishing). He is the recipient of several awards from organizations such as The Allied Artists of America, The Salmagundi Club and The Hudson Valley Art Association. In 1973 he received the Prix de West award from the National Cowboy and Western Heritage Museum, where his painting Grand Canyon, Kaibab Trail is in the permanent collection. In his adopted state, Mr. Hulings was recognized with his first one-man show in 1945 at the New Mexico Museum of Art, Santa Fe. In 1985, the museum installed a Hulings plaque on its artist walk of fame; and in 2004, he received the New Mexico Governor's Award for Excellence in the Arts. Mr. Hulings is survived by his wife Mary Belfi Hulings, daughter Elizabeth Hulings Diamond, son-in-law Patrick Diamond, grandson Nicolas and sister Susan Ottinger. In lieu of flowers, donations are being accepted at the Santa Fe Community Foundation for the Clark Hulings' Memorial Fund, 516 Alto St., Santa Fe, NM 87501, www.santafecf.org. The fund will provide support for visual artists Arrangements are under the direction of Berardinelli Family Funeral Service 1399 Luisa Street Santa Fe, NM 87505 (505) 984-8600 Please sign our guestbook for the family at: berardinellifuneralhome.com

FULLEN--William Patrick, 65, of New York City, beloved husband of Jean Boston Fullen, died suddenly January 29, 2011. Born in Brooklyn, NY, on June 11, 1945, he was the son of the late William and Katherine Fullen. Bill served in the US Navy from 1966 to 1968. He attended Fordham University. He worked for 30 years at Broadridge, formally part of ADP, as part of his long career in brokerage services. A New York City resident his entire life, he was an active member of the board of directors at 10 Park Avenue where he resided for 21 years. Bill was a source of humor, wisdom, and above all vitality to all who knew him. Survivors in addition to his wife of 39 years are his siblings Sandra Peterson and her husband, Ted; Peter Fullen and his wife, Carole; Michael Fullen and his wife, Terry; Cathryn Fanti and her husband, Timothy; a sister-in-law, Barbara Boston; 17 nieces and nephews and 30 great-nieces and nephews. He is predeceased by brother-in-law, James Boston. There will be a memorial service in New York City for his family and friends in the spring. Interment will be in Sewickley, PA. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made in his name to Cancer Research Institute, www.cancerresearch.org or Alzheimer's Association, www.alz.org.

McKITTERICK--Gertrude, First female to serve as ambassador for the United Nations. Gertrude McKitterick, age 91, of Hamden, CT., passed away January 29, 2011. Ms. Mckitterick served as U.N. Development Program resident representative for Tanzania in 1968, part of a 37-year career with the U.N. mostly in Paris. Born on Dec. 24, 1919 in Milton, MA, she was a WWII US Marine Corps Veteran. A Memorial Service will be held on February 19, 2011 at 10:30 a.m. in Grace & St. Peter's Church, 2927 Dixwell Ave., Hamden. Contributions may be made to the National Alliance on Mental Illness.

THEY are well-heeled warriors. These squash players do battle behind thick glass at the courts of the Yale Club, in Midtown Manhattan, backed by a soundtrack of roars and grunts and lunging bodies slamming against walls. On a recent weekday, one of the liveliest contests was on Court 2, where an older man was running a much younger player ragged and whipping him in a succession of games. The younger man was soaked with sweat and heaving from exhaustion. The older was calmly holding position on the right side of the court, moving in a radius of a few steps and flicking returns all over the court. Both were going for the jugular, their intensity punctuated by brief moments of civility between points.

BEHRMAN--Stanley J.,DMD, The Department of Surgery mourns the loss of our distinguished colleague, Dr. Stanley Behrman, Professor of Surgery and former Chief of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery and Dentistry. A renowned clinician and teacher for over 55 years, his academic excellence helped innovate his field. A pioneer of new surgical techniques for jaw deformities and tumors of the jaw, his legacy lives on in the generations of surgeons he trained. His commitment to excellence is continued by his nephew, David Behrman, DMD, our Chief of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery & Dentistry. We offer our deepest condolences to his nephew David, his brother Lawrence, and to his family. Fabrizio Michelassi, MD Professor and Chair, Department of Surgery Surgeon-in-Chief, NYP/Weill Cornell Medical Center

DUNN--Kempton, former vice president of the Council on Foreign Relations and program director of The Conference Board, died on January 25 in Maui, HI with his wife by his side. He was 69 years old and lived in New Canaan, CT. Born in New York City on January 5, 1942, Mr. Dunn graduated from the Kent School and from Yale College in 1965. After graduation, he served as a Fulbright scholar in India, received a Master's degree from The Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies, and worked at Time Inc. and the Asia Society before arriving at the Council. During his two decades with the Council in New York City, Kempton eventually rose to Vice President for Membership and Fellowship Affairs, earning from his colleagues the fond nickname "Dean of Admissions" and recognition for his leadership of the Council's prestigious International Affairs Program. Over his decade with the Conference Board, also in New York City, Kempton served as Director of International Programs, organizing hundreds of conferences, seminars, and workshops on issues ranging from economics and marketing to healthcare and sustainability. He also conceived and orchestrated conferences on emerging topics such as corporate security and risk and crisis management. Kempton is survived by his wife, the former Ellen Gage Anderson, of New Canaan, CT; two sons, Kempton Dunn III of San Francisco and Seth Simrall Dunn of Saratoga Springs, NY; a daughter, Heather Anderson Drugge of Darien, CT; and a sister, Holly Bodman of New York City and Cambridge, MA.

Here's a sampling of readers' responses to A. O. Scott's column about American audiences' indifference toward foreign films. ''As an owner of two movie theaters, a film booker and an operator of bigscreenbiz.com (a Web site for theater owners), I sadly agree with Mr. Scott. In small towns, even on the somewhat more aware coast of Maine, the audiences for films that people have not been repeatedly beaten over the head about rarely rise to sufficient awareness. Unknown films, especially with subtitles, are doomed before they start. The same people who happily read screen crawls on CNN and MSNBC seem to not make the effort in a theater.''

THE NEWS Dueling pro- and anti-government rallies in Yemen unfolded peacefully after President Ali Abdullah Saleh said he would neither seek another term in 2013 nor pass power to his son, and made other concessions. BEHIND THE NEWS Both sides appeared to draw lessons from Tunisia and Egypt. Opponents demanded reforms but not the immediate ouster of Mr. Saleh, who has been in office since 1978. After his supporters pre-emptively occupied the capital's main square, opponents shifted the site of their protest to a college campus to avoid clashes.

Facebook can often be a time suck, but a new initiative by JetBlue offers rewards for logging onto the site. JetBlue recently announced an application called Go Places on Facebook that the carrier says will offer customers several deals and promotions this year. The first, which lasts through March 1, allows customers to earn 25 rewards points whenever they check in (virtually, via Facebook) at a JetBlue terminal. The first 100 travelers who check in at Logan International Airport in Boston, Long Beach Airport in California, John F. Kennedy International Airport in New York and Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood and Orlando international airports in Florida will receive 100 points. And users who check in five times receive $100 off a JetBlue Getaways package. Travelers can check in using their smartphones, tablets or other wireless devices.

THE narrow roads of Hauz Khas Village, hidden behind the crumbling structures of its namesake complex -- a mosque, madrasa, royal tomb and reservoir dating to the 13th century -- are among car-congested New Delhi's most enjoyable streets to explore by foot. The village had a brief ''it'' moment in the 1980s, when high-end shops began to open among the old homes here. But the quaint setting soon fell out of favor with the city's nouveau riche, who instead flocked to American-style shopping malls in the suburbs. Now, a new cluster of creative cafes, restaurants, bookstores and boutiques has turned the village into an arty haven that complements its historic neighbor. BRENDAN SPIEGEL

An article last Sunday about American policy toward the upheaval in Egypt quoted incorrectly from comments by Robert Gibbs, the White House press secretary, about the Obama administration's next steps. And because of that error, the article characterized Mr. Gibbs's comment incorrectly. He said, ''We will be reviewing our assistance posture based on events that take place in the coming days.'' He did not say reviewing ''our systems posture,'' and therefore it was not the case that he sounded ''like he was talking about a NASA launch, not chaos in Cairo.''

EGYPT IS NOT ALONE.Fed by the example of Tunisia, whose leader was driven from power by demonstrations last month,anger has begun to boil over, or threatens to do so,across a number of Arab countries living under authoritarian rule or, in the Palestinians' case, in a state of intermittent conflict.While the fury has varied roots, clues to its depth are offered by snapshots of rights violations reported by Amnesty International and Human Rights Watch in the region during thelast year.

The Streetscapes column last Sunday, about residences for working men built by Darius Ogden Mills, misstated the decade in which the 1907 Mills Hotel No. 3 was converted to offices. It was in the 1980s, not the 1950s.

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended Saturday, January 22nd 2011, at many thousands of venues where a wide range of general interest books are sold nationwide. These include hundreds of independent book retailers (statistically weighted to represent all such outlets); national, regional and local chains; online and multimedia entertainment retailers; university, gift, supermarket, discount and department stores; and newsstands. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book’s sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (†) indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Among those categories not actively tracked are: perennial sellers; required classroom reading; text, reference and test preparation guides; journals and workbooks; calorie counters; shopping guides; comics; and crossword puzzles. Expanded rankings are available on the Web: nytimes.com/books.

The N.F.L. season, which culminates in Sunday's Super Bowl between the Green Bay Packers and the Pittsburgh Steelers, has had its share of thrills and drama.There were last-second victories, like DeSean Jackson's Miracle at the Meadowlands against the Giants. There were unlikely contenders like the Seahawks, who made the playoffs with a losing record, then beat the defending Super Bowl champion Saints. There was the re-emergence of Michael Vick and the suspension of Ben Roethlisberger. Gamers followed those headlines, which shaped how they played Madden NFL 11, the most popular football video game. Since the preseason, gamers started more than 290 million games of Madden, or about 1,200 every minute.

LANGLEY--Susan, age 63 passed away peacefully on January 31, 2011, after a long illness. She is preceded in death by her parents, John and Dorothy of Brighton-Sussex UK and her beloved companion, Dominic Annechiarico. Susan leaves behind many devoted friends who will mourn the loss of her unique charm, wit and love of life. She arrived on these shores in 1968 and began her long distinguished career at CBS and Sony Music from which she retired as Director Of Human Relations. Susan will be honored at a Memorial service 11am on February 12, 2011 at the Park Avenue United Methodist Church 106 East 86 In lieu of flowers, please make donations to Park Avenue United Methodist Women.

FROM his bar stool, Askold Verbitsky yelled a message to his fellow Ukrainian-Americans on a recent evening: ''There's no more club anymore! We're finished!'' Then he shook his head mournfully and turned back to the bar. Though other members of the Ukrainian Sports Club wore less visible despair, most turned glum at the mention of the group's future. Because of the club's financial struggles, its space on Second Avenue near Seventh Street, which has been owned and occupied by this ''Ukrainian sports fraternity'' since 1972, was recently put on the rental market. Already, 15 interested businesses have responded, said Gary Rubinstein, the club's real estate broker.

WILLIAM DIAMOND and Anthony Baratta of Diamond Baratta Design are known for their chic, irreverent interiors and bold use of color. But they're also famous for putting a contemporary spin on traditional crafts like quilting and upholstery, challenging their collaborators to push those crafts in new directions. One such example is the upholsterer Kenneth DeAngelis, the owner of Guido DeAngelis Inc., whom they admire for realizing ''our crazy ideas,'' like this headboard, inspired by George Nelson's midcentury classic, the Marshmallow sofa, and conceived for Mr. Baratta's Miami Beach apartment. Its five rows of circular pieces seem to hover effortlessly on the wall when, in fact, they are all bolted together in the back. As Mr. Diamond said, ''a decorator is only as good as his upholsterer.'' Guido DeAngelis Inc.; (212) 348-8225. PILAR VILADAS

In previous columns I have argued that academic work is distinctive - something and not everything - and that a part of its distinctiveness is its distance from political agendas. This does not mean that political agendas can't be the subject of academic work - one should inquire into their structure, history, etc. - but that the point of introducing them into the classroom should never be to urge them or to warn against them. I have never felt that my attempts to explain this point have been entirely successful, but I am moved to try again by the recent experience of a conference that, I believe, exemplifies the point in action.

The Watts Towers, the soaring outdoor structures in the Watts neighborhood of Los Angeles, are endangered by cuts in the city budget. This 100-foot-tall  work of folk art, constructed from pipes and other detritus, struggles to draw crowds and requires roughly $5 million in restoration. But cuts recently forced the City of Los Angeles to lay off the three city workers in charge of taking care of the site; the city has contracted the Los Angeles County Museum of Art to restore and maintain it. "Fahrenheit 9/11," Michael Moore's 2004 documentary about President George W. Bush, is still generating heat. Mr. Moore on Monday filed suit against Bob and Harvey Weinstein, who formed Fellowship Adventure Group to distribute "Fahrenheit 9/11" in an alliance with Lionsgate and IFC Films, claiming that the Weinsteins defrauded him of at least $2.7 million in profits from the film. The suit, filed in Los Angeles County Superior Court, charged the Weinsteins with "accounting tricks and financial deception" in connection with "Fahenheit 9/11," which took in about $222 million at the worldwide box office, and millions more on home video. Bert Fields, a lawyer for the Weinsteins, said Mr. Moore had been paid everything he was due, and was trying to make a public spectacle out of what he called "a routine kind of auditing" dispute. "Mr. Moore has put in a number of very inflammatory claims designed for the press," Mr. Fields added. "He should be ashamed of himself." Larry Stein, a lawyer for Mr. Moore, said in a statement that Mr. Moore had never sued anyone in his filmmaking career and that "it's very sad that it had to come to this."Mr. Moore and the Weinsteins have worked together on several films, including "Sicko" and "The Big One."

This year's Super Bowl delivered great ratings, which is probably making the producers of the Oscars - the second-most-watched event in the U.S. after the ball game - extra antsy. This year the producers and the telecast's network, ABC, are aiming to increase viewership among younger people, with younger, weirder hosts (James Franco and Anne Hathaway), hipper singers (Florence of Florence and the Machine) and a promotional campaign aimed at breaking down the event's perceived fustiness. The campaign, called "You're Invited," opens up the red carpet and backstage experience to viewers at home via "ambitious live streaming" - a first, according to Ad Age.

As I reported last week, many parents in New York City are worried about the presence of the chemicals known as PCBs in light fixtures and caulking in school buildings. The latest spot inspection by the federal Environmental Protection Agency -- on Jan. 29 at Public School 68 in the Bronx -- turned up lighting ballasts that were leaking PCBs above the regulatory level of 50 parts per million in 10 of 13 samples taken, the agency announced Monday. Over the past several weeks, the E.P.A. found similar contamination at all three other city schools that it inspected, too.

Daniel Bell, who died last week at 91, is closely associated with a group of New York intellectuals who included Irving Kristol, Nathan Glazer and Daniel Patrick Moynihan. But as I write in an essay for the Feb. 13 Book Review (published early online), Bell deserves our attention as a singular - and singularly ambitious - thinker and writer, who followed in the system-building tradition of Karl Marx and Thorstein Veblen, both heroes of his. Like them, Bell could be impatient with those he judged to be on the wrong side of history or ideas, even in those post-war years remembered for their cozy political "consensus," as is clear from Bell's correspondence with William F. Buckley Jr. in 1955.

Doctors are becoming increasingly aware that attention problems in childhood may not be something that a child simply outgrows. While attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, or A.D.H.D., is one of the most common behavioral disorders in young people, affecting up to 7 percent of the school-age population, up to 4 to 5 percent of adults have A.D.H.D. The disorder can interfere with most domains of life, including education, work, family, relationships and health.

Commissioner Roger Goodell should have done Monday morning was announce A) there would be no lockout and B) he was doubling the Super Bowl shares of the Packers and the Steelers. And he should consider delivering the checks to all of their houses in person. Because although Goodell would never admit it (because his league is dead set on grabbing as much money away from the players as it can), those players bailed out his Super Bowl. PARIS -- The scene of gleaming cars and motorcycles positioned beneath a vast iron and glass vault could have come from an early 20th century engraving, if not for the near-total absence of hats worn by the ladies and gentlemen present. The setting, the Grand Palais, is a masterpiece of the machine age, an opulent temple of industrial progress built for the Universal Exposition of 1900.

Along with the news that Punxsutawney Phil didn't see his shadow, here's another harbinger of spring: At 9 a.m. on Feb. 15, tickets for the 2011 tours of the Philip Johnson Glass House in New Canaan, Conn., will go on sale. To mark the program's fifth year, the Glass House (a National Trust for Historic Preservation site) is adding several new tours to its already varied menu. (The tour season runs from May through November.) Three new two-hour, $45 tours will focus on specific aspects of the 47-acre site: the architecture; the art (Johnson and his partner, David Whitney, assembled a significant collection of postwar and contemporary painting and sculpture); and the landscape, which includes everything from historic trees to Whitney's idiosyncratic succulent gardens.

As if Abraham Lincoln Halloween costumes and television commercials weren't enough, Hollywood is getting the 16th president ready for his close-up. A bunch of them. You might have thought Matthew McConaughey was first in line, with his lead role in ''The Lincoln Lawyer,'' due from Lionsgate on March 18. But the title refers to a Lincoln sedan used by Mickey Haller, a criminal defender played by Mr. McConaughey (who has the jaw, but perhaps not the gravitas, for a presidential turn).

BOURDETTE--Dorothy N.,passed away on February 2, 2011. Devoted wife of the late Leonard C. Bourdette, loving mother of Claudia, Eric and Carol Bourdette. Dorothy had a joy for life. Her wit and wisdom delighted us. Her eloquence and grace defined her. Dorothy was a gentle soul who loved nature and all creatures great and small. She was loving and caring to all. Dorothy will be dearly missed. We are grateful that she is at peace and with her beloved husband, Leonard.

SLIFKA--Alan B. The Abraham Joshua Heschel School community mourns the passing of our dedicated and beloved Honorary Trustee and past Vice President Alan B. Slifka. From the founding of the school to the present day his vision, inspiration and incredible generosity have been instrumental in the school's growth and success. Alan's philanthropy has no boundaries and we are privileged to be recipients of his support. Alan will always be remembered for the instrumental role he played in developing, supporting and preparing for the school's strength and growth. Alan's passion, commitment and vision inspired a next generation of leadership. More recently, he and his wife, Riva, have been major benefactors to our One Campus Campaign and have continued to be very generous supporters of the school's Annual Fund. We send our heartfelt sympathy to his devoted wife, Riva, sister Barbara, children David (class of 1993) (Michele), Michael, Randy (Jan), his stepchildren Skye, Victoria and Max, and his grandchildren. May the family be comforted by the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Barry N. Winograd, President Roanna Shorofsky, Head of School

Google has weathered criticism in the past that it has copied some features of Microsoft's Bing search engine, like background images. Now it has turned the tables, contending that Bing copies something much more important: search results. Danny Sullivan, head of the blog Search Engine Land, wrote Tuesday about a ''sting operation'' by Google that the company says proves that Bing watches Google's search results to improve its own.

CIRILLO--Nancy Natalie, 96, died February 4, 2011. Born in Brooklyn, NY on November 4, 1914. Graduate of Fordham University. Her steadfastness, courage, and grace were an example to her surviving daughters, Maria and Joan; son-in-law Roger Cooke; and granddaughters Julia and Elizabeth. Predeceased by husband, Peter, and daughters, Diana and Patricia. Viewing Monday, Harrison Funeral Home 914-835-0284. Burial Tuesday, Brooklyn, NY.

Computer makers have been forced to shut down some of their assembly lines because of a design flaw in chips produced by Intel. Dell and Hewlett-Packard have both stopped producing several models of personal computers to await a modified version of the chipset.

Mary Cleere Haran, a classic popular singer and writer much admired for her cabaret shows celebrating the American song book, died on Saturday in Deerfield Beach, Fla., two days after a cycling accident. She was 58 and was living in Florida, having taken a break from a career that saw her perform in every major New York supper club. Ms. Haran was struck from the side by a car coming out of a driveway, according to a friend, Bridge McIntyre. She never regained consciousness.

SLIFKA--Alan. The employees of Cassidy Turley mourn the loss of our friend and client Alan Slifka. We extend our sincere condolences to Alan's wife Riva, his sons Michael, Randy and David and his sister Barbara.

On Saturday night, the Writers Guild of America awards - or the ''introverted Emmys'' as the New York host, Kristen Schaal, put it - doled out their prizes simultaneously and bicoastally, as usual. The group honored Aaron Sorkin and Christopher Nolan for their adapted (''The Social Network'') and original (''Inception) screenplays, respectively. Both were in Los Angeles to accept. ''Inside Job'' won for best documentary; the director and lead writer, Charles Ferguson, was also in Los Angeles. In New York, we got Kathleen Turner, John Waters, Denis O'Hare and John Laroquette as presenters (and Tina Fey in the audience). But it was okay, because it allowed Ms. Schaal - full disclosure, a pal of the Bagger's - to earn her comedic keep. And did she! She opened the show with a song-and-dance number that she lip-synced with the help of a passel of male dancers. She made numerous costume changes, each more ludicrous than the last, and accepted for absent winners, doing their speeches on their behalf; one was apparently Spanish, and another a smoker.
CHIARA--Judith Loeb Beaty. Please join us to celebrate Judy's life on Tuesday, February 8th 2011 at 5:30pm. For venue please email: jlcmemorial@hotmail.com

SLIFKA--Alan B. The partners and employees of Halcyon Asset Management LLC mourn the passing of Alan B. Slifka, our founder, colleague and friend, who died on Friday, February 4. After graduating from Yale University and Harvard Business School, Mr. Slifka started his career at L.F. Rothschild, where he became partner in charge of risk arbitrage. In 1981 he established our firm, which began investing with assets of $50 million; today Halcyon manages over $10 billion. Until recent years, Mr. Slifka was active in a variety of not-for-profits, several of which he helped found. He conducted his professional and philanthropic lives with a keen sense of fiduciary responsibility. He took a passionate, businesslike approach to the activities of the charities he supported, which benefited from his intense involvement as board member, benefactor, and tireless fundraiser. Through good times and bad, his support for the firm, its investors and associates, and his philanthropies was steadfast. We extend our condolences to his wife, Riva Ritvo Slifka; his sons Michael, Randy, and David; his sister, Barbara Slifka; his step-children Victoria, Skye and Max; his grandchildren Grace and Joshua and step-grandson Braylan; and the extended Slifka family. His warmth, vision, and generosity of spirit will be missed.

MIRCHIN--Joseph, died February 5. He is survived by his wife of 62 years Phyllis (Zisblatt), his sister Edith Sobel, three children and their spouses, seven grandchildren and one great-grandchild. He proudly served in WWII and was a past president of the Paterson Hebrew Free Loan and Camp Veritans. He was a long time NYT reader and is a first time "caller". Funeral at Schoem's Chapel in Paramus at noon on February 7. Donations may be made to the above charities or to the Fair Lawn Jewish Center

BAHLKE--George W.,76, of Clinton, NY, died on February 1, 2011, following a brief illness. His family, friends, colleagues and students mourn the loss of an extraordinary teacher, noted literary scholar, devoted husband, and loving father and grandfather. George was Emeritus Professor of English at Hamilton College, where he was the inaugural recipient of The Class of 1962 Outstanding Teaching Award. He taught previously at Kirkland College, Middlebury College, Rutgers University and Mary Washington College. He was predeceased by his first wife, Valerie Worth Bahlke. He is survived by his wife Felicity Colby, his children Conrad, Catherine and Margaret, and six grandchildren.

FAGENSON--Josephine Krakower, passed peacefully on Saturday morning, February 5th, unaware that her dear cousin, Alan Slifka, had passed only several hours earlier. A lifetime resident of Manhattan and Deal, New Jersey, she enjoyed thirty five wonderful winters in St Thomas in the Virgin Islands with her beloved late husband of over sixty years, Bertram, whom she has missed terribly these last ten years. She was predeceased by her loving twin brother, Arnold Krakower and is survived by her two sons, Toby and Robert and their wives, Jane and Margaret; her granddaughters Stephanie Fagenson and Jennifer Fagenson Young and her husband, Josh and her much adored great granddaughter, the light of her life in recent months, Sophie. A woman of exceptional beauty, grace and charm, she was the consummate hostess to friends and family. With a wry sense of humor and a sharp tongue and wit, she was a commanding presence in any setting. Weekend barbecues at her home usually numbered fourteen or more with her favorite aunt and uncle, the late Sylvia and Joe Slifka and her mother, Lil Krakower and Uncle Sidney and Aunt Vicky. She lived a full life surrounded by family and friends. Annie and Princess and Enid who took such good care of her for a lifetime and later Elsie, Maureen, Gilian, Sarah and Desiree. She wanted to bid a special farewell to her dear friends Bernice, Anice, Honey and Suzanne and of course her dear cousin Barbara Slifka, as well as Paul and Joseph and Tony in St Thomas. Services will be held at Frank E Campbell, 81st Street and Madison Avenue on Wednesday at 11:00am. In lieu if flowers, donations can be made to The New York Service for the Handicapped, Camp Oakhurst, 1140 Broadway, Suite 903, New York City 10001 in her memory.

SLIFKA--Alan B. UJA-Federation of New York mourns with sadness the passing of our cherished friend and supporter, Alan B. Slifka, a former board member and prominent leader who has strengthened the Jewish community in New York, in Israel, and around the world through his exceptional commitment and generosity. Recognized for his devotion to Jewish education and humanitarian causes, he inspired others through his tireless efforts to promote co-existence in Israel and worldwide. We extend our condolences to his wife, Riva Ariella Ritvo-Slifka; his sister, Barbara; his children, Michael, Randolph (Jan), and David (Michele); his stepchildren, Torrie, Skye, and Max Ritvo; and the entire family. Jerry W. Levin, President; Alisa R. Doctoroff, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

POLLAK--Martha H.,age 92, of Bethesda Md formerly of Manchester NJ died on Saturday, February 5, 2011 after a long illness. She was predeceased by her husband Ernest six months ago. She is survived by her son Mark (Janet Meyers) also of Bethesda, and grandchildren Zoe, Todd, and Adina. Graveside services today in Maryland.

GLASS--Ruth Mersel, 99, of Wayland, MA, and previously of long residence in New Rochelle, NY, passed away on February 3, 2011, after a brief illness. Predeceased by her husband, Irving R. Glass, of 56 years, she is survived by her sons Jeremy Mersel (Linda) of Newton, MA, and Jonathan (Jane Crandell), of Shreveport, LA; grandchildren Deborah, Andrew, David, Charles, and Jonathan, and ten great-grandchildren. An inveterate New Yorker, she traveled the world widely with her husband, Executive VP of the Tanners' Council and Leather Industries of America, including trips to the Soviet Union, China, and Japan. Ruth was a great champion of the "life of the mind" and encouraged each of her children, grandchildren, and great-grandchildren to pursue their intellectual and artistic dreams. She will be greatly missed and cherished forever. Her memory may be honored by donations to Dr. Jonathan Glass Cancer Research Fund, Feist-Weiller Cancer Center, LSUHS Foundation, 1501 Kings Highway, Shreveport, LA 71106.
