AUERBACH--Philip B.,died February 4, 2011, survived by his loved and loving family, his wife of 67 years, Augusta, sons Howard (Mickey) and Richard, daughter-in-law, Andrea and beloved granddaughter, Joy. He was a graduate of Brooklyn Technical High School, The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art and the Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn. Prior to retirement, he served as Vice President and General Manager of Sperry Corporation's Tactical Systems Division and was the founder and first President of Paramax Systems, a Canadian subsidiary of Sperry. He was an active alumnus of Cooper Union and served on its Board of Trustees. He was awarded Cooper's President's Citation in 1981 and Gano Dunn Award for achievement in science and engineering in 1987. Loved and admired by all who knew him.

This morning I decide to try a little experiment: I opened up my iPad, clicked on the little Wired icon and purchased the magazine's latest digital issue. After I agreed to fork over $4, it began downloading. For the next phase of the experiment, I grabbed my car keys, left my apartment and drove about 12 blocks to a local magazine store in Brooklyn, where I also purchased the latest issue of Wired magazine, this time in print. I didn't run any red lights, or speed, or park illegally during my shopping expedition. Yet when I returned home with the glossy paper product in hand, the digital iPad version still hadn't finished downloading to my iPad. Anybody who reads Wired would call this an Epic Fail.

WINANT--Rivington R.,affectionately known as "Riv", passed away suddenly Thursday evening, February 3, after courageously fighting a prolonged illness. He served in the Marine Corps in the South Pacific during WWII fighting in the Battle of Okinawa. He then spent six months in China with a detachment of the 6th Marine Division. A graduate of Balliol College of Oxford University, England, a financial analyst and longtime Treasurer of the United Nations, he is survived by his spouse Joan O'Meara Winant, nephews Charles Velando, John G. Winant, Jr., and Marion Eppley Winant. Remembered with great love by his many in-laws, friends and colleagues around the world. A memorial service is planned for the end of February.

For Bruce Josten, the feisty top lobbyist for the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, it got personal last fall on a Sunday talk show when President Obama's spokesman invoked his name. ''They called me out'' during a White House attack on the chamber's midterm campaign efforts, Mr. Josten recalled. Mr. Obama had his own reason to take things personally; his policies were on the receiving end of a $50 million ''voter education'' barrage by the chamber, the signature lobby for American business.

SLIFKA--Alan B.,a prominent New York investment manager and philanthropist died on Friday, February 4, 2011 at home after a battle with cancer. Mr. Slifka is survived by his beloved wife Riva Ariella Ritvo-Slifka, his sister Barbara Slifka, his children, Michael, Randolph (Jan), and David (Michele) Slifka, his stepchildren Torrie, Skye and Max Ritvo and his grandchildren Grace Gill, Joshua Slifka and Braylan Ritvo. Born in New York City in 1929, Mr. Slifka graduated from the Fieldston School, received his B.S. from Yale in 1951, and his M.B.A. from Harvard in 1953. In 2003, he received an honorary Doctorate from Brandeis University and also in 2008 Mr. Slifka received an Honorary Doctorate in the field of Coexistence from Haifa University. Mr. Slifka was the founder and co-chairman of Halcyon Asset Management LLC. He was also the founding chairman of the Big Apple Circus which became an institution in New York. In 1989 he co-founded The Abraham Fund Initiatives, which is the first not-for-profit organization whose purpose is to further coexistence between Israel's Jewish and Arab citizens. At the time of his death, he was an honorary trustee of the Abraham Joshua Heschel School in NY. Mr. Slifka was instrumental in the development and expansion of the school. Additionally, he was a member of the boards of the Jewish Funders Network, the Tannenbaum Center, the Interfaith Center, and the American Jewish Congress. In 2001, Mr. Slifka established the Slifka Program on Intercommunal Coexistence at Brandeis University. Mr. Slifka was passionate about and committed to coexistence, Judaism, and Israel. He founded the Alan B. Slifka Foundation through which he could impact his love for Israel and his commitment to Jewish life and coexistence. We, the Slifka family, will deeply mourn Alan's loss. He was our strong and loving leader, always inspiring us to serve humanity, grow in our faith, and embrace and respect differences. We will continue his mission of Tikun Olam. The funeral service will be private. A memorial service will be held at B'nai Jeshurun synagogue on April 10th, 2011 at 11am. For more information please call 212-303-9442. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to The Abraham Fund Initiatives, The Big Apple Circus or the Abraham Joshua Heschel School.

SLIFKA--Alan. We note with sadness the loss of Alan Slifka, a dear friend for more than 60 years. In his personal, professional and philanthropic careers, Alan represented the best our society has to offer. He lives on in his good works, which were many and varied, and in the wonderful example he set for us all. Dan and Joanna Rose

After months of wrangling, a successful end may be near for the merger talks between Sanofi-Aventis and Genzyme. The two companies are in the final stages of discussions over what would likely be a $19 billion takeover of Genzyme by Sanofi, people briefed on the matter told DealBook on Sunday. The talks have taken longer than expected because of due diligence work on Sanofi's part, as the French drug maker continues to pore over Genzyme's books.

JOHNSON--Boine Theodore. The Amateur Comedy Club salutes our esteemed colleague Boine, who died February 4 in White Plains at 79. Elected to the club in 1965, he was a cherished fixture in many roles: video archivist, historically minded curtain speaker, dress code stickler, Green Room raconteur. He served as president 1986-88, and was inspirational founder and fierce champion of the Century Fund endowment. His meatballs will be missed whenever we dine; he and his wise counsel always.

He was a man cherished for his heart, his intellect, his devotion to the Jewish community, and his commitment to all humanity. A memorial service and shiva will be held in Sarasota, Florida.

My column this week describes a new strategy for improving the performance of government programs. In short, private investors -- typically foundations -- pay the costs of a new program in its early years, and the government later repays the investors, often with a bonus, as long as the program meets its goals. If it fails, taxpayers pay nothing.

Investors in Diamondback Partners, one of four hedge funds raided by federal authorities in November amid a widening investigation of suspected insider trading on Wall Street, have asked for more than $500 million back from the firm, according to the fund's latest investor letter..The amount, totaling $534 million, represents around 9.4 percent of Diamondback's total assets, according to the letter, defying expectations that the firm would experience enormous outflows after it was implicated in the investigation. The elements behind the success of "The Social Network," as its makers rarely tire of telling us, were an odd mix. There were no stars, save for a pop singer; a subject that was an Internet punch line even before the Internet heard its actual punch lines; directed by a visual mastermind, David Fincher, and based on the pulsing dialogue of Aaron Sorkin - both of them big personalities with opposing styles. Mr. Fincher has been nominated for an Oscar and Mr. Sorkin has already been rewarded; he just won the Writers Guild of America award for best adapted screenplay and is likely to pick up the Oscar in that category as well. Based on recent episodes of  "Glee" and the ever-changing loyalties of its characters (not to mention their ever-intertwining love lives), we have absolutely no idea where this hit Fox musical-comedy is headed in the weeks to come. But we know where the cast members will be in May and June: they'll be hitting the road for another tour of North American arenas and performance spaces. On Tuesday Fox said that a 16-city "Glee Live! in Concert" series will begin on May 21 at the Mandalay Bay Events Center in Las Vegas and conclude on June 18 at the Nassau Coliseum in Uniondale, N.Y. (Another performance in the New York area will be on June 16 at the Izod Center in East Rutherford, N.J.; interestingly, no performance has been scheduled on June 12, the date that the Tony Awards are presented.) A statement from Fox said that the show, conceived by the "Glee" co-creator Ryan Murphy, will feature songs performed on the series, including "Empire State of Mind," "Toxic," "It's My Life" and - deal with it - "Don't Stop Believin'."

Mr. Dudamel will conduct all nine Mahler symphonies, some with the Philharmonic and others with the Simon Bolivar Symphony Orchestra, the flagship orchestra of Venezuela's nationwide music education system. He will also conduct the Philharmonic in ''Don Giovanni,'' followed by the other Mozart operas with librettos by Lorenzo Da Ponte in succeeding seasons (''Le Nozze di Figaro'' and ''Cosi Fan Tutte''). A major new work by John Adams, a composer closely associated with the Philharmonic, will have its premiere. Called ''The Gospel According to the Other Mary,'' it is a 90-minute oratorio based on New Testament texts and Latin American poetry.

Marty Markowitz, the Brooklyn borough president, was fined $2,000 by the New York City Conflicts of Interest Board for using his chief of staff as his lawyer when he bought a home in 2009, the board announced on Monday. Documents released by the board said that when Mr. Markowitz asked Mr. Scissura to recommend a lawyer to handle the closing of his new home in Windsor Terrace, Mr. Scissura suggested a lawyer, Leslie Lombard, who worked at his law firm.

TRAINA--John A.,Jr., (September 26, 1931 February 1, 2011) passed away last Tuesday in San Francisco. Beloved father and grandfather, notable society figure, entrepreneur, civic leader and San Francisco legend, John Traina attended Grant School, Lowell High School, graduated from Stanford University '53, and served in the U.S. Army in the Pacific. He enjoyed a long and respected career in shipping (American President Lines, Grace Lines, Prudential Lines, Delta Lines) and was among the first to start cruises into China. Traina engaged in numerous pursuits, with vineyards in the Napa Valley, was the author of two books ("Extraordinary Jewels" and "The Faberge' Case"), was a world traveler and famous collector of important objects. He had the largest collection of Faberge' cigarette boxes exhibited in museums around the world. Interested in everything, engaged in many endeavors, beloved by all, Traina had a passion for exotic travel, lived in Washington, D.C. in the 1960's, and loved his homes in San Francisco and the Napa Valley. He was extremely elegant, known for his impeccable style and limitless charm, he added glamour and sophistication to the San Francisco social scene for his entire life. He is survived by three sons, Trevor, Todd and Maxx, and four daughters, Samantha, Victoria, Vanessa, and Zara, and was the father of the late Nick Traina. He was the stepfather of Beatrix Lazard Seidenberg. And he was the grandfather of Johnny and Delphina Traina, Daisy Traina, and Sebastian and Isabel Seidenberg. He is also survived by two ex-wives Diane "Dede" Buchanan Wilsey, and Danielle Steel. He was married to each for 17 years. He is also survived by a sister, Marisa Traina Hahn, three nephews and a niece. Funeral services will be held privately. A memorial service will be held at The Maritime Museum, 900 Beach Street, San Francisco, 94109, on Friday, 11 February, at 2:00pm. The family requests that memorials be contributions to the California Historical Society, 678 Mission Street, San Francisco, 94105, or The Nick Traina Foundation, P.O. Box 470427, San Francisco, 94147.

Her contagious laughter, quick wit and sense of humor will always be remembered. Lois was devoted to family and friends, especially her five grandchildren, who lovingly called her Gigi. She was a highly regarded and dedicated Realtor in Larchmont, New York for over 30 years and became life long friends with many of her clients and co-workers. She is survived by her husband, Leonard, her two children, Shari Philipps and Jonathan Lichter, her five grandchildren, Emma, Laine, Paige, Aaron and Harrison and her sister, Brenda Frank. Funeral services will be held at 11am on Wednesday, February 9th at Larchmont Temple, 75 Larchmont Ave, Larchmont, NY 10538.

FAGENSON--Josephine Krakower, passed peacefully on Saturday morning, February 5th, unaware that her dear cousin, Alan Slifka, had passed only several hours earlier. A lifetime resident of Manhattan and Deal, New Jersey, she enjoyed thirty five wonderful winters in St Thomas in the Virgin Islands with her beloved late husband of over sixty years, Bertram, whom she has missed terribly these last ten years. She was predeceased by her loving twin brother, Arnold Krakower and is survived by her two sons, Toby and Robert and their wives, Jane and Margaret; her granddaughters Stephanie Fagenson and Jennifer Fagenson Young and her husband, Josh and her much adored great granddaughter, the light of her life in recent months, Sophie. A woman of exceptional beauty, grace and charm, she was the consummate hostess to friends and family. With a wry sense of humor and a sharp tongue and wit, she was a commanding presence in any setting. Weekend barbecues at her home usually numbered fourteen or more with her favorite aunt and uncle, the late Sylvia and Joe Slifka and her mother, Lil Krakower and Uncle Sidney and Aunt Vicky. She lived a full life surrounded by family and friends. Annie and Princess and Enid who took such good care of her for a lifetime and later Elsie, Maureen, Gilian, Sarah and Desiree. She wanted to bid a special farewell to her dear friends Bernice, Anice, Honey and Suzanne and of course her dear cousin Barbara Slifka, as well as Paul and Joseph and Tony in St Thomas. Services will be held at Frank E Campbell, 81st Street and Madison Avenue on Wednesday at 11:00am. In lieu if flowers, donations can be made to The New York Service for the Handicapped, Camp Oakhurst, 1140 Broadway, Suite 903, New York City 10001 in her memory.

MITCHELL--Irma Clurman, died peacefully on February 6, 2011, in Ojai, California, after a short illness, at the age of 95. She was the daughter of Morris J. Clurman, M.D., and of Elsie Abrams Clurman; the niece of Harold Clurman, the theater director; and the widow of Nathan Mitchell, M.D., who died in 2003. She grew up in Brooklyn and received a B.A. in French from Hunter College. Dr. and Mrs. Mitchell lived in Boro Park for many years; they moved to East 57th Street in Manhattan in the late 1960s, and then to Palm Beach Gardens, Florida, in the late 1980s. She was a sculptor, and the highlight of her career was five different shows of her animal sculptures in the windows of Tiffany's on Fifth Avenue. She was cheerful and funny until shortly before the end, a sweet, kind woman, and a devoted mother. She is survived by her two sons, Stephen and Bob; her daughters-in-law, Katie and Susan; her grandchildren, Noah, Jenny, and Sarah; and her great-grandchildren, Stephen and Gavon.

Phylicia Rashad will receive the lifetime achievement award at the 19th annual Pan African Film Festival, officials said on Monday. The festival, which will take place in Los Angeles Feb. 16 to 23, showcases films by and about people from the African diaspora. This year's a lineup includes more than 120 films representing more than 30 countries. ''She is a modern-day griot,'' Ayuko Babu, the festival's executive director and co-founder said of Ms. Rashad. ''Over the years she has had parts that give insight into who we are, from August Wilson's 'Gem of the Ocean' to 'The Cosby Show.' She speaks to us and lets the world know who we are, on a high intellectual level and on an emotional level. Black folks across the world have a lot of respect for her.''

Direct descendant of Governor William Bradford, first governor and historian of the Plymouth Colony, MA and a niece of Edna Mead, a poet published often in the New York Times and James O. Spearing, the New York Times first automobile editor in the 1930's. Funeral Services will be in New Haven, CT at the convenience of the immediate family. Interment will be in New Haven City Burial Ground--Grove Street Cemetery.

It was arguably the most anticipated new musical of the season and then, just as arguably, one of the most critically derided. It struggled with technical problems and last-minute revisions once the production was already on its feet. And now it has received the most nominations in a prestigious theater-award competition. No, it's not the Broadway adventures of a certain red-and-blue web-slinger (though the team behind ''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark'' would surely love the same outcome): we're talking about ''Love Never Dies,'' Andrew Lloyd Webber's sequel to ''The Phantom of the Opera,'' which on Monday received seven nominations for the Olivier Awards, the British equivalent of the Tonys, more than any other musical. The Society of London Theater, which represents West End theaters and producers and organizes the awards, nominated Ramin Karimloo, who portrays the Phantom, for best actor in a musical; Sierra Boggess, who plays his love, Christine, for best actress; and ''Love Never Dies'' for best new musical, alongside ''Fela!,'' ''Legally Blonde'' and ''Love Story.''

GITTLER--Rosalie Derham. On Friday, February 4, 2011 in New York. A devoted wife, mother and friend who touched many people's lives. First trained as a nurse, and later as a hospital administrator, Rosalie served in the U.S. Navy where she met her beloved husband Robert, starting a 50-year love affair. A graduate of Yale and Columbia Universities, Rosalie served in hospital administration at Memorial and Maimonides Hospitals before dedicating herself full time to caring for her husband and son Andrew. Rosalie's love for the elegance of life was unsurpassed, and she cultivated a sense of style and grace that will be cherished. French language and culture were her passions, and Rosalie was most content traveling with her husband through the French countryside. Rosalie's friends and family will remember many fond memory-filled weekends in West Hampton Beach and Quogue playing cards or seeing her absorbed in her latest French novel. She took great pride in her grandsons, Daniel and Evan. A memorial service is planned for Saturday, February 12th at 10:30am at St. Thomas More Church, 65 East 89th Street, NY. In lieu of flowers, gifts may be made to the Palliative Medicine Unit at Lenox Hill Hospital, 100 East 77th Street, New York, NY 10075.

ALBANY - A week after he criticized Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo's budget as unfair to New York City, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg appeared before lawmakers on Monday and offered grim examples to prove his point.Classroom crowding would worsen, he said. More than a third of the city's senior citizen centers would close. The scale of layoffs, in the schools and at government agencies, would be ''devastating.'' But when he was done chronicling the budgetary fallout that lies ahead, Mr. Bloomberg sounded a note of detente. The city, he said, would largely accept the proposed cuts, which by his math add up to $2.1 billion, but he wants something in return.

QUIGLEY--Martin S.,Writer, editor, publisher, educator, mayor, sailor and spy, died of natural causes at home in West Hartford, CT., February 5, 2011. Born in Chicago on November 24, 1917, he is survived by his wife of 65 years, Katherine Dunphy Quigley, his sister Mary Q. Eller, nine children and their spouses, 27 grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. Dr. Quigley graduated from Loyola High School in New York City and was first in his class at Georgetown University in 1939, where he founded the Georgetown Sailing Club. He received his M.A. and a Doctorate in Education, from Columbia University almost forty years after his undergraduate degree. During World War II, Martin Quigley was a spy for the United States attached to the Special Intelligence Division of the Office of Strategic Services (OSS) engaged in undercover work in Ireland and Italy. While some material concerning his work is still classified nearly 70 years later, he wrote two books about his clandestine activities: A U.S. Spy in Ireland and Peace Without Hiroshima. Quigley spent most of his career leading the motion picture trade publishing company, Quigley Publishing Company, founded by his father in 1915. He started as a reporter for the Motion Picture Daily, became editor of the Motion Picture Herald in 1949, editorial director of all the publications in 1956 and was president from 1964 to 2001. Quigley was chairman of the health education committee of the Will Rogers Institute from 1980 to 1997. As one of the most important figures in motion picture trade journalism, he was the editor or author of five books about movies, including the classic work, Magic Shadows The History of the Origin of Motion Pictures. From 1977 to 1990, Quigley was an adjunct professor at Baruch College of the City University of New York and Teachers College, Columbia University, where he authored a book on the role played by community colleges in expanding access to higher education. A devout Roman Catholic, Dr. Quigley was very involved in religious and ecumenical matters. He was a member of the Board of Trustees of the American Bible Society since 1964, and was a former chairman of both the Religious Education Association and the Laymen's National Bible Association. A sixty plus year resident of Larchmont, NY, following service as a village trustee in 1980, he was the first Democrat elected mayor since the Great Depression. An avid lifelong sailor, he was a member of the Larchmont Yacht Club and enjoyed sailing with the LYC Cruising Club, even skippering a 42-foot Beneteau at the start of a race four years ago. A long time Rotary Club member, he was given the Paul Harris Distinguished Rotarian Award both in Larchmont and West Hartford. In addition to his wife and sister, he is survived by his children: Dr. Martin Quigley of St. Petersburg, FL, Elin Quigley of Garrett Park, MD, William Quigley of Groton, MA, Kevin Quigley of Arlington, VA, Karen Quigley of Portland, OR, Patricia Quigley of Concord, NH, John Quigley of Cumming, GA, Kate Quigley Lynch of West Hartford, CT and Peter Quigley of Duxbury, MA. The family wishes to extend their deepest thanks and appreciation for the tremendous care and support given by VNA Hospice. Family will receive friends on Thursday from 4-7pm at the Molloy Funeral Home, 906 Farmington Ave., West Hartford, CT. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated on Friday at 10am at St. Peter Claver Church, 47 Pleasant St., West Hartford. Online expressions of sympathy may be made at: www.molloyfuneralhome.com

The hedge fund manager David Einhorn does not seem to mind revealing his bets against a company, at least on his own terms. Over the years, Mr. Einhorn, the founder of Greenlight Capital, has announced several major short positions, most notably in 2008 when he publicly derided Lehman Brothers just months before the investment bank collapsed.

Although national signing day was last Wednesday, there is still plenty of intrigue surrounding the nation's top recruit, Jadeveon Clowney, who has put off announcing his decision until Feb. 14. Clowney, a defensive end from South Carolina, decided to wait in part so that he could see how teams fared on signing day. As it turns out, Clowney's choice to delay his announcement might have helped Clemson's chances.

KURZ--Edythe, Edythe Kurz, a therapist and psychiatric social worker who dedicated her life to family, friends, and those in need, died, age 85, Saturday, January 29, 2011 in Nyack, New York, after a long illness. Born Edythe Levin in Bennington, Vermont on March 31, 1925, her family moved to Jackson Heights, Queens where she attended Richmond Hill High School. She earned a bachelor's degree from the University of Michigan and a master's degree in social work from Columbia University. Edythe married Herbert Kurz on March 21, 1948. They moved to Brooklyn where they had two children, Leonard and Ellen. In 1959 they moved to Rockland County. Kurz worked with children and families at the Pleasantville Cottage School, St. Agatha Home for Children, the Whitehill Counseling Service, and the Westchester Jewish Community Services. This led to a private practice as a therapist in Rockland, Westchester, elsewhere. She brought her professional experience to her work in philanthropy as a founding director of the Kurz Family Foundation. Among the programs and institutions she helped establish are the annual Edythe Kurz Conference at Westchester Jewish Community Services in White Plains, NY and the Ewen Academic Freedom Center at NYU. Edythe is survived by her husband of 63 years, Herbert, their son Leonard, daughter Ellen, and grandchildren Tommy and Sophie.

Ensco, a London-based offshore oil drilling contractor, announced on Monday that it would acquire Pride International of Houston for $7.3 billion in cash and stock. The merger will create the second largest offshore driller in the world, with 74 rigs spanning 25 countries on six continents. The combined company will have 21 ultra deepwater and deepwater rigs.

Plants, like many other organisms, have circadian clocks that help them anticipate environmental and biological events that occur at precise times of the day. Processes like photosynthesis, fragrance emission and time of bloom are regulated by this timekeeping mechanism. Now, researchers report in the journal Nature that genes in certain plants fend off infections with the help of the clock as well.

FAGENSON--Josephine. On behalf of the employees and shareholders at Document Security Systems, Inc. including CEO Patrick White, COO Bob Bzdick and CFO Philip Jones, we would like to offer our sincere condolences to our Chairman Robert Fagenson on the passing of his mother, Josephine Fagenson. We also offer our sympathies and prayers of comfort to not only Robert, but to all the family members, friends and relatives of Josephine whom we understand led a wonderful, full life and touched the hearts of all who were graced by her friendship and presence.

An article on Dec. 29 about a church in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, that is divided between Spanish speakers and Chinese immigrants misstated its origins. Though historians are not able to determine exactly what mix of ethnic groups founded the church more than a century ago, it is known that it was not built by Norwegian immigrants. A reader pointed out the error in an e-mail in January; this correction was delayed for research.

KRANTZ--Rabbi Abraham, of West Nyack, on February 7, 2011 at age 89. Born October 2, 1921 to Reubin and Clara Kranz. He served in WWII and went on to become a Rabbi. He served as Pulpit Rabbi for several congregations and as Chaplain for the Bronx VA Hospital and Rockland Psychiatric Hospital. On December 22, 1946 he married the late Jane Krantz. Survived by his children, Deborah Feldman (Marc), Melissa Krantz (David Fleisher) and Jeremy Krantz (Robin) and grandchildren, Jenny and Russell Fishman, Sara Fleisher, Rachel Feldman, Amanda Krantz, Emily Krantz, Noah Krantz and Ethan Krantz. Funeral service today 9:30am First Hebrew Congregation of Peekskill 1821 E. Main Street followed by interment at Mt. Pleasant Cemetery. For more information, Zion Memorial Chapel 914-381-1809.

The Securities and Exchange Commission is nearly broke. Not just ''broke'' as in it failed to regulate Wall Street or that it missed catching Bernard L. Madoff's Ponzi scheme. But ''broke'' as in it is out of money.

RUBINFELD--Seymour, passed away on February 7th after a brief illness. He had a passion for life which he shared with all his family and friends. Sy was born May 11, 1923 to Lewis and Ida Rubinfeld and is survived by his wife of 62 years Shirley (Rocky), three married sons Howard and Dale, Fred and Giles, Ira and Willa, six grandchildren, and one great grandchild. Sy was predeceased by his sister Shirley. Sy was a warrant officer for the US Army during WWII. He learned to ski while stationed in Europe and brought that passion back which he passed on to his children and grandchildren. Sy was an avid golfer and a member of the Old Westbury G&CC, and recently became a skilled bridge player. Sy developed a successful business in the sportswear industry under the name Character Suburbanwear which he retired from in 1998. Services: Wednesday, 1:30pm, Parkside Chapels, 9860 Queens Blvd, Rego Park. Interment will be at Mt Lebanon Cemetery in Glendale. For more information visit: jewish-funeral-home.com. Donations may be made to Old Westbury Hebrew Congregation, The Belleayre Conservatory Highmount, NY or a charity of the donor's choice.

In agreeing to buy The Huffington Post for $315 million, AOL is putting what appears to be a significant premium on the ability to attract and build a community of readers. Yet as more and more advertising dollars flow to the Web and to mobile devices, demand for popular and prolific online content producers like The Huffington Post, is rising. The market for online advertising is expected to increase 14 percent, to $51.9 billion, this year, according to the research firm Borrell Associates.

Berkshire Hathaway, the holding company led by Warren E. Buffett, has agreed to buy the remaining shares of Wesco Financial Corporation, one of its largest subsidiaries, for $547.6 million in stock and cash, the companies announced Monday. The ties between the companies run deep. The relationship started in the early 1970s when Berkshire indirectly invested roughly $30 million in Wesco; Berkshire has owned an 80.1 percent share since 1983. Wesco, which is based Pasadena, Calif., is run by Charles T. Munger, Berkshire's vice chairman and Mr. Buffett's longtime business partner.

WINANT--Rivington. The Board of Directors of Americans for Oxford and the entire Oxford community mourn the passing of Riv Winant. A loyal and devoted Oxonian throughout his life, Riv inspired all with his generosity, humor, and keen interest in a wide variety of projects and programs within the University. We extend our sincere condolences to Joan and the Winant family. Paul M. Dodyk, Chairman, Americans for Oxford; Michael G. Cunningham, Director, Oxford NA Office.

Banco Santander, the Spanish lender, said on Monday that it was offering 16.6 billion zloty ($5.82 billion) for Bank Zachodni WBK of Poland, which has been controlled by Allied Irish Banks. Santander is looking to expand into Poland, Eastern Europe's biggest market, by acquiring all of Zachodni's shares for 226.89 zloty each, according to a statement. Allied Irish, effectively nationalized last year after the collapse of Ireland's real estate bubble left it ostracized by international credit markets, has been forced to divest itself of its 70 percent stake as it tries to raise capital.

The Democratic Leadership Council, which for more than two decades preached a centrist brand of politics embodied by President Bill Clinton, is suspending its dwindling operations, the organization's founder said in a statement e-mailed to The Caucus late Monday. Al From, who founded the council in the mid-1980s as a vehicle to prod Democratic politicians toward the political cehttp://thecaucus.blogs.nytimes.com/wp-admin/index.phpnter, said the group was considering how it can find a new purpose in modern-day politics.

SLIFKA--Alan B. The partners and employees of Halcyon Asset Management LLC mourn the passing of Alan B. Slifka, our founder, colleague and friend, who died on Friday, February 4. After graduating from Yale University and Harvard Business School, Mr. Slifka started his career at L.F. Rothschild, where he became partner in charge of risk arbitrage. In 1981 he established our firm, which began investing with assets of $50 million; today Halcyon manages over $10 billion. Until recent years, Mr. Slifka was active in a variety of not-for-profits, several of which he helped found. He conducted his professional and philanthropic lives with a keen sense of fiduciary responsibility. He took a passionate, businesslike approach to the activities of the charities he supported, which benefited from his intense involvement as board member, benefactor, and tireless fundraiser. Through good times and bad, his support for the firm, its investors and associates, and his philanthropies was steadfast. We extend our condolences to his wife, Riva Ritvo Slifka; his sons Michael, Randy, and David; his sister, Barbara Slifka; his step-children Victoria, Skye and Max; his grandchildren Grace and Joshua and step-grandson Braylan; and the extended Slifka family. His warmth, vision, and generosity of spirit will be missed.

Fox and the producers of ''X Factor'' said Monday that they would award the winner of their forthcoming singing competition a Sony Music record deal worth $5 million. That record deal would be ''the largest guaranteed prize in television history,'' the companies said in a statement.

ABRAHAM--Robert. The Woodmere Club deeply regrets the passing of our good friend and long-time member Robert Abraham. Our heartfelt sympathies are extended to his family and friends. Board of Governors The Woodmere Club

SLIFKA--Alan. The Board of Trustees and staff of The Educational Alliance mourn the passing of prominent philanthropist Alan Slifka, brother of our friend and generous supporter Barbara Slifka. We offer our sincere condolences to the entire Slifka family.

''Fahrenheit 9/11,'' Michael Moore's 2004 documentary about President George W. Bush, is still generating heat. Mr. Moore on Monday filed suit against Bob and Harvey Weinstein, who formed Fellowship Adventure Group to distribute ''Fahrenheit 9/11'' in an alliance with Lionsgate and IFC Films, claiming that the Weinsteins defrauded him of at least $2.7 million in profits from the film. The suit, filed in Los Angeles County Superior Court, charged the Weinsteins with ''accounting tricks and financial deception'' in connection with ''Fahenheit 9/11,'' which took in about $222 million at the worldwide box office, and millions more on home video. Bert Fields, a lawyer for the Weinsteins, said Mr. Moore had been paid everything he was due, and was trying to make a public spectacle out of what he called ''a routine kind of auditing'' dispute. ''Mr. Moore has put in a number of very inflammatory claims designed for the press,'' Mr. Fields added. ''He should be ashamed of himself.'' Larry Stein, a lawyer for Mr. Moore, said in a statement that Mr. Moore had never sued anyone in his filmmaking career and that ''it's very sad that it had to come to this.''Mr. Moore and the Weinsteins have worked together on several films, including ''Sicko'' and ''The Big One.'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

The Los Angeles County Museum of Art and the J. Paul Getty Trust said on Monday they had jointly acquired a huge collection of the prints, negatives and letters of Robert Mapplethorpe, further strengthening California's position as a major center for 20th-century photography. The acquisition is the first time the two institutions have collected works of art to share, in a partnership they formed to compete more effectively against other major museums being considered by the Robert Mapplethorpe Foundation as homes for the collection. The foundation is donating the majority of the more than 2,000 photographs - including Mapplethorpe silver-gelatin prints and Polaroid works - and the Getty and the county museum, with help from the David Geffen Foundation, are buying the rest.

Keith Olbermann, the former top-rated host of ''Countdown'' on the news channel MSNBC, will announce his next television home on Tuesday, and people familiar with his plans pointed Monday to a possible deal with the public affairs channel Current TV. Neither Mr. Olbermann, his representatives, or executives from Current TV would comment on the move, but they did not deny that the channel, which counts former Vice President Al Gore as one of its founders, will become at least one partner in Mr. Olbermann's future media plans.

SLIFKA--Alan B. Tanenbaum Center for Interreligious Understanding's Board, Leadership Council and staff mourn the passing of Founding Leadership Council member Alan B. Slifka. We have lost a giant. Tanenbaum extends our sympathy to his devoted wife, Riva, and to their children and grandchildren.

In my column today, I talk about two videos that demonstrate the brutality exhibited by elements of the Egyptian regime. Both have been on TV, but if you haven't seen them take a look. Dame Vivienne Westwood's collections have gone through more transformations than Jocelyn Wildenstein. From bohemian to punk and even paganism, Westwood's pieces channel her ideas through fashion. Her latest offering, the Get a Life jewelry collection (produced in conjunction with the Palladium Alliance International), is intended to represent "hope, renewal and preservation." Launching during London Fashion Week with a kickoff soiree at the Wallace Collection (London's answer to the Frick), the pieces are made entirely from - you guessed it - palladium, a natural material. All of the pieces are inscribed with messages from Westwood's eco-conscious spring/summer 2010 collection, which was called Planet Gaia. What better way to wear your heart near your sleeve? The necklace will be available to order this spring at Vivienne Westwood boutiques in Los Angeles, or go to viviennewestwood.co.uk.

The Pacific walrus is imperiled by climate change, which is melting its icy Arctic home, and merits protection under the Endangered Species Act, the federal Fish and Wildlife Service said this week. Yet protections must wait until threats to higher-priority species are addressed, the agency said.

SACRAMENTO - As states across the country struggle to deal with massive budget deficits, a number - including California - have resorted to attempting to sell state office buildings, pouring the proceeds into the general funds, and lease back the space. Arnold Schwarzenegger, the former governor of California, was one of those, moving to sell and lease back 11 state office buildings, providing $1.2 billion in revenues to a state budget that sorely needs it.

Jonathan Taggart, 26, a photojournalist based in Vancouver, British Columbia, focuses largely on the indigenous communities of Canada. He is a 2008 graduate of Ryerson University in Toronto and teaches photography to aboriginal youths. His work has been published in The Globe and Mail and in Toronto Life Magazine. He is a founder of Boreal Collective, a documentary photo group. Kerri MacDonald's conversation with Mr. Taggart for Turning Point has been edited and condensed.

The rise of e-books and declining store sales have led to layoffs at Powell's Books, the landmark bookstore in Portland, Ore. The store's management said on Tuesday it would lay off 31 employees as part of its "response to the unprecedented, rapidly changing nature of the book industry." Ryan Takas, the union representative for the employees who were laid off, said that the 31 employees make up more than 7 percent of the store's 400-person unionized work force. Mr. Takas said that Powell's had reduced its work force by about 40 employees in the last year through attrition, but still felt that layoffs were necessary because of a decline in sales of new books and a rise in health care costs. It was the first round of layoffs since the store's workers formed a union in 2000.

It is now a stripped-down, dimly lit Gothic church that is painted an Armani gray and is dedicated to a real Madonna, the source of Vezzoli's diva complex - his own mother.

After a couple of cycles in which an above-average number of incumbents have lost their seats in Congress, it's easy to forget that being an incumbent is normally an extremely powerful advantage. Political science models have generally found that the incumbency advantage amounts to 6 to 10 percentage points for a senator, meaning that an incumbent Democrat would be expected to get 56 to 60 percent of the vote in a state where a nonincumbent Democrat would get about 50 percent.

A spring-summer 2011 daydream: There is a collision of vehicles carrying bolts of material. Prada's stripes are unfurling in the street near a billowing pouf printed with lemons, grapefruits and oranges (Stella McCartney!). A band of wayward women have wrapped themselves in the cloth, like victorious marathoners. This imagined scene surfaces when presented with the paintings of Sydney Albertini. The East Hampton, N.Y.-based artist is perhaps best known for her whimsical pottery and quilting but is now ready to present her true love: painting. On the occasion of "Sydney Albertini: ephemere," a show of 20 large charcoal and oil works opening tonight at New York's French Institute Alliance Francaise, she shares her (kaleidoscopic) world.

The two discuss whether financial markets are in fact serving the needs of the economy, as opposed to just creating investment vehicles.

An article in Wednesday's Times describes how a routine procedure for the treatment of early breast cancer - the surgical removal of cancerous lymph nodes from the armpit - has been found unnecessary for many patients. The finding turns 100 years of standard medical practice on its head.

Christina Aguilera, Jennifer Hudson, Martina McBride, Yolanda Adams and Florence Welch will participate in the homage to the 68-year-old Ms. Franklin. Grammy sponsors are describing it as a "valentine" and a "get-well card" to Ms. Franklin, who has won 18 Grammys herself. She was hospitalized in Detroit late last year, underwent surgery for an undisclosed ailment and canceled several months' worth of scheduled performances.

As Oscar campaigns go, the street artist Banksy's is unusual - never showing up to schmooze (as far as we know), insulting other contenders, making a documentary that seems liked a hoax and leaving fellow filmmakers to debate whether that matters. A new video parodying his film, "Exit Through the Gift Shop," takes his uncampaigning even further. The "Exit Through the Pet Shop" trailer imagines what Banksy's movie would look like if it were populated by Keyboard Cats and I Can Has Cheezburger.

Lovers of Baroque art and architecture can add one more stop to their Rome travel itinerary: the recently inaugurated Museo Missionario di Propaganda Fide. The new museum, which documents four centuries of the Catholic Church's missionary work, has opened in part of the 17th-century Palazzo di Propaganda Fide, a masterpiece of Baroque architecture designed by the period's leading architects, Francesco Borromini and Gianlorenzo Bernini. Visitors to the museum will have access to halls and chapels in the Palazzo that are open to the public on a permanent basis for the first time.

WEINSTEIN--Jean, on February 9, 2011. Beloved wife of the late Sol. Devoted mother of Bobby and Francine and father-in-law of Dan Bleier. Cherished grandmother of Andy Miller. Services private.

TANNENBAUM--Paul, J. DDS. The New York Academy of Dentistry deeply mourns the sudden passing of our colleague and friend, Dr. Paul J. Tannenbaum, who died as a result of a tragic skiing accident on February 2nd. A Past President of the Academy, Paul will be remembered for his ongoing commitment to dentistry and his continued contributions to organized dentistry. He served in the military and was a dedicated researcher, teacher, a gifted clinician and photographer. We extend our sincere condolences to his family. He will be missed by all.

FRIEDMAN--Samuel Nathaniel, 94, grew up in a small apartment on Saratoga Avenue in Brownsville, Brooklyn, and died Monday night at his spacious park-view Central Park West apartment. He went the way he would have wanted to, having dinner with his wife, Barbara Somers, a gourmet cook. Sam, as he was known, had led a full and happy life until a few years ago when he began to have health problems. He was blind and wheelchair-bound at his death. But until the last few years, he was a force of nature for family and friends. Tall, handsome (a striking resemblance to Gregory Peck), a great story teller, a fabulous businessman and salesman, agricultural expert and possessed of exquisite taste. He wore off-the-rack clothing that looked as if it were bespoken. His favorite garment was a loose black shirt designed by friend, Massimo Vignelli. As a youth, Sam was an avid Zionist as was his father, Israel, an immigrant from Cracow and a union leader. Sam's mother Sarah immigrated from Siroka in what is now Moldova. He spent all his teens through the Depression years (he was thirteen at the crash of 1929) and had to work after school throughout his high school years to help support the family. Sam worked his way through Cornell and got a BS, '36, in diary chemistry. During summers, he worked as an apprentice on dairy farms upstate. His father had hopes Sam would go to what was then Palestine as a pioneer. But Sam was a committed American and moved to a then-new cooperative community in central New Jersey called Jersey Homesteads, later Roosevelt, where, with his first wife, Charlotte Safir, he raised three children - Miriam Aliminos, 60; Dinah Lefkowitz, 66; and Joshua Friedman, 69. At the end of WWII, a friend and neighbor, artist Ben Shahn, introduced Sam to Klaus Grabe, a Bauhaus-trained German architect who had fled to Mexico as a political refugee in the 1930's. Sam went to work for Klaus in his furniture business, which -- despite Sam's efforts-did not prosper. But Sam stayed in furniture, working for other firms -- Berge Norman and George Tanier -- and then started his own firm ICF (International Contract Furnishings) in 1962 with a friend from Tanier, Hal Stearns. Aided by furniture designer Pat Hoffman, who became his second wife, Sam built ICF into an iconic design firm. He introduced Americans to classic architect-designed European furniture of the early 20th Century--especially that of Finnish architect Alvar Aalto. ICF introduced to the United States market the work of Josef Hoffmann, Mario Botta, Philippe Starck and Richard Neutra, among others. At its height, ICF was blazing the way for a look that persists in executive suites around the U.S. When Pat Hoffman died of cancer, Sam was heartsick, sold ICF and retired. He spent the rest of his life gardening at his country home in Amagansett, entertaining in his city apartment, then on Park Ave., and traveling with Barbara, who became his third wife. But most of all, he loved doting on his grandchildren and great grandchildren: Miriam and husband Yannis' kids: Angelos, Kiki, Lysistrata, Cassandra; Dinah and Stephen Lefkowitz's kids: Benjamin and Bridget Bly (Nora and Zoe) and Jennifer and Robert Donahue (Cait and Samantha); and Josh and Carol Ash Friedman's daughter, Susannah and her fiance, Gareth Crawford. As if that weren't enough nachas, he also doted on his nieces and nephews, the children of his surviving brother, Abraham Friedman and wife Diana, and the children of his deceased sister Esther Swiller-and their kids' kids. Funeral service, Wednesday, 12:45pm at The Riverside, 331 Amsterdam Ave., at 76th St. Burial for family only will follow at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. For Shiva information contact Riverside at 212-362-6600. It was a full and happy life.

CARSKY--Katherine. The Westchester Community College family extends condolences to the family of our friend Katherine "Kay" Carsky. For decades, Kay had been a strong supporter of both the college and the Westchester Community College Foundation. Her lifelong interest in education led her to assist in the college's expansion during her successful tenure as a county legislator. This support continued after she left her government role and became a member of the foundation board. As a foundation board member, she was involved in various aspects of community outreach. She was also instrumental in a number of other projects including the structuring of student focus groups, the formulation of the foundation's strategic plan, and the implementation of the Gateway Center project which resulted in fundraising for and construction of a new classroom building in 2010. Kay was an active and dedicated member of the board and used her intelligence, wisdom accrued during her many years as a legislator, and natural warmth to help the college and foundation realize its many goals relating to educational access. She will be missed by the college's trustees, administrators, faculty, staff and students in addition to those who work with the foundation.
BRODSKY--Milton. Precious memories are treasures which last forever. With love, Grace and Ruth

A map on Jan. 28 with articles about major winter storms in the Northeast misstated the amount of snowfall above the normal level in New York City through January. With a total of 56.1 inches, New York was 45 inches above normal, not 28.9 inches above normal. The map also misstated the total snowfall for Boston at that point and the number of inches above normal through January. The total was 60.3 inches, with 38.9 inches above normal -- not 59.7 total inches, with 38.3 inches above normal. (The lower numbers were provided on Jan. 27 by Accuweather before the official data for Boston was revised by the National Weather Service.)

Two ironworkers died on Tuesday morning after falling 65 feet in an elevator shaft inside a building on the Upper West Side that is being redeveloped for a church, city officials said. The men fell, investigators believe, while they were installing steel beams in the elevator shaft on the fifth floor and one of the beams shifted. However, it appeared that several required protective measures were not in place, said Robert LiMandri, the commissioner of the Department of Buildings.

A critic's notebook on Jan. 7 about a new effort to sanitize the language of ''Huckleberry Finn'' misattributed another example of such efforts -- the editing of ''Out, damned spot!'' in Shakespeare's ''Macbeth'' to ''out, crimson spot!'' Some scholars cite an 1865 adaptation by Thomas Bulfinch and the Rev. S. G. Bulfinch as a source of that change; it was not Thomas Bowdler, the English doctor whose name produced the verb ''bowdlerize.''

MILWAUKEE -- It was exhilarating for Maricela Aguilar to stand on the steps of the federal courthouse here one day last summer and reveal for the first time in public that she is an illegal immigrant. ''It's all about losing that shame of who you are,'' Ms. Aguilar, a college student who was born in Mexico but has lived in the United States without legal documents since she was 3 years old, said of her ''coming out'' at a rally in June.

The doctor is out, temporarily, and headed back to Broadway: Robert Sean Leonard, who plays the infinitely patient oncologist Dr. James Wilson on the hit Fox medical drama ''House,'' will return to the stage in the coming revival of ''Born Yesterday,'' its press representatives said on Tuesday. Mr. Leonard is set to join the production as Paul Verrall, the journalist tasked with educating Billie Dawn, the showgirl and gal pal of the crooked mogul Harry Brock. This latest revival of the Garson Kanin play, which is to begin previews at the Cort Theater on March 31 and open on April 24, previously announced that it would star Jim Belushi (of ''According to Jim'') as Brock and Nina Arianda (''Venus in Fur'') as Dawn, and would be directed by Doug Hughes (''Doubt''). The original 1946 Broadway production starred Paul Douglas, Judy Holliday and Gary Merrill, and the 1950 film version starred Broderick Crawford, Ms. Holliday and William Holden. Mr. Leonard's previous theater credits include the Broadway production of Tom Stoppard's ''Invention of Love,'' which won him the Tony Award for featured actor in a play, as well as Broadway revivals of ''Candida'' and ''Long Day's Journey Into Night'' that earned him Tony nominations, and an ill-fated production of ''Midsummer Night's Dream'' seen in ''Dead Poets Society.''

FAGENSON--Josephine Krakower, passed peacefully on Saturday morning, February 5th, unaware that her dear cousin, Alan Slifka, had passed only several hours earlier. A lifetime resident of Manhattan and Deal, New Jersey, she enjoyed thirty five wonderful winters in St Thomas in the Virgin Islands with her beloved late husband of over sixty years, Bertram, whom she has missed terribly these last ten years. She was predeceased by her loving twin brother, Arnold Krakower and is survived by her two sons, Toby and Robert and their wives, Jane and Margaret; her granddaughters Stephanie Fagenson and Jennifer Fagenson Young and her husband, Josh and her much adored great granddaughter, the light of her life in recent months, Sophie. A woman of exceptional beauty, grace and charm, she was the consummate hostess to friends and family. With a wry sense of humor and a sharp tongue and wit, she was a commanding presence in any setting. Weekend barbecues at her home usually numbered fourteen or more with her favorite aunt and uncle, the late Sylvia and Joe Slifka and her mother, Lil Krakower and Uncle Sidney and Aunt Vicky. She lived a full life surrounded by family and friends. Annie and Princess and Enid who took such good care of her for a lifetime and later Elsie, Maureen, Gilian, Sarah and Desiree. She wanted to bid a special farewell to her dear friends Bernice, Anice, Honey and Suzanne and of course her dear cousin Barbara Slifka, as well as Paul and Joseph and Tony in St Thomas. Services will be held at Frank E Campbell, 81st Street and Madison Avenue on Wednesday at 11:00am. In lieu if flowers, donations can be made to The New York Service for the Handicapped, Camp Oakhurst, 1140 Broadway, Suite 903, New York City 10001 in her memory.

C.C. Sabathia was the heaviest player in baseball last season, but he may be on the verge of ceding that distinction. A sleeker version of Sabathia, who carried a listed 309 pounds on his 6-foot 7-inch frame, is scheduled to report to Yankees spring training after an off-season recovering from arthroscopic knee surgery. A baseball official confirmed that Sabathia had lost weight but could not say whether it was as much as 30 pounds, as reported Tuesday on Twitter by ESPN's Buster Olney. Sabathia has never missed a start in two seasons with the Yankees, but shedding weight would alleviate the stress on his right knee. Sabathia, who was 21-7 with a 3.18 earned run average and finished third in Cy Young Award balloting, had surgery in October to repair a meniscus tear.

One question that remained from last summer's Prospect Park goose slaughter was just how many geese the United States Department of Agriculture rounded up and gassed in an effort to improve air safety. The answer has arrived: 1,509 citywide, including 368 at Prospect Park and 208 at Alley Pond Park in Queens, and 167 more in western Nassau County. The figures (see also below) were quietly released in November in a report presented for review to the New York City Airports Wildlife Hazard Management Steering Committee.

The House Tour column on Jan. 28, about a three-bedroom home on three acres in Woodstock, N.Y., using information from Rachel Jackson, one of the owners, contained several errors. Ms. Jackson moved to New York in 1988, not 1986. She and her husband, Bruce, discussed their possible renovation for nine years, not eight. They hired an architect in September 2008, just before the stock market crash, not in 2007. Their renovation increased the size of the house by 65 percent; it did not double it. And although the attic was opened up to create a large bedroom, it did not also include a balcony.

The producers of the Broadway play ''Lombardi'' are hoping for a halo effect at the box office from the Green Bay Packers' victory in Sunday night's Super Bowl, ordering championship T-shirts to display at the theater, inviting Packers players to see the show, and planning a springtime media campaign linking the play to that storied N.F.L. franchise's fourth Super Bowl win. Tony Ponturo, one of the lead producers of the play about the legendary Packers coach Vince Lombardi, said in an interview that his marketing team would highlight the Super Bowl win on new fliers, e-mail blasts and signage in the lobby of the Circle in the Square Theater. He also said that the show's spring advertising buy on television and radio would almost certainly include references to the Packers' victory in Sunday night's second-half nail-biter against the Pittsburgh Steelers. The N.F.L. is a producer of the play, as is a group called Friends of Lombardi, which includes many Packers' boosters.

Over the centuries, Galileo's trial in 1633 for defending heliocentrism -- that Earth orbits the Sun, not the other way around -- the Inquisition's finding that he was ''vehemently suspect of heresy'' and his recantation have grown far beyond just a seminal clash between science and religion. The Galileo affair has become general shorthand for speaking truth to power, a cautionary tale to invoke whenever new ideas challenge the established order. A play that peels back the myths and metaphors, then, to peer into the personal would be welcome. Too often the legend wins out, starting with the notion that Galileo, having renounced his belief that Earth moves, muttered, ''But still, it moves.'' (There is no evidence that he did.) Brecht's famous drama ''Life of Galileo'' buys into that rumor and goes even further, painting a harsh portrait of a sly self-promoter who turns cowardly when it counts most.

People don't have faith in government. They have faith in their neighbors. MARÍA DEL SOCORRO VELÁZQUEZ VARGAS, a sociologist, on families who have chosen to stay in Ciudad Juárez, Mexico, despite widespread violence. [A6]

CIUDAD JUÁREZ, Mexico -- Telma Pedro Córdoba could have left this blood- and bullet-marked city when she lost her husband to a drive-by shooting in 2009, or when an injury kept her mother from factory work, or when gunmen killed a neighbor in front of a friend's 3-year-old son a few months ago. Instead, she has stayed. Her tiny one-bedroom home, decorated with carefully done red and silver stenciling, is shared with her mother, grandmother, sister, younger brother and two children. In local slang, unlike their neighbors whose abandoned homes are now stripped of even windows, they have become a ''familia anclada,'' a family anchored to Ciudad Juárez.

Based on recent episodes of ''Glee'' and the ever-changing loyalties of its characters (not to mention their ever-intertwining love lives), we have absolutely no idea where this hit Fox musical-comedy is headed in the weeks to come. But we know where the cast members will be in May and June: they'll be hitting the road for another tour of North American arenas and performance spaces. On Tuesday Fox said that a 16-city ''Glee Live! in Concert'' series will begin on May 21 at the Mandalay Bay Events Center in Las Vegas and conclude on June 18 at the Nassau Coliseum in Uniondale, N.Y. (Another performance in the New York area will be on June 16 at the Izod Center in East Rutherford, N.J.; interestingly, no performance has been scheduled on June 12, the date that the Tony Awards are presented.) A statement from Fox said that the show, conceived by the ''Glee'' co-creator Ryan Murphy, will feature songs performed on the series, including ''Empire State of Mind,'' ''Toxic,'' ''It's My Life'' and - deal with it - ''Don't Stop Believin'.'' The 13 ''Glee'' cast members who will participate in the tour, Fox said, are Lea Michele, Cory Monteith, Amber Riley, Chris Colfer, Kevin McHale, Jenna Ushkowitz, Mark Salling, Dianna Agron, Naya Rivera, Heather Morris, Harry Shum Jr., Chord Overstreet and Darren Criss. (Apparently the ''Glee'' co-stars Matthew Morrison and Jane Lynch will stay at home and knit during this time.)
An article last Wednesday about pepperoni misstated the name of a southern Italian region where a spicy sausage similar to pepperoni is made. It is Apulia -- not Abruzzi, which is in central Italy.

LICHTER--Lois, died at home peacefully on February 6, 2011, supported by her family and friends, after a long courageous battle with brain cancer. She was loved dearly and will be greatly missed. Her contagious laughter, quick wit and sense of humor will always be remembered. Lois was devoted to family and friends, especially her five grandchildren, who lovingly called her Gigi. She was a highly regarded and dedicated Realtor in Larchmont, New York for over 30 years and became life long friends with many of her clients and co-workers. She is survived by her husband, Leonard, her two children, Shari Philipps and Jonathan Lichter, her five grandchildren, Emma, Laine, Paige, Aaron and Harrison and her sister, Brenda Frank. Funeral services will be held at 11am on Wednesday, February 9th at Larchmont Temple, 75 Larchmont Ave, Larchmont, NY 10538.

The National Museum of African American History and Culture, the new Smithsonian museum set to open in 2015, has chosen a designer for its exhibitions. In a conversation earlier this week, the museum's director, Lonnie G. Bunch III, said that Mr. Appelbaum had brought together a group of young, culturally diverse designers to work on the project. The Smithsonian will pay Mr. Appelbaum's firm roughly $3 million to design of the museum's planned 82,000 square feet of exhibition space.

The New York University professor who had a camera inserted in the back of his head as part of an art project was forced to remove part of the camera on Friday because his body had rejected it, the Chronicle of Higher Education reported. The camera was to take a photograph every minute as the professor, Wafaa Bilal, went about his day. The project, which raised privacy concerns at the university, was called ''The 3rd I,'' and was organized by a new Qatari museum called Mathaf: Arab Museum of Modern Art. According to the Chronicle, the device, which was installed by a body modification artist in a tattoo shop in Los Angeles, was originally mounted on three posts that were attached to a titanium plate implanted between Mr. Bilal's skin and his skull. But Mr. Bilal's body rejected one of the posts, despite treatment with antibiotics and steroids, and he was in constant pain. So on Friday he had the post removed. While the wound heals, he is tying the camera to the back of his neck. Why didn't he do that in the first place? "It's a performance," he told the Chronicle. "With the performance comes endurance. But also it's a commitment. And I didn't feel that strapping something around my neck would be the same."

The will-he, won't-he riddle about Banksy and the Oscars - will he show up? won't he be in disguise? - has a solution. After the Oscar nominees luncheon on Monday, Steve Pond reports, the Academy president, Tom Sherak, and executive director, Bruce Davis, "huddled at a table" with Jaimie D'Cruz, a producer of "Exit Through the Gift Shop," Banksy's Oscar-nominated documentary. They worked through the potential situations of Banksy winning and having to appear on stage, which he would presumably do in costume, his costume of choice being a monkey mask. Undignified, the Academy felt. "If Banksy isn't comfortable showing his face on the Kodak stage, Sherak said, then the Academy isn't comfortable having him on that stage," Mr. Pond writes. Instead, the Academy officials and Mr. D'Cruz agreed, if the movie wins, Mr. D'Cruz will accept "without any additional shenanigans."

An article on Feb. 3 about Planned Parenthood's firing of a clinic manager who was seen on videotape advising a man posing as a sex trafficker referred incorrectly to charges against an activist known for making similar undercover videos in the offices of the community group Acorn. The activist, James O'Keefe, was charged in 2010 with entering the New Orleans office of Senator Mary Landrieu under false pretenses, with the purpose of committing a felony; he was never explicitly accused by the authorities of planning to tamper with the senator's telephones. (The error also appeared in an article on March 27, 2010, about charges in the case.)

The banking industry may have to spend more than $60 billion to buy back troubled mortgages, according to a report released on Tuesday by Standard & Poor's. The exposure stems from risky loans that the banks packaged and sold as securities at the height of the mortgage bubble. The terms of the mortgage security deals often required lenders to repurchase loans that failed to meet certain underwriting criteria.

STEGER--Evelyn E.,PhD, philosophy professor, author, artist, and architectural designer died in her Glen Cove home on January 29 at the age of 93. She was once described by the NY Times as "A Force of Nature". She is survived by her three sons, L. Craig Johnstone, Michael Johnstone and Sean Steger, eight grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at her home in Glen Cove on February 12 at 10:30am. Contact: 571-426-2934.

After hovering close to the No. 1 spot on Billboard magazine's music charts since November, Nicki Minaj has finally gained the top slot. ''Pink Friday,'' the debut CD by this 26-year-old singer, sold 45,000 copies last week -- up 18 percent from the previous week and enough to nudge cumulative sales of the CD past one million. As Billboard's editors pointed out, for a CD to climb to the top of the charts is ''a rare sight'' these days. ''For the most part, an album is only No. 1 because it debuted there,'' they noted. Last year, for example, 30 recordings occupied the No. 1 spot. But only one, Lil Wayne's ''I Am Not a Human Being,'' did not open in the top slot.

WINANT--Rivington. The Board of Directors of The National Committee for an Effective Congress mourns the death of our fellow board member and esteemed colleague, Riv Winant. His compassion for the less fortunate, his sound political judgment, his dedication to progressive and open government, his keen sense of humor and enduring charm, will always be remembered and sorely missed. We send our deepest sympathy to Riv's wife Joan, to his family and his many friends whose lives he touched and who loved him. Russell Hemenway, National Director

RUBINFELD--Seymour. For over 30 years we solved life's problems on the golf course, over the phone or over the bridge table. Words will never express how much I will miss you. All our love, Charlie and Jean Baraf

FRIEDMAN--Samuel Nathaniel. Generous, handsome, wise and loving. His nieces and nephews and their offspring will miss him and remember him with love always. Jonathan Swiller Raphy & Richard Haimowitz Willa & Hillel Swiller Judi & Gordon Davidson

SORG--Francis J.,Jr. The staff and trustees of the North Shore-Long Island Jewish (LIJ) Health System are greatly saddened by the death of Life Trustee Francis (Frank) Sorg, Jr. Mr. Sorg served North Shore University Hospital (NSUH) since 1961, playing a key role in the hospital's growth as co-chairman of its expansion program eight years later. In 1970, he became president of the NSUH board of trustees. His leadership, generosity and many years of dedicated service enabled NSUH to advance patient care and community service as well as further education and research. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife Mary Ann and family. Michael Dowling, President and CEO Richard Goldstein, Chairman North Shore-LIJ Health System

Were you attacked by a Rottweiler? Has your heart been ripped open? Relax. Pain is a myth. Or so says the momentum, a kind of self-help program that cures what ails you. And what ails the young urbanites of ''The Momentum,'' a sort of existential cabaret performed with minimal means at the Laurie Beechman Theater -- itself a no-frills cabaret, with a small stage and tables -- is not so unusual. They suffer from unmet expectations, romantic disappointments gay and straight, and a lingering sense of ill-being.

TISHCOFF--Sanford, who died at 76 on February 9, 2011, is missed by friends and family including his wife Hazel; his children Leah and Joel; their spouses David and Faye and grandchildren Zachary, Natalie, Zeke and Ezra. Sandy is also survived by his sister Shirley, brother-in-law Dan and sister-in-law Herta. Sandy, the founder of Mostly Books on Brooklyn's Cortelyou Rd., was a community fixture, an opera and theater lover, a foodie, a storyteller, and an obsessive Times reader / one-man clipping service. In fact, we know you're reading this now, Sandy, so Gute Nacht, Shlaf gut, Bis Morgen. Love you Dad.

CARSKY--Katherine. The Honorable Katherine S. Carsky dies at 74. Former Westchester County legislator Katherine (Kay) S. Carsky passed away on February 5th in Bronxville, NY. She is survived by five children, their spouses, and 13 grandchildren. Her husband of 28 years, Jim Carsky died in 1987. Raised on a farm in Nebraska, she served her community from 1972-2001, including the Yonkers School Board, League of Women Voters, Yonkers City Council, and Westchester County Legislature. She was an active member of NACo, the Bronx River Parkway Reservation Conservancy, the Westchester Arts Council, the Westchester Community College Foundation, and the Westchester Historical Society. Funeral arrangements will be handled by Fred McGrath & Sons of Bronxville, New York. Visiting hours 2-4pm and 6-9pm February 11th. Mass of Christian burial at Annunciation Church, Crestwood, February 12, at 11am. Donations to the Bronx River Parkway Reservation Conservancy at http://www.bronx-river.com/membership.htm.

Coming this fall are versions of classic board games like Monopoly that watch your every move and know whose turn is next. In Monopoly Live ($50), you still land on Boardwalk and collect $200 for passing go. But the money flows electronically to your bankcard, and a computer manages such details as dice rolls and rent calculations, which can speed the pace of the game.

WASHINGTON -- Under pressure to make deeper spending cuts and blindsided by embarrassing floor defeats, House Republican leaders are quickly discovering the limits of control over their ideologically driven and independent-minded new majority. For the second consecutive day, House Republicans on Wednesday lost a floor vote due to a mini-revolt, this time over a plan to demand a repayment from the United Nations. Earlier in the day, members of the party's conservative bloc used a closed-door party meeting to push the leadership to go well beyond its plans to trim about $40 billion from domestic spending and foreign aid this year, demanding $100 billion or more.

The seating fiasco Sunday at the Super Bowl, in which 1,200 temporary seats at Cowboys Stadium were deemed unusable shortly before the game, has produced an expected response from some angry fans: a class action lawsuit with accusations of fraud and breach of contract. One fan from Texas and another from Pennsylvania are the named plaintiffs in a suit filed in federal court in Dallas Tuesday night that seeks $5 million in damages from the Cowboys, their owner, Jerry Jones, and the National Football League. The team and league declined to comment.

There may be a certain deja vu to the new Canon EOS Rebel T3i. Not just that it shares DNA with its popular predecessors, but its new features - a swivel-out screen and built-in photography guide - look a lot like those found on a pair of Nikon cameras. The Canon T3i has a rotating screen that lets you hold the camera overhead and frame a shot, or turn the lens on yourself without guessing what you are getting, as you'd find on the Nikon D5000.

The rise of e-books and declining store sales have led to layoffs at Powell's Books, the landmark bookstore in Portland, Ore. The store's management said on Tuesday it would lay off 31 employees as part of its ''response to the unprecedented, rapidly changing nature of the book industry.'' Ryan Takas, the union representative for the employees who were laid off, said that the 31 employees make up more than 7 percent of the store's 400-person unionized work force. Mr. Takas said that Powell's had reduced its work force by about 40 employees in the last year through attrition, but still felt that layoffs were necessary because of a decline in sales of new books and a rise in health care costs. It was the first round of layoffs since the store's workers formed a union in 2000. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

8 P.M. (13) BORIS GODUNOV The German bass René Pape, above, has the title role in the Metropolitan Opera's new production of Mussorgsky's work, based on a play by Alexander Pushkin, about the reign of the ruthless 16th- and 17th-century Russian czar. Stephen Wadsworth directed, taking over from Peter Stein, who quit three months before the October premiere; Valery Gergiev conducts. Reviewing ''Boris Godunov,'' presented here by ''Great Performances at the Met'' and running three and a half hours, Anthony Tommasini wrote in The New York Times: ''This production comes to life through the nuanced and affecting performances of the cast and chorus. This is Mr. Wadsworth's doing, abetted, of course, by the vivid, gravely beautiful performance elicited by Mr. Gergiev.'' Still, Mr. Tommasini said: ''The production does not seem fully realized. How could it be? It is impossible to know what Mr. Wadsworth would have done had he been able to fashion a look and concept that conveyed his insights into the story as told by Mussorgsky.'' Mr. Pape, he wrote, not only looked regal and imposing but ''has vocal charisma as well, and his dark, penetrating voice is ideal for the role. Not knowing Russian, I cannot vouch for the idiomatic quality of his singing. But his enunciation was crisp and natural. And in every language Mr. Pape makes words matter.'' 8 P.M. (NBC) COMMUNITY It's Valentine's Day, and Troy (Donald Glover) and Abed (Danny Pudi) compete for the attention of the Greendale Community College librarian, while Britta (Gillian Jacobs) tries to get chummy with a student she thinks is a lesbian. In ''Perfect Couples,'' at 8:30, Julia (Christine Woods) is upset when Dave (Kyle Bornheimer) meets a woman while hiking; Rex (Hayes MacArthur) doesn't know how to tell Leigh (Olivia Munn) that he has financial difficulties; and Vance (David Walton) and Amy (Mary Elizabeth Ellis) prod each other into jealousy. In ''The Office,'' at 9, Michael (Steve Carell) and Holly (Amy Ryan) cause everyone to squirm with their public displays of affection. In ''Parks and Recreation,'' at 9:30, Tom (Aziz Ansari) plots revenge on Ron (Nick Offerman) by going on a date with Ron's ex-wife, Tammy (the guest star Megan Mullally). ''30 Rock,'' at 10, finds Jack (Alec Baldwin) and Avery (Elizabeth Banks) traveling to Canada for one last romantic getaway before the baby is born -- but scrambling back to New York so as not to give birth to a Canadian. Meanwhile Liz (Tina Fey) and Carol (Matt Damon) are stranded on the tarmac. And in ''Outsourced,'' at 10:30, Todd (Ben Rappaport) decides to give his employees anger management training.

The iPad is not a TV, but it can almost be one. Altec Lansing has produced a stand that enhances sound and charges your pad as you view TV or listen to music. The Octiv Stage MP450 is a stand with a cradle for the iPad. In its eight-and-a half by six-inch base includes an amp and two speakers that make TV listenable to a small group, and boosts tunes enough to play DJ at a dorm room-size party.
