WINANT--Rivington. On behalf of the Roosevelt Institute, we mourn the passing of a loyal friend and long-term board member. Riv inherited an extraordinary legacy of public service from his father, John Winant, a Republican progressive who helped create the Social Security system and was appointed as wartime Ambassador to Great Britain by President Franklin D. Roosevelt. Riv was the guardian of that legacy and enhanced it by his own career and his lifelong commitment to the creative values of Franklin and Eleanor Roosevelt. Our sincere condolences to the Winant family. William J. vanden Heuvel, Founder & Chair Emeritus; Anna Eleanor Roosevelt, Chair; and Andrew Rich, President & CEO

HOW does dust fall onto a bookshelf? Slowly. Very slowly. A piece of dust that is 100 microns in diameter (the size of a dot of chalk powder) will fall about a foot a second, said Richard Flagan, chairman of the chemical engineering program at the California Institute of Technology. A mote that is 1 micron in diameter, the size of a bacteria, will fall just 30 microns a second. And many of the particles created by cooking, which is a leading source of indoor dust, measure less than half a micron across.

After the financial crisis, the Alberta Teachers' Retirement Fund decided to reassess its strategy. At the time, the Canadian pension had roughly $150 million, or 3 percent of its assets, devoted to private equity, with the bulk in so-called funds of funds that invest across several different portfolios. Alberta Teachers' quickly found the approach too expensive and pulled its money from such intermediaries. Instead, the pension fund opted to handle private equity in-house, increasing its allocation to as much as 10 percent.

FRIEDMAN--Samuel Nathaniel, 94, grew up in a small apartment on Saratoga Avenue in Brownsville, Brooklyn, and died Monday night at his spacious park-view Central Park West apartment. He went the way he would have wanted to, having dinner with his wife, Barbara Somers, a gourmet cook. Sam, as he was known, had led a full and happy life until a few years ago when he began to have health problems. He was blind and wheelchair-bound at his death. But until the last few years, he was a force of nature for family and friends. Tall, handsome (a striking resemblance to Gregory Peck), a great story teller, a fabulous businessman and salesman, agricultural expert and possessed of exquisite taste. He wore off-the-rack clothing that looked as if it were bespoken. His favorite garment was a loose black shirt designed by friend, Massimo Vignelli. As a youth, Sam was an avid Zionist as was his father, Israel, an immigrant from Cracow and a union leader. Sam's mother Sarah immigrated from Siroka in what is now Moldova. He spent all his teens through the Depression years (he was thirteen at the crash of 1929) and had to work after school throughout his high school years to help support the family. Sam worked his way through Cornell and got a BS, '36, in dairy chemistry. During summers, he worked as an apprentice on dairy farms upstate. His father had hopes Sam would go to what was then Palestine as a pioneer. But Sam was a committed American and moved to a then-new cooperative community in central New Jersey called Jersey Homesteads, later Roosevelt, where, with his first wife, Charlotte Safir, he raised three children - Miriam Alimonos, 59; Dinah Lefkowitz, 66; and Joshua Friedman, 69. At the end of WWII, a friend and neighbor, artist Ben Shahn, introduced Sam to Klaus Grabe, a Bauhaus-trained German architect who had fled to Mexico as a political refugee in the 1930's. Sam went to work for Klaus in his furniture business, which -- despite Sam's efforts-did not prosper. But Sam stayed in furniture, working for other firms -- Berge Norman and George Tanier -- and then started his own firm ICF (International Contract Furnishings) in 1962 with a friend from Tanier, Hal Stearns. Aided by furniture designer Pat Hoffman, who became his second wife, Sam built ICF into an iconic design firm. He introduced Americans to classic architect-designed European furniture of the early 20th Century--especially that of Finnish architect Alvar Aalto. ICF introduced to the United States market the work of Josef Hoffmann, Mario Botta, Philippe Starck and Richard Neutra, among others. At its height, ICF was blazing the way for a look that persists in executive suites around the U.S. When Pat Hoffman died of cancer, Sam was heartsick, sold ICF and retired. He spent the rest of his life gardening at his country home in Amagansett, entertaining in his city apartment, then on Park Ave., and traveling with Barbara, who became his third wife. But most of all, he loved doting on his grandchildren and great grandchildren: Miriam and husband Yannis' kids: Angelos, Aggeliki, Lysistrati, Cassandra; Dinah and Stephen Lefkowitz's kids: Benjamin and Bridget Bly (Nora and Zoe) and Jennifer and Robert Donahue (Cait and Samantha); and Josh and Carol Ash Friedman's daughter, Susannah and her fiance, Gareth Crawford. As if that weren't enough nachas, he also doted on his nieces and nephews, the children of his surviving brother, Abraham Friedman and wife Diana, and the children of his deceased sister Esther Swiller-and their kids' kids. Funeral service, Wednesday, 12:45pm at The Riverside, 331 Amsterdam Ave., at 76th St. Burial for family only will follow at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. For Shiva information contact Riverside at 212-362-6600. It was a full and happy life.

With Mick Jagger already signed on to perform at the Grammy Awards in a tribute to the singer Solomon Burke, who called himself ''King Solomon'' and who died in October, it's only fitting that Aretha Franklin, the still-reigning ''Queen of Soul,'' should also be honored at the awards ceremony on Sunday in Los Angeles. Christina Aguilera, Jennifer Hudson, Martina McBride, Yolanda Adams and Florence Welch will participate in the homage to the 68-year-old Ms. Franklin. Grammy sponsors are describing it as a ''valentine'' and a ''get-well card'' to Ms. Franklin, who has won 18 Grammys herself. She was hospitalized in Detroit late last year, underwent surgery for an undisclosed ailment and canceled several months' worth of scheduled performances. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

An article on Nov. 30 about the granting of an educational waiver to Cathleen P. Black so she could become the New York City schools chancellor misidentified an official who commented on the requirement that Ms. Black appoint a chief academic officer as a condition for receiving the waiver. It was Assemblyman David I. Weprin -- not his brother, City Councilman Mark S. Weprin -- who said that he hoped Ms. Black's deputy would be ''more than a figurehead.'' The error was pointed out shortly after the article was published; this correction was delayed because The Times failed to follow through on the complaint.

For modern viewers, Aristophanes' ''Lysistrata'' may be easier to admire than to like. The story, of course, compels: Lysistrata leads the Athenian and Spartan women in a sex strike to end the war between their cities. But all that ribaldry and priapism can be tough going. (Hell, perhaps, is other people's bawdy comedy.) In Theodora Skipitares's production of ''Lysistrata'' at La MaMa, her puppets and masks come to the rescue. They provide distance between audience and play, a veil that offers both discretion and license. The puppets, mostly life-size and elegantly attired, are used for the individual characters. The choruses, male and female, are masked and more grotesque. They sport crude wigs and exaggerated sexual appendages: cloth penises for the gents and, for the ladies, pendulous breasts attached to their tunics.

When ''Colin Quinn Long Story Short'' opened at the Helen Hayes Theater in November, producers presented Mr. Quinn and the show's director, Jerry Seinfeld, with a Hirschfeld caricature of the two. An article on Saturday about the Henrietta Lacks Foundation, which was established in honor of a woman whose astonishingly hardy cancer cells have been used widely in medical research, included several errors. The foundation was formed shortly before a book about Mrs. Lacks was published last February, not ''soon after.'' The foundation is still in the process of applying for tax-exempt status from the I.R.S., not for ''nonprofit status.'' And the group has always intended to help those in need beyond the Lacks family; it does not have to ''enlarge its mission'' to do so.

In Asia, Chinese contemporary art is still a hot collecting area. So it was with great fanfare that in Hong Kong on Wednesday morning, Sotheby's announced the forthcoming sale of 106 works dating from the 1980s and early 1990s. The works belong to Guy Ullens and his wife, Myriam, Belgium collectors who opened the Ullens Center for Contemporary Art in a former munitions complex in Beijing's Dashanzi warehouse arts district in 2007. The Sotheby's auction will take place on April 3 in Hong Kong and is expected to bring $12.7 million to $16.7 million. For sale will be everything from paintings and sculpture to photography and installations. Among the highlights are Zhang Xiaogang's triptych ''Forever Lasting Love'' (1988), which is estimated at $3.2 million to $3.8 million, and Wang Guangyi's ''Mao Zedong: P2, 1988,'' one of the earliest paintings from that artist's series of Mao images. In this one he has superimposed lines and symbols on top of a silhouette of the leader. It is expected to sell for $190,000 to $260,000.

Picard, from Bankruptcy Court to Federal Court, calling the $6.4 billion complaint an ''enormous backdoor class action.'' An article on Jan. 19 about the challenge of getting mental health treatment for someone like Jared L. Loughner, charged in the Jan. 8 shootings in Tucson, referred incorrectly to the mental health history of Seung-Hui Cho, the gunman who in 2007 killed 32 people at Virginia Tech University. Mr. Cho was ordered to seek treatment on his own and did not follow through; he was not ''committed involuntarily,'' which involves an extended period of forced hospitalization.

Marc Kudisch and Bobby Steggert will star in Lincoln Center Theater's production of ''A Minister's Wife,'' a new musical based on an early 1898 version of George Bernard Shaw's ''Candida.'' Originally presented at the Writers' Theater in Glencoe, Ill., near Chicago, ''A Minister's Wife'' has a book by Austin Pendleton, the director of the Classic Stage Company's new production of ''Three Sisters,'' music by Joshua Schmidt (Off Broadway's ''Adding Machine'') and lyrics by Jan Levy Tranen. Michael Halberstam will direct.

Spider-Man didn't get the kindest reception on Broadway, but in his Marvel Comics adventures he's about to receive a much warmer welcome. The web slinger will become a member of the Fantastic Four - or, more precisely, join the surviving teammates of that superhero group to form a new team - whose exploits will be chronicled in a new series called FF, Marvel Entertainment said on Wednesday. As fans and mourners know all too well, Johnny Storm (alias the Human Torch) of the Fantastic Four appeared to meet his demise in a battle with the minions of Annihilus, in issue No. 587 in January. In issue 588 this month, Storm's teammates Ben Grimm (a k a the Thing) and Reed and Susan Richards (Mr. Fantastic and the Invisible Woman) will reflect on their loss with some help from Spider-Man, and then the Fantastic Four series will be no more.

There are few gaps in Phil Jackson's cluttered coaching résumé. He has more N.B.A. championships than anyone and more victories than most. He won a title in the Continental Basketball Association, with the Albany Patroons. He even coached a few tours in Puerto Rico. Yet somehow, Jackson never made it back to his N.B.A. roots, back to his favorite city, back to the corner of 33rd Street and Eighth Avenue. Jackson interviewed with the Knicks three times over the last three decades but the timing was never right. In 1987, the Knicks passed up Jackson, then coaching the Patroons, to hire Rick Pitino. Jackson joined the Chicago Bulls' staff. Twelve years and six championships later, Jackson - a free agent after leaving the Bulls - spoke with the Garden president Dave Checketts. The exploratory talks went nowhere and Jackson instead joined the Los Angeles Lakers. Jackson was a free agent again in 2005 when Isiah Thomas asked him to coach the Knicks. Jackson declined because he got a better offer: a return to the Lakers. Now 65, Jackson intends to retire from the N.B.A. after this season, and this time for good. The opportunity for a prodigal return has seemingly passed. But at least one authority on Jackson can still envision him joining the Knicks some day. "Phil is definitely a full-circle kind of a guy, and that would bring him full circle," said Jeanie Buss, Jackson's girlfriend and a Lakers executive.

Earlier this week, I wrote about text4baby, a free service that sends text messages to pregnant women, or new mothers, to provide them with useful health tips. What struck me as most noteworthy about this program was how hundreds of different types of organizations - for-profit health care providers, nonprofit community groups, wireless carriers, government agencies, and many others - had collaborated to make it all work. Text4baby seemed to shed light on the question: How do you get a country - with all its diverse institutional strengths - to work as a team?

The cause of Riccardo Muti's fall from the podium during a rehearsal of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra on Feb. 3 has been determined. In a joint statement with Mr. Muti and officials of the orchestra, two cardiologists at the Northwestern University Feinberg School of Medicine, Donald Lloyd-Jones and Bradley P. Knight, reported on Friday that Mr. Muti had fainted because of "a common heart rhythm disturbance." Although their tests reveal that he retains excellent heart function, they added, he has had a pacemaker installed to monitor his heart rhythm and deliver a small electrical charge if the heart rate should fall too low. "Patients with pacemakers live full and active lives with excellent prognosis," the doctors concluded. Mr. Muti remains in Northwestern Memorial Hospital, where he is recovering from surgery for facial injuries incurred in the fall. He has canceled his remaining performances this winter, which were to run through Feb. 19. His next scheduled appearance with the orchestra is a concert performance of Verdi's opera "Otello" on April 7, to be repeated twice in Chicago and, on April 15, in Carnegie Hall.

For the modern YouTube hunter the world of Japanese television and pop culture can be a seemingly bottomless treasure trove. Among some of the finest gems are clips like the one above of Takarazuka, a 98-year-old Japanese song and dance troupe that specializes in performing adaptations of Western pop songs, classic musicals, operas, plays, novels or films as well as Japanese folk tales. (The clip above shows the musical number "The Great Century," which incorporates the '80s soft rock anthem "Final Countdown.") But in a bizarre twist on the idea of an all-male Shakespearean cast, the members of the ensemble are all women - making Takarazuka perhaps the only Vegas-style musical theater group in the world with professional drag kings on permanent payroll. But despite appearances, Takarazuka was never meant as an early-20th-century chorus line for Japanese women's liberation. To this day, cast members are put through a rigorous and patriarchally organized training program for several years before they are even allowed to set one foot on stage, with "female" (musumeyaku) and "male" (otokoyaku) actresses strictly separated in classrooms and dormitories. The inevitable lesbian overtones were largely ignored until the mid- to late 1930s, when Japanese officials were alarmed to a point that a ban on contact between the "male" cast members and their passionate female fans was imposed. To this day, most of Takarazuka's over-2.5 million-strong annual audience consists of women, and so do the performers: an attempt in the 1940s to introduce male actors was successfully boycotted by Takarazuka's own disgruntled cast.

As a filmmaker, David Fincher has the reputation of an extreme perfectionist, so finely attuned to detail that he doesn't trust anyone else to get even minor secondary shots. That vision earned him an Oscar nomination as the director of "The Social Network" - but what about the guys who have to work with him? While Mr. Fincher is celebrated for doing dozens and dozens of takes , what's often forgotten is that other people then have to look at each and every one of those takes to put the film together. Apparently they don't mind; the editors Kirk Baxter and Angus Wall, and the sound designer, editor and mixer Ren Klyce have all worked with Mr. Fincher multiple times, on films like "The Curious Case of Benjamin Button" and "Zodiac." They are all Oscar-nominated for "The Social Network," and are working with Mr. Fincher on his next film, "The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo."

In most people's minds, there are only two settings on the Nordic furniture dial: Then (meaning postwar Modern) and Now. While I went to this year's Stockholm Design Week, which ends on Sunday, excited solely about the latter, it turned out that the fair had something to offer in the former department as well. The Danish manufacturer Gubi recently shifted its attention towards resurrecting mid-century design icons, and the first fruits of that effort are on display this week. It has reissued Greta Grossman's 1947 Grasshopper lamp and the 1966 Stokke Chair by Jens Qvistgaard, and is now the sole owner of reproduction rights for the cult Hungarian designer Mathieu Mategot's work, starting with a multicolored coat rack and two pieces in his signature perforated metal: the Nagasaki chair and the Dedal bookcase. Mategot fans accustomed to 1stdibs sticker shock should rejoice.

Three months after Yale University and the government of Peru announced a tentative accord under which Yale would return a group of artifacts excavated at Machu Picchu, Yale formally signed a partnership agreement on Friday with a Peruvian university to establish a joint center where the objects will be conserved, studied and displayed. The center will be at the Universidad Nacional de San Antonio Abad del Cusco, in Cusco, the city closest to Machu Picchu, and will be called the U.N.S.A.A.C.-Yale International Center for the Study of Machu Picchu and Inca Culture. It will include a museum exhibition space; a storage site for the archeological artifacts, which include stone tools, ceramics and human and animal bones; and a laboratory and research area. Students and faculty members from Yale are expected to visit the center for training, research projects and field work; students and faculty members of the Peruvian university will also visit Yale. Meanwhile, a small number of artifacts will be loaned to Yale for display at the Yale Peabody Museum of Natural History.

The sports analytics movement has given basketball decision makers more valuable information than they have ever had, but, in a way, their experience in implementing their findings is atypical in the information age. The modern world is marked by the rapid dissemination of incredible amounts of information to relevant and interested parties; people from all over the planet know more today about one another and the world they inhabit than any human beings have before, primarily because of how freely information is exchanged. When it comes to analytical data in sports, however, coaches in particular face a unique challenge in passing along the statistical information they deem important. It's not enough to know that a player is most effective running one type of play or shooting from one area of the floor. Coaches today must also understand how to convey that information in a way that makes it digestible and useful.

The going rate for your thoughts used to be a penny. Now the producers of the Broadway musical "Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark" are offering $60 goodie bags to people who serve in focus groups that will respond to several performances. Two focus groups attended Thursday night's performance, and four more are scheduled to be at Friday night's show and the Saturday matinee. It's not unheard of for Broadway producers to use focus groups, and the musical has used them before since preview performances began on Nov. 28. But these are the first since largely negative reviews of the show by theater critics across the country were published on Tuesday. OnTrack Research, a marketing and consulting firm, is coordinating the focus groups, and here's the rub: participants only get to see Act I or Act II, not both. They are then asked to fill out surveys and join in discussions in a "V.I.P. room." The details of the focus groups were outlined in an e-mail to participants from OnTrack Research. Here is the full e-mail, which a focus group participant passed along and which was authenticated by the production on Friday.

No figure in the music industry is more closely associated with the Grammy Awards than Clive Davis, who for more than 30 years has held his see-and-be-seen party at the Beverly Hilton the night before the show. This year Mr. Davis, 78, expects plenty of the usual pop stars and industry bigwigs at the fete, as well as boldface names from sports like Magic Johnson and Serena Williams -- a guest list large enough that he has had to make some unpleasant choices in who doesn't make the cut. "This year I really can't go out to public restaurants," he said in an interview.This year Mr. Davis's link to the Grammys grew a little closer with the dedication on Wednesday of the Clive Davis Theater at the Grammy Museum, a 200-seat space in downtown Los Angeles near the Staples Center, where the awards ceremony will be held on Sunday night. In front of a crowd of industry friends, curious fans and artists like Toni Braxton, Mr. Davis reminisced about his career, drawing oohs and ahhs for his stories about taking Lou Reed to the Bottom Line in 1975 to see Bruce Springsteen and the time he told an aspiring songwriter, "If you were Irving Berlin, we would have known it by now."

Whenever I write about inflation or the lack thereof, I get a lot of remarkably angry mail from people who are focused on commodity prices; they just can't imagine how people like me or Ben Bernanke can be relaxed about the overall inflation picture when the prices of wheat, oil, etc. have risen so much lately.

"Peter's inspiration was a very fabulous American artist called Cindy Sherman," said the (very fabulous French) makeup artist Tom Pecheux backstage at Peter Som. "She does self-portraits where she takes herself on a crazy journey. She always brings a twist into her face, so in terms of makeup we wanted to do that." This translated into nearly nude skin (with a bit of rosy blush and a touch of shimmery powder topping cheeks), bare brows, lashes and eyelids, punctuated with a statement lip. "We started with a red lipstick, the definition of a grown-up woman," said Pecheux, noting that the designer's fall 2011 collection seemed more adult to him than previous seasons. "To twist it, we are adding a layer of metallic color." Lips were lined with M.A.C. Cherry Lip Pencil, filled in with a lipstick color being tested for fall tentatively called Runaway Red (according to M.A.C., Dare You is the closest shade currently available), dusted with M.A.C. Invisible Powder, and then dabbed with M.A.C. pigments in silver, rose gold and melon. "I'm not a fan of a lip with shimmer, a frosted lip - I think it's cheesy," said Pecheux of his matte metallic creation. The look was paired with a hairstyle inspired by Tippi Hedren's character in "The Birds," using Wella Ocean Spritz for texture and extensions with roots dyed into them. "It gives the hairstyle depth, it makes hair look thicker, the minute you have a root it makes hair look thicker and a bit denser," the hairstylist Eugene Souleiman, who crafted the look, explained of the extensions. "It's a little like when I used to do Prada and Miu Miu. It has that '90s take on the '50s - it's slightly minimal, but now it's a bit more raw."

The prevalence of Carmelo Anthony trade rumors has brought forth an understandable amount of analysis and criticism concerning the exact nature of Anthony's game. After all, in order to best understand how Anthony would fit with a team like the Knicks or the Nets, it is crucial to look closely at the way he plays with and without the ball. Some players are more compatible with certain systems or teams than others, in no small part because of the way those players go about contributing to their teams' success.

An exhibition of ancient Chinese artifacts will go forward at the University of Pennsylvania Museum of Archeology and Anthropology, after all. The exhibition, "Secrets of the Silk Road," which includes materials, including two mummies, recently excavated at desert burial sites in western China, was organized by the Bowers Museum in Santa Ana, Calif., and was shown there last year and subsequently at the Houston Museum of Natural Science, where it closed on Jan. 2. It was scheduled to open at the Penn Museum on February 5, but last week, three days before the planned opening, the museum announced that China had requested that none of the artifacts be displayed. As a result, the museum would only show photographs, multimedia presentations, and a recreation of an excavation site; it offered refunds to those who had bought advance tickets and said that the exhibition would now be free.

Namibia designates its entire 976-mile coastline a national park, consolidating several existing preserves into the 26.6 million-acre Namib-Skeleton Coast National Park. The Namibian authorities have recently expanded wildlife conservation efforts in a successful effort to boost tourism; in one notable success, a population of lions has been re-established along the arid Skeleton Coast after being totally extinguished by hunting and poisoning in the 1980s. "I had this vision of a woman who can get by in any situation - she reads stars, uses natural medicine, makes fire - and wanted to translate that to a fearless modern girl," Lizzie says. "Isabella Bird was also an inspiration," Kathryn adds. "She was a 19th-century traveling naturalist who used to ride front-saddle instead of sideways to appear more like a man."

LAS VEGAS -- In an upset victory for Electronic Arts and its BioWare studio, the science-fiction adventure Mass Effect 2 won game of the year here on Thursday evening at the 14th annual Interactive Achievement Awards ceremony. Voted on by members of the video-game industry under the auspices of the Academy of Interactive Arts & Sciences, the Interactive Achievement Awards are the most prestigious in video games and are the industry's equivalent of the Oscars. The awards are announced each year at the academy's DICE conference, which stands for Design, Innovate, Communicate, Entertain.

On Thursday night, at the start of Fashion Week, several hundred people came to the David Zwirner Gallery to see an exhibition of Philip-Lorca diCorcia's photographs. Originally published in W magazine, between 1997 and 2008, the images are a remarkable record of a free-spirited period in publishing that seemed to come to an end with the recession and, as well, the Internet. They speak directly to the eye of Mr. diCorcia, with their capacity to excite and disturb, and to seek truth about human behavior in the most banal of scenes. These photographs were also the result of a fortuitous collaboration between Mr. diCorcia and Dennis Freedman, the former art director of W, who gave the artist carte blanche to shoot fashion stories in places like Havana, Cairo and New York. They have collected all 11 shoots in a new book, "Eleven" (Damiani Editions).

In the art world, Tara Donovan has become the belle of the banal. She employs everyday objects such as drinking straws, buttons or No. 2 pencils to create large-scale sculptures and prints that take on a life (and light) of their own. She allows the shape of the chosen material to determine the form of the piece until it becomes magically other (think vast moonscape in Styrofoam cups), managing to transcend both materiality and gimmickry in a culture that celebrates both.

Barnaby Roper doesn't do things by half. But he is not against the idea of using a 16-part grid. In his latest high-impact video, 'Kruse,' created exclusively for The Moment, Roper turns his lens on Christina Kruse, a '90s catwalk queen and a talented artist in her own right. Kruse's image is carved up into a digital chopping block that twists and turns and squeezes her through a series of kaleidoscopic formations. Look out for more videos from Roper as the year progresses - assuming the technology can keep up.

And so it has come to this: Trading begins not with the customary ringing of the bell, but with the blast of a French horn. Pierre squints at the big board, yanks off his beret and shouts ''À vendre! À vendre!'' (''Sell! Sell!''). Outside on Wall Street, the steakhouses, cigar bars and elite private clubs stand empty, as brokers and traders stream into beer halls for steins of pilsner and plates of hot schnitzel. It was announced Wednesday that the New York Stock Exchange is yelling ''Sell!'' in reference to its very self and is in advance talks toward a merger with the Frankfurt Stock Exchange, which would open the market to 14 European countries, from France to the new company's proposed headquarters in the Netherlands. We have come full circle, from New Amsterdam to New York and, it seems, back again.

'LIGHT HEARTED' IN TIMES SQUARE (Friday through Feb. 20) For the next 10 days, a visit to Times Square can be a heart-lifting experience -- especially if the heart is the winning design in the annual Valentine's Day competition presented by the Times Square Alliance. This year's display, designed by Lauren Crahan and John Hartmann, is the first that is interactive (last year's was a 10-foot-tall stationary ice sculpture), and volunteers are needed to lift and unfold the lightweight construction, also 10 feet tall but made of aluminum and fabric, for 15-minute intervals, daily from 10 a.m. to 9:30 p.m. (The sculpture at rest, above, after its installation on Wednesday night.) Volunteers can register at timessquarenyc.org/valentine. For those who prefer celebrating Valentine's Day by walking, eating, laughing or looking for the loves of their lives, plenty of those activities are in the listings on this page. (Anne Mancuso)

If the phone rings one morning and you hear a cheery ''good morning'' from Magic Johnson on the other end of the line or the R&B singer Trey Songz telling you to ''get your education,'' don't hang up and roll over, bury yourself under your blanket and go back to sleep. This is no prank call. It's the city's latest attempt to get students who persistently skip class to start showing up more often. The campaign, appropriately named ''Wake Up! NYC,'' rolls out next week. It will focus on the 6,500 students who have been absent for 10 or more school days in a single year and attend one of the 25 schools whose principals volunteered to join the effort. If it yields results, it will be expanded citywide, where roughly 250,000 students miss at least one month of school in a given year, officials said.

Williamstown Theater Festival has announced three mainstage productions for summer 2011: a Broadway-bound revival of Moss Hart and George S. Kaufman's ''You Can't Take It With You,'' directed by Christopher Ashley; Oliver Goldsmith's Restoration comedy ''She Stoops to Conquer,'' directed by Nicholas Martin; and ''Ten Cents a Dance,'' a celebration of the songs of Rodgers and Hart, directed by John Doyle. The company usually produces four mainstage shows, but Jenny Gersten, the new artistic director, said in a phone interview that the cut was not based on financial constraints; in fact, she said, the budget for the season was ''exactly the same'' as last year, or a little over $3 million. Rather, she said, she wanted to experiment with running two of the shows (''You Can't Take It With You'' and ''Ten Cents a Dance'') for longer than the typical two-week Williamstown run. ''We're trying to run them a little bit longer and see if that gives them time to catch on,'' she said.

One of four consultants who were charged with an $80 million scheme to steer city contracts for an automated employee timekeeping program to businesses they controlled pleaded guilty this week to bribery and other crimes, court records show, and is now cooperating with investigators. News of the guilty plea came as prosecutors on Thursday announced the indictment of another person - a cousin of the man accused of being the mastermind of the scheme. That raises to seven the number of people charged to date in a scandal that has erupted in Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's third term.

The injured payload operator was unable to move and lying in the dirt and water of a cavernous construction area 50 feet below the streets of Midtown Manhattan - a dark, cold ditch far from the firefighters' grasp. And the payload operator, with his left shoulder hurt and his arm swollen, seemed cognizant of the risks.

One late night in 2008, Lisa Dowda was waiting on an empty Brooklyn street for a bus home to Sunset Park. The bus never came, but a sanitation worker - one of the 7,899 ''San Men'' who keep New York City's streets clean - stopped emptying baskets to check in on her and make sure she was O.K. and knew her way.

An article last Friday about the Marathon Independent School District, and a foundation created by residents to help support it, misstated the amount of the district's debt when Neal Harrison became superintendent in 2009. The district had just finished paying off a $248,000 loan to cover its debt; it was not $248,000 in debt.

9 P.M. (ABC) WRONG TURN: THE KATI KIM STORY After spending Thanksgiving 2006 in Seattle the members of the Kim family -- James, Kati and their two daughters, 4 years and 7 months, above -- were on their way home to San Francisco on Nov. 25 when they took a wrong turn in a remote area of southwestern Oregon and became lost in a dense wilderness. Trapped in their car during a snowstorm, they rationed food while Ms. Kim breast fed the children, and kept warm by occasionally turning on the car's engine. When they ran out of fuel, they built fires of dried wood and magazines and, hoping to attract the attention of rescue helicopters, the car's tires. On Dec. 2 Mr. Kim set off on foot, believing the nearest town to be four miles away. He never returned. Rescuers found Ms. Kim and her children on Dec. 4. Mr. Kim's body was discovered on Dec. 6 in more than a foot of icy water -- and only a mile from a lodge that, while closed for the winter, was stocked with supplies. In this two-hour ''20/20'' report, Ms. Kim describes the family's ordeal for the first time on television. 3 P.M. (Fox) THE DR. OZ SHOW In ''The Naked Hour,'' Dr. Mehmet Oz joins forces with Dr. Laura Berman, the sex therapist; Lisa Lynn, a weight-loss specialist; and Samantha Heller, a registered dietician, to help women improve their body images.

SCHMITT--Debra. (1957-2011). Debbie, a high school English teacher, was born on Staten Island and lived in Manhattan before moving to California in 2001. She is survived by her husband and son of Ross and a sister of Staten Island.

ROSENSHEIN--Bernard. We mourn the loss of Bernard Jacob Rosenshein, beloved father of Lisa Todes, Michele Geller, and Julie Rosenshein, husband of Rahma, widower to Carol, grandfather to Cayla, Joshua, Noah, Sasha, Becca and Jodie. Mr. Rosenshein passed away on Tuesday after a heroic nine-year battle with Multiple Myeloma. He was the founder and president of Rosenshein Associates, a real estate development firm that built and managed shopping centers. Mr. Rosenshein owned and operated Mamaroneck Beach and Yacht Club. Mr. Rosenshein served as a trustee for the International Council of Shopping Centers, board member of the Holocaust and Human Rights Education Center, former board member of the Hudson River Museum, and was also dedicated to UJA, Bnai B'rith, Westchester Children's Museum, and The Multiple Myeloma Research Foundation. He was an avid skiier, sailor, tennis player and lover of the arts. He was a lion of a man who was loved for his unweilding optimism, generosity of spirit, and passion for life.

An article on Thursday about efforts by House Republicans to cut the federal budget paraphrased incorrectly in some copies from a comment by Representative Jeff Flake of Arizona regarding his party's goal for reducing spending. Mr. Flake said that Republicans should propose, if necessary, an across-the-board reduction to meet the $100 billion -- not $100 million -- level of cuts they had pledged during the recent campaign.

A Federal Court of Appeals reinstated a lawsuit that accuses the Blackstone Group of inadequately disclosing information in its initial public offering documents - claims that echo an oft-heard criticism about the opaque business results of publicly traded private equity firms. The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in Manhattan said in an opinion issued Thursday that the trial court should not have dismissed the complaint because the Blackstone shareholders ''plausibly allege'' that the firm misstated or omitted material information about its private equity investments from its 2007 I.P.O. filing.

CARSKY--Katherine. The Honorable Katherine S. Carsky dies at 74. Former Westchester County legislator Katherine (Kay) S. Carsky passed away on February 5th in Bronxville, NY. She is survived by five children, their spouses, and 13 grandchildren. Her husband of 28 years, Jim Carsky died in 1987. Raised on a farm in Nebraska, she served her community from 1972-2001, including the Yonkers School Board, League of Women Voters, Yonkers City Council, and Westchester County Legislature. She was an active member of NACo, the Bronx River Parkway Reservation Conservancy, the Westchester Arts Council, the Westchester Community College Foundation, and the Westchester Historical Society. Funeral arrangements will be handled by Fred McGrath & Sons of Bronxville, New York. Visiting hours 2-4pm and 6-9pm February 11th. Mass of Christian burial at Annunciation Church, Crestwood, February 12, at 11am. Donations to the Bronx River Parkway Reservation Conservancy at http://www.bronx-river.com/membership.htm.

DELAYED TRIAL A federal judge on Thursday pushed back by a week the trial of Raj Rajaratnam, below, who has been accused of being at the center of an insider trading network. The trial, which was scheduled to start on Feb. 28, will now begin on March 8, according to the order from Judge Richard J. Holwell of United States District Court in Manhattan. He gave no reason for the postponement.

Justin Kubatko is the creator of Basketball-Reference.com, an online basketball encyclopedia. He is also a statistical consultant for the Portland Trail Blazers. In Thursday's game against the Los Angeles Lakers, Ray Allen of the Boston Celtics broke the career record for 3-point field goals set by Reggie Miller, who made 2,560. Allen's pursuit of Miller's mark shows the impact that a rule change can have on a player and on the game itself.

ROSENBERG--Norman M.D.,a pioneer in the development of vascular surgery, passed away February 7, 2011 following a stroke. Formerly Emeritus Professor of Surgery at UMDNJ-Robert Wood Johnson Medical School and Chief of General Surgery, Chief of Vascular Surgery, and Chief of Staff at Robert Wood Johnson University Hospital in New Brunswick, NJ, Dr. Rosenberg developed a new treatment for arterial disease, a modified bovine graft - later marketed by Johnson & Johnson and now by Artegraft. A long-term advocate for the development of health policies, Dr. Rosenberg served on the board of the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation for 38 years. He is survived by his wife of 70 years, the former Ruth H. Feller, his daughter, Lois Ebin, and two granddaughters, Lauren Ebin and Julie Ebin.

An architecture review on Thursday about the new residential tower at 8 Spruce Street in Lower Manhattan designed by Frank Gehry misstated its location relative to three nearby landmarks: City Hall Park, Cass Gilbert's 1913 Woolworth building, and McKim, Mead & White's 1912 Municipal building. The park and the Woolworth building are to the west, and the Municipal building is to the north; they are not ''to the east'' of the new tower.

WASHINGTON - Gary Gensler has his work cut out for him. As chairman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, he is leading the charge to overhaul the murky $600 trillion derivatives market, which was at the center of the financial crisis. The Dodd-Frank Act, the financial overhaul law enacted last year, requires Mr. Gensler's agency to draft dozens of new derivatives rules by July.

12:53 p.m. | Updated The Metropolitan Opera's new ''Ring'' cycle has lost its Siegfried. Ben Heppner, one of the best Wagnerian tenors around, withdrew from performances of the last two installments of the cycle, ''Siegfried'' and ''Gotterdammerung,'' next season. Mr. Heppner decided that the notoriously challenging role ''was just not the right repertoire for him,'' said his manager, William Guerri, in an interview. Mr. Guerri said the tenor was unavailable for comment on Tuesday evening.

GARRETT--Guy Thomas, Jr. A resident of Buffalo Junction, VA for over twenty years, departed this life on Monday, February 7, 2011 in Cary, NC. Guy Garrett was born in Peekskill, NY on June 7, 1932, the eldest of four sons of the late Guy Thomas Garrett, Sr. and the late Annie Garrett Williams. Mr. Garrett graduated from Howard University in Washington, D.C. in 1954 with a degree in Political Science. In 1955, he married Geraldyne Baker and from that union, two children were born, a daughter, Lynn, and son, Guy, III. Following college, Mr. Garrett served in the US Army for three years as an infantry officer. After his military service, he returned to New York City and held a series of positions of increasing responsibility. He taught in the New York City School system, was a branch manager for Household Finance, and managed the personnel department at the Long Island Lighting Company. Mr. Garrett joined the New York Times Company in 1974 as Director of Personnel. He was elected Vice President of Personnel of The Times Company in July 1976 and served in that capacity until he retired in 1988. Guy Garrett was a long service member of the March of Dimes Board of Trustees in its New York Chapter. Throughout his life, Mr. Garrett used his leadership skills in the service of God. He was a faithful member of Wharton Memorial Baptist Church in Nelson, VA where he served for more than twenty years as a Deacon. He was bestowed the honorable status of Deacon Emeritus in April 2007. Mr. Garrett is survived by his two children, Lynn Henderson Harris and Guy Garrett, III, both of Durham, NC; a daughter-in-law, Linda Burdine Garrett; a brother, William Garrett of Oklahoma City, OK; four grandchildren, Kira Henderson of Macon, GA, Otis Henderson, Priscilla Garrett, and Shirley Garrett, all of Durham; one great-grandchild, Michael Henderson of Macon, GA, and a host of other relatives and friends who cherish his memory. He was preceded in death by his brothers, James Garrett and Arnold Garrett and a son-in-law, Lucious Harris. A Celebration of Life service will be held on Saturday, February 12, 2011, at 11:00am at Wharton Memorial Baptist Church at 57 White House Road in Nelson, VA. The service will be preceded by a visitation from 10:00 to 11:00am in the church sanctuary. The family requests that friends and family consider making a donation in Mr. Garrett's honor to Alzheimers North Carolina, Inc. in lieu of sending flowers (1305 Navaho Drive, Suite 101, Raleigh, NC 27609; telephone 919-832-3732 or 1-800-228-8738). Should a gift of flowers be preferred, the family florist is Avenue Florist in Clarksville, VA; 434-738-8888.

SCHNIPPER--Sidney, 93, of Boca Raton, FL, previously of Roslyn, NY, died February 10, 2011, following a brief and courageous battle with cancer. He is survived by his wife of 44 years Elaine, sons Robert and Eric, daughter-in-laws Ellen and Rhonda, his beloved grandchildren, Elizabeth, David, Lauren, Julia, and Ava, his sister Ruth, and his brother Murray. He was predeceased by his daughter Cheryl and his sister Esther. He was a decorated Captain of the New York Fire Department, and was credited with single-handedly saving four children from a burning building in 1950. The patriarch and first of his family born in America, he was a graduate of Newtown High School, and attended St. John's University and Law School. Following his retirement from the NYFD, he became a stockbroker at Phillips, Appel and Walden and then a record setting life insurance agent at Massachusetts Mutual, where in 1979 he sold the largest group policy in American history to the New York Fire Department, and led the firm nationwide in lives sold and volume consistently until his retirement in 1987. An avid lifelong student of history and politics, he spared no expense or effort for the pursuit of his sons' education. He was blessed with incredible charisma, perseverance, wit and humor, and took tremendous pride in having raised two sons who became physicians and saved lives as he did in the Fire Department. Services will be held on Sunday at 2pm, at IJ Morris, 21 East Deer Park Rd, Dix Hills, NY.

HUBSCHMAN--Henry A. Henry A. Hubschman, who had a distinguished career in law, government and business, died of cancer at the age of 63 in his Greenwich, Connecticut home on February 9, 2011. He was revered by all as a person of the highest intellect, character and integrity, as a caring and steadfast friend, and as a loving and devoted husband and father who put his family first. His boundless energy, insatiable curiosity, bed-rock authenticity, deep compassion, wry humor, natural leadership and commitment to the public interest made him an exemplar in both his professional and personal life and earned him profound respect, admiration and love from all who knew him. Henry was born in Newark, New Jersey on August 12, 1947, the son of Morris and Esther (Weissmann). On June 9, 1985, he married Joanne L. Goode, and their marriage of 25 years was marked by strong mutual support, the shared joy of raising their four children and Joanne's selfless care-giving in the last years of Henry's life. They took special pleasure in hosting friends and family at their summer home on Martha's Vineyard. He is survived by Joanne, his two daughters, Lilly and Josie, his two sons, Ellis and Nathan, as well as his sister, Susan Wainberg, and his nephews, Jonathan (wife Sarah) and Zev (wife Cara) Wainberg. As a father, he had high expectations for his children's service to society but also was committed to helping them find their own lodestar and chart their own course. Henry graduated summa cum laude from Rutgers University in 1969 and magna cum laude from Harvard Law School in 1973, the same year in which he received a Master's in Public Policy from Harvard's Kennedy School of Government. He was a law clerk to Judge Frank Murray of the U.S. District Court for Massachusetts from 1973-74. He was an associate (1974-77 and 1979-80) and then a nationally recognized litigation partner (1980-1992) at the law firm of Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver and Jacobson in Washington, D.C. He was Executive Assistant and invaluable advisor to Patricia Roberts Harris, the Secretary of the Department of Housing and Urban Development, from 1977-79, and served on the board of directors of the Federal National Mortgage Association from 1979-81. Following his outstanding service in law and government, he became General Counsel of GE Aircraft Engines in 1992, where he was a lawyer, counselor and leader beloved by the global leadership both of GEAE and the parent company, GE. In 1997, he became the President and CEO of GE Capital Aviation Services, the commercial aircraft financing and leasing business of GE (and a unit of GE Capital). He enjoyed remarkable global success, growing the company to a fleet of 1800 aircraft placed with nearly 250 airlines in over 75 countries. Under his leadership, the company's aircraft assets grew from $10 billion to $49 billion, making it the largest aircraft leasing business in the world. It had offices in 25 cities across the globe and offered productivity solutions as well as aircraft finance to the world's airlines. Henry has been widely recognized as one of the aviation industry's outstanding leaders, enjoying unqualified respect from his customers and his competitors. Henry served as Chairman of GE Capital Aviation Services from 2009 until his retirement earlier this year. He has served as a director of the GE Fund and the Jewish Federation of Greenwich. He was an avid reader and tennis player who enjoyed talking for hours with his friends about law and government, business and global developments, books and movies---and sharing an occasional bit of political gossip. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, www.mskcc.org 888-444-6613 or Dana-Farber Breast Cancer Treatment Center www.dana-farber.org 800-525-4669. A funeral service was held on February 10, 2011 at Temple Sholom in Greenwich, Connecticut.

LADD--John, of Providence, RI and Lancaster, NH, died at home on February 6. A Professor of Philosophy at Brown University for over 50 years, he published widely on ethics, political and legal philosophy, Kant's ethics, medical ethics, and computer ethics. His interviews with Navajo elders became the basis of his first book The Structure of a Moral Code. He was the founder of Brown's Program in Biomedical Ethics and the first director of the Center for the Study of Race and Ethnicity in America. He was educated at Harvard and during World War II he saw active duty on minesweepers and submarines, retiring with the rank of Lt. Comm. He is survived by his wife of 46 years, Rosalind Ekman Ladd, three daughters and four grandchildren.

An article last Friday described the group Jewish Voice for Peace, whose support for antigovernment protests in Egypt has led to tensions among some Jews in the Bay Area. After the article was published, editors learned that one of the two writers, Daniel Ming, had been active in pro-Palestinian rallies. Such involvement in a public cause related to The Times's news coverage is at odds with the paper's journalistic standards; if editors had known of Mr. Ming's activities, he would not have been allowed to write the article.

Let's have a 21-gun salute and one last encore of ''Time of Your Life'' for the performers who will be leaving the Broadway musical ''American Idiot,'' as it prepares to welcome a new round of cast members on March 1. Davey Havok, right, the lead singer and frontman of the rock band AFI, is the latest California punk rocker set to make his Broadway debut in the show. For a two-week run he will play the role of St. Jimmy, taking over from the Green Day frontman, Billie Joe Armstrong, the composer and a co-author of ''American Idiot,'' publicity representatives said on Thursday. Also joining the cast are Justin Guarini, the ''American Idol'' runner-up and a veteran of the Broadway musical version of ''Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown,'' who will inherit the role of Will from Michael Esper, and Van Hughes (''9 to 5,'' ''Hairspray''), who will succeed John Gallagher Jr. as the show's protagonist, Johnny. Another newcomer, Libby Winters, makes her Broadway debut as the Extraordinary Girl, taking over from Christina Sajous.

The New York University professor who had a camera inserted in the back of his head as part of an art project was forced to remove part of the camera on Friday because his body had rejected it, the Chronicle of Higher Education reported. The camera was to take a photograph every minute as the professor, Wafaa Bilal, went about his day. The project, which raised privacy concerns at the university, was called ''The 3rd I,'' and was organized by a new Qatari museum called Mathaf: Arab Museum of Modern Art. According to the Chronicle, the device, which was installed by a body modification artist in a tattoo shop in Los Angeles, was originally mounted on three posts that were attached to a titanium plate implanted between Mr. Bilal's skin and his skull. But Mr. Bilal's body rejected one of the posts, despite treatment with antibiotics and steroids, and he was in constant pain. So on Friday he had the post removed. While the wound heals, he is tying the camera to the back of his neck. Why didn't he do that in the first place? ''It's a performance,'' he told the Chronicle. ''With the performance comes endurance. But also it's a commitment. And I didn't feel that strapping something around my neck would be the same.'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

GALLANTZ--Lillian, 94, died at home January 13. Born in Rochester, she received her diploma in Art and Design from the Rochester Athenaeum in 1935, then set out for New York City, where she kept painting for seven-plus decades. From 1959-61 and again from 1964-69 she was at the Art Students League and later painted daily at her Union Square studio. Her work was selected for the ASL's Fellowship Exhibition, optioned for its permanent collection, and selected for a juried show at the National Academy. She loved painting, but she loved her family even more, worrying about, fussing over, and taking care of one and all. She is survived by George, her husband of 71 years, her children Michael and Judy, grandchildren Abby and Ben, and great-grandchildren Micah and Emmet. In the days since her passing, cards and letters from the many people drawn to her over the years speak of her "vibrant and infectious warmth," "easygoing charm and friendship," "independence and lack of pretense," "generosity of spirit," and "open, kind good nature." All true, and yet not enough to do her justice. We miss her so. Her memorial will be held Sunday, February 13, 2011, 1:00pm, at The Pen and Brush, 16 E. 10th St. Send donations in her memory to the New York Theater Workshop, NARAL Pro-Choice America, or Amnesty International.

In his last fall collection, Joseph Altuzarra showed black wool suits trimmed out in glossy black goat hair and dresses with lacing. At once sensual and tough, the clothes made a statement. Retailers were impressed with Mr. Altuzarra's sophistication. But there is another aspect of his talent that has shown itself before: a desire to be a little less constructed and formal. On Saturday night, at Milk Studios, Mr. Altuzarra played with that style for his loosest, most commercial collection to date. It wasn't his most exciting, but it may relate easily to how young women like to dress. And it may supply Mr. Altuzarra with working capital for future collections.

Keeping in mind dozens of fashion week parties can, well, start to blur, the designer Prabal Gurung has come up with a sort of forget-me-not for his after-party, which is being held tonight at Mr. H in the Mondrian Hotel. Detail-obsessed Prabal has teamed up with Sally Hansen and Belvedere Vodka to create a nail lacquer line and cocktail list, that match his own collection. A way to continuously serve up his modern take on Victorian-era style (he describes his fall collection as Miss Havisham meets John Singer Sargent's ''Parisian Beggar Girl''), "Crinoline" is your classic Greyhound, and a White Cosmopolitan masquerades as "Dorian Grey." Each drink has a coordinating nail shade available at Sally Hansen. Or, follow the recipes below to keep your fashion-week buzz going.

In Wisconsin, winners apparently appreciate other winners. After No. 13 Wisconsin beat No. 1 Ohio State, 71-67, on Saturday and ended the Buckeyes' run at an undefeated season, Badgers Coach Bo Ryan was the subject of a laudatory Twitter message from Green Bay quarterback, and Super Bowl M.V.P., Aaron Rodgers that called him "the best coach in college basketball." Not a bad day for Ryan: his team beats the No. 1 team in the country and he gets a major compliment from the state's No. 1 folk hero. (Hat tip to Quickish for the Rodgers Twitter message.)

A terrific show from Daisuke Obana at N. Hoolywood paid an elegaic homage to Ansel Adams' photographs of Yosemite and the intrepid mountaineers who scaled the famed Half Dome. The hirsute and hearty models, looking sun ravaged, carried ropes, picks, and oversized packs down the runway in the elegant Park Avenue Armory that serving as an ersatz explorers club. This mustard yellow chunky cable knit sweater, matching gaiters and cap worn with a blown out plaid coat and knickers was tops.

Linda Fargo, the fashion director of Bergdorf Goodman, was coming out of the backstage area of Prabal Gurung's show just as I was going in. I think both of us were a little surprised at the shift seen on Mr. Gurung's runway, from his clean and bright sportswear last season to full-on evening glamour for fall, with louche-ly draped dresses in vampy red and pink, feathers from top to bottom on some looks, lace prints that seemed to disintegrate on others and stockings with a pattern that suggested corset ribbons.

I said hello to one or two members of the fashion tribe I had not yet seen - you see everyone eventually in your dreams - and then I went out into the cold and walked to the Prince Street station. Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Elle Muliarchyk.

From the looks of their fall collection, this winter has taken a toll on Rag & Bone designers David Neville and Marcus Wainwright. "There's a lot of shearling; it's Eskimo-inspired," said the makeup artist Gucci Westman backstage. "It's makeup you would do if you were on a trek in Bhutan or something. Like you'd use eyeliner because you heard it would keep bugs away." Unfortunately, at least for John Galliano during a damp summer, this last part is not true - but nonetheless, Westman's handiwork, all done using the products she's created with Revlon, is very pretty. "I'm using a purple lipstick on the bottom [lid] and then brown shadow over it, and then I'm using black liner to rim the eyes. I'm bringing the shadow down further than normal. The cheeks are just windswept; I'm using that same purple color all over the cheeks and the lips." The hairstylist Guido Palau crafted very loose braids of varying thickness and number to go with the reference. "It's very clean and natural," he said. "I want it to feel hardly in there, so there's a point of reference but it's not overly anything--like when a girl starts braiding her hair by herself. It's kind of an easy one." Exactly what you'd want when hiking through the Himalayas or, you know, Brooklyn.

Though winter salt's effects on the city are numerous - de-iced sidewalks, salt-splotched cars, canines sporting booties or cradled in the protective arms of owners - less immediately obvious is the impact on the natural environment, including the fungi underfoot. MOYSE--Blanche Honegger. The musicians, board and staff of the Marlboro Music School and Festival mourn the loss of the last of our founders and extend deepest sympathy to her family. Through her 101 years, her infectious love of music and of the works of J.S Bach inspired generations of our participating artists and also illuminated her performances for her devoted audiences. In addition, with her creation of the Brattleboro Music Center, its school and concerts, she gave an invaluable gift to the community that will remain as a vital legacy of her vision and generosity. The Marlboro Music Family

After months of uncertainty, the near financial collapse of a movie studio, a change in directors and a heated labor dispute, the cast of Peter Jackson's two-film adaptation of ''The Hobbit'' was at last introduced to the news media on Friday at a press conference in New Zealand. The event, held on Friday at the Park Road Post production facility in Wellington, featured Martin Freeman, the British ''Office'' and ''Sherlock'' star who will play the pint-sized Bilbo Baggins, as well as the actors who will play his 13 dwarf companions, but Mr. Jackson, who was hospitalized last month for ulcer surgery, did not attend. In a statement that was read at the news conference, Mr. Jackson said: ''I'd love to be with you all this morning, but I'm currently under a medical form of house arrest, to prevent me from overdoing it until fully recovered from my recent operation. I'll be jumping back into it very soon, and to be honest the guys that you'll be talking to this morning make me laugh so hard, right now I'd be in danger of popping a few stitches.''

An exhibition of ancient Chinese artifacts will go forward at the University of Pennsylvania Museum of Archeology and Anthropology, after all. The exhibition, ''Secrets of the Silk Road,'' which includes materials, including two mummies, recently excavated at desert burial sites in western China, was organized by the Bowers Museum in Santa Ana, Calif., and was shown there last year and subsequently at the Houston Museum of Natural Science, where it closed on Jan. 2. It was scheduled to open at the Penn Museum on February 5, but last week, three days before the planned opening, the museum announced that China had requested that none of the artifacts be displayed. As a result, the museum would only show photographs, multimedia presentations, and a recreation of an excavation site; it offered refunds to those who had bought advance tickets and said that the exhibition would now be free. The problem now seems to have been crossed signals between the museum and the Chinese government, in which the museum was approved as a venue by regional officials but not, as required, by the central authorities in Beijing. The Philadelphia Inquirer on Thursday quoted a spokesman for the Chinese Embassy, Wang Baodong, saying that the central government had only approved the show going to Santa Ana and Houston.

An article last Saturday about the ability of Fred Wilpon to retain ownership of the Mets in the wake of the lawsuit filed by the trustee in the Bernard L. Madoff fraud referred incorrectly to a senior editor at Forbes magazine, which values sports franchises. Michael Ozanian is one of several executive editors; he is not ''the executive editor.'' (The magazine's editor in chief is Steve Forbes.)

A bill that has been proposed in the Iowa state legislature would require the University of Iowa to sell Jackson Pollock's ''Mural,'' an 8-by-20-foot painting, to pay for scholarships. The work was valued at $140 million in 2008, the Iowa City Press-Citizen reported on Thursday. ''Such a sale would violate a fundamental ethical principle of the museum field,'' the Association of Art Museum Directors and the American Association of Museums said in a joint statement on Friday. ''An accessioned work of art may not be treated as a disposable financial asset.''

Well, you're in luck. A spate of Q.&A. sites have started up in recent years with a personal finance focus.

A former convict wanted on charges that he stole a BMW sports car last month and stuffed its critically injured owner in the trunk was killed Friday in a shootout with officers on a fugitive task force in Florida, officials said. The suspect, Barion A. Blake, 30, had been sought since Jan. 26 in the attack on Akeem Ajimotokan, 33, who had advertised the car, a BMW M3 coupe, for sale online for $46,000. After meeting Mr. Ajimotokan, the police said, Mr. Blake stabbed him repeatedly, nearly sliced off one of his ears, stuffed his bound body into the trunk of the car and drove off. The car was abandoned after an accident in Upper Manhattan.

(Hallmark) ACCIDENTALLY IN LOVE (2011) Jennie Garth (''Beverly Hills, 90210''), above, plays Annie, a widow and mother of a 6-year-old girl, Taylor (Dannika Northcott), who is losing her eyesight. Ethan Erickson is Eddie, the actor behind -- or rather, inside the costume of -- Mulligan the Rabbit, a popular children's television character, who, on his way to a film audition, crashes his car into Annie's. At first Eddie and Annie are enemies. And then, after Eddie invites Taylor onto the set of his show to meet Mulligan, whose human identity Eddie hasn't yet revealed, they're not. Soon Mulligan is paying for an experimental surgery that could give Taylor her vision back -- and Eddie is falling in love with Annie. Marilu Henner plays Annie's mother; Fred Willard is Eddie's manager. Peter Facinelli, Ms. Garth's husband, wrote the script. 8:15 A.M. SUTTER CREEK, Calif. -- Standing in a cramped, slanted and slippery crevice some 500 feet below the earth's surface, David Cochrane turned his eyes to a ribbon of marbled quartz -- mainly gray, amber and white -- and found the one hue he was actually looking for. ''Right there, see? It's small but it's very colorful,'' Mr. Cochrane said, pointing at a shiny speck no bigger than a seed. ''It's got that nice yellow color.''

An article on Thursday about efforts by rights groups in Afghanistan to seek an International Criminal Court investigation of possible war crimes by Taliban insurgents misstated the United States government's position regarding the legitimacy of the court, established by a treaty that took effect on July 1, 2002. The Clinton administration signed the treaty on Dec. 31, 2000, but the Bush administration renounced the treaty on May 6, 2002, contending the court could be used to prosecute American soldiers. It is not the case that the United States ''never signed the treaty.''

An article on Thursday about differing business strategies at Nokia and Hewlett-Packard misstated the weight of the H.P. TouchPad in relation to a rival device, the Apple iPad. Both devices weigh 1.6 pounds; the TouchPad is not ''half the weight'' of the iPad.

LAPIDES--Ruth R. passed away peacefully at home in Woodbridge, CT on February 10, 2011. Her zest for life, love of family and friends and creative spirit was ever present in her passion for the arts, her warm and hospitable home, and her many paintings, sculptures and garden. Mrs. Lapides was the beloved wife for 54 years of the late Robert E. Lapides, and daughter of the late Dr. Harry S. and Gladys L. Rosenberg of Meriden, CT. Mrs. Lapides attended St. Margaret's School, now the Chase School, in Waterbury, CT, and graduated from Barnard College with a B.A. in history in 1947. Her lifelong involvement in the arts of New Haven was honored twice. In 2005, she received the C. Newton Schenck III Award for Lifetime Achievement and Contribution to the Arts from the Arts Council of Greater New Haven, a cast bronze award which she had designed in 1993. In 2010 Mrs. Lapides was the recipient of the New Haven Symphony Women of Note Award. She pursued her artistic talent in the 1960s when she began painting with watercolors, acrylic and oils. Always on top of the current trends in art, fashion and style, she began creating oversized abstract paintings. She could be often found exploring MoMA and the galleries of NYC. Mrs. Lapides began sculpting, inspired by the aluminum manufactured at her husband's company, United Aluminum Corporation in North Haven. Kaiser Aluminum purchased several of her sculptures for their national headquarters in Oakland, California, and also produced a video on Mrs. Lapides' work, which was shown on public television. She was awarded commissions for cast bronze sculptures for local and national charities and organizations. Mrs. Lapides' tree of life sculptures are installed across the US, including the Leadership Development Center of the YWCA in Phoenix, Arizona and the Michael J. McGivney Center for Cancer Care of the Hospital of St. Raphael's, in New Haven in 1993. She created a bronze sculpture in 1995 for the Brennan Center for Justice in New York City, which was presented to former Justice Brennan of the US Supreme Court by his law clerks. Mrs. Lapides was an active leader in the arts community. She motivated countless others to actively connect with New Haven's leading arts organizations. As President of the O.C. Marsh Fellows program, Mrs. Lapides entertained the crowd as she introduced the monthly speakers. Over five decades, she served as a member of the Boards of the Arts Council of Greater New Haven, Creative Arts Workshop, Yale Art Gallery Associates and the New Haven Symphony Auxiliary and she was also a fellow of Branford College at Yale. Ruth delighted in helping to plan spectacular galas on behalf of many New Haven arts organizations. She was also politically active. She was a founding member of the Women's Grassroots Committee of The Aluminum Association, Inc., of Washington, D.C. in 1977, and Secretary and Vice-Chairperson of the North Haven Parks Commission from 1960 to 1966. Mrs. Lapides was a member of the North Haven League of Women's Voters where she also served on the Board of Directors from 1960 to 1975 and she served as President of the Democratic Women's Club of North Haven during the 1970s. Mrs. Lapides adored flowers, especially orchids. Her spectacular garden included rare and unusual plants. But most of all, she was thoughtful and generous, sending her love with gifts of flowers on any and all occasions. Mrs. Lapides is survived by her loving children and their spouses, John Lapides and his wife Melanie Ginter of New Haven and their children Natalie and Harrison, James Lapides and his wife Michelle of Brookline, MA, and Susan Lapides and her husband Peter Wilson and their children Sofia and Xia of Cambridge, MA. The funeral service will be held Sunday, February 13 at 1:30pm at Congregation Mishkan Israel, Hamden, CT. Memorial contributions may be made to Congregation Mishkan Israel, 785 Ridge Road, Hamden, CT 06517, the Art's Council of Greater New Haven, 70 Audubon Street, 2nd Floor, New Haven, CT 06510, the Creative Arts Workshop, 80 Audubon Street, New Haven, CT 06510 or the charity of your choice. Services are being made by The Weller Funeral Home, 493 Whitney Ave., New Haven. To sign a memorial book please visit wellerfuneralhome.com.

An article in the special Wealth section on Thursday about private placement life insurance misstated the number of basis points and the percentage used to arrive at the $50,000 in fees on a $5 million onshore insurance policy. It is 100 basis points, or 1 percent of the total policy value -- not 10 basis points or 0.1 percent of the total.

An obituary on Thursday about Mark J. Hulkower, who successfully prosecuted the C.I.A. agent Aldrich H. Ames for treason, referred incorrectly to his espionage work. Mr. Ames worked for the Soviet Union and Russia for nine years; he was not based in Moscow for nine years.

WASHINGTON -- With a showdown approaching over the need to raise the federal debt limit, White House officials feel they have the upper hand over Congressional Republicans who want to use the debate on the measure to force deep spending cuts, people familiar with the administration's thinking say. While Republican leaders say they hope to avoid a market-shaking crisis, many conservatives in the party are insisting on using the issue as leverage to extract big if unspecified concessions from President Obama, leaving Wall Street concerned and even some Democrats wondering if the White House is in for a more dangerous fight than it anticipates.

Back when the Wayne Shorter Quartet made its first tour, in 2001, it sometimes gave the impression of holding back. It seemed infinitely elastic, as if its members could theoretically push the music far into abstraction and still make sense but that they preferred to work within limits. The group -- Mr. Shorter on tenor and soprano saxophone, Danilo Pérez on piano, John Patitucci on bass, Brian Blade on drums -- hungrily and sympathetically explored Mr. Shorter's compositions, and set a high level of collective improvisation. But it was Mr. Shorter's show, and the rhythm section elevated his individual presence and performance, his unpredictable phrases and vulnerable shouts. If you felt good about Wayne Shorter, you were seeing him get what he deserved.

The Internet radio service Pandora Media filed Friday to go public, and the company said it planned to raise as much as $100 million in its stock offering. The company's filing shows that Pandora's revenues have significantly improved in the past year, although it is still not profitable. The company's revenues roughly tripled to $90.1 million for the first nine months of 2010, compared with a year earlier. Still, Pandora's recorded a net loss of $328,000 for the period. For the first nine months of 2009, the company's loss was far wider: $18.6 million.
The State of the Art column on Thursday, about Internet-organized group buying, misspelled the name of a defunct predecessor to the popular current site Groupon. It was called Mercata, not Mercato.

The woman I was sharing a taxi with the other night, after a dinner party, told me that she would rather report from a high-risk combat zone than do what I do for a living. This, by the way, is a quintessentially urban woman who values highly her creature comforts. So what she was saying to me was that theater was, to her, a form of unspeakable torture. Mercifully, I can say that I am more familiar with the happy kind of showstopper than its opposite. But in the past couple of weeks I have experienced two instances of bummer showstoppers, though with different reactions. The first was at the Theater at St. Clements Church, where the Red Bull Theater was performing the seldom-seen Jacobean drama ''The Witch of Edmonton.'' An early scene involves two fathers coming to an agreement that their son and daughter should be married. The dialogue was exchanged with credible naturalness when suddenly one of the actors seemed to go blank.

The Wealth Matters column on Jan. 29, about the comparative advantages of private foundations and donor-advised funds for charitable giving, referred incorrectly to the tax benefits of the two approaches. The tax deductions are limited to a percentage of the donor's annual income; they are not determined as a percentage per gift.

Things are often best when small; many find kittens infinitely preferable to cats, and sports cars preferable to minivans. And to Julian Velasco, curator of Brooklyn Botanic Garden's collection of 400-plus bonsai, his tiny spruces and minuscule maples are far superior to their sky-high siblings. When it comes to gala dinners, less is rarely more, but as guests at Small Scale, the garden's bonsai-themed Japanese dinner on Friday night discovered -- the meal was also miniature.

The going rate for your thoughts used to be a penny. Now the producers of the Broadway musical ''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark'' are offering $60 goodie bags to people who serve in focus groups that will respond to several performances. Two focus groups attended Thursday night's performance, and four more are scheduled to be at Friday night's show and the Saturday matinee. It's not unheard of for Broadway producers to use focus groups, and the musical has used them before since preview performances began on Nov. 28. But these are the first since largely negative reviews of the show by theater critics across the country were published on Tuesday. OnTrack Research, a marketing and consulting firm, is coordinating the focus groups, and here's the rub: participants only get to see Act I or Act II, not both. They are then asked to fill out surveys and join in discussions in a ''V.I.P. room.'' The details of the focus groups were outlined in an e-mail to participants from OnTrack Research. Here is the full e-mail, which a focus group participant passed along and which was authenticated by the production on Friday. From: OnTrack ResearchDate: Thursday, Feb. 10, 2011 at 5:30 A.M.Subject: Confirmations - Spiderman - Turn Off the Dark - February 2011

Three months after Yale University and the government of Peru announced a tentative accord under which Yale would return a group of artifacts excavated at Machu Picchu, Yale formally signed a partnership agreement on Friday with a Peruvian university to establish a joint center where the objects will be conserved, studied and displayed. The center will be at the Universidad Nacional de San Antonio Abad del Cusco, in Cusco, the city closest to Machu Picchu, and will be called the U.N.S.A.A.C.-Yale International Center for the Study of Machu Picchu and Inca Culture. It will include a museum exhibition space; a storage site for the archeological artifacts, which include stone tools, ceramics and human and animal bones; and a laboratory and research area. Students and faculty members from Yale are expected to visit the center for training, research projects and field work; students and faculty members of the Peruvian university will also visit Yale. Meanwhile, a small number of artifacts will be loaned to Yale for display at the Yale Peabody Museum of Natural History. The agreement ends a long-running cultural-patrimony dispute over the artifacts, which were excavated in 1912 by a Yale explorer, Hiram Bingham, and have resided at Yale since then. For years, Peru has said the objects were only on loan to Yale and should long since have been returned. Yale argued that it had returned all borrowed objects in the 1920s, and had full title to the rest. In 2008, Peru sued Yale in federal court, and last year it threatened to file criminal charges against the university.

In 1859, Paul Du Chaillu, a young explorer of French origin and adopted American nationality, wandered out of the jungle after a four-year expedition in Gabon.  He brought with him complete specimens of 20 gorillas, an animal almost unknown outside West Africa.  The gorilla's resemblance to humans astonished many people, especially after Darwin published "On the Origin of Species" later that year.  The politician Edwin M. Stanton was soon calling Abraham Lincoln "the original gorilla" and joking that Du Chaillu was a fool to have gone to Africa for what he could as easily have found in Springfield, Ill.But the more common way to deal with our resemblance to monkeys and apes then was to fob it off onto other ethnic groups - typically black people, or sometimes the Irish.  A few white scientists even purported to find physiological evidence, in the configuration of the skull, for classifying other races as separate species, not quite as far removed as Caucasians from our primate cousins.  This undercurrent of scientific racism would play out to devastating effect in Du Chaillu's own life.

Larry Mishel emails me to second my concern about Charles Plosser's blithe assertion that unemployment is about shifting workers out of construction.
