The sweeping appearance of remixed fabrics has been an early trend of the fall collections, where you're as liable to find a cloth coat with fur sleeves as a dress made out of four kinds of tweed. What I liked about Preen's fall collection was that the designers Justin Thornton and Thea Bregazzi combined fabrics in a way I haven't seen anyplace else. Plus the show was darn good.

Derek Lam's last few collections have been tailored and somewhat minimalist, the type of clothing that often gets paired with a nearly nude face and natural waves on the runway. But Lam hasn't shied away from making beauty statements: most recently, the electric coral eyeliner and '60s waves for spring 2011 created by the hairstylist Orlando Pita and the makeup artist Tom Pecheux, both of whom were on hand early on this Sunday morning to work that magic again. "The collection today is inspired by uniforms, so I did this school-girl uniform hairstyle, where the girl scrapes her hair back and puts a barrette in her hair," explained Pita. "But we're not doing the barrette, to keep it a bit more streamlined." The hair was straightened with a T3 iron, pulled into a clean half-ponytail and set with T3 Control Hairspray. Pecheux created a slate gray smoky eye using silver and black Estee Lauder shadows (available this fall), which he paired with a nude matte lipstick, brow pencil, and Estée Lauder Bronze Goddess Soft Duo Bronzer. "Derek Lam's clothes are very feminine and very luxurious, but very graphic and minimal at the same time," said Pecheux, a sentiment that was echoed by the manicure Jin Soon Choi paired it with. "It's a wintery white from Estée Lauder called Porcelain - very clean, minimalistic, bright white," she said. "White nail polish works on short to medium length nails, and I did a round shape - I've done it at a lot of shows, it's more feminine."

Patrik Ervell's precise aesthetic and consistent references to technical fabrics made a perfect foundation for this tight, dramatic show. In his runway set, as in his clothing, he makes the most efficient and effective use of the seemingly simple:  overlapping opaque nylon parachutes furled in the wind provided by a series of fans. There was a stark uniformity to the clothing, both cohesively and militaristically. A navy cotton twill jumpsuit covered in zippered pockets and topped by a bomber style jacket was my favorite of the flyboy styles.

Sunday morning, coffee and a sparkling Derek Lam show: not a bad start to the day. Invoking George Balanchine's practical wisdom ("There are no new steps, only new combinations"), Mr. Lam showed classic sportswear shapes and fabrics in fresh ways. The show was a pleasure to watch. He had a variety of jackets: a smoky-blue wool peacoat, a trim bomber that combined ebony beaver and black nylon. And he paired them with sharp-looking trousers with a wide stripe down the side or, say, a pencil skirt in a nubby black-white-wine tweed.

LOS ANGELES -- To the general public, the Grammy Awards are three and a half hours of television in which about nine awards are quickly handed out between starry performance segments. But for the music industry, the ceremony -- to be held on Sunday night at the Staples Center -- is the culmination of a weeklong schmoozefest of private parties, daytime conferences and breakfast meetings in different hotel restaurants.

"It was kind of Kate Moss in her Johnny Depp days meets Oasis meets couture, to take the collection from a rock-n-roll feel to more of a womanly look," explained the hairstylist Tina Outen of the directive that inspired the amorphous hair at Altuzarra. She was filling in on sound byte duty for Paul Hanlon, the show's key hairstylist, who was busy presiding over the swarm of stylists - three per girl - busy scraping hair back from the face, dousing it in product (chief among them Frederic Fekkai Coiff Bouffant Lifting & Texturizing Spray Gel), clipping it into twists and coils, and setting with a blow-dryer. "When the clips come out, they're going to start to destroy [the shapes] by pulling out pieces to make it more 3-D," said Outen. "When [the models] are in the line, Paul's going to do his magic." In between, the makeup artist Tom Pecheux painted on a glamorous take on the '90s Kate Moss cat-eye. "I was like, what is a young designer like? Who does he want to dress? And which kind of woman wants to wear a cool young designer? A rock chick," said Pecheux. His take replaced that "rock chick" staple, black liquid liner, with M.A.C. Rich Purple Chromagraphic Pencil on the eye's waterline and M.A.C. Keep It Cool Eye Shadow (available fall 2011), used to a soft liner effect, brushed out to the brows. "I went for silver on the inner corner of the eye, almost like a futuristic tear." And the crimson lip? "It's a huge controversy! Because that lip color is so ladylike, so bourgeois," said Pecheux with a laugh. "But I was like, why not break the rules? A rock chick is a rock chick."

Apparently, an awful lot of things can go wrong on Valentine's Day. Last week, we asked you to reach into the darkest cranny of the heart-shaped box where you store your memories of romantic torment, and share a tainted bonbon or two with us. Many of you did. Here they are.

Just when things couldn't get any tougher for "Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark" on a weekend when that musical was slapped with two safety violations by the New York State Department of Labor, Broadway's favorite $65 million punch line was once again skewered by "Saturday Night Live." Saturday's "S.N.L." included the above fake commercial for a law firm that specializes in winning settlements for audience members who have been injured by the show (including a certain Irish rock star who's sustained irreparable damage to his reputation). That firm's name? Gublin and Green, of course.

For his fall men's collection, the designer Richard Chai homed in on individuality, and the striking relationship between "unconventional beauties in refined clothes." The hair stylist Kevin Ryan agreed backstage, explaining that "these men are not perfect, these are real men with flaws." To create a "disheveled, slept-in feel," Ryan first liberally applied Bumble & Bumble Surf Spray and Sumo Tech to create a matte, dry texture, then used his own R Session Tool "Root Control," a ceramic heated comb, ideal for taming frizz and flyaway strands. And since the overall goal was to "make hair look rough and not too groomed," styles were finished with spritzes of TIGI Rockaholic Dirty Secret Dry Conditioner. For mysterious, sultry eyes, the makeup artist James Kaliardos used M.A.C. Satin Taupe and Charcoal Brown eye shadows and M.A.C. Brush #213, which "created a smoky eye without looking like sharp eyeliner." Kaliardos then pressed M.A.C.'s Brit Wit Creme Blush into models' lips and cheeks, and patted M.A.C. Line Filler all over the face to minimize pores and even out complexion. Forgoing foundation altogether, Kaliardos used concealer minimally, to "veil the skin" and not disguise individual imperfections.

Kevork Kiledjian, the Paris-born designer who founded the Guilty Brotherhood line, recently moved to New York to start a new namesake women's wear label from his Crosby Street atelier. In this novel, a teenager’s crush on David Cassidy helps shape the rest of her life.
A father reports on, and a son describes, the experience of schizophrenia.
The rise and fall of an anarchist collective is the subject of Justin Taylor’s first novel.
An ex-C.I.A. bin Laden hunter worries about U.S. complacency.
Amy Chua preaches tough love and high expectations in a memoir about the lengths she went to in pushing her daughters to excel.
Economic principles may not sound romantic, but knowing a bit about game theory and loss aversion may increase the likelihood of happiness.
The Allure of the Seas is a cruise ship built for those longing to get lost in a strange, wondrous, digital world of lights and colors.
In creating the Raptor, Ford essentially ignored the engine and lavished its efforts on transforming the chassis into a Baja-ready bump-annihilation system.
Dr. Shutterbugs; doctored expenses.
Why pictures of object collections are popular now.
Ford will take a shot at a hazily defined product niche later this year with its C-Max — whether it’s called a small minivan or multipurpose vehicle.
Jonathan Klinger is driving his 1930 Model A Ford for a year as his regular transportation.
When your daily driver is an octogenarian Model A Ford, you must be prepared to improvise.
The new Mazda 5’s size offers a compromise for skeptical minivan buyers.
After a stroke, the words go missing for the very first time.
You’re welcome to linger in a cafe, as long as your reading material isn’t battery-powered.
A selection of cultural events.
The new Mazda 5 is distinguished from other minivans by its small size, a design that is more common in Europe and Japan, where such minivans are called “multipurpose vehicles.”
Larger-than-life figures, ripped from the headlines, are giving new juice to opera.
As Natalie Portman continues to slash across movie screens as a ballerina playing the Swan Queen for the first time, four real women are preparing for the role.
John Fetterman has turned the busted town of Braddock, Pa., into a national symbol of hope, hard work and authentic blue jeans. As an actual place to live, however, it’s a much harder sell.
The great achievement of Kenneth Slawenski’s reverent biography, coming just a year after Salinger’s death, is its evocation of the horror of his experiences in World War II.
A sampling of intriguing tactics for locating love: familiar oldies that have been dusted off, and modernized, technology-driven alternatives.
Many people are finding it hard to accept the “new” signs of the zodiac. And many think the designations affect their relationships, too.
If an early bird’s car horn is disrupting your sleep, ask the offender: why honk when you could twitter?
Photos of President Richard Nixon’s 1972 trip to China, and photos from the Met’s new production of “Nixon in China,” the opera inspired by that visit.
A look at recent productions of Tennessee Williams’s late works.
The artist’s work is the subject of a retrospective at the New Museum.
A beach-lovers’ suburb that’s not overly car-dependent, with a sociability factor that keeps people coming back.
The redesigned best-seller lists, which make their debut this week, open up strange new vistas on the publishing multiverse.
Fifth Avenue was once prime town house territory. Today, an 1871 brownstone stands alone between 62nd and 63rd Streets.
Federal safety regulators are considering whether a rule change in 2006 has increased the likelihood of accidents caused by a vehicle rolling away.
No need to gaze longingly at Manhattan when the action is all around you.
Brooklyn, New York City’s most populous borough, is a destination in its own right.
After Anne Bauso decided to move out of Garden City, N.Y., she went apartment-hunting in the livelier area of Brooklyn Heights.
The A.P.R. is seen as providing a more complete picture of the cost of a mortgage, but it often omits some expenses.
Babycastles in Queens recreates the camaraderie and the aesthetics of playing video games in a friend’s basement, but it features titles that can’t be found anywhere else.
An independent video game arcade in Ridgewood, Queens, with a low-fi, do-it-yourself aesthetic.
A look at the opera “Nixon in China” by Max Frankel, a former executive editor of The New York Times who won a Pulitzer Prize for his coverage of Nixon’s trip to China.
Lynda Benglis, who has challenged the art establishment for decades, remains in the avant-garde. A retrospective of her work is being shown at the New Museum in New York through June 19.
The Japanese don’t rush their drip-coffee process, and the results speak for themselves.
Unlike Cirque du Soleil, which masks its acrobats, the 7 Fingers circus troupe insists its performers share themselves — faults and all — with the audience.
Cloth filters, slow drips and hand-cranked mills.
Recipe from Caitlin Williams Freeman, the pastry chef of Blue Bottle Coffee.
For the centennial year of Tennessee Williams’s birth a few enterprising companies are attempting rehabilitation of his unsuccessful later works.
Steven Tyler of Aerosmith brings a rock ‘n’ roll affability to “American Idol” to replace Simon Cowell’s deliberate bile.
With cruise bookings on the upswing, bargains are harder to come by this year. But it’s still possible to nab a deal, if you know what to do and act quickly.
Sex-abuse scandals involving priests have shaken Ireland, but is that enough to break the grip of the Catholic Church?
Sex-abuse scandals involving priests have shaken a nation to its core, but will the anger translate into a separation of church and state?
“Stephen Rodrick’s vivid picture of Marty Peretz underplays one ofthe man’s essential characteristics: his extraordinary kindness to young people.:
As newsrooms shrink or disappear altogether, the power of an independent press goes with them.
Proposals that Prime Minister Ehud Olmert and President Mahmoud Abbas made in 2008 offer a path to a deal amid the region’s turmoil.
America’s role in the peace process.
As Egypt erupted, a band of imprisoned Islamists fought for their lives amid the flames.
With the death last month of Daniel Bell, we lost a prescient big thinker on many subjects, including ideology and American politics.

BENGTSSON--Bob. Artist and Industrial Designer, 74, died at home in Mukilteo, WA, on January 18. Bengtsson was born in New York City, to Ernest and Gertrude Bengtsson, March 19, 1936. He attended Bryant High School, Queens, and graduated with a Bachelor of Industrial Design, Pratt Institute, 1957. He also painted at the Art Students League for seven years. His career began in New York furniture design. He also worked at the Port Authority of NYNJ where he designed the PATH logo. After working for United Aircraft and Westledge School in Connecticut, he was the first Director of Design for Amtrak. He retired from Boeing's Concept Center in February, 2010. A prolific painter, Bengtsson, won numerous awards for painting and sketching. A retrospective show will hang at the Whidbey Island Center for Arts, Langley, WA, until the end of February. He is survived by his wife, Merilee Armstrong Bengtsson, son, Jon and daughter, Jordi.

BROCKWAY--Don, 62, died on February 6, 2011 after a year long illness. He passed away in a perfect circle of love surrounded by his adored daughters Carolyn and Emma and his devoted wife Kathy. Son of Hope Brockway and the late Robert Brockway, he is also survived by his brothers Richard and Peter (Susan), his son-in-law Rob Parrish, his loving aunt Joy and his beloved sister-in-law Karen Johnson. He will be remembered by his many friends for his gentleness, his passion for music and books, and his brilliant, quirky wit. A memorial service will be held at a later.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Banks Could Have Key Role in Mets Suit,'' Feb. 9: The trustee in the Bernard L. Madoff fraud cause, Irving H. Picard, will argue that the Mets owners Fred Wilpon and Saul Katz were sophisticated investors who should have known that Madoff's returns were impossible. But what about JPMorgan Chase, which forbade its brokers to deal with Madoff (because of information obtained by being Madoff's banker)? Or Merrill Lynch, which also refused to do business with Madoff because of knowledge (arrived at via sophisticated analysis, one assumes) that his stated returns were impossible?

THE Pakistani public, long skeptical of American goals in Afghanistan and the Muslim world, is now outraged over Washington's insistence that the authorities release a former United States Special Forces soldier charged with killing two Pakistani men last month. In this instance, as always, Pakistan's tumultuous news media is the prism through which United States policy is reflected to the people, who have found themselves at the center of America's struggle against terrorism. So far, the picture has not been pretty: the George W. Bush administration demonized the Muslim news media; Muslim journalists returned the favor. But research shows that the Obama administration has the opportunity to take a more sophisticated approach to those who drive public opinion throughout the Islamic world.

An article last Sunday about the Denver Art Museum's decision to attribute Indian art to individual artists rather than to tribes misidentified the president of the Native American Art Studies Association. She is Karen Kramer Russell, who is also associate curator of Native American art and culture at the Peabody Essex Museum in Salem, Mass. -- not Kate C. Duncan. Ms. Duncan is past president of the Native American association.

IT'S official, ladies: You can now get married in Vera Wang for less than $1,500. From the draped bodices to the swirls of tulle to the hand-appliquéd lace, her new line is called White and it's all Vera. In addition to that virginal shade, the dresses are available in ivory, blush and champagne -- something women taking another trip down the aisle might appreciate. Hair accessories, including a crystal comb ($128) and an embellished headband (shown, $98), are the final touch. As to finding the perfect guy? That's your problem. For information, go to davidsbridal.com. EDWARD BARSAMIAN

BRAGARNICK--Ruth. December 20, 1914-January 23, 2011. Survived by son, Peter, nieces and nephews. Predeceased by parents, Nels and Ida Welander, husband, Robert, daughter, Ellen, sisters Gert Swanson and Mim Gunkleman. Board of Trustees, People to People. Served as President and on Board of Directors of the Girls Clubs of New York (now BronxWorks). Director of Development for the Family Counseling Services and involved in many fundraising galas and events. Memorials to BronxWorks, Inc., attn: Noelle Ito or Family Counseling Services, Attn: Judith Margolis in Westhampton Beach.

WALBRIDGE--Elizabeth M. (Libby) died at home on February 7th in Blue Bell, PA. She was 94. Born on November 21, 1916 in New York City, she graduated from Chapin School and Bennington College. During WWII she worked for the Quartermaster Corps. She married Cope B. Walbridge on July 26, 1947; they were together 62 years! She was a talented artist, homemaker, and volunteer. A member of the Blue Hill Troupe, Ltd since 1940, she was also active in the Colonial Dames of New York City and Goldwater Hospital. She is survived by three children: Charlie (Sandy), Eliza and Peggy. A memorial service will be held at 11:30am on Tuesday, February 15th at St. Thomas's Episcopal Church, Fort Washington, PA.
Manohla Dargis and A.O. Scott take reader questions about the Oscars, and will answer them in the Feb. 27 Arts & Leisure section. nytimes.com/carpetbagger

An article on Jan. 30 about San Francisco's first-rate Italian restaurants misspelled the name of one restaurant and omitted part of the name of another. The restaurants are Adesso, not Odesso, and Tataki South, not merely Tataki.

MANY taxpayers may be in for an unpleasant surprise this filing season: despite the extension of Bush-era tax rates, some of the breaks they enjoyed on their 2009 returns are not available for 2010. As a result of the tax changes that President Obama signed into law on Dec. 17, taxpayers should also make sure they have the most up-to-date information, as many tax publications were printed before then.

Survivors: Carolyn Woodard, sister, and husband, David, Lincoln Abbott, brother, and wife, Elizabeth. KOSSOY--Joan Y. (Nee Laxer). After a courageous battle with cancer my wife and best friend for 55+ years in the presence of her loving family passed away peacefully on Friday, February 11, 2011. Her love, kindness and warmth radiated every day of our lives and all who knew her. She was a devoted wife, cherished mother and adored grandmother. She is survived by her daughter Pamela, her three sons and their wives Peter (Sharon), Matthew (Dana) and Adam (Jennifer) and seven grandchildren, Colby, Alexa, Ryan, Jesse, Ricki, Katherine and Sydney. She will be greatly missed, but my family and I have precious memories which we will treasure and which will last forever. You fought a good fight; now rest in peace my love. A memorial service will be held Friday, February 18, 2011, at 10am at Gutterman's Memorial Chapel, 7240 N. Federal Hwy., Boca Raton, FL.

RUBIN--Phillip H. passed away in New York City on January 30, 2011. Born in the US and raised in Paris, France, he became an accomplished and well regarded international businessman. He is survived by his long time companion Ana R.S. Eskreis who lived with him in Paris and New York City and his family in Paris: his brother Bruce Rubin (and family), his aunt Nicole Amson and his two daughters Nathalie and Karine. He will be greatly missed and loved forever.

METROPOLITAN A caption with the Connecticut Calendar in some copies last Sunday for a painting by Margaret Tsirantonakis misidentified the gallery where an exhibition of her work can be seen through Saturday and misstated the title of the show. The exhibition is at the Loft Artists Gallery in Stamford, not the Minor Memorial Library in Roxbury, and it is titled ''Inside/Outside Color,'' not ''Inside Out.'' Because the wrong gallery was given, additional information was also incorrect. The Lofts Artists Gallery is at 845 Canal Street; the phone number is (203) 323-4153; and the gallery's Web site is loftartists.com.

Dearg grandmother of Steven (Jen), Mindy (Richard), Ricki (David), Shari, Randi (Larry), and Seth (Farrah). Adored great-grandmother of 11. She will be forever in our hearts. Services at Guttermans, Woodbury, L.I. Sunday 2pm.

A review on Jan. 23 about ''Lastingness,'' by Nicholas Delbanco, erroneously connected some sculptures by Michelangelo with ''the aesthetic of old age.'' Though Michelangelo, who was nearly 89 when he died, continued to create great art in advanced age, his half-finished ''Slaves'' were by and large the work of his 40s.

Ritz, and two sisters Geraldine Cope and Lucile Adams. A 1937 graduate of Southwest Texas State Teachers College, she had a long career as a Federal Government accountant. She is survived by her son, John David Treadway-Ritz and granddaughter, Robyn Framme of Richmond, Virginia; and two nieces, Gerry Jordan of McKinney, TX and Kristen Paula Adams of San Marcos, TX. The cover article on Jan. 30 about extreme sports in New Zealand erroneously attributed a distinction to Shotover Jet, a jet boat company. Other commercial jet boat companies there offer 360-degree spins; Shotover Jet is not the only one in the country to do so. The article also included a quotation from an American who referred incorrectly to No. 8 wire, a type of wire that most farmers in New Zealand used for fixing things. The reference should have been to fencing wire, not chicken wire.

An article on Jan. 30 about Martin Peretz, former editor and publisher of The New Republic, misstated the difference in ages between him and Al Gore, a friend whose campaigns Peretz has supported. It is nine years, not six. The article also misstated the combined ages of Norman Mailer and Peretz when they clashed over a review Peretz wrote. It was 147, not 149. Additionally, the article referred incorrectly to the fate of the siblings of Peretz's father, Julius. His brother Jacob also emigrated from Poland to the United States; not all his siblings died in the Holocaust.

The Evening Hours column on Jan. 30 referred incorrectly to the barber chair used by the artist Al Hirschfeld, which was unveiled at the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts on Jan. 25. He sat in the chair while drawing; his subjects did not sit there.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Wilpon's Ownership of Mets Is Threatened,'' Feb. 5: If the Wilpons need help to get through their current financial crisis, give New Yorkers the chance to help them. Stop looking for an individual partner and take the Mets public. The Boston Celtics did so in 1986, when the team was worth only $120 million. The Florida Panthers followed suit in 1996, as did the Cleveland Indians in 1998.

A BLIZZARD that stranded hundreds of cars on Lake Shore Drive, followed by a series of subzero nights, might have left Chicago motorists dreaming of summertime tire burnouts and top-down cruising. Automakers are gladly stoking those fantasies during the Chicago auto show, which opened to the public on Friday and runs until Feb. 20. Functionally, the show serves as a victory lap for vehicles seen in January at the Detroit auto show, which this year included electric and hybrid machines like the Ford Focus Electric and Toyota Prius C concept. But American automakers, having emerged from the Detroit pressure cooker with increased production momentum and a restored measure of public good will, are primarily treating Chicago this year as an anachronistic showcase of pig iron and horsepower.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Facing Title IX Pressure, Cal May Restore the Teams It Cut,'' Feb. 9: Universities would have an easier time meeting Title IX requirements if the N.C.A.A. would bring back limited substitution for football.

Grandmother of Jordan, Eric, Lauren, Truly, Alison, Sophia, Zander, Logan, Avi and Jonathan. Also survived by her mother Ann Gordon. Service: Sunday, 11:45am at "The Riverside," 76th St., at Amsterdam Ave.

SALDUTTI--Valerie A.,age 49, of Goldens Bridge, NY died Friday, February 11, 2011. She is survived by her husband: Samuel Saldutti and children: Michael J., Stephen J. and Lauren M. all of Goldens Bridge and her father Richard Donald Hanrahan of Long Beach, NY. Sister of Mark (Mary) Hanrahan of Westport, CT, Kyle (Kenneth) Reitman of Goldens Bridge, NY; Corinne (Thomas) DiBari of Long Beach, NY and Brian (Lorraine) Hanrahan of East Meadow, NY. also survived by 12 nieces and nephews. SCHNIPPER--Sidney, of Boca Raton, FL, formerly a longtime resident of Roslyn, NY passed away on February 10, 2011 at the age of 93. He is survived by his devoted wife Elaine, two sons, Robert Schnipper, M.D., and Eric Schnipper, M.D., (and their wives Ellen and Rhonda), five grandchildren Dr. Elizabeth Schnipper Maidman, David, Lauren, Julia and Ava, and two great-grandchildren, Sofia and Alex. He is also survived by his sister, Ruth Orkand, and his brother, Dr. Murray Schnipper. Sidney was predeceased by his daughter Cheryl, his sister Esther, and his first wife Sophie. Sidney was a distinguished and decorated member of the New York Fire Department, retiring as a Captain, and went on to an outstanding career in the insurance and securities industries. He was a serious student of history, government and politics, a lifelong Republican, and very fervent in his pursuit of education for all of his family-his children, his grandchildren and his nieces and nephews. Sidney will be forever in our hearts and will be remembered always for his devotion, love and generosity to his family. Rest in peace Sidney. You had a great ride!!

TOWNIES The most surreal -- or perhaps just confusing -- aspect of my new work space is the quietude. At my old job at Harper's Magazine, people would congregate in the hallways kibitzing about books and politics, swapping gossip and jokes. When deadlines loomed everyone retreated to their offices to complete their tasks when no one was looking, as if hard work was a vaguely unstylish matter best left to the imagination. But here at Green Desk, a ''virtual office'' space in the Dumbo neighborhood of Brooklyn, conversation is démodé. Most of the folks here work at jobs that have been represented to me -- a forced refugee from print publishing -- as exciting, borderline sexy and bristling with restless Web 2.0 energy: Bloggers! Graphic designers! An Internet radio station with enough listeners that its D.J. can afford an office! Yet they all seem content to spend the day tapping away at their laptops in utter silence, the only aural distraction the low-tone hum of whichever indie rock anthem leaks from their headphones. That I find all this disconcerting marks me as a newcomer. But that's a role I'm ready to embrace. The newness-which-isn't-surrealism is important to me, and I intend to maintain it even if it requires contriving ways to stay confused. It reinforces the knowledge that my old job is over, and now I must immerse myself fully in this new one -- as a full-time writer at work on a book rather than a full-time editor trying to write a book at night.

An article on Jan. 30 about the Ace Hotel in Manhattan referred incorrectly to McMaster-Carr, which supplied a lamp in the hotel. It is based in Chicago, not California, and it is an industrial supply company, not a manufacturer.

COLE--Todd Godwin. The management, employees, retirees and fellow board members of Kaiser Ventures will be forever grateful for Todd's leadership and vision and pay special tribute to Mr. Cole as the poster child for the folly of mandatory retirement ages. All of us at Kaiser were looking forward to the celebration of Mr. Cole's 90th birthday next month, even as he worked to advance Kaiser businesses on the day of his passing. We will always remember Mr. Cole as the consummate gentleman and a man of great humor and gentleness. Kaiser Ventures LLC Richard E. Stoddard Chairman & CEO

ROBILOTTO--Joseph J.,94, died peacefully at home on January 11, 2011. He worked for The New York Times for 32 years. Upon his retirement, he was an Executive Foreman in the composing room. He enjoyed many hobbies - doing the New York Times crossword puzzles, playing chess, reading, fishing, and photography. He leaves behind his wife, Vivian and daughters Jane and Anne.

The Canadian Erik Guay won the men's downhill skiing title at the world championships ahead of the prerace favorites Didier Cuche of Switzerland and Christof Innerhofer of Italy, speeding down a 2.05-mile course in Garmisch-Partenkirchen, Germany, in 1 minute 58.41 seconds.

JUST in time for Cupid-appropriate gifting, Agent Provocateur, the naughty but very nice English lingerie label, has opened a sprawling new flagship on Madison Avenue. Boasting black lacquer furniture, hand-painted silk walls and a giant vintage chandelier, the sexy, boudoirlike space has a mezzanine level for private appointments. Pieces in this hot-pink lace and peony print are $140 to $220; 675 Madison Avenue, (212) 840-2436. SANDRA BALLENTINE

PAIGE--Judy (nee Brown), died in La Jolla, CA, on February 5th, 2011. Judy was strongly committed to helping the elderly, which started many years ago when her mother died, and which continued through-out her life time. She was the President and CFO of a successful company that she founded in 1980, and that supplied floral arrangements and plants to trade shows. She was interested in politics, and was an animal lover who gave generously to many charities. Judy was a strong, beautiful, kind woman who was respected and revered by her many friends and by her family. She is survived by her handsome husband of 60 years, Herb, and her niece Gwyn M. Brown. She is also survived by her niece Heidi L. Brown, with whom she had an especially loving and whimsical relationship. A celebration of her life will be held on February 17th, 2011, 1:00pm at Pacific Beach Chapel, 4710 Cass St., San Diego, CA, 92109. 858-488-5553.

SPORTS An article on Jan. 30 about the comedic tone displayed by N.H.L. players during a live televised draft on Jan. 28 to choose the two rosters for the All-Star Game contained several errors pertaining to one source of comedy -- Patrick Kane's humorous effort to prevent his friend and Chicago Blackhawks teammate Jonathan Toews from being drafted for his side. Kane was an alternate captain for Nicklas Lidstrom's team, not Eric Staal's. The article gave the incorrect context for a quotation by Toews and included several words not spoken by Toews. He said: ''I was halfway up the steps right here. I am kind of shocked and disappointed right now.'' That referred to his reaction when Kane chose their Chicago teammate Duncan Keith instead of him in the second round. Toews was not referring to the first-round pick by Staal's team, Carolina goalie Cam Ward. Toews did not begin his comment by saying, ''When he said 'my boy,' I was halfway up the steps right here.'' The phrase ''When he said 'my boy''' was spoken by the show's host, who asked Toews: ''When Kaner said, 'my boy,' did you start to stand up?'' And before choosing Toews, Lidstrom's team selected Dustin Byfuglien, who played for the Blackhawks last season -- not the current Blackhawk Patrick Sharp.

A picture caption last Sunday with an article about National Football League players' preparations for a possible lockout by owners referred incorrectly to the N.F.L. experience of Steelers receiver Limas Sweed, who had been saving money in case of a work stoppage. The 2010 season, which he missed because of injury, was his third in the N.F.L.; he was not a rookie.

The Field Notes column last Sunday, about Facebook and how people use its relationship-status feature, misstated part of the title of a book by Nancy Baym. It is ''Personal Connections in the Digital Age,'' not ''Personal Communications in the Digital Age.''

WASHINGTON -- With the Republican presidential campaign poised to open, conservative activists signaled on Saturday that they were unsettled over who should win the party's nomination, indicating a wide-open race for the right to challenge President Obama. For three days, prospective Republican presidential contenders delivered speeches at the Conservative Political Action Conference here, introducing themselves to influential figures who will help choose the nominee. The results of a straw poll on Saturday underscored the fluidity of the field.

ROSENBERG--Norman M.D.,a pioneer in the development of vascular surgery, passed away February 7, 2011 following a stroke. Formerly Emeritus Professor of Surgery at UMDNJ-Robert Wood Johnson Medical School and Chief of General Surgery, Chief of Vascular Surgery, and Chief of Staff at Robert Wood Johnson University Hospital in New Brunswick, NJ, Dr. Rosenberg developed a new treatment for arterial disease, a modified bovine graft - later marketed by Johnson & Johnson and now by Artegraft. A long-term advocate for the development of health policies, Dr. Rosenberg served on the board of the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation for 38 years. He is survived by his wife of 70 years, the former Ruth H. Feller, his daughter, Lois Ebin, and two granddaughters, Lauren Ebin and Julie Ebin.

The Star Street neighborhood in Hong Kong's Wanchai district is quickly becoming a magnet for creative entrepreneurs. The area is just far enough from the commercial downtown to be considered off the beaten track, but is conveniently accessible by the MTR mass transit system, as well as by Star Ferry from the Kowloon cruise terminal. Stylish boutiques and cozy restaurants have been cropping up alongside design firms in this pedestrian-friendly enclave. As Shirley Yiu, owner of nlostnfound, a vintage shop in the area, said, ''It's an intermediary between old and new Hong Kong.'' CHRISTINE CHOW
Art Robin Pogrebin

THIS month, a raucous hearing on citywide school closings offered the spectator a little bit of everything, including one parent who criticized the city's take on education reform by singing her own lyrics to the tune of Sam Cooke's ''Wonderful World.'' (''They know a lot about charter schools, and they think that merit pay is cool.'') Two members of the Panel for Educational Policy, which votes on the closings, nearly came to blows over whether to cancel the meeting because of the weather. Charter school supporters followed a script, students rapped and the schools chancellor, Cathleen P. Black, lost her composure at the end of the night when she mocked protesters.
FORGE By Laurie Halse Anderson

Andrew Breitbart, the owner of several conservative Web sites, was served at the conference on Saturday with a lawsuit filed by Shirley Sherrod, the former Agriculture Department employee who lost her job last year over a video that Mr. Brietbart posted at his site biggovernment.com. The video was selectively edited so that it appeared Ms. Sherrod was confessing she had discriminated against a farmer because he was white. In the suit, which was filed in Washington on Friday, Ms. Sherrod says the video has damaged her reputation and prevented her from continuing her work.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Two Teams Show Divide in Debate on Safety,'' Feb. 4: Green Bay's Donald Driver is a true football hero for reminding quarterback Aaron Rodgers that no game is worth the risk of his health, and for urging him to sit out the rest of a game after a hard hit. As it turned out, Rodgers had sustained his second concussion of the season and eventually left that game and missed the next game, proving Driver's concerns to be well founded.

Some of winter's newest coats have flyaway hems with tablecloth points. From the back, the long versions of the coats suggest a praying mantis standing on its hind legs. It all started a few years ago with a sweater with one sleeve, the other side a trailing scarf. The designer Rick Owen applied the idea to sophisticated city coats. A Rolls-Royce on Fifth Avenue seemed to be thinking along the same lines.

Here's a sampling of readers' responses to Judith H. Dobrzynski's article about the Denver Art Museum's decision to attribute Indian works to individual artists rather than to tribes. ''It is good to see museums going through the effort to credit the artists for their creativity. Artists have signed their names to their art and craft pieces since writing began. When I read the name of the artist next to the piece that he or she created, for that moment that person is being remembered, the inspiration being passed on to me, no matter when he or she died.''

BLASHKO--Abe, 90, artist and political satirist, died on January 13 from complications of pneumonia. Born to Marx and Esther Blashko, pre-deceased by sister Rebecca and brother Leo, he is survived by his sister Sara Alchermes, her daughter Adria and two grandnieces. Born and raised in Seattle, WA, Abe began his professional career in 1938 with a one-man exhibit of twenty-five drawings at the Seattle Art Museum (SAM). Kenneth Callahan of the Seattle Post Intelligencer noted in his review that Abe's drawings were fully developed, remarkable for a young man only 18 years old. Tall and very slim, he still managed to hold a job on the Seattle docks as a longshoreman during the Depression while continuing his artwork. In 1943, he moved to New York City finally landing in Paramount Studios as an animator, eventually moving into the commercial art world. Keenly aware of the continuing struggles of the working class and atrocities of WWII, he published cartoons in progressive magazines and newspapers. He was affiliated with various galleries, most recently (1987) with the Susan Teller Gallery where in June 2010, he had a seventy-five year retrospective. His work is in many private collections throughout the United States and abroad and in many permanent public and university museum collections. In a recent letter to Patricia Junker, curator at SAM, Abe explained what inspired his drawings and lithographs: "The turbulent social and political events of the 1930s were major contributors to my early development of a point of view. I was able to feel the pulse of that period and was fascinated with the faces and activities of the people around me, a fascination with their work, play, determination, strength, greed and evil." On Saturday, 29 January, family and friends gathered at the Susan Teller Gallery to view Abe's work and to offer him a toast for enriching their lives. No one will forget Abe's genius, his talent, and his formidable wit.

Born on March 5, 1921 in Coushatta, LA., and educated at LSU, Mr. Cole was a noted businessman, with special expertise in finance and aviation. He held several positions, including Chairman and CEO of CIT Financial and CFO and Director of Delta Airlines, and served on the Boards NYSE companies, including Kaiser Ventures LLC and Primerica Corp. Mr. Cole will forever be remembered by his family and friends as a loving husband, deeply devoted to his wife, Pamela, adoring grandfather and uncle, great gentleman and scholar, a loyal friend, as well as an esteemed and affectionate mentor to many of the next generation. He was truly a Renaissance man and a Southern gentleman. In lieu of flowers, donations made be made in his memory to The Kampong, in Coconut Grove, Florida.

DUNBAR--Ernest, a globe-trotting journalist and the first black reporter hired by a national magazine, died on February 3, 2011, after a long illness. He was 83 years old and lived in Manhattan. He joined Look Magazine as a reporter in 1954 and was Senior Editor from 1959 until Look ceased publication in 1971. He was also the author of two books: The Black Expatriates (1968) and Nigeria (1974). From 1975 until 1990 he was the Chief Editor of Publications for the Exxon Corporation. He is survived by his sisters Lorraine Randle of Philadelphia, PA and Wilhelmina Johnson of Aldan, PA., his daughter, Dr. Hepsharatt Amadi, and son-in-law Qenmaakes Amadi, of Coral Springs, FL, his son Dean Dunbar and daughter-in-law Terry Cade of Manhattan, and four grandchildren: Lauren Dunbar and Makeda, Ausar, and Kamaria Amadi. In accordance with his wishes his body will be cremated. A memorial service will be held at St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University, on March 17th at 3pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in memory of Ernest Dunbar to: Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture at The New York Public Library, 5l5 Malcolm X Boulevard, New York, New York 10037-1801.

MINER--Estelle and George. Loving parents and grandparents devoted to family and their many friends. After 65 years of marriage they died five days apart. They were together in life and will now be together again, forever. Their love and laughter will be missed.

I was in the cafe at Borders last month when a homeless man asked to sit next to me. He cast several glances my way before offering me two sandwiches from his plastic Conway bag. If I hadn't already had dinner plans, I might have taken him up on his tuna fish. After an exhausting decade of dating in New York, I was grateful for any offer that came my way. My once lofty list of must-haves had been whittled down to: ''clean; ability to hold conversation a plus.'' Once I realized the man was hitting on me (either that, or he thought I was also homeless, which, being between apartments, I technically was), I, too, sized him up. He had a good frame under the layers of coats, and after a shave, a shower and some laundered clothes, he could pass for a handsomer Quentin Tarantino. I found myself lamenting the man's unrealized potential as well as the rigidity of my two-item list.

THE NEWS In a brutally frank internal memo, Stephen Elop, the recently appointed chief executive of Nokia, lambasted his company for falling behind competitors, missing big trends and losing market share. BEHIND THE NEWS Nokia, once the dominant mobile phone maker, has been outstripped at the top of the market by the iPhone, by Android-based phones in the middle and by Chinese makers at the low end. Mr. Elop compared Nokia to a man on a burning offshore oil platform, imperiled where he is but afraid to leap off into the water.

SWENSRUD--Stephen B. of Boston, MA, son of Sidney and Isabelle Swensrud, on Sunday, February 6, 2011, after a long battle with cancer. He leaves a wife, Patricia; three children, Leslie, Blake and Tony; thirteen grandchildren; his sister Lois; niece Nancy and nephew Jeff and countless devoted friends. Born in Cleveland, OH in 1933, Steve graduated from Shady Side Academy of Pittsburgh, PA in 1951, Princeton University in 1955 and, after two years of service in the US Army, Harvard Business School in 1961. As one of the early innovators in the venture capital community in Boston, he worked with Boston Capital Corporation in the 1960s and served as a Director of many venture funded enterprises for the remainder of his life. Actively involved in investment management, Steve was a Co-Founder of Batterymarch Financial Management Corporation in 1973, a Founder of Fernwood Advisors in 1975 and a Director of mutual funds sponsored by Merrill Lynch and Eaton Vance Corporation from 1982 to 2005. Steve's leadership in community service was extensive. He was a Trustee of The Federation for American Immigration Reform, Washington, DC. In the Harvard medical community he served as a Trustee of the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute for more than 25 years, a Trustee of The Children's Hospital Medical Center, a Member of the Committee on Resources of the Harvard Medical School and the Committee on University Resources of Harvard University. Additionally, he was active in the governance of The Park School in Brookline and the Museum of Science in Boston, and was a Fellow of the Massachusetts Historical Society. Gifts in Steve's memory would be welcomed by any of these organizations. Steve will be remembered for many things but particularly for his immense capacity for friendship and for his joy in the richness of life.

Jerry Sloan's coaching style was the subject of tributes and testimonials last week, but a more acute critique came a half-dozen years ago in the form of an ice bag in Greg Ostertag's right hand. Fed up with Sloan's postgame harangue about a Utah Jazz loss, the 7-foot-2 Ostertag chucked the handiest missile he could find at the silver-haired Sloan. Witnesses said Sloan simply ducked and continued his lecture unfazed.Such was the practice of player relations during Sloan's 23 seasons in Utah, an era that ended abruptly on Thursday with his resignation and that of his chief counsel, Phil Johnson.

LUIRE--Harvey, 82, of Delray Beach, Florida, Died peacefully at his kitchen table on February 10, surrounded by his loving wife, children and sisters. Harvey succeeded in business, as founder of Wilmington Paper, as he did in life fearlessly, brilliantly and on his own terms. Harvey was a gifted athlete winning two national handball championships. A self-educated man, Harvey had an insatiable appetite for learning through travel and cultural experiences of all kinds. Most of all he loved films especially the ones that took him back to his youth. He is survived by his wife Barbara, sons Steven and Stuart, daughter Betty Poster, sisters Harriet Zuckerman and Joyce Schwartz and brother Donald, grandchildren Josh, Eric, Erin, Jessica, Brett, Jonny, Briana and Hannah. HUBSCHMAN--Henry A. Henry A. Hubschman, who had a distinguished career in law, government and business, died of cancer at the age of 63 in his Greenwich, Connecticut home on February 9, 2011. He was revered by all as a person of the highest intellect, character and integrity, as a caring and steadfast friend, and as a loving and devoted husband and father who put his family first. His boundless energy, insatiable curiosity, bed-rock authenticity, deep compassion, wry humor, natural leadership and commitment to the public interest made him an exemplar in both his professional and personal life and earned him profound respect, admiration and love from all who knew him. Henry was born in Newark, New Jersey on August 12, 1947, the son of Morris and Esther (Weissmann). On June 9, 1985, he married Joanne L. Goode, and their marriage of 25 years was marked by strong mutual support, the shared joy of raising their four children and Joanne's selfless care-giving in the last years of Henry's life. They took special pleasure in hosting friends and family at their summer home on Martha's Vineyard. He is survived by Joanne, his two daughters, Lilly and Josie, his two sons, Ellis and Nathan, as well as his sister, Susan Wainberg, and his nephews, Jonathan (wife Sarah) and Zev (wife Cara) Wainberg. As a father, he had high expectations for his children's service to society but also was committed to helping them find their own lodestar and chart their own course. Henry graduated summa cum laude from Rutgers University in 1969 and magna cum laude from Harvard Law School in 1973, the same year in which he received a Master's in Public Policy from Harvard's Kennedy School of Government. He was a law clerk to Judge Frank Murray of the U.S. District Court for Massachusetts from 1973-74. He was an associate (1974-77 and 1979-80) and then a nationally recognized litigation partner (1980-1992) at the law firm of Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver and Jacobson in Washington, D.C. He was Executive Assistant and invaluable advisor to Patricia Roberts Harris, the Secretary of the Department of Housing and Urban Development, from 1977-79, and served on the board of directors of the Federal National Mortgage Association from 1979-81. Following his outstanding service in law and government, he became General Counsel of GE Aircraft Engines in 1992, where he was a lawyer, counselor and leader beloved by the global leadership both of GEAE and the parent company, GE. In 1997, he became the President and CEO of GE Capital Aviation Services, the commercial aircraft financing and leasing business of GE (and a unit of GE Capital). He enjoyed remarkable global success, growing the company to a fleet of 1800 aircraft placed with nearly 250 airlines in over 75 countries. Under his leadership, the company's aircraft assets grew from $10 billion to $49 billion, making it the largest aircraft leasing business in the world. It had offices in 25 cities across the globe and offered productivity solutions as well as aircraft finance to the world's airlines. Henry has been widely recognized as one of the aviation industry's outstanding leaders, enjoying unqualified respect from his customers and his competitors. Henry served as Chairman of GE Capital Aviation Services from 2009 until his retirement earlier this year. He has served as a director of the GE Fund and the Jewish Federation of Greenwich. He was an avid reader and tennis player who enjoyed talking for hours with his friends about law and government, business and global developments, books and movies---and sharing an occasional bit of political gossip. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, www.mskcc.org 888-444-6613 or Dana-Farber Breast Cancer Treatment Center www.dana-farber.org 800-525-4669. A funeral service was held on February 10, 2011 at Temple Sholom in Greenwich, Connecticut.
Film Neil Genzlinger

SPORTS An article last Sunday about the voting for this year's Pro Football Hall of Fame class misidentified, in some copies, the National Football League commissioner whom Ed Sabol, the founder of NFL Films and a newly elected member of the hall, called to ask about filming the championship game in 1962. The commissioner at that time was Pete Rozelle -- not Paul Tagliabue, who succeeded Rozelle.

Victoria Cardone and Martin G. Reiser were married Saturday at the Waveny House, a mansion used as a municipal building, in New Canaan, Conn. James P. Carroll, a Connecticut justice of the peace, officiated. Until July, Mrs. Reiser, 39, was a senior English language fellow at the Royal University of Phnom Penh in Cambodia, where she trained English teachers and wrote curriculums. She graduated from Loyola University Maryland and received a master's in teaching English to speakers of other languages from Columbia.

An article last Sunday about the market for new products for an aging population erroneously included a service among those offered by the Mirabella, a retirement community in Portland, Ore. It does not provide Toyota Priuses as loaner cars to residents. (A sister Mirabella community in Seattle does provide its residents with the loaner cars.)

SMITH--Chester Taber, Jr. Died February 11, 2011 in Richmond, VA. Former resident of Darien, CT and Kingston, NY. Son of the late Chester Taber Smith and Catherine Carr Smith. Devoted father of Page Smith Wilson (Kurt), Chester Taber Smith, III (Simone Peyton), and DeForest Carr Wayne (Jeff). Proud grandfather of Kaitlin, Sophie, Graham and Willy Wilson. Survived also by his only sister Carol Smith Ankerson and two nephews, Robert William Ankerson, Jr. and Samuel Brewster Ankerson. Private interment service to be held at a later date. Semper Fi.

LURIE--Harvey, 82, of Delray Beach, Florida, Died peacefully at his kitchen table on February 10, surrounded by his loving wife, children and sisters. Harvey succeeded in business, as founder of Wilmington Paper, as he did in life fearlessly, brilliantly and on his own terms. Harvey was a gifted athlete winning two national handball championships. A self-educated man, Harvey had an insatiable appetite for learning through travel and cultural experiences of all kinds. Most of all he loved films especially the ones that took him back to his youth. He is survived by his wife Barbara, sons Steven and Stuart, daughter Betty Poster, sisters Harriet Zuckerman and Joyce Schwartz and brother Donald, grandchildren Josh, Eric, Erin, Jessica, Brett, Jonny, Briana and Hannah. He was pre-deceased by his daughters Judith and Susan. Memorial contributions to Susan Lurie Scholarship Fund, East Harlem Tutorial Program, 2050 Second Avenue, New York, NY 10025. Services Sunday, February 13, 1pm at Gutterman's, 175 N. Long Beach Rd., Rockville Center.

SCHNIPPER--Sidney, 93, of Boca Raton, FL, previously of Roslyn, NY, died February 10, 2011, following a brief and courageous battle with cancer. He is survived by his wife of 44 years Elaine, sons Robert and Eric, daughters-in-law Ellen and Rhonda, his beloved grandchildren Elizabeth, David, Lauren, Julia, and Ava, great-granchildren Sofia and Alex, his sister Ruth, and his brother Murray. He was predeceased by his daughter Cheryl and his sister Esther. He was a decorated Captain of the New York Fire Department, and was credited with single-handedly saving four children from a burning building in 1950. The patriarch and first of his family born in America, he was a graduate of Newtown High School, and attended St. John's University and Law School. Following his retirement from the NYFD, he became a stockbroker at Phillips, Appel and Walden and then a record setting life insurance agent at Massachusetts Mutual, where in 1979 he sold the largest group policy in American history to the New York Fire Department, and led the firm nationwide in lives sold and volume consistently until his retirement in 1987. An avid lifelong student of history and politics, he spared no expense or effort for the pursuit of his sons' education. He was blessed with incredible charisma, perseverance, wit and humor, and took tremendous pride in having raised two sons who became physicians and saved lives as he did in the Fire Department. Services will be held on Sunday at 2pm, at IJ Morris, 21 East Deer Park Rd, Dix Hills, NY.

ALERT taxpayers can give themselves a tax cut by taking advantage of the many opportunities that Congress has put into the nation's tax code, just as this hypothetical New York suburban couple have done. This sample return was prepared by Jan M. Rosen of The New York Times in consultation with Bob Meighan, vice president of TurboTax, the tax software evening job, which he hopes will be temporary. Their biggest source of income is Felicity's salary, $71,000, as reported on Box 1 of her W-2. That, along with Samuel's salary for part-time employment, comes to $102,000 (Line 7). Felic- ity had $5,000 withheld for a tax-deferred 401(k) retirement plan, which shows up on her W-2 form, but not on their tax return. Taxable interest income of $100 is reported on Line 8a. Ordinary dividends of $425 on Line 9a include qualified dividends of $325 (Line 9b). Qualified dividends, which include most dividends from domestic stocks and stock-based mutual funds, are taxed like long-term capital gains at 15 percent for most taxpayers. (People in the 10 per- cent and 15 percent income-tax brackets, however, do not have to pay taxes on qualified dividends or capital gains.) These numbers come from the year-end tax statements on Form 1099-DIV, issued by financial institutions. Because they did not have more than $1,500 of either interest or dividends, this couple does not have to file Schedule B. Business income of $34,800 (Line 12, from Schedule C) is what Samuel earned as a consult- ing engineer after office rent and other expenses. Capital gains of $11,872 (Line 13) come from Schedule D. Samuel inherited several stocks from an aunt last year. Having seen their own portfolios wither in the market plunge of 2008, the Taxpay- ers sold the stocks as soon as they received them. system by Intuit. During 2010, our hypothetical couple -- Samuel and Felicity Taxpayer -- used several of those credits. First, they had solar energy panels installed on the roof of their home -- a project that they expect will bring substantial savings on their electric bills. Because solar panels will also help save the environment, Congress authorized a generous tax They are liable for taxes only on the realized gains on the stock sales, not on the value of the inheri- tance itself. They used the proceeds for the solar panels and to pay down credit-card debt, which had grown in the last two tough years. Their total income is $149,197 (Line 22). Next come two adjustments, often called above-the-line deductions. Samuel can deduct half, or $2,459, of his self-employment tax, which is for Social Security and Medicare (Line 27). Employers must pay one-half of those taxes for their employ- ees and can deduct their share, so self-employed people, who pay the entire tax, can deduct half. On Line 31a is $9,000 for alimony that Samuel paid to his first wife, whose Social Security number must be shown. Recipients must report alimony as income on Line 11. The couple's adjusted gross income is $137,738 (Line 37). After itemized deductions of $22,710 (Line 40, from Schedule A) and four personal exemp- tions worth $14,600 (Line 42), the couple's taxable income is $100,428 (Line 43). The program, using the most advantageous method allowed by the tax code, not the tax tables, calculated the regular tax as $16,249 (Line 44). An enormous complication in the tax code is that taxpayers are required to calculate their regu- lar tax, then calculate the alternative minimum tax, which denies personal exemptions and certain other tax breaks, notably the deduction for state and local taxes, and pay whichever is higher. Line Schedule D: Capital Gains and Losses Asset sales last year that resulted in a capital gain or loss are reported on Schedule D. Samuel sold the 200 shares each of five stocks that he inherited from his aunt. Because the value of all five stocks rose between the time of his aunt's death -- in March 2009 -- and last year, when he received and sold the shares, he has capital gains. The net gains of $11,872 are entered on Line 15. Incidentally, all gains on inheritances are treated as long term. The cost in Column (e) normally includes brokerage fees and charges, but in this case, it is simply the value on the day his aunt died. The sale price in Column (d) is calculated after brokerage fees and charges are deduct- ed. Long-term gains on stocks and stock-based mutual funds are taxed at 15 percent for people in the 25, 28, 33 and 35 percent brackets, but are tax- free for those in the 10 and 15 percent brackets. credit, which will reduce this family's taxes by $7,500. They were also able to claim education credits for their son and the ''making work pay'' credit. The interview format of tax software can greatly ease the preparation of a return and help filers, even those who know little about tax law, find the tax breaks to which they are entitled. The program selects the best options for a particular return, fills out the forms and does the calculations. TurboTax can even download many W-2 and 1099 forms that report income. An expanded version of the sample return and commentary is at nytimes.com/taxes.

AFTER midterm exams in January, my daughter's new status became official and she eagerly made the announcement: ''Mom, I'm a second-semester senior now.'' I had heard from teachers and parents that high school seniors undergo an inevitable attitude change. Some teachers plan ahead, front-loading their courses in anticipation of more laissez-faire behavior. But as the mother of a typically responsible child, I wasn't sure what to expect.

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended Saturday, January 29th 2011, at many thousands of venues where a wide range of general interest books are sold nationwide. These include hundreds of independent book retailers (statistically weighted to represent all such outlets); national, regional and local chains; online and multimedia entertainment retailers; university, gift, supermarket, discount, department stores and newsstands. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book’s sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (†) indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Perennial sellers are not actively tracked. Expanded rankings are available on the Web: nytimes.com/books. All four children’s lists appear each week on the Book Review’s Web site. EVER one to reinvent himself and his work, the photographer Bert Stern is at it again. This time, he has embellished 35 of his storied photographs from the 1960s and '70s (including this one of the model Twiggy, which is $20,000) with colorful crystals that have been hand-glued onto the prints. The images are at Staley-Wise Gallery through March 12; 560 Broadway, (212) 966-6223. SANDRA BALLENTINE

An article last Sunday about Pittsburgh Steelers quarterback Ben Roethlisberger's postseason success and how it compared to that of other quarterbacks like Terry Bradshaw and Tom Brady misstated the number of seasons over which Roethlisberger would have won three championships had he won the Super Bowl against the Green Bay Packers. He would have had three titles in seven seasons, not 10 seasons.

A report in the DVD column last Sunday about the reissue of Disney's ''Alice in Wonderland'' misstated the title of the Jefferson Airplane's 1967 hit song that refers to Alice. It is ''White Rabbit'' -- not ''Go Ask Alice,'' which is a refrain from the song.

NOVINS--Kevin Lawrence, 47, died on January 26 from complications of treatment for Hodgkin's Disease. B.A. Harvard University, 1985; Ph.D. (Computer Science) Cornell University, 1994. Former Faculty at two New Zealand Universities - University of Otago and Auckland University and recently working in the financial services industry. Mourned by his devoted partner Lisa Baas, his mother Rochelle, his siblings Douglas and Kara, and his many relatives and friends. He loved hiking, birding, running, people, and knowledge of all sorts. He was kind, caring, and a joy to be with.

KATY GOODMAN, better known as Kickball, is garage-pop's heroine of the moment. The stylish redhead from Vivian Girls and All Saints Day (seen here wearing her own clothes and an Eddie Borgo cuff) has a new pop outfit, La Sera, whose self-titled debut album (out Feb. 16 on Hardly Art) showcases her sugar-coated, church-choir-cum-'60s-dream-pop vocals. ''I had a creative burst and spent two weeks just writing,'' Ms. Goodman said of eerily morbid yet toe-tapping songs like ''Hold,'' about a couple who hug each other to death. Ms. Goodman, who has been touring Britain in support of the new album, returns to New York to play the Bowery Ballroom on March 2 alongside the husband-wife indie duo Tennis and Florida's Holiday Shores. Then she picks up right where she left off: with ''Share the Joy,'' the much-anticipated new album by the Vivian Girls, due in April. KATHRYN BRANCH

A report in the DVD column on Jan. 16 about the British television series ''Downton Abbey'' misidentified one of the characters who went down with the Titanic. It was James Crawley, an heir to the earl of Grantham -- not the earl himself.

PRICE--Carol, Cosden. former Chair of the Smithsonian Women's Committee and co-founder of the Washington Chapter of Recording for the Blind/Dyslexic, died at her home in Washington, D.C., on January 26th. She was 93. Mrs. Price was born Carol Cosden of Southold, New York, daughter of Alfred Houston Cosden and Loraine Barry Cosden. Mr. Cosden was the former president of the RikerHegeman Pharmaceutical Company. Miss. Cosden attended Miss Porter's School, graduated from Wellesley College in 1940. After the bombing of Pearl Harbor, Miss. Cosden worked in the physiotherapy clinic at New York Hospital's Cornell Medical Center, and trained to be a Red Cross nurses' aide. After the war, Miss. Cosden moved to Washington, D.C. where she worked for over a decade as the administrative assistant to Joseph and Stewart Alsop, syndicated columnists for the New York Herald Tribune. Following her marriage to Thomas Malcolm Price in 1957, Mrs. Price volunteered for Planned Parenthood, served as chair for numerous committees, including the Smithsonian Women's Committee, the Washington Opera Committee, and the Sidwell Friends Auction. Survivors include daughters Carol Loraine Price of Washington, DC, Patricia Spence Price of Evanston, IL, and nephew Edward Daley Cosden, Jr., of New Canaan, CT. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to National Parkinson's Foundation, Recording for the Blind/Dyslexic.

ON Thursday night, at the start of Fashion Week, several hundred people went to the David Zwirner Gallery on West 19th Street to see an exhibition of Philip-Lorca diCorcia's photographs. Originally published in W magazine from 1997 to 2008, the images are a remarkable record of a free-spirited period in publishing that seemed to end with the recession. They speak directly to the eye of Mr. diCorcia, with its capacity to excite and disturb, and to seek truth about human behavior in the most banal of scenes. The images were also a result of a fortuitous collaboration between Mr. diCorcia and Dennis Freedman, then the art director of W, who gave the artist carte blanche to shoot fashion stories in places like Havana, Cairo and New York. They have collected all 11 shoots in a new book, ''Eleven.'' Are they fashion stories? In a way, yes, though you rarely notice the clothes. They are really about a vacuum in the middle of contemporary life, of which fashion has been a key element. That is one interpretation anyway. I spoke to Mr. diCorcia (or P. L., as he is known) about the work then and now. Young artists should feel gratified when he says of the creative process: ''It's exactly what it's always been. It's just hard work.''

COOK--Diana Pattison, died January 24, 2011 in Los Angeles at the age of 88. A graduate of Scripps College in Claremont, CA, she pursued a career in teaching, social work, and psychotherapy in New York City that lasted 40 years. Poet, dancer, music-lover, and champion of the underdog, she is mourned and missed by her five children.

TRAVELING at this time of year presents a packing challenge: what to do with the coat? MaxMara's solution is the Cube, a reversible, convertible, collapsible Siberian goose-down puffer. Should the destination require only a bathing suit, the jacket folds into its own zippered tote. The Cube ($750 to $4,350) can be restyled with interchangeable hood trims and cuffs or shortened with hidden buttons. MaxMara, 813 Madison Avenue, (212) 879-6100. CHELSEA ZALOPANY

"You know those old women in the street who are a little bit eccentric? There's always one living next to you. They put too much blush on and they don't do their eyeliner quite well, but it looks fabulous in the end. That's what the idea was," explained the makeup artist François Nars backstage at the Marc Jacobs show. This translated to a black eyeliner NARS is releasing this fall called Via Venetto applied with a downward curve ("the opposite of Audrey Hepburn's look," explained Nars) and NARS Lokum Cream Blush applied low, near the mouth. "I think it looks like a grandmother who put lipstick on her cheeks," said Nars with a laugh. The hairstylist Guido Palau gave this aging glamor girl a Croydon facelift, creating what he called "a dominatrix ponytail" using Redken Blow Away, a gel for blow-drying, and Shine Flash for serious gloss (models wore berets made of PVC by the milliner Stephen Jones secured with black chin straps). Nails were painted a shiny peach Jacobs chose from the polish brand Zoya. "Marc is very hands on," said the manicurist Elisa Ferri, pun unintended. "He has an amazing eye."

One way to interpret the padded vinyl columns and mirrored runway at the Marc Jacobs show tonight was that it evoked the sophistication of a 1950s dressing room. Backstage, Mr. Jacobs, in a jovial mood, said he was thinking of New York this winter - hence the chilly arctic blue of the vinyl.

Just four months after revealing production plans for a four-door vehicle intended for the North American market, Penske Automotive Group said it would relinquish control of Smart USA to Mercedes-Benz USA. The announcement was made in a jointly released statement on Monday. Under the terms of the deal, Mercedes would assume distribution, marketing, sales and management responsibilities in the second quarter of 2011.

Ronaldo, the gap-toothed Brazilian striker who once dominated world soccer with an astonishing blend of strength, speed and skill, announced Monday that he was retiring from the game at age 34. Worn down by knee injuries, fitness problems and nearly two decades as a professional, he tearfully confirmed his plans at a news conference in Sao Paulo.

CAIRO - In December 2007, six weeks before Kosovo's independence I was privileged to sit in Pristina with a group of young, idealistic rising stars in the Kosovar political scene, as they tirelessly discussed their thoughts, hopes and plans for their nation to be born strong, democratic, dynamic, and politically mature. And I felt jealous. And I hoped I would, one day, I would too have such an animated discussion on the future of my country.

"Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark" had strong tickets sales last week, despite the fallout from largely terrible reviews, according to the first slice of box-office data to be released since critics weighed in on Tuesday before the oft-delayed show's official opening.

Lovers of all things Lagerfeld are already familiar with Baptiste Giabiconi, whether it's from Chanel couture shows, where the 21-year-old French male model and muse to Kaiser Karl invariably closed the show by sashaying around the runway with a giant lion's head, or frolicking in the hay with Lara Stone. Or they might know him from his various photo shoots (signés Lagerfeld, of course) or public outings with his septuagenarian mentor, including a memorable St. Tropez trip in the summer of 2010, when Giabiconi and Lagerfeld stopped by a local newsstand, dressed to the nines and trailed by hordes of paparazzi and curious tourists. But being the male face for Chanel, Fendi and Karl Lagerfeld (as well as starring in a Coca-Cola Light campaign) is apparently not enough for the slightly cross-eyed little Corsican that could; in late 2010 Giabiconi also embarked on a singing career and released his first single, "Showtime." Even though the song has been out for a few months and enjoyed considerable chart success in France, it's gone largely unnoticed by the American public. Granted, under normal circumstances the epic video (above) accompanying the release of the heavily auto-tuned single would not be considered kitsch; its Wild West theme, with Giabiconi saving a bodacious brunette from her abusive boyfriend, complete with explosive super powers in the Californian desert, is pop video cliché at its best. And Giabiconi's English ("Woz wrong wiz you, man?") is certainly better than Lady Gaga's French. But the fact that it has Karl Lagerfeld's blessing and the remote possibility of him doing a special cameo as a Bond-style villain makes it all the more enjoyable. That sadly doesn't happen, but then again, Giabiconi knows how to keep us on our toes: the video ends with a promising "To be Continued."

Mercedes-Benz's new-product parade continues apace, with the all-new C-Class coupe scheduled to be revealed at the Geneva auto show next month. In its base C250 trim, the coupe is powered by the brand's new 1.8-liter turbocharged 4-cylinder engine, developing 201 horsepower and 229 pound-feet of torque, while the higher-spec C350 receives a 3.5-liter V-6 with 302 horsepower and 273 pound-feet of torque.

Stop the presses! Or should that be, restart the presses? Either way, "Newsies," the misunderstood but much-loved Disney movie musical about the New York City newsboys who organize a labor strike in 1899, is getting a second edition. On Monday, the theater said that a stage version of "Newsies" would be the opening production at the 2011-12 season of the Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn, N.J., and would feature music by Alan Menken (the film's original composer) and Jack Feldman (its original lyricist) as well as a new book by Harvey Fierstein.

The juvenile red-tailed hawk that injured his wing crashing into the glass-walled atrium at the headquarters of The New York Times last month was released at Tupelo Meadow in the Ramble at Central Park, after a recuperative stay at Wildlife in Need of Rehabilitation and Rescue on Long Island.

The Miami Heat of last season were equal parts depressing and inspiring. The Heat roster (Dwyane Wade aside) was limited, and as a result, Jermaine O'Neal and Michael Beasley became the pillars on which Miami was forced to stand. Their season wasn't one of disaster, merely of reality; although the Heat had the league's sixth-best defense, they lacked competent offensive players to produce consistently or distract defenses away from Wade.

Peter Forsberg's latest comeback of sorts -- all of two games long, neither of which was played in front of the Colorado Avalanche fans who adore him -- is a tough way to bid goodbye to one of the game's great players. Forsberg will never show up in a lot of all-time great lists because his career was hampered by injuries, but those who watched him in his prime can recount tales of one of the most gifted players on the planet. His two Stanley Cups, two Olympic gold medals, one Hart Trophy and 885 career points in 708 games are ample evidence as well.

Nearly 10 years after the death of his father at the same speedway, Dale Earnhardt Jr. averaged 186.09 miles per hour in his Chevrolet on Sunday to earn pole position for the Sprint Cup Series' Daytona 500, scheduled for Feb. 20. It was the second consecutive Daytona 500 pole for Earnhardt's team, Hendrick Motorsports, which also won the coveted starting-line position in 2010 behind Mark Martin's qualifying performance.

Speaking of love and the Army, there is an exhibit at the National Army Museum in London chronicling the letters exchanged between soldiers in battle and those they left at home. The hundreds of pages -- some from as far back as 200 years ago -- capture a longing and a loneliness that will sound familiar even to modern lovers who close the distance with tools like Skype.

Unlike designers who approach collections with a particular theme or era in mind, Billy Reid, the recipient of this year's CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund, designs his piece by piece, which explains his infectious passion for the unique. For his fall collection, Reid said backstage, "My focus was on construction, a lot of tailoring. I spent an inordinate amount of time perfecting each piece. My men's looks are cleaner, with more subtle details than before." In line with Reid's penchant for individuality, the hairstylist Marcos Diaz created looks that were "groomed but not Don Draper." Using just the newly launched Mat Forming Ground from Davines (a supermatte clay) and his fingers, Diaz formed a natural-looking side part and left the rest of the hair "dry-looking and clean." Emphasizing approachability, Diaz said, "I'm interested in keeping hair more realistic, something you could easily create at home." The makeup artist Nadine Luke relied on a few key players from M.A.C. and her belief of "a little goes a long way" for men's makeup. Luke hydrated skin with Studio Moisture Fix, concealed as necessary, moisturized lips with Lip Conditioner, and tamed unruly brows with Brow Set (which she considers a guy's "secret weapon," as it instantly grooms both brows and mustaches). Luke finished the look with Mineralize Skinfinish, a shimmer-free bronzer that contours and provides a matte finish in a pinch, noting that "Billy Reid's guy is someone you wouldn't imagine grooming because he's slightly rugged. But really, he's a polished gentleman."Runway slide show

Few designers create pieces as timeless as Carolina Herrera, and backstage at her fall show, the beauty team was hard at work creating a look to match. The makeup artist Diane Kendal painted on what she called "a classic Carolina face": black cream eyeliner on the top lash line only with a bit of a wing, M.A.C. Haute and Naughty Mascara only on outer lashes, M.A.C. Eye Gloss on lids and M.A.C. Blush in Angel on the cheeks. "On the lips we're using a new [M.A.C.] color called Prince Noir, and we're applying it with a lip brush and then blotting it with tissue so it gives a really beautiful stained burgundy look," Kendal said. Nails were kept relatively short and painted with two coats of a shade from Creative Nail Design called Dark Ruby followed by a generous coat of Super Shiney Top Coat, "to contrast the matte textures such as fur, velvet, suede," said CND's Wanda Ruiz. The hairstylist Orlando Pita, who took the "big, beautiful necklines" into account when creating his polished, rolled bun-chignon hybrid using Moroccanoil products, clearly also had the Carolina Herrera client in mind. "I've seen messy updos for a long, long time, and I'm moving away from them," he said. "This collection is too polished for that."
