A full inventory of the Egyptian Museum in Cairo has found that 18 valuable artifacts are now missing after a break-in on Jan. 28, Egypt's antiquities minister, Zahi Hawass, wrote on his blog on Sunday. Previously, Mr. Hawass had only said that objects were damaged. Among the most important of the missing items are a limestone statue of the god Akhenaten holding an offering table and a gilded wooden statue of Tutankhamen being carried by a goddess. On Monday, however, CNN reported that 2 of the 18 objects - a heart scarab and a funerary statuette of the nobleman Yuya - had been found on museum grounds. Mr. Hawass also said that a storeroom at Dahshur was broken into on Saturday night. He told Ahram Online that eight amulets were missing. Meanwhile, there were accounts on Twitter of protests outside the offices of the Supreme Council of Antiquities, the government body run by Mr. Hawass, who was appointed by former President Hosni Mubarak.

Artists as diverse as Ashford and Simpson, Lena Horne, Del Marquis of the Scissor Sisters and Bread and Puppet Theater have all had the pleasure of being sung to, backed by or collaborating with Xavier Smith, a dreadlocked, extremely tall (6'6") fixture on the downtown Manhattan performance circuit. For the past several years, Smith - who grew up in New York, has a gently soulful voice and prefers to be called simply "Xavier" ("with a hard X," he notes, "like Ex-ayvier") - has produced a Valentine's song as a love letter to his friends, fans and whomever he might have been in love with that year. It started in 2004 with a cover of the Beatles' "In My Life," and this year's offering is a heartbreaking rendition of Curtis Mayfield's "The Makings of You" set to a small orchestral arrangement. From Bushwick, Brooklyn, where Xavier lives with Dima, his once-vicious but now sweet Himalayan blue-eyed cat, Xavier told T why he does the yearly Valentine's song.

Today is Valentine's Day, a day when you want to set the romantic mood by choosing the perfect music. To inspire us, last night was one of the music world's biggest nights: the Grammy Awards. All you have to do now is to pick the right songs - today's digital musical players and smartphones make it a snap to select them from your playlist to suit every mood. But what if you were stuck with a player that (thanks to Apple's marketing genius) makes a virtue of randomness, like the iPod shuffle? This is the conundrum that gives rise to a fascinating puzzle contributed by Dion Wong of Australia. Previously, in When Randomness Produces Certainty, we saw how randomness acting over and over can create order. The question that arises in Dion's puzzle is: How can we optimally combine randomness and order? It's a fitting question for today because, no matter how orderly a plan you might have made for a perfect Valentine's Day, randomness might just intervene. And the connection of randomness to the Grammy Awards ceremony is clear too - what random pattern of clothes (or what passes for them) did Lady Gaga wear? That might take us too far afield, so without further ado, here's the puzzle.

President Obama's proposed budget for fiscal year 2012 includes $861.5 million for the Smithsonian Institution, an increase of $100 million over the Smithsonian's last appropriation, in fiscal year 2010. The difference is accounted for by $125 million the administration is requesting for the construction of the National Museum of African American History and Culture, set to open in 2015. The Smithsonian's 2010 appropriation included $20 million for the museum's design and planning process. The museum's total construction budget is $500 million, half of which is being paid for by the federal government.

"I was really looking at tribes, at the different sorts of tribes and tribal sensibilities and habitual things tribes do, from the Masai tribe culture to the people during the Rococo period," the designer Thakoon Panichgual said backstage before his fall show. "There was a sense of uniformity about the way that they were dressing." This translated into a collection he described as "electric," and for the hair and makeup, Panichgual said he decided to go for bold instead of tempering the clothes with a basic look. The makeup artist Diane Kendal used Nars Velvet Matte Lip Pencil in Dragon Girl on eyelids and on top of it, and applied three blushes - Desire, Taj Mahal and Exhibit A, in that order from inner lid to outer lid to an ombre effect - which she blended out past the bleached eyebrows. "We wanted to have that feeling of sun and hotness but then also exotic," Kendal explained. The hairstyle created by Odile Gilbert using Kerastase products echoed that sentiment, with pieces provided by the designer weaved into a complicated-looking updo. Panichgual explained, "The hair is superslick - almost posh, really - in the front, and then it's pulled back and it's got this weird chignon whipped up with yarn and hats that we've cut up and put into the bun. There's a reality base there, but it's a bit hyper."

"I'm the sunny face of polygamy.'' Let's just acknowledge that this line, delivered by Margene, was surely the best of Sunday's episode of "Big Love." Margene, who is getting deeper into the crazy pyramid scheme that is Goji juice, has also become the spokeswoman for a family increasingly in crisis. But before we get to that and the impending divorce proceedings, I have a bone to pick with the haphazard unfolding of the episode. The matter of Alby hiring Verland to attack Don during his ice fishing trip felt random and pointless. This is the best way the writers could think of for Alby's getting back at Bill for getting Lura away from him? Even as the scene was transpiring it seemed as if the writers were doing it on a lark and were fully conscious that the plotting was arbitrary and almost jokey. (The jaunty music accompanying the attack made this especially clear.)Also: Bill's mother's dementia isn't feeling fully integrated either. Her dementia may be relevant to the season's theme of the Henricksons' general deterioration, but beyond that symbolic value, it's hard to see how Lois's condition will matter much to the final outcome of the show. Another plot development that felt half-baked was the sudden turnaround of Bill's fate at the legislature. The tabling of the impeachment felt way too abrupt.

The dream of the '90s will remain alive at least through 2012: IFC announced on Monday that it had picked up a new batch of episodes of "Portlandia," its original comedy series created by Fred Armisen of "Saturday Night Live" and Carrie Brownstein, a former guitarist and singer of the rock band Sleater-Kinney. The series, which chronicles a fanciful, not-all-that-alternate-from-reality version of the slacker paradise of Portland, Ore. (and which gave rise to hit viral videos like "Dream of the '90s" ), has become a modest hit for IFC. The cable channel, which has been emphasizing a lineup of new and classic comedy programs alongside its schedule of independent films, said the first three episodes of "Portlandia" have been viewed by 1.1 million total viewers, with most of them in the 18-49 age group that recognizes the grunge bands referenced on the show and the cameo appearances by Kyle MacLachlan and Aimee Mann. IFC said the second season of "Portlandia," consisting of 10 half-hour episodes, will make its debut in January.

It wasn't a total rout for "The King's Speech" Sunday night at the Baftas, the British version of the Oscars. The ur-British movie did take home trophies for best film, best British film, best original screenplay, best score and best acting prizes for Geoffrey Rush, Helena Bonham Carter and Colin Firth. But David Fincher won best director for "The Social Network," which also took best adapted screenplay for Aaron Sorkin. Mr. Sorkin attended, Mr. Fincher did not - he's shooting "The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo" - so his award was accepted by his stars Jesse Eisenberg and Andrew Garfield. But it was Mr. Firth's speech that was the hit of the event in London on Sunday night. (Mr. Firth also won a Bafta last year, for "A Single Man.")

8 P.M. (USA) THE 135TH WESTMINSTER KENNEL CLUB DOG SHOW The Mexican Xolo, beloved by the artists Frida Kahlo and Diego Rivera, becomes the latest addition to the American Kennel Club's list of more than 170 recognized purebreds at this event held each year at Madison Square Garden. ''Even the most ardent admirers of the Xolo concede that the dog is plug-ugly,'' Guy Trebay wrote in The New York Times. ''One description of this hairless canine of ancient lineage, a national treasure in its native Mexico, characterizes the Xolo as a hot-water bottle with pig eyes, bat ears and a rat tail. That is being polite.'' The judging begins on this opening night with the hound, toy, nonsporting and herding groups. Coverage begins on the USA Network before moving to CNBC from 9 to 11 p.m. Sporting, working and terrier groups, followed by best in show, will be judged on Tuesday from 8 to 11 p.m. on USA. David Frei and Mary Carillo are the hosts. (Above, standard poodles.) 8 P.M. (Fox) HOUSE A waitress (Tina Holmes) with an unusually detailed memory is paralyzed, but her recovery is complicated by a never-forgotten grudge against her older sister (Claire Rankin). Elsewhere Foreman (Omar Epps) helps Taub (Peter Jacobson) prepare for an exam, and House discovers the identity of the secret companion of Wilson (Robert Sean Leonard). In ''The Chicago Code,'' at 9, the police exact revenge against a cop killer, but Alderman Gibbons (Delroy Lindo) has ulterior motives when he visits the fallen officer's family.

Hoping to seize upon investor excitement over social-networking companies like Facebook, JPMorgan Chase is planning to start a new fund to invest in an array of Internet and new media companies, people briefed on the matter told DealBook on Sunday. The proposed fund, which will be run by JPMorgan's asset-management unit, is seeking to raise between $500 million and $750 million from wealthy investors to pour into privately held technology companies like Twitter and the social-buying site Groupon, these people said.

The top digital songs last year included pairs by Taio Cruz, above at a July concert, and Eminem. Rock bands (Train) and country artists (Lady Antebellum) made the list, but the chart was dominated by hip-hop and pop artists. Radio still plays a part in the digital age, since seven of the top 10 digital songs were also among the most played songs. Absent is Taylor Swift, whose many hits combined put her atop the overall airplay ranking. She was the top-selling artist last year, and her album ''Speak Now'' was the year's third-best-selling album.

The Emergency Medical Services Corporation, the nation's biggest provider of ambulance services, is near a deal to sell itself to the private equity firm Clayton Dubilier & Rice for more than $3 billion, people briefed on the matter said on Sunday. A deal could be announced as soon as Monday morning, these people said, cautioning that talks were continuing and might still fall apart. They spoke only on condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to publicly discuss the confidential deal negotiations.

FELDMAN--Annette B.,of Boynton Beach, Fla. (formerly of Mamaroneck, New York) died Saturday at age 92 after a long battle with Parkinson's Disease. Predeceased by her husband Murray and survived by her son Paul (Karen) and daughter Carol Sumers, grandchildren Lynn Lowy (Joe) and Mark (Heather), Jordan and Jonathan (Jessica) and greatgrandchildren Sophie, Matthew, Julia and Casey. She was a kind, generous, caring and loving person and an example to all who knew her. Funeral services to be held at Zion Memorial Chapel, 785 E. Boston Post Road, Mamaroneck, NY on Tuesday, February 15 at 10am. Contributions may be made to the Parkinson Foundation .

MEESE--David Harron. Died February 10th, 2011. He is survived by his second wife Mary Michell Meese, his children Cynithia, Philip, Brian, Peter and Craig and two step-children Susan Windels Ames and Edward Michell Windels. He arranged for his body to be donated for medical research. A service in his memory is planned for a later date. Memorial gifts to the Colonial Williamsburg Foundation or the Winterthur Museum would please David. They and their staff provided many new interests in history, seminars and making floor clothes adding richly to his retirement in Chadds Ford after over 31 years with IBM in New York.

BALLON--Margot Elaine, 59, died Albuquerque, NM, February 13, 2011. Longtime deputy D.A. in Albuquerque. Loving mother to Molly and Sam, grandmother to Emily, sister to Kenneth and our beloved daughter. Died peacefully after a year of pain. Lillian and Martin Ballon

We all know there are risks to storing personal information online, yet few of us take even the most basic precautions, like choosing unique and hard-to-guess passwords. On Thursday, Google will introduce a tool, known as two-step verification, that will make Google accounts more secure and less vulnerable to hackers and phishing scams.

WALBRIDGE--Elizabeth M. (Libby) died at home on February 7th in Blue Bell, PA. She was 94. Born on November 21, 1916 in New York City, she graduated from Chapin School and Bennington College. During WWII she worked for the Quartermaster Corps. She married Cope B. Walbridge on July 26, 1947; they were together 62 years! She was a talented artist, homemaker, and volunteer. A member of the Blue Hill Troupe, Ltd since 1940, she was also active in the Colonial Dames of New York City and Goldwater Hospital. She is survived by three children: Charlie (Sandy), Eliza and Peggy. A memorial service will be held at 11:30am on Tuesday, February 15th at St. Thomas's Episcopal Church, Fort Washington, PA.

Jane McGonigal is a game designer and author of the new book ''Reality Is Broken,'' in which she argues that by playing games, people can improve their lives and solve real-world problems. Here is an edited version of our talk: Nick Bilton: How did you end up as a game designer?Jane McGonigal: I was in graduate school and I was looking for a job on the side that would be fun, sort of a hobby, and I found a job working with a game designer on Craigslist.

Apparently, an awful lot of things can go wrong on Valentine's Day. Last week, we asked you to reach into the darkest cranny of the heart-shaped box where you store your memories of romantic torment and share a tainted bonbon or two with us. Many of you did. Here they are: One Valentine's Day, there was a huge snowstorm. My boyfriend called to urge me to stay at work (where my boss was offering to put people up in the nearby hotel) rather than risk driving 35 miles home. But I had a special V-Day meal all prepped, and I insisted on going home. When I got there, I got stuck on the unplowed one-way road next to our apartment, and I called him to see if he'd help dig me out.
GROSS--Robert. Loving uncle we appreciate your advice and council. Harold, Lori, Diane, Matt and Isabella

PHOENIX -- Representative Gabrielle Giffords, an eloquent speaker before she was shot in the head last month, is relearning the skill -- progressing from mouthing words and lip-syncing songs to talking briefly by telephone to her brother-in-law in space. With a group of friends and family members acting as a backup chorus, Ms. Giffords has been mouthing the lyrics to ''Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star'' and ''I Can't Give You Anything but Love, Baby.'' And as a surprise for her husband, who is celebrating his birthday this month, a longtime friend who has been helping her through her rehabilitation videotaped her mouthing the words to ''Happy Birthday to You.''
GROSSMAN--Louis. May 5, 1905--February 14, 1998 You are still our hero. Your loving family
HERFIELD--Rachel. Died February 11, 2011, at age 93. Funeral services, Tuesday at Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY. She will be greatly missed.

BERK--Chuck. February 14, 2008. Three years... hard to believe! Not a moment goes by when you are not in our thoughts. Our memories are precious. Our lives have gone on, but with an emptiness and pain that run deep. Your smile, your laughter, your love lives on in both of us. Happy Valentine's Day Chuck. You will forever be our one and only Valentine. Your so hard to live without. Now and forever you will stay in our hearts. Love, Joan and Samantha
VITAU--Jean. A true gentleman and a wonderful friend. He will be missed. Our love to Irene, Mimi, Julien, and Jake. Maura and Joel

Two years ago, Representative Chris Van Hollen and fellow House Democrats were responsible for setting President Obama's legislative agenda in motion. It was heady, historic - and hard. Today, Mr. Van Hollen, a fifth-term congressman from Maryland, is less player than color commentator. He is the ranking minority member of the House Budget Committee, which will pore over the Obama administration's budget being released Monday morning.

CREMERS--Madeleine Buchanan Palmer of Aubonne, Switzerland and East Hampton, NY died on January 15, 2011. Born in New York City on May 25, 1913, she married Herbert von Metzler in 1932; they were divorced in 1955. In 1961 she married Frederic Chapuisat, who died in 1981. In 1987, she married Epimachus Cremers, who died in 1991. She spent most of her adult life in Switzerland, and each summer would stay in her house in East Hampton. She loved the mountains and the sea and all things beautiful, both in people and in nature. Hers was a soul touched by kindness, warmth and grace. She is survived by daughters, Sascha Rockefeller and Maria von Bischoffshausen and son in law, Hans-Werner von Bischoffshausen; stepsons, Peter Chapuisat and Epimachus Cremers Jr.; stepdaughter Gita Saunders; three grandchildren, and 14 great grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

Governors and mayors facing large deficits have set their sights on a relatively new target -- the soaring expense of health benefits for millions of retired state and local workers. As they contend with growing budget deficits and higher pension costs, some mayors are complaining that their outlays for retiree health benefits are rising by 20 percent a year -- a result of the wave of retirements of baby boomers and longer life expectancies on top of the double-digit rate of health care inflation.

The Federal Trade Commission on Tuesday named Tim Wu, author of the book ''The Master Switch,'' a senior adviser for consumer protection and competition issues that affect the Internet and mobile phones. Mr. Wu, a law professor at Columbia University, is best known for coining the term ''net neutrality,'' which refers to the principle that consumers should have unfettered access to all kinds of Internet content.

While people debated whether Web sites like Twitter were important in organizing protests in Tunisia and Egypt, Andy Carvin was organizing information about the protests in an innovative way. Mr. Carvin's Twitter account was transformed into a personal news wire about Egypt and was widely praised in news media circles. By seeking out the voices of sources in Egypt and sharing them almost in real time on a social networking site, he ''provided a hint of what news can look like in an increasingly networked media environment,'' the Nieman Journalism Lab wrote in a blog post on Friday.

TEL AVIV -- When Google, the world's largest search engine, joined forces with Yad Vashem, keeper of the world's largest Holocaust archive, the first thing one Google employee here did was search for his grandfather's name. A link took the employee, Doron Avni, to a Google-operated page on the Yad Vashem Web site showing a photograph of his grandfather, Yecheskel Fleischer, taken in 1941 just after he was released from a Nazi-run prison in Lithuania.

LOS ANGELES - Arnold Schwarzenegger, no longer the governor of California, told his Twitter followers on Thursday that he was back in the film business and looking for offers. How Hollywood will welcome Mr. Schwarzenegger, now 63, is anyone's guess. But he will find much has changed since he left the movies in 2003.

HACK--Leo, beloved husband of the late Sarah, devoted father of Marcia (Isaac) Zlochower and Harold (Adelle) Hack, loving grandfather of 13, great-grandfather to 34. Leo dedicated his life to Jewish community service and worked with UJA-Federation of Greater New York and then as a long time Religious Advisor to Riverside Gordon Memorial Chapels in Southern Florida. Funeral service took place on Sunday February 13th. A traditional period of shiva will be observed at the home of Marcia Zlochower, 200 JFS Drive, Pittsburgh, PA and Harold Hack, 42 Hobart Street, New Haven, CT. Memorial donations may be directed to Yeshiva Ohel Moshe 7914 Bay Parkway, Brooklyn, NY 11214.

Senator Charles E. Schumer signaled on Sunday that he might support a merger of NYSE Euronext and Deutsche Borse -- so long as the New York Stock Exchange's name comes first in the combined company. Mr. Schumer, Democrat of New York, said in a statement that he had met with Duncan Niederauer, NYSE Euronext's chief executive, on Friday and Saturday to speak about the potential deal. Chief among the senator's requirements is whether the deal will ''keep New York on top as the financial center of the world.''

LASKEY--Harriet C. Peacefully, at age 90, on February 11, 2011. Beautiful green-eyed daughter of the late Lil and Jack Corper. Adored and survived by Joel, her devoted husband of more than 67 wonderful years. Cherished by Richard and Abbie Laskey and Jane Laskey and Charles Turcotte, her children. Beloved by Kari and Kjersti Amdam, her Norwegian AFS daughters. And treasured by Alex Laskey and Rachel Farbiarz, Jacob Laskey and Jesse Turcotte, her grandchildren. Harriet's family will endeavor to honor her memory through munificent acts of kindness and bountiful expressions of love. Funeral services at 1pm on Tuesday, February 15, 2011, at Boulevard-Riverside-Hewlett Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett. Shiva will be observed at the family home, 1354 Noel Avenue, Hewlett, on Tuesday (7-9pm), Wednesday (2-4pm and 7-9pm) and Thursday (2-4pm and 7-9pm) and at the home of Richard and Abbie Laskey, 120 Harbor Hill Road, East Hills, NY, on Friday (1-3pm) and Saturday (7-9pm). In lieu of flowers, contributions in Harriet's memory may be made to American Field Service (http://www.afsusa.org/donate/tributes-and-memorials/) or Temple Sinai of Roslyn, 425 Roslyn Road, Roslyn Heights, NY 11577.
CLOTT--Enid. Wife of Bill, mother of Abe (Sabirzyan) and Ruth. Funeral today at SAJ (212-724-7000).

Seattle's esteemed Intiman Theater, which in recent months has acknowledged financial problems, announced on Friday that it would have to close unless it could raise $500,000 by the end of March and another $250,000 each by June and September. The Intiman's board president, Kim Anderson, said in an interview that the board only became aware of the dire financial situation after the theater's former managing director, Brian Colburn, abruptly resigned on Nov. 1. At that point, Ms. Anderson said, the board unearthed problems that included unpaid bills, significant unreported cost overruns, and income that had been booked from a co-producing arrangement that had not been finalized.

KRONSTADT--Sylvia, formerly of Rockville Centre and East Rockaway, died peacefully February 6 in Los Angeles, at age 91. Survived by sons Michael (Joji Yoshimura) and Dan, preceded in death by husband Robert and daughter-in-law Angel. Retired from Bio-Science Labs and Adelphi Breast Cancer Hotline. Also remembered by nephew Peter, dearest friends Dolly and Elaine, and countless other friends.

Time Inc. has a memo for Apple: We're not waiting at the altar forever. We have Google. As magazine publishers continue their discussions with Apple to sell subscriptions on the iPad, Time Inc. has begun selling subscription bundles that include apps that run on the Android tablet software from Google.

HARRIS--Joseph Tatcher, M.D.,80, of Boynton Beach, FL, previously of Quogue, NY, passed away February 11, 2011, following a brief illness. Prominent physician, proud and loving father and grandfather. He is survived by his son Arthur and daughters Abby (Bruce), Pamela (Tom) and Julie (Jeff), and his grandchildren, Arielle, Olivia, Alexander, Matthew, Martin, Max, Sam, Lauren, Blair and Harrison. He was born in Philadelphia and grew up in New York City. He attended the Bronx High School of Science and was awarded a basketball scholarship to Rutgers College, graduating in 1952. He then attended The Chicago Medical School, receiving his M.D. degree in 1956. After an internship at Kings County Hospital, he entered military service, completing his duties at the rank of Captain in the Army. He then pursued specialty training in Urology at the East Orange VA Hospital. Dr. Harris spent his entire professional career in the private practice of Urology in New Jersey, based initially in Perth Amboy and later expanding to Edison. During his career he served as Chief of Surgery at John F. Kennedy Hospital and Chief of Urology at Perth Amboy General Hospital. He was a lover of art, classical music, travel, fine wine, landscaping dogs and a devoted booster and benefactor of Rutgers University. He was blessed with wit, humor and generosity and had a remarkable business acumen for a physician. Services will be held 10:30am Monday, February 14th at Flynn & Son Funeral Home 319 Amboy Ave Metuchen, N.J. Interment will follow at Shaarey Tefiloh Cemetery, Perth Amboy.

The cause of Riccardo Muti's fall from the podium during a rehearsal of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra on Feb. 3 has been determined. In a joint statement with Mr. Muti and officials of the orchestra, two cardiologists at the Northwestern University Feinberg School of Medicine, Donald Lloyd-Jones and Bradley P. Knight, reported on Friday that Mr. Muti had fainted because of ''a common heart rhythm disturbance.'' Although their tests reveal that he retains excellent heart function, they added, he has had a pacemaker installed to monitor his heart rhythm and deliver a small electrical charge if the heart rate should fall too low. ''Patients with pacemakers live full and active lives with excellent prognosis,'' the doctors concluded. Mr. Muti remains in Northwestern Memorial Hospital, where he is recovering from surgery for facial injuries incurred in the fall. He has canceled his remaining performances this winter, which were to run through Feb. 19. His next scheduled appearance with the orchestra is a concert performance of Verdi's opera ''Otello'' on April 7, to be repeated twice in Chicago and, on April 15, in Carnegie Hall. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Obviously this is neither a formal nor a scientific poll, but let's see what happens. After writing this week's column, I'm curious - even determined - to collect your thoughts on genetically engineered food. It should take you all of a minute to answer these four questions, with a "yes", "no", "maybe", or "need more information." Extended comments are welcome and encouraged, but for the sake of my expert poll analysis - for this, please read "casual tallying" - please begin your comment with something that looks (for example) like this:

If you want to avoid sugar, aspartame, trans-fats, MSG, or just about anything else, you read the label. If you want to avoid G.M.O.'s - genetically modified organisms - you're out of luck. They're not listed. You could, until now, simply buy organic foods, which by law can't contain more than 5 percent G.M.O.'s. Now, however, even that may not work.

In Mortimer's heyday, those charms were conferred by its patrons, and not less by their chum Bill Blass, who swathed his ladies in fox and the witty pinstripes and foulards that were the genteel uniforms of the Uptown set.

As reports of the riots in the Middle East continue to flood news outlets, I follow with a distance that is rather peculiar considering my history and interests. Having spent nearly seven months of my four years at West Point in Egypt and Tunisia, I hold a special place in my heart for the people of both countries. After all, they helped me learn their language, and thus gave me a conduit to understanding the depths of one of the world's most misunderstood regions. And while a call for liberation is certainly worthy of praise, it's difficult for me to feel proportionally excited for my friends in Egypt and Tunisia, because there is a third country close to my heart that few have considered in this equation: Afghanistan.

Are the Iowa presidential caucuses really less than a year away? How time flies. But an election year looms, as does the return of "Gore Vidal's The Best Man," the deliciously tart (when done well) play about politics, campaigns and the presidency. Jeffrey Richards and his fellow producers announced on Tuesday that they would revive that 1960 play in the spring of 2012 with hopes of catching election fever. Originally titled "The Best Man," Mr. Vidal's play involves a showdown at a presidential convention between two candidates, in essence an Adlai Stevenson character and a Richard Nixon type, brokered by an ill ex-president and complicated by secrets, machinations, and troubled marriages. Broadway had a revival of "The Best Man" not so long ago, during the campaign between George W. Bush and Al Gore and the subsequent legal battle in the fall of 2000. With political resonance and a cast led by Spalding Gray, Chris Noth, and Charles Durning, that production started off strong at the box office but had mixed reviews and declining ticket sales before closing in late December. (Mr. Gore had conceded two and a half weeks earlier.) That 2000 revival was the first Broadway producing credit for Mr. Richards, who has been a press agent since the 1970s and is now one of Broadway's busiest producers. He is reuniting his producing team from 2000 - Jerry Frankel, Michael B. Rothfeld, and Darren Bagert - to mount this production. The director will be Michael Wilson ("The Orphans' Home Cycle," "Dividing the Estate"). No cast members have been announced.

The foundation of the Broadway director Arthur Laurents and his longtime partner, Tom Hatcher, announced on Tuesday that its first playwriting award, worth $150,000, would go to Jeff Talbott, a New York City actor who has branched out and will make his Off Broadway debut as a playwright next season. The award, which is to be given annually, provides $50,000 to the writer and $100,000 toward the production costs for mounting the recipient's play. Mr. Talbott's winning play, "The Submission," described as an exploration of the importance of cultural authenticity in authorship, will be produced next season at MCC Theater, which is led by Robert LuPone, Bernard Telsey, and William Cantler. The Laurents/Hatcher Foundation Award is among the most generous in playwriting, and it is intended for emerging writers. Mr. Talbott, 46, has written only a few plays and, as a playwright, still lacks an agent. Mr. Laurents, the book writer for "Gypsy" and "West Side Story" and the Tony Award-winning director of the original "La Cage aux Folles," created the award last year. At 93, he is still writing plays himself; Mr. Hatcher, his partner of 52 years, died in 2006.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's family foundation is planning to distribute $32 million in grants to arts organizations around New York City, The Wall Street Journal reported on Tuesday. The announcement comes a year after the mayor ended a charitable program administered through the Carnegie Corporation of New York, which over a decade funneled $200 million of his personal fortune to arts and social-service groups around the city. (The Carnegie program was ostensibly supported by an anonymous donor, but that donor was widely known to be Mr. Bloomberg.)

You might have seen Go Try It On's 80s-inspired cursive logo plastered over downtown fitting room mirrors this past weekend. Now Marissa Evans, the founder and CEO of Go Try It On, has asked some of T's fashion team to take a break from New York fashion week and virtually style her online community. The almost one-year-old social network site (they launched last year at SXSW) is committed to answering the eternal question "What should I wear?" with positive criticism only - negative or inappropriate comments and photos are screened and removed immediately, says Evans. An iPhone app allows members to easily upload images of outfits in question from any location, so go ahead, take the plunge and get fashion tips from our fashion editors on gotryiton.com. T's Rae Boxer leads off today and will answer your questions between 12-1 p.m.

FRANKLIN--Dan, died of Lymphoma in his home on the evening of February 11, 2011. He was 60. Thoughtful, funny, immensely talented as a writer and communicator, and, above all, sincere, he reveled in sharing himself and his favorite things with the people he loved. For many teenagers navigating the social challenges of high school, the ultimate goal is to become part of the ''popular'' crowd. But new research suggests that the road to high school popularity can be treacherous, and that students near the top of the social hierarchy are often both perpetrators and victims of aggressive behavior involving their peers.

The few public statements by Richard S. Fuld Jr. about the demise of Lehman Brothers have often been in front of the glare of a Congressional panel. In 2008, Mr. Fuld, the investment bank's chief executive, known for his temper, appeared defensive and angry during televised testimony in which he faced a barrage of pointed and politically charged questions. As one congressman noted at the time, Mr. Fuld was the designated villain. But audio recordings released last week by the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission show a different side to the embattled chief. In a two-hour telephone interview in 2010, nearly two years after Lehman's demise, Mr. Fuld was more thoughtful and calm, occasionally pausing to ask for time to answer questions.

A full inventory of the Egyptian Museum in Cairo has found that 18 valuable artifacts are now missing after a break-in on Jan. 28, Egypt's antiquities minister, Zahi Hawass, wrote on his blog on Sunday. Previously, Mr. Hawass had only said that objects were damaged. Among the most important of the missing items are a limestone statue of the god Akhenaten holding an offering table and a gilded wooden statue of Tutankhamen being carried by a goddess. On Monday, however, CNN reported that 2 of the 18 objects - a heart scarab and a funerary statuette of the nobleman Yuya - had been found on museum grounds. Mr. Hawass also said that a storeroom at Dahshur was broken into on Saturday night. He told Ahram Online that eight amulets were missing. Meanwhile, there were accounts on Twitter of protests outside the offices of the Supreme Council of Antiquities, the government body run by Mr. Hawass, who was appointed by former President Hosni Mubarak. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

A new study backed by pro-business groups takes a harsh stance on rules intended to bring transparency to the $600 billion derivatives market. The report, published on Monday, claims that proposed regulation could cost 130,000 jobs and could cut corporate spending by $6.7 billion. The findings are clearly meant to scare politicians and drum up public support - just as financial regulators are set to testify on the issue before a Congressional committee on Tuesday. And at first blush, the study would seem to be good ammunition for the Chamber of Commerce and its other supporters.

President Obama's proposed budget for fiscal year 2012 includes $861.5 million for the Smithsonian Institution, an increase of $100 million over the Smithsonian's last appropriation, in fiscal year 2010. The difference is accounted for by $125 million the administration is requesting for the construction of the National Museum of African American History and Culture, set to open in 2015. The Smithsonian's 2010 appropriation included $20 million for the museum's design and planning process. The museum's total construction budget is $500 million, half of which is being paid for by the federal government. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

KIRBY--Fred M. II. The Rockefeller University mourns the passing of our longtime friend and benefactor Fred M. Kirby. A philanthropist of generosity and distinction, Fred Kirby will be remembered for his dedication to many causes, including medical research and education. As president of the F.M. Kirby Foundation, he was a generous supporter of The Rockefeller University, helping to create the F.M. Kirby Center for Sensory Neuroscience. Under the direction of F.M. Kirby Professor A. James Hudspeth, the Kirby Center plays a vital role on campus, fostering interdisciplinary studies of the human senses. At Rockefeller, the Kirby Foundation has also supported postdoctoral fellowships in sensory neuroscience and endowed the F.M. Kirby Fund in Regenerative Neuroscience, to help advance studies of how the sensory systems might be repaired when damaged by illness, injury or aging. In addition, the Foundation has provided generous funding for the University's Bio-Imaging Core Resource Center and our Fisher Center for Alzheimer's Disease Research. With deep gratitude, we extend our heartfelt sympathy to Fred Kirby's cherished wife, Walker; to their children, Alice Kirby Horton, Fred M. Kirby III, S. Dillard Kirby, and Jefferson W. Kirby; and to the entire Kirby family. Richard Furlaud, Chairman Emeritus John C. Whitehead, Trustee Emeritus Paul Nurse, President Paul Greengard, Ph.D., Director, Fisher Center for Alzheimer's Disease Research A. James Hudspeth, M.D., Ph.D., Director, F.M. Kirby Center for Sensory Neuroscience

The dream of the '90s will remain alive at least through 2012: IFC announced on Monday that it had picked up a new batch of episodes of ''Portlandia,'' its original comedy series created by Fred Armisen of ''Saturday Night Live'' and Carrie Brownstein, a former guitarist and singer of the rock band Sleater-Kinney. The series, which chronicles a fanciful, not-all-that-alternate-from-reality version of the slacker paradise of Portland, Ore. (and which gave rise to hit viral videos like ''Dream of the '90s'' ), has become a modest hit for IFC. The cable channel, which has been emphasizing a lineup of new and classic comedy programs alongside its schedule of independent films, said the first three episodes of ''Portlandia'' have been viewed by 1.1 million total viewers, with most of them in the 18-49 age group that recognizes the grunge bands referenced on the show and the cameo appearances by Kyle MacLachlan and Aimee Mann. IFC said the second season of ''Portlandia,'' consisting of 10 half-hour episodes, will make its debut in January. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

10 P.M. (CUNY) MORIN KHUUR: THE SOUL OF THE MONGOLIAN HORSEMAN ''Living Cultures'' is a series exploring customs and traditions around the world that are threatened with extinction. In the premiere the director Benoit Ségur travels to the Mongolian steppes, where four city children who join a family of horse herders are taught by Omba, a wise old musician, to play the morin khuur, above, a fiddlelike stringed instrument considered a symbol of Mongolia. The subjects of this 13-part documentary were chosen from a list of 166 Masterpieces of the Oral and Intangible Heritage of Humanity, identified by Unesco as deserving of promotion and protection, especially when the techniques can be passed down to children. 8 P.M. Along a freight train line that winds through Brooklyn and Queens, desolate areas are used as gathering spots or refuges for minor outlaws: graffiti painters, drug users and those who camp out with little more than a piece of cardboard, a blanket and a bottle of vodka to keep them company. In one spot, beneath an overpass on Ocean Avenue in Brooklyn, graffiti tags and writings cover the concrete walls, the illustrations rendered in so many layers and forms that they are difficult to discern. Among them, in bright red paint, is the name ''Max,'' which the police said was a tag used by Maksim Gelman, the 23-year-old man accused of killing four people during a 28-hour rampage this weekend. One of the victims was Yelena Bulchenko, an acquaintance of Mr. Gelman's who was said to have rebuffed his obsessive advances.

Scientist at Work Roland Kays, curator of mammals at the New York State Museum, is comparing the behavior of fishers (cousins of the weasel) in urban and wild settings. He posted at nytimes.com /scientistatwork. The members of the weasel family, Mustelidae, are built for running in tubes, with short legs and skinny, flexible bodies. This evolved as an adaptation to pursue prey into holes in the ground, but is now helping fishers colonize suburban forests. Carnivores require larger areas to survive than herbivores. This has traditionally kept them out of urban environments, because the remaining forest fragments simply weren't large enough to support them. Using high-resolution GPS, we have been tracking an animal called Phineas, who shows the fisher's solution to this problem: linking small forest fragments with a series of corridors. Using tubes under roads is a critical adaptation to help fishers use these forests without getting hit by cars. On the map at movebank.org, you'll see a few places where Phineas has repeatedly crossed roads in the same place. I visited four of these and found his tracks in the snow -- going through drainage culverts at three, and over the road at the fourth. Other animals were using these same strips of natural habitat, but were not able to fit through the culverts. Deer and coyote tracks showed that these animals had to risk their lives to cross the road, while Phineas and his fisher friends take the safer low road underneath. The New Old Age Karen Stabiner posted at nytimes.com/newoldage. My widowed father-in-law didn't tell anyone about his symptoms -- not his doctor and not his grown son, who found out only when a member of the extended family called to say my husband needed to fly across the country immediately to see his dad. By that point, the kidney cancer that would have been easy to treat if detected early had passed the fail-safe point. My father-inlaw was not the kind of guy who liked to depend on people, so he made sure he had to for only a very short time before he died. He was an extreme example of a familiar dynamic, which Deborah Tannen, a professor of linguistics at Georgetown University, calls ''the guy's view.'' Dr. Tannen, the author of seven books about how we communicate with one another, says many older men consider keeping difficult information to themselves a badge of courage. In this view, it's what men are supposed to do to keep from upsetting the womenfolk. That was what my father-inlaw ended up doing. My husband, deprived of the opportunity to help his father with a problem, instead helped him deal with its consequences. He showed up on his father's Philadelphia doorstep with no agenda but to do whatever his father allowed him to do -- which became more and more as the weeks went by. Eventually his father realized that it was possible to ask for and accept assistance without feeling like an obligation. Well For Valentine's Day, readers were asked for complete love stories in six words. They responded at nytimes.com/well. Ashley H: Love means never leaving me behind. Stéphane: Forty years later, dreams come true. Nicole: Boy. Girl. Best friends. Lovers. Parents. JCepans: Wounded heart healed by good man. Selma: Dog approves; maybe this guy's good? Lynsey: I was wrong. You are right. Daphne: ''Marry me?'' ''No.'' Happy ever after.

The master is Tyne Daly, playing the diva extraordinaire Maria Callas in a coming Broadway production, and now we know who is in her class: Sierra Boggess. Ms. Boggess and Ms. Daly will play student and teacher in the Manhattan Theater Club revival of Terrence McNally's Tony Award-winning play ''Master Class,'' which is scheduled to begin previews on May 24 and open on June 21. Ms. Boggess will play Sharon Graham, the aspiring opera star portrayed by Audra McDonald in the original 1995 Broadway production. (The role earned Ms. McDonald one of her four Tony Awards, this one for supporting actress in a play; Zoe Caldwell, playing Callas, won the lead actress Tony.)

''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark'' had strong tickets sales last week, despite the fallout from largely terrible reviews, according to the first slice of box-office data to be released since critics weighed in on Tuesday before the oft-delayed show's official opening. ''Spider-Man'' grossed $1,330,014, an increase of almost 3 percent over the previous week, and was the second-highest-grossing show on Broadway behind the musical ''Wicked,'' which grossed $1.44 million for the same number of performances as ''Spider-Man.'' Ticket sales for the $65 million ''Spider-Man'' hardly collapsed in the face of critical evisceration (the New York Times and Washington Post theater critics both called it one of the worst musicals in history), but the show's grosses went up minimally in an otherwise robust week on Broadway. Top-grossing musicals like ''Wicked,'' '' The Lion King'' and ''Mary Poppins'' were up 15 to 20 percent in grosses from the prior week, compared to the 3 per cent increase for ''Spider-Man.''

The conventional wisdom has it that the final report of the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission was a low-budget flop, hopelessly riven by internal political disputes and dissension among the commission's 10 members. As usual, the conventional wisdom is completely wrong. Actually, the report - and the online archive of testimony, interviews and documents that are now available - is a treasure trove of invaluable information about the causes and consequences of the Great Recession.

This week's Bits: Tech Talk show features a look at site-specific digital art. Bettina Edelstein chats with the Adobe Museum of Digital Media's first guest curator, Tom Eccles, and the first artist to exhibit on the site, Tony Oursler. Mr. Oursler, who created his piece "Valley" for the museum, explains that it reflects the human relationship to the Internet. And Mr. Eccles discusses his impressions of working with a digital environment.

The sixth day of New York Fashion Week found America's pre-eminent female designers fashioning diverging conceptions of national identity. So whose heroines were chicest? At Vera Wang, it was pleats, please. But Scorecard knows critics were over the rainbow with the Mulleavy sisters' wearable distillation of their former wool cobweb-cheesecloth-macramé creations as tailored prairie dresses. That's one way to do country strong.

The opening looks in black-and-white graphic prints at Anna Sui's show on Wednesday night really popped. That's saying something for a designer who doesn't shy away from the psychedelic, the mod, the groovy, the Art Nouveau and the Art Deco, all of which made an appearance on her runway.

President Obama this afternoon called Lara Logan, the CBS News correspondent who is recovering at home in Washington after a brutal sexual attack last Friday in Cairo's Tahrir Square, an administration official said.

The Federal Reserve periodically polls the members of its Open Market Committee -- board members and presidents of the regional Fed banks -- on their economic outlook. Their expectations are worth looking at because those are the forecasts that affect monetary policy decisions, and are therefore more important than other forecasts whether or not they are better forecasters.

Waris Ahluwalia transformed the oval space on the seventh floor of the Museum of Arts and Designinto an elegant tearoom to unveil his latest accessories collections. Surrounded by Ahluwalia's signature palm leaves and beige pleated canvas, guests admired his dazzling wing-shaped pendants and colorful cashmere and silk scarves while sipping on vintage Dom Perignon (and House of Waris tea for the abstemious). It was Ahluwalia's first New York Fashion Week presentation, and he could not contain his excitement. "I've never worked with models before!" he explained. The House of Waris pieces are made all over Asia - Bangkok, Jaipur, Kashmir, Rajasthan - but we asked this New York-based designer to share his favorite spots in the city.

Prova, Irini Arakas's five-year-old accessories line of kaleidoscopic beads, jewels and scarves favored by Michelle Obama and the electro punker TK Wonder, now includes dresses. The patterns - in a short day dress and maxi style - have the deceptively slinky curves and sassy detailing of the '40s (sleeves! knee length!) with the louche glamour of the '70s (florals, animal prints and disco fringe!). Arakas says she's found the zipper factor: "You know, when you zip yourself into a dress and it just feels so good and perfect and makes you happy." By all means, zip us up. From $595, at Ikram (Chicago) and Blue Tree (New York), or go to kirnazabete.com.

One thing you do not want to see on the way into a fashion show is an ambulance at the door. Walking on West 22nd Street this afternoon, a few editors en route to the Marchesa show were nearly run down when an ambulance pulled onto the sidewalk in an attempt to bypass the stalled traffic, but another had beaten them to the scene by turning onto the street from the opposite end. All this for what turned out to be a bloodied nose.

Two years after scrapping its original plans, Roundabout Theater Company announced Wednesday that it would produce "Bob Fosse's Dancin' " this fall at Broadway's Studio 54 theater, with director Graciela Daniele recreating Fosse's original choreography from his hit revue "Dancin'."

On Monday, the world of children's publishing lost one of its last great 20th century editors, Margaret K. McElderry, who died at age 98. As Douglas Martin noted in his obituary today, Ms. McElderry came to be known as "the grande dame of children's publishing." She was the first children's book editor to earn an eponymous imprint - Margaret K. McElderry Books - which continued, even after her retirement in 1998, and still publishes within Simon & Schuster today.

Fragrance is the most ephemeral of subjects. If you follow such things, you rapidly lose the impulse to bat an eyelash when told a scent is inspired by a flower that actually has none (Marc Jacobs Daisy), a chick flick (Fresh's Eat Pray Love trio) or the High Line (Bond No. 9) - especially when told by a well-dressed French person. So it doesn't sound unreasonable (quite romantic, in fact) that the new fragrance Cartier de Lune is meant to smell like a bouquet picked in the moonlight, but the reality is that those of us without a trained nose (or fantastic imagination) have no idea how that smells.

That's slightly higher than their last projection of 3 to 3.6 percent, released in November.

Rage Against the Money Machine Matt Taibbi is frustrated and angry at the lack of prosecutions stemming from the financial crisis: "The mental stumbling block, for most Americans, is that financial crimes don't feel real; you don't see the culprits waving guns in liquor stores or dragging coeds into bushes. But these frauds are worse than common robberies. They're crimes of intellectual choice, made by people who are already rich and who have every conceivable social advantage, acting on a simple, cynical calculation: Let's steal whatever we can, then dare the victims to find the juice to reclaim their money through a captive bureaucracy." Interboro Partners, a nine-year-old New York architecture firm, has won the annual Young Architects Program competition to transform MoMA P.S. 1's courtyard for its summer outdoor music program, the museum announced Wednesday. The architects took their inspiration from the community around the museum, which is located in Long Island City, Queens, interviewing the proprietors of local businesses and nonprofits about what materials might be of use to them and then incorporating those materials into their design, with the intention of donating them at the end of the summer.

J. C. Chandor's directorial debut, "Margin Call," a feature that takes place over the course of 24 hours on the trading floor of an investment bank, will be the opening night feature of the 40th annual New Directors/New Films series, the Museum of Modern Art and the Film Society of Lincoln Center said on Wednesday. "Margin Call," one of 28 films that will be presented during the series, features a cast that includes Kevin Spacey, Paul Bettany, Zachary Quinto, Demi Moore, Stanley Tucci and Jeremy Irons, and chronicles "a day that brings layer upon layer of human and professional wrongdoing that jeopardizes the entire fabric of the banking system," according to a statement from MoMA and the Film Society. The closing night film of the series, which runs from March 23 through April 3, will be Maryam Keshavarz's "Circumstance," about two Iranian women who begin to step outside the boundaries of their oppressive lives, and which won the Audience Award at this year's Sundance Film Festival.

The festivities then kicked off in earnest at 9 p.m., followed by yet another party - held in conjunction with V Man - at Mr. H bar in the new Mondrian hotel in SoHo. Elsewhere, Marc Jacobs and Robert Duffy held a sit-down dinner at the Lighthouse at Pier 51; Vena Cava hosted an American Express dinner at the Royalton; and Narciso Rodriguez and friends downed industrial amounts of Belvedere at his after-party at the Mulberry Project. And what would a night be without everyone ending up at the Standard?

Certain shoes have the aesthetic legs to stand the test of time. Consider the Bernardo sandal, that 1960s staple of Euro-hippiedom favored by Jane Birkin, fashion's perennial boho. Dennis Comeau, president of Bernardo Vintage Couture, is realigning the brand for this century. ''The difference with Bernardo is that you can put on a pair of sandals made in 1967 and look completely 2011,'' Comeau says. Several classic styles are being reissued this month at Bergdorf Goodman. There's a navy Bandeau platform, a chocolate Moon disc flat (updated from the original pink and priced at $225) and a jeweled thong called the Goldfinger.

There is a moment when the lens shifts, and you see life through the eyes of the person you are becoming rather than the person you have been. "I am becoming my mother," we say, and sometimes we are joking, but sometimes we have learned something deep.

"We've never done anything like this at Narciso," the hairstylist Eugene Soulemain said backstage at the Narciso Rodriguez show. "I scared the life out of him." The style, a simple and somewhat haphazard knot just above the nape of the neck, was roughed up further with the addition of a few pats of Wella Professionals Texture Touch pressed in near the hairline, followed by a few spritzes of Wella Professionals Shimmer Delight "to make it look like she's been running and sweating." Soulemain said the edgier cast of models, which included Jamie Bochert (who had never walked for Rodriguez), inspired the look. "Even though the clothes are incredibly expensive, not everything's pretty and so fitted," Soulemain explained. "It's not a red-carpet feeling." Clearly, Rodriguez was convinced, seeing as he rang the manicurist Deborah Lippmann at 3 p.m. yesterday with some color direction. "He said, 'I want a color that's not charcoal and not blue and not black, but strong' - they wanted to have some strength and toughness," Lippmann said. (The gray she created will be named by Rodriguez and produced later this year.) The makeup artist Dick Page lined eyes with Shiseido cream shadows in Purple Dawn and Caviar, a black (available this fall). "I'm trying to leave the skin alone as much as possible. Since we're at the beginning of the season, there are no big skin disasters yet," Page said, joking that his own disaster - a black eye he acquired last week - inspired the look. One skin care product even made it onto models' faces: Shiseido Benefiance Full Correction Lip Treatment, which was smudged onto the lids just before the show to create a melty effect. "It's a ridiculously expensive lip balm," Page said (it's $36). What, you expected the Narciso woman to use Carmex?

The segment linked above, which was broadcast this morning on NBC's "Today'' show, takes viewers behind the closed doors of the admissions process at Grinnell College in Iowa. Grinnell, which has received nearly 3,000 applications for an incoming freshman class of about 400, follows an intensive, holistic process similar to those used at dozens of other selective (and in some cases fiercely competitive) colleges, both public and private.

There appears to be a breath of fresh air wafting through the environmental community, reflected in Degrees of Risk: Defining a Risk Management Framework for Climate Security, a new report from the Britain-based nonprofit group Third Generation Environmentalism, or E3G. The report is enthusiastically endorsed by Bill Becker, the head of the Presidential Climate Action Plan, in a guest post at Climateprogress.

Louise Goldin, one of the bright young things of English design, chose to unveil her collection in New York this time round. "It's because of my engagement," says Goldin, 28, flashing her sparkling ring finger. "It's always because of a guy." Not that her work is taking a second seat to her man - today she leaves for Los Angeles to dress Rihanna for her birthday bash and then it's back to London. It's easy to imagine Rihanna loving the designer's metal hardware leather and suede lace-up booties (Manolo Blahnik teamed up with her this season), cashmere knit body-con dresses and sweaters (inspired by South African murals). There is also a punky quilted leather skirt and a jacket lined with fox fur and embossed with a leather tribal print that is a nice addition to Goldin's usual all-knit collections.

Drivers, put down your phones, for the good of your licenses. Starting today, a ticket in New York State for talking on a cellphone while driving will cost you two points, in addition to the $100 it has cost since 2001, way back when New York became the first state in the nation to ban hand-held phone use while driving.

Lekelia D. Jenkins, a postdoctoral researcher at the University of Washington, writes from Ecuador, where she is studying factors in the cross-cultural adoption of marine conservation technologies like turtle excluder devices and circle hooks. She co-leads this project with Patrick Christie, who is an environmental sociologist and Associate Professor at the University of Washington.

A Somali man who pleaded guilty to hijacking an American-flagged cargo ship off the coast of Africa in 2009 was sentenced on Wednesday in Federal District Court in Manhattan to 33 years and 9 months in prison.

Just beyond the stands of mainstream manufacturers during last week's Chicago auto show press previews, stood an unusual, rugged-looking vehicle. Though its crude appearance might suggest otherwise, the Clandestine Extended Range Vehicle, or CERV, is an all-wheel-drive diesel hybrid that $14 billion in federal financing for dual-use advanced technology helped to build.

In the late 1930s, the Duchess of Windsor proposed a fashionably novel and, for the time, technologically complex idea to Van Cleef & Arpels: make her a piece of jewelry that zips. More than a decade later, the duchess got her wish. "The necklace that resulted was really a kind of partnership," says Sarah Coffin, the curator of the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum. "This wasn't just a little brooch," she says, noting the necklace's intricacy and the intervening war, which brought French jewelry production to a near standstill. This piece and many other diamond-encrusted feats of ingenuity will be on display at the Cooper-Hewitt from Feb. 18 to June 5 as part of "Set in Style: The Jewelry of Van Cleef & Arpels."

What happens when you put Trey Parker and Matt Stone, the unrepentant provocateurs behind Comedy Central's animated series "South Park," together with Robert Lopez, who tarnished sacred childhood memories as a co-creator of the Tony-winning puppet musical "Avenue Q"? At the very least, you get "The Book of Mormon," their new musical comedy -- nearly eight years in the making -- about a pair of young Mormon missionaries whose sunny dispositions and understandings of their faith are seriously challenged when they are dispatched to remote Uganda.

If you're itching to visit the new advanced waste management plant that will open in 2016 in Copenhagen, be sure to bring your skis. An urban ski park will cover the plant, which will incinerate the waste from five municipalities to generate heat and electricity for 140,000 homes. While their trash is burning inside, locals will be able to take an elevator to the top of the building, then ski down one of three different slopes, graded by difficulty, that jointly run about 5,000 feet.

That the Borders Group has filed a Chapter 11 petition is not so much news. Its fate will undoubtedly be blamed on e-books and Amazon.com, but big box retail companies like Borders, Barnes & Noble, Blockbuster and Circuit City long ago decided to compete solely on the basis of price, and they rise and fall on that basis alone. Last week, the multitalented Amber Martin wrapped up a four-week run of her latest show, "Amber Alert," in front of a sold-out house at the Wild Project in the East Village. Martin seamlessly floated between multiple costumes, personae and skits, never once leaving the stage, and carrying the calm of a seasoned performer through comedic routines, duets and classic vocal covers. Martin's first such transformation was from "Daydra," a walking trailer-trash disaster complete with raspy smoker's voice and greasy mullet, into the very vision of a solo diva, in a floor-length gown and heels, launching into a pitch-perfect rendition of Dionne Warwick's first hit, "Don't Make Me Over." Guest performers included the Scissor Sisters frontman Jake Shears, the hysterical Bridget Everett and the gender-bending guitarist NathAnn Carerra, with whom Martin performed a very curious duet.

''An inquest into the death of a kidnapped British aid worker who died during an American Special Forces' rescue raid in Afghanistan last fall exonerated the United States soldier who threw the grenade that killed her. Scientists still haven't discovered a cure for the common cold, but researchers now say zinc may be the next best thing. A sweeping new review of the medical research on zinc shows that sniffing, sneezing, coughing and stuffy-headed cold sufferers finally have a better option than just tissue and chicken soup. When taken within 24 hours of the first runny nose or sore throat, zinc lozenges, tablets or syrups can cut colds short by an average of a day or more and sharply reduce the severity of symptoms, according to the Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews, a respected medical clearinghouse.

PARKER--Gertrude Hess, 99, devoted wife of the late Morrison Parker, aunt, cousin and outstanding community leader. Gertrude's life always focused on her family, friends, and civic organizations. She served for over 60 years as the Executive Secretary of the New York County Republican Committee and was a leading force in the economic and legal development of New York City, especially in her beloved Westside of Manhattan. She was admired by government and community leaders and especially by her family, to whom she was always devoted. MARK--Katherine Anne, 49, also known as Kathy Riemenschneider, of Croton-on-Hudson, NY, died Friday, February 11, 2011 at her winter home in St. Petersburg, FL. Widely respected for her talents as an artist, teacher and photographer, she was the daughter of Lawrence H. Mark, Jr. and the late Martha W. Mark, of Croton-on-Hudson, NY. She leaves her husband, Bill Riemenschneider, of St. Petersburg, FL, the proprietor of Artistic Copper; her sister, Elizabeth Mark Meyerson of Atlantic Beach, NY, her uncle, Richard C. Mark of Purchase, NY, her nephew, Benjamin Jacob Meyerson, her niece, Hanna Grace Meyerson, and many cousins. A graduate of Williamsville East High School, a suburb of Buffalo, NY, Kathy also attended Skidmore College in Saratoga Springs, NY. She was born in New York City, spent her childhood years in Ringwood, NJ and Chappaqua, NY, and lived most of her adult life in Croton-on-Hudson with winters in Florida. In addition to her artistic and photographic skills, Kathy will be remembered for her laughter, her love of life, and her ability to spread joy and sunshine to all with whom she came in contact. Many people will remember her many years of participation in Renaissance festivals and other fairs where she adopted the persona of "Mama JuJu" and ran a booth where she and others interpreted objects, cards and handlines for clients in search of guidance for their personal lives. I'm not a fortune-teller," she often said. "If I could tell the future, I'd be a retired millionaire instead of working for a living." At Kathy's request, there will be no funeral service. Instead, her family asks all who knew and loved her to think of her and/or say a prayer in her memory on Friday, February 25, 2011. In lieu of flowers, please make donations in her name to a favorite charity. www.rlwilliams.com

CERUSSI--Michael A.,Jr. Michael A. Cerussi Jr., of Riverside, CT died comfortably in his home, surrounded by family, after a prolonged illness on February 14, 2011. He was 61. Mr. Cerussi was the President and Founder of Cerussi & Spring, P.C., a civil litigation law firm in White Plains, New York. He was a prominent trial lawyer who received national recognition in products liability defense litigation throughout the country. He served as a Member of the Board of Trustees of Berkshire School and the Board of Visitors of Pace University, School of Law. In 1996, he was inducted as a Fellow in the American College of Trial Lawyers. Mr. Cerussi was born on October 21, 1949 in New York City to parents, Michael A. and Anne T. Upon graduating from Iona Grammar School and Cardinal Farley Military Academy, he attended Georgetown University and in 1972, received a Bachelor of Arts degree from Iona College. Mr. Cerussi earned his law degree from Hofstra University, School of Law in 1976. On September 24, 1977, he married Kathryn Lovett Zinn, who survives him. Mr. Cerussi and his wife have lived in Riverside, CT for the past 28 years, and maintain a home in Juno Beach, Florida where he enjoyed spending the winter months. He was an active participant in Old Marsh Golf Club of Palm Beach Gardens, Florida, and at Innis Arden Golf Club, in Old Greenwich, CT, where he was President from 2008 through 2009. Prior to 1983, Mr. Cerussi lived in Bronxville, New York and New York City. Mr. Cerussi is survived by, in addition to his wife, his son, Michael A. III, of New York City; sisters, Rosemary Ferrer of Greenwich, CT, Nancy A. of Delray Beach, Florida; and brother, Thomas F., of Darien, CT. A brother, Ernest M., predeceased him in 1994. A memorial service will be held on Friday, February 18, 2011 at 2pm at The First Congregational Church of Greenwich, 108 Sound Beach Avenue, Old Greenwich, CT. Donations in Mr. Cerussi's memory may be made to The Leukemia & Lymphoma Society online at www.leukemia-lymphoma.org or by mail to 1311 Mamaroneck Avenue, Suite 130, White Plains, New York 10605.

CREMERS--Madeleine Buchanan Palmer of Aubonne, Switzerland and East Hampton, NY died on January 15, 2011. Born in New York City on May 25, 1913, she married Herbert von Metzler in 1932; they were divorced in 1955. In 1961 she married Frederic Chapuisat, who died in 1981. In 1987, she married Epimachus Cremers, who died in 1991. She spent most of her adult life in Switzerland, and each summer would stay in her house in East Hampton. Are the Iowa presidential caucuses really less than a year away? How time flies. But an election year looms, as does the return of ''Gore Vidal's The Best Man,'' the deliciously tart (when done well) play about politics, campaigns and the presidency. Jeffrey Richards and his fellow producers announced on Tuesday that they would revive that 1960 play in the spring of 2012 with hopes of catching election fever. Originally titled ''The Best Man,'' Mr. Vidal's play involves a showdown at a presidential convention between two candidates, in essence an Adlai Stevenson character and a Richard Nixon type, brokered by an ill ex-president and complicated by secrets, machinations, and troubled marriages. Broadway had a revival of ''The Best Man'' not so long ago, during the campaign between George W. Bush and Al Gore and the subsequent legal battle in the fall of 2000. With political resonance and a cast led by Spalding Gray, Chris Noth, and Charles Durning, that production started off strong at the box office but had mixed reviews and declining ticket sales before closing in late December. (Mr. Gore had conceded two and a half weeks earlier.) That 2000 revival was the first Broadway producing credit for Mr. Richards, who has been a press agent since the 1970s and is now one of Broadway's busiest producers. He is reuniting his producing team from 2000 - Jerry Frankel, Michael B. Rothfeld, and Darren Bagert - to mount this production. The director will be Michael Wilson (''The Orphans' Home Cycle,'' ''Dividing the Estate''). No cast members have been announced. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Though he describes himself as a good friend of hers, the fashion and art photographer David LaChapelle has decided to settle his differences with the pop star Rihanna in a place where friends don't usually end up: court. Mr. LaChappelle, known for his candy-colored, sexually over-the-top images, claims in a suit filed Monday in federal court in Manhattan that Rihanna helped herself to too many of the images in the recently released video for her sexually over-the-top song ''S & M.'' The suit, which asks for at least $1 million in damages, argues that the video is ''directly derived from and substantially similar to'' photographs he has created and published that show, among other things, a dominatrix walking a chained man on a leash, a woman in latex headgear and another woman (Lady Gaga, to be precise) wearing only screaming headlines. In all, the suit claims, eight of Mr. LaChapelle's images were used to create scenes in the video, which the suit calls a ''willful, wanton and deliberate'' infringement of his copyright protections.

BURTON--Evangela Del Sandys, passed away on February 13, 2011 in Concord, NH, where she had been living in a retirement community. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's family foundation is planning to distribute $32 million in grants to arts organizations around New York City, The Wall Street Journal reported on Tuesday. The announcement comes a year after the mayor ended a charitable program administered through the Carnegie Corporation of New York, which over a decade funneled $200 million of his personal fortune to arts and social-service groups around the city. (The Carnegie program was ostensibly supported by an anonymous donor, but that donor was widely known to be Mr. Bloomberg.) The Bloomberg foundation's new arts initiative, which was developed by a consultant, Anita Contini, invited 250 organizations to apply. It requires that grant recipients, small-to-midsized arts groups, to have been operating for at least two years, and that they secure matching funds equal to 20 percent of the grant amount. The grants also come with an arts management training program run by Michael M. Kaiser, the president of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts. Ms. Contini told the Journal that city staff had not been involved in the program and the distribution of grants, although the foundation's chief executive is the first deputy mayor, Patricia E. Harris.

''As a child, I used to dream of traveling to every country in the world,'' said Dale Layne, a native of Guyana. ''Living in New York City has given me a chance to go to many of them.'' Mr. Layne, 29, lost his sight to glaucoma a decade ago. Though he can't see the city where he has lived for four years, his other senses are constantly on high alert. ''If there is tension in the subway I have to exit right away because it is a lot more dangerous for me.'' This series presents multiple-exposure portraits of perceptions of the city described by New Yorkers missing one or more senses.

The foundation of the Broadway director Arthur Laurents and his longtime partner, Tom Hatcher, announced on Tuesday that its first playwriting award, worth $150,000, would go to Jeff Talbott, a New York City actor who has branched out and will make his Off Broadway debut as a playwright next season. The award, which is to be given annually, provides $50,000 to the writer and $100,000 toward the production costs for mounting the recipient's play. Mr. Talbott's winning play, ''The Submission,'' described as an exploration of the importance of cultural authenticity in authorship, will be produced next season at MCC Theater, which is led by Robert LuPone, Bernard Telsey, and William Cantler. The Laurents/Hatcher Foundation Award is among the most generous in playwriting, and it is intended for emerging writers. Mr. Talbott, 46, has written only a few plays and, as a playwright, still lacks an agent. Mr. Laurents, the book writer for ''Gypsy'' and ''West Side Story'' and the Tony Award-winning director of the original ''La Cage aux Folles,'' created the award last year. At 93, he is still writing plays himself; Mr. Hatcher, his partner of 52 years, died in 2006. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Conservative Party leaders in Britain abandon a controversial plan to sell off virtually all of the country's publicly owned forests over the next decade. The proposal, which would have sold off even historic woodlands like the Forest of Dean and Sherwood Forest, generated widespread public outrage that had shown no signs of abating. "I am sorry, we got this one wrong, but we have listened to people's concerns," Environment Secretary Caroline Spelman told the House of Commons. [The Guardian]

"A dangerous eye - that's what L'Wren said to me," said the makeup artist Aaron de Mey backstage at L'Wren Scott. "It conjured up images of smokiness. I also love this kid Taylor Momsen very much - it's interesting to see how a teenager would apply her makeup." To wit, de Mey created an exaggerated version of the kind of black eye makeup he said Scott herself always wears, which included heaps of Lancome Hypnose Mascara (in black, of course) and black eye shadow layered over pencil for a gothic look. "There's no highlight, no skin showing through," he said. The hairstylist Serge Normant also was inspired by the designer: "The way L'Wren wears things, it doesn't look overly done. The girls aren't supposed to look like her, but I wanted that easiness." Hair was brushed into a deep side part with volume added through the crown of the head for a "just woke up" look, which Normant set with products from his new namesake product line. The manicurist Yuna Park filled out the look with one coat of a gold-flecked black nail polish from Lancome called Noir 29, available this fall. You know you love it. XOXO.

The photographer Danielle Levitt has an eye for disaffected youth. Her 2008 monograph "We Are Experienced" compiled more than 100 portraits of American teenagers taken over several years as Levitt hopscotched across the country shooting features and fashion editorials for Interview, Arena Homme Plus and The New York Times Magazine, among many others. Levitt began her career shooting a street style column for The Wall Street Journal, a natural window onto the downtown scene, and her work has evolved to include "werewolves" in Texas for Dazed & Confused and sissy bouncers for Arena Homme Plus. This fall, she was sent to Lowell, Mass., to shoot Mickey Ward and Dicky Eklund, the real-life characters behind David O. Russell's Oscar-nominated film "The Fighter"; the magazine assignment turned into a new series of portraits and a collection of short films. "Pride of Lowell," curated by Naheed Simjee, will opened on Wednesday at Los Angeles's Known Gallery. T caught up with Levitt via e-mail to talk about the show.

As public and private colleges and universities have been forced to make painful budget cuts in the past couple of years, many educators have worried that the humanities are getting short shrift. To bolster support for teaching and research in the liberal arts, the American Academy of Arts and Sciences on Thursday announced the creation of a national commission on the humanities and social sciences. The panel was established at the request of a group of Democratic and Republican senators who asked the academy for a top 10 list of actions that government, educators and philanthropists could take to maintain excellence in the humanities and social sciences and strengthen civil society.

There is a situation in chess called zugzwang in which any legal move leaves the player worse off (in other words, he'd be better off to pass his turn). Oftentimes, in fact, the zugzwang is mutual: both players would rather that the other one move next. A typical situation -- black's only legal move would lead to a loss, but white's only legal moves would turn an advantageous position into a draw -- is illustrated below.

This weekend marks the kickoff of Modernism Week, Palm Springs's annual celebration of all things midcentury modern. One of its highlights is "Steel and Shade: The Architecture of Donald Wexler," an exhibition at the Palm Springs Art Museum. Wexler, 85, has practiced in Palm Springs for almost six decades, developing an architecture that is acutely sensitive to the extremes of the desert climate. Wexler's all-steel Alexander houses, designed in 1962 with the structural engineer Bernard Perlin for the developers George and Robert Alexander, were sustainable before sustainability was trendy. Affordable, elegant and quick to assemble on site, thanks to a prefabricated structural system, Wexler's houses (their framing, roofs and exterior siding are steel, with drywall interior siding) were the perfect answer to the postwar housing boom. "Steel, concrete and glass are ideal materials for the desert," Wexler says. "They are inorganic and don't deteriorate in the extreme temperatures of the desert." And since these structures are relatively maintenance-free, the seven Alexander houses in a north Palm Springs enclave are as pristine today as they were almost 50 years ago.
