The coming transfer of Jez Butterworth's "Jerusalem" will combine members of the play's original Royal Court and West End cast with a few familiar Broadway veterans, including one soon-to-be-available Tony Award winner: John Gallagher Jr., the "Spring Awakening" star who is slated to leave "American Idiot" at the end of the month.  Mr. Gallagher will appear in "Jerusalem" as Lee, one of the many lovably seedy characters who inhabit the world of the play's protagonist, Johnny "Rooster" Byron, press representatives for the production said on Thursday. It was previously announced that Mark Rylance (of "La Bête") and Mackenzie Crook (of Britain's "The Office") will reprise their roles as Johnny and his chum Ginger; they will be joined by Max Baker ("Cyrano de Bergerac") as Wesley, Geraldine Hughes ("Translations") as Dawn and Molly Ranson ("August: Osage County") as Pea.

Fashion's latest hairstylist darling, the charming Paul Hanlon, knows the Proenza Schouler girl quite well. Last season, he imagined she'd fallen asleep on a bus, and created what was meant to look like a French twist that had been battered by a long day (and a long commute, one assumes). This season, she's grown her hair nearly to her elbows (Hanlon used 22-inch extensions) and pulled it into a low ponytail with some knotty nubs at the end. "When [designers Jack McCollough and Lazaro Hernandez] called me in London, the first thing they said to me was that they loved the idea of the girls having really long hair. The first test we did, the girls had this really long straight hair, very blunt, but it didn't feel like their woman - it was a bit army," said Hanlon, adding that the boys were inspired by a cross-country road trip they'd just been on. As an alternative, Hanlon referenced photographer Edward S. Curtis' portraits of American Indian women, their hair parted in the middle, heavy behind their shoulders. He began a very low braid, which he then tied with a black elastic, leaving the last loop halfway pulled through. After the tips of the hair were razor cut, the entire head was sprayed with Frederic Fekkai Sheer Hold Hairspray (through a net, a favorite Hanlon technique) for some "crunch." "It's like when girls go out and they leave their ponytail tucked into their jackets, and when they take it off it looks kind of wrong. I'm looking around at Diane's assistants," Hanlon said, referring to the makeup artist Diane Kendal, "and some of them walked in with their hair like that. It's nice to have a wearable look. Hairstylists get a bit carried away sometimes."

Banksy has made it to Hollywood, or at least some of his work has. In the last few days, several pieces by the British street artist have appeared around Los Angeles: a urinating dog (placed in Beverly Hills), a mischievous Charlie Brown and a drunk Mickey and Minnie Mouse, with the slogan "Living the Dream." (All the images are viewable on Banksy's Web site.) Though Banksy's reps confirmed to The Los Angeles Times that the work belonged to him, they did not mention whether it was part of his ongoing un-campaign for his Oscar-nominated documentary, "Exit Through the Gift Shop." But since Banksy rarely does anything without it being carefully thought out, we can assume it's more than a coincidence.

The Franco-Algerian director Rachid Bouchareb has got to be hoping that the third time is the charm. He received Oscar nominations for best foreign-language film in 1996 for his "Dust of Life" and again in 2007 for "Days of Glory," both of which are films that tackle difficult aspects of the relationship between the West and the Third World. And now he is back with "Outside the Law," which addresses the long and violent struggle in which Algeria sought its independence from France, finally achieved in 1962.

For the first time since 2001, the American Geriatrics Society and the British Geriatrics Society have updated their guidelines for preventing falls in older people. The update includes two notable changes: One recommends tai chi -- the meditative, slow-motion Chinese exercise -- as an effective way to prevent falls, while another suggests that doctors review medication use by all elderly patients, with an eye toward reducing use of those drugs that increase the risk of falling.

Classic Car Club Manhattan, which offers a fleet of classic and contemporary sports cars to dues-paying members, will expand early next month from its original SoHo branch to the Upper East Side. "It's a turn-of-the-century carriage house," said Michael Prichinello, co-founder of the club, of the new outpost. "We chose it because physically it's in the right area: easy to get in and out of town."

In 2010, so much progress was made at the World Trade Center that officials saw no need to cook up fabricated milestones, as they had in the past. But in December, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey showed that old habits die hard. It announced in a press release (accompanied by this picture) that 1 World Trade Center - the building formerly known as Freedom Tower - had reached "halfway to the top." Meaning what? That the structural steel had reached the level of the 52nd floor in what will be a 104-story building.

In recent weeks, President Obama has traveled the country calling for renewed government spending to foster small-company innovation, but on Monday his administration unveiled a Small Business Administration budget (pdf) for 2012 that limits growth in its most important program, government-guaranteed general business loans. Deborah Pagani, a willowy Manhattan-based jewelry designer, may well be her own best model. A fashion lover who's usually clad in cutting-edge ensembles by Azzedine Alaïa, Haider Ackermann and Rick Owens, she often gets stopped in shops and restaurants by women who want to know where she got her jewelry. "I've been tempted to sell things right off my body," she jokes. Pagani (left, in a Versace dress and her own jewelry) describes her Queen Bee collection as a cross between Joan Crawford and Anita Pallenberg. "I don't like classic stones by themselves," she says. Instead, she mixes diamonds, sapphires and amethysts with moodier materials like jasper "zebra" agate, purple turquoise, Nubian opals and moonstones. "My pieces are a bit dark, but dark in a sophisticated way." The earrings above are $16,105 at Ikram, in Chicago.

Interboro Partners, a nine-year-old New York architecture firm, has won the annual Young Architects Program competition to transform MoMA P.S. 1's courtyard for its summer outdoor music program, the museum announced Wednesday. The architects took their inspiration from the community around the museum, which is located in Long Island City, Queens, interviewing the proprietors of local businesses and nonprofits about what materials might be of use to them and then incorporating those materials into their design, with the intention of donating them at the end of the summer. ''A lot of the things are commonsensical,'' like benches and a volleyball net, Tobias Armborst, one of the firm's partners, said in a phone interview. Other items-like the large mirrors requested by a local dance school-proved harder to integrate. (Mr. Armborst said the architects are hoping to use them to make a ''little, crazy house of mirrors'' at one end of the courtyard.)

HILFIGER SHOW HITS ALL THE SEASON'S TRENDS Tommy Hilfiger's women's collection hit all of the season's big trends, before an audience that included Wyclef Jean, Rosario Dawson and fashion's latest oddball addict, Amar'e Stoudemire of the New York Knicks. The looks included sharp double-breasted gray flannel pantsuits, some shown with shearling vests, and clever takes on the navy cable-knit sweaters embroidered with beads. Printed pajamas also looked cool under a cloth coat. Ponchos and capes have been just about everywhere this season, but here there was a cool hybrid variation: wrapped around their necks, two models wore wide scarves that attached with hooks in the back, creating a quasi-poncho. One was lined with a blanket fabric.

HESS--Carl B. We mourn the passing of our Founder, mentor and colleague Carl Hess. Carl came to the office every day until three weeks ago, engaged to the end, ever watchful that we were maintaining the standards for AEA that he and the Founders had established over 40 years ago. We will miss his quiet and wise counsel. Our young colleagues will also miss their regular "lunches with Carl" that they cherished greatly. We and our colleagues will forever be indebted to Carl for the pivotal role he played in establishing our firm. On behalf of the entire AEA community we extend our sympathies to Ludmila and the whole Hess family. John Whitehead, Chairman Emeritus Vincent Mai, Chairman John Garcia, Chief Executive

PARKER--Gertrude Hess, 99, devoted wife of the late Morrison Parker, aunt, cousin and outstanding community leader. Gertrude's life always focused on her family, friends, and civic organizations. She served for over 60 years as the Executive Secretary of the New York County Republican Committee and was a leading force in the economic and legal development of New York City, especially in her beloved Westside of Manhattan. She was admired by government and community leaders and especially by her family, to whom she was always devoted. HESS--Carl B. The Rockefeller University deeply mourns the loss of our beloved friend Carl Hess, a revered member of The Rockefeller University Council for over thirty years. A true gentleman and a man of deep character, integrity, and compassion, Carl left the world a better place. He was a legendary businessman whose foresight and innovative leadership created the private equity enterprise before those very words were coined. His strong sense of corporate ethics and social responsibility carried over into an active pro bono and philanthropic life. Carl first became involved with Rockefeller in 1976. He brought vision, astute judgment, and a belief in the promise of basic science to his service as a member of the Council and its Executive Committee. Seven university presidents benefited from his wise counsel and generosity. Carl loved to ask leaders about the projects they dreamed of launching. He would then make the first, critical gift. At Rockefeller he helped create the Center for Studies in Physics & Biology; the stem cell research fund, and the Academic Venture Fund, which provides seed funding for promising scientists conducting high risk, high reward research that does not qualify for government support. Carl was that rare benefactor who never sought public recognition for his gifts. Indeed he much preferred to name initiatives for friends whom he admired. Carl had a gift for friendship, and he enjoyed warm relationships with many Rockefeller scientists. He was adored by the university staff who felt privileged to know a man of such class and distinction. We will miss Carl greatly, and we extend our heartfelt condolences to his cherished wife, Ludmila, also a member of The Rockefeller University Council, and his children, grandchildren, and great-granddaughter; and to the entire Hess family. Russell Carson, Chairman David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman Richard Furlaud, Chairman Emeritus John Whitehead, Trustee Emeritus Paul Nurse, President Torsten Wiesel, President Emeritus Thomas Sakmar, Furlaud Professor Marnie Imhoff, Vice President

Even as critical features of the landmark health care legislation of March 2010 are being put into place, the battle over reform rages on. House Republicans, whose unified vote for repeal was blocked by Senate Democrats, would now like to bar spending on the law. Meanwhile, President Obama, in a recent speech to the Chamber of Commerce, reminded business executives that ''we could not accept a broken system where insurance companies could drop people because they got sick, or families went bankrupt because of medical bills.'' And of course, the legal challenges continue to wend their way toward the Supreme Court. Health reform, in short, is very much a work in progress. This report--the second in a series--examines that progress on three key dimensions: Roll-Out (Are milestones being met?), Reactions (Are key players cooperating?) and Results (is reform controlling costs of covering Americans?).

BOSTON -- Halfway around the world from Tahrir Square in Cairo, an aging American intellectual shuffles about his cluttered brick row house in a working-class neighborhood here. His name is Gene Sharp. Stoop-shouldered and white-haired at 83, he grows orchids, has yet to master the Internet and hardly seems like a dangerous man. But for the world's despots, his ideas can be fatal.

Just in time for the new government dietary guidelines, an app to help you adhere to healthier eating. Fooducate lets shoppers scan a product bar code in the grocery store for an instant read on a food's health value, represented by a letter grade from A to D. Once a food has been scanned and recognized, the app offers healthier alternatives or can compare two products side-by-side.

SCOTT--Stan. July 14, 1955- February 14, 2011; at New York Presbyterian Hospital of complications related to leukemia. Stan loved music, reading, word games, technology, travel, and animals of all kinds. He is survived by his partner of 21 years (and husband of 16 months), Bruce Shenitz; his mother, Elizabeth of Jerseyville, Illinois; his sister, Susan Sievers, of Carrollton, IL; nine aunts and uncles and spouses, innumerable cousins, his in-laws, George and Adelee Shenitz, and Bruce's brother Charles; many friends and colleagues, especially those he worked with for 30 years as a software designer at KPMG. Services 11:15am Friday, February 18, at "The Riverside" West 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Leukemia and Lymphoma Society or any animal-welfare related charity would be appreciated.

GOOD thing New York Fashion Week happens but twice a year. In addition to the 250-plus designers who paraded new collections last week, an even greater number, it seems, could be found partying the night away in the city's bars, hotels, clubs, museums, restaurants and unfinished stores.

DIAMOND--Anne L. Beloved wife of the late Leon, loved mother of Barbara and Laura (Mark), loving grandmother of Matthew (Misty), Andrew (Leah) and Elizabeth and great-grandmother. Words cannot describe how very much we will miss her. She was, and always will be, the center of our family.

9 P.M. (CBS) CSI: CRIME SCENE INVESTIGATION Langston (Laurence Fishburne) testifies against Nate Haskell (Bill Irwin, above right, with Mr. Fishburne), the ''Dick and Jane'' killer. Nick (George Eads) gets a call warning him that Jason McCann (Justin Bieber), the troubled teenager who in the season premiere had shot him, has returned to town. In ''The Mentalist,'' at 10, Patrick Jane (Simon Baker) is joined in the field by Agent Hightower (Aunjanue Ellis) after Lisbon (Robin Tunney) is injured while investigating the death of a modern-day prospector whose body was found near a mining site. 8 P.M. (NBC) COMMUNITY Pierce (Chevy Chase) ends up in the hospital after swallowing some mysterious pills and bequeaths a few final gifts after deciding he's dying. Meanwhile Jeff (Joel McHale) ponders the possibility of reconnecting with his long-absent father, and Troy (Donald Glover) meets his idol LeVar Burton (playing himself, above left, with Mr. Glover). In ''Perfect Couples,'' at 8:30, Julia (Christine Woods) tries to make Dave (Kyle Bornheimer) feel like more of a man, and Vance (David Walton) and Amy (Mary Elizabeth Ellis) argue about the role of Leigh (Olivia Munn) as a wedding planner after the shrimp rolls she serves at a ''Mad Men'' party cause food poisoning. In ''The Office,'' at 9, Michael (Steve Carell) finally presents ''Threat Level Midnight,'' the action movie he has been working on for 11 years. The stars: Michael, as Agent Michael Scarn; Dwight (Rainn Wilson), as Scarn's butler sidekick; and Jim (John Krasinski), as Scarn's archnemesis, Goldenface. ''Parks and Recreation,'' at 9:30, finds Leslie (Amy Poehler) stirring up a media frenzy as she promotes the harvest festival. In ''30 Rock,'' at 10, a sleep-deprived Jack (Alec Baldwin) loses his edge when negotiating the new nanny's salary, and Jenna (Jane Krakowski) tries to distract Liz (Tina Fey) from her breakup. And in ''Outsourced,'' at 10:30, Todd (Ben Rappaport) orders his staff to be on its best behavior when his American boss, Jerry (Matt Walsh), makes a surprise visit. But it turns out that Jerry only wants to party.
I for one welcome our new computer overlords. KEN JENNINGS, a former ''Jeopardy!'' quiz show champion, writing on his video screen as he faced certain defeat by a computer. [A1]

Four questions for JENNIFER MANKINS (above), of Bird and Shopbird.com: What's your best-selling item now? A printed cotton halter jumpsuit by Étoile by Isabel Marant ($296). It is sweet and feminine and flattering on different shapes and sizes. It can be layered up with boots and cozy knits for the rest of the winter, but will be light and breezy on its own during the dog days of summer. For men right now it is a slim-cut classic button-down oxford shirt by Band of Outsiders ($228). It is a classic preppy with a modern fit and comes in colors like lavender and green.

VILEBREQUIN, the men's swimwear brand from St.-Tropez, is starting a sunglass line. A modern take on the classic Wayfarer, the glasses are made from durable rubber, float on water and come in bright colors including army, red and yellow ($200). Available at Vilebrequin stores including 1070 Madison Avenue (East 81st Street), (212) 650-0353; vilebrequin.com.

An article on Wednesday about litigation by three Twitter users seeking to block a government order demanding access to their account records as part of a WikiLeaks investigation misstated the nationality of Rop Gonggrijp, one of the three litigants. He is from the Netherlands, not Denmark.

MANIN--Martin C.,M.D. On February 15th, a month shy of his 83rd birthday, we said goodbye to a skilled and respected orthopedic surgeon, a loving father, a devoted husband and a doting grandfather. Mel, as he was known, passed away near his winter residence in Florida, surrounded by family and friends, after succumbing to a sudden but mercifully short illness. He worked until the very end. Retirement was never a consideration. His intelligence, wit, warmth and perpetual thirst for knowledge will be dearly missed by all who were privileged to know him. Mel is survived by Marilyn, his valentine of almost 53 years, his two sons, Steven and Sam, his daughter-in-law Cathy, six grandchildren (Matthew, Michael, Hillary, Harry, Morgan and Dylan), brother Stan and sister Lynn. Services will be held at Riverside Chapel in Mount Vernon, NY on Thursday, February 17th at 10am.

TAYLOR--Betty Kaye, age 86, formerly of Freeport, NY, died on February 15th. A graduate of the University of Wisconsin, past Assistant National Director of the Jewish Labor Committee and later a Vice President of that organization, she led the Ad Hoc Committee on the Human Rights and Genocide Treaties, and later became Deputy Commissioner of the New York State Department of Labor. She leaves longtime companion Moshe (Martin) Kagan, brother Stephen Kaye, son David Taylor and daughter-in-law Dena Taylor, and three grandchildren, Alex, Josh and Matthew. Memorial to be announced. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Friends of Moreshet, 114 West 26th Str. 10th Flr., New York NY 10001.

The Grammy Awards have always had an effect on record sales. But in the digital age that effect is felt more quickly than ever, since fans' impulse buys made during the show on Sunday night register as part of the tail end of Nielsen SoundScan's sales week. By one measure, the show's biggest early beneficiary was a group that didn't win any awards at all: Mumford & Sons, the young British folk-rock band that performed on its own and with Bob Dylan, lost in the two categories it was nominated (including best new artist), but nearly doubled sales of its album ''Sigh No More'' (Glassnote), reaching No. 2 on the Billboard chart with 49,000.

Soon, it will be possible to hand your child their very own tablet computer, providing, of course, you can pry your smartphone out of their hands. At this week's Toy Fair, two such devices were previewed, scheduled to be in stores later this year.

On a brisk morning on Governors Island, as winter begins to surrender to spring, the fake palm trees that greet the ferry on Water Taxi Beach appear even more surreal than usual, poking up out of snow above the empty picnic tables. The ferry pulls in. The sun peeks through bare branches. A handful of people veer left toward the offices of the Trust for Governors Island and various maintenance jobs. The rest of the ferry's passengers - high school students and their adult keepers - file toward the newly opened Urban Assembly New York Harbor School, housed in a former Coast Guard infirmary.

Despite reports that it gives off hazardous porcelain dust and that there are traces of lead in the paint, one of the Chinese artist Ai Weiwei's works ''Sunflower Seeds'' sold at Sotheby's in London Tuesday evening for 349,250 ($559,394). Four bidders competed for a mountain of 100,000 hand-painted seeds, weighing 220 pounds. By Sotheby's calculations the anonymous telephone buyer paid about 3.50 (or $5.60) a seed.
MANIN--Dr. Mel, beloved Grandfather of Harry Manin. He was a kind and generous man. He will be missed. The Spiegel Family

An article on Feb. 5 about a decline in high school science fair participation referred imprecisely to one of the education policies that teachers blamed for failing to promote independent research skills. While the No Child Left Behind act has been in effect during the Obama administration, it was passed under the Bush administration. The act, which emphasizes standardized math and reading tests, is not a policy created by the Obama administration.
DOSIK--Sherry. 2/17/04. As long as we live, you too will live, for you are now a part of us as we remember you with love. Morty, Jill, Jon, His wife Tara and your grandson Spencer

J. C. Chandor's directorial debut, ''Margin Call,'' a feature that takes place over the course of 24 hours on the trading floor of an investment bank, will be the opening night feature of the 40th annual New Directors/New Films series, the Museum of Modern Art and the Film Society of Lincoln Center said on Wednesday. ''Margin Call,'' one of 28 films that will be presented during the series, features a cast that includes Kevin Spacey, Paul Bettany, Zachary Quinto, Demi Moore, Stanley Tucci and Jeremy Irons, and chronicles ''a day that brings layer upon layer of human and professional wrongdoing that jeopardizes the entire fabric of the banking system,'' according to a statement from MoMA and the Film Society. The closing night film of the series, which runs from March 23 through April 3, will be Maryam Keshavarz's ''Circumstance,'' about two Iranian women who begin to step outside the boundaries of their oppressive lives, and which won the Audience Award at this year's Sundance Film Festival. The lineup of selections for this year's New Directors/New Films series, provided by its press representatives, appears below:
ABRAMSON--Sy, died peacefully on February 15. Beloved husband of Muri, best dad to Lani, Steve, Nina and Kevin. Adoring grandfather of Tiffani, Kerrin, Olivier, Jaci and Erika. We miss him so.

KAHN--Bella Viteri. 3/23/47 2/17/06 To a greatly missed and loved mother, daughter, sister, aunt, wife and friend, it is now five years from your untimely passing. You would be so proud of Michael, Johanna and your new 21 month old grandson, Jacob! You would also be so proud of Ivan, Chantal, Maria Luisa, Ana Maria, Magda and Greta and your entire family. You were the lynchpin of our lives and we strive to go forward. Forever, from all of us.

An article last Thursday about the Syrian government's relaxation of curbs on domestic access to Facebook and YouTube misstated the name of a pro-government Syrian Web site that said about 200,000 Syrians use Facebook. It is DP-News.com.

An article last Thursday about the complexities of classifying Americans by race and ethnicity referred incompletely to the designation that the National Center for Health Statistics, the government agency that tracks data on births and deaths, would use for a university student who is of Peruvian, Chinese, Irish, Shawnee and Cherokee descent. The agency would classify the student as Asian racially and as Hispanic ethnically -- not only as Asian.

A Somali man who pleaded guilty to hijacking an American-flagged cargo ship off the coast of Africa in 2009 was sentenced on Wednesday in Federal District Court in Manhattan to 33 years and 9 months in prison. The man, Abduwali Abdukhadir Muse, whose age is in dispute, was the only survivor among four men who hijacked the Maersk Alabama on April 8, 2009; the others were killed during a daring Navy Seal operation in which the ship's captain was rescued.

WEINSTEIN--Ruth, former resident of Brooklyn and Valley Stream. A graduate of Thomas Jefferson High School and Brooklyn College. Beloved wife of the late Morris. Loving mother of Lewis (Barbara) and Carol. Devoted grandmother of Andrew. Cherished sister of Murray Axel. Services 11:30am Friday at Boulevard-Riverside Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, New York. Donations can be made to: The Alzheimer's Association.

De LIZZO--Frank, on February 16. Beloved husband of the late Diane. Loving father of Peter and Irene and father in law of Anthony. Devoted grandfather of Frank and Tereza. Reposing Thursday and Friday, 2-5 and 7-10 at Cusimano & Russo Funeral Home, 2005 West 6 St., Brooklyn. Funeral Mass Saturday 10:30 am St. James Pro-Cathedral, Brooklyn, NY. Interment Resurrection Cemetery.

8:34 p.m. | Updated The former chief financial officer of Freddie Mac has been notified by securities regulators that they may soon file civil charges against him, stemming from his tenure at the mortgage finance company, according to a recent public filing.

TAYLOR--Betty Kaye. The officers, staff and members of the Jewish Labor Committee note with deep sadness the passing of Betty Kaye Taylor, former Assistant National Director of the JLC, Executive Secretary of our National Trade Union Council for Human Rights, and a Vice President of our organization. Longtime labor and human rights activist, a friend and mentor to many, she founded and became the Executive Secretary of the Ad Hoc Committee on the Human Rights and Genocide Treaties. She also held the position of Deputy Commissioner of the New York State Department of Labor, and was President of the Association of Jewish Community Relations Workers. Heartfelt condolences to her family. She made an extraordinary contribution to the work of the JLC; and will be profoundly missed. Stuart Appelbaum, President; Martin Schwartz, Executive Director.

KALMAN--Dr. Harold H.,passed away Sunday. Husband of the late Pearl Kalman. Father of George and Roy, grandfather of Scott, Meredith and Melissa and brother of Doris Shapiro. Funeral Friday, February 18, 10am, Riverside, 21 West Broad St., Mt. Vernon, NY.

Arena Stage on Wednesday announced 11 productions for its second season in its $135 million new home in southwest Washington, D.C. -- a lineup that reflects its commitment to mounting home-grown plays, new works and American classics. Among the highlights are the 2011-12 season opener, a new musical adaptation of the film ''Like Water for Chocolate,'' which is said to be aiming for Broadway, and works by two of Arena's resident playwrights: ''The Book Club Play'' by Karen Zacarias and ''You, Nero,'' by Amy Freed. Those three works will begin performances in the fall; among the shows in 2012 will be the world premiere of an Arena commission, ''Mary T. & Lizzy K.,'' written and directed by Tazewell Thompson, inspired by the historical relationship between Mary Todd Lincoln and her White House seamstress, the freed slave Elizabeth Keckley.

In a sign that more than half the Republican freshmen are willing to cut military spending, the House voted 233 to 198 on Wednesday to cancel an alternate fighter jet engine that the Bush and Obama administrations had tried to kill for the last five years. The vote was another instance in which some of the new legislators, including several affiliated with the Tea Party, broke ranks with the House speaker, John A. Boehner, Republican of Ohio, where the engine provided more than 1,000 jobs.

An article on Wednesday about Bernard L. Madoff, the imprisoned creator of a multibillion-dollar Ponzi scheme, misidentified, in two passages, whom Mr. Madoff met with in what he said were efforts to help Irving H. Picard, a court-appointed trustee, recover assets for the fraud victims. As the article correctly noted elsewhere, Mr. Madoff met with members of Mr. Picard's legal team, not with Mr. Picard personally. The article also gave an incorrect middle initial for Mr. Madoff's accountant. He is David G. Friehling, not David H.

Nikon just released the specifications on eight new cameras, many with upgrades from existing models, but two with notable advances. The Coolpix P300 is a new Nikon point-and-shoot that is particularly good for low light. The camera gathers enough light that it can shoot at f1.8 - compare that to the f2.8 to f3.5 common to point-and-shoots. Nikon said it achieved this using a high-quality glass in the lens. Canon got a similarly low f2.0 in its S95 point-and-shoot camera.

Now for a bit of good news: Rationality may be breaking out in the hedge fund world. Investors are punishing funds that have engaged in questionable behavior and balking at ever-escalating fees. Regulators are showing uncharacteristic backbone, insisting that they will not merely fight the last war when it comes to new rules.

SAOUTER--Joseph J.,69, of Freehold, quietly passed away on February 12. He was a retired Postmaster of Freehold and Keyport, NJ. He also retired from USAR as a Lieutenant Colonel. He will dearly be missed by all who had the pleasure of knowing him.

An article on Monday about the collaboration between young Tunisian and Egyptian activists that helped lead to the revolutions in their countries misspelled the name of a city in Egypt where a violent police crackdown in March 2008 proved to be an important event in the evolution of the Egyptian opposition movement. It is Mahalla, not Malhalla.

DIANE VON FURSTENBERG, above in 1972, is reissuing vintage styles, like her wrap dress, with updated silhouettes. At left, the New Jeanne dress, $325. The collection will be available online and at DVF stores, including the one at 874 Washington Street (West 14th Street); (646) 486-4800; dvf.com.

The CBS Corporation said Wednesday that its fourth-quarter revenue rose 11 percent over the same period in 2009, helped by growth in local advertising. Revenue for the full year increased 8 percent, to $14.06 billion, the company reported.
Apollo Global Management filed the seventh amendment to its filing with securities regulators late on Friday as its prepared for its long-awaited public listing on the New York Stock Exchange.

In this weekend's Your Money column, Tara Siegel Bernard explains what happens to your credit score when you pay multiple bills late, your home goes into foreclosure or you file for personal bankruptcy. She also gives readers a blueprint for repairing your credit report and credit score once the worst has happened.
Michael Slackman reports from Manama, moments after an attack on protesters by security forces.
Bill Scher, left, of the Campaign for America's Future and Kristen Soltis of the Winston Group debate high-speed rail.

With a debate over government spending raging on the House floor, Democrats late Friday night proposed a temporary extension of the stopgap measure now financing the government that would maintain expenditures generally at 2010 levels through March 31 and avert a federal shutdown.

In trading Tomas Kaberle to Boston for a prospect, a first-round pick and a conditional pick on Friday, Toronto General Manager Brian Burke pulled off a rarity in the business of hockey transactions: he got both aspects of a complicated deal right.

SATURDAY'S PUZZLE - Tim Croce is back with his third themeless puzzle, and he hits us with 10 10-letter entries that didn't seem too tough for a Saturday. With the possible exception of 1 Across, they were all eminently gettable, many are unique and I thought they were all interesting. In general, I found that I tussled more with some of the shorter entries than I did with the longer ones. How did you do?
When Wyoming Coach Heath Schroyer was dismissed last week and replaced on an interim basis by Fred Langley, Jared Grasso could relate.

William Webb was a typical Southerner. He was born in Georgia in the late 1840s, but like hundreds of thousands of Americans he rode the expansion of cotton westward, carried as a teenager first to Mississippi and then to Kentucky. Webb spent long days at work outdoors: driving wagons, hoeing cotton, harvesting tobacco. When he needed to raise cash, he sold homemade treats at camp meetings, those lengthy religious revivals popular among antebellum Americans. Webb started with ginger cakes, but when he realized that the Christians were not averse to something stronger, so he quickly switched to whiskey. It "paid the best," Webb later admitted in a narrative he wrote years later.

﻿In response to Tuesday's column about two programs in India that train relatively uneducated women as their villages' health workers, readers provided an avalanche of information about other community health worker programs around the world. Gregory Ortiz from London (95) wrote about Operation ASHA, which has semi-literate counselors treating tuberculosis in slums in India and Cambodia.  In thefield from Alaska (109) wrote about para-dentists in rural Alaska.    Marianne Loewe (121) from Santa Ana, Calif., commented on her organization, Concern America, which works with health promoters in Colombia and Central America.

The New York Academy of Art, a graduate university that has been teaching figurative art since 1982, is not the kind of institution you would expect to get into trouble for mischief on Facebook. Yet the school recently received a stern warning from the site: "You uploaded a photo that violates our Terms of Use, and this photo has been removed." The message went on to explain the kinds of things that Facebook does not allow: photos that attack a person or group, that depict drug use or contain violence or nudity.
Many guests attending designers’ shows for next fall wore a transparent curtain-skirt, while some designers’ runway visions showed a marked drop — to mid and lower calf.

On the eighth and final day of a New York fashion week that turned out to be all about fashioning modern Americana, Scorecard knows critics weren't quite sure what to make of the erstwhile master of prairie-luxe Ralph Lauren's rather literal love letter to the screen siren glamour of a "Limehouse Blues"-era Anna May Wong. Meanwhile over at Calvin Klein, Francisco Costa infused his minimalist chic with a new sporty vibe. That was deemed a stylistic home run.

How rapidly will the economy grow this year? The Federal Reserve has become somewhat more upbeat about the prospects for growth, and we feature its new appraisal on this week's Weekend Business podcast.

Some Web pages are crowded with so many graphical elements that it can be hard to locate the text you went there to read in the first place. The latest version of Apple's Safari browser might help clear things up, however. When visiting an overly busy page, check the browser's address bar to see if a small gray "Reader" button is visible. If so, click the button to get an uncluttered version of the page that is free of everything except the text and accompanying photographs.
Prepaid phones are often a great deal, offering voice and data at a low price and without tying you to a two-year contract. But the stripped-down handsets often limit the apps and services.
The White House's new chief of staff, William M. Daley, is rich -- so much so that his recent earnings from JPMorgan Chase appear to give even Jamie Dimon's pay package a run for the money.

Tapping into what it sees as a need for impartial international news on cable, the BBC said Friday that it would aggressively seek distribution in the United States for BBC World News, its 24-hour news channel.
The story line that ultimately emerged on the runways was pure Americana.

The father of the 5 Browns, a high-profile performing quintet of classical pianists, has pleaded guilty to sexually abusing his daughters when they were under 14. The father, Keith S. Brown, 55, entered his plea on Thursday in Fourth Judicial District Court in Provo, Utah. In an agreement with prosecutors, Mr. Brown pleaded guilty to a first-degree felony count of sodomy and two second-degree felony counts of sexual abuse of a child. He faces a sentence of 10 years to life in prison at sentencing on March 31.
The takeover of Liverpool F.C. may be complete, but the key players in the drama continue to squabble.
At least seven people had died in clashes between protesters and security forces in Bahrain before Friday’s violence.
MSNBC has certainly felt the impact of the departure of its most successful host, Keith Olbermann, last month, though the network has not suffered anything that could be called a collapse.
In this weekend's "Wealth Matters" column, Paul Sullivan writes about the ways in which the affluent try to protect their family's reputation.

Dr. Margaret Hamburg, commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration, called on Friday for a new process to allow makers of generic drugs to pay user fees to the F.D.A. to speed up approval of the low-cost drugs.
Talk about a quick learner: in just 50 years, a fish has evolved a resistance to toxic chemicals polluting its Hudson River home, a new study finds.

THE final day of Fashion Week felt a bit like a dash for the last plane out of Lisbon, if you know what I mean. Everyone wore very tight expressions. The journalists heading to London were already in the transit lounge. Still, the day's shows held some delights: Ralph Lauren's beautifully rendered Deco glamour and subplot of a Chinese retail assault; L'Wren Scott's Gauguin colors and a pitch, from both Ms. Scott and Francisco Costa of Calvin Klein, for short hemlines. Skirt lengths have generally been below the knees or to the ankles.
President Obama will make his promised trip to Latin America from March 19 to 23, visiting four cities in three countries, the White House said on Friday.
A week after Mubarak's fall, crowds gather to celebrate.

BARCELONA, Spain -- This week, tens of thousands of mobile technology executives, entrepreneurs and enthusiasts descended on this beautiful city to watch demonstrations of new software, get a close look at the latest phones and tablets and stop at a tapas bar or two.
With Chris Mullin being named a finalist for the Basketball Hall of Fame, the Dream Team from the 1992 Olympics moved one step closer to perfection.
It's no great secret that the United States national team lacks the position-by-position depth of the world's top soccer nations.

Men's-wear-inspired women's wear isn't anything revolutionary. From Diane Keaton in "Annie Hall" wearing Ralph Lauren to Cate Blanchett channeling Katharine Hepburn in "The Aviator," dressing like the boys doesn't have to mean androgyny. This fall plaids are designers latest nod to men's wear - and we're not talking suits. Thakoon's tribal-inspired cobalt blue and cherry red checkered 18th-century red puffer jacket would be foreign to Gaelic Scots. Similarly, Rag & Bone used a mixed color palette, but also paired neo-traditional houndstooth kilts with tough biker jackets. Some were more direct: Theyskens' Theory delivered plaids exactly how you want and expect them, a little oversized and unbuttoned, as if you threw on your boyfriend's. Conservative looks did resurface, however - patterns woven in maroon, brown and yellow made an appearance at Chris Benz as a simple long smock dress and Altuzarra-fitted trousers. Thankfully, this is one of those brilliant trends that you always have somewhere buried in your closet. Happy hunting.
Photographs from Uganda, Egypt, Bahrain and Yemen.

For technology spectators, a dinner on Thursday evening with President Obama and a dozen Silicon Valley executive seems like a scene straight out of an Agatha Christie novel: a pile of questions and very few answers surrounding the dinner and its guests.
Andy Cohen, executive in charge of dysfunction at Bravo TV, talks to Horacio Silva about the housewives and their many ancillary products.

As a native Wisconsinite, I can't tell you how often I've heard the old saw that Badger State politics mirrors its geography: to the right of Minnesota and above Illinois. Well, the first part was proven last November, when Republicans achieved a near-stranglehold on state politics, while the latter is contradicted by the fact that this week all 14 Democrats from the State Senate fled to a hotel across the border in the Land of Lincoln.

Green roofs have become increasingly popular in the United States as a way to beautify and insulate buildings and reduce heat pollution in urban areas, but last week one drew attention for a far different reason: it collapsed.

One thing I'm hearing and reading from liberal sources is the argument that we can find big savings by ending the war in Afghanistan, and more generally by cutting bloated defense spending. So, a few words on that issue.

HCA, the giant hospital operator that was acquired by buyout firms in 2006, is seeking to price its initial public offering at as much as $30 a share when it begins its presentation to investors next week, people briefed on the matter told DealBook on Friday.

John Strauss, composer of the theme song to "Car 54, Where Are You?" has died. Rather than a moment of silence, we propose 31 seconds of indelible catchiness, a whirlwind tour of the crime-and-mayhem news cycle of New York City circa 1961 (Khrushchev's due at Idlewild!) and a peek inside an old-school r.m.p., all available above via the miracle of YouTube.

Is Goldman Really to Blame? Some bloggers take issue with the view that Goldman Sachs was responsible for the 2008 collapse of the American International Group. "For me, it is difficult to see any malpractice from Goldman here. Goldman acted to protect itself, as it had every right to do. If A.I.G. did not want to have to accept Goldman's valuations, it could have negotiated a different valuation procedure for the trades. Instead it left itself open to massive liquidity risk by agreeing to the collateral arrangements that it did. A.I.G. never considered the consequences were the underlyings to its trades to become illiquid, nor where it would find the collateral were the trades to go against them. For me that is by far the worst of the behavior seen here." Deus Ex Macchiato
New Mexico's Jeff Bingaman announced his retirement Friday, making him the fourth member of the Senate Democratic caucus to have done so since the start of the year.

Like most bad news, the departure of Jack Griffin - the chief executive of Time Inc. for less than six months - dropped at the end of the day, leaving the publishing community scratching its head and wondering how things had gone so wrong. No one, including Mr. Griffin, saw this one coming. He was at a board meeting of Next Issue Media until 4 p.m. on Thursday, and another executive at the meeting said it was clear that Mr. Griffin did not know he was about to be fired from the world's largest magazine publisher.

There are certain things that creative people share in common, and lately a chat with the artist Doug Aitken seems to be one of them. Aitken's 2006 book, "Broken Screen," featured interviews with 26 artists, including Robert Altman and Rem Koolhaas. Now, with his latest video project, "Patterns & Repetition," the artist sits down with a new cast in an attempt to put the pieces of the creative puzzle back together again. Each week, The Moment will feature a different segment: Mike Kelley talking about the Motor City; Jacques Herzog on instinct and architecture; Jack White (above) imagining Michelangelo as a modern-day blogger. But don't be fooled by the coffee mugs and the California sunshine. Aitken doesn't do anything casually. The subtext of the conversations is nothing less than the future of art itself.

Talks and panel discussions are scheduled for Friday and Saturday at the International Association of Culinary Professionals conference. The events cover topics like the New York restaurant scene, food blogging and the farm-to-table movement. Receptions, lunches and dinners are also scheduled. Tickets are $149 for the conference, and a schedule of events is available from theculinarytrust.org.

Important archeological sites in Egypt were looted during the antigovernment protests, Egypt's antiquities minister, Zahi Hawass, wrote on his blog on Thursday. The announcement contradicted earlier statements by Mr. Hawass that Egypt's archeological sites were safe. Mr. Hawass wrote that tombs at Saqqara and Abusir and storage buildings at Saqqara and at Cairo University, among other sites, had been broken into. He added that he had formed a committee to determine and report on what objects were missing.

ThreeASFOUR - the science-obsessed label designed by Adi Gil, Gabriel Asfour and Angela Donhouser- is synonymous with geometric bags. "It all started when Adi dreamt of the bag," says Asfour, referring to the label's kidney-shaped bag. Adds Donhouser, "The kidney reflects our fascination with human anatomy." To celebrate its new e-commerce site, which goes live tomorrow, threeASFOUR is issuing the bag in two styles - a metal chain link version ($666) in black or pale gold snakeskin leather, and a split cell variety ($555) in bone or black canvas or leather. They join its perennially popular circle bag ($555). Available at planetofstyle.com.

LOS ANGELES- ABC, working feverishly to improve the digital components of this year's Oscar telecast, unveiled a "backstage pass" app on Friday for iPad, iPhone and iPod touch users. Ho-hum, you say, another app. We're worn out with app mania too, but this one is notable partly because it is designed to be used while you are also watching the show.

When making pizza at home, I've taken to dividing the dough in half and making two smaller pies with different toppings, one with tomato and one without. Usually, the one without is just drizzled with olive oil and sprinkled with coarse salt and an herb like rosemary. It comes out cracker-crisp in the middle, with great big bubbles and a nice rim of puffier crust at the perimeter. It tastes like focaccia; because of its crispness, however, it eats like pizza. My wife, Jackie, and I generally wolf it down in the kitchen while waiting upon the tomato/mozzarella/whatever pizza, which takes longer to bake.

ON THE SCREEN Blogs that cover niche topics usually appeal to niche audiences. In this city, where there are more bloggers per square mile than perhaps anywhere else in the world, highly specialized blogs create zealously exclusive communities around topics as diverse as cupcakes (Cupcakes Take the Cake) and fixed-gear bicycle freestyling (Prolly Is Not Probably).

Whether or not you agree that comedy is a male-dominated field, it is hardly an industry with a male-to-female ratio of 30-to-1. Yet that was the gender breakdown on the initial lineup of performers announced for SXSW Comedy, a long-running component of the annual South by Southwest festival in Austin. Of the 31 comedians in this year's lineup, including notable funnymen like Michael Ian Black, Thomas Lennon, Donald Glover and John Oliver, only one - Tig Notaro - is a woman.

I've never had a particularly great rapport with mulled wine, that staple of ski slopes and Christmas markets throughout Northern Europe. In theory it should be a tremendously restorative, literally heartwarming (one tries to avoid the reference to Gemütlichkeit) tonic from the alpine quiver, carried to table preferably by a St. Bernard. In reality, however, I couldn't count how many frankly off-putting mulled wines I've choked down slopeside over the years: harsh reds gussied up with a load of sugar and overwhelming spices to cover their unpalatable edge, then cooked, which only intensifies the jangle. Nein, danke.

Radiohead has released its new album a day earlier than expected. On Monday the band said that the album, "The King of Limbs," would be available for download on Saturday -- for fixed prices, unlike the widely noted name-your-own-price experiment of its last record. But on Friday morning Radiohead said in a statement that "with everything ready on their website, the band decided to bring forward the release rather than wait until the previously announced date." A video for the first single, "Lotus Flower," is also available and can be seen above.

Our love for all things Swedish knows no bounds. Would that we could have a Little Stockholm right here in New York, a neighborhood where'd snap up our favorite Scandanavian duds (and meatballs). So imagine our excitement when we found out that the Swedish label Our Legacy has built a temporary corner shop at Odin that will be open throughout spring. It's the largest selection of Our Legacy wares outside of Sweden, including a sizable pick from their latest collection, "Observations." A one-stop spot for an entire wardrobe, the store sells eminently wearable pieces - go-anywhere tees, soft plaid Oxfords, lightly structured blazers, no-fuss pants - designed to be layered and assembled into an outfit as easily as an Ikea bookcase.

The warmest day of the year so far, with the temperature reaching 63 degrees, but cloudy skies. Don't pack your coats yet, though; winter weather is on its way back. Clouds and wind to continue through the weekend.

Ed Balls is right: Mervyn King, governor of the Bank of England, has stepped way over the line by turning into a cheerleader for the current government's policies. He's wrong on the economics -- front-loaded spending cuts are the wrong policy for a still-depressed economy -- but that's not the key point; rather, the point is that if you're going to have an independent central bank, the people running that bank have to be careful to stay above the political fray.

I don't mind admitting that I can be afraid of dogs - can be, rather than am, because it depends on their size and bark. But there's a reason the New York City Department of Parks and Recreation requires that dogs in parks be leashed between 9 a.m. and 9 p.m., except in dog runs, and there's a reason it regulates their behavior even in designated off-leash areas before and after those hours. Dogs are welcome at urban parks, but the parks are primarily for people, and while the vast majority of dogs are domesticated, acts of aggression by roaming dogs are, unfortunately, not uncommon.

The jewelry designer Hannah Martin thinks there is something in the air in London that breeds creativity. "We are not as chic as the French, as technically brilliant as the Germans or as luxurious as the Italians," she says, "but there is a synergy in the scene here, where people are not afraid to experiment." Martin is among an emerging group of innovative jewelry designers creating achingly cool collections that are singularly English. Emma Franklin, another English jeweler who wears a colossal ram's ring on her pinkie, ascribes this creativity to London's history and the rich roots of the gentry. "I am constantly inspired," she says.

9 P.M. (Investigation Discovery) THE INJUSTICE FILES In February 2007 the F.B.I. began the Civil Rights-Era Cold Case Initiative to look anew at racially motivated homicide investigations from before 1970. More than 100 cases have been identified as the F.B.I. has worked with local and state authorities, the N.A.A.C.P., the Southern Poverty Law Center and the National Urban League to bring justice to victims' families. In this new series, in honor of Black History Month, Investigation Discovery teamed up with the filmmaker Keith Beauchamp, the director of ''The Untold Story of Emmett Louis Till,'' to explore three of the cases. They begin with ''The Secrets of Natchez,'' about the unsolved murder on Feb. 27, 1967, of Wharlest Jackson, a father of five and the treasurer of the Natchez, Miss., chapter of the N.A.A.C.P. who was killed by a car bomb and whose body was discovered by his 8-year-old son. Above, the Jackson family. 8 P.M. (CW) SMALLVILLE Oliver (Justin Hartley) and Chloe (Allison Mack) are kidnapped while investigating a string of murders committed by Desaad (Steve Byers), who then tries to make Chloe ill by using the darkness against her. Meanwhile Lois (Erica Durance) suggests that Clark (Tom Welling) conceal his identity with a disguise. In ''Supernatural,'' at 9, Dean (Jensen Ackles) races against the clock to protect Lisa (Cindy Sampson), and Sam (Jared Padalecki) investigates the deaths of several men who may have played a cruel practical joke on a female colleague.

The chief executive of Time Inc., Jack Griffin, is leaving the company after less than six months on the job - forced out over what company executives said was a widespread sense that his management style was brusque and did not fit the corporate culture there. Mr. Griffin, 50, drew an unusual public rebuke from Jeffrey L. Bewkes, the chief executive of Time Inc's parent company, Time Warner, who said in an e-mail to employees on Thursday evening that the situation had become unworkable.

THE OLD GUARD In a sign of how much the New York Stock Exchange has changed, one of its oldest fixtures, LaBranche & Company, has agreed to be sold to the Cowen Group for $192.8 million in stock. LaBranche sold its Big Board specialist operations, an 87-year-old business, to Barclays Capital for $25 million last year. Over the last decade, many specialist firms sold or left the business as electronic trading became more dominant. The scion of its founding family, Michael LaBranche, above, also the firm's chairman and chief executive, will become a Cowen senior managing director and join its board. MICHAEL J. de la MERCED

de ST. PAER--Claude J. It is with great sadness that the Board of Directors of the Group of North American Insurance Enterprises memorializes the death of Claude J. de St. Paer, the father of GNAIE Executive Chair, Jerry de St. Paer. Claude J., de St. Paer, age 93, a resident of Wheaton for over 50 years, died Friday, February 11 at Wynscape Nursing and Rehabilitation Center in Wheaton. He was born on January 3, 1918 in Larrabee, Iowa to Claude and Ruth de St. Paer. Claude graduated from Buena Vista College in 1940 and did graduate work at the University of Iowa and the University of Chicago. On August 15, 1940 he married Virginia "Ginny" B. Edwards. He served in the US Navy in the Pacific Theater from 1944 until 1946 as a Lt. J.G. Upon returning from the military he worked as a school teacher, basketball coach and principal in Iowa. He then worked for the Iowa Farm Bureau and then the American Farm Bureau Federation from 1948 until his retirement in 1983. They lived in Iowa until 1959 when they and their children, Sue and Jerry, moved to Wheaton. He and Ginny were passionate about Wheaton and Republican politics. Claude was the campaign manager for many local and congressional Republican candidates. He was an active member of Gary United Methodist Church, including service as a trustee. He served for many years in the Kiwanis Club of Wheaton, where he was involved in many service projects. During the 1980's and 1990's he served on the Wheaton Fire and Police Commission. He also served on the Mosquito Abatement Commission. He was an avid fisherman, both with Ginny and also with many friends. He is survived by two children, Sue Lee and her husband William of Horicon, Wisconsin and Jerry de St. Paer and his wife Karen of Chatham, NJ, nine grandchildren and fourteen great-grandchildren, a sister, Jeannie Green from Des Moines, IA and sisters-in-law, Ruth de St. Paer from Bryan, TX and Mary Ellen Kelling of Montezuma, Iowa. He was preceded in death by his wife, Virginia, his parents and his brother, Francis de St. Paer. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, February 19 at 11:00am at Gary Memorial United Methodist Church, 224 N. Main St., Wheaton, IL 60187. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be directed to Wheaton Kiwanis Charitable Foundation, PO Box 33, Wheaton, IL 60187. Information and guest book are available at hultgrenfh.com or call Hultgren Funeral Home at 630-668-0027.

OSAKA, Japan -- Japan may cut short this year's annual whale hunt in the Antarctic Ocean after obstruction by an environmental group has largely prevented its ships from killing whales, Japanese newspapers reported Friday. The Agriculture Ministry, which runs Japan's widely criticized research whaling program, said harassment by the group, the Sea Shepherd Conservation Society, has kept its catch far below its annual quota of 850 whales, mostly minke, the reports said. The reports said the fleet had not been able to catch a single whale since Feb. 9.

PARKER--Gertrude Hess, 99, devoted wife of the late Morrison Parker, aunt, cousin and outstanding community leader. Gertrude's life always focused on her family, friends, and civic organizations. She served for over 60 years as the Executive Secretary of the New York County Republican Committee and was a leading force in the economic and legal development of New York City, especially in her beloved Westside of Manhattan. She was admired by government and community leaders and especially by her family, to whom she was always devoted. The funeral will be held at Plaza Funeral Chapel, 91st St. and Amsterdam Ave, New York City. The visiting hours are 7-9pm on Thursday. The funeral service will be held Friday at 11am.

'Portraits of Leadership: African American Entrepreneurs on Staten Island' (through Nov. 1) They have made their lives and their livelihoods on Staten Island and believe in giving back to their community. That is the thread that connects the eight individuals featured in a multimedia exhibition at the Staten Island Museum's History Center in Snug Harbor. Among the entrepreneurs is Gerald Barclay, above, a filmmaker born in Liberia who started his video production company on the north shore. He will be on hand on Thursday from 6 to 8 p.m. to discuss his film ''Killa Hill: The Park Hill Documentary,'' which chronicles the destructiveness of a crack epidemic in the late 1980s. Others profiled in the exhibition, which consists of photographic portraits and filmed interviews, include Kevin Buford, a vendor popular with riders of the Staten Island Ferry, and Ruby Dailey, a centenarian from Alabama who came to the borough with her husband for a better life. Admission is free for Thursday's event as well as for the exhibition, on view Tuesdays through Saturdays from 1 to 4 p.m.; 1000 Richmond Terrace, Building H, Livingston; (718) 727-1135, statenislandmuseum.org. (Anne Mancuso)

HESS--Carl B.,Founder and Chairman Emeritus of AEA Investors, died peacefully at his home in New York City on February 15, 2011, age 98. He was born in Chicago, Illinois, October 28, 1912, and attended the University of Chicago Lab School. He went on to Dartmouth College, where his many college activities included serving as editor of Daily Dartmouth and as President of The Arts, The Round Table, and The Junto, and membership in Palaeopitus and Casque & Gauntlet. He graduated with honors in history in 1934. His business career led to his becoming a partner in Cresap McCormick & Paget, Management Consultants, and then vice president and director of American Securities Corp. In 1963, Mr. Hess conceived and created a new form of private investment firm which, in 1968, became American Euro pean Associates. Thus began his legendary career as a pioneer in private equity. Known since then as AEA Investors Inc., AEA, initially with financial support and endorsement of S.G. Warburg & Co. and shortly thereafter from senior members of the Rockefeller, Mellon, Harriman, Du Pont and other major families, was the first privately funded organization devoted solely to direct equity investment. From the outset and still today, its ownership and direction has been dominated by the chairmen and chief executive officers of many of America's leading corporations. The firm is now global in its reach with shareholder/participants of the same prominence and achievement in Europe, Asia, South and Central America, and the Middle East. As Chairman Emeritus, Mr. Hess remained active in the firm and was a regular presence in the AEA offices until shortly before his death. Ever loyal to Dartmouth College, he was a member of the Dean's Council and the President's Leadership Council. He was a member of The Rockefeller University Council and served on its Executive Committee. He was also on the Oversight Committee for Preservation of Objects at the Metropolitan Museum. He was predeceased by his beloved brother and friend, John D. Hess. He is survived by: his wife, Ludmila Schwarzenberg Hess; his son, Eric Hess and his daughter-in-law, June Hess; his daughter, Safiya Bonaventura; five grandchildren: Arden Hess Rowland and her husband Walter, and Aram, Joachim and his wife Kisha, Fleur and Claire Williams; one adored great-granddaughter, Wyatt Rowland; two nephews, Anthony and Oliver and his wife Leslie Hess; and two grand-nephews, John and Carl Hess. He is also survived by his first wife, Juliet Forbes. He was predeceased by his second wife, Desanka Pavlu, in 1990. Funeral services will be private. A memorial service will be held on Monday, March 7, 2011 at 4pm at the University Club. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Academic Venture Fund at Dartmouth College or to the Academic Venture Fund at The Rockefeller University.

PARIS - Eva Gabrielsson, the longtime partner of the late Swedish novelist Stieg Larsson, has written her version of their life together. ''Millennium, Stieg and Me'' is a slim memoir published in France, Sweden and Norway last month with a co-author, the French journalist Marie-Francoise Colombani. Ms. Gabrielsson claims that Larsson wrote slightly more than 200 pages of a sequel to his three-part ''Millennium'' series - ''The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo,'' ''The Girl Who Played with Fire'' and ''The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet's Nest'' - shortly before his sudden death in 2004. She has been seeking the legal authority to finish it; his family has refused.

LOS ANGELES- ''Toy Story'' fans, rejoice. Pixar will release two new short films starring Woody and pals by year's end. The first short, ''Hawaiian Vacation,'' will run with ''Cars 2,'' which will arrive in theaters on June 24. Pixar unveiled ''Hawaiian Vacation'' at a gathering of about 300 Disney investors and analysts in Anaheim, Calif., on Thursday. (Barbie and Ken try to stow away with Bonnie for a Hawaiian trip but get left home, to their enormous disappointment; Woody, Buzz and the other toys try to console the pair by improvising an island vibe but . . . it doesn't go well.) The second short - a title was not announced - will run with ''The Muppets,'' a Disney feature film set for a Thanksgiving release. In related Pixar news, Disney announced a direct-to-DVD spin-off of ''Cars,'' with airplanes as the main characters. ''Planes,'' undoubtedly accompanied by related merchandise, will arrive in spring 2013. The movie will focus on Dusty, a small-town dreamer who longs to enter an around-the-world air race despite his fear of heights. ''Phineas and Ferb,'' the Disney Channel cartoon, is also headed to the big screen; Disney said it was in the early stages of developing a ''Phineas and Ferb'' feature that will be a hybrid of live action and animation.

de JANOSI--Peter Engel, 82 of Chappaqua, NY, died suddenly of a massive stroke on February 16, 2011. Born in Pecs, Hungary, he attended Wesleyan University, graduating in 1950 and received his Ph.D. in Economics from the University of Michigan in 1956. He was a Senior Economist at the Exxon Corp. 1956-1962, a program officer at the Ford Foundation from 1962-1980 and a Vice-President of the Russell Sage Foundation, 1980-1990. He became Director of the International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis in Laxenburg, Austria, 1990-1996. Upon retiring he was a senior advisor for LEAD International and for Transforming Faces Worldwide and on the boards of IGES, Japan and IHGP, Germany. He received numerous awards, including the Austrian Honorary Cross for the Sciences and Arts, an Honorary Doctorate from the Budapest School of Economics and an Honorary Doctorate from the Russian Academy of Sciences. Peter was the adored husband of Monica, devoted father of Paul (Lydie), Nicholas, Alexander (Amber), beloved grandfather to Max and Evan, and loving brother to Clarisse Arnhold. He will be missed by all who knew him for his outstanding humanity, warmth and wit, his fondness for classical music, good food and bespoke British tailoring. A memorial will be held at later date.

HESS--Carl B. The Rockefeller University deeply mourns the loss of our beloved friend Carl Hess, a revered member of The Rockefeller University Council for over thirty years. A true gentleman and a man of deep character, integrity, and compassion, Carl left the world a better place. He was a legendary businessman whose foresight and innovative leadership created the private equity enterprise before those very words were coined. His strong sense of corporate ethics and social responsibility carried over into an active pro bono and philanthropic life. Carl first became involved with Rockefeller in 1976. He brought vision, astute judgment, and a belief in the promise of basic science to his service as a member of the Council and its Executive Committee. Seven university presidents benefited from his wise counsel and generosity. Carl loved to ask leaders about the projects they dreamed of launching. He would then make the first, critical gift. At Rockefeller he helped create the Center for Studies in Physics & Biology; the stem cell research fund, and the Academic Venture Fund, which provides seed funding for promising scientists conducting high risk, high reward research that does not qualify for government support. Carl was that rare benefactor who never sought public recognition for his gifts. Indeed he much preferred to name initiatives for friends whom he admired. Carl had a gift for friendship, and he enjoyed warm relationships with many Rockefeller scientists. He was adored by the university staff who felt privileged to know a man of such class and distinction. We will miss Carl greatly, and we extend our heartfelt condolences to his cherished wife, Ludmila, also a member of The Rockefeller University Council, and his children, grandchildren, and great-granddaughter; and to the entire Hess family. Russell Carson, Chairman David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman Richard Furlaud, Chairman Emeritus John Whitehead, Trustee Emeritus Paul Nurse, President Torsten Wiesel, President Emeritus Thomas Sakmar, Furlaud Professor Marnie Imhoff, Vice President

The producers of the Broadway musical ''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark'' have asked Roberto Aguirre-Sacasa, a playwright who also written Spider-Man stories for Marvel Comics, if he is interested and available to help rewrite the script for the big-budget, critically assailed musical, according to two people familiar with the discussions. Nothing has been signed and no verbal agreement has been made, but the two people said that Mr. Aguirre-Sacasa had indicated that he wanted to join ''Spider-Man.'' He has seen the musical at least twice, in December and earlier this month, and has had a deep and long-standing fondness for the character of Spider-Man, said the people, who do not know Mr. Aguirre-Sacasa personally; they both spoke under condition of anonymity because the talks are private and no agreement has been reached.

Again with the hand-wringing over what to name a bridge. Edward I. Koch is having as much trouble getting a bridge for himself as George Washington did 80 years ago on the other side of the island. In George Washington's case, there was actually a public referendum on whether to call the George Washington Bridge the George Washington Bridge. And George Washington actually lost. George had popped up entirely from out of the blue. Not once from the very conception of the world's mightiest suspension span had anyone intended to call it the George Washington Bridge. Not once, not over the three decades it took for the pols of New York and New Jersey to decide to build the thing in the first place, not over the several more years that followed the September 1927 groundbreaking, as workers lustily bored and poured and hammered and riveted and strung up cables, was it ever known as anything but the Hudson River Bridge.

HESS--Carl B. We mourn the passing of our Chairman Emeritus, Founder, mentor and colleague Carl Hess. Carl came to the office every day until three weeks ago, engaged to the end, ever watchful that we were maintaining the standards for AEA that he and the Founders had established over 40 years ago. We will miss his quiet and wise counsel. Our young colleagues will also miss their regular "lunches with Carl" that they cherished greatly. We and our colleagues will forever be indebted to Carl for the pivotal role he played in establishing our firm. On behalf of the entire AEA community, we extend our sympathies to Ludmila and the whole Hess family. John Whitehead, Chairman Emeritus Vincent Mai, Chairman John Garcia, Chief Executive

The coming transfer of Jez Butterworth's ''Jerusalem'' will combine members of the play's original Royal Court and West End cast with a few familiar Broadway veterans, including one soon-to-be-available Tony Award winner: John Gallagher Jr., the ''Spring Awakening'' star who is slated to leave ''American Idiot'' at the end of the month. Mr. Gallagher will appear in ''Jerusalem'' as Lee, one of the many lovably seedy characters who inhabit the world of the play's protagonist, Johnny ''Rooster'' Byron, press representatives for the production said on Thursday. It was previously announced that Mark Rylance (of ''La Bete'') and Mackenzie Crook (of Britain's ''The Office'') will reprise their roles as Johnny and his chum Ginger; they will be joined by Max Baker (''Cyrano de Bergerac'') as Wesley, Geraldine Hughes (''Translations'') as Dawn and Molly Ranson (''August: Osage County'') as Pea. From the British cast, Alan David, Aimee-Ffion Edwards, Danny Kirrane, Charlotte Mills, Sarah Moyle, Harvey Robinson, and Barry Sloane will all appear in the Broadway production. The play, directed by Ian Rickson, is to begin previews at the Music Box Theater on April 2 and its opening night is scheduled for April 21.

KROEGER--Catherine Clark, New Testament scholar, author, and a leading figure within the biblical egalitarian movement, died February 14, 2011 at the age of 85. Born in St. Paul, MN, she was a resident of Brewster, MA. Dr. Kroeger graduated from Bryn Mawr College and received a Ph.D. in Classical Studies in 1987 from The University of Minnesota. She served as Protestant chaplain and lecturer in the Department of Religion at Hamilton College. Dr. Kroeger was a ranked adjunct professor of classical and ministry studies at Gordon Conwell Theological Seminary, where she taught from 1990 until her death. She authored, co-authored or edited thirteen books, including The IVP Women's Bible Commentary. Dr. Kroeger was founding president of Christians for Biblical Equality, president of Peace and Safety in the Christian Home, and trustee emerita of Whitworth University. She was cited in Helen Kooiman Hosier's 100 Christian Women Who Changed the 20th Century, and received an honorary Doctorate in Humane Letters from Houghton College in 2004. She is survived by her five children, their spouses, and ten grandchildren. She was preceded in death by her husband of 60 years, Rev. Richard Clark Kroeger, in November, 2010. A funeral service will be held at Brewster Baptist Church, Brewster, MA on Saturday, February 19 at 2pm. For online condolences and directions, please visit www.nickersonfunerals.com

BAHRAIN -- There's delirious joy in the center of Bahrain right now. People power has prevailed, at least temporarily, over a regime that repeatedly used deadly force to try to crush a democracy movement. Pro-democracy protesters have retaken the Pearl Roundabout - the local version of Tahrir Square - from the government. On a spot where blood was shed several days ago there are now vast throngs kissing the earth, chanting slogans, cheering, honking and celebrating. People handed me flowers and the most common quotation I heard was: "It's unbelievable!"

Andy Barall writes about pro football history for The Fifth Down. Dave Duerson died on Thursday at age 50. Dave Duerson was an important contributor to one of the most interesting and colorful defenses in N.F.L. history: the mid-'80s Chicago Bears. It was also one of the greatest. At its peak, in 1985, that defense wouldn't just stop opponents, it would frequently intimidate and embarrass them. The producers behind ''Lombardi,'' about the storied Green Bay Packers football coach Vince Lombardi, are shifting to basketball for their next Broadway-aimed sports play. ''Magic/Bird'' will dramatize the fierce on-court rivalry and friendship between two Hall of Fame stars: Magic Johnson and Larry Bird. ''I just remember growing up and being so inspired by the way they played against each other,'' said Fran Kirmser, who co-produced ''Lombardi'' with Tony Ponturo. ''It was an extremely competitive relationship but it was also a respectful one.''

An article on Tuesday about plans by biologists to celebrate the 202nd anniversary of Charles Darwin's birth in rural areas around the country misidentified the city in Iowa where a museum official said he anticipated dissent over the festivities. The official was in Davenport, not Putnam. Because of an editing error, the article also referred incorrectly to the 475 events scheduled to mark Darwin's Feb. 12 birthday. Besides the biologists' visits, at least one celebration was scheduled in Virginia, Nebraska and Iowa; it was not the case that no events were planned in those states.

Important archeological sites in Egypt were looted during the antigovernment protests, Egypt's antiquities minister, Zahi Hawass, wrote on his blog on Thursday. The announcement contradicted earlier statements by Mr. Hawass that Egypt's archeological sites were safe. Mr. Hawass wrote that tombs at Saqqara and Abusir and storage buildings at Saqqara and at Cairo University, among other sites, had been broken into. He added that he had formed a committee to determine and report on what objects were missing. Meanwhile, Mr. Hawass's long-running campaign to repatriate Egyptian antiquities is making legal waves in the United States. The Saint Louis Art Museum filed suit this week in an effort to prevent the United States attorney's office in St. Louis from seizing a 3,200-year-old funerary mask that Mr. Hawass has claimed was stolen from Egypt, the blog Looting Matters reported. In its suit, the museum said that the American government had not gathered sufficient evidence that the mask was stolen, and that the statute of limitations had run out on the government's right to seize the mask. The mask was discovered in Saqqara in 1952 by an Egyptian excavator, and Mr. Hawass has said that it was stolen sometime after 1959, when it was registered as stored at Saqqara. The Saint Louis Art Museum bought the mask in 1998, for about $500,000, from Phoenix Ancient Art, an antiquities dealership owned by the brothers Hicham and Ali Aboutaam. Since that time, Hicham Aboutaam has been convicted in New York of falsifying customs documents (for another object), and an Egyptian court has convicted Ali Aboutaam in absentia of smuggling and sentenced him to 15 years in prison. According to the museum's complaint, the assistant attorneys from the United States attorney's office in St. Louis held a meeting about the mask on Jan. 13, in which they announced their intention to seize it.

5:52 p.m. | Updated Graying audiences: the subject causes great concern to opera houses, which fear that the number of people in their seats will dwindle as fewer young people become interested in the art form. So it seemed to be cause for celebration when the Metropolitan Opera proudly announced on Wednesday that the average age of its audience had dropped from 65 to 57 over the five years of Peter Gelb's tenure as general manager, according to internal surveys. Except that it wasn't true. After the Met was asked to provide documentation on the surveys, a spokesman said that Mr. Gelb - who provided the numbers - had been given incorrect information. In fact, the spokesman said, the average age of subscribers dropped from 66.4 in 2005 to 64.8 in 2011, and the average age of all audience members - single ticket buyers and subscribers - went from 60.4 to 57.7. Still, that's a three-year overall average drop, a positive trend in the eyes of the Met.

(Starz) THE RUNAWAYS (2010) Kristen Stewart portrays Joan Jett and Dakota Fanning (left, with Ms. Stewart) is Cherie Currie, the guitarist and lead singer for the real-life band of the title in this biopic set in Southern California in the mid-1970s. ''Girls can't play the electric guitar,'' a teacher informs Joan. ''This is not about women's lib,'' counters Michael Shannon, as the promoter Kim Fowley, who takes the girls under his wing and preaches a brand of macho feminism. ''It's about women's libido.'' Reviewing this feature-film debut from Floria Sigismondi, based on a memoir by Ms. Currie and with Ms. Jett as an executive producer, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times: ''Shot (by Benoît Debie) with a grainy, smeary look that evokes the decade as effectively as the clothes and haircuts, 'The Runaways' balances nostalgia for wild bygone times with a cautionary sense of their less heroic side. Acknowledging the brazen, rebellious energy of rock 'n' roll at the dawn of punk, Ms. Sigismondi also tallies the costs that an ardent, ambitious love of the music can exact.'' He added: ''The movie may be a little too tame in the end, but at its best it is just wild enough.'' 5 P.M. (TNT) N.B.A. ALL-STAR GAME AT 60 The N.B.A. leads up to its 2011 All-Star Game (Sunday night at 8:30) with an evening of specials, starting with this showcase of highlights from six decades as well as memories from the former stars Charles Barkley, Kevin McHale and Chris Webber. ''The Lost Dunks,'' at 7, looks back at the most spectacular dunks by players who failed to win the annual slam dunk contest. ''N.B.A. Tip-Off,'' a pregame show at 8, introduces ''N.B.A. All-Star Saturday Night: From Los Angeles,'' at 8:30, featuring a three-point shootout, a skills challenge, and the dunk competition with DeMar DeRozan of the Toronto Raptors, Blake Griffin of the Los Angeles Clippers, Serge Ibaka of the Oklahoma City Thunder and JaVale McGee of the Washington Wizards.
