Some stars take longer than others to come into telescopic range. Such is the case with Luis Camnitzer, who, in his early 70s and with a half-century career behind him, is just now having his first New York museum survey. The show, at El Museo del Barrio, is terse, almost to the vanishing point in places, as might be expected from one of the pioneers of 1960s Conceptualism. Much of what's here is based on printed language: cryptic propositions, random lists of words and descriptive phrases -- unmoored from, or very loosely tethered to, other spare-to-barely-there visual matter.

An article on Friday comparing resistance to the proposed renaming of the Queensboro Bridge with resistance to naming of the George Washington Bridge in 1931 misstated the proposed name for the Queensboro. It would be called the Ed Koch Queensboro Bridge, not the Edward I. Koch Bridge.

As public and private colleges and universities have been forced to make painful budget cuts in the past couple of years, many educators have worried that the humanities are getting short shrift. To bolster support for teaching and research in the liberal arts, the American Academy of Arts and Sciences on Thursday announced the creation of a national commission on the humanities and social sciences. The panel was established at the request of a group of Democratic and Republican senators who asked the academy for a top 10 list of actions that government, educators and philanthropists could take to maintain excellence in the humanities and social sciences and strengthen civil society. The three dozen commission members include the former Supreme Court justice David Souter; filmmakers George Lucas and Ken Burns; James McNerney, the chairman and president of Boeing Company; the actor John Lithgow; the songwriter Emmylou Harris; the architect Billie Tsien; a raft of college presidents like John Sexton, Donna Shalala, David Skorton, Drew Gilpin Faust, Amy Gutmann, and John L. Hennessy; and professors like Kwame Anthony Appiah, Anthony Grafton and Annette Gordon-Reed and the academy president, Leslie Berlowitz. The commission, which is expected to exist for 18 to 24 months, plans to focus on education and research institutions.

In some ways it was a very rock 'n' roll after-party: guests whispered a password at the door of the Bowery Hotel (it was ''Radio City'') and passed through a hall of exposed brick, into a crowd dotted with the expected number of motorcycle jackets and the sort of young men who protect their eyes from UV rays - indoors, at night. But though the guests at the party celebrating the band Interpol's stellar gig at Radio City Music Hall on Thursday night included the usual indie rock melange of D.J.'s, ex- and current girlfriends of the band and music journalists, there was none of the genre's usual grit.

MANISOFF--Miriam "Evie", nee Tauber, 91, formerly of New York City and Shelter Island, New York, a resident of Indianapolis since 2008, passed away peacefully on February 17, 2011. Born and educated in New York City, Ms. Manisoff was a graduate of Brooklyn College and Bellevue School of Nursing. Her lifelong dedication to the field of reproductive health included serving for many years as Director of Professional Education World Population for The Planned Parenthood Federation of America. An early pioneer of the nurse practitioner movement, Ms. Manisoff established the role of the nurse practitioner in family planning clinics, creating and running a training program which has since trained more than 800 nurse practitioners. The author of many professional articles and two books on family planning which have been translated into numerous languages, Ms. Manisoff was recognized with the Alan Guttmacher Lectureship in 1993, an honor it had previously never granted to a nurse. Ms. Manisoff served as a consultant to the World Health Organization and was appointed to the boards of a number of nursing training programs. The Miriam Manisoff Award was created in 1982 by The Planned Parenthood Federation of America in honor of Ms. Manisoff and is granted annually to an advanced clinician who has advanced the role of the OB/GYN nurse practitioner. Miriam Manisoff was preceded in death by her parents Sam and Clara and her husband Israel "Manny" Manisoff, a former Federal Theater director and fundraising consultant. Surviving Ms. Manisoff are her brother, Dr. Leo Tauber of Ventura, her sister, Hilda Tauber of New York City, her daughters, Michele Manisoff of New York City and Dr. Madelaine Wohlreich of Indianapolis, and her grandson, David Wohlreich of Indianapolis. Funeral services will be held privately in New York. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to The Nature Conservancy Mashomack Preserve, Shelter Island.

UNITED NATIONS -- The Obama administration vetoed a United Nations Security Council resolution on Friday condemning Israeli settlement building in occupied territory as illegal, choosing not to alienate Israel and risking the anger of Arabs. The lopsided vote in the Council, where among the 15 members only the United States voted no, as well as the more than 100 co-sponsors of the measure, underscored the isolation of the United States and Israel on the issue.

Federal prosecutors have ended a criminal investigation of Angelo R. Mozilo, the former chief executive of the mortgage lender Countrywide Financial, without taking any action against him, according to a person with direct knowledge of the investigation who spoke only on the condition of anonymity. A grand jury investigation took more than two years exploring Mr. Mozillo's conduct during the mortgage crisis at Countrywide, once the nation's largest mortgage lender. In October, Mr. Mozilo paid $67.5 million to settle a civil securities fraud lawsuit by the Securities and Exchange Commission. The S.E.C. had accused Mr. Mozilo of masking the risks of the subprime mortgage market in public statements to shareholders. In settling, Mr. Mozilo neither admitted nor denied the S.E.C.'s accusations. The Justice Department does not announce when it has ended an inquiry. News of the inquiry's closing was reported earlier by The Los Angeles Times. .

As Ahmed Samir stood in a ring in the Flatiron district throwing punches the other day, his mind was on another fight - for the future of his homeland, and for his right to return there. Three and a half years ago, Mr. Samir had stood in Kennedy International Airport grappling with the decision of his life. He had arrived with the Egyptian national boxing team to fight in the 2007 World Boxing Championships in Chicago. Instead of boarding the connecting flight, he skipped out, leaving his team and effectively defecting.

UNIONDALE, N.Y. -- Michael Grabner, a speedy right wing for the Islanders, has done so well lately, scoring almost at will for a team on a roll, that he does not want to talk much about the most difficult three months of his brief N.H.L. career. Grabner, 23, has a team-high 25 goals in his first full season -- 16 in his last 16 games -- and has become a candidate for the Calder Trophy as the league's top rookie. It is hard to believe that two N.H.L. teams got rid of him between last season and this season.

I HAVE always felt as if Brooklyn belonged to me. At the very least, Fort Greene was mine. While I was growing up in the late 1980s and the 1990s, Fort Greene was notorious for being a rough neighborhood, home to one of New York City's largest public housing projects. For most of my life, this provided me with incredible and undue street cred: I survived life in the Fort.

We will miss his quiet and wise counsel. Our young colleagues will also miss their regular "lunches with Carl" that they cherished greatly. We and our colleagues will forever be indebted to Carl for the pivotal role he played in establishing our firm. On behalf of the entire AEA community, we extend our sympathies to Ludmila and the whole Hess family. John Whitehead, Chairman Emeritus Vincent Mai, Chairman John Garcia, Chief Executive

THERE are certain things that creative people share in common, and lately a chat with the artist Doug Aitken seems to be one of them. Mr. Aitken's 2006 book, ''Broken Screen,'' featured interviews with 26 artists, including Robert Altman and Rem Koolhaas. Now, with his latest video project, ''Patterns & Repetitions,'' the artist sits down with a new cast in an attempt to put the pieces of the creative puzzle back together again. Each week, The Moment will feature a different segment: Mike Kelley talking about the Motor City; Jacques Herzog on instinct and architecture; Jack White (above) imagining Michelangelo as a modern-day blogger. But don't be fooled by the casual format. The subtext of the conversations is nothing less than the future of art itself. ALIX BROWNE

I don't mind admitting that I can be afraid of dogs - can be, rather than am, because it depends on their size and bark. But there's a reason the New York City Department of Parks and Recreation requires that dogs in parks be leashed between 9 a.m. and 9 p.m., except in dog runs, and there's a reason it regulates their behavior even in designated off-leash areas before and after those hours. Dogs are welcome at urban parks, but the parks are primarily for people, and while the vast majority of dogs are domesticated, acts of aggression by roaming dogs are, unfortunately, not uncommon. Yet, some pet owners routinely flout these policies, their lackadaisical attitudes suggesting that the rules are silly if not unnatural and that anxious civilians like me are nothing short of hysterical. Well, I have been pounced upon by dogs during my otherwise cherished runs in Central Park on more than one occasion. The most recent episode involved a dog that stood taller than my five-foot height - he jumped me from behind. His owner returned my stunned gasp with a chuckle and what he thought was a compliment: ''Oh, he was just flirting with you!''

After an absence of more than two decades, the Golden Nugget brand is returning to Atlantic City. Landry's, the casino's parent company, announced this week that it would buy the Trump Marina Hotel and Casino and open a Golden Nugget on that site. The company said it planned to update the casino with new bars, lounges, shops and renovated rooms. Among other new features: a spa, a race and keno room and a lounge that will include all-season hot tubs and fire pits. The improvements will take place by the end of the year, Landry's said. And travelers who have customer points with the Trump casino will be able to use them at the new Golden Nugget in Atlantic City and at two others owned by Landry's, in Las Vegas and Laughlin, Nev.
NEW YORK An article last Sunday about speed dating for Muslims in Queens described the term ''Adhan'' incorrectly. It is a call to prayer, not a prayer itself.

CERTAIN shoes have the aesthetic legs to stand the test of time. Consider the Bernardo sandal, that 1960s staple of Euro-hippiedom favored by Jane Birkin, fashion's perennial boho. Dennis Comeau, president of Bernardo Vintage Couture, is realigning the brand for this century. ''The difference with Bernardo is that you can put on a pair of sandals made in 1967 and look completely 2011,'' Mr. Comeau said. Several classic styles are appearing this month at Bergdorf Goodman. There's a navy Bandeau platform, a chocolate Moon disc flat (above, $225, updated from the original pink) and a jeweled thong called the Goldfinger. EDWARD BARSAMIAN

IN their wool-tweed pants, brown shirts and Grenson boots, the three puppeteers blended in perfectly with the brown-colored cane and silk of their Joey, a staggeringly lifelike horse who gallops, neighs and suffers along with his owner, Albert, through World War I in the play ''War Horse.'' Joey has been the nonhuman star of the London production of ''War Horse'' for three years, and is set to trot onto the Vivian Beaumont stage of Lincoln Center Theater when preview performances begin March 15. The magic of Joey owes much to the three rotating teams of puppeteers who operate the head, ears, chest, legs, tail and other body parts, with two people inside the horse puppet and a third outside. ''I basically handle the emotional state of Joey, because I control his breathing by bending up and down, depending on whether he is winded or tense or afraid or at ease,'' said Alex Hoeffler, who is under Joey's front half, joined by Zach Villa behind and Jude Sandy outside. (The other six puppeteers for Joey are Joby Earle, Ariel Heller, Jeslyn Kelly, Jonathan David Martin, Prentice Onayemi and Enrico D. Wey.)

THE final day of Fashion Week felt a bit like a dash for the last plane out of Lisbon, if you know what I mean. Everyone wore very tight expressions. The journalists heading to London were already in the transit lounge. Still, the day's shows held some delights: Ralph Lauren's beautifully rendered Deco glamour and subplot of a Chinese retail assault; L'Wren Scott's Gauguin colors and a pitch, from both Ms. Scott and Francisco Costa of Calvin Klein, for short hemlines. Skirt lengths have generally been below the knees or to the ankles. To me, the most striking change this season was the amount of innovative fabrics and embellishment, whether it was Oscar de la Renta's Oriental embroidery and patchwork or Marc Jacobs's rubber skirts crafted to look sequined.

''KIDNAPPED!'' reads the Web site of Barbès, a Park Slope, Brooklyn, bar and restaurant popular for its live music. Beneath that is an image of a statue -- the bust of a man with jet black hair and a matching mustache and eyebrows. It is about two feet tall and sits in a cubbyhole. ''José Gregorio has been our mascot and protector for now 10 years,'' reads the message, posted about a month ago by Olivier Conan, a co-owner of Barbès. ''Someone stole the bust. We don't think it's funny.''

With Chris Mullin being named a finalist for the Basketball Hall of Fame, the Dream Team from the 1992 Olympics moved one step closer to perfection. Inducted as a unit last year, the 1992 Dream Team has been nearly as dominant in individual Hall of Famers as it was on the court, with 10 of the 12 players on the team already enshrined.

THE NEWS President Obama proposed a budget of $3.7 trillion for the 2012 fiscal year, cutting outlays on a wide array of programs but stepping up spending on education and research, infrastructure and clean energy. BEHIND THE NEWS Republicans blasted the planned cuts as not nearly deep enough, citing the $1.1 trillion deficit the president projected for 2012. But neither side signaled any willingness to cut entitlement programs like Medicare and Medicaid that make up most federal spending. Mr. Obama acknowledged as much and said those programs could be tackled only if Republicans and Democrats worked together.

ISRAEL--Joan S. of San Diego, CA and New York on February 17, 2011 at the age of 85, after a brief illness. She is survived by her husband of 60 years, Benjamin (Professor Ben), children Roger (Marilyn) and Ken. Grandchildren Michael, Dan, Marlee, Katherine and Adrianna and six great-grandchildren. Deeply admired as a teacher she continued to receive fond letters from students who were in her Bellmore, NY fifth grade class of 40 years ago. Her warmth, intelligence, sense of humor, and love and generosity towards family and friends will be dearly missed.

IT is hardly unusual for a girl to dream of becoming a respected actress, but Mona Mansour once belonged to what must surely be a subset: those who take notes while watching regional theater productions as teenagers and cut out articles and photos of Meryl Streep, Swoosie Kurtz and others, keeping them organized in folders. ''I was this very freaky kid,'' Ms. Mansour said recently in an interview at the Public Theater, where her play ''Urge for Going'' will be presented beginning March 25. The path from starry-eyed adolescent amassing fan folders in Southern California in the 1970s (she declines to give her age) to increasingly noticed playwright included acting at Southern Methodist University, doing improv comedy with the Groundlings in Los Angeles soon after and, in 2001, writing her first play, ''Me and the S.L.A.'' A solo show about Patricia Hearst (''I was very, very obsessed with her''), it was also the start of her transition from actor to playwright. ''I think I had no concept of what it was to write a play, so for me acting felt like it was the way to be a part of this amazing thing,'' Ms. Mansour said. ''Until I realized I didn't like doing it anymore.''

THE American Council for an Energy-Efficient Economy, a Washington-based nonprofit group financed by foundations, electric utilities and state and federal agencies, released its annual list of the greenest vehicles of the model year on Tuesday. With six new models, this year's list differs markedly from last year's group. With the Nissan Leaf electric car and Chevrolet Volt plug-in hybrid now available the United States, one would think they would duke it out on the group's list for top honors, too. Not so.

Black, the schools chancellor, testified in the State Legislature on Tuesday about the teacher layoffs in New York City that she said would be unavoidable if the governor's proposed education budget were approved, a line from her remarks might have rung familiar to television viewers. ''The answer is obvious: Keep the most effective teachers, whether they have been in the system 2 years or 22 years,'' Ms. Black told the Assembly and Senate budget committees.

A picture credit last Sunday with a photograph of the actress Mo'Nique -- appearing with a column about black actors and the Oscars -- misstated the name of the agency that provided the photo. It is European Pressphoto Agency, not European Photopress Agency.

WHEN the cast of ''Hair'' heard in 2008 that it would be making the move from Central Park to Broadway, Patina Miller, who played Dionne, admits she felt a twinge. ''I got a little sick feeling,'' said Ms. Miller, 26, who had kicked off the show by singing the opening lines of ''Aquarius.'' Unbeknown to her fellow cast members, Ms. Miller had secretly auditioned for the lead in a London production of ''Sister Act,'' the role Whoopi Goldberg made famous in the 1992 movie. The part of Deloris Van Cartier, an aspiring disco diva, was the kind of fabled break Ms. Miller had always hoped for. ''The opportunity to create a role and be a lead, that was my dream,'' she said. But it would mean leaving ''Hair.'' As it turned out, Ms. Miller ended up with the best of both worlds. After winning the part and an Olivier Award nomination on the West End, she is now making her Broadway debut after all, with the musical's move to New York this spring.

It's no stampede, but the length of skirts seems to be turning into an issue as an alternative to leggings and trousers. Many guests attending designers' shows for next fall wore a transparent curtain-skirt, while some designers' runway visions showed a marked drop -- to mid and lower calf. The designer Cynthia Rowley solved the skirt proportions with a new above-the-ankle boot for day and evening.

Tweeting Since April 2009Followers 57, 545Twitter Bio Actress, author, personality, singer Sandra Bernhard's Twitter-worthy notions start out a lot like anyone else's. SPORTS Because of an editing error, a question in the ''30 Seconds With ...'' column on Feb. 6, featuring fullback John Kuhn of the Green Bay Packers, misidentified the type of Navy vessel in which he watched last year's Super Bowl with more than 2,000 sailors. It was a supercarrier, a type of aircraft carrier -- not a submarine.

ON THE SCREEN Blogs that cover niche topics usually appeal to niche audiences. In this city, where there are more bloggers per square mile than perhaps anywhere else in the world, highly specialized blogs create zealously exclusive communities around topics as diverse as cupcakes (Cupcakes Take the Cake) and fixed-gear bicycle freestyling (Prolly Is Not Probably). Tugster, a blog by Will Van Dorp covering the city's harbor through daily, photograph-filled posts, seems at first to be a narrow alcove geared toward seafaring captains or tugboat aficionados. Yet Mr. Van Dorp, who began Tugster in 2006 as a ''working water vessel ethnology,'' has attracted a broad audience. Professional mariners and landlocked lawyers alike, he said, are drawn in by his enthusiasm for ''the sixth borough,'' his nickname for New York's waterways.

Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about new itineraries for cruise lines misstated the price for a Mediterranean cruise on the Norwegian Epic, leaving July 24 from Barcelona; prices start at $1,149 per person, based on a family of four traveling.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Dog Show's Rare Breeds Are Glimpse of History,'' Feb. 14: It's silly to fret about rare dog breeds becoming extinct because of the lack of popularity while tens of thousands of dogs -- mutts and purebreds alike -- sit in animal shelters, waiting for homes. Breeders' attempts to save certain breeds doom homeless dogs by producing puppies who fill homes that could have gone to dogs in shelters. Dogs don't care what they look like, what breed they are, or what their papers say. They just want a loving home.

TIMOTHY EGAN The idea that an armed citizenry is the best assurance of freedom is deeply embedded in American thought, starting with the Second Amendment and those maddeningly imprecise words: ''A well-regulated militia being necessary to the security of a free state, the right of the people to keep and bear arms shall not be infringed.'' But this philosophy hasn't been a good export. The Egyptian revolution is only the latest example of how people can bring down tyrants without firing a shot. A century of successful nonviolent mass movements, in fact, makes the case that America's bloody insurrection against British rule was the anomaly, and perhaps not worthy of emulation. -- Excerpt from ''There Won't Be Blood'' TOWNIES Now that I was out of a job, and with more than $1,300 per month in Cobra payments looming, it seemed Tomoko and I had no choice. No ritual act of asking for her hand ensued. My knees went unsullied with dust from the floor. I didn't have a ring. I came home from the lawyer's office and launched into a lecture on what I took to be our connubial options, then muttered something about the refreshing simplicity of a civil affair. Tomoko pressed her mouth firmly shut, did a neck stretch that I recognized from her yoga practice, and frowned beatifically -- an indication, I knew, that her reserves of forbearance had been dangerously depleted. -- THEODORE ROSS, Excerpt from ''Love and Other Insurance Policies'' For more, nytimes.com/opinionator

Columbia Heights, a neighborhood in Northwest Washington, D.C., that just a decade ago was best known for vacant homes and empty storefronts, saw gentrification come not with the usual creep but with a boom. A new Metro stop in 1999 was followed by an influx of retail development, including the city's first Target store, followed by the predictable barrage of luxury condos. But while the blocks surrounding the Metro stop now feel something like a suburban mall, Washington's hippest new strip has cropped up just a few blocks away: a cluster of independent businesses has revitalized a once-desolate stretch of 11th Street, where big box stores and chain restaurants give way to indie rock dance parties and guerrilla theater performances. BRENDAN SPIEGEL

THE Rolls-Royce Phantom's prodigious V-12 engine, capable of propelling nearly three tons of iron, leather and exotic hardwoods from a standstill to 60 miles per hour in under six ticks of a Piaget watch, has new competition, and it comes with a plug port. In a news release on Sunday, Rolls-Royce revealed plans to build a one-of-a-kind Phantom luxury sedan powered purely by electricity.

A review on Feb. 6 about ''Ugly Beauty: Helena Rubinstein, L'Oréal, and the Blemished History of Looking Good,'' by Ruth Brandon, misstated the place of Rubinstein's birth. It was Krakow; she was not ''Hungarian-born.''

de JANOSI--Peter Engel, 82 of Chappaqua, NY, died suddenly of a massive stroke on February 16, 2011. Born in Pecs, Hungary, he attended Wesleyan University, graduating in 1950 and received his Ph.D. in Economics from the University of Michigan in 1956. He was a Senior Economist at the Exxon Corp. 1956-1962, a program officer at the Ford Foundation from 1962-1980 and a Vice-President of the Russell Sage Foundation, 1980-1990. He became Director of the International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis in Laxenburg, Austria, 1990-1996. Upon retiring he was a senior advisor for LEAD International and for Transforming Faces Worldwide and on the boards of IGES, Japan and IHGP, Germany. He received numerous awards, including the Austrian Honorary Cross for the Sciences and Arts, an Honorary Doctorate from the Budapest School of Economics and an Honorary Doctorate from the Russian Academy of Sciences. Peter was the adored husband of Monica, devoted father of Paul (Lydie), Nicholas, Alexander (Amber), beloved grandfather to Max and Evan, and loving brother to Clarisse Arnhold. He will be missed by all who knew him for his outstanding humanity, warmth and wit, his fondness for classical music, good food and bespoke British tailoring. A memorial will be held at later date.

Bill Buckner had 2,715 hits during his major league career, but he is best remembered for a defensive miscue almost 25 years ago. As the Boston Red Sox first baseman, he allowed a slow ground ball by Mookie Wilson to squirt between his legs to give the Mets a victory in Game 6 of the 1986 World Series. Buckner, 61, is back in Massachusetts as manager of the Brockton Rox, an independent team in the Can-Am League. He was a guest at a recent screening of ''Summer of '86: The Rise and Fall of the World Champion Mets,'' a four-part series that will have its premiere March 1 on MSG Network. Each 30-minute episode, broadcast on consecutive nights, will feature interviews with former players, including Buckner, and coaches. VINCENT M. MALLOZZI

The bridge that links Manhattan to New Jersey bears the name of George Washington. The bridge that connects Manhattan, Queens and the Bronx, once known as the Triborough, now carries the name of Robert F. Kennedy. Two months ago, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said he wanted to rename the Queensboro Bridge after another political figure: Edward I. Koch, the former mayor. Initially, many fellow politicians embraced the idea, which requires City Council approval. But Councilman Peter F. Vallone Jr. of Queens came out in opposition last week. ''Mayor Ed Koch is truly a great man and deserving of an honor like this,'' Mr. Vallone wrote, ''but renaming a landmark so closely linked to our borough's culture and history is not appropriate.'' The City Room blog asked readers to weigh in on the issue. Here are some of the responses:

WARREN--Irwin. Creator of some of the nation's most successful advertising campaigns, passed away at his home in Manhattan on December 11, 2010, at the age of 71. Cause of death was an aortic aneurysm. During an advertising career spanning more than 40 years, Mr. Warren worked at Doyle Dane Bernbach, BBDO, and other leading agencies, before moving to McCann Erickson, the world's largest advertising agency, where he retired as senior creative director in 2006. Notable campaigns and clients included Major League Baseball, Johnson & Johnson, Nestle, Unilever ("I Can't Believe It's Not Butter"), Lowe's, Campbell's Soup and Volkswagen. The elegant simplicity of his VW ads for DDB in the late 1960's earned their inclusion in the Museum of Modern Art's permanent advertising collection. Mr. Warren was born in St. Paul, Minnesota in 1939. Because his father was killed in an auto accident before his birth, Mr. Warren's mother, a concert pianist, raised him alone for several years before she re-married. Mr. Warren credited St. Paul Academy, where he completed high school, with developing in him the writing skills and intellectual rigor that he regarded as the keys to his success. He attended Colorado College and the University of Minnesota, before beginning his advertising career. Mr. Warren's marriage ended in divorce; there were no children. One of Mr. Warren's favorite campaigns was the long-running, very popular "Taster's Choice Couple" series that ran in the late 1990's. Each new installment generated extensive publicity, usually including an exclusive Today Show interview with Mr. Warren, who unveiled the latest 30-second plot twist. After recruiting Johnson & Johnson to McCann, Mr. Warren designed a campaign, which advanced no products, but stressed the company's long-term involvement with families, and dealt with such subjects as getting children to laugh; encouraging them to try to achieve; and dealing with being different. The company was deluged with requests from parents, schools, and organizations for DVDs of these spots. One McCann colleague recalled Mr. Warren as both brilliant and stubborn, and "enormously loyal to his clients and his friends. His work was always smart, hard-working and stylish," he said. Outside of work, he served as an energetic fund-raiser and board member of Riverside Park Fund on New York's West Side, helping to drive its rejuvenation from a tawdry, needle-strewn place to a safe and attractive park fit for families. It is now one of only eight officially designated scenic landmarks in the City of New York. He was a voracious reader and a knowledgeable collector of antique furniture. After private funeral services, a memorial service will be announced at a later date. Donations in Mr. Warren's name may be made to Team Jim Scholarship, c/o New Canaan Community Foundation, PPO Box 1285, New Canaan, CT 06840. Mr. Warren is survived by his brothers, Adrian of Tucson, Robert, San Francisco and Joel, Los Angeles, his niece Rachel Warren, his nephews Alex Warren and Samuel Warren, and his godchildren Chris, Oie, A.J. and Molly McKennan.

de ST. PAER--Claude J. It is with great sadness that the Board of Directors of the Group of North American Insurance Enterprises memorializes the death of Claude J. de St. Paer, the father of GNAIE Executive Chair, Jerry de St. Paer. Claude J., de St. Paer, age 93, a resident of Wheaton for over 50 years, died Friday, February 11 at Wynscape Nursing and Rehabilitation Center in Wheaton. He was born on January 3, 1918 in Larrabee, Iowa to Claude and Ruth de St. Paer. Claude graduated from Buena Vista College in 1940 and did graduate work at the University of Iowa and the University of Chicago. On August 15, 1940 he married Virginia "Ginny" B. Edwards. He served in the US Navy in the Pacific Theater from 1944 until 1946 as a Lt. J.G. Upon returning from the military he worked as a school teacher, basketball coach and principal in Iowa. He then worked for the Iowa Farm Bureau and then the American Farm Bureau Federation from 1948 until his retirement in 1983. They lived in Iowa until 1959 when they and their children, Sue and Jerry, moved to Wheaton. He and Ginny were passionate about Wheaton and Republican politics. Claude was the campaign manager for many local and congressional Republican candidates. He was an active member of Gary United Methodist Church, including service as a trustee. He served for many years in the Kiwanis Club of Wheaton, where he was involved in many service projects. During the 1980's and 1990's he served on the Wheaton Fire and Police Commission. To the Sports Editor: Re ''The Negro Leagues Discovered an Oasis at Yankee Stadium,'' Feb. 13 : Although the Yankees were slow to integrate after Jackie Robinson's 1947 debut with the Brooklyn Dodgers, signing Elston Howard in 1955, Yankee Stadium was as a significant platform, stage and civil rights springboard to integration in America.

INTERNATIONAL The Sèvres Journal article last Sunday, about a mysterious loss of weight in the kilogram prototype stored at the International Bureau of Weights and Measures in Sèvres, France, misidentified one of the three units of measurement that scientists are proposing to redefine, along with the kilogram, at the General Conference of Weights and Measures in October. Besides the ampere and the mole, they hope to redefine the kelvin, a measurement of temperature -- not the candela, a measurement of the intensity of light.

de RHAM--Casimir Jr.,86, of Cambridge, MA and Webster, New Hampshire died Sunday, February 6 from complications following a stroke. Son of Casimir de Rham and Lucy (Patterson) de Rham, of Tuxedo Park, "Casie" descended from Henri Casimir de Rham, first Swiss Consul (1822) to the United States, and John Motley Morehead, Governor of North Carolina, 1841-1845. Paternal grandparents were Henry Casimir and Georgiana (Berryman) de Rham, of Tuxedo Park, New York City and Newport, RI Maternal grandparents were Rufus Lenoir and Margaret (Morehead) Patterson, of New York City and Southampton. Mr. Patterson was founder and Chairman of AMF. Casie went to Malcolm Gordon School ('36), St. Mark's School ('42), Harvard ('46), Harvard Law ('49), and joined the law firm of Palmer & Dodge. He enlisted in the Marine Corps and was transferred to Yale in June 1943 under the V-12 Navy College Training program. He married Elizabeth Moran Evarts in June 1945. Save for fifteen months active duty as a US Marine Corps. Reserve captain in 1951-1952, Casie remained at Palmer & Dodge until moving to Hemenway & Barnes in 2008 where he remained "Of Counsel" until his death. Casie served for many years on numerous boards including Commonwealth School; St. Mark's School; the Boys and Girls Clubs of Boston; Sterling and Francine Clark Art Institute; the Mount Auburn Hospital, and the NAACP Legal Defense Fund. He was a Mason and a member of the American Legion. His beloved wife "Wiz" and his brother, David, predecease Casie. He is survived by his children, Lizzie, Harry, Rufus, and Jerry and his wife Amy, and his grandchildren Eruch, Elizabeth, Rufus, Daniel, Anna, Rose and Georgiana. In addition, he leaves his companion in laughter Edith "Deedie" Keppel of Brookhaven. A memorial service will be held at Christ Church, Cambridge, MA, Saturday, April 16, 2011 at 3pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: Mount Auburn Hospital, Elizabeth Evarts de Rham Hospice Home, Cambridge Community Foundation, all of Cambridge, MA; Boys & Girls Clubs of Boston, Boston, MA; NAACP Legal Defense Fund, New York City, NY.

For decades, Japan has been at the forefront of high-speed rail technology. Now, the Central Japan Railway Company has announced that it plans to build the fastest train in the world, between Tokyo and Nagoya, to be completed by 2027. The new line, estimated to cost about $64 billion, runs about 178 miles on part of an existing Tokyo-to-Osaka line; the company expects speeds up to 310 miles per hour, shaving travel time between the two cities to 40 minutes from about 95 minutes. (Trains currently in use top out at about 167 miles per hour.) An extension of the high-speed line to Osaka is planned by the end of 2045.

SADLER--Sheila. Village Community School honors Sheila Sadler, its visionary founding Director and leader from 1969-1989. What she created was and continues to be an exemplary K-8 independent school in Greenwich Village, New York. The school's mission has remained true to Ms. Sadler's founding principles, which we speak about often and live by in our daily practice. At the time of her retirement in 1989 the Sheila Sadler Fund for Professional Development was established in her name to honor her commitment to lifelong learning for educators. Some of us at the school today personally knew Ms. Sadler. We will miss her lively presence and treasure our personal memories of her. All of us are saddened by the loss of a person of such import to our school. We see this moment as an historic one, and want to establish a public record of Ms. Sadler's ongoing impact on society in making a difference in the lives of countless children, not only in the past, but today and well into the future. As we mourn her loss, we are filled with gratitude for her life. We are pleased to be able to join with countless others in celebrating her and in expressing our condolences to the family. A Celebration of Sheila's life will be held at Village Community School on June 12, 2011 at 11am.

THE New York Times's theater critics are not the only ones willing to opine on spring theater highlights. We also polled a random assortment of Tony award winners and nominees from last season to find out what they are most excited about seeing in the coming months. Here are some of their answers. Though ''The Book of Mormon,'' the irreverent new musical created by Matt Stone and Trey Parker, the guys behind 'South Park,' is looking like a popular choice among theater people (and others, presumably) the rest of the assortment below is as eclectic as our group of panelists. STEVEN McELROY SEAN HAYES, nominee, leading actor in a musical, ''Promises, Promises'': ''How To Succeed In Business Without Really Trying.'' Not only because I just finished working with Craig Zadan, Neil Meron, Beth Williams and Rob Ashford but I'm anxious to see my friend Daniel Radcliffe in his Broadway musical debut. I know he'll be nothing short of spectacular. And I hope that he can finally make a name for himself in this business.

MARK--Katherine Anne, 49, also known as Kathy Riemenschneider, of Croton-on-Hudson, NY, died Friday, February 11, 2011 at her winter home in St. Petersburg, FL. She leaves her husband, Bill Riemenschneider, of St. Petersburg, FL, the proprietor of Artistic Copper; her sister, Elizabeth Mark Meyerson of Atlantic Beach, NY, her uncle, Richard C. Mark of Purchase, NY, her nephew, Benjamin Jacob Meyerson, her niece, Hanna Grace Meyerson, and many cousins. A graduate of Williamsville East High School, a suburb of Buffalo, NY, Kathy also attended Skidmore College in Saratoga Springs, NY. She was born in New York City, spent her childhood years in Ringwood, NJ and Chappaqua, NY, and lived most of her adult life in Croton-on-Hudson with winters in Florida. In addition to her artistic and photographic skills, Kathy will be remembered for her laughter, her love of life, and her ability to spread joy and sunshine to all with whom she came in contact. Many people will remember her many years of participation in Renaissance festivals and other fairs where she adopted the persona of "Mama JuJu" and ran a booth where she and others interpreted objects, cards and handlines for clients in search of guidance for their personal lives. I'm not a fortune-teller," she often said. "If I could tell the future, I'd be a retired millionaire instead of working for a living." At Kathy's request, there will be no funeral service. Instead, her family asks all who knew and loved her to think of her and/or say a prayer in her memory on Friday, February 25, 2011. In lieu of flowers, please make donations in her name to a favorite charity. www.rlwilliams.com

For decades, endorphins have hogged the credit for producing ''runner's high,'' that fleeting sense of euphoria and calm that many people report experiencing after prolonged exercise. Who among us, after an especially satisfying workout, hasn't thought, ''ah, my endorphins are kicking in.'' Endorphins are the world's sole celebrity peptide. Endorphins first gained notoriety in exercise back in the 1980s when researchers discovered increased blood levels of the substance after prolonged workouts. (Endorphins, for those who know the word but not the molecules' actual function, are the body's home-brewed opiates, with receptors and actions much like those of pain-relieving morphine.) Endorphins, however, are composed of relatively large molecules, ''which are unable to pass the blood-brain barrier,'' said Matthew Hill, a postdoctoral fellow at Rockefeller University in New York. Finding endorphins in the bloodstream after exercise could not, in other words, constitute proof that the substance was having an effect on the mind. So researchers started to look for other candidates to help explain runner's high. Now an emerging field of neuroscience indicates that an altogether-different neurochemical system within the body and brain, the endocannabinoid system, may be more responsible for that feeling.

The N.H.L.'s second Heritage Classic will be played Sunday at McMahon Stadium in Calgary, a revival of the league's first regular-season outdoor game from eight years ago designed to feature two Canadian teams. The first game matched the Montreal Canadiens against the host Edmonton Oilers. Montreal will once again provide the opposition, this time for the Flames. The Canadiens won the first Heritage Classic, 4-3, on Nov. 22, 2003, and many consider it the best of the N.H.L. outdoor games so far. Played before more than 57,000 fans in subzero temperatures at Edmonton's Commonwealth Stadium, its most lasting image is probably that of Montreal goalie Jose Theodore wearing a stocking cap pulled over his mask to keep his head warm.

IN Britain, Bel Powley is best known as Daisy Millar, the undercover teenage spy and master of disguise she played in the BBC's children's series ''M.I. High.'' Starting this month Broadway audiences will get to see her in a very different role: as the 19th-century mathematical prodigy Thomasina in Tom Stoppard's brainy 1993 comedy ''Arcadia.'' Ms. Powley, who has a round face and large ''E.T.''-shaped eyes, said she was a bit daunted at first by the part. ''Thomasina has a big speech about the laws of physics, determinism and math, and I thought, 'There is no way I can give it before I understand it all,' '' she said. ''There were a lot of lines I really needed help with.'' Fortunately Mr. Stoppard was in New York with the cast (which includes Billy Crudup and Raúl Esparza) during the first week of rehearsals and discussed the complexities of the characters and the play, which shifts back and forth between the present and the 19th century.

THREEASFOUR, the science-obsessed label designed by Adi Gil, Gabriel Asfour and Angela Donhauser, is synonymous with geometric bags. ''It all started when Adi dreamt of the bag,'' Mr. Asfour said, referring to the label's kidney-shaped bag. Added Ms. Donhauser: ''The kidney reflects our fascination with human anatomy.'' To celebrate its new e-commerce site, threeASFOUR is issuing the bag in two styles: a metal chain-link version ($666) in black or pale gold snakeskin leather, and a split cell variety ($555) in bone or black canvas or leather. They join its perennially popular circle bag ($555; pictured). Available at planetofstyle.com. CHELSEA ZALOPANY

RICHENSTEIN--Elyse, of Key Biscayne, FL, formerly of Manhattan and Kings Point, New York, died peacefully on February 18, 2011. She is survived by her beloved husband, Victor, two loving sons, Lawrence and Kenneth, devoted family members, daughters-in-law, Mindy and Julie, and four grandchildren, Eric, Lisa, Marti, and Samantha. Elyse was born in Nurnberg, Germany, and survived Nazi persecution fleeing to Paris and later arriving in NY in her teens. An elegant, kind, and sunny woman loved by all who crossed her path, Elyse was a patron of the arts and devoted to her family, friends, and Judaism. A fund in Elyse's memory has been established at Chabad of Key Biscayne.

TONY SHELDON had just finished playing a cross-dresser in an Australian run of ''The Producers'' in 2005 when he took on the role of the transsexual chanteuse Bernadette in a workshop for a new musical, ''Priscilla Queen of the Desert,'' based on the 1994 film. ''I was reluctant at first,'' he said, '' because I thought I'd be trapped in this frock-wearing stereotype forever, and it would be the end of my career.'' Still, Mr. Sheldon, 55, has stuck with the part over the last five years in the Australian, West End and Toronto productions, and is now set to make his Broadway debut in ''Priscilla,'' which begins previews on Feb. 28. He has made his peace, calling Bernadette ''the role of a lifetime.'' A classically trained actor, he had never even performed outside of Australia until ''Priscilla'' took him to London.

HESS--Carl B.,Founder and Chairman Emeritus of AEA Investors, died peacefully at his home in New York City on February 15, 2011, age 98. He was born in Chicago, Illinois, October 28, 1912, and attended the University of Chicago Lab School. He went on to Dartmouth College, where his many college activities included serving as editor of Daily Dartmouth and as President of The Arts, The Round Table, and The Junto, and membership in Palaeopitus and Casque & Gauntlet. He graduated with honors in history in 1934. His business career led to his becoming a partner in Cresap McCormick & Paget, Management Consultants, and then vice president and director of American Securities Corp. In 1963, Mr. Hess conceived and created a new form of private investment firm which, in 1968, became American Euro pean Associates. Thus began his legendary career as a pioneer in private equity. Known since then as AEA Investors Inc., AEA, initially with financial support and endorsement of S.G. Warburg & Co. and shortly thereafter from senior members of the Rockefeller, Mellon, Harriman, Du Pont and other major families, was the first privately funded organization devoted solely to direct equity investment. From the outset and still today, its ownership and direction has been dominated by the chairmen and chief executive officers of many of America's leading corporations. The firm is now global in its reach with shareholder/participants of the same prominence and achievement in Europe, Asia, South and Central America, and the Middle East. As Chairman Emeritus, Mr. Hess remained active in the firm and was a regular presence in the AEA offices until shortly before his death. Ever loyal to Dartmouth College, he was a member of the Dean's Council and the President's Leadership Council. He was a member of The Rockefeller University Council and served on its Executive Committee. He was also on the Oversight Committee for Preservation of Objects at the Metropolitan Museum. He was predeceased by his beloved brother and friend, John D. Hess. He is survived by: his wife, Ludmila Schwarzenberg Hess; his son, Eric Hess and his daughter-in-law, June Hess; his daughter, Safiya Bonaventura; five grandchildren: Arden Hess Rowland and her husband Walter, and Aram, Joachim and his wife Kisha, Fleur and Claire Williams; one adored great-granddaughter, Wyatt Rowland; two nephews, Anthony and Oliver and his wife Leslie Hess; and two grand-nephews, John and Carl Hess. He is also survived by his first wife, Juliet Forbes. He was predeceased by his second wife, Desanka Pavlu, in 1990. Funeral services will be private. A memorial service will be held on Monday, March 7, 2011 at 4pm at the University Club. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Academic Venture Fund at Dartmouth College or to the Academic Venture Fund at The Rockefeller University.
Film Stephen Holden

FOR his first solo show in a New York gallery, Francesco Vezzoli chose an apt title: ''Sacrilegio.'' Its irreverence starts with his redesign of that gallery, the expansive Gagosian space on West 21st Street. It is now a stripped-down, dimly lighted Gothic church that is painted an Armani gray and is dedicated to a real Madonna, the source of Mr. Vezzoli's diva complex: his own mother. In each niche along the chapel nave hang appropriations, or rather apparitions, of Madonna-and-child paintings from the Italian Renaissance. But these digital prints on canvas have the faces of Cindy Crawford (at right), Christie Brinkley, Naomi Campbell and other supermodels of the 1970s and '80s, the period of Mr. Vezzoli's own coming-of-age as an artist. Each sheds his signature embroidered tears, only here they double as Warholian thought bubbles sampling icons of Arte Povera and Pop. And each wears gobs of actual designer makeup. They are encased in gold-leaf frames that ''melt'' at the bottom, Dalí style, as if they were crying, too. ''The real sacrilege of the exhibition is not the fashion model or the Madonna,'' he said. ''It's more challenging to discuss motherhood, or an obsession with your own mother, in a Chelsea gallery.'' Amen to that. LINDA YABLONSKY

NETTER--Edward. Edward Netter, age 78, of Greenwich, CT and Montecito, CA, a distinguished philanthropist and business leader, passed peacefully at his home on February 16, 2011. By his side were his beloved wife of 56 years, Barbara, their daughter and son-in-law, Vicki and Bill Fitzgerald, their son, Don, daughter-in-law, Stephanie, and granddaughters, Arianna Nell (4) and Samantha Charli (2), who will forever keep "Gramps" in their prayers. Edward was raised in Scarsdale, NY, and following his marriage to Barbara, settled in Larchmont, NY before moving to Greenwich in 1979. Edward began his business career following graduation from the University of Pennsylvania in 1953; he joined and then became a partner of Cogan, Berlind, Weill & Levitt, a prominent investment banking firm in New York City which evolved into Shearson Loeb Rhoades. Edward's seminal writings on what was referred to as "surplus, surplus" or "redundant capital" helped transform the fire and casualty insurance industry by demonstrating how companies could unlock value for all stockholders. Edward became legendary as one of the architects of the modern-day financial services holding company wherein varieties of investment products (e.g. mutual funds, insurance, business services, banking, etc.) are amalgamated under a common entity, and his ideas spawned many eminent transactions. Edward went on to devote his unsurpassed combination of intellect, creativity and stamina as founder of Netter International, Ltd. in 1971, and then as Chairman of its successor, Geneve Corporation, a financial services holding company that has controlling interests in numerous prominent public and private businesses which straddle the financial, distribution and manufacturing worlds principally in the insurance and education sectors, including Independence Holding Company, American Independence Corp., The Aristotle Corporation, Standard Security Life Insurance Company of New York, Madison National Life Insurance Company, Independence American Insurance Company and Southern Life and Health Insurance Company. In 2006, Edward was inducted into the Business Leader Hall of Fame at the Quinnipiac University School of Business, Hamden, CT for his enduring contribution to business through extraordinary leadership. A significant philanthropist through much of his life, Edward donated his time, knowledge and resources to many charities concentrated principally on science, education and human services, including those in the local communities of Greenwich and Montecito. Edward and Barbara have provided visionary leadership to the Barbara and Edward Netter Center for Community Partnerships at the University of Pennsylvania, whose mission, through a virtual classroom, is to provide the broad range of knowledge needed to solve the complex, comprehensive and interconnected problems of the American city. Edward was also an active trustee of Thanks to Scandinavia in New York City and a respected participant of The Greenwich Roundtable. Edward was a longtime member of The Harmonie Club in New York City, Beach Point Club in Mamaroneck, NY, and Burnham Wood Golf Club in Montecito, CA. He was an enthusiast of classical music, jazz and dance, and an accomplished competitive bridge player; he enjoyed collecting cartoons and sending them to his family, colleagues and friends; and he was a voracious reader, a student of finance, science, education and politics, an avid swimmer and tennis player, and a proud grandfather. Despite his vast accomplishments, Edward was a private man, of great humility, kindness and compassion, and always delighted in lending his talents as a mentor to assist others achieve their best. Perhaps Edward's finest achievement was his most recent---the extension of his innovative business principles and financial resources to visionary philanthropy in the form of Alliance for Cancer Gene Therapy (ACGT). The courageous 11-year battle against breast cancer of their first daughter-in-law, Kimberly Lawrence-Netter, inspired Edward and Barbara to found ACGT in 2001 as the only public charity focused exclusively on cell and gene therapy research, which is widely believed to be the next significant key to the development of effective and safe treatments of all types of cancer. With 100% of contributions going directly to science, and a 17-member Scientific Advisory Council composed exclusively of pre-eminent doctors and academics in the field of cell and gene therapy, ACGT has made grants of more than $22 million to pioneering investigators at 27 renowned U.S. research institutions; and there are currently 17 ongoing clinical trials based on ACGT's sponsorship. The members of the Netter family are thankful to those dedicated and talented colleagues in the business and philanthropic communities, as well as their numerous dear friends, who have made Edward's extraordinary journey so exciting and rewarding. Funeral services will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York, NY at 11:30am on Wednesday, February 23, 2011. In lieu of flowers, donations in Edward's memory will be gratefully appreciated by Alliance for Cancer Gene Therapy at www.acgtfoundation.org.

HOROWITZ--Milton, M.D. The members of The New York Psychoanalytic Society and Institute mourn the loss of our esteemed member, Milton Horowitz. He has been the model of a supervising and training analyst, teacher, mentor and colleague for more than 50 years. His renowned therapeutic talent has been built upon his brilliant intellect and his constant and sincere question, "How can I be of help?" He was a generous friend and had a funny and telling story for every occasion. The list of grateful patients and students is long. He will be missed. Philip Herschenfeld, M.D. Roger Rahtz, M.D. President Richard Weiss, M.D. Dean

Dom DeLuise, the comedian (and five of clubs), was implicated in the following unseemly acts in my mind's eye: He hocked a fat globule of spittle (nine of clubs) on Albert Einstein's thick white mane (three of diamonds) and delivered a devastating karate kick (five of spades) to the groin of Pope Benedict XVI (six of diamonds). Michael Jackson (king of hearts) engaged in behavior bizarre even for him. He defecated (two of clubs) on a salmon burger (king of clubs) and captured his flatulence (queen of clubs) in a balloon (six of spades). This tawdry tableau, which I'm not proud to commit to the page, goes a long way toward explaining the unexpected spot in which I found myself in the spring of 2006. Sitting to my left was Ram Kolli, an unshaven 25-year-old business consultant from Richmond, Va., who was also the defending United States memory champion. To my right was the lens of a television camera from a national cable network. Spread out behind me, where I couldn't see them and they couldn't disturb me, were about 100 spectators and a pair of TV commentators offering play-by-play analysis. One was a blow-dried mixed martial arts announcer named Kenny Rice, whose gravelly, bedtime voice couldn't conceal the fact that he seemed bewildered by this jamboree of nerds. The other was the Pelé of U.S. memory sport, a bearded 43-year-old chemical engineer and four-time national champion from Fayetteville, N.C., named Scott Hagwood. In the corner of the room sat the object of my affection: a kitschy, two-tiered trophy of a silver hand with gold nail polish brandishing a royal flush. It was almost as tall as my 2-year-old niece (if lighter than most of her stuffed animals). The audience was asked not to take any flash photographs and to maintain total silence. Not that Kolli or I could possibly have heard them. Both of us were wearing earplugs. I also had on a pair of industrial-strength earmuffs that looked as if they belonged to an aircraft-carrier deckhand (in the heat of a memory competition, there is no such thing as deaf enough). My eyes were closed. On a table in front of me, lying face down between my hands, were two shuffled decks of playing cards. In a moment, the chief arbiter would click a stopwatch, and I would have five minutes to memorize the order of both decks.

This is the view from the American outpost at Band-e Sardeh, in Ghazni Province. To the left is a large Soviet-built reservoir. Its pale green surface, at least near the dam beneath the road, is now frozen. The dam was built by the Soviet Union in the 1960s, during the Kremlin's long and frustrating period of Moscow-Kabul engagement. The American outpost today lies within the confines of what was once a much larger Soviet Army position astride a significant Kremlin public-works investment. Last fall, before air and water temperatures plummeted with the onset of the Afghan winter, the American soldiers here swam in the lake, no doubt just like their Soviet predecessors did.

At first, even second glance, Eric Cantona, 44, looks as if he could be minutes away from shedding his stylish street clothes and stepping back onto the soccer field without embarrassing himself. An enigmatic Frenchman, Cantona starred for Manchester United in the 1990s, retired at age 30 and left it all behind for a budding film career. He is back in the game for the first time in 14 years. Cantona has been named the director of soccer operations for the reborn New York Cosmos, a team that really is not a team -- yet -- but that hopes to become the 20th entry in Major League Soccer, perhaps as soon as the 2013 season. Cantona spoke with Jack Bell of The Times (who, as he took notes using an iPad and wireless keyboard, heard Cantona say that he felt "strange, like I'm talking to the police at the station") about his days at Old Trafford, his exploits on the silver screen and his expectations with the Cosmos.

When it comes to makeup, the runway often resembles a glamorous laboratory, where mad scientists (a k a makeup artists) cook up otherworldly or exaggerated looks that work well in photos but rarely make it to real life. The molten silver eye at Prada's spring show seemed exactly that - a hothouse exotic that wouldn't survive outside a fashion show. Not so, according to Pat McGrath, who created the look and also employed silver at Valentino and Galliano. "Metallics are unique, modern and chic," she says. "But most of all, they are completely wearable on every skin tone." For an evening out, she suggests using Laura Mercier's intense Foiled Eye Color in V.I.P. Silver on the lid, keeping the color centered, rather than extending up to the brow, and following with black liquid liner and mascara. For day, try Covergirl Smoky ShadowBlast in Silver Sky from the lash line to the browbone, and finish with two coats of mascara. Romy Soleimani, who created the liquid mercury look for this story, recommends a sheer wash of Make Up For Ever Aqua Cream No. 3 all over the lid and in the crease, followed by mascara. "Fill in your brow, do a beautiful pale pink lip, and you have a delicate version of the look," she says.

Are there enough categories in the Academy Awards race? Not according to Alice Rawsthorn, design columnist for The International Herald Tribune. She proposes an Oscar for the opening and closing credits and offers her own nominees for the most creative, or effective, of this movie season. Typography is important but not always paramount. Her standard is one set by Saul Bass, who worked on Hitchcock, Kubrick and Scorsese films among many others: Do the credits set the mood for the movie to come? As he said in a 1966 interview with Film Quarterly, "I saw the title as a way of conditioning the audience, so that when the film actually began, viewers would have an emotional resonance with it."

You've heard of high-tech start-ups being in "stealth mode," meaning they're not telling anyone what they're up to yet. It has a glamorous aura to it, conjuring up images of a brilliant project in the works that will soon be sprung upon the world, disrupting established players and leaving everyone scrambling to catch up. All smart companies with really great innovations keep those ideas hidden away until they're ready to release them, lest competitors steal them. Look at Apple, which has perfected the art of secretiveness, to enormous profit. You can tell people about your great idea -- but only if they sign one of those nondisclosure agreements you keep in your briefcase at all times. No exceptions!

A decade ago, two economists -- Stacy Dale and Alan Krueger -- published a research paper arguing that elite colleges did not seem to give most graduates an earnings boost. As you might expect, the paper received a ton of attention. Ms. Dale and Mr. Krueger have just finished a new version of the study -- with vastly more and better data, covering people into their 40s and 50s, as well as looking at a set of more recent college graduates -- and the new version comes to the same conclusion.

On Saturday the American Cinema Editors guild, considered a good harbinger of the best picture Oscar, announced its winners (known as the Eddies), and it was enough to cause - if we're going to keep going with this metaphor - a tempest in a teapot. The big prize went to Angus Wall and Kirk Baxter for "The Social Network" over "The King's Speech" (and over "Black Swan," "The Fighter" and "Inception"). In the comedy/musical category, "Alice in Wonderland" bested "The Kids Are All Right" and several other non-Oscar contenders, and "Exit Through the Gift Shop" won for documentary - an illustration of how well-liked it is as a film. Meanwhile pundits pounced on a victory for anything other than the projected favorite, "The King's Speech."

BARCELONA, Spain -- This week, tens of thousands of mobile technology executives, entrepreneurs and enthusiasts descended on this beautiful city to watch demonstrations of new software, get a close look at the latest phones and tablets and stop at a tapas bar or two. Amid the multitude of products and services introduced at the Mobile World Congress, several major themes threaded their way into many of the announcements and panels. I've emptied out my notebook and listed them below.

LOS ANGELES - Hollywood is a whisker away from naming Christopher J. Dodd as its new chief lobbyist. The Motion Picture Association of America is wrapping up the hiring of Mr. Dodd, the former Democratic senator from Connecticut, as its chairman, according to two people with knowledge of the matter who spoke on the condition of anonymity to avoid conflicts with the movie organization. Barring a last-minute snag, a contract announcement could come early this week, these people said.

The management of the debt-burdened Detroit Symphony Orchestra canceled the rest of its season on Saturday, after executives and the players failed to resolve a strike that has lasted four and a half months. Negotiations went on last week and included mediation by Senator Carl Levin of Michigan and Dan Gilbert, the owner of Quicken Loans. In a press release posted on its Web site, the orchestra's management said it had ''reluctantly released artists and conductors from their contracts and suspended all remaining orchestral concerts through June.''

Google and its YouTube division strongly outpaced all other video content properties in January. Top properties include Vevo, a music site, and Viacom, which has shows like ''SpongeBob SquarePants'' on Nickelodeon and ''The Game,'' with Tia Mowry and Pooch Hall, above, a BET sitcom. Turner Digital has teamed up with Sports Illustrated to present Nascar, P.G.A. and N.B.A. content, along with episodes from its TNT portfolio. CBS Interactive has a similar reach with sports, TV shows and news, and Break Media offers entertainment aimed at men. SHELLY FREIERMAN

MAYER--Donald Stewart, 78, died Saturday, February 19, at noon after a series of illnesses. Born in New York, the son of Ernst and Helen Mayer, he was a person with an extraordinary sense of humor. His absence will be most keenly felt by his family who loved and respected him as he loved and respected them. Those mourning their loss and celebrating his life are his wife of 49 years, Ylain; his children Sari and Brian; their spouses Jeffrey and Jane; and grandchildren Maya, Ellery, Emmett, Alyana and Annie. Services will be held 3:30pm, Tuesday at Cong Rodeph Sholom, 7 W. 83rd St., New York City. Memorial contributions to the Mayer Youth Leadership Fund of Rodeph Sholom or the charity of your choice.

RAPHAEL--Norma, 82, February 19, 2011. Survived by her beloved husband of 60 years, Paul; loving mother of Mark, Karen and Amy; proud grandmother of David, Tali, Daniel, Sara and Ian. Beautiful, strong, generous, and devoted to family and her many friends. She radiated warmth to all. Graveside service at King Solomon Cemetery in Clifton, NJ on Sunday 11:30. Donations to Planned Parenthood or UJA.

Rudolph R. Resta, 77, walked out of a wintry rain recently, through the revolving door of a largely empty Times Square office building, and into his distant past. He found his two sons, now in their 40s, when they were small enough to fit into the same lawn chair, side by side. He found his wife, Angela, posing before a knife-sharp Pontiac Grand Prix in Prospect Park, looking very sultry in a jaguar stole; ''real jaguar,'' he said, ''not the stuff they have today.'' He found a picture of his father, Nicola, that he once worried he would never see again. He found a Social Security card issued by the Federal Security Agency (the office hasn't existed since 1953) and an American Express card so old that it wasn't green, it was purple and white. (Member Since 64.)

James Levine, the music director of the Metropolitan Opera, withdrew from a matinee performance of ''Don Pasquale'' on Saturday because of illness, the house said. It was the third performance - including a concert at Carnegie Hall - that Mr. Levine has missed since Jan. 24. Successive health problems in recent years have caused the Met conductor to miss an unusual number of performances.

RUKIN--Michael. Hillel: The Foundation for Jewish Campus Life mourns the passing of our dear friend Michael Rukin. His commitment to Israel and to the Jewish people was inspiring. As chairman, Michael was an architect of Hillel's renaissance. May his memory be a blessing. Wayne L. Firestone, President, On behalf of the Boards of Governors and Directors.

9 P.M. (Lifetime) AMANDA KNOX: MURDER ON TRIAL IN ITALY (2011) Hayden Panettiere (''Heroes'') plays Ms. Knox, the Seattle student studying abroad who was convicted of sexually assaulting and murdering her roommate Meredith Kercher (Amanda Fernando Stevens), in Perugia, Italy, on Nov. 2, 2007, with her boyfriend Raffaele Sollecito (Paolo Romio) and an acquaintance, Rudy Guede (Djibril Kébé). Ms. Knox was sentenced to 26 years in prison; Mr. Sollecito to 25; and Mr. Guede to 30, which was reduced to 16 on appeal. Vincent Riotta plays Ms. Knox's Italian prosecutor, Guiliano Mignini; Marcia Gay Harden (above right, with Ms. Panettiere) is her mother, Edda Mellas. Ms. Knox and Mr. Sollecito are appealing their convictions. Their lawyers tried this month to block the showing of this movie. At 11 ''Beyond the Headlines: The Amanda Knox Story'' uses interviews with Ms. Knox's parents and friends, as well as investigators, prosecutors and legal scholars, to go inside the Italian legal system and piece together the details of what happened to Ms. Kercher, and what Ms. Knox's role might have been. 8 P.M. (Fox) HOUSE House (Hugh Laurie) breaches confidences when he shares detailed medical stories with students at a school career day. Later two fifth graders (Austin Michael Coleman and Haley Pullos) share their thoughts about House's relationship woes with Cuddy (Lisa Edelstein) and offer a solution. In ''The Chicago Code,'' at 9, Jarek (Jason Clarke) and Caleb (Matt Lauria) try to uncover a few vital facts about the bank robber they're pursuing.

BREGER--Edward E. The Hammerman family deeply mourns the passing of Eddie, a devoted friend, a most respected partner with whom we have had the privilege of sharing in many ventures. His ability and foresight made him to be recognized as an outstanding person in his field of endeavors. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his endearing and devoted wife Denise, his children David and Maxine, grandchildren and stepdaughter Cynthia. Eddie will be truly missed by all and his memory will live on forever. Lovingly, David & Sarah Hammerman

FRIEDMAN--Rita Yvette. The family of Rita Friedman mourns the passing of a woman who devoted her life and breath to the Jewish community. She will be sorely missed and remembered for her dynamic personality and her many accomplishments. The Molod Family

The New York Academy of Art, a graduate university that has been teaching figurative art since 1982, is not the kind of institution you would expect to get into trouble for mischief on Facebook. Yet the school recently received a stern warning from the site: ''You uploaded a photo that violates our Terms of Use, and this photo has been removed.'' The message went on to explain the kinds of things that Facebook does not allow: photos that attack a person or group, that depict drug use or contain violence or nudity. Facebook apparently had determined that an image the academy had uploaded to its Facebook page ran afoul of its ban on nudity. Yet the image -- an ink-on-paper drawing of a woman's naked upper body by Steven Assael -- was hardly racy. It was the kind of drawing you might see in galleries and museums the world over.

HOROWITZ--Milton, M.D. The members of The New York Psychoanalytic Society and Institute mourn the loss of our esteemed member, Milton Horowitz. He has been the model of a supervising and training analyst, teacher, mentor and colleague for more than 50 years. His renowned therapeutic talent has been built upon his brilliant intellect and his constant and sincere question, "How can I be of help?" He was a generous friend and had a funny and telling story for every occasion. The list of grateful patients and students is long. He will be missed. Philip Herschenfeld, M.D. Roger Rahtz, M.D. President Richard Weiss, M.D. Dean

Last year while writing about students entering their first year of college I made an interesting observation: these newly commissioned freshmen don't use wristwatches. In fact, the wristwatch is so alien to this group of late teens, that even the mere action of pointing to a wrist to ask someone the time is akin to speaking an unfamiliar foreign language. (They use mobile phones and laptops to tell the time.) Equipped with this knowledge, we could be led to believe that the wristwatch's time is almost up and that this piece of technology is destined for the same graveyard as vinyl records or the horse-drawn carriage.

RUKIN--Michael B. Beloved and cherished friend of thirty years. A graduate of CCNY School of Engineering, he turned his business success and acumen to helping others. A lover of Kol Israel, his leadership in philanthropic activities was appreciated at home and abroad. He was a highly respected, long-time client of Perelson Weiner LLP and will be missed by partners and staff. We grieve with his daughters and their families, his brother, cousins and friends of all ages. Ruth and Sam Perelson

RUKIN--Michael B. HIAS, the Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society, mourns the loss of its devoted Board member and immediate past Chair of the Board Michael B. Rukin. An early activist in the Soviet Jewry movement, Michael was dedicated to safeguarding Jewish communities worldwide and protecting the rights of refugees. His life and memory inspire us all. May his loving family be comforted among the mourners of Zion. Marc Silberberg, Chair Gideon Aronoff, President & CEO

BREGER--Edward E. "Eddie". The Parkoff Family and Richard Parkoff mourn the passing of a dear friend, mentor, partner and a true inspiration in our lives. There will never be enough words to console the family, the giant he was, and the true value that he provided not only for me and my family but for everyone that he touched. With deep regret and sadness we will mourn him for the rest of our lives. There will be a void that will never be able to be filled, maybe differently, but never the same. Lovingly, Richard and Debra Parkoff.

RICHENSTEIN--Elyse, of Key Biscayne, FL, formerly of Manhattan and Kings Point, New York, died peacefully on February 18, 2011. She is survived by her beloved husband, Victor, two loving sons, Lawrence and Kenneth, devoted family members, daughters-in-law, Mindy and Julie, and four grandchildren, Eric, Lisa, Marti, and Samantha. Elyse was born in Nurnberg, Germany, and survived Nazi persecution fleeing to Paris and later arriving in NY in her teens. An elegant, kind, and sunny woman loved by all who crossed her path, Elyse was a patron of the arts and devoted to her family, friends, and Judaism. A fund in Elyse's memory has been established at Chabad of Key Biscayne.

HOROWITZ--Milton H, M.D. 84, on February 19, after a long illness. Survived by Carla, his wife of 64 years, son James, daughter Emily, and grandson Arlo. After his family, Muff's greatest source of pleasure and satisfaction was the help he gave his patients in his long career as a psychoanalyst. A knowledgeable lover of music, art and literature, he was a warm and caring friend who will be greatly missed. Other survivors are his sister Elizabeth Dince, niece Nancy Dince Street, and nephews David and William Dince.

Just two years ago, President-elect Barack Obama staged the final leg of his pre-inaugural journey by boarding a train in Baltimore for a very public rally at the Amtrak station, followed by a leisurely rail journey to Washington, where the media and a large and exuberant crowd welcomed the future president and his wife. Preceding as it did Mr. Obama's "new birth of freedom" inauguration, billed as a tribute to his hero, Abraham Lincoln, there was little doubt that the carefully crafted trip from Baltimore was meant as a symbolic prelude. Lincoln, too, had traveled from Baltimore to Washington on the final sprint of his own so-called journey to greatness.

It's been said that the sun never sets on the British Empire - or at least not on the Burberry Prorsum live stream. But Scorecard knows the jury's still out on whether all of Christopher Bailey's nostalgic archive digging on the third day of London fashion week was his label's own.  Before a more intimate audience that included the brand ambassador Tilda Swinton, meanwhile, the creative director of another heritage house that has 41 years on Burberry's 155, Clare Waight Keller, enlisted the help of Central Saint Martins students to rethink Pringle of Scotland's iconic knits. That's one way to create from past and present a new warp and weft.
At a time of economic gloom, businesses and Britain’s government are hoping that the wedding of Prince William to Kate Middleton on April 29 will give the economy a lift.

There's a feeling of inevitability in writing about McDonald's latest offering, their "bowl full of wholesome" - also known as oatmeal. The leading fast-food multinational, with sales over $16.5 billion a year (just under the G.D.P. of Afghanistan), represents a great deal of what is wrong with American food today. From a marketing perspective, they can do almost nothing wrong; from a nutritional perspective, they can do almost nothing right, as the oatmeal fiasco demonstrates.

At first, even second, glance, Eric Cantona, 44, looks as if he could be minutes away from shedding his stylish street clothes and stepping back onto the soccer field without embarrassing himself. Cantona, the enigmatic Frenchman who starred for Manchester United in the 1990s, retired at age 30 and left it all behind for a budding film career, is back in the game for the first time in 14 years.

In my column this week, I mention that government employment and private sector employment have both fallen during the last two years. Over just the last year, private employment has risen -- though more slowly than the population has been growing -- while government employment has continued falling. These numbers make clear that a surge of government hiring can't be the economy's problem right now -- because there has been no surge.

Don't say we didn't warn you. The bold patterns and prints that cropped up in the pre-fall collections have materialized into a full-blown trend for fall. From the pastoral landscape prints at Rodarte to the techno Navajo patterns at Proenza Schouler (with checks and florals and tartans from the likes of Thakoon, Suno, Gregory Parkinson and Preen in between), there is no blending in with the crowd. Of course, anyone who would like to try her hand with the trend right away can grab this tribal-inspired clutch ($735, center) from the Marni spring collection. Just the thing to carry you clear through to September.

Gentlemen, get out your plastic and get ready to spend till you bend: Mr. Porter, the male counterpoint to Net-a-Porter, the high-end fashion e-tailer, is finally live after more than a little hype over the past few months. Aimed at men who want to purchase clothes, accessories and other dapper goods online, Mr. Porter is a stand-alone destination, not an add-on to its sister site. "We started from scratch," said Natalie Massenet, the founder of Net-a-Porter. "We didn't want to simply include a men's tab on Net-a-Porter." Massenet hired the former British Esquire editor Jeremy Langmead and a team of experienced men's-wear editors to tailor the editorial content (style advice, guides and portfolios of non-models like the poet Nick Laird, above) for an audience that is generally held to be more interested in connoisseurship than in passing fads. Not surprisingly, the site will carry classic establishment brands like Ralph Lauren and Dunhill as well as harder-to-find heritage labels like Lock & Co. and Swayne Adeney Brigg. Its handsome black and white packaging will ship to 170 countries, proving that for stylish men, even e-commerce is all about the details.
