A set of important murals depicting events in African-American history will be restored and sent on tour for the first time through a collaboration of Talladega College in Alabama, which owns the murals, and the High Museum of Art in Atlanta. In 1938 Talladega, one of the country's oldest all-black colleges, commissioned Hale Aspacio Woodruff, an African-American artist who had studied with Diego Rivera, to create the murals for the lobby of its new library. Comprising six canvases, the murals depict events like the uprising on the slave ship La Amistad, scenes from the Underground Railroad and the founding of the college. At the High, the murals will be cleaned and restretched, Philip Verre, the museum's chief operating officer, said in a phone interview. They will go on view in an exhibition opening in Atlanta on June 2, 2012, and will travel later to the Indianapolis Museum of Art. Woodruff, who taught art at New York University for more than 20 years, died in 1980. He had a retrospective at the Studio Museum in Harlem in 1979 and an exhibition at the High Museum, focused on his paintings in Atlanta, in 2004.

For the second installment of our celebrity Oscar ballot and questionnaire, we're allowing a little bias. Kristen Schaal, best known as the ardent fan Mel on the HBO series "Flight of the Conchords" and as a correspondent on "The Daily Show With Jon Stewart," voices Trixie the triceratops in "Toy Story 3," an Oscar nominee this year. She also stars as Louise in the new animated series Bob's Burgers on Fox, and is the author, with Rich Blomquist, a "Daily Show" writer who also happens to be her boyfriend, of "The Sexy Book of Sex Sex." Ms. Schaal, who is not (we repeat, not an Academy member), is also a longtime pal of the Bagger's. We spoke to her about her Oscar choices in an interview conducted in the most informal way possible, over Instant Message.

A former photo assistant of Richard Burbridge, Michael Hauptman has been taking pictures and living in New York City for the past five years. This week Hauptman, whose photographs have appeared in T and the Japanese cult magazine Untitled, releases his first book, "Notes on, Something Like Life Should Be." Published by the Williamsburg, Brooklyn-based AndPress, it's a personal portrait of Hauptman's relationships over the years. The Moment caught up with Hauptman to ask him about his peccadilloes and his favorite haunts in his adopted city.

The long-running musical "The Lion King" is the first show to hit No. 1 in Broadway's weekly box office grosses so late in the life of its run, earning $1,534,779 last week to edge out its closest competitors, "Wicked" and "Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark." One likely factor was Disney Theatrical Productions' decision to shift the show's usual Tuesday evening performance to Monday evening, Feb. 14, to capitalize on date nights for Valentine's Day.

Ann Bonfoey Taylor, born in 1910, was a paragon of midcentury grace and timeless gumption. She was invited to ski in the 1940 Olympics, but then World War II spoiled the games, so she became a flight instructor. (Yes, she was also a licensed pilot.) Taylor went on to join the jet set, ride dressage, hunt fox, marry a man known as Moose, design kooky ski wear and build one of the first residences in Vail, Colo., before dying in 2007 at the age of 96. (She's unrelated to the retail chain Ann Taylor, which takes its name from a best-selling dress.) "Fashion Independent" ($60), a catalog from a show of the same name at the Phoenix Art Museum, evokes Taylor's indefatigable style.

Researchers from the National Institutes of Health have found that less than an hour of cellphone use can speed up brain activity in the area closest to the phone antenna, raising new questions about the health effects of low levels of radiation emitted from cellphones.

The American Folk Art Museum, which is facing serious financial problems, is nonetheless embarking an ambitious project: an exhibition of African-American self-taught and graffiti artists to take place in Venice during the Biennale there. The exhibition will open June 1 at the Fondaco dei Tedeschi, a building owned by the Benetton Group that may ultimately become a Rem Koolhaas-designed retail and exhibition space. Benetton is offering the building to the museum for free, as well as providing advertising and art materials and holding the opening-night party. The museum's director, Maria Ann Conelli, said that the budget for the one-month exhibition was between $300,000 and $400,000 and that the museum was reaching out to foundations and corporations for financing. Since January, the museum has been unable to make payments on the roughly $30 million it owes against its building on West 53rd Street. Last summer, it entered into a forbearance agreement with the company that insured its debt, ACA Financial Guaranty. That agreement expires on June 30. According to the most recent available financial statements, in the fiscal year that ended June 30, 2010, the museum ran a deficit from unrestricted activities of $3.6 million. Ms. Conelli said that the museum had a balanced budget for this year.

President Obama met with small-business owners in Cleveland on Tuesday, saying he'd come not to talk but to listen. At one session, one local businessman, Phillip Davis, told Mr. Obama that he was having trouble getting access to capital to help him meet demand for sales of microwaves in Europe. He urged Mr. Obama to change tax policy to allow people to invest in small businesses without having to pay capital gains tax. "That is such a good idea," Mr. Obama responded, smiling, "that we implemented it last year." Then, he added, presumably for the benefit of reporters in the room, "this was not a setup."

In the past half-century, Mets fans have plenty of reasons to cry, including Marv Throneberry, Tom Seaver's departure and the team's epic collapse in 2007. To survive, many fans have learned to laugh about the team's foibles.

Overview | Where in the Arab world have protests sprung up? Why? What is happening? Who is involved? When, why and how did these movements begin, and how have the various governments responded to citizen protests? In this lesson, students find out basic information about the upheaval that has spread across the Arab world so that they can understand the background and the events and continue to follow the events as informed news consumers.

Deformities in frogs in the northeastern United States are far more common in suburban and urban areas, not in and around farmlands, a Yale ecologist's research shows. The findings upend the conventional wisdom that agricultural pesticides are largely responsible for the abnormalities. Rather, the combination of many household chemicals, including pharmaceuticals and plastics that mimic hormones, appear to be the root cause. [Yale Environment 360]

I mentioned in a recent post that students who choose to attend a historically black college instead of a more selective college may be hurting their future earnings prospects. There's more evidence for this finding than I knew. A 2007 study, by Roland Fryer and Michael Greenstone, came to a similar conclusion.

Mark Seliger's collection of nudes, portraits and landscapes is just about the handsomest book of photographs to be published in a while. Every detail of "Listen," from the quality of the binding and endpapers to the selection and reproduction of the platinum-plated prints, is a book-lover's treat. Mr. Seliger is such a believer. And he has put together a book, with Rizzoli, that sharpens the senses for the silent and seemingly insignificant. He is well known for his portraits of actors and musicians and his fashion work for magazines, among them Vanity Fair and Italian Vogue. "Listen" displays a natural feeling for things that hover between ordinary and monumental, sad and self-renewing. You can catch his show of photographs from "Listen" at the Steven Kasher Gallery in Chelsea; it closes on Saturday. Here's an excerpt from our recent conversation.

After months of insufferable rumor after insufferable rumor, Carmelo Anthony is finally set to be a Knick. But Anthony is not the only likely inbound Nugget; Chauncey Billups will take over the outgoing Raymond Felton's job as starting point guard, and three role players - Shelden Williams, Anthony Carter and Renaldo Balkman - could help fill in minutes at the bottom of Coach Mike D'Antoni's rotation. This is obviously a substantial deal for New York, as D'Antoni will have to integrate two major contributors on the fly while also dealing with the losses of Felton, Danilo Gallinari, Wilson Chandler  and Timofey Mozgov. That's a substantial portion of the Knicks lineup that is headed to Denver, and trading away so many foundational players makes the process of incorporating Anthony, Billups, et al., even more difficult.

The death last week of John Strauss, composer of the theme song to "Car 54, Where Are You?" put the tune in heavy rotation on the playlist in our brains all weekend. And it got us thinking: What are some other super-catchy New York television themes? Here, again by the miracle of YouTube, is the theme from "The 4:30 Movie," which ran for many years on Channel 7. Movies were either divided in half, with lots of commercials, to stretch across two hour-and-a-half slots on successive afternoons, or cut to ribbons to fit into one. MAYER--Donald Stewart, 78, died Saturday, February 19, at noon after a series of illnesses. Born in New York, the son of Ernst and Helen Mayer, he was a person with an extraordinary sense of humor. His absence will be most keenly felt by his family who loved and respected him as he loved and respected them. Those mourning their loss and celebrating his life are his wife of 49 years, Ylain; his children Sari and Brian; their spouses Jeffrey and Jane; and grandchildren Maya, Ellery, Emmett, Alyana and Annie. Services will be held 3:30pm, Tuesday at Cong Rodeph Sholom, 7 W. 83rd St., New York City. Memorial contributions to the Mayer Youth Leadership Fund of Rodeph Sholom or the charity of your choice.

With the global markets on the mend last fall, a private equity consortium moved to sell its 93 percent stake in the Egyptian drug maker Amoun Pharmaceutical. In January, the consortium of American investors, including a Citigroup fund, seemed hopeful they could sign a deal for $1 billion, more than triple what they paid in 2006. But as student protests in the country turned to revolutionary upheaval, buyers never materialized. Now, the deal is up in the air, a person with knowledge of the situation told DealBook, speaking only on the condition of anonymity.

CUNNINGHAM--Joseph N.,Jr. The Trustees, physicians, nurses, staff and volunteers of Maimonides Medical Center mourn the sudden loss of Joseph N. Cunningham, Jr. Dr. Cunningham was a friend, esteemed colleague, mentor and teacher to all of us. Joe came to Maimonides from NYU in 1982, bringing with him a new level of clinical excellence and advanced surgical techniques. In his nearly three decades as Chair of the Department of Surgery, he created a high level and renowned cardiac and general surgical program. He recruited leading surgeons from around the country, initiated important clinical research and trained generations of new surgical leaders. Most recently, Dr. Cunningham served as our Senior Vice President of Strategic Initiatives. Joe was a dynamic leader, forward thinking physician and warm and compassionate man. He will be deeply missed by the many people whose lives he touched. Martin D. Payson, Chairman of the Board Pamela S. Brier, President and CEO

The It Gets Better Project, an online video campaign to cheer up gay teenagers who have been victims of bullies, has joined with the stars of the new Broadway musical ''Priscilla Queen of the Desert'' to produce the project's first public service announcement, which will begin airing on Tuesday on the CBS affiliate in the New York region. In the 30-second spot, the actors Nick Adams, Tony Sheldon, and Will Swenson take turns offering encouraging words - ''All the greats were ahead of their time,'' Mr. Sheldon says - and urging viewers to sign on to a pledge on the project's the website. The pledge asks people to spread the message that ''everyone deserves to be respected for who they are'' and promise to ''speak up against hate and intolerance whenever I see it, at school and at work.''

Mouse researchers conducting stress hormone experiments have stumbled onto a surprising new discovery -- a potential treatment for hair loss. Scientists at the University of California, Los Angeles, and the Veterans Administration were working with genetically altered mice that typically develop head-to-tail baldness as a result of overproducing a stress hormone.

The producers of the Broadway musical ''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark'' have brought on a veteran musical supervisor and conductor, Paul Bogaev, as a consultant to help improve the performance, vocal and orchestration arrangements, and sound quality of the songs and numbers, a production spokesman, Rick Miramontez, confirmed on Monday. The hire comes amid growing expectation among ''Spider-Man'' cast and crew members that the show's official opening, now set for March 15, will be delayed for a sixth time - perhaps for a significant period of time - to undertake a significant revamping of the $65 million show, which drew near-universal condemnation from theater critics in reviews this month. The show began preview performances on Nov. 28 and has already had one of the longest preview periods in Broadway history (hence the critics' early reviews), although it never had the usual out-of-town tryout first.

NATIONAL An article on Sunday about Gov. Scott Walker, who has set off a storm of protest in Wisconsin and around the country with a proposal that would limit collective bargaining rights and benefits for public workers, gave an incorrect given name in some editions for one of 14 Democratic state senators who fled the state last week to block a vote on Mr. Walker's proposal. He is Chris Larson, not Scott.

The investment round also included DST Global, the Russian investment firm that has also taken big stakes in Facebook and Groupon.

LIBYA Forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi struck back at protesters in Tripoli, the capital, with security forces and militiamen backed by helicopters and warplanes besieging parts of the city. Some senior officials and diplomats broke with Mr. Qaddafi's government and Libya's second largest city, Benghazi, remained under the control of protesters. EGYPT Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain held talks with government and military leaders in Cairo, making him the highest-ranking foreign leader to visit Egypt since President Hosni Mubarak resigned Feb. 11. In addition, the country's top prosecutor said he would request that the Foreign Ministry ask governments to freeze assets of Mr. Mubarak, his family and a handful of senior associates.

WEISER--Ruth, 90, died early Sunday morning in her Florida home after a series of illnesses. Born and raised in NYC she was the wife and "campaign manager" for her beloved late husband Joseph, who was an assemblyman for many years. She is survived by her two loving daughters, Susan Finley and Wendy Chayet, her son Stanley, her grandchildren Dashiell, Cara, Jackie and Casey. Those who would like to join the family to celebrate her long life are welcome to attend services Wednesday 1pm at "The Riverside" 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. Donations may be made to NYC Hadassah or Parkinson's Association.

BHP Billiton said on Monday afternoon that it would buy Chesapeake Energy's shale-based natural gas assets in northern Arkansas for $4.75 billion. The deal is the first by the Anglo-Australian giant following its failed effort to buy the Potash Corporation of Saskatchewan last year. The company previously stumbled in its efforts to acquire Rio Tinto, and then form a joint venture with its rival in recent years.

Dynegy, the embattled power company, said late on Monday that its top management team, including its chief executive, plan to resign, as the company failed in its second attempt to sell itself amid strong shareholder opposition. Bruce A. Williamson will step down as the company's chairman immediately, and will resign as chief executive on March 11. Holli C. Nichols will also resign as chief financial officer then. Dynegy named interim replacements for the two, drawn from the company's board.

An early activist in the Soviet Jewry movement, Michael was dedicated to safeguarding Jewish communities worldwide and protecting the rights of refugees. His life and memory inspire us all. May his loving family be comforted among the mourners of Zion. Marc Silberberg, Chair Gideon Aronoff, President & CEO

Bob Diamond has spent nearly his entire adult life curating the Atlantic Avenue train tunnel in Downtown Brooklyn, an abandoned 19th-century rail line that once ran beneath Atlantic Avenue between Court and Hicks Streets. Mr. Diamond, 51, located the tunnel as a teenager and got the city to let him go down a manhole while wearing tennis shorts and an oxygen tank and smash through a concrete wall to break into the long-forgotten cavern. In the following years and decades, he gradually expanded his access to the space, obtaining city permits to bring large tour groups in. He formed a nonprofit group to collect voluntary admission fees, to put toward improvements, a tour staff and other expenses.

SENOR--Gabriel E.,87, passed away on February 17, 2011 peacefully in Mission Viejo, CA formerly of Ardsley, NY. Born in 1924 in New York City. Humanity's musical treasures -- Beethoven piano sonatas, Schubert songs, Mozart symphonies and the like -- come to life in performance. But they truly survive as black marks on a page, otherwise known as scores. Now a Web site founded five years ago by a conservatory student, then 19 years old, has made a vast expanse of this repertory available, free. The site, the Internet Music Score Library Project, has trod in the footsteps of Google Books and Project Gutenberg and grown to be one of the largest sources of scores anywhere. It claims to have 85,000 scores, or parts for nearly 35,000 works, with several thousand being added every month. That is a worrisome pace for traditional music publishers, whose bread and butter comes from renting and selling scores in expensive editions backed by the latest scholarship. More than a business threat, the site has raised messy copyright issues and drawn the ire of established publishers.

Egypt has reopened many of its museums and historical sites, which were hit by sporadic looting during the uprising that led to President Hosni Mubarak's ouster, Reuters reported. On Sunday, the Egyptian Museum in Cairo, which is just off Tahrir Square and which served as an embattled backdrop during the protests, opened its doors again, and museum workers handed roses to the few visitors who came to see its treasures. The galleries of the museum, which are usually bustling, were nearly empty throughout the day, however, as tourism continues to suffer in the wake of the unrest, Reuters added.

Whether or not you agree that comedy is a male-dominated field, it is hardly an industry with a male-to-female ratio of 30-to-1. Yet that was the gender breakdown on the initial lineup of performers announced for SXSW Comedy, a long-running component of the annual South by Southwest festival in Austin. Of the 31 comedians in this year's lineup, including notable funnymen like Michael Ian Black, Thomas Lennon, Donald Glover and John Oliver, only one - Tig Notaro - is a woman. After an outcry from comedy fans around the Web, the festival's organizers have explained that they too are aware of the disparity. In a statementreported by the comedy Web site Splitsider.com, the organizers said that while their comedy lineup was not necessarily complete, ''we were disappointed by the fact that we could only include one woman in our initial release.''

McGRATH--Christopher Columbus Jr.,entered into eternal life on February 18, 2011 at the age of 74. Chris was a loving and dedicated husband, father, grandfather, brother, and uncle. He is survived by his wife, Jayne; his five children and their spouses, Christopher Columbus III (Beth), Patrick (Christine), Siobhan, Matthew (Michael), and Luke (Viviana); his grandchildren, Christopher James, Aidan, Grace, Bridget, Rory, Leah and Coco; his siblings, Michael, Terence, Kevin, and Kathleen "Muffin"; and a large loving extended family. Christopher is pre-deceased by his parents, the Honorable Christopher Columbus McGrath Sr. and Helen Gaffney McGrath, and his sister Mary Ann. Chris was a triple Ram; he graduated from Fordham Prep, received his B.A. from Fordham University, and then acquired his J.D. from Fordham School of Law. Upon finishing his studies, he served as Associate Council to the Cuban Families Relief Committee; being instrumental in the negotiated release of more than 300 prisoners being held by the Cuban Government. Chris was then campaign assistant to Senator Robert F. Kennedy, campaign scheduler for Governor Hugh L. Carey, and Deputy Borough President of Manhattan. Leaving the job of Executive Director of the N.Y. State Petroleum Council, Chris founded New York Capitol Consultants. Along with loyally servicing his clients, he also served as Executive Director for The New York, New Jersey, Massachusetts, Rhode Island, and Vermont State Associations. Family will receive friends at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street on Wednesday 2-5 and 7-9pm. A mass of Christian Burial will be held at the Fordham University Chapel, Bronx NY on Thursday at 10:15am. Burial will be held at Greenwood Union Cemetery, Rye, NY. A reception will follow at Manursing Island Club. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in Christopher's memory to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Pediatric Cancer Research, Hagerstown, Maryland 21741.

As a medical student 20 years ago, I learned all about anatomy, physiology and pharmacology. My professors also taught me, implicitly, how to put on the white doctor coat as a shield against human vulnerability. With the coat on, you could get right up close to frailty, even touch it, and it wouldn't be able to reach out and pull you in. Residency training, with its harsh hours and unrelenting pace, added several more layers of protective shellac. But in all those years I didn't have one class on how to be a patient, never mind how to be the spouse of one.

GAMBY--Vera, 95, died at home on February 20th surrounded by her close-knit family, including her husband of 74 years, her identical twin, her three children, their spouses and her devoted caretaker. Born in Frankfurt, Germany she moved to Hamburg as a child. She later escaped the Holocaust, arriving in New York in December 1939 with her husband, parents and young son. Unassuming, gracious and a gifted painter, she had a heartwarming smile, enduring strength and was immediately loved by all she met. She is survived by her loving husband Werner, son Peter (Julie) Gamby , daughters Dorothy (Ira) Kovel and Monica (Lee) Evslin, twin sister Ilse Lane, and was the proud grandmother of Kimberly, Andrea, Jeffrey, Tanya, Noah, Nathaniel and Luke and the playful great-grandmother to Nicolas, Jackson, Zeke, Lola, Max, Violet and Isaac. She gave us all so much and will live in our hearts forever. Funeral service today 12 noon at Beth El Synagogue in New Rochelle. Interment to follow at Mt. Eden Cemetery.

BURROUGHS: A MAN WITHIN ''Death smells,'' Burroughs, left, says, reading an excerpt from his novel ''Cities of the Red Night,'' just one of the many film clips and interviews used by Yony Leyser to create a portrait of this Beat author of ''Naked Lunch.'' ''There is not a word or image wasted in a documentary you wish ran an extra half-hour beyond its condensed 90 minutes,'' Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times. He called the film ''a kind of genealogy of hip that connects Burroughs, who was born in St. Louis in 1914, a wealthy Harvard-educated grandson of the founder of the Burroughs Adding Machine company, with many currents of America's outlaw cultural tradition'': among them, Allen Ginsberg, the Clash, Iggy Pop, Sonic Youth and Patti Smith. The film, an ''Independent Lens'' presentation, also touches on family tragedy: the death of Burroughs's wife Joan Vollmer, whom he accidentally shot in the head while playing a drunken game of William Tell in Mexico in 1951, and the death of his son, Billy Burroughs, who died of acute alcoholism in 1981. His friend John Giorno, the poet, says that it was the only time he ever saw Burroughs weep. 8 P.M. Histories of mid-19th century America tend to separate its two most important threads: a war over slavery engulfs the East, while mineral rushes transform the West. But while these developments are geographically distinct, they could not be more interdependent. At its heart, the political crisis that led to the Civil War was fought over the extension of slavery into the West, and it was the subsequent implosion of the Union that enabled the Northern, Republican-controlled Congress to create these western territories.

Since losing my job I've struggled with countless questions for which I have no suitable response: Is it healthy for my family to subsist on a diet entirely of packaged ramen, canned beans and grocery-store samples, and if so, must it be certified organic? Does baby really need a new pair of shoes? If I'm so smart how come I'm so broke? The worst question, though, and the one most likely to induce paroxysms of guilt, irritation and half-joking existential despair, is one that seems so simple to answer, but has proven the most vexing: if I'm not working, why don't I have more time? Shouldn't a jobless fellow like myself be free to relax, clean house, run errands for my fiancée Tomoko and, most important, spend time with my children, J.P., 4-years-old, and Ellie, the baby?

Justin Bieber, Lady Gaga, Mumford & Sons and Lady Antebellum all got big "Grammy lifts" - the typical boost in record sales after the awards show. But who had the biggest lift depends on how you look at the numbers. Mr. Bieber, who did not win any awards but who had a prominent performing slot at the ceremony, dominates this week's Billboard album chart. "Never Say Never: The Remixes" (Island), the soundtrack to his new 3-D concert film, opened at No. 1 with 161,000 copies sold. But just as impressive, he has three other albums in the Top 40: "My World 2.0" is No. 8, "My Worlds Acoustic" is No. 18, and "My World," the mini-album that was his debut, is No. 31. Billboard said Mr. Bieber was the first artist to pull off that feat since Garth Brooks in 1993. The British alt-folk band Mumford & Sons and Lady Antebellum, the country-pop trio that went home with the most Grammy awards (five, including record and song of the year), also had good runs on the album chart. Mumford & Sons' "Sigh No More" (Glassnote) holds at No. 2 this week. Its rise to No. 2 from No. 11 last week was largely based on impulse buys made during the Grammys telecast, on which the group performed with Bob Dylan, with 133,000 sales, a 169 percent increase from the week before. Lady Antebellum's "Need You Now" (Capitol Nashville) is No. 4, with 85,000 sales, a 205 percent gain. (No. 3 this week goes to Vol. 37 of the series "Now That's What I Call Music!," which sold 95,000.) In terms of digital downloads, however, Lady Gaga and Cee Lo Green came out way ahead. "Born This Way," which Lady Gaga performed at the awards, sold 509,000 copies in its first full week on sale, bringing its total sales in the United States - in just 10 days - to 957,000. And sales of Cee Lo's "____ You" jumped 178 percent, to 412,000.

The Van Horn Sandwich Shop, which combines Southern fried fare with an industrial chic aesthetic, opened recently in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn. Jacob Van Horn, an architect who grew up in Chapel Hill, N.C., but has spent the last four years living in Brooklyn, conceived of the restaurant last year after getting laid off from Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, an architectural and engineering firm. He hired the chef Rick Hauchman (of Roberta's Pizza in Bushwick and The Commodore), a friend and fellow North Carolinian, to run the kitchen, and spent about four months hunting for the right space. In July, he found it at 231 Court Street, falling in love with its unobstructed view down leafy Baltic Street.

In Vancouver, street food is an emerging mini-industry. But new vendors who want to sell hot dogs and cheese steak sandwiches may need to switch to healthier options. A controversial city council decision made last month requires vendors seeking licenses to conform to a range of new rules, which emphasize healthier fare; organic, local and fair-trade foods; and an increased diversity of options.

Though London Fashion Week's endearingly creative reputation rests on its relentless embrace of the new, Pringle of Scotland's collaboration with the M.F.A. students at Central St. Martins, which was unveiled earlier this week, looks to the past. The 196-year-old cashmere purveyor - it's often credited with inventing the twin set - threw open its archives in Hawick, Scotland, last summer to the design school's students, who first catalogued them, then mined them for inspiration. The result is a woolly mashup that mixes 1950s argyles with a postmodern sensibility - in other words, perfect for fall's emerging grunge-meets-prim trend.

Before I pop over to Versace to have coffee with Donatella, let me dash off a few words about the Gucci show. It will only take a few moments, so comprehensibly '70s were Frida Giannini's fur-covered shoulders, tie-at-the-neck blouses and chic gaucho trousers in flannel or suede with boots or platforms. The palette was all violet, wine, rust, emerald green, teal and a bit of cherry. Ms. Giannini also offered those lady-ish full-sleeved dresses with tiny belts that figure so prominently in memories and archives of the '70s, along with fedoras and feathers. Her press notes referred to Helmut Newton and Bob Richardson's fashion photographs of Anjelica Huston, his girlfriend at the time, who practically lives on every designer's mood board. The silhouette is certainly one for the ages - Marc Jacobs made a pass for spring - but it hardly lifts the old skirts.

Viewers of Univision, the Spanish-language network, know Raúl de Molina, a veteran journalist, as El Gordo. Mr. de Molina is also a contributor to The Huffington Post, where he writes about food and health, and an inveterate world traveler (even though he was almost mauled by lions while on safari last year). He filled out our Oscar ballot, and when the Bagger spoke with him from his home in Miami, he wasted no time in sharing his picks.

Today, at the opening of the Design Indaba conference in Cape Town, South Africa, the designer Dror Benshetrit of Studio Dror unveiled QuaDror, a space truss geometry that he invented and patented. Although the words "space truss geometry" may not sound sexy at first, QuaDror's potential is impressive: its interlocking, load-bearing members function at several scales, from the small (a table base or room divider) to the large (a bridge support or structure for a house). When used in multiples, these forms are not only as stable as a solid cube (while using only 20 percent of the volume), but also have acoustical properties, as in a highway sound barrier. But the application about which Dror is most excited is that of emergency housing. The QuaDror Home is a kit that includes instructions, tools and QuaDror universal joints - to which structural members (of wood, bamboo, etc.) can be attached. Because these pieces take up so little room, Dror estimates that 1,750 of the kits can be shipped in a single 40-foot container. Small, sturdy houses can be built with whatever local materials are available, making them even more cost-effective, not to mention sustainable. The first QuaDror Home kit is just beginning production, and the studio hopes to build its first houses in Sierra Leone and Brazil next year.

A lecture by the Nigerian author and Nobel Prize winner Wole Soyinka, readings by Wallace Shawn and Malcolm Gladwell, a debate on the prison industry and an evening on the topic of sex led by Edmund White are among the offerings at this year's PEN World Voices Festival of International Literature, which will take place from April 25 to May 1 in New York. Other events in the festival, which is put on by the PEN American Center, include a discussion of cultural and political conditions in China featuring the New Yorker contributor Jianying Zha; a night with the storytelling group the Moth, on the theme of "What's Gone Wrong"; a celebration of poetry, curated by Laurie Anderson and featuring Antony and the Johnsons; and a game of telephone in which a Tibetan lama will pass along sutras down a list of 200 festival attendees, ending with Salman Rushdie, who will Tweet the result. The festival, which is being organized by the former Hungarian Cultural Center director Laszlo Jakab Orsos, will be based out of the Standard Hotel, with events taking place at the New York Public Library, Cooper Union, the 92nd Street Y and elsewhere. Mr. White's sex event, which, according to a news release, will feature "celebrated members" of the fashion and music worlds, will take place in the Standard's rooftop bar, Le Bain (French for "the bath").

A compact man in a buttoned-up, collared shirt was standing outside a faded but grand turn-of-the-century building in a neighborhood in West Berlin, looking rather confused. Suddenly, he was buzzed in and told to take an ancient elevator to the fourth floor. A mysterious blonde woman with a Mona Lisa smile and a glass of Champagne in her hand greeted him at the door of an expansive Berlin-style apartment. "Welcome to Salon K," she said as she led him into a large room with wood parquet floors and impossibly high ceilings. It was bare except for pillows and futon-style seating around the edges and an arrangement of candles that glowed in the center.

SULZBERGER--Judith P. The Board of Trustees and staff of the Wildlife Conservation Society mourn the loss of our friend and compatriot Dr. Judith Sulzberger, who inspired us with her dedication to health and science and her commitment to making the world a better place. As a longstanding benefactor, Dr. Sulzberger's passion and support for wildlife health and its links to human health played a pivotal role in establishing a successful WCS global wildlife health program. She was a great advocate and will be missed. Our deepest sympathies go to her family and friends. Ward W. Woods, Chair, Board of Trustees Steven E. Sanderson, President and CEO Wildlife Conservation Society

GOTTESMAN--Dov. The America-Israel Cultural Foundation is deeply saddened by the loss of our longtime friend, Mr. Dov Gottesman and grieves with his beloved wife, Mrs. Rachel Gottesman, children and grandchildren. Together, they have a long history of supporting Israeli culture and nurturing young artists on a personal level. Mr. Gottesman's passion for Israel and her artists helped thousands. The European Central Bank criticized political leaders Tuesday on the grounds of moving too timidly against countries whose excessive spending and borrowing had endangered the stability of the euro. In its first official comment on the European Commission's proposals to better enforce rules on spending and debt, the bank's governing council said there were too many escape clauses for nations using the euro.

HUGHES--Olga M.,lost her eight-month battle with cancer on Wednesday, February 16, 2011. Olga leaves behind her son Mark, daughter-in-law, Amy Johnston, and grandchildren Tessa, Benjamin, and Elizabeth.

FOSTER--Diana Worth, 67, beloved mother, grandmother, sister, and friend died Sunday, February 20, 2011 after a brave and determined battle with leukemia. Born in Rochester, NY on May 24, 1943 and raised in Raleigh, NC she was the daughter of the late Thomas Clarkson Worth and Barbara Luther Worth. She is survived by her children Alison Foster Reining (Michael) of Midlothian, VA and Archibald M. Foster III (GiGi) of Locust Valley, NY; grandchildren Hailey, Charlotte, and Andrew Reining, and Trilby Foster; and four brothers. Mrs. Foster touched many lives while pursuing her multiple passions including the culinary arts, art history, travel and theatre. While a southerner until the end, she drank in the culture and energy of the City and was truly a New Yorker at heart. The Metropolitan Museum of Art was a happy thread woven into her life for over 36 years. After joining the weekend volunteers answering questions at the front desk, her passion grew and that task evolved into giving tours of American paintings and sculpture, French and English decorative arts, finally coming to rest on the Impressionists. Hers was a tour not to be missed. She recently mentioned that her years as a docent at the Met "enriched my brain but, most of all, enriched my soul." A new chapter in her life threw open doors to fresh adventures (including a trip to Hudson Bay to observe polar bears), a number of dear new friends, and a long career in development at the Japan Society. Her many years there instilled in her an appreciation of Eastern tradition and a deep love of Japanese culture. Her shorter career as the director of development at St. Vincent's hospital gave her other, very different insights as well as an appreciation of the sacrifices men and women make to care for the indigent. The family will welcome friends on the evening of Thursday, February 24 from 5:00pm to 8:00 pm at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home on 81st and Madison. A memorial service for Mrs. Foster will be held at The Brick Church on 92nd and Park, Friday, February 25 at 3:00pm.

Will Arena Stage's revival of ''Oklahoma!'' make it to Broadway? In an unusual move, the Arena, a Washington theater, announced on Tuesday that it will resume performances of ''Oklahoma!'' on July 8 at its in-the-round Fichandler Stage, more than six months after the critical hit closed in December. The reprise is scheduled to run through Oct. 9. Directed by the Arena artistic director, Molly Smith, ''Oklahoma!'' opened in November to strong reviews and went on to smash several box-office records for that 60-year-old theater company. Yet the show closed less than two months later because of previous commitments by the actors and Arena's subscription schedule of productions.

DEAL CRITICIZED Institutional Shareholder Services, the proxy adviser, weighed in against the leveraged buyout of J. Crew in a report on Tuesday. Chief among its complaints is that the bid undervalues the retailer relative to its competitors. I.S.S. also pointed to a much criticized part of the J. Crew deal: the seven weeks that the company's chairman and chief executive, Millard S. Drexler, above, waited before he informed the board about the buyout interest. MICHAEL J. de la MERCED

CUNNINGHAM--Joseph N.,Jr. The Division of Cardiology at Maimonides Medical Center mourns the passing of Dr. Joseph Cunningham. Dr. Cunningham, the long time Chairman of the Department of Surgery and a renowned cardiothoracic surgeon, touched the hearts and changed the lives of thousands of patients and colleagues. Joe had endless charm and charisma and was loved by patients and staff alike. His presence will be deeply missed. Our sincere condolences to the entire Cunningham Family. Jacob Shani, M.D. Director Division of Cardiology and The Division of Cardiology at Maimonides Medical Center

FARRO--Eugene F. of Sands Point, NY passed away on February 20, 2011. Beloved husband of Estelle. Loving father of Pat, Joann, Elizabeth, Marilyn and the late Kathleen. Cherished grandfather of nine. Gene was vice president of Time Warner, Inc. Former commodore of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club. Member of the New York Yacht Club and Village Club of Sands Point. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd, Manhasset, Thursday 7-9pm and Friday 3-5 and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass, 9:45am, Saturday at Our Lady of Fatima Church in Manorhaven. Interment Calvary Cemetery Woodside. In lieu of flowers, donations to a charity of your choice would be appreciated.

A federal judge ruled Tuesday that Ivi TV, an ambitious online video start-up, must stop rebroadcasting signals of local television stations on the Internet, dealing a major setback to the company. Ivi said the injunction by the United States District Court in New York had forced the company to shut down most of its service, though it said some channels would remain available for Web streaming. The company said it would appeal the ruling.

Driving his black Mercedes-Benz over the Fourth of July weekend, a Morgan Stanley Smith Barney broker, Martin Joel Erzinger, hit a cyclist, leaving the rider seriously injured on the side of the road. Not long after, police found Mr. Erzinger in the parking lot of an abandoned Pizza Hut, removing the side mirror and bumper from his car, according to court documents. Mr. Erzinger told officers he didn't remember striking anybody. Mr. Erzinger was charged with a felony over the summer and pleaded guilty to two lesser misdemeanor charges in December. Morgan Stanley Smith Barney, which was supposed to tell regulators within 30 days of the initial charges, took months to report the incident.

NETTER--Edward. Thanks To Scandinavia mourns the passing of Edward Netter, a longstanding leader of our Board and the brother of our founder, Richard Netter. With his wife, Barbara, Edward established an annual scholarship at the University of Pennsylvania commemorating the rescue of Jews during World War II. Each year, the Barbara and Edward Netter Scholar is a living tribute to a man whose life was dedicated to justice and action. Laurie Netter Sprayregen, President Rebecca Neuwirth, Executive Director

Justin Moran may not have much power on Broadway, but that hasn't discouraged him from taking on the formidable responsibility of ensuring that New York has at least one Spider-Man musical that officially opens by mid-March. Frustrated by the web of delays engulfing ''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark,'' the $65 million Broadway spectacle that is now to open on March 15 (if not later), Mr. Moran, an improv comedian and a composer, has decided to beat Julie Taymor and her team to the punch by opening his own show about that comic-book wall-crawler one day earlier, on March 14.

Researchers from the National Institutes of Health have found that less than an hour of cellphone use can speed up brain activity in the area closest to the phone antenna, raising new questions about the health effects of low levels of radiation emitted from cellphones. The researchers, led by Dr. Nora D. Volkow, director of the National Institute on Drug Abuse, urged caution in interpreting the findings because it is not known whether the changes, which were seen in brain scans, have any meaningful effect on a person's overall health.

They grow up so quickly these days. Two weeks after the opening of ''Justin Bieber: Never Say Never,'' a 3-D concert documentary about that 16-year-old, Canada-preferring, floppy-hair-cutting, Grammy-almost-winning pop phenomenon, an extended version of that film will be released into theaters. Paramount's Insurge Pictures division, which released the original film, said a ''director's fan cut'' of ''Never Say Never,'' with 40 minutes of new footage, will be shown in theaters for one week starting Friday. The re-release, which could add significantly to the $51.3 million in tickets that the film had sold in the United States by Monday, is a test of the loyalty of Mr. Bieber's fans, but also, its director said, an experiment to see how quickly a studio can place a film in theaters once its editing is complete.

CUNNINGHAM--Joseph N.,Jr. The Trustees, physicians, nurses, staff and volunteers of Maimonides Medical Center mourn the sudden loss of Joseph N. Cunningham, Jr. Dr. Cunningham was a friend, esteemed colleague, mentor and teacher to all of us. Joe came to Maimonides from NYU in 1982, bringing with him a new level of clinical excellence and advanced surgical techniques. In his nearly three decades as Chair of the Department of Surgery, he created a high level and renowned cardiac and general surgical program. He recruited leading surgeons from around the country, initiated important clinical research and trained generations of new surgical leaders. Most recently, Dr. Cunningham served as our Senior Vice President of Strategic Initiatives. Joe was a dynamic leader, forward thinking physician and warm and compassionate man. He will be deeply missed by the many people whose lives he touched. Martin D. Payson, Chairman of the Board Pamela S. Brier, President and CEO

Richard Mourdock, the state treasurer of Indiana, announced on Tuesday that he would challenge Senator Richard G. Lugar in the state's Republican primary next year, one of several anticipated Tea Party challenges to incumbent Republican senators in 2012. Mr. Mourdock officially announced his candidacy with a speech in Indianapolis, and a video on his new campaign Web site portrayed Mr. Lugar, who has represented the state in the Senate since 1977, as ''Obama's favorite Republican.''

A picture on Feb. 15 with the Global Update report, about a decline in H.I.V. cases in Zimbabwe, was published in error. The photograph showed a patient receiving methadone in Tanzania. (The picture should have been published on Tuesday with a Global Update report about the first methadone maintenance program in sub-Saharan Africa.)

SULZBERGER--Judith. Columbia University Medical Center celebrates the life and mourns the passing of Judith Sulzberger, alumna and friend. A member of the College of Physicians and Surgeons Class of 1949, Dr. Sulzberger maintained a close relationship with our medical school, sharing her wisdom and offering her guidance as writer-in-residence for the genome division and as a member of the CUMC Board of Visitors, the P&S Alumni Steering Committee, and the Health Sciences Advisory Council. Her extraordinary generosity helped us establish the J. P. Sulzberger Genome Center and provided crucial support for activity across our campus, including the Columbia Initiative in Systems Biology, the Mailman School of Public Health, and the Nolting Student Loan Fund. She was a great friend to so many at CUMC, and her warmth, kindness and generosity of spirit will be much missed. All of us at Columbia extend our condolences to her husband, Budd Levinson; her sons, James and Daniel Cohen; her grandchildren; and to all of the members of her extended family. Lee Goldman, M.D. Dean of the Faculties of Health Sciences and Medicine Executive Vice President, Columbia University

McGRATH--Christopher Columbus Jr.,entered into eternal life on February 18, 2011 at the age of 74. Chris was a loving and dedicated husband, father, grandfather, brother, and uncle. He is survived by his wife, Jayne; his five children and their spouses, Christopher Columbus III (Beth), Patrick (Christine), Siobhan, Matthew (Michael), and Luke (Viviana); his grandchildren, Christopher James, Aidan, Grace, Bridget, Rory, Leah and Coco; his siblings, Michael, Terence, Kevin, and Kathleen "Muffin"; and a large loving extended family. Christopher is pre-deceased by his parents, the Honorable Christopher Columbus McGrath Sr. and Helen Gaffney McGrath, and his sister Mary Ann. Chris was a triple Ram; he graduated from Fordham Prep, received his B.A. from Fordham University, and then acquired his J.D. from Fordham School of Law. Upon finishing his studies, he served as Associate Council to the Cuban Families Relief Committee; being instrumental in the negotiated release of more than 300 prisoners being held by the Cuban Government. Chris was then campaign assistant to Senator Robert F. Kennedy, campaign scheduler for Governor Hugh L. Carey, and Deputy Borough President of Manhattan. Leaving the job of Executive Director of the N.Y. State Petroleum Council, Chris founded New York Capitol Consultants. Along with loyally servicing his clients, he also served as Executive Director for The New York, New Jersey, Massachusetts, Rhode Island, and Vermont State Self Storage Associations. Family will receive friends at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street on Wednesday 2-5 and 7-9pm. A mass of Christian Burial will be held at the Fordham University Chapel, Bronx NY on Thursday at 10:15am. Burial will be held at Greenwood Union Cemetery, Rye, NY. A reception will follow at Manursing Island Club. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in Christopher's memory to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Pediatric Cancer Research, Hagerstown, Maryland 21741.

The long-running musical ''The Lion King'' is the first show to hit No. 1 in Broadway's weekly box office grosses so late in the life of its run, earning $1,534,779 last week to edge out its closest competitors, ''Wicked'' and ''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark.'' One likely factor was Disney Theatrical Productions' decision to shift the show's usual Tuesday evening performance to Monday evening, Feb. 14, to capitalize on date nights for Valentine's Day. ''The Lion King'' has run for about 13 years and four months on Broadway. Only six shows have run longer; in order, ''The Phantom of the Opera,'' ''Cats,'' ''Les Miserables,'' ''A Chorus Line,'' ''Oh, Calcutta,'' and the current revival of ''Chicago.'' According to a spokeswoman for the Broadway League, a trade group that collects and analyzes box office data, none of those six shows ever reached #1 in the weekly box office grosses at a comparable point - or afterward - in the lives of their runs.

PUTNAM--Rosamond "Ros" Page, 92, died on February 16th, peacefully, at her home in Keene, NH. She was born in New York City on August 1, 1918, the daughter of Izola (Forrester) and Mann Page, grew up in Santa Monica, CA and married David F. Putnam of Keene, NH in 1938. She gave decades of service on the boards of the MacDowell Colony in Peterborough, NH and the Saint-Gaudens Memorial in Cornish, NH. She is survived by her six children. Services will be February 26th, at 11am, St. James Episcopal Church, 44 West St. in Keene.

A recent post asked working parents how they put dinner on the table every night. The post received more than 40 comments. Here are some highlights from the many useful suggestions. THINK EGGS. THINK FAST. Keep weeknight dinners super easy. I've become a master of making delicious egg dinners during the week (hello, 10-minute dinner): quinoa huevos rancheros, quickest curried eggs, adding poached eggs to made-ahead soup or lentils or frittatas. You get the point. -- One Hungry Mama, Brooklyn, N.Y.

The economics of the N.B.A. dictate that there are only two ways to build an elite team:1. Acquire players who produce above-average value relative to the salaries they are making. 2. Exploit the loopholes in the salary cap so that you spend more money than other teams.This is not merely a rule of thumb; it's a mathematical axiom. At least one of these two things absolutely must be true for a team to be better than its competition.

RUDER--William. The Ruder Finn Group mourns the passing of Bill Ruder, co-founder of Ruder Finn, Inc., one of the world's largest public relations firms, who passed away in New York, on February 22, 2011 at the age of 89. He remained an active member of the board of the firm until his death. His insight and experience will be missed. The Ruder Finn Group

The Republican presidential contest remains ill defined, with no announced candidates for 2012. But there are signs that the race is taking shape as potential rivals to President Obama inch closer to making it official -- and others make it clear they will not run. The campaign in waiting of Jon M. Huntsman Jr. unveiled a Web site on Tuesday declaring that ''maybe someday'' the country will find the right leader, another indication that allies of the ambassador to China are preparing for a presidential campaign.

SABETY--Adrian, MD. It is with sadness, respect and grateful recognition that The Cardiovascular Care Group recognizes the passing of Dr. Adrian Sabety on February 18, 2011 at his home in Washington DC at the age of 95 years. As one of the founding members of The Thoracic Cardiovascular Surgical Group (now, The Cardiovascular Care Group) Dr. Sabety, along with Dr. Franklyn Gerard, established a standard for the delivery of patient care that has grown since 1963. Dr. Sabety developed one of the first noninvasive vascular laboratories in New Jersey. He was active at Mountainside, Orange Memorial, East Orange General and Saint Barnabas Hospitals. A board certified Thoracic Surgeon, Dr. Sabety performed open heart surgery and lung surgery for over 40 years before retiring in 1989.The Group and all of the patients he cared for are grateful for his vision and expertise. Our sincerest sympathies are extended to Dorothea and his entire family. The Cardiovascular Care Group Belleville & Westfield, NJ

ZANE--Susan "Sudy" Reinauer, passed away suddenly on February 19, 2011. She is survived by her husband of 19 years, Alan Zane; her children, Amy and Randall Blumenthal; daughter-in-law, Sabra Krock, of New York City; stepson, Randall Zane, and wife Pamela of Corpus Christi, TX; stepdaughter, Cheryl Zane of Houston, TX; stepson, Bradley Zane, and wife Melissa of Flower Mound, TX; stepson, Robert Zane of Frisco, TX; and stepdaughter, Susan Epstein, and husband Robert of Austin, TX;. Sudy was adored by 11 grandchildren: Max Blumenthal; Andrea and Stacy Zane; Arielle, Alyssa, Julianna and Joshua Epstein; Richard and Julia Zane; and Audrey and Aiden Zane. She is also survived by her brother, David Reinauer, and wife Anne of Lake Charles, LA; and twin sister, Jere Glaser, of New Orleans, LA. Sudy was born in Lake Charles, Louisiana, on September 23, 1943, graduated from Lake Charles High School in 1961, and the University of Illinois in 1965. She moved to Houston in 1975. She initially worked in the advertising department of the Houston Chronicle and soon entered the insurance business with the Connecticut Mutual Insurance Company. Insurance and estate planning became a lifelong passion of hers, mainly for the assistance she was able to offer to families in understanding and planning for their future. Her clients were particularly moved by her ability to connect with them on both emotional and analytical levels. Over many years, she became a trusted advisor and worked tirelessly to refine her technical knowledge. A true relationship builder, she pioneered a way for businesswomen to network with each other to provide contacts, access to business leads and support. In 1976 in this context, she started "women's breakfast clubs", ultimately starting 12 clubs including the River Oaks Breakfast Club, Charter 100 Breakfast Club, the Women's City Club and the Jewish Federation of Greater Houston Breakfast Club. These are the largest such groups in Houston and have provided a high degree of emotional support, business guidance and pure friendship to countless professional women. Sudy had a vivacious spirit, energetic demeanor and generous character, as evidenced by her many friends and diverse interests. She was passionate about the arts, was working diligently to achieve Life Master status at bridge, and recently became a mentor for the Brigid's Hope Program, a group that helps women re-integrate into society after incarceration in Texas jails. With her husband, she literally traveled the world, exploring all seven continents and over 75 countries in the past 20 years including, to name a few of the more exotic adventures, Bhutan, Central Asia, and Antarctica. Sudy could light up a roomful of people, share an intimate conversation or nurture a distant e-mail exchange. Her infectious smile and abundant laughter were always easily at hand. Full of stories about travel and life, a reliable and willing play date for her adoring grandchildren and simply a great listener, she will be dearly missed by her family and numerous friends. The memorial service to celebrate the life of Sudy Zane will be held on Monday, February 21, 2011, at 1pm at Temple Beth Israel, 5600 N. Braeswood Blvd., Houston, Texas 77096. A graveside service will be held on Sunday, February 27, 2011, at 11am at Orange Grove-Graceland Cemetery in Lake Charles, Louisiana. Should friends so desire, in lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Brigid's Hope, 1117 Texas Ave., Houston, Texas 77002.

SULZBERGER--Judith P. The students and faculty of the CUNY Graduate School of Journalism offer their condolences to the family and friends of Dr. Judith Sulzberger. Along with her sisters, Dr. Sulzberger was one of the earliest donors to our new J-School, establishing an internship and scholarship fund in honor of her brother, Arthur Ochs "Punch" Sulzberger, chairman emeritus and former publisher of The New York Times. Dr. Sulzberger's generosity has enabled the CUNY J-School to attract a talented, diverse student body, greatly enhancing the future of journalism. We are grateful for her strong, early support, and we mourn her loss. Stephen B. Shepard, Founding Dean

JANNEY--Donald, age 61. February 18. Died peacefully at Vanderbilt Medical Center, from liver failure following an initially successful liver transplant. A graduate of the Rhode Island School of Design, he was an Emmy Award-winning cameraman for WCBS TV News for over thirty years working with, befriending and gaining the professional respect of the great reporters, correspondents, and producers of the 1980's and 1990's and beyond, including Mike Taibbi, Anna Phillips, J.J. Gonzales, Chris Borgen, Vic Miles, Magee Hickey, Jim Jensen, and Dan Rather. They all called him one of the best in the business. A free spirit, Don spoke his mind, to his friends, superiors, and even several mayors of New York City, never falling to point out the error of their ways while photographing them in the news. Not having much family of his own, he was beloved by many, adopting surrogate families throughout his life. He was the only child of the late Isabel Kroener Janney and the late actor Leon Janney. He is survived by his dear, devoted friends the photographer Lawson Little and Sandra Watson, R.N., who both cared for him for the last six months of his life, his loving Uncle Nate and Aunt Dyanne Janney, his lifelong friend Dr. John Cappadona, and many, many other close friends. Quoting Mike Taibbi:"...we lost a unique and thoroughly human friend."

MEZEY--George Julius, George Julius Mezey was born June 5, 1927 in Szeged, Hungary. He passed away Saturday, February 19th. George was the Executive Vice President of H. Sand and Co., a Skanska Company, headquartered in New York City. During his tenure at H. Sand he was responsible for hundreds of significant projects in the New York City Area. Two of the most notable were the re-building of the World Trade Center after the first bombing in 1992 and the North River Wastewater Treatment Plant, one of the largest of its kind in the world. He retired from Skanska in 1996. He is survived by his wife Susan, his five children, as well as his 15 grandchildren and numerous nieces and nephews. In lieu of flowers, his family requests that donations be made to the Camillus Ski Association in his honor. Please share condolences at: BuranichFuneralHome.com

New York State has long had a policy of countersuing patients who demand compensation for being injured in state psychiatric hospitals. The Office of Mental Health immediately bills them for the time they spend in the hospital, often stopping the case cold and making it nearly impossible for the patient to attract or keep a lawyer, a practice we explored in this article in December. The strategy was hugely effective at quashing claims, even ones borne of extreme tragedy. But to avoid any chance of a public outcry, it now appears that billing personnel were told to code certain cases - for instance, those involving the death or rape of psychiatric patients - differently, apparently to signal the need for special handling, according to an examination of state records turned over in response to a long-running lawsuit called Brown v. Stone.

The American Folk Art Museum, which is facing serious financial problems, is nonetheless embarking an ambitious project: an exhibition of African-American self-taught and graffiti artists to take place in Venice during the Biennale there. The exhibition will open June 1 at the Fondaco dei Tedeschi, a building owned by the Benetton Group that may ultimately become a Rem Koolhaas-designed retail and exhibition space. Benetton is offering the building to the museum for free, as well as providing advertising and art materials and holding the opening-night party. The museum's director, Maria Ann Conelli, said that the budget for the one-month exhibition was between $300,000 and $400,000 and that the museum was reaching out to foundations and corporations for financing. Since January, the museum has been unable to make payments on the roughly $30 million it owes against its building on West 53rd Street. Last summer, it entered into a forbearance agreement with the company that insured its debt, ACA Financial Guaranty. That agreement expires on June 30. According to the most recent available financial statements, in the fiscal year that ended June 30, 2010, the museum ran a deficit from unrestricted activities of $3.6 million. Ms. Conelli said that the museum had a balanced budget for this year. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

For many, a familiar scent can arouse a forgotten memory. Jennifer Fraser wouldn't know that feeling. She does not have a sense of smell. In 2007, Ms. Fraser moved from Los Angeles to New York. For her, the city is a carnival of movement and motion: classical and modern dancing, bright lights, fast cars and street musicians. ''New York City is like a circus of music,'' she said, ''music coming out of the streets, the bodegas, the subway tracks.'' When she closes her eyes, Ms. Fraser envisions a ballerina en pointe. Sometimes, she feels as if she is living in black and white: when she visits new neighborhoods and can't smell the different fragrances, it seems as if the city has lost some of its color. But most of the time, she is comfortable with her unique perception of New York. ''I don't feel like I'm missing out,'' she said. This series presents multiple-exposure portraits of perceptions of the city described by New Yorkers missing one or more senses. Earlier in the series: nytimes.com/lens.

FRIDAY'S PUZZLE - Henry Hook has a reputation as the mad genius of puzzles, and rightly so. His wit and delightfully twisted themes are applauded by beginners and veteran solvers alike. Today's puzzle is not the most difficult Friday grid I've ever solved, and the majority of clues are fairly straightforward compared with other Hook puzzles, but that's all right. Mr. Hook's personality shines through, and even on a themeless Friday, he manages to squeeze in a groaner of a mini-theme and some brilliant cluing.

La La Vazquez, the wife of the NBA star Carmelo Anthony, won't just be busy setting up house when the couple moves to New York. She has landed a reality series on VH1, "La La's Full Court Life," which will chronicle the couple's move from Denver. On Monday Mr. Anthony was traded by the Denver Nuggets to the New York Knicks. The 10-episode, half-hour series, which is scheduled to premiere in August, will show Ms. Vazquez, an actress and television personality, as she copes with the demands of career and home in New York. It is a follow-up to "La La's Full Court Wedding," a series about the couple's wedding broadcast last year on VH1. "Viewers connect with La La because despite the fairy tale wedding and NBA star husband, she is a real, down to earth, hardworking woman who stays true to herself," said Jeff Olde, executive vice president for original programming and production at VH1.

State legislation that would have forced the University of Iowa to sell "Mural" - an 8-by-20-foot painting by Jackson Pollock valued at more than $100 million - to raise money for the school has been dropped, The Des Moines Register reported. State Representative Scott Raecker introduced the bill this month as a way to create an endowment to pay for as many as 1,000 full student scholarships a year, but the proposal drew widespread criticism. David Miles, the president of the Board of Regents, State of Iowa, described the bill as "a profoundly bad idea," one that was examined by the board in 2008 and "determined to be not in the best interests of the University of Iowa or the state." Mr. Raecker told the student newspaper The Daily Iowan that he still believed the painting should be sold but said that the issue had become "so polarized that reaching consensus is unlikely." "I'm a firm believer in the legislative process," he added, "and further discussion of the sale of the Pollock painting will not be moved forward in the legislature this year."

The word "fund-raiser" evokes an image of endless speeches, bland evening gowns and even blander buffets, but Edible Schoolyard's yearly benefit should veer a little more toward the wild side. With three fabulous hostesses (the food artist Jennifer Rubell, the fashion buyer Julie Gilhart and the 303 gallerist Lisa Spellman) and a storied downtown locale (the Odeon), the event promises to be more Studio 54 than Cipriani Ballroom. "It's the kind of fund-raiser that I would love to attend, a fund-raiser that is not boring" says Rubell, just back from the opening of her "Engagement" show at the Stephen Friedman gallery in London. "My favorite women in the city will be there, including Lynn Wagenknecht" - the restaurant's owner - "who came up with the idea."

Clearly this is something I'll be writing about for years to come; emotions are high and many pro-GMO people are industry boosters in disguise. Nothing wrong with that, I suppose, but fake impartiality is obnoxious. There were two pieces in Forbes about my column. The more reasonable one categorized me as a "foodie elite" - presumably not because I sometimes eat well but because I refuse to acknowledge that genetically engineered foods will save the world, which they will not (you might read this terrific piece by Christopher Cook in The Christian Science Monitor, about Monsanto's business and its threat to food safety, and then remember that not all new developments are progressive) and a "luddite" (which is ridiculous, unless believing that not every bit of technology is world-saving makes you a luddite).

Ford's recall on Wednesday of 135,000 F-150 pickup trucks, conducted because the driver's air bag may inadvertently deploy, could be seen as a laudable act of corporate responsibility. But for the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, which has called for 10 times as many vehicles to be recalled, it is a rebuff and a challenge.

You sometimes hear the claim that the economy cannot  recover before the housing market recovers. I think that's wrong. Just because real estate led the economy into the recession does not mean it must lead the economy out. Other sectors can accomplish that. It's more likely that the economy will need to recover -- with unemployment falling and income rising -- first and then housing will begin a very slow recovery.

3:54 p.m. | Updated The founding president of the Seaport Museum New York, which in recent weeks lost a third of its trustees and furloughed half its staff, has called for the resignation of the museum's current president, Mary Pelzer, and its chairman, Frank J. Sciame. In a letter to Ms. Pelzer that he shared with The New York Times, the former president, Peter Stanford, said that the museum needed new leadership to survive. He wrote that Ms. Pelzer's and Mr. Sciame's credibility had been damaged by "concealment" of its financial problems, and that the "overall direction of the Seaport Museum has been neglectful of its principal physical asset," its historic ships. Mr. Sciame, a real estate developer, has lent the museum $3 million in the last year to cover operating expenses. "Mr. Sciame and Ms. Pelzer are extremely surprised and deeply disappointed by these inaccurate comments," said Adam Pockriss of Rubenstein Communications and a spokesman for the museum. Neither Ms. Pelzer nor Mr. Sciame returned phone calls.

In their deal to acquire Carmelo Anthony, the Knicks opted to consolidate. Danilo Gallinari and Wilson Chandler are solid players, but rather than have those two good scorers in their rotation, the Knicks cashed in on their trade value to net one terrific scoring talent. Neither Gallinari nor Chandler can touch Anthony when it comes to shot creation or scoring volume, but the cost for the upgrade in first-unit production is the team's depth. Both former Knicks played over 34 minutes a night, which means that in addition to Anthony, New York will have at least one more new regular filling in minutes on the wing.

Two thieves were arrested last week trying to break apart an important 20-foot-tall statue of the pharaoh Ramses II embedded in a quarry in the southern city of Aswan, Egypt's antiquities minister, Zahi Hawass, said in a phone interview. Mr. Hawass said that the thieves wrongly believed that the statue was hollow and had gold hidden inside it. They were caught by guards at the site, he said, comparing the thieves to the people who looted the Egyptian Museum on Jan. 28. Those looters were also looking for gold, according to Mr. Hawass, and for a fictitious substance called red mercury that is believed by "ignorant people" to have been used in mummification and to have magical properties.

The Commerce Department's inspector general has completed a review of actions by climate scientists at the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration that was requested by Senator James Inhofe, Republican of Oklahoma. It found no evidence of manipulation of climate data by NOAA scientists in their communications with scientists at the University of East Anglia in Britain, or of flawed testimony by NOAA's administrator, Jane Lubchenco, at a 2009 Senate hearing. However, the report questioned the agency's response to some Freedom of Information Act requests in 2007. NOAA's press release is here.

I mentioned on Wednesday that World War II was the stimulus program that finally ended the Depression. My colleague Alan Schwarz -- he of concussion-expose fame -- said that the mention reminded him of one of his high school teachers, Werner Feig, who used to tell students that the Depression was ended by the Full Employment Act of Dec. 7, 1941. (Mr. Feig evidently made a big impression: Aaron Sorkin, another former student, wove him into a "West Wing" episode.)

When his time behind the wheel at "Driving Miss Daisy" comes to an end, James Earl Jones need not resort to reciting Justin Bieber lyrics for fun and profit (unless he wants to), as his next term of office on Broadway has been decided: Mr. Jones, a Tony Award winner for "Fences" and "The Great White Hope," will next portray a former United States president in the revival of "Gore Vidal's The Best Man," a political play scheduled for spring of next year. Press representatives for the revival said on Thursday that Mr. Jones will play Arthur Hockstader, a Truman-esque chief executive deciding between endorsing the potential presidential nominees William Russell and Joe Cantwell. When "The Best Man" was first presented on Broadway in 1960 (and made into a film in 1964), Russell was perceived as an analogue for Adlai Stevenson and Cantwell as an amalgam of John F. Kennedy and Richard M. Nixon; a 2000 Broadway revival, starring Charles Durning as Hockstader, Spalding Gray as Russell and Chris Noth as Cantwell, seemed to have its eye on the real-life contest between Al Gore and George W. Bush. Michael Wilson ("The Orphans' Home Cycle") will direct the 2012 production, though its producers have not yet announced their nominees to play Russell and Cantwell.

Handicapping the competition for the Oscar for best foreign-language film is a bit more complex than for some of the other categories, since there's no telling how many people are going to vote, what motivates those who do, or even who they are. To qualify to vote, an academy member must see all five nominated films, and many - or most - Oscar voters simply can't be bothered with a category considered so marginal or esoteric. That's not the case with categories like best film or best actor and actress.

With some tours, you wonder what songs will appear on the set list; for this one, we wonder what they'll serve at the concession stands. Anthony Hopkins, who has variously cooked up the liver of a census taker and the brain matter of Ray Liotta in his onscreen capacity as Dr. Hannibal Lecter, plans to take on more digestible material in a series of concerts featuring his own musical compositions. BBC News reported that Mr. Hopkins will participate in the City of Birmingham Symphony Orchestra's summer tour of Britain, on which the orchestra will perform the original scores he created for his films "August" and "Slipstream," as well as a new work by the actor. The orchestra, conducted by Michael Seal, will also play selections from the scores of Mr. Hopkins's best-known films, including "The Remains of the Day" and "The Silence of the Lambs," and Mr. Hopkins will discuss his music and creative process (and who knows, maybe even favorite recipes) with Tommy Pearson, a producer of the concerts. There was no immediate announcement if the concert series might come to the United States or if Mr. Hopkins might take a brief detour to the Bahamas to have an old friend for dinner.

FLOM--Joseph H. The partners, counsel, associates and staff of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom LLP mourn the death of Joseph H. Flom, who joined Skadden, Arps as the firm's first associate in 1948. Over the course of a singularly distinguished law career, he fundamentally transformed the practice of corporate law, while guiding Skadden from a four-lawyer firm to a global law firm with 2,000 attorneys and scores of practice areas. Joe combined a brilliant intellect, impeccable judgment and relentless dedication, which he applied to everything he touched with true humility. A most trusted adviser, beloved and respected partner and mentor, faithful friend and formidable adversary, he was, in every sense, a great man. The consummate deal attorney smart, strategic and tireless he was among the first to drive mergers and acquisitions to the top of corporate agendas; and, in 1999, he was named one of the "lawyers of the century" by The American Lawyer. With a steady hand and clear vision, he set the course for Skadden's development, never wavering from his principles of unparalleled legal advice, loyalty to his colleagues and peers, and social responsibility. Joe was a dedicated humanitarian, supporting education and equal opportunity in the legal profession, and likely would have wanted to be remembered most for his philanthropic endeavors. He was particularly gratified by the enduring work of the Skadden Fellowship Foundation, of which he was the founding trustee in 1988. More recently, Joe led the development of the Skadden Honors Program in Legal Studies at City College of New York, an initiative designed to increase diversity in the legal profession. Along with his first wife, Claire, who predeceased him in 2007, Joe supported the Gateway School in New York founded by Claire for students with learning disabilities. They also supported cancer research at the Mount Sinai-NYU Medical Center Health System, among other institutions and causes. More recently, he and his wife Judi provided significant financial support for the widely praised "Play Me, I'm Yours" public installation of 60 pianos in all five boroughs of New York City for several weeks last summer. In addition to his law practice, Joe served on numerous corporate boards and was a trustee of the Carroll and Milton Petrie Foundation. In 2005, Joe and the Petrie Foundation provided funding for the creation of the Petrie-Flom Center for Health Law Policy, Biotechnology and Bioethics at Harvard Law School to promote an interdisciplinary analysis of legal issues in the areas of health care, biotechnology and bioethics. He volunteered his time and expertise to numerous other educational and civic organizations, including the Harvard Law School Dean's Advisory Board; The City College 21st Century Foundation; the American Academy of Arts and Sciences; the Council on Foreign Relations; the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars; the New York City Commission on the Bicentennial of the U.S. Constitution; the New York City Operation Welcome Home Commission; the New York City Commission on the Status of Women; the Archdiocesan Task Force on Crime Prevention and Youth; the New York City Holocaust Memorial Commission; the Mayor's Council of Economic Advisors; the Metropolitan Museum of Art; the United Way of New York City; the America-Israel Friendship League; and the Mount Sinai-NYU Medical Center Health System. Joe is survived by his wife Judi, sons Jason and Peter, and daughter Nancy Laing, as well as six grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. He will be deeply missed and always cherished by all who knew him. The family is holding a private remembrance. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Skadden Fellowship Foundation for the support of new projects undertaken by former Skadden Fellows. The address is: Skadden Fellowship Foundation, Four Times Square, Room 29/218, New York, N.Y., 10036.

Score one for the broken-windows theory, that largely hypothetical correlation between vandalism and crime. Overall crime in the New York metropolitan area has declined in the past six years. So has the number of broken windows. Of the five million homes and apartments counted in 2009, windows were reportedly broken in 23,500, compared with 156,900 in the 4.8 million counted six years earlier, the Census Bureau said this week.
