A legend in both the worlds of law and philanthropy, his legacy will be felt by generations to come. We extend our condolences to his wife, Judi; his sons, Jason and Peter, and daughter, Nancy Laing; and the entire family. Jerry W. Levin, President Alisa R. Doctoroff, Chair of the Board, John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

The biggest American financial institutions are still benefiting from the perception that the government will always come to their rescue. But a slight narrowing in the gap between what large banks like JPMorgan Chase and Bank of America and others in the industry pay for deposits may suggest a hint of progress. That offers hope for those, like Thomas M. Hoenig, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City, who would like to eradicate the notion that some banks are too big to fail. In fairness, the evidence is barely perceptible and may be fleeting. According to fourth-quarter figures released by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation on Wednesday, the 107 American banks with more than $10 billion of assets are still financing themselves ridiculously cheaply. The top banks paid just 0.77 percent in annual interest to depositors in the quarter. That is the lowest rate in the statistics published by the F.D.I.C., which stretch back to the first quarter of 1984. Smaller banks, on average, had to pay customers around 1.18 percent.

He was a retired senior partner of the international patent and trademark firm of Ladas, Parry, Von Gehr, Goldsmith, and Deschamps, and of council to the successor firm of Ladas and Parry. He graduated Columbia College in 1926 and New York University Law School in 1942. He was a charter member of the Putnam and Northern Westchester Fire Police Association and Life Member and Chaplain Emeritus of the Patterson, NY Volunteer Fire Department No. 1. His wife of 75 years, Ann Kortlang, passed away at the age of 100 in 2007. He is survived by his son Stephen and daughter Susan Deborah, son-in-law Ronald Franz, three grand children, Elizabeth and Christopher Goldsmith, and Brandon Franz, as well as two great-grandchildren, Alex and Stephanie Brown. Services are being handled by Dwyer Funeral Home in Patterson, NY.

Prepaid phones are often a great deal, offering voice and data at a low price and without tying you to a two-year contract. But the stripped-down handsets often limit the apps and services. However, prepaid services that bundle a package of apps for a specific audience are emerging. A pioneer is the Jitterbug phone, which allows seniors to have a simple phone then add on subscription services, like LiveNurse, which connects users to a registered nurse who has the caller's health history and is prepared to answer questions.

An article last Thursday about illnesses that can be contracted from sleeping with pets referred incorrectly to Chagas disease. It is spread by the insects known as kissing bugs or assassin bugs, not by fleas, and it can cause serious harm or even death, not just mild fever and fatigue.

The Crib Sheet column last Thursday misidentified the character portrayed by Burgess Meredith in the ''Batman'' television series. He was The Penguin -- not The Riddler, who was played by Frank Gorshin.

BIGGAR--Charles P. It is with great sadness that the family of Charles P. Biggar announces his death on February 21, 2011 after a long battle with Parkinson's disease. Charley was 80 years old, born on October 13, 1930 in Albany, New York, son of Charles and Margaret Biggar. Charley served in the United States Navy in the early 1950's. He joined IBM as a customer engineer in 1955 and enjoyed a prominent 32-year career at IBM where he retired as President of their service division. He attended Siena College and was a Stanford Sloan Fellow at Stanford University Business School. Charley's IBM career quickly advanced and in June of 1971 he was appointed IBM Director of Service, and in October of 1975 he was elected an IBM Vice President. He was promoted to President of Field Engineering in October 1976, and later named President of the National Service Division. Charley retired from IBM in 1987 to focus on his family and the game of golf. Some of his happiest moments were spent in the early morning on his beloved Whippoorwill golf course with friends and family. He was a tireless spirit, an achiever and a fierce competitor with a great love for life. Charley is survived by his wife of 55 years, Mary Patricia (Pat) and their seven children. He will also be fondly remembered by his seventeen grandchildren, as well as his three sisters and his brother. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated on Saturday, February 26th at 12:30pm at St John and St Mary Roman Catholic Church in Chappaqua, NY. The family will receive friends at the Beecher Funeral Home, 418 Bedford Road, Pleasantville, NY on Thursday February 24th from 4 to 8pm. Memorial contributions to the American Parkinson Disease Association, 135 Parkinson Avenue, Staten Island, NY 10305 or www.apdaparkinson.org would be greatly appreciated in lieu of flowers.

It's an old pattern by now. Phase 1: Apple introduces some new gadget. The bloggers and the industry tell us why it'll fail. Phase 2: It goes on sale. The public goes nuts for it. Phase 3: Every company and its brother gets to work on a copycat. It happened with the iMac and the iPhone. Now the iPad is entering Phase 3. Apple sold 15 million iPads in nine months, so you can bet that 2011 will be the Year of the iPad Clone.

To lose one parent, Lady Bracknell declares in ''The Importance of Being Earnest,'' may be regarded as a misfortune and to lose both looks like carelessness. But the loss of three performers from Roundabout Theater Company's Broadway revival of that Oscar Wilde comedy is an inevitability. Though it was recently announced that ''Earnest'' would extend its run at the American Airlines Theater through July 3, the cast members Dana Ivey (who plays Miss Prism), Paxton Whitehead (Rev. Canon Chasuble) and Sara Topham (Gwendolen Fairfax) are set to depart after the March 20 performance. On Wednesday, press representatives for the production announced their replacements: Jayne Houdyshell (whose Broadway credits include ''Wicked'' and ''Bye Bye Birdie'') will join the show as Miss Prism, Brian Murray (''Mary Stuart'') will play the Reverend, and Jessie Austrian (''Lend Me a Tenor'') will portray Gwendolen, all beginning with the March 22 performance. And while Mr. Bunbury makes up his mind whether he will live or die, Brian Bedford, the revival's director, is staying on in the role of Lady Bracknell.

An article on Tuesday about superfast Internet services in South Korea misstated the number of households involved in a pilot project. Under the program, which aims to connect customers to the Internet at speeds of up to one gigabit per second, 1,500 homes in five South Korean cities have so far been connected, not 5,000 homes.

6:29 p.m. | Updated The private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts on Wednesday posted fourth-quarter profit of $697 million, more than double its earnings in the period a year earlier, as the landscape for leveraged buyouts continued to improve. When people complain about the iPhone, one of the loudest complaints is the phone's lack of a physical keypad. For many, no physical keys is a deal-breaker, driving consumers to a BlackBerry or Android phone instead. If you use an iPhone, you know that the virtual keypad takes some getting used to; fingers slip to the wrong ''keys,'' turning simple words into occasionally embarrassing ones (some users have changed the default ''sent from my iPhone'' signature to ''typos courtesy of my iPhone.'')

SULZBERGER--Judith. The Parkinson's Disease Foundation has lost a wise, elegant and generous friend. We mourn with her family and treasure the memory of her many accomplishments. Page Morton Black, Chairman Robin Elliott, Exec. Director

Because of an editing error, an obituary on Wednesday about the physician and philanthropist Judith P. Sulzberger misstated the year she became a director of The New York Times. It was 1974, not 1972. (As correctly noted elsewhere in the obituary, she remained a director for 26 years.) The obituary also referred imprecisely to the Pasteur Foundation, on whose board she served. While it is affiliated with the Pasteur Institute in France, it is not the institute's ''New York branch.''

HONG KONG - Prada's first store, which unveiled the luxury retailer to the world in 1913, still operates in the grandiose Galleria Vittorio Emanuele II, the 19th-century glass-domed building that is home to some of Milan's oldest and most exclusive shops and restaurants. The setting for the company's stock market debut this year will be markedly different. Prada plans to list its public shares nearly 6,000 miles away, in Hong Kong, the modern city that is one of the world's leading financial centers.

RESTA-FLARER--Bonnie, homemaker and artist, died Tuesday, February 22 at age 59. She was a devoted family woman known for her cooking and ability to run a dinner party. A committed member of her summer community and a friend to many in her native Brooklyn, Bonnie died of complications from a battle with liver disease. She was married for 33 years and is survived by her husband, Franco and two children, Morgan, 27, and Tessa, 20. A memorial service will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel on February 25th at 2:30.

Every spring brings one or two late entries to the Broadway season, opening just under the wire to qualify for the Tony Awards. This year it will be ''The Normal Heart,'' Larry Kramer's landmark play about love, AIDS and New York in the 1980s, which will begin preview performances at the Golden Theater on April 19 and open on April 27, a spokesman for the production said Wednesday. To qualify for this year's Tonys shows must open by April 28. The production has its roots in an acclaimed staged reading in October on Broadway, at the Walter Kerr Theater, which raised $150,000 for charity. The veteran producer Daryl Roth will back ''The Normal Heart'' for the Broadway run, as she did for the staged reading. The actor and director Joe Mantello, above left, with Mr. Kramer, will play the central character Ned Weeks, and John Benjamin Hickey (''Love! Valour! Compassion!'') will play Ned's lover, Felix Turner, reprising their performances from the reading. Joining them in her Broadway debut will be the film actress Ellen Barkin as Emma Brookner, the doctor in a wheelchair who recognizes the seriousness of the AIDS crisis. (Glenn Close played the role at the reading.) Mr. Kramer wrote in an e-mail on Tuesday night that the production was also in talks with Cheyenne Jackson to play Tommy, a young gay activist who was played by Jack McBrayer (''30 Rock'') last fall. This Broadway production will be a relatively hectic affair. The director, Joel Grey, is now in rehearsals as an actor; he'll play Moonface Martin for the Broadway revival of ''Anything Goes,'' which starts previews on March 10 and opens on April 7. Mr. Mantello is also directing the Off Broadway play ''The Other Place,'' which is scheduled to begin previews on March 11 and run through April 24. ''The Normal Heart'' will move into the Golden almost immediately after ''Driving Miss Daisy'' closes on April 9.

SHORT-TERM LOSS Regulators and lawmakers have applauded Wall Street's decision to pay employees less cash and more stock. But the shift may result in short-term pain for New York. ''The industry's greater emphasis on deferred compensation will hold down tax collections this year, but the state and the city will benefit in future years when taxes are paid on this deferred compensation,'' Thomas P. DiNapoli, above, the New York State comptroller, said in a statement on Wednesday. EVELYN M. RUSLI

CHICAGO -- By now, Jon Erpenbach, one of 14 Democratic state senators on the run from Wisconsin, has switched hotels in this city three times, a necessity, he says, as word kept slipping out about where he was staying. At first it was unsettling: the essentials were forgotten -- extra slacks, socks, even underwear -- in a last-minute race to get south of the state line. But gradually the lawmakers restocked, thanks to packages delivered by family members and trips to discount stores.

In lieu of flowers, donations should be sent to the Ruth Ellin Friedman fund of Temple Emanuel, 455 Neptune Boulevard Long Beach, NY 11561-2437.

The gene responsible for cystic fibrosis was discovered in 1989. Now, 22 years later, a drug that tries to compensate for the genetic defect might be nearing the market. Vertex Pharmaceuticals announced Wednesday morning that the drug, VX-770, improved lung function in people with cystic fibrosis in a late-stage clinical trial. The drug also reduced the frequency of disease exacerbations that required treatment with antibiotics.

CHARLES PHILIP POZZI -- who is from Milan, went to college in Boston and lives in Shanghai -- sees his signature slipper collection as a cool, casual version of an English gentry style. The street-worthy slippers come in a variety of solid vibrant colors and patterned fabrics. Justin Bieber, Lady Gaga, Mumford & Sons and Lady Antebellum all got big ''Grammy lifts'' - the typical boost in record sales after the awards show. But who had the biggest lift depends on how you look at the numbers. Mr. Bieber, who did not win any awards but who had a prominent performing slot at the ceremony, dominates this week's Billboard album chart. ''Never Say Never: The Remixes'' (Island), the soundtrack to his new 3-D concert film, opened at No. 1 with 161,000 copies sold. But just as impressive, he has three other albums in the Top 40: ''My World 2.0'' is No. 8, ''My Worlds Acoustic'' is No. 18, and ''My World,'' the mini-album that was his debut, is No. 31. Billboard said Mr. Bieber was the first artist to pull off that feat since Garth Brooks in 1993. The British alt-folk band Mumford & Sons and Lady Antebellum, the country-pop trio that went home with the most Grammy awards (five, including record and song of the year), also had good runs on the album chart. Mumford & Sons' ''Sigh No More'' (Glassnote) holds at No. 2 this week. Its rise to No. 2 from No. 11 last week was largely based on impulse buys made during the Grammys telecast, on which the group performed with Bob Dylan, with 133,000 sales, a 169 percent increase from the week before. Lady Antebellum's ''Need You Now'' (Capitol Nashville) is No. 4, with 85,000 sales, a 205 percent gain. (No. 3 this week goes to Vol. 37 of the series ''Now That's What I Call Music!,'' which sold 95,000.) In terms of digital downloads, however, Lady Gaga and Cee Lo Green came out way ahead. ''Born This Way,'' which Lady Gaga performed at the awards, sold 509,000 copies in its first full week on sale, bringing its total sales in the United States - in just 10 days - to 957,000. And sales of Cee Lo's ''-------- You'' jumped 178 percent, to 412,000. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

CUNNINGHAM--Joseph N. Jr.,M.D. The Medical Staff of Maimonides Medical Center is deeply saddened by the sudden death of Dr. Joseph N. Cunningham, Jr. Dr. Cunningham was a renowned cardiac surgeon, coming to Maimonides in 1982 as the Director of Surgery. He led Maimonides to being one of the premier heart hospitals in New York. He served as one of the first physicians on the Board of Trustees from 1991 -- 2004. In the last two years he served as Senior Vice President for Strategic Planning. The Medical Center will forever be in debt for his contributions, leadership and guidance over the past 29 years. Sincere condolences are extended to his wife, children and entire family. H. Wasserman, MD, President E. Fitzpatrick, MD, President-Elect G. Neiderman, MD, Secretary E. Chapnick, MD, Treasurer W. Wexelman, MD, Past-President

FLOM--Joseph H. Fordham Law School records with profound sorrow the passing of Joseph Flom, a pioneer, a trusted advisor and, with his wife Claire, a devoted and generous friend of the Law School and Fordham University. Joseph built one of this nation's finest law firms and the Law School, through its students, alumni, and faculty, deeply values its unique relationship with his firm. We extend our deepest sympathy to his family. Michael M. Martin, Interim Dean

Water flecked with Brooklyn dirt trickled down on Tom O'Brien's hard hat from the arched ceiling of the Gowanus Canal flushing tunnel. Fifty-five feet underground, it made for a funny kind of rain. Each drop began as snow on Degraw Street in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, seeping slowly through sand and earth before wending its way through the tunnel's seven tightly fitted layers of aging brick and finally falling into its empty cavern.

Joseph H. Flom, a pioneering corporate lawyer who helped build Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom into one of the nation's leading law firms, died on Wednesday morning in Manhattan. He was 87. The cause was heart failure, a spokeswoman for the law firm said. He had homes in Manhattan and Palm Beach, Fla.

(Fox Business Network) STOSSEL At this point in the awards season you'd have to be living under a rock not to know that George VI -- portrayed by Colin Firth, the best actor Oscar favorite for ''The King's Speech'' -- stuttered. But did you know that John Stossel was also a stutterer? In this edition Mr. Stossel, above, describes how he overcame it. He also looks at the happily-ever-after messages projected by Hollywood movies in general and asks how realistic they are. His guests include Glenn Garvin, the television critic for The Miami Herald; Suzanne Somers, the actress and author of ''Sexy Forever''; Lisa Kennedy Montgomery, a former MTV host; Dr. Paul Offit, chief of the infectious diseases division at Children's Hospital of Philadelphia; and Michael Medved, the radio host and film critic. 7 A.M. (ABC) GOOD MORNING AMERICA A report on Kate Middleton, the future bride of Prince William.

A VOCADO is a gateway seed -- a way station on the path from horticultural dabbler to gardening addict. The pit, the toothpicks, the glass of water: this is seed germination at its most intoxicating. Marc Hachadourian became hooked on avocados in third or fourth grade. Growing up in suburban New Jersey, he said, ''I planted a little army on the windowsill. It got to the point where my mother got upset. She'd say, 'We don't need any giant avocado trees in the house.' When they'd hit the eight-foot ceiling, it was time for them to go.''

After three dismal years, the American banking industry regained its footing in 2010, according to a regulatory assessment released on Wednesday. Bank profits rebounded sharply. Loan losses eased. And only 24 lenders were added to the government's list of troubled banks, the smallest increase since the financial crisis erupted in late 2007.

Larry King the one-man interviewing machine is now Larry King the one-man showman. Mr. King, who stepped down in December after 25 years as the host of CNN's ''Larry King Live,'' will begin a national tour of a new autobiographical show, called ''Larry King: Standing Up,'' in the spring. According to a press release, the show is a comedic look at Mr. King's ''life growing up as a street-smart kid in Brooklyn'' and his decades as as a broadcast journalist; Mr. King will participate in a Q&A with audience members at each performance. Jim Millan, the creative director of the Kids in the Hall comedy troupe, will direct.

Hanover, N.H. TWO images serve as bookends to the four-decades-old rule of Libya's ruler, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. The first is the picture taken a few days after the Sept. 1, 1969, coup that brought him to power: it shows a handsome, pencil-thin revolutionary in military uniform, kneeling in the desert sand to pray. The other was taken two days ago: Colonel Qaddafi in bedouin garb as an uprising sparked by the arrest of a human rights lawyer in Benghazi continued to overtake the country, defiantly and incoherently defending his self-styled revolution, vowing to struggle on until death.

JF & SON, with its hand-enhanced garments made in India and China, has moved from Kenmare Street in NoLIta to larger, sunnier digs in Greenwich Village. ''We are near the fancy antiques stores on University Place and Union Square's fast-fashion chains,'' said Jesse Finkelstein, an owner. He and his partner, Katie King (above), said they manufacture their items, which include men's clothes, in factories that offer a living wage and health insurance. Spring items include skirts in light fabrics, sleeveless maxi-dresses (like the Swan dress, above, $320) and textures like simple beading and embroidery. JF & Son, 56 University Place (10th Street); (212) 343-3131, jfandson.com.

SINGER--Diane Grant Singer, 86, died February 23. Beloved wife of Herman Grant and Abraham Singer. Loving mother and stepmother, adoring grandmother, devoted sister. Dedicated teacher and lifelong learner. Above all, a survivor with passion for life. We will miss you always.

FLOM--Joseph. The staff and board of Sing for Hope extend their condolences to the family and friends of Joseph Flom. Along with his wife Judi, Joe was dedicated to providing creative opportunities for all New Yorkers, and his support of the Sing for Hope Street Pianos resonated throughout our city. The 2011 Street Piano's will be a reminder of Joe's legacy and the impact one person can have on us all.

In stores March 27, the Nintendo 3DS ($250), a pocket-size game system that Nintendo says will reshape the the portable gaming landscape by offering glasses-free 3-D viewing. But will enough people part with $250 for the experience? On first glance, the Nintendo 3DS looks a lot like last year's DSi. It can play more than 2,000 existing software cartridges, and is even compatible with the older charger. But once the lid is opened, the comparisons end. The upper screen is now iPhone-sized, at 800 by 240 pixels. And with 400 of those pixels reserved for each of your eyes, the display can trick your brain into seeing a three-dimensional image.

A report in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column on Wednesday about an exhibition that the American Folk Art Museum has scheduled for June in Venice characterized incorrectly the status of plans for the building where it will be held, the Fondaco dei Tedeschi. The Benetton Group, which owns the building, is considering a design by Rem Koolhaas to convert it into a retail and exhibition space; the company has not announced that it will pursue the design.

SULZBERGER--Judith P. On behalf of the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism, we offer condolences to the family and friends of Dr. Judith P. Sulzberger. Dr. Sulzberger, with her sisters Ruth S. Holmberg and Marian S. Heiskell, provided the school with a $4 million gift to launch the Punch Sulzberger News Media Leadership Program to honor the legacy of their brother's leadership of The New York Times and news industry. Since the program's start, more than 100 "Sulzberger Fellows" have received a unique level of innovative education and mentoring. The School joins members of the news industry that Dr. Sulzberger cared so passionately to sustain in mourning her loss. Nicholas Lemann, Dean Arlene Morgan, Associate Dean, and Director of the Punch Sulzberger Program

A lecture by the Nigerian author and Nobel Prize winner Wole Soyinka, readings by Wallace Shawn and Malcolm Gladwell, a debate on the prison industry and an evening on the topic of sex led by Edmund White are among the offerings at this year's PEN World Voices Festival of International Literature, which will take place from April 25 to May 1 in New York. Other events in the festival, which is put on by the PEN American Center, include a discussion of cultural and political conditions in China featuring the New Yorker contributor Jianying Zha; a night with the storytelling group the Moth, on the theme of ''What's Gone Wrong''; a celebration of poetry, curated by Laurie Anderson and featuring Antony and the Johnsons; and a game of telephone in which a Tibetan lama will pass along sutras down a list of 200 festival attendees, ending with Salman Rushdie, who will Tweet the result. The festival, which is being organized by the former Hungarian Cultural Center director Laszlo Jakab Orsos, will be based out of the Standard Hotel, with events taking place at the New York Public Library, Cooper Union, the 92nd Street Y and elsewhere. Mr. White's sex event, which, according to a news release, will feature ''celebrated members'' of the fashion and music worlds, will take place in the Standard's rooftop bar, Le Bain (French for ''the bath''). This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Add to the already crowded list of summer music festivals a new one destined for Governors Island, just off the southern tip of Manhattan. The inaugural Governors Ball Music Festival is scheduled to take place on the island, where Ronald Reagan once met with Mikhail Gorbachev, on June 18. It will offer a stylistically mixed bill, with a variety of indie rock, electronica, dance and hip-hop acts booked to perform. Headlining acts include Girl Talk; Pretty Lights; and Big Boi, of Outkast. Tickets are scheduled to go on sale on Thursday. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Joanne Tarzian's friends are all telling her to open a store. And it is easy to see why. In 1997, Ms. Tarzian joined her sister, who was running her father's neighborhood kitchenware store in New York. Over the next 11 years, she bought out her sister and transformed the store into a modern mecca for both gourmet and aspiring cooks. She ultimately sold the store and moved to Chicago to pursue a new opportunity working for a housewares manufacturer. It is three years later and things did not work out as planned. Her job was eliminated because of the recession and, like many people, she has been left to ponder her next move. She started to think that one of her options might be to open a store in Chicago. She is getting plenty of advice, and it has all pointed in the same direction. Two chief executives who know her skills, drive and personality have encouraged her to, ''Get it done.'' When she shows some anxiety about taking the inevitable risks, they insist, ''Just do it!''

The United States economy can't seem to catch a break. On Friday, the federal government revised its calculation of fourth-quarter growth to 2.8 percent from 3.2 percent. In the Weekend Business podcast, Catherine Rampell explains why: the turmoil in the Middle East has sent oil prices soaring. Investors fear that the unrest will spread to other countries, further disrupting production. In the United States, major cutbacks by state and local governments and threats of federal cutbacks are throwing more workers into the unemployment pool. Taken together, the uncertainty means businesses are unlikely to invest, let alone hire more workers.

In my column this week I examined the work of an organization called Youth Villages, which offers intensive in-home services to help children in the foster care system return to their families, or extended families, wherever it is possible to do so safely. My point was to highlight the fact that this approach, which is vastly underutilized and underfunded, is proving to be superior to the current practices in the child welfare system. It's now common for youth to remain in foster care or residential treatment for years. When they age out of these systems, many are unable to live successfully as adults.

Frederick Douglass drew on many influences during his life as an orator, journalist and anti-slavery activist. Few, however, are more unlikely than the man he met in 1845, during a two-year lecture tour of Ireland, Scotland and England: Daniel O'Connell.

This is the inaugural edition of a new feature we'll be running to highlight reactions from around the web (positive, negative, indifferent and otherwise) to posts here at FiveThirtyEight. Over the years, one of the charges against the murderous regime of Colonel Muammar el-Qaddafi was that state funds were being used to further the footballing career of his third-oldest son, Al Saadi. He was once thought to run the Libyan Football Federation. It is hard to know if Libyan football will survive revolution and civil war, but it is worth telling the story, again, of Saadi's surreal, so-called career in Italian football.

Donatella Versace was back in the family palazzo tonight, on a baroque carpeted runway, with members of Duran Duran in the front row, but the collection didn't vibrate with that extra feeling. Still, this was a solid showing of sharp tailoring, with belted coats streaked with gold buttons, and imaginative use of the baroque motifs that her brother Gianni loved to extravagance. Ms. Versace wisely turned the detail into abstract swirls set into coats and mini sheaths, sometimes interpreted with a coiling bit of colored python on a knee-length black or white sheath.

Retail C.D.S.? The Chicago Board of Options Exchange will soon begin trading credit event binary options. "In essence these will be like credit default swaps, accessible to everyone, which will have a $1,000 payoff per contract in the event of a bankruptcy before contract expiration ..What this will do is to revolutionize the shorting aspect of trading, as there will be no borrowing need to express a bearish outlook on a company, and no possibility for State Street, BoNY or your favorite repo desk to pull your borrow from underneath your feet thus forcing a short squeeze. In essence, this will be a marginable equity product trading as a credit derivative." Zero Hedge

It will have its premiere in April on GSN, the game show network.

CAIRO -- I've been on the phone today again with people in the Tripoli area in Libya, and I had an inquiry that goes to the heart of the need for NATO, the United States and Europe to move more forcefully. Several Libyan navy ships were ordered to bombard the city of Benghazi, which has been liberated by rebels. The ships' officers don't want to do that and don't like Qaddafi, and they're also fearful that if they attack Benghazi they'll be attacked right back by shore batteries. They would like to make a run for Malta and defect, but they fear that the Libyan air force is watching them and will bomb them if they head in that direction. And the commanding officers also aren't entirely sure who on board is trustworthy and who isn't. They're in a bind.

Dogged by a virus and his back ailment, James Levine has yet again canceled a performance. The Boston Symphony Orchestra, where Mr. Levine is music director, said he was withdrawing from Friday's concert. Sean Newhouse, an assistant conductor, will take his place in leading Mahler's Symphony No. 9 at Symphony Hall in Boston. Mr. Levine is also music director of the Metropolitan Opera. He has canceled three performances with the Met since Jan. 24, although his absences had not been blamed on back problems. Mr. Levine had major spine surgery in April. The Boston Symphony on Friday said he was "experiencing ill effects from a recent procedure addressing his ongoing back issues, further complicated by a viral infection."

Like an early spring bud poking out of a thicket, a compromise emerged on Thursday in one of the intertwined legal battles that pit California's major agricultural and urban water users against federal scientists and environmentalists. For the moment, both sides agree on how to protect the endangered delta smelt while managing water deliveries through the West Coast's largest and most degraded estuary, the delta where the Sacramento and San Joaquin rivers meet.

On television series like "Buffy" and "Dollhouse," Eliza Dushku was perfectly comfortable holding her own against tough guys, and maybe throwing a punch or two when the situation required it. So her next role is a bit of a departure, and not only because she isn't called upon to swing her fists. In the boxing video game Fight Night Champion, which EA Sports will release for the Xbox 360 and PlayStation3 consoles on Tuesday, Ms. Dushku plays the daughter of an unscrupulous fight promoter, and finds herself drawn into an intrigue involving her father and an up-and-coming boxer (played by the actor and athlete LaMonica Garrett). The story, which is told in movie-style sequences that unfold between the game's playable boxing matches, is written by Will Rokos, an Academy Award-nominated writer and producer of "Monster's Ball," and represents the latest effort to bridge the worlds of gaming and cinema. These sequences (which were created using 3-D motion-capture technology) also allowed Ms. Dushku to play a character who was very much herself and yet as unearthly as anything seen on a Joss Whedon show.

There are plenty of reasons to venture off Milan's fashion week treadmill. For starters, dozens of outstanding museums dot the city, including the new Museo del Novecento (Palazzo dell'Arengario), which opened in December. The collection of mainly Italian painting and sculpture - like Pirandello and Morandi - occupies the Palazzo dell'Arengario, which was gutted to make room for a giant white spiral ramp that feeds into linear white gallery spaces. Attached is the instant hot-spot, Ristorante Giacomo all'Arengario. If you can get a table, I applaud you.

My wife and I were in London recently, and on our way to an excellent exhibition at the Whitechapel Gallery, we stopped for coffee and a snack at St. John Bread and Wine. Options included a seed cake, something I had only seen referenced in 19th-century novels. The St. John version was so simple and delicious that I decided to try making it at home. Dean Baker points us to Feyrer and Sacerdote, who use cross-state variation in stimulus spending per capita to estimate the employment effects of the stimulus. They find a clear positive effect: states that got more money per person did better on jobs. And as Baker points out, the national effects must have been larger, since some money spent in New Jersey presumably creates jobs in New York and vice versa.

These days, Mitch Daniels is being held up as an icon of fiscal responsibility. There are a lot of reasons to question his actual stewardship in Indiana; but what I can't forget is his key role in the squandering of the fiscal surplus Bush inherited. It wasn't just that he supported the Bush tax cuts; the excuses he made for that irresponsibility were stunningly fraudulent.

One of the best things about my business is the variety of phone calls I get. My husband and I frequently look at each other at the office and say, "I wonder who's going to call today." It could be a business owner we met three years ago who is ready to talk about selling, or perhaps a referral from an interesting or unexpected source. There is, however, one particular type of phone call that I've come to dread -- the ones from buyers who say they are looking for a business to buy as a passive investment.

Tom Ford likes his ladies (and gents) to show more than a little skin, so it's no surprise that he decided to expand his beauty franchise with the Neroli Portofino Collection, a sexy-smelling line of bath and body products that are meant to evoke the fragrant orange groves and jet-set élan of the Italian Mediterranean. (The leisurely scent of money, in other words.) Intended to be unisex - the ad campaign, shot by Ford, depicts a boy and girl getting down and dirty in the shower - the collection contains a moisturizer, shower gel, body oil (shown here; $70), body scrub and soap, and will be available April 1 at Bergdorf Goodman.

Derrick Wiggins, 44, began his daily tweeting at 5:41 Wednesday morning, and it wasn't about the quality of his French roast coffee or his favorite ''American Idol'' contestant. It was to let his roughly 3,800 followers know that he had woken up safely in the New York City Rescue Mission, a drop-in shelter on Lafayette Street, and eaten breakfast there.

Felix Hernandez is one of baseball's best young pitchers, but when he arrives at the United States Embassy in Caracas, Venezuela, before the start of spring training each year, he has to walk through a metal detector and submit to being fingerprinted -- like every other applicant for a visa to work in this country. The reward for Hernandez, the reigning American League Cy Young Award winner, who is in camp with the Seattle Mariners, is permission to play in the United States. But for others, obtaining that coveted seal in the passport can be an adventure. The words ''pitchers and catchers report'' are music to the ears of fans, but at the start of every season several players fail to report on time because of difficulty securing visas.

GERCHICK--Ruth, 84, of New York City passed away peacefully on Wednesday, February 23. She is survived by her sister Leah Fritz, children Mark Gerchick and Anina Gerchick, and four grandchildren. Services will be held at 10:15am, Sunday, February 27, at "The Riverside", 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

A ''State by State'' legislative roundup on Thursday with an article about discord between union workers and some state legislators in Wisconsin, Ohio and Indiana referred incorrectly to a proposed bill in Indiana. The legislation would bar any requirement that employees in unionized, private-sector workplaces pay any union dues or fees; it would not prohibit making union membership a prerequisite for employment in the private sector.

EARL--Consuelo Vanderbilt, a great-great-granddaughter of Commodore Cornelius Vanderbilt, died on February 21, 2011, at the age of 107. Mrs. Earl was a long-time resident of Ridgefield, CT. Commodore Vanderbilt was an American financier who amassed a great fortune in railroad and shipping interests and founded the Vanderbilt family in this country. Mrs. Earl's father, William Kissam Vanderbilt, Jr., like his father, William Kissam Vanderbilt, was President of the New York Central Railroad. Her mother, Virginia Graham Fair, was the daughter of United States Senator James G. Fair of Nevada, a forty-niner from the time of the California gold rush and one of the "Silver Kings" who developed the Comstock Lode in Nevada. Mrs. Earl was devoted to the welfare of animals and was a prominent breeder of skye terriers. She was the widow of N. Clarkson Earl, Jr., who died in 1969. Mrs. Earl's first marriage was to the late Earl E. T. Smith, who was United States Ambassador to Cuba when Fidel Castro came to power. Mrs. Earl is survived by her daughter from her marriage to Ambassador Smith, Virginia Consuelo Smith Burke of Palm Beach, FL, seven grandchildren and 18 great-grandchildren. Her daughter, Iris Smith Christ, predeceased her. Funeral service and burial will be private. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Animal Medical Center, 510 East 62nd St, New York, NY 10021 or Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Ave., New York, NY 10065, would be appreciated.

An obituary on Thursday about the corporate lawyer Joseph H. Flom misstated the location of Townsend Harris High School when he graduated, in 1940. The school, now in Queens, was in Manhattan at that time.

A picture caption on Thursday with the continuation of an article about Wisconsin and Indiana legislators who have fled to Illinois to block the passage of bills that restrict public-sector unions and collective-bargaining rights misidentified the state representative from Indiana who was shown. She is Representative Vanessa Summers, not Representative Terri Austin.

State legislation that would have forced the University of Iowa to sell Jackson Pollock's ''Mural'' - an 8-by-20-foot painting valued at more than $100 million - to raise money for the school has been dropped, The Des Moines Register reported. State Representative Scott Raecker introduced the bill this month as a way to create an endowment to pay for as many as 1,000 full student scholarships a year, but the proposal drew widespread criticism. David Miles, the president of the Board of Regents, State of Iowa, described the bill as ''a profoundly bad idea,'' one that was examined by the board in 2008 and ''determined to be not in the best interests of the University of Iowa or the state.'' Mr. Raecker told the student newspaper The Daily Iowan that he still believed the painting should be sold but said that the issue had become ''so polarized that reaching consensus is unlikely.'' ''I'm a firm believer in the legislative process,'' he added, ''and further discussion of the sale of the Pollock painting will not be moved forward in the legislature this year.'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.
An Op-Ed article on Thursday, about Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya, incorrectly described the death of President Gamal Abdel Nasser of Egypt. He died of a heart attack; he was not assassinated.

German prosecutors are broadening their inquiry into Porsche, threatening the luxury carmaker's merger with Volkswagen. On Thursday, state authorities said they were investigating former Porsche executives for possible market manipulation, breach of trust and credit fraud. The company officials include a former chief executive, Wendelin Wiedeking, and a former chief financial officer, Holger P. Harter, according to a person with direct knowledge of the matter.

FLOM--Joseph H. It is with great sadness that The City College of New York marks the death of Joseph H. Flom, Class of 1948, even as we celebrate the life of one of our most illustrious graduates. Having had to leave the College to serve in World War II, Flom went directly into Harvard Law School immediately after the war. He was awarded his long-awaited Bachelor's Degree by City College in 2003; in 2004, he received the President's Medal and in 2005, the Honorary Doctor of Laws Degree, Honoris Causa, from his alma mater. On a personal note, President Lisa Staiano-Coico said that Joe Flom's infectious enthusiasm in support of our students' success and his deep and creative thoughtfulness about how to help them achieve that success -- placed him among the greatest friends to any college that she had ever known. In the 61 years since he was hired as the first associate at the law firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher, and Flom, Joe Flom built the law firm into to one of the largest and most widely admired firms in the world. Skadden Arps has consistently been ranked at the top of every list of the best law firms, and he has been described as "the best lawyer of his generation." As one of the charter signatories of the American Bar Association's pro bono challenge, Flom led the way in setting the industry standard for commitment to pro bono service. Under his leadership, Skadden Arps was one of the first law firms to hire a full-time senior attorney whose primary responsibilities include the coordination of pro bono efforts, and his New York office now places attorneys in the New York Legal Aid Society and The Lawyers Alliance of New York. In addition, in 1988 he established the Skadden Fellowship Foundation in recognition of the dire need for greater funding for graduating law students who wish to devote their professional lives to providing legal services to the poor, the elderly, the homeless and the disabled, as well as those deprived of their civil or human rights. The Skadden Fellows Program, described by The Los Angeles Times as a "legal peace corps," gives Fellows the freedom to pursue public interest work, and more than 90% of its graduates continue working in the public interest. Joe Flom's service to City College has been quiet but unwavering over a lifetime of professional success. His support of City College's Honors Program, Center for Mathematics Education, and Emergency Fund through the Flom and Petrie Foundations exemplifies the scope and depth of his determination to give future generations the opportunities that he had. In 2005, as a special present for his 80th birthday, his fellow partners at Skadden Arps joined together to endow the Joseph H. Flom Award for Academic Excellence at The City College of New York. The Flom Prize, as it is called, is awarded annually to the most outstanding graduate of the class. Previous recipients have included CCNY Rhodes Scholars Lev Sviridov and David Bauer. In 2008, together with his colleagues at Skadden Arps, Flom established the groundbreaking Skadden Arps Honors Program in Legal Studies at City College with a $10 million grant. The Skadden Arps Program seeks to help address a national problem and increase the number of individuals from populations currently underrepresented in law school and the legal profession. The Program provides talented students of low income status and diverse backgrounds with the tools, experience and education necessary to succeed in law school and ultimately a legal career.He served as a highly regarded leading member of the City College 21st Century Foundation Board. In 2004, Joe Flom's alma mater presented him with the President's Medal for Distinguished Achievement and Public Service to the City of New York and The City College of New York. In 2005, the City College of New York awarded him the Doctor of Laws Degree, Honoris Causa. Our sincere condolences go out to his wife, Judi Sorenson Flom, his sons Jason and Peter Flom, his daughter Nancy Laing, and his six grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. His contributions to the profession of law and to a just society will forever remain a beacon to the students, faculty, and alumni of the City College and to the countless lives he transformed. Lisa Staiano-Coico, President, The City College of New York

With time running out before Hollywood's big party, perhaps you're still struggling to complete that Oscar ballot. Who better to help than some famous movie buffs? Melena Ryzik, a k a the Carpetbagger, has spoken with figures from the media and entertainment worlds for their insights. Here are snippets of those chats, which appear in full at nytimes.com/carpetbagger. Then click over to oscars.nytimes.com/ballot to see other celebrity picks and to make your choices. Katie Couric

Two thieves were arrested last week trying to break apart an important 20-foot-tall statue of the pharaoh Ramses II embedded in a quarry in the southern city of Aswan, Egypt's antiquities minister, Zahi Hawass, said in a phone interview. Mr. Hawass said that the thieves wrongly believed that the statue was hollow and had gold hidden inside it. They were caught by guards at the site, he said, comparing the thieves to the people who looted the Egyptian Museum on Jan. 28. Those looters were also looking for gold, according to Mr. Hawass, and for a fictitious substance called red mercury that is believed by ''ignorant people'' to have been used in mummification and to have magical properties. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

ALTMAN--Shirley, 74, of Croton-on-Hudson, New York died on February 22 from Leukemia. She is survived by her husband of 55 years William, and her daughters Meryl of Greencastle, Indiana and Janet of Miami Beach. A funeral service will be held on Sunday, February 27, at Beecher Funeral Home, 418 Bedford Rd, Pleasantville, NY.

KRIPALANI--Mangho C.,resident of New York City, passed away from natural causes on Monday, February 21, 2011. A private service for family members is being held today, Friday, February 25, 2011. Mangho (popularly known as Mangha) Kripalani was born in Karachi, Pakistan, on June 8, 1924. One of nine children born to Chetanram and Rukmani Kripalani, he was the second oldest of five brothers, all of whom were born before the four sisters who followed them. The family moved to Bombay, India right after the Partition in 1947. Following his wife-to-be, Ishu Mirchandani, Mangha migrated to the United States in 1957 and very soon was proud to be called a "New Yorker" and loved the sights and sounds of New York City. Several years later, now married and raising a young family, he sponsored most of his brothers and sisters who all wished to migrate to the U.S. In addition, many other relatives, including cousins, nieces, nephews and/or their children followed in his path. He was an extremely loving husband, father, brother and grandfather. A widower since 1971, he is survived in his immediate family by his two sons, Sanjay and Ranjit Kripalani; a daughter-in-law, Kerstin Tibbetts Kripalani; and two loving grandchildren, Serena and Marisa Kripalani.

SULZBERGER--Judith, M.D. The Judith Sulzberger M.D. Genome Center of Columbia University and the Columbia Initiative in Systems Biology mourn the loss of our dearest friend and benefactor, Judith Sulzberger. Judy helped create the Genome Center and her encouragement and support have further inspired our efforts to create a new research initiative at the Columbia University Medical Center. We will miss her deeply and will always appreciate her remarkable vision, her love of fundamental biomedical research, and her true friendship. Andrea Califano and Barry Honig

An article on Feb. 15 about the role of Facebook in the revolts that have toppled governments in Tunisia and Egypt, referred imprecisely to the policy of Saudi Arabia regarding domestic access to Facebook. While Saudi Arabia has temporarily limited such access in the past, it is not currently doing so.

Nate Silver is providing awards-season insight for Carpetbagger leading up to the 83rd Academy Awards on Feb. 27. Mr. Silver is the author of The Times's FiveThirtyEight blog, which is devoted to the analysis of statistics and data in politics and other areas. Two years ago, I tried to predict the Oscar winners for New York Magazine by crunching data from the last 30 years of awards history. The project was a mixed success. I got 4 out of 6 categories right, an acceptable score on paper. But several of the choices (like ''Slumdog Millionaire'' for Best Picture) were giveaways and conversely, the system's longshot pick -- Taraji P. Henson for her role in ''The Curious Case of Benjamin Button'' -- was a total flop.

11:33 p.m. | Updated CBS and the television production studio Warner Brothers have decided to shut down production of the hit comedy ''Two and a Half Men,'' the companies said Thursday, after the show's star, Charlie Sheen, attacked the creator of the show, Chuck Lorre, in two incendiary interviews. In a terse statement, CBS and Warner Brothers, which produces the show, said, ''Based on the totality of Charlie Sheen's statements, conduct and condition, CBS and Warner Brothers Television have decided to discontinue production of 'Two and a Half Men' for the remainder of the season.''

Flom, who served as a member of the Barnard Board of Trustees from 1983 to 1993. We honor his legacy as a pioneering force in the field of corporate law, and express our gratitude for his commitment to Barnard. Jolyne Caruso-FitzGerald Chair, Board of Trustees Debora Spar President

WEITZ--Robert M.,93, on February 23, 2011. Husband for 67 years to the late Dorothy. Father of Saul Weitz and Anne Weitz Hamburger, father-in-law of Linda Amrani and David Hamburger. Grandfather of Joel Hamburger, Debbie Hamburger Farkas and Benjamin Weitz. Great-grandfather of Dahlia Bea and Rosella Dorothy Farkas. Bob lived all of his life in New York and attended DeWitt High School in the Bronx. He was a graduate of the City College of New York and Brooklyn Law School. He served in the US Army during 1945-1946. In addition to his own practice, Bob worked as an attorney for the Corporation Counsel of New York and General Counsel for the City Commission on Human Rights, participating in discrimination cases on behalf of African-Americans against Chase Manhattan Bank, NYU and the New York Philharmonic among others. Bob is remembered with love and devotion by his entire family. Service: Sunday, February 27th, 11:15am, "The Riverside" 76th St. at Amsterdam Ave.

The insurer American International Group reported a $2.2 billion adjusted loss for its fourth quarter on Thursday, as it prepares to sell a big portion of the government's stake in the company that was gained as part of a huge taxpayer-financed bailout. The loss, reported as an after-tax operating loss and driven by accounting charges, amounted to $16.20 a share, widening from $9.98 a share in the quarter a year ago. Yet the company also recorded $17.2 billion in gains from asset sales, including two big international life insurance units.

With some tours, you wonder what songs will appear on the set list; for this one, we wonder what they'll serve at the concession stands. Anthony Hopkins, who has variously cooked up the liver of a census taker and the brain matter of Ray Liotta in his onscreen capacity as Dr. Hannibal Lecter, plans to take on more digestible material in a series of concerts featuring his own musical compositions. BBC News reported that Mr. Hopkins will participate in the City of Birmingham Symphony Orchestra's summer tour of Britain, on which the orchestra will perform the original scores he created for his films ''August'' and ''Slipstream,'' as well as a new work by the actor. The orchestra, conducted by Michael Seal, will also play selections from the scores of Mr. Hopkins's best-known films, including ''The Remains of the Day'' and ''The Silence of the Lambs,'' and Mr. Hopkins will discuss his music and creative process (and who knows, maybe even favorite recipes) with Tommy Pearson, a producer of the concerts. There was no immediate announcement if the concert series might come to the United States or if Mr. Hopkins might take a brief detour to the Bahamas to have an old friend for dinner. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

When his time behind the wheel at ''Driving Miss Daisy'' comes to an end, James Earl Jones need not resort to reciting Justin Bieber lyrics for fun and profit (unless he wants to), as his next term of office on Broadway has been decided: Mr. Jones, a Tony Award winner for ''Fences'' and ''The Great White Hope,'' will next portray a former United States president in the revival of ''Gore Vidal's The Best Man,'' a political play scheduled for spring of next year. Press representatives for the revival said on Thursday that Mr. Jones will play Arthur Hockstader, a Truman-esque chief executive deciding between endorsing the potential presidential nominees William Russell and Joe Cantwell. When ''The Best Man'' was first presented on Broadway in 1960 (and made into a film in 1964), Russell was perceived as an analogue for Adlai Stevenson and Cantwell as an amalgam of John F. Kennedy and Richard M. Nixon; a 2000 Broadway revival, starring Charles Durning as Hockstader, Spalding Gray as Russell and Chris Noth as Cantwell, seemed to have its eye on the real-life contest between Al Gore and George W. Bush. Michael Wilson (''The Orphans' Home Cycle'') will direct the 2012 production, though its producers have not yet announced their nominees to play Russell and Cantwell. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

WARREN--Irwin. Creator of some of the nation's most successful advertising campaigns, passed away at his home in Manhattan on December 11, 2010, at the age of 71. Cause of death was an aortic aneurysm. During an advertising career spanning more than 40 years, Mr. Warren worked at Doyle Dane Bernbach, BBDO, and other leading agencies, before moving to McCann Erickson, the world's largest advertising agency, where he retired as senior creative director in 2006. Notable campaigns and clients included Major League Baseball, Johnson & Johnson, Nestle, Unilever ("I Can't Believe It's Not Butter"), Lowe's, Campbell's Soup and Volkswagen. The elegant simplicity of his VW ads for DDB in the late 1960's earned their inclusion in the Museum of Modern Art's permanent advertising collection. Mr. Warren was born in St. Paul, Minnesota in 1939. Because his father was killed in an auto accident before his birth, Mr. Warren's mother, a concert pianist, raised him alone for several years before she re-married. Mr. Warren credited St. Paul Academy, where he completed high school, with developing in him the writing skills and intellectual rigor that he regarded as the keys to his success. He attended Colorado College and the University of Minnesota, before beginning his advertising career. Mr. Warren's marriage ended in divorce; there were no children. One of Mr. Warren's favorite campaigns was the long-running, very popular "Taster's Choice Couple" series that ran in the late 1990's. Each new installment generated extensive publicity, usually including an exclusive Today Show interview with Mr. Warren, who unveiled the latest 30-second plot twist. After recruiting Johnson & Johnson to McCann, Mr. Warren designed a campaign, which advanced no products, but stressed the company's long-term involvement with families, and dealt with such subjects as getting children to laugh; encouraging them to try to achieve; and dealing with being different. The company was deluged with requests from parents, schools, and organizations for DVDs of these spots. One McCann colleague recalled Mr. Warren as both brilliant and stubborn, and "enormously loyal to his clients and his friends. His work was always smart, hard-working and stylish," he said. Outside of work, he served as an energetic fund-raiser and board member of Riverside Park Fund on New York's West Side, helping to drive its rejuvenation from a tawdry, needle-strewn place to a safe and attractive park fit for families. It is now one of only eight officially designated scenic landmarks in the City of New York. He was a voracious reader and a knowledgeable collector of antique furniture. After private funeral services, a memorial service will be announced at a later date. Donations in Mr. Warren's name may be made to Team Jim Scholarship, c/o New Canaan Community Foundation, PPO Box 1285, New Canaan, CT 06840. Mr. Warren is survived by his brothers, Adrian of Tucson, Robert, San Francisco and Joel, Los Angeles, his niece Rachel Warren, his nephews Alex Warren and Samuel Warren, and his godchildren Chris, Oie, A.J. and Molly McKennan.

3:54 p.m. | Updated The founding president of the Seaport Museum New York, which in recent weeks lost a third of its trustees and furloughed half its staff, has called for the resignation of the museum's current president, Mary Pelzer, and its chairman, Frank J. Sciame. In a letter to Ms. Pelzer that he shared with The New York Times, the former president, Peter Stanford, said that the museum needed new leadership to survive. He wrote that Ms. Pelzer's and Mr. Sciame's credibility had been damaged by ''concealment'' of its financial problems, and that the ''overall direction of the Seaport Museum has been neglectful of its principal physical asset,'' its historic ships. Mr. Sciame, a real estate developer, has lent the museum $3 million in the last year to cover operating expenses. ''Mr. Sciame and Ms. Pelzer are extremely surprised and deeply disappointed by these inaccurate comments,'' said Adam Pockriss of Rubenstein Communications and a spokesman for the museum. Neither Ms. Pelzer nor Mr. Sciame returned phone calls. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

We will remember him always for his strength, vision, and philanthropic spirit. Todd J. GREENE--Joan Hope Ewers, 79, died, on February 14, 2011 at home in Riverdale, NY. A winter resident of Palm Beach, she will be buried with deep love and respect at Arlington National Cemetery. Bright, warm, and wonderful, with class, Joan was the trusted assistant of Dr. Jules Stein, Chairman of Universal Movie Studios, at his Eye Institute at UCLA. Here she hosted luminaries such as William Randolph Hearst and Ross Perot. Mrs. Greene was employed at the New York Times, Life Magazine, and later was manager of the Riverdale, N.Y. Tennis Club. Joan attended Converse College and the Juilliard School as a concert pianist. Her keyboard mates were Van Cliburn, John Browning and Daniel Pollack, all of whom received lessons from the renowned Madame Rosina Lhevinne. Here she accompanied Leontyne Price. We shall remember the beautiful melody of Joan's life. She had a deep love for her husband and family that was unconditional and irresistible. Joan said, "I'll love you, just as much if you have only $5 instead of 5 trillion."' Her virtuous goal in life was simply to love and to be loved. She taught love by example. For 48 years Joan was totally devoted to her first and only love, her husband Dr. Robert Ford Greene, college Athletic Director and author of tennis instruction books. Also surviving is, Joan's caring and good brother, Quinto Vallei, Jr., of Richmond Virginia where she was raised to become a true Southern lady. We'll miss her so much. Good-bye buddy. In Joan's memory you could make the following free and human gift to mankind: Give love to your dearest and kindness to all.

AZUAJE--Jose Colmenares, Venezuelan Educator, father, grandfather and great-grand father, 95. Jose Colmenares Azuaje died peacefully at his home in Caracas, Venezuela on Sunday, February 20, 2011. Services will be held in Funeraria La Monumental, Capilla del Cementerio del Este in Caracas at 11am on Tuesday February 22, and the internment will follow at Cementerio del Este at the side of his beloved Wife for 51 years Isabel. Who predeceased him in 1993. Jose was born in December 26, 1916 at Boraure, Estado Yaracuy, Venezuela, and lived there before moving to Caracas to obtain an education. He got interested in education affairs and worked through the ranks until becoming Director for Commercial Education at the Department of Education in Venezuela, and Vice Principal at the Instituto de Comercio Santos Michelena in Caracas. He was a devoted husband, father and grandfather. He liked playing baseball and soccer, and got to be an AA baseball player and amateur soccer player. He played in Caracas local teams among them the Hipodromo La Rinconada Baseball Team. He was a New York Yankees fan and visited numerous times the old stadium. He also wrote poems and always had great stories to tell from the good old times. He moved to the US and became a permanent resident and lived in Florida, Tennessee and New Jersey, loving his grandchildren and great-grandchildren. He went back to Caracas last year and was hoping to come back to the US this year. Those of us that will grieve and celebrate Jose's life are: His Sister Paula, from Boraure, Venezuela. His children: Eliecer J. and Cristina from La Asuncion, Venezuela; Narses J. from Old Bridge, NJ; Igor J. from Caracas, Venezuela; Lisbeth M. and Ismael from Spring Hill, TN; and Abner J. from Dania Beach, Fl. His daughters-in-law: Linda B, Ana Maria G, Madeleine R., Mariela R., and Angelica C. His grandchildren: Juan Carlos and Megan, from Dallas, Texas; Cristina, from Dallas, Texas; Anabel and George from Coconut Creek, FL; Reynaldo and Denise from Spring Hill, TN; Alejandra from Coconut Creek, Fl; Leah R. from Holmdel, NJ; Diana and Simon from Miami, Fl; Maria Elisa from Miami, Fl; Cynthia from Miami, FL; Miguel from Barcelona, Spain; Angie from Buenos Aires, Argentina; Abner Johanes, from the US Truman. His great-grandchildren: David from Miami, FL; Miguel from Miami, FL; Alessandra from Coconut Creek, FL and Isabella from Coconut Creek, FL. Condolences to the family can be sent to n.colmenares@att.net

FRIEDLANDER--Jennie E.,of Great Neck, New York, and formerly of Far Rockaway, Queens, and Boro Park, Brooklyn, passed away peacefully at the age of 105, on February 21, 2011. She was the widow of the late Rabbi J.W. Friedlander, who had been Principal of Yeshivas Ohel Torah and Executive Vice President of Yeshiva Torah Vodaath. When her husband served as president of the Young Israel of Wavecrest and Bayswater in the 1960's, she partnered with him to serve as President of the synagogue's sisterhood. A family matriarch, she was clear-minded to the end, and was the keeper and recounter of family lore extending back to her ancestral roots in czarist Russia. She is survived by her children Dr. Cynthia (and Dr. Alvin) Engel, of Sharon, Massachusetts, Lynda (and Burton) Mandelbaum, of Great Neck, New York, and New York State Supreme Court Justice Mark (and Mindy) Friedlander, of Riverdale, New York; as well as by her grandchildren Michael Engel, Sheryl (and Josh) Olshin, Avi (and Alissa) Ossip, Sharon (and Sol) Merkin, Chayim Ossip, Eric Friedlander, Ari (and Stephanie) Friedlander, and Sima (and Jonathan) Burstein; and her great-grandchildren Amos Engel, Romy Engel, Emma Olshin, Adam Ossip, Tamar Ossip, Jonathan Ossip, Jonathan (and Jordana) Merkin, James Merkin, Philip Merkin, Samuel Merkin, Isaac Merkin, and Moses Burstein.

GOTTLIEB--Jack. The Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion family records with sorrow the death of Jack Gottlieb, an accomplished composer whose erudition and exquisite taste were superbly blended into an impressive artistic persona. He was privileged to study with the masters of composition, including Aaron Copland and Leonard Bernstein, and his works were performed worldwide. He was the first recipient of the Ahad Ha'am Award from The Center of Jewish Creativity and Culture. He influenced generations of students blessed to call him their teacher and served as our Composer in Residence and the first full time faculty member of The Debbie Friedman School of Sacred Music. May we find comfort together with all those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi David Ellenson, President Irwin Engelman, Chairman of the Board of Governors

My Sunday column notes that there is a fair amount of anxiety about what a democratic revolution will mean in the Arab world, and specifically about whether the Arab world (and other less developed parts of the world) are ready for democracy. I find this entire debate patronizing, especially after witnessing the incredible courage of democracy activists in recent weeks. Sure, there are plenty of rough spots ahead --but if people are dying for democracy, who are we to say that they're not ready for it? Read the column and post your thoughts.

Once seemingly immune to anti-immigrant sentiment, Sweden faces a growing sense that it allowed too many foreigners in.

PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. - The Mets play 36 spring training games this year, and 22 of them are against three of their four National League East rivals, including five of the last six games of the spring. Because of that, Manager Terry Collins said he would have his starting pitchers throw their last starts against minor league competition to prevent the Atlanta Braves, the Washington Nationals and the Florida Marlins from getting too familiar with the pitchers they will face in the regular season.

It is the dream of every sports fan to own his or her favorite team. For Terry Pegula, that dream has come true. Pegula, a Buffalo Sabres fan who had season tickets for 18 years, then became a billionaire in the energy business, completed his purchase of the team from Tom Golisano last week.

Jim Courier is a former No. 1 tennis player who won 23 Tour singles titles, including two French Opens and two Australian Opens, before he retired in 2000. Last October, Courier, 40, was named the captain of the United States Davis Cup team. The first round of the competition begins Friday, with the United States facing Chile in Santiago. JOE BRESCIA

With his punishing topspin ground strokes, Lendl won eight Grand Slam singles titles, reached the final of at least one Grand Slam tournament for 11 straight years (Sampras is the only other man to do that), advanced to 19 Grand Slam finals (only Roger Federer has played in more), and was ranked No. 1 for 270 weeks (only Sampras and Federer have surpassed him). He is also familiar with the Garden: during the 13 years that the Masters Tournament was held there, Lendl reached a record nine straight finals, losing four times (including twice to McEnroe) but winning five (beating McEnroe once).

The German Bundesliga will have four places in the UEFA Champions League starting with the 2012-13 tournament. Its gain will come at the expense of Italy's Serie A, which will have its allotment cut to three based on UEFA's five-year rankings of the leagues' performances in Europe.

The Utah Jazz had an eventful February, losing its longtime coach, Jerry Sloan, to retirement and trading the superstar point guard Deron Williams to the Nets. With all the disarray, it was easy to not notice that as of Friday, the team was still eighth in the Western Conference, meaning if the season ended the Jazz would qualify for the playoffs.

Bumping into an old friend today, I heard him lament that fashion shows had become events - geared to the demands of social media and branding strategies - and had lost their charm. This is not an overnight change, but it feels that way. "Designers are doing what they have to do, and not want they want to do," he said. And many collections this season seem overly influenced by films and fashion of the 60s and 70s. The other night, while searching for a Bob Richardson photograph of Donna Mitchell, I found one of Jill Kennington wearing a beige-pink shag fur coat virtually identical to the one Miuccia Prada showed. Oh, well, I thought. But this habit gives everything a kind of movie-still quality, even when there may not be a direct reference.

SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE - Some days you conquer the puzzle, and some days, as they say, the puzzle conquers you. Although it was immensely enjoyable, I narrowly escaped with my life on this one, and I think it's because 1) this is only the second cryptic I've ever done, and 2) Since the only other cryptic I've solved was by Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon, I feel like I'm more on their wavelength.

Two years ago, Nathalie Yepez - a 29-year-old first generation New Yorker who was born to Dominican parents in the Bronx and grew up in Washington Heights and the East Village - moved back to her mother's house, quit her bartending and waitressing jobs to pursue music full time, and reinvented herself as the singer Maluca Mala. "I thought to myself, Enough is enough!" she recalls. "I'm miserable sitting at home writing music and just talking about it." Mala, who not surprisingly identifies as a "hood hipster," performs a mix of what she calls "ghetto-techno, Latin-dance, hip-hop, rave music." It's a decadent mix that has not gone unnoticed - especially by Lady Gaga, whose beer-cans-as-rollers look in the video for "Telephone" appears to have been inspired by Mala's headgear in her video for "El Tigeraso."

PARIS- Roman Polanski, the 77-year-old director whose film "The Ghost Writer" was snubbed by the Oscars, won a measure of solace on Friday when the French cultural elite showered the thriller with four Césars. The honors (France's version of the Academy Awards) included a best directing nod for Mr. Polanski, who was vigorously supported by French film and political celebrities when he was arrested in September 2009 on a more than 30-year-old sex crime warrant from the United States and jailed and detained in Switzerland until he successfully fended off extradition last July.

8 P.M. (HBO) DATE NIGHT (2010) The professional funny people Steve Carell and Tina Fey (above) portray Claire and Phil Foster, a real estate agent and an accountant with two children and a house in New Jersey who try to spice up their ordinary (read: dull, dull, dull) marriage by dining at an impossible-to-get-into Manhattan restaurant. What they don't count on is being pursued by thugs with guns (Jimmi Simpson and Common) after being mistaken for the blackmailers (James Franco and Mila Kunis) whose reservation they stole. Mark Wahlberg plays a former client, a sort of special ops expert with stellar pecs and a knowledge of Hebrew, to whom Claire turns for help. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott said the film ''is superior to most recent movies of its kind, the marital action comedy. This is not saying much: better than 'The Bounty Hunter' or 'Did You Hear About the Morgans?' is not quite the same as 'good.' '' 10:30 A.M. (13) RELIGION & ETHICS NEWSWEEKLY Kim Lawton reports on churches that are making their own movies in response to their displeasure with those created in Hollywood. In another segment, Bob Abernethy profiles Rabbi A. James Rudin, the former director of national interreligious affairs for the American Jewish Committee and the author of ''Christians & Jews, Faith to Faith: Tragic History, Promising Present, Fragile Future.''

WEITZ--Robert M.,93, on February 23, 2011. Husband for 67 years to the late Dorothy. Father of Saul Weitz and Anne Weitz Hamburger, father-in-law of Linda Amrani and David Hamburger. Grandfather of Joel Hamburger, Debbie Hamburger Farkas and Benjamin Weitz. Great-grandfather of Dahlia Bea and Rosella Dorothy Farkas. Bob lived all of his life in New York and attended DeWitt High School in the Bronx. He was a graduate of the City College of New York and Brooklyn Law School. He served in the US Army during 1945-1946. In addition to his own practice, Bob worked as an attorney for the Corporation Counsel of New York and General Counsel for the City Commission on Human Rights, participating in discrimination cases on behalf of African-Americans against Chase Manhattan Bank, NYU and the New York Philharmonic among others. Bob is remembered with love and devotion by his entire family. Service: Sunday, February 27th, 11:15am, "The Riverside" 76th St. at Amsterdam Ave.

La La Vazquez, the wife of the NBA star Carmelo Anthony, won't just be busy setting up house when the couple moves to New York. She has landed a reality series on VH1, ''La La's Full Court Life,'' which will chronicle the couple's move from Denver. On Monday Mr. Anthony was traded by the Denver Nuggets to the New York Knicks. The 10-episode, half-hour series, which is scheduled to premiere in August, will show Ms. Vazquez, an actress and television personality, as she copes with the demands of career and home in New York. It is a follow-up to ''La La's Full Court Wedding,'' a series about the couple's wedding broadcast last year on VH1. ''Viewers connect with La La because despite the fairy tale wedding and NBA star husband, she is a real, down to earth, hardworking woman who stays true to herself,'' said Jeff Olde, executive vice president for original programming and production at VH1. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

FLOM--Joseph H. I join with all my former partners in mourning the loss of a great lawyer and true friend. I was often touched by his willingness to extend his personal warmth and support to those who needed it most. As great as his talents were as a lawyer, his heart was even greater. Stephen M. Axinn

Dogged by a virus and his back ailment, James Levine has yet again canceled a performance. The Boston Symphony Orchestra, where Mr. Levine is music director, said he was withdrawing from Friday's concert. Sean Newhouse, an assistant conductor, will take his place in leading Mahler's Symphony No. 9 at Symphony Hall in Boston. Mr. Levine is also music director of the Metropolitan Opera. He has canceled three performances with the Met since Jan. 24, although his absences had not been blamed on back problems. Mr. Levine had major spine surgery in April. The Boston Symphony on Friday said he was ''experiencing ill effects from a recent procedure addressing his ongoing back issues, further complicated by a viral infection.'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

KILBOURNE--Edwin. New York Medical College is saddened by the loss of our colleague and friend, Edwin S. Kilbourne, M.D., professor emeritus of microbiology and immunology. A leading authority on influenza, he brought prestige to NYMC through his dedicated efforts to provide recombinant strains used in preparing the annual influenza vaccine, thus helping to ensure an adequate supply worldwide. During the 2009 H1N1 influenza crisis, he was frequently called upon for his expertise and vast knowledge of earlier flu epidemics. He served on many scientific boards and advisory committees, and in 1983 was honored by The New York Academy of Medicine with its highest scientific award. Dr. Kilbourne was a member of the College faculty from 1992 until his retirement in 2002. We will miss his dedication and scientific acumen, and we extend heartfelt condolences to his family. Ronald F. Poe, Chairman Board of Trustees Karl P. Adler, M.D. President and CEO Ralph A. O'Connell, M.D., Provost and Dean School of Medicine Ira Schwartz, Ph.D. Professor and Chairman Department of Microbiology and Immunology

Molly Sweeney will soldier on after all. The widely praised revival of Brian Friel's play about a blind woman who recovers her sight was scheduled to close at the Irish Repertory Theater on West 22nd Street on March 13, but after a little actress-shuffling it will be extended through April 10, the theater announced Monday. Geraldine Hughes, who plays Molly, was unable to remain in an extended production because she is joining the cast of Jez Butterworth's ''Jerusalem,'' which is rehearsing in London and is scheduled to open at the Music Box Theater on Broadway on April 21. So the Irish actress Simone Kirby, who portrayed Molly in a revival at the Curve Theater in Leicester, England, in 2010, has signed on to play the role for the show's final month beginning March 9, joining Jonathan Hogan and Ciaran O'Reilly in the cast.

ABRAMSON--Roslyn, of Bal Harbour, FL, formerly of New Rochelle, NY and prior thereto of Undercliff Avenue, Bronx, NY, died on February 24, 2011, at age 97, following a protracted series of brief illnesses. She was predeceased by her husband of nearly fifty years, Sam H. Abramson, in 1983, her elder son, Edward M. Abramson, in 2001 and her brother, Harry Fish, in 1955. She is survived by her younger son, David A. Abramson, and his wife, Ellen. Also surviving are three grandchildren, Daniel, Deborah and Marc, and their respective spouses; five great-grandchildren Ezra, Levi, Lilah, Sara and Uval; nephews, Jerry and Robert Fish, and their respective wives and children; her husband's grandnephew Hillel Maximon, and his wife; and Edward's widow, Harriet. Roz will always be remembered for her intelligence, wit, and feistiness and as a champion of the underdog. The family has requested that donations in Roslyn's memory be given to American Technion Society (for the benefit of the Technion-Israel Institute of Technology) or the Parkinson's and Movement Disorder Center of NYU Langone Medical School, in either case in support of research in neurodegenerative diseases. Graveside service and interment at Beth El Cemetery, Paramus, NJ, Sunday, February 27, at 1:00pm.

FLOM--Joseph. The Board of Directors of Goddard Riverside Community Center mourn the passing of Joe Flom, a great leader, brilliant attorney, concerned citizen and generous philanthropist.
