SULZBERGER--Judith P. The Rainforest Alliance Board of Directors and staff mark with sadness the passing of Dr. Judith P. Sulzberger, an active board member from 1992 to 2003 and emeritus member thereafter. As one of the organization's earliest benefactors, she helped establish sustainable certification programs and other core projects. A world traveler and science lover, she was a passionate advocate for the rainforest's biodiversity and continued her support and strong interest in our work even after leaving the board. We will miss Judy's brilliant wit and contagious wry humor, as well as her strength, caring and sage counsel. We send our heartfelt condolences to her family. Daniel R. Katz, Chairman Tensie Whelan, President and all of her friends at the Rainforest Alliance

WASSERMAN--Maxine, a long-time resident of East Hills, Long Island passed away Thursday at North Shore University Hospital, Manhasset after a long illness. A wife, mother and grandmother, Mackie, as she was known to the many people who loved her, inspired those around her with her grace, warmth and sense of humor. She gave tirelessly to her family, her neighbors and her friends - and most important of all to the ill children of the Child Life Program at North Shore Hospital, where she was a volunteer for more than three decades and Chairman of the program. In that role, her artwork decorated the rooms of countless ill children and she continually brought smiles and happiness to these beautiful children, with her compassion and creativity. Maxine grew up in Brooklyn and taught school for a few years. As a teenager, she met her long-time husband and the love of her life, Buddy Wasserman, at sleep away camp (Blue Ridge and Equinunk). To this day, the couple has retained many close friends from those cherished camp days. The Wassermans have lived in East Hills for 30 years. Maxine's beloved brother, Bert Grossman, died last year. Maxine is survived by her husband as well as children, Jill Selby of Irvington, NY and Steven and Cathy Wasserman of Manhattan; and two extraordinary grandchildren, Emma Selby of Irvington, NY and Jimmy Wasserman of Manhattan. Funeral services will be held Sunday at Riverside Memorial 55 North Station Plaza Great Neck at 12:30pm. The family is sitting shivah throughout the week at the Wasserman home. Donations in honor of Maxine may be sent to: The Child Life Department of the North Shore University Hospital, 300 Community Drive, Manhasset, NY 11030.

On Wednesday, President Obama directed the Justice Department to stop defending the law that bans federal recognition of same-sex marriages. And while the decision will -- and should -- be celebrated by gay couples across the country, practically speaking, their lives won't change much for some time. After all, the move doesn't actually repeal the so-called Defense of Marriage Act. So same-sex couples will still remain strangers, for the most part, in the eyes of the federal government. Couples will still be unable to jointly file their federal tax returns, and they won't be eligible to receive Social Security benefits based on their spouse's earnings record.

SALTZMAN--Lawrence, 89, of Pompton Plains, NJ, died on February 23, 2011 after a long illness. Born in Brooklyn to Samuel and Celia (Sipowitz) Saltzman, Larry graduated from Brooklyn College with a degree in economics. He served with distinction in the U.S. Army in WWII, attaining the rank of First Lieutenant. Larry enjoyed a long career in the hosiery and ready to wear businesses, rising from salesman to become President of Round-the-Clock Hosiery, a division of International Playtex. An avid boater and fisherman, he retired to Longboat Key, Florida, serving as president of his condominium association for many years. He was also a voracious reader and a longtime member of a Great Books discussion group. In addition to his wife of 60 years, Anita, he is survived by his son and daughter-in-law Edward and Mary Saltzman of New Vernon, NJ, daughter and son-in-law Emily and Stuart Rosen of Avon, CT, grandchildren Jeffrey and Leah Rosen and Madeleine Saltzman, brother and sister-in-law Dr. Marvin and Sylvia Saltzman of Plainville, CT. He was predeceased by his sister and brother-in-law Enid (Saltzman) and Oscar Fienberg. Donations may be made to Iraq/Afghanistan war veterans, www.iava.org, or to the charity of your choosing.

TAMPA, Fla. -- Any proper highlight montage of Andruw Jones's career would begin with video from the opening game of the 1996 World Series and go on to show a dizzying assortment of gravity-defying catches and majestic home runs. Jones, for all of it, would be wearing an Atlanta Braves uniform. His last game with the Braves was in 2007. For the sake of accuracy, Jones has since played for the Los Angeles Dodgers, the Texas Rangers and the Chicago White Sox, adjusting every season to the industry's changing perception of him. A prodigy at 19, a star at 25 and a backup at 31. ''People still think that I'm 19, that I'm going to do the same things that I did back then,'' the 33-year-old Jones said. ''People think you're going to be the same guy for 14 years, and that just doesn't happen.''
International AFGHAN OFFICIALS RELEASE

On television series like ''Buffy'' and ''Dollhouse,''Eliza Dushku was perfectly comfortable holding her own against tough guys, and maybe throwing a punch or two when the situation required it. So her next role is a bit of a departure, and not only because she isn't called upon to swing her fists. In the boxing video game Fight Night Champion, which EA Sports will release for the Xbox 360 and PlayStation3 consoles on Tuesday, Ms. Dushku plays the daughter of an unscrupulous fight promoter, and finds herself drawn into an intrigue involving her father and an up-and-coming boxer (played by the actor and athlete LaMonica Garrett). The story, which is told in movie-style sequences that unfold between the game's playable boxing matches, is written by Will Rokos, an Academy Award-nominated writer and producer of ''Monster's Ball,'' and represents the latest effort to bridge the worlds of gaming and cinema. These sequences (which were created using 3-D motion-capture technology) also allowed Ms. Dushku to play a character who was very much herself and yet as unearthly as anything seen on a Joss Whedon show. Ms. Dushku spoke recently to ArtsBeat about the making of Fight Night Champion and her role in the game, and the burdens of being an able-bodied woman in the entertainment industry. These are excerpts from that conversation.Q.I thought it was very brave of you to allow yourself to be photographed during your motion-capture session with your face covered with all those - uh, what do you call them?A.Dots. It's a very technical name. Motion-cap dots. My makeup artist from ''Dollhouse,'' her name's Tegan, she worked on ''Avatar'' and she worked on the game as well, so that was really fun. Nobody places sexy dots like Tegan. If one dot tries to slip off, she is quick on the draw. She will reattach it. Q.And you wouldn't want a dot to go astray.A.No, that would mean, like, a droopy eyelid. It could send your whole expression off and turn you into another person. It would be a travesty.Q.You grew up just outside of Boston. Were you legally required to appreciate boxing?A.Yeah, pretty much. My dad was from the South End and grew up loving sports and boxing himself. I remember having a Mike Tyson T-shirt back in the day that I used to sleep in. And there some things that Tyson did along the way that I wasn't too psyched to associate myself with. But back in the day, just as a fighter, what a dream that was to watch and root for him.Q.Tell me about your Fight Night character, Megan McQueen. She seems to associate with a lot of unsavory figures.A.It's a gnarly, cutthroat world. She's the only daughter of D. L. McQueen, the shady promoter, and her whole life she's had a loyalty to him, but everything changes when she really gets to see his behavior and what he does to Andre. She's always wanted to be a fighter, but she gets into the managing world when she meets Andre. She sees in him the resilience and the passion, and the redemption that he's seeking, and it's something that appeals to her. And for the first time, she goes against her dad and stands for good.Q.Is there a cheat code that makes her a playable character?A.Oh my gosh, I should totally lie and say there is. Yeah, there's a secret password, so everyone buy the game and try to crack the code because there'll be a payoff on the other side. Ooh, child.Q.How was the experience of working on Fight Night Champion different from other games you've been involved in?A.I hadn't done anything like it. I've done other video-game voices: I started with the Buffy video game, and then I did Saints Row, Yakuza and Wet. I grew up with three older brothers and today my two nephews and my boyfriend's son are video-game-freak teenagers, so it's cool to be able to have them play me. You've got to connect any way you can with teenagers today.

The chart accompanying this column last week shaded Italy's and Spain's math scale scores incorrectly. They should have been included among the ''worst of the worst,'' not merely ''the ''worst.'' In addition, shadings for the United States and Taiwan were reversed. Taiwan should have been among the ''worst of the worst'' for life expectancy at birth, and the United States should have been among the ''worst.'' Finally, the French prison population per 100,000 citizens was incorrect. It is 96, not 365. A corrected version of the chart is available at www.nytimes.com/opinion.

A former employee of the Galleon Group has agreed to testify on behalf of federal prosecutors as they pursue a case against the hedge fund firm's founder, Raj Rajaratnam, according to a person familiar with the case. The whistle-blower testimony is likely to involve statements that the anonymous employee reportedly heard Mr. Rajaratnam make while working at the firm, said the person, who spoke on the condition of anonymity because the details of the case were not public. These comments could support the government's accusations that Mr. Rajaratnam traded on inside information, said the person.

PICKARD--Francine, 86, of Delray Beach, Florida and Great Neck, NY, died peacefully at home on February 2, 2011. She is survived by Leonard, her beloved husband of 66 years, daughters, Janet Pickard Kremenitzer, Maxine Davis, and son Mark Pickard and daughter-in-law Kristina Brennan Pickard. Her greatest joy was seeing and talking to her five wonderful grandchildren: Rebecca Kremenitzer, Jason Pickard, Heather Diamond and husband Adam, David Kremenitzer, and Jared Pickard. Her career ambition as a young woman was to become a lawyer but this plan was interrupted by WWII and the need to contribute to the war effort. Her wedding plans had to be changed many times to accommodate the pending deployment of Leonard to the Pacific theater . She used her accounting skills to earn several advancements and to help support her recently widowed mother, Esther Saltzman. After the war she worked alongside her husband in his fledgling CPA firm and loyally helped him through many difficult tax seasons. Funeral services, Sunday, February 27th, 1:30pm, at Parkside Memorial Chapels, 98-60 Queens Boulevard , Rego Park, NY. Interment will follow at the Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, New York.

Every elevator should be so clean. Not normally the case here, at 555 Roosevelt Drive in the Baruch Houses, the scarred, eastern face of the Lower East Side, its strips of peeling paint the size of loose-leaf paper. Here, the sight of a squeaky-clean elevator - generally treated as a urinal, ashtray and graffiti canvas - arouses suspicion: What happened? It has been almost two weeks since someone in the hallway pressed the button to go up, and the sliding doors opened to reveal the crumpled body of Jomali Morales, 42, a former model whose youthful beauty may have led the police at first to mistakenly put her age at 30. The floor was thick with her blood, and officers would later count 19 stab wounds. The murder was overshadowed by the unrelated citywide manhunt and arrest of a suspect in four other killings. But this case sent ripples through one particular city population: the New York Police Department. Ms. Morales's half-brother, Joseph Vitale, is a 20-year veteran police officer who, assigned to the Manhattan South Task Force, has worked the very area where she lost her life. Perhaps second only to the murder of a fellow officer, in terms of let's-find-this-guy determination, would be the murder of an officer's kid sister, and residents of 555 Roosevelt say detectives have been up and down its halls many times since Feb. 12. There is a $12,000 reward for information. But so far, no arrests and no known suspects. Murder leaves a crater that must be backfilled, starting at the topsoil of the final hours. She was celebrating a birthday she would never reach. She went to work that Friday, Feb. 11, at Just Calm Down, a boutique spa in Chelsea, as she had for almost a year, since returning to New York after a failed relationship in the upstate town of Scotia and moving in, along with her teenage daughter, with her mother on Grand Street. She had old friends from growing up in the neighborhood, and new friends from the spa, and she was starting her night with the latter. ''She told her daughter that she was going to go out with one of the girls from the job,'' said Ms. Morales's mother, Petra Montanez-Vitale. The police said Ms. Morales and others spent part of the night at O'Hanlon's, an Irish bar on East 14th Street. Her daughter, Constance, said she learned at the wake that her mother had met up with friends from high school and that she may have been thrown out of that bar, and may have visited another bar on Avenue C. Whatever dots exist between there and a grimy elevator hard by the F.D.R., Ms. Montanez-Vitale - a 70-year-old woman who refers to the killer as a ''demon'' - has yet to connect them. ''Jomali told her daughter, 'Don't go near the projects,' '' she said. ''And that's not nice to say. There are good people there, and they just can't get out.'' She sighed and repeated a complaint that good people there have made for years: ''There was no cameras at all.'' That Friday night, Ms. Morales did not come home. The next morning, her half-brother - who was 6 when she was born and has only ever thought of her as his sister, not half anything - was doing what many police officers were doing that day: searching for or chasing or cleaning up after Maksim Gelman, the Brooklyn man wanted in a rampage that by its end left four people dead and four wounded. Officer Vitale was securing part of a crime scene when he was called down to the Seventh Precinct station house on Pitt Street. He thought he was in some kind of trouble. The body in the elevator had no identification, and the victim's family was able to confirm she had an Asian-script tattoo that her mother never liked. ''It's supposed to be, in their language, 'beautiful,' '' Ms. Montanez-Vitale said. Ms. Morales's purse was found amid litter in a patch of grass near the front door of the building. The police estimate her time of death to have been a bit before 5 a.m. on Saturday. She had no history with drugs, just a drunken-driving arrest from her time in Scotia. Her family still wonders why she was at the Baruch Houses. She would have been 43 on Sunday.

A front-page article on Tuesday about reaction among private-sector workers in Wisconsin to Gov. Scott Walker's effort to cut benefits and collective-bargaining rights for unionized public employees referred incorrectly to the work history of one person quoted, and also misspelled his surname. While the man, Rich Hahn (not Hahan) described himself to a reporter as a ''union guy,'' he now says that he has worked at unionized factories, but was not himself a union member. (The Times contacted Mr. Hahn again to review his background after a United Auto Workers official said the union had no record of his membership.)

A number of married couples lie to their spouses about their financial behavior, according to a couple of surveys released in the past year. According a December online poll commissioned by ForbesWoman and the National Endowment for Financial Education, and covered in a recent Forbes.com blog post, 31 percent of Americans who have combined their finances said they lied to their spouses about money.

Among the things you'll soon be able to find on every street corner in Manhattan: a Chase bank; a fresh fruit stand; a Duane Reade; and a theater presenting a musical based on Spider-Man. To an embarrassment of riches that already includes ''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark'' (which opens - maybe - at Broadway's Foxwoods Theater on March 15) and ''The Spidey Project: With Great Power Comes Great Responsibility'' (which comes to the Peoples Improv Theater on March 14), you can now add ''Spidermann,'' which will arrive at the Tank on W. 45th Street in Manhattan for three performances beginning March 13, possibly in an attempt to capitalize on the outsize publicity generated by one of the two aforementioned projects. ''Spidermann,'' which was presented earlier this year in Seattle, is the handiwork of Jose Bold, the stage name of the artist John Osebold, and is described in a press release as ''a hastily-constructed abstract musical'' that ''threads together elements of the original comic book story, references to the buzz-heavy Broadway debacle, songs stripped down to their essential core, and dreamlike video sequences to create a new mythology in an art-house style.'' The cast includes Mr. Osebold as the title character; Kirk Anderson as his alter ego, Peter Parkre; Erin Jorgensen and Sara Edwards, who both play the character Mary Jane Taymor; Mark Siano as Radioactive Steve Winwood; and Evan Mosher as Everyone Else.

I hope to be watching the Oscars tonight, at least the red carpet. It starts around 1 a.m. here. Meanwhile, Milan's obsession with the movies this season persists. The music for Missoni this afternoon came from "True Romance" and "Natural Born Killers," and the chaotic, pastel clothes brought to mind Juliette Lewis, though not specifically her character in the Oliver Stone film. The mood was girlish innocence verging to girlish wreck, with long silk-print and knit dresses, impressively fat cardigans, and maxi coats in multi-hued python. The colors seem to flood from a girl's bedroom, or the bathrooms of a 1960s subdivision: baby yellow, mint green, pink, and violet. Angela Missoni threw them together, sometimes causing one to cringe (example: a crinkly violet knit pants outfit with a sick twinkle of Lurex). It was strong and little perverse, thanks to the pastel upchuck. The accessories also pointed to bad movie girls: floppy knit caps and adorable motorcycle boots in a collage of python and colors.
In Zawiya, a city 30 miles west of Tripoli, hundreds of people rejoiced in a central square on Sunday, while opposition leaders in Benghazi started to form a provisional government.

When adding up the benefits from three centuries of species discoveries, I'm tempted to start, and also stop, with Sir Hans Sloane.  A London physician and naturalist in the 18th century, he collected everything from insects to elephant tusks.  And like a lot of naturalists, he was ridiculed for it, notably by his friend Horace Walpole, who scoffed at Sloane's fondness for "sharks with one ear, and spiders as big as geese!"   Sloane's collections would in time give rise to the British Museum, the British Library, and the Natural History Museum, London.  Not a bad legacy for one lifetime.  But it pales beside the result of a collecting trip to Jamaica, on which Sloane also invented milk chocolate.

LOS ANGELES- Oscar loves a Cinderella story, and this year one of the best has belonged to Jacki Weaver. A veteran Australian stage actress, Ms. Weaver hadn't been in a movie in a dozen years and was unknown in the U.S. until she starred in "Animal Kingdom," the Australian indie crime drama from a first-time filmmaker that earned her a best supporting actress nomination. She has been a petite charmer on the circuit all season long. We spoke to her at a party for Sony Pictures Classics, the film's distributor, on Saturday, and she revealed a bit of country pride. "It's the first time an Australian has been nominated in an Australian film since 'Shine,'" she said. Her Australian-designed gown had arrived only hours before, and it, too, was a Cinderella moment. "It takes about six able-bodied people to lift me into my frock," she said. "I'm going to have to lean on my husband walking up the red carpet." As a first-time nominee, Ms. Weaver had no problem admitting that she really, really wanted to win, and sharing details of her acceptance speech strategy.

''The stage was my kingdom, and I ruled,'' said the Queen of Rockabilly, now 73, on her way to a recent guest performance in ''Million Dollar Quartet,'' a musical about the golden days of rock 'n' roll. It's a hoary old chestnut, but who can blame her for the reminder? She certainly lives up to her claim on stage. Despite having buried her mother the day before and awakened at 4 a.m. to fly from her native Oklahoma for an afternoon taping of ''Letterman,'' Jackson belied her exhaustion and charmed the Broadway audience, closing the show with her bawdy 1958 hit, ''Fujiyama Mama.'' The hips may not quite gyrate like they used to, but Jackson shows no signs of abdicating anytime soon.

The pint-size branding genius behind the Terminal Presents, which oversees Fashion Week's M.A.C. & Milk events hub, has fierce personal style, mixing cutting-edge designers with semi-destroyed garage-sale and flea-market finds. ''Dime stores also interest me,'' she says. ''They have unusual treasures like the beige orthopedic socks I wear with black, red or turquoise heels.'' SANDRA BALLENTINE

I'm not an activist, an alarmist, a Democrat, environmentalist or anything like that. I'm just a person who isn't able to manage the health of my family because of all this drilling. KELLY GANT, whose says her children have had severe asthma attacks and headaches since a gas well was set up near her house in Bartonville, Tex. [18]

In the 1980s, when he was at the height of his fame and maybe his powers, too, Albert Hadley had the opposite of a public relations problem. Just when you thought the commissions couldn't get any grander, Parish-Hadley Associates, the decorating firm he ran with his partner Sister Parish, was tapped by the Duchess of York, who had fallen in love with their work at the Connecticut home of Barbara Allen, the former model and Andy Warhol moll. The Duchess's mother-in-law -- that would be the queen -- ultimately put the kibosh on using a foreign designer at Sunninghill Park, the Yorks' pile near Windsor Castle, and Nina Campbell took sloppy seconds. But from a publicity point of view, it was probably even better that they didn't do Sunninghill than if they had. People calling the office back then to commission not just Hadley but also his lieutenants, who included Gary Hager, David Kleinberg and Brian McCarthy, were not encouraged. ''We're very busy!'' (God help you if you wanted Mrs. Parish herself.) Usually it's the client who signs off on the vendor, but those who made it past the switchboard and weren't named Getty or Whitney had to submit to an interview. In the early '90s, two decades after Hadley decorated Glenn Bernbaum's town house, it still riled Bernbaum, the original owner of Mortimer's, that he had had to be vetted.
An article last Sunday about New York City Opera's spring season misstated the vocal range of Marco Nistico. He is a baritone, not a bass.

SULZBERGER--Judith P. The Rainforest Alliance Board of Directors and staff mark with sadness the passing of Dr. Judith P. Sulzberger, an active board member from 1992 to 2003 and emeritus member thereafter. As one of the organization's earliest benefactors, she helped establish sustainable certification programs and other core projects. A world traveler and science lover, she was a passionate advocate for the rainforest's biodiversity and continued her support and strong interest in our work even after leaving the board. We will miss Judy's brilliant wit and contagious wry humor, as well as her strength, caring and sage counsel. We send our heartfelt condolences to her family. Daniel R. Katz, Chairman Tensie Whelan, President and all of her friends at the Rainforest Alliance

Kappos, who became director of the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office 18 months ago. The office has been working to cut down on delays and inefficiencies that are hindering entrepreneurs and venture capitalists. As the carriers have tried to keep up with rapidly rising oil prices, they have already increased fares four times since the start of the year, compared with only three increases for all of 2010.

The jewelry designer Hannah Martin thinks there is something in the air in London that breeds creativity. ''We are not as chic as the French, as technically brilliant as the Germans or as luxurious as the Italians,'' she says, ''but there is a synergy in the scene here, where people are not afraid to experiment.'' Martin is among an emerging group of innovative jewelry designers creating achingly cool collections that are singularly English. Emma Franklin, another English jeweler who wears a colossal ram's ring on her pinkie, ascribes this creativity to London's history and the rich roots of the gentry. ''I am constantly inspired,'' she says. Dominic Jones says most of his friends are designers: ''It is a little community that really keeps you on your toes.'' His sharp, double-spiked silver rings and geometric drop earrings are favorites of Rihanna and the glamorous Alice Dellal, who not only models in his current look book but is also his business partner.
PIZARRO--David A. Was a past organist and master of choristers of The Cathedral of St. John the Divine. Passed away peacefully in his sleep in Nyack, NY on February 23.

In 2007, when Laura and Kate Mulleavy collaborated with the Gap, after winning the CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund prize, disrobed mannequins were the only indication that their white smocks had ever made it through the door. Two years later, their line of blush-toned tulle lingerie dresses and quirky cute cardigans for Target sold out almost as soon as it hit the floor. This month, Rodarte for Opening Ceremony is taking the collaborative spirit one step further, granting every style freak (including the boys) a wish come true: drapey lace-up dresses, men's floral-print shirts and accessories like tattoo tights and oxford heels, all starting at $100. It was an inevitable match, according to the sisters, who have known Humberto Leon and Carol Lim, co-founders of Opening Ceremony, since they were all students at the University of California, Berkeley. ''We were a group of like-minded people that managed to find each other at a really magical time, and that's what college is all about,'' Laura Mulleavy says, over the phone from Rodarte's studio in L.A.

Jim Courier is a former No. 1 tennis player who won 23 Tour singles titles, including two French Opens and two Australian Opens, before he retired in 2000. Last October, Courier, 40, was named the captain of the United States Davis Cup team. The first round of the competition begins Friday, with the United States facing Chile in Santiago. JOE BRESCIA Q. Andy Roddick has been the warhorse of the United States Davis Cup team for years. Who is in line to replace him?

It is the dream of every sports fan to own his or her favorite team. For Terry Pegula, that dream has come true. Pegula, a Buffalo Sabres fan who had season tickets for 18 years, then became a billionaire in the energy business, completed his purchase of the team from Tom Golisano last week. Pegula fought back tears at his introductory news conference Tuesday when he noticed members of the 1974-75 Sabres team in attendance, especially the man he called ''my hero,'' the Hall of Famer Gilbert Perreault.

Zimmerman. Sidney's participation in our Hospital spanned more than 60 years and his contributions made a profound difference. His devotion was extraordinary and he was deeply committed to improving the quality of life for his patients and their families. His endearing nature, friendship and vivacious spirit will be missed by all of us. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to his beloved wife, Gloria, his children, Neil and Sheri, Amy, Beth and Peter Post, his grandchildren and his great-grandchildren. J. Michael Divney, Chairman of the Board of Directors Jon B. Schandler, President and CEO

Did you suppose that Liz, slipping out of Weston Liggett's Fifth Avenue apartment in a silk slip under a purloined mink, was the first? Or that Bette, when she studiously ignored Eve and Addison at the Cub Room of the Stork Club and claimed she intended to show up for her wedding wearing, ''oh, something simple, a fur coat over a nightgown,'' was an even earlier adopter? News flash: two hundred or so years ago, in the Age of Empire, women were scaling snowbanks in scandalously sheer nightie-like gowns, tied under the bosom with limp ribbons. Apparently, the desire to play outside in your undergarments, to stroll about in broad daylight in robe and pajamas, oblivious to stares and catcalls, is a persistent fashion fantasy. Though this occurrence drifts in and out of style, it seems to be experiencing a wake-up call -- just look at the spring collections, with their slip dresses and bathrobe coats.

A review on Feb. 13 about ''Forge,'' by Laurie Halse Anderson, misstated aspects of the author's professional career. Though she was a spokeswoman for the American Association of School Librarians last year, she herself has never been a librarian. Nor has she ever worked as a park ranger. (Her grandfather was a forest ranger in the Adirondacks.)

ZIMMERMAN--Sidney P.,MD., a gentle, kind, wise and caring man who was a cherished husband, brother, father, grandfather and great-grandfather passed away Friday evening. Sidney, 92 years old, succumbed to complications from Leukemia while he was being treated at White Plains Hospital in White Plains, NY, where he served on the board of directors; where he was affiliated for his 53 years of medical practice; where one of his children and several of his grandchildren were born; and where, in 2001, the Sidney P. Zimmerman Nuclear Cardiology Center was dedicated in his honor. As a physician he trained at Mt. Sinai Hospital and New York Medical College and published the results of his research in medical journals but is best known for his uncommonly optimistic demeanor and his high standard of care. Born in Wilkes Barre, PA, he graduated from Wyoming Seminary preparatory school in Kingston, PA; the University of Pennsylvania; and the Syracuse University College of Medicine, Magna Cum Laude. Sidney is also known for his passion for the game of golf and his skilled short game. He leaves behind his beloved wife of 68 years Gloria, his children Neal, Beth and Amy, grandchildren, great-grandchildren, extended family, patients and friends. Following a private funeral, there will be a memorial service at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel in White Plains, NY at 11am on Monday, February 28th. Family will be receiving friends at Quaker Ridge Golf Club, Griffen Avenue, Scarsdale, NY following the service. In lieu of flowers, donations in his name are being accepted by the White Plains Hospital, 41 East Post Road, White Plains, 10601.

MARK BITTMAN Real oatmeal contains no ingredients; rather, it is an ingredient. As such, it's a promising lifesaver: oats are easy to grow in almost any non-extreme climate and, minimally processed, they're profoundly nourishing, inexpensive and ridiculously easy to cook. They can even be eaten raw. But like so many other venerable foods, oatmeal has been roundly abused by food marketers for more than 40 years. Now, McDonald's is doing everything it can to turn oatmeal into yet another bad choice. ''Cream'' (which contains seven ingredients, two of them actual dairy) is automatically added; brown sugar is ostensibly optional, but it's also added routinely. There are also diced apples, dried cranberries and raisins, the least processed of the ingredients (even the oatmeal contains seven ingredients).

To the Sports Editor: Re ''By a Point, Caltech Ends a 26-Year Conference Skid,'' Feb. 24: Generations of Caltech players have grappled with the streak, and before this team was able to finally end it, the Beavers came excruciatingly close many times. Perseverance, hard work and a love for the game are what athletics is all about.

When it comes to makeup, the runway often resembles a glamorous laboratory, where mad scientists (a k a makeup artists) cook up otherworldly or exaggerated looks that work well in photos but rarely make it to real life. The molten silver eye at Prada's spring show seemed exactly that -- a hothouse exotic that wouldn't survive outside a fashion show. Not so, according to Pat McGrath, who created the look and also employed silver at Valentino and Galliano. ''Metallics are unique, modern and chic,'' she says. ''But most of all, they are completely wearable on every skin tone.'' For an evening out, she suggests using Laura Mercier's intense Foiled Eye Color in V.I.P. Silver on the lid, keeping the color centered, rather than extending up to the brow, and following with black liquid liner and mascara. For day, try Covergirl Smoky ShadowBlast in Silver Sky from the lash line to the browbone, and finish with two coats of mascara. Romy Soleimani, who created the liquid mercury look for this story, recommends a sheer wash of Make Up For Ever Aqua Cream No. 3 all over the lid and in the crease, followed by mascara. ''Fill in your brow, do a beautiful pale pink lip, and you have a delicate version of the look,'' she says.

SCHILLER--Eleanor, 68, of Teaneck, NJ passed away on February 18. Ellie was blessed to live her passion daily: playing and teaching the violin. Her loving husband, Allan, daughters Jackie and Laura, sons-in-law Rami and Andy, grandchildren, Ben, Ari, Lili and Mellie, and aunt Hanka will miss her always. Her "Smile" rings in our ears.

THE 2011 Geneva auto show steps into the batter's box Tuesday. The on-deck circle, however, is looking crowded. Shanghai and New York traditionally hold their auto shows in the spring, but this year both shows' press previews are the week of April 17.

Forget the dress -- whatever puff of silk or column of white satin Kate Middleton decides to wear on the day of her wedding to Prince William in April. The real drama for this conventional but modern-minded queen-to-be is what to do about the royal jewels. There are hundreds if not thousands of them: brooches, necklaces, tiaras, diadems in every color as long as it is not black. Although, come to think of it, with Queen Victoria's legacy of 40 years in mourning, there are probably a ton of jet black (but definitely not jet-set) baubles.

CUNNINGHAM--Joseph, N. Jr. M.D. The former partners, associates and residents whom he trained mourn the passing of Joseph N. Cunningham Jr., M.D. As former Chairman of Surgery at Maimonides Medical Center, for nearly three decades, he was a dynamic leader who catapulted the medical center's cardiac and general surgery programs to national and international recognition for its clinical and research excellence. Dr. Cunningham believed very strongly in the importance of basic science research and its role in producing excellent clinical surgeons. He was always very proud of the accomplishments of his trainees and reveled in their success. Our deepest sympathies and prayers are with his family for their sudden loss. Anthony J. Acinapura, MD Israel J. Jacobowitz, MD

We know that Congresswoman Michele Bachmann gave the Tea Party's State of the Union response, believes that the founding fathers abolished slavery and urged her Minnesota constituents to be ''armed and dangerous'' -- but do we know that Congresswoman Barbara Lee of California is calling for the United States' withdrawal from Afghanistan?

WIERDSMA--David Rypperda Allen, 74, died February 22, 2011, at his home in Greenwich, CT. Art and artifact collector, conservationist and preservationist, gifted horticulturalist, he turned his four-acre property into one of the areas most unique gardens. Known as French Farm, it encompassed the core of a farm built for Mary Billings French in 1910. Wierdsma, born in Greenwich, graduated from Greenwich Country Day School and Brown University. He was the son of Elisabeth Trinkner and Frederick Wierdsma. He was also the stepson of financier Nathan R. Allen. In lieu of flowers contributions can be made to the non-profit trust Friends of French Farm at 516 Lake Ave., Greenwich, CT 06830. Information 203-869-0516.

FRUGAL TRAVELER Seth Kugel heads to the Amazon to explore a largely flooded island the size of the Netherlands and finds a natural paradise. Among the wildlife he spots: water buffalo, sloths, monkeys and fire-red scarlet ibises.

New York has Madison Avenue, Rome has the Via Condotti and Buenos Aires has Recoleta -- a shopping district that's similarly luxurious , but with a feeling all its own. This old quarter is as high-end as it gets, but among the $1,500-a-night boutique hotels and the famous Italian labels, there are some charming stores that are refreshingly unique and affordable. As on Madison Avenue, you'll probably have to ring the doorbell and wait awkwardly on the street while a salesclerk opens the door (it's a security thing), but Recoleta lacks the snobbishness of its fancier cousins in the Northern Hemisphere. Staff members are friendly, and the shopping -- from innovative leather goods to futuristic fashions -- does not disappoint. DANIELLE PERGAMENT
SIEGAL--Annette. We are very sorry for the recent loss of our dear friend, Annette Siegal. We extend to her family our deepest sympathy. Elma and Milton Gilbert

The men's wear being worn in New York is sending early signals that the era of dressing down is over. With a tight economy, many businessmen are underscoring their worth with traditional clothes, some with a tweak. But most looks suggest the conservative gray-flannel man of the early 1950s. This winter, Harris tweed is a leader. Tweed sports jackets and suits are doubling as outerwear, recalling the heavy-weight suiting of Europe in the days before widespread central heating. The return of the tried and true is also seen in women's fashion, which had gotten out of hand with too many choices.

The harmonium's undulating sound is mostly associated with the music of the Indian subcontinent, and less so with rock 'n' roll. Except, that is, when it's in the hands of Shilpa Ray, a first-generation American of Indian descent. Since escaping her conservative parents (her father banned Western music in their home) and moving to New York about nine years ago, she has hauled the unusual instrument to gigs to accompany her honey-toned wail of a voice. The sound is Patti Smith meets Nick Cave, both of whom she's played with. And with a big tour (with her band, Her Happy Hookers) kicking off in March, there's plenty of hard-core bellows-pumping ahead.

METROPOLITAN The City Critic column in some editions last Sunday, about a Stop N Swap event on Staten Island in which items discarded by some users were taken by new users, misstated the day of the week on which it was held. It was a Saturday, not a Sunday.

Tahar Rahim sat at a small table in the bar of the Hôtel Lutetia, an elegant, century-old pile of early-Art Deco opulence in the St.-Germain section of Paris. The Lutetia, a magnet for artists and bohemians in its early years, was a headquarters for German officers during the occupation and then served, after the war, as a repatriation center for returning deportees. Now it is a gathering place for international business travelers and the occasional French movie star. Rahim, a fine-boned man of 29, with hyperactive eyebrows and a friendly, energetic manner, fits the category, even as he may also end up redefining it. Born in 1981 to Algerian immigrant parents in the small city of Belfort in eastern France, Rahim, a year after winning two César awards for his electrifying lead performance in Jacques Audiard's prison drama ''A Prophet,'' is about to blow up everywhere, with five very different movies coming soon to French cinemas, possibly to Cannes and even to American multiplexes.

A review on Feb. 13 about three books on Nelson Mandela referred incorrectly to Thabo Mbeki, the former South African president. He was never a prisoner on Robben Island. The review also misspelled the surname of an African leader who, like Mandela, attended Fort Hare, a college in South Africa. He was Julius Nyerere, not Nyere.

EISENBERG--M. Michael, MD. We mourn the loss of Dr. M. Michael Eisenberg, a beloved colleague, highly skilled clinician and dedicated teacher. Earning his MD from Harvard University in 1956, he completed his general surgery residency at Yale Medical Center. For almost 20 years, he served as Professor of Surgery at Weill Cornell. As Director of the Surgical Education Program, he trained generations of medical students. Beloved by his students, they selected him five times to receive the prestigious Teaching Award at graduation. We offer sincere condolences to his wife Barbara, his daughters, Elyse, Ellen and Andrea, his son-in-law Neal and his grandchildren Gabrielle and Thomas. Fabrizio Michelassi, MD Professor and Chair Department of Surgery Surgeon-in-Chief NYP/Weill Cornell Medical Center

A picture caption on Feb. 6 with an article about a road trip in Cambodia misstated the name of the temple complex in which the carvings of the smiling face of the bodhisattva Avalokiteshvara at Bayon are situated. The Bayon carvings that were shown are in the Angkor Thom complex, not the Angkor Wat complex, which is another temple complex at Angkor.

Pinchas Zukerman, who is considered one of the world's greatest violinists, has definite opinions about investing. He likes to buy musical instruments and real estate. ''I'm either sleeping in it or I'm playing it,'' he said of his portfolio.

(ABC) THE 83RD ANNUAL ACADEMY AWARDS The young and the beautiful -- in this case, James Franco and Anne Hathaway -- make their debut as Oscar hosts at this ceremony broadcast live from the Kodak Theater in Los Angeles. Oddsmakers are predicting that Colin Firth will take home the best-actor Oscar for his role as the stuttering George VI in ''The King's Speech'' and that Natalie Portman will win the best actress award for her turn as an increasingly demented ballerina in ''Black Swan.'' ''The fantasy is in the fabrics,'' says Sonya Park, creative director of Arts & Science, a seven-year-old Japanese label. Park provides the most basic of original clothing: smocks, work shirts and utilitarian coats that have an ineffably chic essence. The catch? Clothes this unironic and straightforward make the notion of young and cool a tough fit. That's why we asked Alexander Wang, 27, the king of nonchalant, downtown T-shirt dressing (he recently opened his first store on Grand Street), to come in and give us a lesson in style. ''It's about taking what you know to the next level,'' says Wang, who effortlessly scrunched a sleeve and rolled a pants leg, mixing in pieces from his own label.

HURLEY--Nancie Keating, passed away peacefully in Santa Fe, NM, on February 22, 2011. Born and raised on Long Island, she will be buried in Westhampton Beach. She had lived in New Mexico, since the late 1980s. A graduate of The Spence School and Manhattanville College, she also studied at the Neighborhood Playhouse, School of the Theatre in New York and at the Universite de Laval in Quebec. Earlier in her life she was a stage actress in New York, and later a social worker and volunteer for the Red Cross and other organizations, including the Junior Leagues of New York and Greenwich, CT, where she lived prior to moving to New Mexico. She was preceded in death by her brothers, Edward, William, Robert, and Pierson Keating; by her former husband, James Lance Hurley, mother Anne Pierson Keating, and father William J. Keating. She leaves behind her loving family, including daughter, Joanna Hurley of Santa Fe, nephew David Keating of Albuquerque, sister Lois Keating Learned of Danbury, Connecticut, and nieces Elizabeth and Mary, also of Connecticut, and Carolyn and Anne Keating of New York City. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Disabled American Veterans and Catholic Charities organizations. A Funeral Mass will be held at 11am on Tuesday, March 1, at the Church of the Immaculate Conception in Quiogue, NY.

FORD'S recall on Wednesday of 135,000 F-150 pickup trucks because the driver's air bag might inadvertently deploy could be seen as a laudable act of corporate responsibility. But for the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, which has called for a recall 10 times larger, it is a rebuff and a challenge. The agency says its investigation into 1.3 million F-150s revealed a significant number of incidents involving inadvertent air-bag deployments, the largest such number ''in N.H.T.S.A. history.''
Art Holland Cotter

Prova, Irini Arakas's five-year-old accessories line of kaleidoscopic beads, jewels and scarves favored by Michelle Obama and the electro punker TK Wonder, now includes dresses. The patterns -- in a short day dress and maxi style -- have the deceptively slinky curves and sassy detailing of the '40s (sleeves! knee length!) with the louche glamour of the '70s (florals, animal prints and disco fringe!). Arakas says she's found the zipper factor: ''You know, when you zip yourself into a dress and it just feels so good and perfect and makes you happy.'' By all means, zip us up. From $595, at Ikram (Chicago) and Blue Tree (New York), or go to kirnazabete.com. CHELSEA ZALOPANY

Deborah Pagani, a willowy Manhattan-based jewelry designer, may well be her own best model. A fashion lover who's usually clad in cutting-edge ensembles by Azzedine Alaïa, Haider Ackermann and Rick Owens, she often gets stopped in shops and restaurants by women who want to know where she got her jewelry. ''I've been tempted to sell things right off my body,'' she jokes. Pagani (left, in a Versace dress and her own jewelry) describes her Queen Bee collection as a cross between Joan Crawford and Anita Pallenberg. ''I don't like classic stones by themselves,'' she says. Instead, she mixes diamonds, sapphires and amethysts with moodier materials like jasper ''zebra'' agate, purple turquoise, Nubian opals and moonstones. ''My pieces are a bit dark, but dark in a sophisticated way.'' The earrings above are $16,105 at Ikram, in Chicago. SANDRA BALLENTINE

ALBANY - School superintendents are used to having relatively thankless jobs. So after completing successful negotiations for a wage freeze with labor officials in his school district in central New York, Christopher R. Brown was content with a celebratory lunch with his father at a local hamburger establishment last Friday. That seemed like the extent of the fanfare -- but Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo thought otherwise. In an unusual gesture, he has taken to publicly saluting school superintendents like Dr. Brown who he deems to have taken up the mantle of shared sacrifice.
If you want to dress up, Then prepare to strip down. the feisty actress and freshly minted New Yorker Rinko Kikuchi works the season's new minimalism.

FOSTER--Diana Worth, 67, beloved mother, grandmother, sister, and friend died Sunday, February 20, 2011 after a brave and determined battle with leukemia. Born in Rochester, NY on May 24, 1943 and raised in Raleigh, NC she was the daughter of the late Thomas Clarkson Worth and Barbara Luther Worth. She is survived by her children Alison Foster Reining (Michael) of Midlothian, VA and Archibald M. Foster III (GiGi) of Locust Valley, NY; grandchildren Hailey, Charlotte, and Andrew Reining, and Trilby Foster; and four brothers. Mrs. Foster touched many lives while pursuing her multiple passions including the culinary arts, art history, travel and theatre. While a southerner until the end, she drank in the culture and energy of the City and was truly a New Yorker at heart. The Metropolitan Museum of Art was a happy thread woven into her life for over 36 years. After joining the weekend volunteers answering questions at the front desk, her passion grew and that task evolved into giving tours of American paintings and sculpture, French and English decorative arts, finally coming to rest on the Impressionists. Hers was a tour not to be missed. She recently mentioned that her years as a docent at the Met "enriched my brain but, most of all, enriched my soul." A new chapter in her life threw open doors to fresh adventures (including a trip to Hudson Bay to observe polar bears), a number of dear new friends, and a long career in development at the Japan Society. Her many years there instilled in her an appreciation of Eastern tradition and a deep love of Japanese culture. Her shorter career as the director of development at St. Vincent's hospital gave her other, very different insights as well as an appreciation of the sacrifices men and women make to care for the indigent. A memorial service was held for Mrs. Foster at The Brick Church on 92nd and Park, on Friday, February 25.

Amtrak started a YouTube channel this month to offer travelers a new way to get information about the rail line. The channel (youtube.com/amtrak) will feature videos about safety, security and other travel tips, information about the Trails & Rails program (done in conjunction with the National Park Service), high-speed rail initiatives and expansion plans for its Wi-Fi service. Personal stories of passengers who share their travel experiences will also be highlighted. Amtrak has successfully used social media sites like Facebook and Twitter, said Darlene Abubakar, director of national advertising at Amtrak, ''but video is just that next level of engagement.''

PICKARD--Francine, 86, of Delray Beach, Florida and Great Neck, NY, died peacefully at home on February 24, 2011. She is survived by Leonard, her beloved husband of 66 years, daughters, Janet Pickard Kremenitzer, Maxine Davis, and son Mark Pickard and daughter-in-law Kristina Brennan Pickard. Her greatest joy was seeing and talking to her five wonderful grandchildren: Rebecca Kremenitzer, Jason Pickard, Heather Diamond and husband Adam, David Kremenitzer, and Jared Pickard. Her career ambition as a young woman was to become a lawyer but this plan was interrupted by WWII and the need to contribute to the war effort. Her wedding plans had to be changed many times to accommodate the pending deployment of Leonard to the Pacific theater . She used her accounting skills to earn several advancements and to help support her recently widowed mother, Esther Saltzman. After the war she worked alongside her husband in his fledgling CPA firm and loyally helped him through many difficult tax seasons. Funeral services, Sunday, February 27th, 1:30pm, at Parkside Memorial Chapels, 98-60 Queens Boulevard , Rego Park, NY. Interment will follow at the Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, New York.

TOM FORD likes his well-heeled ladies (and gents) to show more than a little skin, so it's not surprising he decided to expand his beauty franchise with the Neroli Portofino Collection, sexy-smelling bath and body products meant to evoke the fragrant orange groves and jet-set élan of the Italian Mediterranean. (The leisurely scent of money, in other words.) Intended to be unisex, the collection contains a moisturizer, shower gel, body oil (shown here, $70), body scrub and soap, and will be available April 1 at Bergdorf Goodman. SANDRA BALLENTINE

Troy Jackson, one of the best-known stars of street basketball -- a showy style of play that gained global attention when its games were shown on ESPN -- died Sunday in Los Angeles. He was 38 and lived in Dix Hills, N.Y. The cause was hypertensive heart disease, the Los Angeles medical examiner's office said.
Dance Roslyn Sulcas

An article last Sunday about the popularity of the game Monopoly at the University of Chicago in the 1970s misspelled the name of a snack bar run by Shorey House, a dormitory. It was Tanstaafl, an abbreviation of ''there ain't no such thing as a free lunch'' -- a favorite expression of the economics professor Milton Friedman.

Is it her voice, her smile or the way she wears her impressive spring blouse that turns prim into fabulous?

FUCHS--George, on February 23, 2011 at age 86. Beloved husband of Ann Whitestone. Cherished brother of the late Robert. Loving uncle of Eddie (Jill), Bobby and Laura (Fred) Golightly. Dear brother-in-law of Jean. WWII veteran, Army Air Corp, B17 bomber. Retired industrial arts teacher, Forest Hills High. He was famous for his whiskey sours. A private ceremony is planned. Contributions in his memory may be made to: The Salvation Army or to a charity of your choice.

BROWNSTONE--Anne Diamond. A Theatre, Film and Television actress, passed away peacefully at age 87 on January 29th in her Manhattan apt. Anne starred in 100's of radio shows in Hollywood opposite every major star of the day including John Wayne and Jimmy Stewart. She wrote and starred in early TV shows such as "Dragnet" "Burns and Allen" "The Nurses" and "Tombstone Territory" and on stage played opposite James Whitmore, Claire Trevor, and Robert Redford to name a few. Well-known in Hollywood and a regular leading actress at The Pasadena Playhouse, she was referred to as "The L'il Gem" in the column "The Boulevardier' from her maiden name "Diamond". While performing the season at Arena Stage, Producer Norman Kean and his wife Gwyda Kean introduced Anne to her husband Joseph Brownstone, an actor and director, who at the time was the stage manager for The Lunts in "The Visit". Joseph went on to become the top company manager for Sol Hurok Productions managing such theatrical troupes as The Bolshoi Ballet, The Royal Ballet, British Tournament and Tattoo and The Royal Highland Fusiliers. Considered theatre royalty, they toured the country with Sol Hurok's Productions and the first ever run of Disney on Parade along with their three children, until Joseph's sudden early death in 1970. During her hiatus from the stage to raise her children, Anne worked as Assistant to the President of Actors' Equity Association to Theodore Bikel, Ellen Burstyn and Colleen Dewhurst from 1974 to 1989 and was granted a Lifetime Membership to Actors' Equity by the Council for her devotion to actors and the Union. She returned to the stage in 1992 touring in such productions as Neil Simon's "Lost in Yonkers" and "Moon Over Buffalo". She is survived by her three children, Robert Brownstone, an attorney who is Technology and eDiscovery Counsel at Fenwick & West LLP, Diana Brownstone, a Broadway Actress and Astrologer and Richard Brownstone, Upper School Dean/English Teacher at the Packer-Collegiate Institute, and their spouses and her three grandchildren.

DON'T say we didn't warn you. The bold patterns and prints that cropped up in the pre-fall collections have materialized into a full-blown trend for fall. From the pastoral landscape prints at Rodarte to the techno Navajo patterns at Proenza Schouler (with bold plaid at Thakoon), there is no blending in with the crowd. Of course, early adopters can grab this tribal-inspired clutch ($735) from the Marni spring collection. Just the thing to carry you clear through to September. Available at Marni boutiques. RACHEL WALDMAN

An article on Nov. 28, 2010, about the Art Basel Miami Beach art fair misspelled the surname of an artist whose videos were shown there. She is Tania Pérez Cordova, not Cordoba. Ms. Cordova pointed out the error in an e-mail received by The Times on Feb. 22.

PANTONE, the undisputed color authority, is the latest brand to attach its name to a hotel, having opened a 59-room boutique establishment in Brussels. The Pantone Hotel (pantonehotel.com) has seven floors, each designated a different color, a gesture meant to entice customers to select a room (beginning at $137 a night) to match their mood. And if a color consultation with a Pantone expert isn't enough of a pick-me-up, there is a small library where guests can read about color therapy if they're feeling blue. ROCKY CASALE

ABRAMSON--Roslyn, of Bal Harbour, FL, formerly of New Rochelle, NY and prior thereto of Undercliff Avenue, Bronx, NY, died on February 24, 2011, at age 97, following a protracted series of brief illnesses. She was predeceased by her husband of nearly fifty years, Sam H. Abramson, in 1983, her elder son, Edward M. Abramson, in 2001 and her brother, Harry Fish, in 1955. She is survived by her younger son, David A. Abramson, and his wife, Ellen. Also surviving are three grandchildren, Daniel, Deborah and Marc, and their respective spouses; five great-grandchildren Ezra, Levi, Lilah, Sara and Uval; nephews, Jerry and Robert Fish, and their respective wives and children; her husband's grandnephew Hillel Maximon, and his wife; and Edward's widow, Harriet. Roz will always be remembered for her intelligence, wit, and feistiness and as a champion of the underdog. The family has requested that donations in Roslyn's memory be given to American Technion Society (for the benefit of the Technion-Israel Institute of Technology) or the Parkinson's and Movement Disorder Center of NYU Langone Medical School, in either case in support of research in neurodegenerative diseases. Graveside service and interment at Beth El Cemetery, Paramus, NJ, Sunday, February 27, at 1:00pm.

WASSERMAN--Elizabeth Bay, 79. Our beloved mother and friend died surrounded by her family at home on February 25, 2011. She was a beautiful, generous spirit loved by her children Lindsay, Andy and Marion Wasserman and Ron Emerson and all who knew her. She will be dearly missed by her two sisters and six grandchildren. A celebration of her life will be held on April 30th in New York to honor Bay.

SCHOENTHAL--Harriet. We regret the passing of our friend, family member and public relations executive on February 22. A Memorial Service will be held to honor her life in the near future.

RUDER--William, died February 22, 2011. We have lost a very special man who was so loved, respected, and admired that it is unbelievable to think he is gone. He was truly unique in his unconditional love for his large family and many friends around the world. Bill was a romantic, an artist, and a superb professional whose wisdom, insights, and advice were widely sought. He will be with us forever. He had "such a good time." He is survived by his wife, Betty, his children, Robin (Daniel), Abby (Ellen), Brian (Ginny), Michal (Amy), Eric (Debbie), Jennifer Cott, and his grandchildren Dylan, Aaron (Kirsti), Sarah, Susannah, Adam (Amy), Jerusha, David, Aron, Eliza, Josh, Ethan, Jesse, and Mira. The funeral service will be private. There will be a Memorial Service on Wednesday, March 30, at 2pm, location to be determined. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the International Multiple Sclerosis Research Center on West 57th Street.

Near Timbuktu, Mali, Jan. 8, 2011 I went to Mali on a group trip for the New Year to explore and to learn while making an odyssey with a woman and her friends who are building a school in Nienebale village. One of our destinations was the Festival au Desert, near Timbuktu. Even though the United States and French governments warned against travel to the region, we were determined to experience the great festival and camp in the Sahara. Many Tuaregs came to the festival on camels to share their song, dance and sell their crafts. Great bands performed at night. On the final day there were camel races. This image of camels on a dune while small planes fly overhead juxtaposes two forms of desert transportation. Hilary Duffy

BAUER--Richard P.,a former lawyer, investment banker and corporate executive died on February 6, 2011 in Denver, Colorado at the age of 80. Mr. Bauer received an AB from Cornell and an LLB from Columbia Law School in 1959. During the intervening years, he served as a carrier pilot in the U.S. Navy. Retired at his death, Mr. Bauer began his career as an attorney with Hughes Hubbard & Reed in New York City. He next joined Smith Barney & Company as an investment banker involved in raising equity and debt capital for domestic and foreign governmental agencies and corporations, including Sony and other of the first Japanese companies to access the United States capital markets after Word War II. Mr. Bauer subsequently served as a turnaround specialist and corporate executive with Consolidated Water Company, Fleming Companies and The CocaCola Bottling Company of New York. Near the end of his career, he returned to investment banking with E.F. Hutton & Company in New York. An ardent skier, Mr. Bauer resided in Vail and Denver, Colorado in his retirement. He previously maintained homes in New York City and Warren, Vermont. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

COFFIN--Rosemary H. (Baldwin), 88, of Exeter, NH, February 22, 2011; beloved wife of David D., mother of Sarah Coffin Klebnikov O'Connor (Thomas) and Peter (Eleanore). Faculty wife at Phillips Exeter Academy, Founder of Seacoast Hospice and Co-founder Riverwoods at Exeter retirement community. Service to be held at Christ Church, Pine Street, Exeter, NH, March 5 at 2pm. www.brewittfuneralhome.com

The Medium column on Jan. 9, about headphones, referred incorrectly to their origin. While some sources do credit Nathaniel Baldwin with inventing them in 1910, early models were used in the late 19th century.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''It Happens Every Spring: 'Driving Mr. Yogi,' '' Feb. 24: I didn't think it possible, but Harvey Araton's article about Yogi Berra and Ron Guidry made this Red Sox fan stop despising the Yankees for a few minutes. Bruce Torff

With ''Modigliani: A Life'' (Knopf, $35), Meryle Secrest rehabilitates the famously dashing Italian, once thought to be a minor painter and something of a brute. The meticulously sourced book coincides with a flurry of art market activity, suggesting that 91 years after his death, Modigliani may be having a moment. 1. ''Nu Assis Sur un Divan'' (1917) sold at Sotheby's last November for $69 million, an all-time record for the artist. With nudes, Secrest says, Modigliani preferred painting unknown models to his mistresses, so this woman's identity is a mystery. ''He was once overheard remarking that women who made the best models never looked as well in their clothes,'' she says. ''That should give fresh hope to us all.''

The Trend: Running with scissors. Slashed sides and a gashlike appliqué give complexity and personality to the standard sheath at Versace, Zac Posen and Max Mara. The Girl: Lykke Li's top-of-head bun became all the rage in Sweden after her first record topped the charts. With a new album, ''Wounded Rhymes'' (and new hair), she looks toward the States.

The Juice Press never sleeps. Between midnight and 9 a.m., seven days a week, three powerful Norwalk juicers (norwalkjuicers.com) pulverize and press the next day's inventory. Designed in 1934 by Dr. Norman W. Walker, an early advocate of juicing and raw food, the $2,495 stainless steel version is the Rolls-Royce of juicers, extracting every drop of nutrient-rich liquid from fruits and vegetables, with little oxidation. For D.I.Y.ers, Antebi recommends the Hurom Slow Juicer (left). ''It operates along some of the same principles as the Norwalk and is excellent for home use,'' he says. It's $360 at williams-sonoma.com. SANDRA BALLENTINE

EARL--Consuelo Vanderbilt, a great-great-granddaughter of Commodore Cornelius Vanderbilt, died on February 21, 2011, at the age of 107. Mrs. Earl was a long-time resident of Ridgefield, CT. Commodore Vanderbilt was an American financier who amassed a great fortune in railroad and shipping interests and founded the Vanderbilt family in this country. Mrs. Earl's father, William Kissam Vanderbilt, Jr., like his father, William Kissam Vanderbilt, was President of the New York Central Railroad. Her mother, Virginia Graham Fair, was the daughter of United States Senator James G. Fair of Nevada, a forty-niner from the time of the California gold rush and one of the "Silver Kings" who developed the Comstock Lode in Nevada. Mrs. Earl was devoted to the welfare of animals and was a prominent breeder of skye terriers. She was the widow of N. Clarkson Earl, Jr., who died in 1969. Mrs. Earl's first marriage was to the late Earl E. T. Smith, who was United States Ambassador to Cuba when Fidel Castro came to power. Mrs. Earl is survived by her daughter from her marriage to Ambassador Smith, Virginia Consuelo Smith Burke of Palm Beach, FL, seven grandchildren and 18 great-grandchildren. Her daughter, Iris Smith Christ, predeceased her. Funeral service and burial will be private. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Animal Medical Center, 510 East 62nd St, New York, NY 10021 or Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Ave., New York, NY 10065, would be appreciated.

EISENBERG--M. Michael, January 27, 1931- February 24, 2011. Died peacefully in his sleep one month following his 80th birthday. Dedicated professor and surgeon, loving husband, father and grandfather. Son of the late George Herman Eisenberg and the late Dorothy Rosenfeld, he is survived by his cherished wife of 27 years, Barbara Yetka-Eisenberg; his devoted daughters from his first marriage to Carol Kossin Cleveland - Elyse, Ellen (Neal Feigenson), and Andrea C. Michaels; his adored grandchildren Gabrielle and Tom Feigenson; and his beloved step-mother Selma (Maidie) Eisenberg. A memorial service will be held at the Harvard Club in midtown Manhattan on Monday, February 28, 2011 from 6-8pm.

Salma Hayek is getting down to business. She has just arrived at our photo shoot in Paris, makeup-free, hair bundled up into a Rasta-like knitted cap, and now she's sitting next to the photographer on the couch, going through pictures they're using as reference points. The Xeroxed photos are provocatively sexy -- Romy Schneider looking pained and delirious, Catherine Deneuve pulling her camisole down for Helmut Newton, a bare-bottomed model leaning over a fur coat on a balcony -- but this seems to bother Hayek not at all. She examines them almost as if she were the producer of the shoot rather than the subject. There is (as is customary) a slight nervousness in the room about what she will turn out to be like to work with, what she will or won't agree to. First of all, she apologizes: most of these images are of women with cigarettes dangling from their lips, but she has a rule about not smoking in pictures. Fine; a lit match is decided upon instead. With all eyes on her, she continues to leaf through until she gets to the naked backside. She stops, and briskly slaps the pile of pictures down on her lap.

Stanley D. Heckman, President Stephan Russo, Executive Dir.

An article last Sunday about Craig's, a West Hollywood, Calif., restaurant opened by Craig Susser, referred incorrectly to his father's plans for a West Coast knockoff of P. J. Clarke's. We've decided to spill the beans on one of Hollywood's best-kept secrets. (After all, why should tabloids have all the fun?) Her name is Joanna Czech, and her facials make the A-list sparkle. SANDRA BALLENTINE CLIENTS: Czech's client list practically needs its own red carpet: Penélope Cruz, Uma Thurman, Christy Turlington, Kate Winslet, Laura Linney, Cate Blanchett and Kim Cattrall are just some of the famous faces who head to her private studio at Paul Labrecque Salon and Spa in Midtown's Core club for bespoke combinations of L.E.D. therapy, Sapphire (an exfoliation treatment that uses granules of the stone to erase fine lines and tighten skin), ultrasound water peels and soothing facials that incorporate products from Nude and Environ, two of her favorite lines. She also gives a mean bikini wax.

SCHLESINGER--Hans L.,age 100, of Hanover, NH, and formerly of Great Neck, NY, on February 18, 2011. He was born on December 15, 1910, in Hamburg, Germany, to Emil and Flora (Strelitz) Schlesinger. After a childhood affected by World War I, he attended high school and business school. He began work in chemical exports in 1930, first in Hamburg, later in Brussels. Hans met his future wife, Luise ("Liesel") Judith Benzian, also a Hamburg native, in 1934. Married in London on May 7, 1939, they returned to Belgium, their lives upended by the German invasion of May 1940, with Hans and Liesel being separated for almost one year, including time Hans spent in a Vichy detention camp. With help from family, the American consulate, and the American Friends Service Committee, they were reunited in Marseilles in spring 1941. Immigration visas granted, they journeyed to the New York area, where they lived until 1996. In 1950, he and the late Ed Gallard founded the Gallard-Schlesinger companies, also specializing in chemical exports and imports. He remained active in business well into his eighties, even after he sold his company. Hans and Liesel subsequently divided their time between a beloved southern Vermont vacation home and the Kendal community at Hanover. Hans was preceded in death by his parents, by brothers Richard and R. Walter, and by Liesel in 2006. He is survived by his son, Peter (Denise), and his granddaughter, Amanda, of St. Paul, MN; and by his extended family. He is fondly remembered by his family; and by friends and acquaintances from his business and personal lives. Heartfelt thanks to the medical and nursing staff of Kendal at Hanover; and to caregivers Candace, Wendy, Emily, Janice, and Lois. In lieu of flowers, donations in Hans's memory may be made to the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum; to the American Friends Service Committee; to the Mountain Valley Medical Clinic of Londonderry, VT; or to a charity of the donor's choice. A memorial gathering will be planned for the spring.
You see shoes and toe rings? Quick! Get the straitjacket!

The Paris-based shoe designer Laurence Dacade, whose in-demand studded biker-style boots are sported by the likes of Vanessa Paradis and Erin Wasson, keeps her footwork in step with her vanity case. Her new mesh bootie, the Tiffany, was inspired by the scent of rose gardens. The crimson peep toe, which is sultry and light, is gracefully adorned with a trellis of satin petals. ''It's sexy and sensual-feeling,'' Dacade says. ''The effect is as subtle as a whiff of perfume.'' CHELSEA ZALOPANY

THE NEWS The benchmark price of crude oil climbed above $100 a barrel for the first time in two years. BEHIND THE NEWS Though unrest elsewhere in the Middle East has kept markets jittery for weeks, prices did not shoot up in earnest until the trouble reached Libya and, for the first time, disrupted an important producer whose oil is prized for being close to Europe and easy to refine. Prices retreated slightly after the spike but still finished the week at $98.26 a barrel, punishingly high for the American economy, and was expected to stay high for a while.

FLOM--Joseph H. I join with all my former partners in mourning the loss of a great lawyer and true friend. I was often touched by his willingness to extend his personal warmth and support to those who needed it most. As great as his talents were as a lawyer, his heart was even greater. Stephen M. Axinn

In Vancouver, food carts are an emerging mini-industry. But new vendors who want to sell hot dogs and cheese-steak sandwiches may need to switch to healthier options. The city council decided last month that its criteria for granting licenses would include nutritional content; use of local and fair-trade foods; and diversity of options. While the decision has some critics crying ''nanny state,'' others believe that the new rules will encourage an emphasis on quality. Last year, officials lifted a 1978 law that allowed food carts to sell only hot dogs, chestnuts and popcorn, unleashing a wave of creative new options, from beef teriyaki and wasabi subs (Fasttrac Fusion) to wild coho salmon sandwiches (Fresh Local Wild).
FLOM--Joseph. Joe, we will miss you so - our sympathy to the family. Jean & Ralph Baruch

INDIANAPOLIS - Rule 1 of the N.F.L. scouting combine: don't talk about anything. Don't mention specific college prospects. Don't discuss potential free agents. The labor situation? Coaches are more willing to recite their credit-card numbers than talk about it.
I am just glad I got this game out of my system. These last two days have been crazy for me.' CARMELO ANTHONY, after his winning debut with the Knicks, who acquired him last week from Denver.

Ann Bonfoey Taylor, born in 1910, was a paragon of midcentury grace and timeless gumption. She was invited to ski in the 1940 Olympics, but then World War II spoiled the games, so she became a flight instructor. (Yes, she was also a licensed pilot.) Taylor went on to join the jet set, ride dressage, hunt fox, marry a man known as Moose, design kooky ski wear and build one of the first residences in Vail, Colo., before dying in 2007 at the age of 96. (She's unrelated to the retail chain Ann Taylor, which takes its name from a best-selling dress.) ''Fashion Independent'' ($60), a catalog from a show of the same name at the Phoenix Art Museum, evokes Taylor's indefatigable style. STEPHEN HEYMAN

She will be greatly missed.

MORTIMER--Kathleen H. The Board of Learning Leaders (formerly NYC School Volunteer Program) wishes to acknowledge the passing of one of its founders. In 1956 she helped launch the strongest family and community engagement organization which still serves our public schools.

KEARNS--David T. February 25, 2011 in Stuart, Florida. Former Chairman and CEO of Xerox Corporation, 1982 to 1991. A graduate of the University of Rochester, he served in the U.S. Navy from 1952-54. He began his career with IBM in 1954, becoming Vice President of the Data Processing Division. In 1971 Mr. Kearns joined Xerox Corporation. Through his leadership, Xerox thrived and in 1989, received the Malcolm Baldrige Award for Quality. He served as Deputy Secretary of Education and was a trustee of several corporations and foundations. He was board chair of the University of Rochester and the National Urban League. He is survived by his wife of 56 years, Shirley Cox Kearns; six children, eighteen grandchildren, two sisters and many nephews and nieces. Friends may call Tuesday, March 1st, 3-5 and 7-9pm at the Anthony Funeral Chapel, 2305 Monroe Ave., Rochester, NY. A funeral service will be held 2pm, Wednesday, March 2nd at St. Paul's Episcopal Church, Rochester NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to David T. Kearns, Center for Leadership and Diversity in Arts, Sciences and Engineering at The University of Rochester www.rochester.edu/college/kearnscenter. EXCLUSIVE VIDEOS: Our cover star, Salma Hayek, switches from smoking mama to working mother in a behind-the-scenes clip from her shoot; T's fashion editors show how to pull off the season's trickiest trends; the artist Mark Borthwick captures the bacchanal that ensues when a ragtag bunch of artists come together as models; and the fashion impresaria Jenné Lombardo goes on a tear.

GREENE--Joan Hope Ewers, 79, died, on February 14, 2011 at home in Riverdale, NY. A winter resident of Palm Beach, she will be buried with deep love and respect at Arlington National Cemetery. Bright, warm, and wonderful, with class, Joan was the trusted assistant of Dr. Jules Stein, Chairman of Universal Movie Studios, at his Eye Institute at UCLA. Here she hosted luminaries such as William Randolph Hearst and Ross Perot. Mrs. Greene was employed at the New York Times, Life Magazine, and later was manager of the Riverdale, NY Tennis Club. Joan attended Converse College and the Juilliard School as a concert pianist. Her keyboard mates were Van Cliburn, John Browning and Daniel Pollack, all of whom received lessons from the renowned Madame Rosina Lhevinne. Here she accompanied Leontyne Price. We shall remember the beautiful melody of Joan's life. She had a deep love for her husband and family that was unconditional and irresistible. Joan said, "I'll love you, just as much if you have only $5 instead of 5 trillion."' Her virtuous goal in life was simply to love and to be loved. She taught love by example. For 48 years Joan was totally devoted to her first and only love, her husband Dr. Robert Ford Greene, college Athletic Director and author of tennis instruction books. Also surviving is Joan's caring and good brother, Quinto Vallei, Jr., of Richmond Virginia where she was raised to become a true Southern lady. We'll miss her so much. Good-bye buddy. In Joan's memory you could make the following free and humane gift to mankind: Give love to your dearest and kindness to all.

HOFFER--Jack Joseph, 92, of Great Neck, NY passed away on Friday, February 25. A proud and generous husband of Esther, father, grandfather and great-grandfather. Longtime Executive at A.E. Nathan and WWII Veteran. Grandpa Joe is survived by his three children, Arlene, Leslie and Clifford, six grandchildren, Matthew, Elizabeth, Natasha, Suzanne, Mark and William, and seven great-grandchildren.

In ''Art and Madness'' (Nan A. Talese/Doubleday, $25), Anne Roiphe recalls her credulous, art-obsessed youth in the 1950s, including the time she quoted Aldous Huxley to a nurse at Smith College in the hopes of being prescribed LSD. ''She offered me aspirin.'' (Roiphe later transferred to Sarah Lawrence.) Gabrielle Hamilton of the New York canteen Prune flambées every food-memoir cliché in ''Blood, Bones & Butter'' (Random House, $26). The WPA guides to San Francisco and Los Angeles have been reissued as stylish paperbacks (University of California Press, $25). Since ''The Tiger's Wife'' (Random House, $25) was excerpted by The New Yorker in 2009, the literati have been drooling over its 25-year-old author, Téa Obreht, and her emotive debut, set in the Balkans. ''Yohji Yamamoto'' (V&A Publishing, $60) accompanies the blockbuster retrospective at the Victoria and Albert Museum. And in ''One Hundred Names for Love'' (W. W. Norton & Company, $27), Diane Ackerman helps her novelist husband relearn to speak after his stroke causes aphasia, or total language loss.
An entry on the hardcover advice and how-to best-seller list last Sunday misspelled the given name of one of the co-authors of ''As One.'' He is Mehrdad Baghai, not Marhdad.

''We all met in 2006 -- the year before my best year ever. Yep, 2007, nailed that year -- was brilliant, really.'' Alexa Chung is talking, wearing a girlie Marc Jacobs dress and a boxy pair of Russell & Bromley men's dress shoes. She claims to have been out all night -- ''Last night's dress, last night's shoes'' -- but looks so fresh and pretty that it's hard to believe. She is explaining, over a hearty breakfast of eggs, avocado and coffee at the Smile, in New York's East Village, how she met her favorite partners in crime: Kelly Osbourne and the girls from the band the Like, Tennessee Thomas and Z Berg. ''That was the year I stopped modeling and started enjoying,'' she says. ''And making friends -- I didn't really have any. The Like was my audition interview for my first job, on 'Popworld.' And Kelly was there trying out, too.'' Just like that, four single girls on the make became a posse. Girls, she says, who played like boys.
