Instead of throwing down weedkiller, why not dig up dandelions for next winter's food? Last year, I decided that instead of suffering through another winter without local greens, I would try my hand at forcing roots - an age-old practice that yields springy vegetables even in the middle of winter. The foraging guru Euell Gibbons forced pokeweed and dandelion roots in his cellar, documenting it in his 1962 book, ''Stalking the Wild Asparagus,'' and I was curious to see if I could recreate it in an apartment in New York City.

It's not even a year old, but the Juice Press in the East Village of Manhattan has gained a cult following among celebrities like Kate Hudson, Naomi Watts and the vegan poster boy Moby. Marcus Antebi, one of the owners, delivers a raw-food diet of salads, entrees, juices and smoothies, including the Guru, a turbo-charged combination of goji and açaí berries, raw cacao and hemp protein -- a favorite of Terry Richardson. According to Antebi, a former competitive muay Thai boxer and an avid skydiver, organic produce has an incredible life force and energy. Indeed, his detoxifying elixirs are guaranteed to sluice the most stopped-up systems.

The Modern Love column last Sunday, about a woman seeking a partner to bear a child, referred incorrectly to the waist-hip ratio (the ratio of the waist circumference to the hip circumference). A 0.7 ratio means that the waist is 30 percent smaller than the hips, not 70 percent smaller.

When I return from the collections each season, my friends invariably ask me to tell them what they need. They don't need anything, of course, which is what I tell them; and then the discussion turns to what they want and what they'll obsess over, save for and, casting aside any notions of reason or utility, splurge on. Fashion, for women, is not a straightforward business: we love things that make us feel new and strange, we love things that return us to essential selves, and we really love things that magically do both. This spring, for example, I adore the new minimal take on evening (see Terry Richardson's ''The Night Shift,'' Page 166 ) because it looks like nothing in my closet yet nods to my lifelong romance with offhand, sensual clothes. And, for much the same reason, I also love the haphazard, layered boudoir-street-chic (Collier Schorr's ''Early Birds,'' Page 122) that couldn't appear more different. Trends mean very little: real style is personal and complicated and (hopefully) fun. The women featured in this issue understand this all too well. What we love about Salma Hayek, Rinko Kikuchi, Alexa Chung, Rachel Feinstein and Lykke Li, to list only a few, is that they are not defined solely by what they do or what they wear or even how they live. They defy categorization, and the choices they make -- to be journalists, musicians, muses, actresses, artists and moms -- always seem to nod to their pasts while moving vigorously forward.

SIGRID NUNEZ In ''Suddenly, Susan'' (Page 129), the six-time novelist Sigrid Nunez recalls the strange period of her 20s spent en famille with Susan Sontag and Sontag's only son, David Rieff. The child of a German mother and a Panamanian-Chinese father, Nunez, 59, has always lived in Gotham, despite short stints beyond the pale. ''I'm beginning to feel like New York is more a place to visit than to live,'' she said. ''If you told me that at 20 or 30 or 40, I would've thought you were mad. I always thought I would feel the way Susan felt: that it was really the only place.''

M ICHAEL HAUPTMAN, an Iowa native and a former photo assistant to Richard Burbridge, has released his first book, ''Notes on, Something Like Life Should Be'' (And Press, $70). His poetic color-drenched photographs, which have appeared in T Magazine and the Japanese cult magazine Untitled, are presented in diary form, with drawings, paintings and musings that offer a window into the photographer's relationships. An answer in the Q & A column last Sunday about major capital improvements in buildings that have been converted to a co-op or condo described incompletely the process by which a landlord/sponsor can pass the cost of the improvements on in a rent increase. The sponsor may be entitled to an increase for units that are occupied by regulated tenants; the right to an increase does not end once the building is converted.

Whether you have health insurance at home or not, if you visit Panama you'll get free coverage for 30 days under a program that the country began last month. The insurance, financed by a $40 departure tax, covers up to $7,000 in hospital and medical fees related to accidents or disease, $2,000 in emergency dental expenses and $20,000 in the case of accidental death. Immigration officials at airports distribute brochures detailing the program. During the first two weeks of the two-year program, which began Jan. 17, 50 visitors tapped their benefits, largely for minor injuries like sprained ankles.

I was a virgin when I met Marcus Antebi, a co-owner of the Juice Press, a tiny temple to organic fruit and veggie elixirs and raw food in Manhattan's East Village. A juice virgin, that is. Sure, I'd toyed with the idea of trying one of Organic Avenue's prettily packaged potions at Fashion Week last season. (They were conveniently available to the thin and wanting-to-be-thinner at Lincoln Center's Alice Tully Hall.) But about the closest I'd gotten to fresh juice up to that point was the O.J. in a good mimosa. As for raw food, well, I thought that meant those cute precut, packaged carrot and celery sticks you get from the corner deli. When I arrived at the Juice Press the first time, it was crammed with lithe young things (the model Erin Wasson swears by the maca tonic) buying concoctions like Drink Your Salad and Ginger Fireball. Immediately I felt pasty, pudgy and distinctly unhealthy. Antebi, an intense 42-year-old with a shaved head and myriad tattoos, introduced himself and gave me a quick once-over. Something about him made me want to fess up all of my sins, at least the ones that involve eating and drinking. Before I could stop myself, I blurted out, ''Hi, my name is Sandra, and I'm a meat-wine-cheese-choco-holic.'' He didn't even smile. He simply said, ''I'm going to change your life.''

STEVENS--Louise, of Lido Beach, NY, on February 23, 2011. Born October 22, 1926, in Long Beach, New York, to Irish immigrants, Anna Callahan, County Mayo, and John J. McDonnell, County Kerry. Predeceased by husband of 56 years, William T. Stevens. Extraordinary mother of seven children, William T. Stevens, Jr., Nancy Coffey, Mary Rafferty, Jean Brennan, Elizabeth Murdy, Thomas Stevens, and Kathryn McCormack. Devoted grandmother of 16 grandchildren and 11 great-grandchildren. Graduate of Saint Agnes High School, Rockville Centre, and the College of New Rochelle, Class of 1948. She will be remembered for her wit and wisdom, but above all for her selfless dedication to helping others. Funeral Mass Saturday, 9:30 am, Our Lady of the Miraculous Medal Church, Point Lookout. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury.

I first met Susan Sontag in spring, 1976, when she was recovering from cancer surgery and needed someone to help type her correspondence. I had been recommended by the editors of The New York Review of Books, where I'd worked as an editorial assistant. I had recently finished graduate school at Columbia and was living on West 106th Street, not far from Susan's apartment at 340 Riverside Drive. We worked in her bedroom, I at her desk, typing on her massive I.B.M. Selectric while she dictated, either pacing the room or lying on her bed. I remember being surprised at how laid-back and chatty she was, much more like someone my own age than someone of my mother's generation. But she was always this way with young people, and I would discover there wasn't the usual generational distance between her and her son, either. A year younger than I, David, who'd dropped out of Amherst, had recently returned to school and was now a sophomore at Princeton. He had a place to stay in Princeton, but most of the week he lived with his mother. His (soon to be our) bedroom was right next to hers.

Even a "small" nuclear war -- one involving only 100 Hiroshima-sized bombs -- would cause catastrophic global cooling, reduced rainfall and widespread damage to agriculture, a new report by federal scientists finds. Explosions from the bombs, representing just 0.03 percent of the global nuclear stockpile, would throw approximately five million tons of black carbon into the upper atmosphere, blocking sunlight and causing a plunge in temperature equivalent to a massive volcanic eruption. [National Geographic]

In today's puzzles, we have fun tying shoelaces. Most of you have probably spent a significant chunk of time carrying out this mundane activity, maybe a few months of your entire life when it's all added up. Perhaps it's even more if you wear lace boots. Done right, shoelaces add to the elegance of footwear. Not done right, they can trip you up or deprive you of an Olympic medal, as might have happened to the notorious ice-skater Tonya Harding in 1994. Nowadays, shoemakers use newfangled ways to make shoes secure, such as velcro fasteners or new space-age materials that need no fasteners at all. To us puzzle lovers, shoelaces provide a wealth of combinatorial delights. So I thought it was worth getting this puzzle out before shoelaces disappear entirely.

When Sara Moonves, T's fashion editor, received a terrarium as a holiday gift, the entire office was smitten. This bijou oasis provided a moment of tranquility in the midst of the daily style department chaos. Incredibly low-maintenance (they only need to be watered once), terrariums are just the thing for urbanites like us who are strapped for space and yearning for a patch of greenery. Further inspired by "Nocturne of the Limax maximus," the artist and landscape designer Paula Hayes's recent installation of cast acrylic and hand-blown glass containers filled with tropical plants at the Museum of Modern Art, we wanted to know where we could get a mini-garden all our own.

Those in the world of basketball analytics are tasked with the impossible: to convert a complex game of interrelated and inextricable factors into simple measures of player and team performance. There's no question that the efforts to develop those measures have intensified in the last few years, but despite every advance toward the coveted "one-number metric" -- a single rating that can accurately describe a player's impact on the floor or a team's relative standing -- basketball's answer to sabermetrics comes with limitations and caveats. No stat in basketball is perfect, regardless of the complexity of its formulation.

The Oscars appear to have dodged a bullet. In a difficult year for the ABC telecast - two youthful and untested hosts and a group of top races with heavy favorites - early ratings from 56 markets were down only a smidge from last year. ABC won't have national ratings, which will include information about millions of viewers, until about 3 p.m. Eastern time on Monday.

LOS ANGELES - So how did the Academy Awards do as a cultural mash-up? Not so hot. Though the hosts, James Franco and Anne Hathaway, joked about being the "hip" Oscars from the start of the show and then acted on it -- Mr. Franco unleashed a torrent of backstage Twitter posts, and Ms. Hathaway mentioned drinking games -- their performance drew decidedly mixed reviews, especially when compared with the riffing of the 94-year-old Kirk Douglas. The "Auto-Tune the News" segment was a bit of a head-scratcher. And the use of the fifth-grade choir from Staten Island's P.S. 22, a YouTube sensation known for its renditions of pop and indie songs, was denuded by singing "Somewhere Over the Rainbow" as the credits rolled. Don't get us wrong, it was still cute (and the shot of Melissa Leo singing along was sweet, especially after she dropped an obscenity in her remarks accepting her Supporting Actress Oscar). But it could have been much sharper. What did you think?

LOS ANGELES- In a year in which younger viewers were aggressively courted, the Oscars rewarded what could be considered the most traditional of traditional Academy bait: a period British drama, set during World War II. The best picture win for "The King's Speech," and the corresponding win for Tom Hooper as best director over "The Social Network" and David Fincher, will be fussed over by critics and bloggers as a return to the Academy's staid tastes. It could equally be called a win for Harvey Weinstein's aggressive campaigning - an unusually superstitious Mr. Weinstein pulled out every stop short of calling in the Queen to promote his comeback film; oh wait, he did get her seal of approval, along with Rupert Murdoch's. (His father's stutter was also cured by Lionel Logue.)

This year’s ceremony had a pair of youthful hosts (but hoary writing) and social media name dropping.

My vantage point for the Oscars was a newsroom set for Web television commentary, from which I watched broadcast television. So not the most visibility, but here is what I saw. The Oscars did the job, but then again, they had an awful lot of good movies to work with. At least eight of the movies were worthy of best picture in one way or another, and there were enough twists and turns to keep the show interesting. Can't say the same about the hosts, who were really a host, namely Anne Hathaway. She gamely soldiered along while James Franco did, um, what exactly? Mr. Franco tweeted about doing the Oscars, made movies about doing the Oscars, gave many interviews about being a host, but when it came time to do the actual Oscars, he entered the witness protection program. Perhaps we should draw some satisfaction from the fact that this time around, it was the man who had the job of standing there and looking pretty. But his frozen smile, punched-out gaze, made you wonder while he was there in the first place.

Egyptian authorities announced on Sunday that they would reopen the nation's stock market on Tuesday, a month after shutting it down because of the widespread protests that unseated the former president, Hosni Mubarak. The country's benchmark index, EGX30, fell nearly 17 percent in the two days before the government halted trading on Jan. 27.

REDMOND, Wash. -- Behind Kinect, the computer game device that recognizes gestures and voice commands, lies a far larger agenda for Microsoft. The Kinect technology, according to Craig Mundie, Microsoft's chief research and strategy officer, is the beginning of a new way of communicating with computers. For the past quarter of a century, computing has mainly meant typing on a keyboard and using a computer mouse to point and click on graphic icons on the screen -- the graphical user interface, or GUI (''gooey'').

Is there a title to one of Jeffrey Tambor's previous projects that might apply here? On Friday night, the producers of the Broadway revival of ''La Cage aux Folles'' said that Mr. Tambor, a star of the television comedies ''Arrested Development'' and ''The Larry Sanders Show,'' had withdrawn from the production following Thursday's performance and after having started in the musical just over a week ago. The ''La Cage'' revival opened at the Longacre Theater in April, starring Kelsey Grammer as the nightclub emcee Georges and Douglas Hodge as his cross-dressing spouse, Albin. On February 13, Mr. Grammer and Mr. Hodge played their final performances and were replaced on Feb. 15 by Mr. Tambor as Georges and Harvey Fierstein as Albin. In a statement, the musical's producers said Mr. Tambor ''was experiencing complications from recent hip surgery and the pain and the challenge of performing in a musical eight times a week proved to be too physically demanding.'' They added: ''We respect his talent enormously and regretfully accept his withdrawal from the production.''

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia -- You walk in the door and the clothes have been washed and ironed, the floors mopped and the toilets cleaned. And dinner is on the table. For most people, the luxury of a live-in maid is a fantasy. In Malaysia, however, even though the annual per capita income amounts to just 25,000 ringgit, or $8,100, maids came to be common in middle-class households, thanks in large part to a low-paid Indonesian labor pool.

ZIMMERMAN--Sidney, MD. The Board of Directors, management, physicians and staff of White Plains Hospital mourn with extreme sorrow the passing of our dear friend and esteemed physician, Dr. Sidney P. Zimmerman. Sidney's participation in our Hospital spanned more than 60 years and his contributions made a profound difference. His devotion was extraordinary and he was deeply committed to improving the quality of life for his patients and their families. His endearing nature, friendship and vivacious spirit will be missed by all of us. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to his beloved wife, Gloria, his children, Neil and Sheri, Amy, Beth and Peter Post, his grandchildren and his great-grandchildren. J. Michael Divney, Chairman of the Board of Directors Jon B. Schandler, President and CEO

On Monday, AT&T will announce the company's first location-based marketing service through which brands can send text messages to users who choose to receive special offers. The service, called ShopAlerts by AT&T, will send users messages from brand partners including Hewlett-Packard, Kmart, JetBlue and S. C. Johnson. The company is working with Placecast, which supplies a technology known as geo-fencing that allows retailers to send messages to users in a defined geographic area.

YOSWEIN--Leonard E. Family, friends, and co-workers mourn the death of Hon. Leonard E. Yoswein, born September 8, 1920 in Manhattan. After a long and distinguished life of public service, he died on February 25, 2011. Judge Yoswein's career began at age 16 when he managed father Adolph Yoswein's tuxedo rental shop after his father was injured. He graduated from Brooklyn College, then enlisted in the United States Army Air Forces during World War II and served as a Captain on the China/India/Burma Route as a navigator, assisting in development of early LORAN navigation systems. Upon his return, Judge Yoswein received his J.D. from NYU Law School and has been a member of the New York State Bar since 1949. Early career pursuits focused on labor law, before he began a lengthy career in public service. From 1961-1968 Judge Yoswein represented the Canarsie area in the New York State Assembly as a liberal Democrat. His humanitarian nature led him to a role as Chairman of the Assembly Mental Health Committee as well as focusing on initiatives like creating more open access to adoption in the state. Elected to the New York City Civil Court in 1969, he later left the bench and served New York City as "Compassionate" Commissioner of the New York City Department of Rent and Housing Maintenance, leading the city's efforts to ensure adequate heating in public housing during the Arab oil crisis. In 1975 he was Executive Assistant to the Mayor of the City of New York for Intergovernmental Affairs. In 1976 Judge Yoswein was elected to the Kings County Supreme Court and was most recognized as Administrative Justice of the New York State Supreme Court for Brooklyn and Staten Island, presiding over headline gathering trials including the arraignment of David Berkowitz (Son of Sam) and trial of P. O. Robert Torsney. After retiring from the Supreme Court in 1997, he continued as an Administrative Law Judge for the U.S. Social Security Administration. Easily recognized with his van dyke, bright blue eyes, and broad smile, and clad in his preferred cut-offs and casual attire, he always knew how to have fun, while guiding and supporting family, friends, and co-workers. But his primary mission was justice with compassion, over a long and distinguished career. He is survived by daughter Rebecca J. Yoswein; grandchildren Kelly and Sean McGreen; beloved companion Hon. Sarah "Sallie" Krauss; sister Renee Zeiger (Bernie), sister-in-law Martha Yoswein. Predeceased by daughter Kathie I. Yoswein and brother David J. Yoswein, as well as Dorothy Yoswein. Services will be held at Boulevard-Riverside Chapel, 1895 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, New York on March 1, at 11:00am.

Joe Long has tried closing his legendary Brooklyn music shop, Birdel's Records, before. Two years ago, Mr. Long posted a going-out-of-business sign in the windows of his Bedford-Stuyvesant storefront, which opened in 1944. With the decline of the music industry and of his profits, and the fact that no family member wanted to take over, he'd had enough. Mr. Long, now 73, began working at Birdel's in 1957 and had owned the shop since the late 1960s. He was ready to retire, he said.

DOWNER--Jannett Tucker, 81, of New York City, died in her home on Friday, February 25, 2011. Born in New York City, New York on March 7, 1929, she was the daughter of the late William Ashton Tucker and the late Jannett Lord Tucker. In 1949 she married the late Joseph Platt Downer. Their marriage ended in divorce in 1984. Mrs. Downer attended Bryn Mawr College and was a graduate of The Brearley School. She was a voracious reader and passionate about art, history, literature and traveling the world, often independently. She entertained her family and friends with colorful stories of her adventures. An avid New Yorker, she especially enjoyed serving as a volunteer for many years at the American Museum of Natural History where she made friends from around the globe. She will be remembered for her sense of humor and keen intellect. She is survived by her children, Jannett Downer McIntyre of Manchester, MA, William Tucker Downer of Hoboken, N.J., and John Ashton Downer of Stamford, CT; two daughters-in law, Amy Chan Downer and Mariko Osada; a son-in-law, Angus P. McIntyre, Jr.; six grandchildren, Caroline Ashton Downer, Nicholas Chan Downer, Christopher Choi Downer, Julia Sayre Donnelly and her husband Michael Edward Donnelly, Joseph Marshall Sayre and his wife Anna Hansen Sayre, and Charles Tucker Sayre; and her great granddaughter, Sara Jannett Donnelly. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that memorial contributions be made to Friends Without A Border (Angkor Hospital for Children), c/o John Downer, 66 Dogwood Lane, Stamford, CT 06903. Burial will be private.

Movie-watching has gotten so confusing. My wife says, ''Let's watch a movie,'' and I say, ''Sure, satellite, Netflix, Xbox Live, Sony's PlayStation Network or how 'bout the old-fashioned DVD, or the Blu-ray player?'' And she gives me an exasperated look that says: ''I had any number of suitors. Pick a medium and let's watch.''

GOODMAN--Barnett, 85, died peacefully on February 26, 2011, loving husband of Janice, adored by her children, Cheryl Glaser (Scott), Craig Fisher (Kathryn), and Brian Fisher (Joanna). His five grandchildren will miss his many wonderful stories. Pincus Schmelahofski and the man with the green ear were two of their favorites. BG was the retired Vice Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Mothercare Stores Inc. In 1963, Selim Zilka invited Barney to join him in the business. The move proved a catalyst for success. The partners split the corporate responsibilities and their "systems-based" management scheme included the adoption of computerized ordering and distribution as early as 1964. Mothercare went public in 1972. For funeral information, please call I.J. Morris Funeral Directors, West Palm Beach, FL 1-800-947-4256.

Three of the contenders for the best picture Oscar were gone from theaters when the nominees were announced on Jan. 26: ''Toy Story 3'' (closed Dec. 2), ''Inception'' (Jan. 6) and ''The Kids Are All Right'' (Oct. 21). Five of the remaining films have taken in substantially more since then, especially ''127 Hours'' and ''The King's Speech.'' The best picture for 2009, ''The Hurt Locker,'' above, with Jeremy Renner, was also out of theaters when nominees were announced. It was re-released the Friday before the awards show, and increased its ticket sales by 26 percent to $17 million. SHELLY FREIERMAN

KEARNS--David T. The Board of Directors and Staff of the National Child Labor Committee mourn the death of our dear friend and colleague. His contributions to the well-being of millions of children and youth through his incisive and innovative leadership in the worlds of business and education over the past four decades are a beacon for the nation. We are humbled to have honored him earlier this year with the creation of the first annual David T. Kearns Award for Excellence and Innovation in Education, which gave him a great sense of pride, and that Award will now become a permanent legacy to his multi-faceted accomplishments. We send our deepest and most loving sympathies to his wife of more than half a century, Shirley, and to his beloved children Kathy, Elizabeth, Anne, Susan, Todd and Andrew, and his equally beloved 18 grandchildren. Erik Butler, Chairman Jeffrey Newman, President/Executive Director National Child Labor Committee

9:30 P.M. (SNY) GOING HOME: DAVID WRIGHT Wright, above, the Mets' third baseman, travels to his hometown, Chesapeake, Va., with the field reporter Kevin Burkhardt, where the two visit Wright's high school. There he excelled as an athlete and aspired to become an engineer but ultimately turned down a scholarship to Georgia Tech to go pro -- making sure his contract stipulated that his college tuition would be paid for after he retires. The men also look at Wright's off-season hitting program and charitable endeavors and visit with his family, where his brother Daniel does a humorous imitation of David answering questions after a game. The Mets' spring training match-up against the Washington Nationals leads in at 7. 6:30 P.M. (ABC) ABC WORLD NEWS WITH DIANE SAWYER ''Made in America,'' a new segment, challenges viewers to remove products manufactured abroad from their homes and replace them with those made in the United States. It also asks: Is buying American products more expensive? What is no longer manufactured in the United States? And what difference would it make if everyone promised to buy more products made at home? David Muir and Sharyn Alfonsi report.

HURLEY--Nancie Keating, passed away peacefully in Santa Fe, NM, on February 22, 2011. Born and raised on Long Island, she will be buried in Westhampton Beach. She had lived in New Mexico, since the late 1980s. A graduate of The Spence School and Manhattanville College, she also studied at the Neighborhood Playhouse, School of the Theatre in New York and at the Universite de Laval in Quebec. Earlier in her life she was a stage actress in New York, and later a social worker and volunteer for the Red Cross and other organizations, including the Junior Leagues of New York and Greenwich, CT, where she lived prior to moving to New Mexico. She was preceded in death by her brothers, Edward, William, Robert, and Pierson Keating; by her former husband, James Lance Hurley, mother Anne Pierson Keating, and father William J. Keating. She leaves behind her loving family, including daughter, Joanna Hurley of Santa Fe, nephew David Keating of Albuquerque, sister Lois Keating Learned of Danbury, Connecticut, and nieces Elizabeth and Mary, also of Connecticut, and Carolyn and Anne Keating of New York City. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Disabled American Veterans and Catholic Charities organizations. A Funeral Mass will be held at 11am on Tuesday, March 1, at the Church of the Immaculate Conception in Quiogue, NY.

WASSERMAN--Elizabeth Bay, 79. Our beloved mother and friend died surrounded by her family at home on February 25, 2011. She was a beautiful, generous spirit loved by her children Lindsay, Andy and Marion Wasserman and Ron Emerson and all who knew her. She will be dearly missed by her two sisters and six grandchildren. A celebration of her life will be held on April 30th in New York to honor Bay.

SPOOR--Edna H.,94, of South Canaan Road died February 23 at Geer Village. She was the widow of Dr. Herbert J. Spoor. Mrs. Spoor was born July 20, 1916 in Haverhill, MA the daughter of the late Josef and Kristina (Pacikonis) Aladovich. She was a 1936 graduate of Simmons College and received her Master's degree in organic chemistry at Ohio State. During WWII she was a teacher and later managed her husband's Medical practice in New York City. She helped run Fieve Foundation for Manic Depression for several years. She lived in Gramercy Park, New York for many years and chaired the admissions as well as the Opera committees and served as a governor and governor emeritus of the National Arts Club in New York for over 30 years. She is survived by two sons Frederick W. Spoor of Sharon, CT and Dr. Thomas C. Spoor of Michigan and Florida. She is also survived by her two grandchildren Stephen and Kristen. All services are private. Memorial Contributions may be made to the National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park South, New York, NY 10003.

ZIMMERMAN--Sidney. The members and staff of Quaker Ridge Golf Club are deeply saddened by the passing of our beloved member of over 50 years. "Doc" was the patriarch of the club, admired by all generations. Quaker Ridge was important to him and he was dedicated to its traditions. His passions were medicine and golf and through them he touched the lives of many. Incredibly caring, he would become personally involved in treating and assisting many members and club staff. An enormously proud husband, father, grandfather and great-grandfather who took great joy in his family's accomplishments. We will all miss his wonderfully infectious smile. Our heartfelt condolences go out to his family and friends. Alan Howard, President

ZIMMERMAN--Sidney P.,MD., a gentle, kind, wise and caring man who was a cherished husband, brother, father, grandfather and great-grandfather passed away Friday evening. Sidney, 92 years old, succumbed to complications from Leukemia while he was being treated at White Plains Hospital in White Plains, NY, where he served on the board of directors; where he was affiliated for his 53 years of medical practice; where one of his children and several of his grandchildren were born; and where, in 2001, the Sidney P. Zimmerman Nuclear Cardiology Center was dedicated in his honor. As a physician he trained at Mt. Sinai Hospital and New York Medical College and published the results of his research in medical journals but is best known for his uncommonly optimistic demeanor and his high standard of care. Born in Wilkes Barre, PA, he graduated from Wyoming Seminary preparatory school in Kingston, PA; the University of Pennsylvania; and the Syracuse University College of Medicine, Magna Cum Laude. Sidney is also known for his passion for the game of golf and his skilled short game. He leaves behind his beloved wife of 68 years Gloria, his children Neal, Beth and Amy, grandchildren, great-grandchildren, extended family, patients and friends. Following a private funeral, there will be a memorial service at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel in White Plains, NY at 11am on Monday, February 28th. Family will be receiving friends at Quaker Ridge Golf Club, Griffen Avenue, Scarsdale, NY following the service. In lieu of flowers, donations in his name are being accepted by the White Plains Hospital, 41 East Post Road, White Plains, 10601.

PICKARD--Francine, 86, of Delray Beach Florida and Great Neck, NY, died peacefully at home on February 24, 2011. She is survived by Leonard, her beloved husband of 66 years, daughters, Janet Pickard Kremenitzer, Maxine Davis, and son Mark Pickard and daughter-in-law Kristina Brennan Pickard. Her greatest joy was seeing and talking to her five wonderful grandchildren: Rebecca Kremenitzer, Jason Pickard, Heather Diamond and husband Adam, David Kremenitzer, and Jared Pickard. Her career ambition as a young woman was to become a lawyer but this plan was interrupted by the WWII and the need to contribute to the war effort. Her wedding plans had to be changed many times to accommodate the pending deployment of Leonard to the Pacific theater. She used her accounting skills to earn several advancements and to help support her recently widowed mother, Esther Saltzman. After the war she worked alongside her husband in his fledgling CPA firm and loyally helped him through many difficult tax seasons. She was an avid Miami Heat fan for 26 years, and when at home games she would "high five" Dwayne Wade before he stepped on the court. Funeral Services were held on Sunday February 27, at Parkside Memorial Chapels in Rego Park, New York, The interment was at the Beth David Cemetery in Elmont, New York.

The launch date of Tina Brown's reinvented Newsweek after its merger with her Daily Beast Web site remains vague, but Ms. Brown's efforts to continue building an impressive roster do not: Andrew Sullivan announced Sunday that his popular blog, ''The Dish,'' would be leaving TheAtlantic.com and joining Ms. Brown's team in April. ''The chance to be part of a whole new experiment in online and print journalism, in the Daily Beast and Newsweek adventure, is just too fascinating and exciting a challenge to pass up,'' Mr. Sullivan said in a blog entry. ''And to work with media legends, Barry Diller and Tina Brown, and with the extraordinary businessmen Sidney Harman and Stephen Colvin, is the opportunity of a lifetime.''

A person could work up a real hunger on a puzzle like this, but thankfully, David Poole has provided us with a snack at 31 Across. Your average vintage clothing shop does not come with the warning "Mind Your Head When Leaving Seat." It's sound advice at Lodekka, a recently opened boutique in the North Williams neighborhood of Portland, Ore., housed inside in an eggshell white two-story Bristol Lodekka bus. The bus itself - built in 1965 for the citizens of Liverpool - has been exhaustively remodeled in shades of almond, coral pink and warm red. The exterior can't help but catch eyes (and foot traffic from the nearby brunch spots), but it's the selection inside that tugs at the bargain hunter's heartstrings: midcentury Oleg Cassini dresses for $12, a pair of purple Halston pumps for $7 and men's western wear culled from the high deserts of eastern Oregon. Comfortable, not cluttered, Lodekka is also home to trunks full of yellowing National Park maps, McCall's pattern books from the early '80s, Brownie Twin 20 Kodak cameras and a curator's closet of Pendleton skirts and button-ups - this is Portland, after all.

CAIRO - The former president of Egypt was not the statue-building kind, or else we'd have already seen a few Baghdad-like images of marble icons being brought down by jubilant masses after his abdication on February 11. (Come to think of it, I wish we had a few statues to bring down.) But after three decades of rule, and with a particularly auspicious name - Mubarak means "blessed" - the number of buildings, roads and projects named after him is impressive; and as Egyptian society is endeavoring to repair the damage of his corrupt regime, it's a different task altogether cleaning up the expressions of the blessed one's megalomania.

I arrived at Sustain, a two-month-old Miami restaurant, clutching my favorite dinner date: low expectations. After all, Sustain's chef, Alejandro Pinero, works almost exclusively with ingredients produced within a 50-mile radius. A 50-mile radius of Miami? Sounds like a punch line, even to someone who has written about South Florida agriculture. But the low expectations didn't last long. Pinero trained under Michelle Bernstein (of Michy's) and worked at Casa Tua, the haute Italian pit stop in Miami Beach, and he hasn't let his ideals cloud his judgment about what it takes to make a restaurant soar.

The Swiss photographer Walter Pfeiffer is known for his realistic, erotically charged images of free-spirited youth. After gaining international recognition in the late 1970s, Pfeiffer was largely relegated to the periphery for the better part of two decades - a recluse who spent most of his time taking photographs, shooting videos and painting watercolors for his own pleasure. But the publication of "Welcome Aboard, Photographs 1980-2000" and a well-received retrospective in his native Zurich exposed Pfeiffer to a new generation of photographers and magazine art directors who these days come a-courting. (Pfeiffer shot the "Flirt in a Skirt" fashion story in the current issue of T.) The Moment spoke via telephone with Pfeiffer, who curated the exclusive slide show, above, of previously unpublished images.
